div2.entryFree:
alphabetical letter n A^q*Y nq* wq*
The twenty-fifth letter of the alphabet; called nuwnN: it is one of the class termed *aloqiy~apN [or liquids]; and is a letter of augmentation. ― -b2- n~ with teshdeed, and preceded by a fat-hah, is sometimes redundantly affixed to a word at the end of a verse: see an ex. voce taw~N. ― -b3- n, the sign of the dual, with damm, in one dial., instead of kesr, see xa$iyfN. ― -b4- See also SaAdN. ― -b5- As a numeral, it denotes fifty.

R. Q. 1 naA^onaA^ahu *
He fed him, or nourished him, well. (K.) -A2- He restrained him, or turned him back, (El-Umawee, S, K,) from a thing that he desired to do. (El-Umawee, S.) -A3- naA^onaA^a fiY Alr~aA^oYi, inf. n. naA^onaA^apN and munaA^onaA^apN; [the latter an unusual form of inf. n.;] and ↓ tanaA^onaA^a; He was weak, (M, K,) or confused; (S;) and not firm or sound, (S, M, K,) in his judgment, or opinion. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- naA^onaA^a fiY AlA^amori He was weak in the affair. (S.) ― -b3- naA^onaA^a Eanohu, and ↓ tanaA^onaA^a, He was unable to do it. (K.) ― -b4- naA^onaA^a, inf. n. naA^onaA^apN; (AA;) and ↓ tanaA^onaA^a; (S;) He was weak, feeble, or remiss. (AA, S, TA.)

R. Q. 2
see R. Q. 1 in three places.

naA^onaA^N * and ↓ naA^onaA='N (S, K) and ↓ nuw^onuw'N and ↓ munaA^onaA^N Weak; cowardly. (S, K.) ― -b2- naA^onaA^N One who frequently turns about, or rolls, the pupil, or black part, of his eye. (K.)

naA^onaA^apN * : see the verb. ― -b2- Weakness. (AA, S.) ― -b3- TuwbaY limano maAta fiY Aln~A^nA^pi [Good betide him who hath died in (the time of) weakness!] i. e., in the first of El-Islám, before it acquired strength, (S,) and its adherents and assistants multiplied. (TA.)
naA^onaA='N * , nuw^onuw'N, and munaA^onaA^N: see naA^onaA^N.

1 naA^ata * , aor.
naAi^a , (S, K,) contr. to analogy, like yarojiE, (TA,) and
naAa^a , (K,) agreeably with analogy, (TA,) inf. n. nay^iytN, (S, K,) of the measure faEiylN, because it signifies a sound, like A^aniynN, (TA,) and naA^otN, (K,) contr. to analogy, because the verb is intrans., (TA,) He (a man, S) moaned; or breathed violently, or with moaning; or uttered his voice or breath with moaning; syn. A^an~a, (S, TA) and nahata: (S, K:) or it signifies he uttered a louder sound than such as is termed A^aniynN. (K.) -A2- naA^atahu He envied him; (K;) [as also naA^adahu]. -A3- naA^ata, inf. n. naA^otN, He walked, or went, at a slow pace. (L.)

naA^~=tN *
i. q. nah~aAtN: (S:) Aln~aA^~=tu The lion. (K.)

1 naA^aja fiY AlA^aroDi * , aor.
naAa^a , inf. n. nuw^uwjN, He went, went away, departed, or set forth journeying, through the land, or earth. (S, K.) ― -b2- naA^aja Alxabaru The news, tidings, or information, went, or went away, through the land. (T.) ― -b3- naA^ajati Alr~iyHu, aor.
naAa^a , inf. n. nay^iyjN, The wind became in a state of commotion: blew with a swift course, and with a sound. (S, K.) ― -b4- naA^ajati Alr~iyHu AlmawoDiEa The wind passed swiftly over the place. (TA.) ― -b5- nuy^ija Alqawomu (like EuniYa [pass. in form but neut. in signification] TA) The people experienced, or suffered, a swift and sounding wind. (S, K.) [See an ex. voce manoA^ajN.] ― -b6- naA^ajati AlA_ibilu fiY sayorihaA [The camels were swift in their pace]. (TA.) ― -b7- naA^ajati Alr~aAy^iHapu i. q. Eaj~at, [app., The odour diffused itself strongly or powerfully]. (TA.) -A2- naA^aja, (aor.
naAa^a , inf. n. naA^ojN, TA,) It (an owl) uttered a moaning cry; or hooted; syn. naA^ama: (K:) and in like manner a man. (TA.) ― -b2- naA^aja, (aor.
naAa^a and
naAi^a , inf. n. naA^ojN and nuw^aAjN, TA,) He (a bull) lowed. (K.) ― -b3- naA^aja A_ilaY All~`hi, (aor.
naAa^a , TA,) He humbled, or abased, himself, with earnestness, in supplication, to God. (S, K.) -A3- nay^ija He ate weakly, or feebly. (K.)

riyHN naw^uwjN *
Wind in a state of commotion: (S, K:) swift in its course, and making a sound: pl. nawaAy^iju. (TA.)

naA^~=jN *
Quick; swift. (TA.) ― -b2- Aln~aA^~=ju The lion: (K:) so called because of his quick leaping, or springing. (TA.) -A2- naA^~=jN A bull that lows much. (TA.) ― -b2- A man having a high voice. (TA.)

naAy^ijaAtN * [Birds of the kind called] haAm uttering cries. (S, L, K.) [In the CK, for hAm is put hawaAm~. See an ex. voce manoA^ajN.] ― -b2- Also, Winds blowing violently: (TA:) pl. nawaAy^iju. (A.)

entryFree.key: A^udoEu rab~aka biA^anoA^aji maA taqodiru Ealayohi

div2.entryFree:
A^udoEu rab~aka biA^anoA^aji maA taqodiru Ealayohi *
Supplicate thy Lord with the utmost humility, or abasement, and earnestness, of which thou art capable. (TA, from a trad.)

manoA^ajN * [A place where a wind blows with a swift course and with a sound]. Ex.
watunoA^aju Alr~ukobaAnu kul~a manoA^aji
bihi nay^iyju kul~i riyHK sayohaji
(S.) ― -b2- [A place where birds of the kind called haAm utter their cries]. Ex.
manoA^ajaA ↓ waA@t~axa*atohu Aln~aAy^ijaAtu
(TA [but quoted in the S as an ex. of mnA^j in the former sense].)

HadiyvN manow^uwjN *
i. q. maEoTuwfN [app. A distorted story]: (K:) so explained by ISk, as occurring in the following verse:
qado Ealima AlA^aHomaA='u waAlA^azaAwiyjo
A^ano layosa Eanohun~a HadiyvN manow^uwjo
(TA.)

1 naA^adatohu daAhiyapN * , (aor.
naAa^a , A, inf. n. naA^odN, L,) A calamity befell him: (K:) or pressed heavily upon him, and distressed him. (A.) ― -b2- See naA^ata.

naA=dN * and ↓ naA=daY (S, L. K) and ↓ naw^uwdN (L, K) A calamity: (S, L, K:) pl. of the second, ??.
(L.) ― -b2- daAhiyapN naA=dN, and ↓ naA=daY, and ↓ naw^uwdN, (A, L,) A calamity that presses heavily, and distresses. (A.)
naA=daY * : see naA=dN.
naw^uwdN * : see naA=dN.

1 naA^a$ahu * , aor.
naAa^a , (S,) inf. n. naA^o$N, (S, A, K,) He postponed, delayed, or retarded, it, syn. A^ax~arahu; (S, M, A, * K, *) namely, an affair. (S, M.) ― -b2- He made it (a thing) to be distant, or remote; put it at a distance; put it, or sent it, away, or far away. (TA.) -A2- naA^o$N also signifies The taking, or reaching, [a thing,] absolutely, or with the hand, or with the extended hand; (A, K;) and so ↓ tanaAw^u$N, (Msb,) and tanaAwu$N, (Msb, K,) and nawo$N: (IDrd, TA:) or ↓ tanaAw^u$N, with ', signifies the taking from a distant place; and without ', the taking from a near place. (Th, TA.) You say, naA^a$otuhu, inf. n. naA^o$N, I took it, or reached it, absolutely, or with my hand, or with my extended hand. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [xxxiv. 51,] ↓ waA^an~aY lahumu A@lt~anaAw^u$u, and Alt~anaAwu$u, with and without ', accord. to different readers: (TA:) with ', the word is from Aln~awo$u, the w being changed to ' because of the dammeh; [so that the meaning is, But how shall the attaining of belief be possible to them?] (Zj, Bd; *) or from naA^a$otu as signifying taA^axarotu [see 6 below]; so that the meaning is the reaching [or attaining] from afar: (Bd:) or from nay^iy$N, meaning, “ motion in a state of slowness or tardiness: ” (Zj:) or it is from naA^a$otu Al$~aYo'a, (Bd,) inf. n. naA^o$N, (IB, TA,) signifying I sought, or sought for or after, the thing: (IB, Bd:) [so that the above phrase in the Kur. may be rendered But how shall the seeking of belief be possible to them?] ― -b2- It also signifies, (namely naA^o$N,) The taking [a thing]: and seizing violently: (A, K:) or taking in a violent seizure: you say, naA^a$ahu, inf. n. naA^o$N, he took him, or it, in a violent seizure. (TA.)

6 tanaA='a$a *
He, or it, became, or remained, behind; became delayed, or retarded; it became postponed; syn. taA^ax~ara; (S;) and so ↓ naA^a$a, said of a man; (Bd, xxxiv. 51;) and ↓ AntA^$, (S, TA,) said of an affair. (S.) ― -b2- He, or it, became distant, or remote; or he went, removed, retired, or withdrew himself, to a distance, or far away; (S, TA;) as also ↓ AntA^$. (TA.) -A2- See also 1, in three places.
8 A_inotaAa^a see 6, in two places.

naw^uw$N *
Strong; overcoming; or prevailing; (K;) possessing might or strength, courage, valour, or prowess. (TA.) You say also, qadarN naw^uw$N An overcoming decree; as also naw~aA$N. (TA.) See also art. nw$.

faEalahu nay^iy$FA *
He did it lastly, or latterly, or last of all. (S, A, K.) And jaA='a nay^iy$FA He came lastly, or latterly, or last of all: (A:) or slowly, tardily, or late. (TA.) And laHiqanaA nay^iy$FA mina Aln~ahaAri He overtook us after the day had declined; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K;) i. e., he held back from us, and then followed us in haste, fearing escape. (TA.) ― -b2- nay^iy$N also signifies Motion in a state of slowness or tardiness. (Zj.) -A2- Th also explains nay^iy$N as signifying Distant or remote. (TA.)

div2.head: nA^T &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 nab~a * , aor.
nabi3a , inf. n. nabiybN (S, K) and nab~N and nubaAbN; and ↓ nabonaba; He (a goat) uttered a sound, or cry, [or rattled,] and was excited by desire of the female: (S:) or uttered a sound, or cry, [or rattled,] when excited by desire of the female, (K,) or at rutting-time. (TA.) laA tanib~uwA EinodiY nabiyba Alt~uyuwsi (assumed tropical:) Do not cry out [in my presence like as he-goats rattle at rutting-time]. Said by 'Omar to some persons who had come to make a complaint to him. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] nab~a (assumed tropical:) He desired sexual intercourse. (TA.) ― -b3- nab~a Eatuwduhu (assumed tropical:) He was proud, or behaved proudly, and magnified himself. (K.)

2 nb~b * , inf. n. tanobiybN, It (a plant) produced a knotted stem. (K.) ― -b2- A_in~iY A^araY Al$~ar~a nab~aba (assumed tropical:) [Verily I see evil, or the evil, to have grown, like a plant producing knotted stems]. (TA.)

4 Anbbhu Tuwlu AlEuzobapi * (assumed tropical:) [Length of celibacy made him to be desirous of sexual intercourse]. (TA.) ― -b2- Anb~, inf. n. A_inobaAbN, if not a mistake for Anbt, inf. n. AnbAt, meaning “ he became pubescent, ” probably signifies He was excited, and uttered libidinous sounds, with the desire of sexual intercourse. (TA.) See R. Q. 1.

5 tnb~b *
It (water) was made to flow; or was set a flowing. (K.)

R. Q. 1
see 1. ― -b2- nabonaba (tropical:) He (a man, TA) talked nonsense, (and uttered libidinous sounds, TA,) in concubitu: (K:) implying his acting like a he-goat at rutting-time. (TA.) ― -b3- He prolonged his work, to do it well. (K.)

nab~apN *
A disagreeable, or abominable, smell. (K.) Probably a mistake for ban~apN; and therefore not mentioned by the leading lexicographers. (TA.)

nub~iY~N *
A table (maAy^idap) made of palm-leaves. (K, voce bat~iYN, q. v.)
A^anobubN * or A^unobubN: see A^unobuwbN and A^unobuwbapN.

A^unobuwbN * see A^unbuwbapN. ― -b2- A^unobuwbu qaronK (assumed tropical:) That part of a horn that is above the knotty portion, to the extremity: [i. e., the smooth part]. (TA:) ― -b3- A^unobuwbN (tropical:) The spout, or tube, of a jug. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A pipe of a tank, or cistern, through which the water flows: either from tanab~aba, or from A^unobuwbN as signifying “ an internodal portion ” of a reed, or cane. (TA.) ― -b5- A^anaAbiybu Alr~iy^api (tropical:) The [bronchi, or] air-passages of the lungs. (K.) ↓ A^anobubN or A^unobubN is said to signify the same, in an instance mentioned by IAar, in which a poet speaks of the substance resembling lights which a camel in heat protrudes from his mouth, and which is called giylap, as coming forth bayona AlA^aunobubi: in which case, the word, if A^anobub, may be a pl., regularly A^anub~, of which the sing. is nab~N; or, if with dammeh to the hemzeh, it may be a contraction of A^unobuwb, used as a coll. gen. n., in a pl. sense. (TA.) ― -b6- A^unobuwbN A way, or road. (K.) [Ex.] A_ilozami AlA^unobuwba Keep to the way, or road. (As.) ― -b7- A^unobuwbu jabalK (tropical:) A track, or streak, (TariyqapN,) in a mountain, (K,) appearing distinctly therein: of the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) Ex. *ahaba fiY kul~i AnbwbK [He went along every track of the mountain, or mountains]. (TA.) [As a coll. gen. n., used in the pl. sense: ex.] Málik Ibn-Khalid El-Khuzá'ee says,
fiY raA^osi $aAhiqapK A^unobuwbuhaA xuDorN
[On the top of a lofty mountain, the streaks of which are green]. (TA.) ― -b8- A^unobuwbN (tropical:) A row of trees (K) &c. (TA.) [See A^usokuwbN.] ― -b9- A^unobuwbN An elevated tract of land: (K:) one that is fine (rqyq) and elevated: pl. A^anaAbiybu. (TA.)

A^unobuwbapN *
An internodal portion of a reed or cane; such a portion thereof as intervenes between two joints, or knots: (Lth, S:) i. q. kaEobN, [which signifies as above, and also a joint, or knot,] with reference to a reed, or cane, or a spear-shaft: (K:) as also ↓ A^unobuwbN (Lth, K) and ↓ A^unobubN, which latter is probably a contraction: (K:) [see below:] or the pl. of Anbwbp is A^unobuwbN and A^anaAbiybu: (S:) [or Anbwb is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is Anbwbp, and the pl. AnAbyb: see also art. Anb]. ― -b2- [Hence,] AijoEali AlA^amora A^unobuwbapF waAHidapF Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr. in TA in art. bA^j.) ― -b3- [Also, A sheath of a plant. See A^umoSuwxapN. ― -b4- And Any kind of tube. See qaSabN.]

1 nabaA^a * . (K,) inf. n. nabo'N, (TA,) He uttered a low voice, or sound: or he (a dog) cried, or barked. (K.) [See nabaHa.] -A2- nabaA^a, aor.
nabaAa , inf. n. nabo'N and nubuwo'N, He was exalted, or elevated. -A3- nabaA^a Ealayohimo, (K,) inf. n. nabo'N and nubuwo'N, (S,) He assaulted them;
came forth upon them: (K:) like nabaEa and nabaha: he came upon them. (AZ, S.) [See also naAbiy^N.] ― -b2- nabaA^a He went forth from a land to another land. (S, K.) [See naAbiy^N.] ― -b3- nabaA^ato bihi AlA^aroDu i. q. jaA='ato bh, The land brought, or led him: (S, L:) [accord. to Golius, The land brought, or produced, it: but it is a phrase well known to the learned among the Arabs in the present day, as similar to naAdaAhu turaAbuhu “ his dust, or earth, (i. e. the place of his burial,) called him: ” and the explanation which I have given is confirmed by the citation, in the S, of the following verse, of Hanash Ibn-Málik, immediately after nbA^t bh in the sense of jA't bh:]
fanafosaka A^aHorizo faA_in~a AlHutuw
fa yanobaA^ona biAlmaro'i fiY kul~i waAdo
[Then take good care of thyself; for deaths (of various kinds) bring (or lead) a man into every valley (or place): i. e., fate brings him to the place where he is destined to be buried, whereever it be]. (S.) ― -b4- nabaA^a, aor.
nabaAa : see 4.
2 nb~A^ * : see 4.

3 nAbA^hu *
He acquainted or informed him, and the latter did the same. (K.) ― -b2- Also, simply, He acquainted or informed him. (TA.) ― -b3- naAbaA^ahumo He quitted their neighbourhood; withdrew to a distance from them. (K.) [See also art. nbw.]

4 AnbA^hu A_iy~aAhu * , and bihi, (and Eanohu, S, K, art. kwd;) and ↓ nb~A^hu (S, * K) and ↓ nabaA^ahu, (S, * TA,) each followed by Ay~Ah or bh; (TA;) He informed him, or told him, of it: (K:) or these verbs, followed by Ay~Ah, signify he made him to know it; and followed by bh, he informed him, or told him, of it. (TA.) ― -b2- Es-Semeen says, that AnbA^ and nb~A^ and Axbr and xb~r, when they convey the meaning of knowledge, are triply transitive, or may govern three objective complements, the greatest number that any verb can govern: (TA:) [ex. A^anobaA^otu zayodFA EamorFA qaAy^imFA I acquainted Zeyd that 'Amr was standing]. ― -b3- It is also said, that ↓ nb~A^ has a more intensive signification than AnbA^: ex. mano A^anobaA^aka h`*aA qaAla nab~aA^aniY AlEaliymu Alxabiyru [Who hath acquainted thee with this? He said, The Knowing, the Intelligent (God), hath apprized me: Kur, lxvi. 3]. (TA.) ― -b4- Sb has mentioned A^anaA A^anabuw^uka [for AnA A^anobaw^uka] as used for the sake of conformity in sound with a preceding word. (M, TA.) [See art. jwA^.] -A2- ramaY faA^anobaA^a He cast, or shot, but did not split, or cleave, or make a slight cut, or scratch: (S, K:) or, did not penetrate. (K.)
5 tnb~A^ * , (S, K,) said to have been pronounced with ' universally; (Sb, S;) but in the L, tnb~Y; (TA;) He arrogated to himself the gift of prophecy, or office of a prophet. (L, K.)

10 AstnbA^ Aln~abaA^a *
He sought, or searched after, information, or news. (K.) ― -b2- wayasotanobiy^uwnaka A^aHaq~N huwa (in the Kur, x. 54) means And they will ask thee to inform them, [saying,] Is it true? (Bd.)

nabaA^N *
Information; a piece of information; intelligence; an announcement; news; tidings; a piece of news; an account; a narrative, or narration; a story: or what is related from another or others: syn. xabarN: (S, Msb, K:) it is generally held to be syn. with xabarN; but accord. to Er-Rághib, signifies an announcement of great utility, from which results either knowledge or a predominance of opinion, and true: (TA:) pl. A^anobaA='u. (K.) ― -b2- Aln~abaA^u AlEaZiymu [Kur, lxxviii. 2,] accord. to some, The Kur-án: others say, the resurrection: and others, the case of the Prophet. (TA.) ― -b3- AlA^anobaA='u, in the Kur, xxviii. 66, (faEamiyato Ealayohimu AlA^anobaA='u) signifies The allegations, pleas, or excuses. (TA.)

naboA^apN *
An eminence, or protuberance, in the earth, or ground. (TA.) ― -b2- naboA^apN A low voice, or sound: (S, K:) or the cry, or barking, of dogs. (K.)

nabiYo'N * , (S, K,) pronounced with ' in the dial. of the people of Mekkeh, (S,) whose pronunciation of it is disapproved by Sb on account of its uncommonness; (TA;) by others, nabiY~N, without '; (S, K, TA;) A prophet: (TA:) of the measure faEiylN used in the sense of the measure mufoEl [i. e. mufoEilN or mafoEalN] (IB) or faAEilN (S, Es-Sunoosee) or mafoEuwlN; (Es-Sunoosee) i. e., who acquaints or informs mankind, (S, K, TA,) or who is acquainted or informed, respecting God and things unseen: or accord. to some, it is derived from nabowapN and nabaAwapN signifying “ elevation; ” (see art. nbw;) in which case it is originally without ': or, accord. to others, from nabiYo'N in a sense given below; that of “ a conspicuous way. ” (TA.) It is a less special word than rasuwlN [when thereby is meant an apostle of God]; for every rswl is a nbY~, but not every nbY~ is a rswl. (TA.) Pl. A^anobiyaA='u (S, K, without ', because the ' is changed into Y in the sing., S,) and nubaA^='u (S, K, like kuramaA='u [pl. of kariymN] TA,) and A^anobaA='N [K, these two preserving the original radical '] and nabiy~uwna, (K,) without ': (TA:) but some pronounced the first and last of these pls., in the Kur-án, with '; though the more approved pronunciation is without '. (TA.) The dim. is nubay~y^N, (S, K,) with those who make the pl. nubaA^='N [or A^anobaA='N]; but with those who make the pl. A^anobiyaA=', it is nubaY~N. (K.) ― -b2- An Arab of the desert said to Mohammad, yaA nabiYo'a All~`hi, and the latter disapproved of his pronouncing nbY' in this case with ', because, as it signifies An emigrant, he meant thereby to call him an emigrant from Mekkeh to El-Medeeneh. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- nabiYo'N A conspicuous, an evident, or a clear, way. (K.) Hence, accord. to some, the apostle [or rather prophet] is so called, because he is the conspicuous, evident, way, that conducts to God. (MF.) ― -b4- nabiYo'N and ↓ naAbiy^N An elevated, or a protuberant, or gibbous, place. (K.) ― -b5- Hence it is said in a trad., laA tuSal~uwA EalaY Aln~abiYo'i [Pray not upon the place that is elevated, or protuberant]. (K.)

nubuwo'apN * , (K, in the CK nubuw~ap) in which the ' is sometimes softened in pronunciation, and sometimes [or rather generally] changed into w which is incorporated into the preceding w so that the word is written and pronounced nubuw~apN, (TA,) Prophecy; the gift of prophecy; the office, or function, of a prophet. (MA, K.) Dim. nubay~iy^apN. (S, K.)

naAbiy^N * act. part. n. of nabaA^a. ― -b2- A bull [app. a vaworN waHo$iY~N] that goes forth from one land or country to another. (TA.) ― -b3- A torrent that comes forth from another land or tract. (S.) ― -b4- A man coming forth unexpectedly from an unknown quarter. (S, A.) ― -b5- [See also nabiYo'N.]
halo Einodakumo naAbiy^apu xabarK * , i. q. jaAy^ibapu xabarK, [Have ye any current news? or — news from a distant place? &c.: see jAy^bp]. (A.)

1 nabata * , (S, M, K,) aor.
nabuta , inf. n. nabotN and nabaAtN; [which two ns. see mentioned as substs.;] and ↓ tnb~t; (M;) and ↓ Anbt; (Fr, S, K;) [respecting which last see below;] It (a thing, M, or a leguminous [or other] plant, S, K,) grew; grew forth; sprouted; vegetated; or germinated. (S, M, K.) As disallows ↓ Anbt in this sense; but AO allows it, alleging the words of Zuheyr, Albaqolu ↓ Hat~aY A_i*aA A^anobata [Until, when the leguminous plants grew]. nabata and ↓ A^anobata are said to be like maTarati Als~amA='u and A^amoTarat. In the Kur, xxiii. 20, Ibn-Ketheer, Aboo-'Amr and El-Hadremee read tunobitu: others, tanobutu: but ISd says, that, accord. to the former reading, some hold b, which follows tunobitu, to be redundant; and others hold that maA tunobutu is understood after tunobitu. Fr holds them to be syn. (TA.) ― -b2- nabata EalaYa HaAlapK HasanapK He, or it, grew in a good manner, condition, or state. (L.) ― -b3- nabata, inf. n. nubuwtN, (tropical:) It (a girl's breast) became swelling, prominent, or protuberant. (K.) ― -b4- nabatati AlA^aroDu, and ↓ A^anobatat, The land produced, or gave growth to, plants, or herbage. (S, K.)

2 nb~t * , inf. n. tanobiytN, (tropical:) He fed or nourished, or reared or brought up, a child: (S, K:) he nourished a girl, and nursed her up well, hoping that she might profit excellently. (TA.) ― -b2- nab~ito A^ajalaka bayona Eayonayoka [(tropical:) Plant the term of thy life before (lit. between) thine eyes; i. e., keep it ever before thee]. (S.) ― -b3- nb~t, inf. n. tanobiytN, He planted a tree. (M, S, K.) ― -b4- He sowed seed, (M,) or grain. (A.)

4 Anbthu * , (S, K,) inf. n. A_inobaAtN [for which nabaAtN occurs, as shown below], (TA,) He (God) caused it, or made it, (a plant) to grow, vegetate, or germinate. (S, K.) ― -b2- Anbt, inf. n. A_inobaAotN; for which inf. n. nabaAtN occurs in the Kur, iii. 32; and lxxi. 16; (tropical:) He (God) caused a child to grow. (TA.) ― -b3- See 1. ― -b4- Anbt His (a boy's) hair of the pubes grew forth; (S, K;) he having nearly attained the age of puberty. (TA.) He (a boy) became hairy: and in like manner a girl. (Msb.)
5 tanab~ata see 1.

10 Astnbthu * [He endeavoured to make it grow, or vegetate, or germinate]. (TA, art. bls.) Astnbthu bAlba*ori [He grew it, or raised it, by means of seed], and biAln~awaY [by means of date-stones], and bAlgarosi [by means of planting]. (Mgh, art. Hrv.)

nabotN * and ↓ nabaAtN [properly coll. gen. ns.] are syn., (S, K,) [signifying A plant, a herb: and plants, herbs, or herbage:] whatever God causes to grow, vegetate, or germinate, in the earth: (Lth:) the latter is an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Lth:) or it is a subst. which is used in the place of an inf. n. of A^anobata: (Fr:) n. un. of the former nabotapN; (AHn;) [and of the latter nabaAtapN of which the pl. nabaAtaAtN is mentioned in the K in this art., and frequently occurs in other works]. ― -b2- A^aholu bayotK waA^aholu nabotK A people of the highest rank, or nobility, and a people whose property has grown to the most flourishing state by means of their own exertions. (L, from a trad.)
nibotapN * The manner, form, state, or condition, in which a thing grows, or germinates. (L.) ― -b2- A_in~ahu laHasanu Aln~ibotapi Verily he, or it, is of a goodly manner, &c., of growth. (L.)

nabaAtN * : see nabotN. ― -b2- suk~ar nabaAt [Sugar-candy; so called in the present day;] an admirable kind of sugar, of which are made pieces resembling crystal, intensely white and lustrous: app. Persian, and post-classical. (MF.)

xabiytN nabiytN *
Vile, and contemptible, or despicable: (Lh, K:) said of a man, and of a thing. (TA.) In some copies of the K, and in the L, instead of HaqiyrN, we read faqiyrN, [accord. to which, the meaning is vile, and poor]. (TA.)

nabiytapN * sing. of nabaAy^itu, which latter signifies the ridges that are raised along the edges of rivulets such as are called fulojaAn (in the CK, falojaAn) to retain the water: AlnbAy^t being expl. by A^aEoDaAdu AlfulojaAni: so in the L, &c.: in several copies of the K we read, in the place of AEDAd, AgSAn: but this is a mistake. (TA.)

naAbitN kul~i $aYo'K *
What is fresh, or new, of anything, when it is growing forth small. (TA.)

nabatato lahumo naAbitapN *
There grew up unto them young offspring, (S, K,) that became conjoined to the old, and increased their number. (TA.) Dim. nuwayobitapN. (L.) ― -b2- A_in~a baniY fulaAnK lanaAbitapu $ar~K [Verily the sons of such a one are an evil offspring]. (S.) ― -b3- maA A^aHosana naAbitapa baniY fulaAnK How good is the manner, condition, or state, in which grow (maA tanobutu Ealayohi, see 1,) the camels &c., (A^amowaAl) and children of the sons of such a one! ― -b4- naAbitapN (TA) and nawaAbitu [pl. of the former] (S, K) Inexperienced young men. (S, K.) You say, h`*aA qawolu Aln~aAbitapi, and Aln~awaAbiti, This is the saying of inexperienced young men. (TA.) ― -b5- Aln~awaAbitu The name of a certain sect who introduced strange innovations in El-Islám. (A, TA.) El-Jáhidh couples them with the raAfiDap. (MF.)
manobatN * : see manobitN.

manobitN * (tropical:) Origin, or race, [from which a man springs;] syn. A^aSolN. (L.) So in the phrase A_in~ahu lafiY manobiti SidoqK (tropical:) Verily he belongs to an excellent race; is of an excellent origin]: and so in the phrase fiY A^akorami AlmanaAbiti [of the most generous of origins, or races.] (TA.) ― -b2- manobitN A place in which plants, or herbs, grow: (S, K:) dev. from the constant course of speech: analogically it should be ↓ manobatN: (K:) as the aor. of the verb from which it is derived is not yanobitu, with kesreh: but there are other examples like it; as masjidN and maToliEN &c.: ↓ manobatN, however, also sometimes occurs. (TA.) [Pl. manaAbitu.]
A^aroDN minobaAtN * [Land abounding with plants, or herbage]. (K, voce raHabapN, &c.)
manobuwtN * (contr. to analogy, S, [for munobatN,]) A plant caused to grow, or germinate. (S, K.)

mutanab~itN *
Firmly rooted; syn. mutaA^aS~ilN. (TA.)

tanobiytN * and ↓ tinobiytN, (K,) the latter so written, not as being so originally, but for the sake of agreement in sound [with respect to the first and second vowels], (AHei,) a subst., signifying What grows or germinates, of slender (i. e. small, TA,) trees, [or shrubs,] and large: (K:) ex.,
bayodaA='u lamo yanobuto bihaA tanobiytu
[A desert in which there grew not aught of shrubs or of large trees]: (TA:) young shoots of palmtrees: (IKtt:) the prickles and branches that are cut off from a palm-tree, to lighten it. (AHn, as from 'Eesa Ibn-'Omar.) ― -b2- Pieces of the hump of a camel. (L.)
tinobiyvN * : see tanobiyvN.

yanobuwtN * [coll. gen. n.] A certain species of trees: (S:) poppy-plants; syn. $ajaru Alxa$oxaA$: and other trees of a large kind: or the trees called xr~wb [see below]: (K:) or a kind of thorny trees, having branches and leaves, with a fruit of the kind called jirow, i. e., round; called in 'Omán gAf: n. un. with p: AHn says that there are two species of ynbwt; one of these is a kind of thorny and short trees, also called xar~uwb [q. v.] having a fruit resembling a bubble, in which are red grains, having an astringent effect upon the bowels, used as a medicine; the other species is a large species of trees: ISd says, An Arab of the desert, of the tribe of Rabeea, described to me the ynbwtp as [a tree] resembling a large apple-tree, the leaves of which are smaller than those of the apple, having a fruit smaller than the zuEoruwr, intensely black and intensely sweet, with grains, or stones, which are put into scales, or balances: [evidently meaning the carob, or locust-tree, (see xar~uwb,) whence our term “ carob, ” applied to a small weight, the twenty-fourth part of a grain]. (L [See gaAfN and furofuwrN].)

1 nabava * , aor.
nabuva , inf. n. nabovN; (and ↓ Antbv, K;) i. q. naba$a; (AZ, S, K;) i. e., He dug with the hand. (AZ, S.) ― -b2- nabava, aor.
nabuva , inf. n. nabovN, He took forth, or dug out, dust, or earth, from a well or a river. (L.) ― -b3- nabavuwA Eani AlA^amori (tropical:) They searched, or sought, for, or after, the thing; inquired respecting it; sought for information respecting it; searched into, inquired into, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it. (TA.) -A2- nabava, [aor.
nabuva ,] inf. n. nabovN, (tropical:) He was angry. (K.)
6 tanaAbavuwA Eani AlA^asoraAri * (tropical:) They searched into each other's secrets. (A.)

8 Antbv * : see 1. ― -b2- He took; received into his hand. (K.) ― -b3- He tucked up the skirts of his shirt, or the like, when sitting on the ground. (K.) ― -b4- It (sawiyq or the like) increased in size (rabaA) in the water: (K:) as also Antb*. (TA.)
10 Astnbv A^axaAhu Eano sir~ihi * (tropical:) He examined his brother respecting his secret. (A.)

nabavN *
A trace, vestige, or mark: (K:) a trace, or mark, of digging: (A:) pl. A^anobaAvN. (TA.) ― -b2- maA raA^ayotu lahu EayonFA walaA nabavFA I saw not the man himself, or the thing itself, nor any trace of him, or it. (L.) ― -b3- See nabiyvN.

nabiyvN * The dust that an animal digs up with its feet in running. (IAar.) ― -b2- ↓ nabiyvapN (S, K) and nabiyvN and ↓ nabavN (L) The dust, or earth, that is taken forth, or dug out, from a well or a river: (S, L, K:) pl. of the first, nabaAy^ivu. (A.) ― -b3- nabiyvN and ↓ manobuwvN Earth, or dust, taken forth, or dug out, from a well or a river. (L.) ― -b4- sabuEK ↓ nabyvapu
Flesh-meat buried by a beast of prey against the time of want. (IAth, from a trad.) -A2- nabiyvN A species of sea-fish; accord. to IAar; but it is also said, on his authority, that it is called yanobiyvN; therefore it seems that one of these two words is a mistake for the other, or that they are two dial. forms. See also bayoniyvN, in art. bnv. (TA.) -A3- xabiyvN nabiyvN (tropical:) Very bad, evil, wicked, or corrupt: (K:) applied to a man: (TA:) the latter word is an imitation sequent to the former. (S, and some copies of the K.) -A4- A^abodaY nabiyvapa Alqawomi, and nabaAy^ivahumo, (tropical:) [He revealed the elicited secret of the people, and their elicited secrets]. (A.) ― -b2- bayonahumo $aHonaA='u wanabaAy^ivu (tropical:) [Between them are enmity and secrets elicited]. (A.)
nabiyvapN * : see nabiyv.

A^anobuwvapN *
A certain game (played by children, TA,) in which something is buried in a hole dug in the ground, and he who takes it forth wins the game. (K.)
manobuwvN * : see nabiyvN.
Zaharato manaAbivuhumo walamo taxofa xabaAy^ivuhumo * (tropical:) [The occasions for the scrutiny of their conduct appeared, and their evil qualities were not hidden]. (A.)

1 nabaja * , aor.
nabuja , inf. n. nabiyjN, He uttered a loud, or vehement voice, or cry. (TA.) ― -b2- nabaja, inf. n. nabojN, Pepedit, certo modo: (TA:) inf. n. nubaAjN, crepitum ventris emisit; pepedit. (S, K.) ― -b3- nabaja, inf. n. nabaAjN and nabiyjN, He (a dog) barked; i. q. nabaHa. (S, K.) -A2- nabaja He mixed up, or beat up, fresh milk, with a nab~aAjap, until it became froth, in which state it is eaten with dates, taken up with three fingers. Only the Benoo-Asad did this. (IKh.) ― -b2- nabaja He mixed up sawiyq &c. (TA.)

nabiyjN * and ↓ manobuwjN Milk mixed up, or beaten up, in the manner explained voce nabaja. (IKh.) ― -b2- nabiyjN and ↓ naAbijapN A kind of food of the Arabs in the time of paganism, (in seasons of dearth, or famine, TA,) made by mixing up, and beating up, soft camel's hair (wabar) with milk. (K.)

nab~aAjN *
Loud, or vehement, in voice, or cry. (S, K.) ― -b2- nab~aAjN and ↓ nubaAjiY~N A dog that barks much; (K;) a loud-barking dog. (S.) [See nab~aAHN.] -A2- nab~aAjN [The wooden implement called] a mijodaH, for [mixing up] sawiyq (K) &c.; (TA;) also called mixowaDN and mizohafN. (El-Mufaddal.) [See also nab~aAjapN.]

Aln~ab~aAjapu *
The anus; syn. AlA_isotu. (S, K.) ― -b2- ka*abato nab~aAjatuhu Pepedit. (S.) ― -b3- nab~aAjapN A wooden implement at the end of which is a thing resembling a falokap [or the round head of a spindle], with which fresh milk is mixed up, or beaten up, in the manner explained voce nabaja. (IKh.) [See also nab~aAjN.]
nubaAjiY~N * : see nab~aAjN.
naAbijapN * : see nabiyjN.

A^anobajN * and ↓ A^anobijN The fruit of a certain Indian tree, (K,) which is preserved, or made into a confection, with honey; in form like the peach, with the head edged (muHar~af); [but this seems rather to apply to a kind mentioned below, resembling the almond;] it is brought to El-'Irák; and has within it a stone like that of the peach: (L:) an arabicized word, from [the Persian] A^anobo [or A^anabo]. (K.) ― -b2- Hence ↓ A^anobijaAtN, (L,) with kesreh to the b, Medical confections: app. an arabicized word: (S:) or confections, or preserves, made with honey, of the A^utoruj~ and A_iholiylaj and the like. (L.) ― -b3- Accord. to AHn, Anbj is the name of Certain trees abounding in Arabia, in the districts of 'Omán; planted; they are of two kinds; one of these has a fruit resembling the almond, which is sweet from the commencement of its growth; the other has a fruit in appearance like the Damask plum (A_ij~aAS), is at first sour, and then becomes sweet when ripe: each has a stone, and has a sweet odour: the fruit of the sour kind is pressed down in jars, or earthern pots, [HibaAb: so I read for jbAb:] while fresh, and kept until it attains to a ripe state, when it becomes as though it were the banana, in its odour and taste: the tree grows great so as to become like the walnut (jawoz), which it resembles also in its leaves: and when it attains to perfection, the sweet [fruit] is yellow; and the bitter, [or sour,] red. (L.)
A^anobijN * : see A^anobajN.

A^anobajaAnN * Dough that has become in a state of fermentation, and inflated, or swollen, (S, K,) and sour: (TA:) in some books written with x; but heard from the Arabs with j, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed and Abu-l-Ghowth and others: (S:) there is no word like it except A^arowanaAnN. (S, K.)
A^anobajaAniY~N * : see manobajaAniY~N. ― -b2- Also, A mess of broken, or crumbled, bread, (variyd,) in which is [some degree of] heat. (K.)

kisaA='N manobajaAniY~N * , (S, K,) the latter word being formed after the manner of maxobaraAniY~N and manoZaraAniY~N, (S,) and ↓ A^anobajaAniY~N, rel. ns. of manobijN, each with fet-hah to the b, contr. to analogy, (K,) the latter disallowed by IKt, but occurring in a trad. and in poetry, and not to be disallowed because contr. to analogy, since there are many such rel. ns., as marowaziY~N and raAziY~N &c., (TA,) A certain kind of ksA', so called in relation to a place named manobijN: (S, K, &c.:) or ksA' A^anobajaAniY~N, and A^anobijaAniY~N, which latter form is related by IAth as the one retained in the memory, a certain kind of ksA', so called in relation to a place named AnbjAn; of wool, having a nap, or pile, without a border; one of the meanest kinds of coarse garments: its A, accord. to some, is an augmentative letter. (TA.)
manobuwjN * : see nabiyjN.

1 nabaHa * , aor.
nabiHa and
nabaHa , [the former of which, accord. to the Msb, seems to be more common,] inf. n. naboHN and nabiyHN and nubaAHN and nibaAHN (S, K) and nubuwHN (L,) and tanobaAHN, (K,) the last having an intensive and frequentative signification, (TA,) He (a dog, S, L, K) barked. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (sometimes, S,) (tropical:) said of a gazelle, (T, S, K,) when he has advanced in years, and his horns have branched forth: (T:) and (tropical:) of a he-goat, (K,) in coupling-time: (L:) and (tropical:) of a serpent; (K;) meaning he uttered a cry, or sound: (L:) also (tropical:) of a hoopoe, (hudohud,) inf. n. nubaAHN, signifying it uttered a harsh cry, by reason of age: (L:) and (tropical:) of a lion, inf. n. nubaAHN, signifying he uttered a cry (L, K) like the barking of a whelp. (Aboo-Kheyreh, L.) ― -b3- nabaHahi Alkalobu and nabaHa Ealayohi, (T, Msb,) and ↓ nAbHhu, (T,) The dog barked at him. (Msb.) ― -b4- fulaAnN laA yuEowaY walaA yunobaHu (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is not howled at nor barked at]: i. e., by reason of his weakness, no account is taken of him, and neither good nor evil is said to him. (L.) ― -b5- nabaHa (tropical:) He (a poet) satirized. (A.) ― -b6- nabaHatoniY kilaAbuka (tropical:) Thy revilings reached, or overtook, me. (L.)
3 naAobaHa see 1.

4 AnbHhu * and ↓ AstnbHhu, He made him (a dog) to bark: (S, K:) Alkaloba ↓ AstnbH he excited, or induced, the dog to bark: said of man when, having lost his way, he imitates the bark of that animal, in order that a dog may hear him, and, imagining him to be a dog, may bark, and so guide him. (L.) Said also of a guest, [or one who would be a guest, and who desires to guide himself to a place of entertainment]. (A.) [See an ex. cited, from the poet El-Akhtal, voce A_irodab~N.]
10 A_isotanobaHa see 4.

nubuwHN * (tropical:) The clamour, confused noise, or mixture of voices, of a tribe, (S,) or of a people, (K,) and the barkings of their dogs, (S, K,) and the cries of their other animals. (A.) ― -b2- Subsequently put in the place of (tropical:) Multitude, and might, or power: (S:) and signifying (tropical:) a numerous assembly. (K.) El-Akhtal says,
A_in~a AlEaraArapa waAln~ubuwHa lidaArimK
[Verily strength, or eminence, or lordship, and multitude, and might, or power, belong to Dárim]. (S.)

nab~aAHN * A dog that barks much. (A.) ― -b2- nab~aAHN A man (L) having a vehement, or loud, voice. (L, K.) ― -b3- ↓ nub~aAHN, with dammeh, (K,) or nab~aAHN (as in the L) (tropical:) A hoopoe (hudohud) that cooes (yuqaroqir) much. (IAar, K.) ― -b4- nab~aAHN (tropical:) A gazelle that cries much, or often: (IAar:) and ↓ naboHaA='u the same applied to the female. (AA, K.) -A2- nab~aAHN White, small [shells such as are called] Sadaf: (TA:) small, white [shells such as are called] manaAqif, of Mekkeh, (T, K, TA,) i. e. brought from Mekkeh: (TA:) put into [necklaces such as are called] qalaAy^id (K, TA) and wu$uH, and used for repelling the [evil] eye: (TA:) n. un. with p. (K.)
nub~aAHN * : see nab~aAHN.
nubaAHiY~N * A dog having a loud bark. (Lh.)

kalobN naAbiHN *
A barking dog: pl. kilaAbN nawaAbiHu, and nub~aHN, and nubuwHN. (L.)
naboHaA='u * : see nab~aAHN.

rajulN manobuwHN *
A man likened to a dog. (L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A man reviled. (L.)

4 Anbx *
He sowed in a land such as is called naboxaA='. (K, TA.)

nabxN * The small-pox; (S;) in an absolute sense: (TA:) or the small-pox of sheep or goats &c., (K,) ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) and ↓ nubaxN, (K,) Blisters, or pustules that fill with water, on the hand, (S, K,) occasioned by work: (K:) when they break, or dry up, the hand becomes callous by work: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (TA.) ― -b3- Also ↓ nabaxN Marks of fire, [or blisters occasioned by burning,] upon the body.
nabaxN * : see naboxN.

naboxaA='u *
A hill, or mound, such as is called A^akamap: (S:) or elevated ground: (TA:) or elevated and loose ground, not consisting of sand, but of hard and stony earth: (Th, K:) pl. nabaAxaY: (K:) it has a broken pl. of the class proper to substs. because it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.)

naAbixapN *
A proud, a haughty, or an imperious, man: (S, K:) pl. nawaAbixu. (S.) ― -b2- A speaker. (K.)

A^anobaxu *
Rude, coarse, rough, gross; (K;) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b2- turaAbN A^anobaxu Dust of a dusky colour, and abundant. (L, K.) [See an ex. voce habay~axN, art. hbx.]

1 naba*ahu * , aor.
nabi*a , inf. n. nabo*N, (S, L, Msb, K,) He cast, threw, or flung, it away, as a thing esteemed of no account or importance: this is the original signification; and in this sense it is mostly used in the Kur-án: (Er-Rághib:) he cast, threw, or flung, it (S, A, L, Msb. K) from his hand, (S, L,) before him or behind him: (L, K:) and he cast, threw, or flung, it far away, or to a distance: (L:) and (so in the L; but in the K, or) he cast, threw, or flung it in any manner: (L, K:) ↓ nb~* has teshdeed given to it to denote frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects. (S, A, L.) ― -b2- naba*a xaAtamahu He threw his signet from his hand. (L, from a trad.) ― -b3- fanaba*uwhu waraA='a Zuhuwrihimo (Kur, iii. 184) (tropical:) [lit., And they cast it behind their backs;] means and they did not observe it; (namely, their covenant;) they disregarded it. (Beyd.) ― -b4- nabo*N is both by act and by word; having for its objects both substances and accidents: (L:) you say naba*a AlEahoda (tropical:) He dissolved the league, or covenant, and cast it from him to him with whom he had made it: (A, L, Msb: *) and naba*a kul~u fariyqK minohumaA A_ilaY SaAHbh AlEahoda Al~a*iY tahaAdanaA Ealayohi (tropical:) [Each party of them cast from him, to the other, the league, or covenant, by which they had made a truce; i. e., each party of them rejected it, or renounced it, to the other]: (T:) and naba*a A_ilaY AlEaduw~i, and ↓ nAb*hu, (tropical:) He cast from him the league, or covenant, to the enemy, and dissolved it: and ↓ tanaAba*uwA (tropical:) They mutually cast from themselves the league, or covenant, and dissolved it. (A.) See also 3. ― -b5- naba*a A^amoriY waraA='i Zahorihi (tropical:) [lit., He cast my affair behind his back; meaning,] he did not perform my affair; (A;) he neglected it. (Msb.) ― -b6- naba*ato fulaAnapu qawolFA maliyHFA (tropical:) Such a woman threw out a goodly, beautiful, or pretty, saying. (A.) ― -b7- naba*otu A_iloyhi Als~alaAma, and Alt~aHiy~apa, (tropical:) I threw to him the salutation. (A.) ― -b8- nubi*otu bika*aA (tropical:) [I had such a thing as it were thrown to me; I had it thrown in my way;] I had it offered, or presented, to me, the meeting with it being appointed, or prepared; as also rumiytu bihi. (A.) ― -b9- lil~`hi A^um~N naba*ato bika (tropical:) To God (be attributed the excellence of) the mother that brought thee forth!] (A.) ― -b10- naba*a He threw forth earth or dust [in digging a hole &c.]; as also nabava. (A.) See also nabiy*apN. ― -b11- naba*a He threw dates or raisins into a bag or skin, and poured water upon them, and left the liquor until it fermented and became intoxicating: (T:) [or, simply, he steeped dates or raisins in water; for the beverage thus made, called nabay*, was not always left until it became intoxicating, as is shown by several trads.] ― -b12- naba*a nabiy*FA, (S, L, K, &c.,) the most usual form of the verb, (Kz,) aor.
nabi*a , only; (MF;) and ↓ nb~*hu, (A, L, K,) and ↓ Anb*hu, (L, K,) a form used by the vulgar, (S, IDrst,) and rejected by Th and others, but mentioned, on the authority of Er-Ruásee, by Fr, who says that he had not heard it from the Arabs, but that the authority of its transmitter is worthy of reliance, (TA,) and ↓ Antb*hu; (L, K;) (tropical:) He made beverage of the kind called nabiy*. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b13- Also, naba*a tamorFA, (Lh, IAth, L,) and EinabFA, (IAth, L,) and ↓ Anb*hu, but this is seldom used, (Kutr, Lh, ISk, and others, and L,) and ↓ Antb*hu, (L,) (tropical:) He made, of the dates, and of the grapes, beverage of the kind called nabiy*; (Lh, L;) he left the dates, and the grapes, in water, that it might become beverage of the kind so called. (IAth, L.) ― -b14- Also, ↓ Antb* (tropical:) He made for himself that beverage. (A.) ― -b15- fulaAnN yanobi*u EalaY~a (tropical:) Such a one boils against me like [the beverage called] nabiy*. (A.) -A2- naba*a, [aor.
nabi*a ,] (S, L, K,) inf. n. nabo*N (L, K) and naba*aAnN, (S, K,) It (a vein) pulsed; (L, K;) a dial. form of nabaDa. (S, L.)
2 nab~a*a see 1.

3 nAb*hu * , inf. n. munaAba*apN, He bargained with him by saying, Throw thou to me the garment, or piece of cloth, (A'Obeyd, L, K,) or other article of merchandise, (A'Obeyd, L,) or I will throw it to thee, and the sale shall become binding, or settled, or concluded, for such a sum: (A' Obeyd, L, K:) or, by throwing to another a garment, or piece of cloth, the other doing the like: (Lh, L, K:) or, by saying, When thou throwest thy commodity, or when I throw my commodity, the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded, for such a sum: (Msb:) or, by saying, When I throw it to thee, or when thou throwest it to me, the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded: (Mgh, art. lms:) or, by saying, When I throw the pebble (L, K) to thee, (L,) the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded: (L, K:) or by another's throwing a pebble to him: (L:) bayoEu AlmunaAba*api and bayoEu AlHaSaApi and bayoEu A_iloqaA='i AlHajari signify the same; (Mgh;) as also bayoEu AlA_iloqaA='i: (A:) such bargaining is forbidden. (L.) ― -b2- nAb*wA, inf. n. munaAba*apN; and ↓ Antb*wA; (tropical:) They retired, each of the two parties, apart, in war. (L, K.) ― -b3- naAba*ahumu AlHaroba, and A_ilayohimu AlHaroba ↓ naba*a, He retired from them to a place aside, or apart, in war, for a just purpose, (liloHaq~i, in the 'Eyn for war, liloHarobi, TT,) they doing the like: (Lth, T, L:) or these two phrases, followed by EalaY sawaA='K, are used when there is between two parties at variance a covenant, or league, or a truce, after fighting, and they desire to dissolve the league, or covenant, and each party casts it from him (yanobi*uhu) to the other: thus, faA@nobi*o A_ilayohimo EalaY sawaA='K, in the Kur, [viii. 60, lit., cast thou from thee, to them, their league, or covenant, in an equitable, or just, manner,] means, announce thou to them that thou hast dissolved the league between thee and them, so that they may have equal knowledge with thee of the dissolving thereof and of the returning to war:
(T, L:) ElY swA' here signifies ElY AlHaq~i waAlEadoli: (Lh:) naAba*ahu AlHaroba also signifies he made war with him openly; (S, L, Msb;) and is syn. with naba*a A_ilayohi AlHaroba: (L:) and naAba*uwhumo EalaY sawaA='K they made war with them openly, in an equitable manner, declaring their hostile intention, so that it was equally known to their enemies and themselves. (L.) See also 1. ― -b4- naAba*otuhumo (tropical:) I acted contrarily to, or differently from, or adversely to, them; or was, or became, contrary to, or different from, or adverse to, them; syn. xaAlafotuhumo. (Msb.)
4 A^anoba*a see 1.
6 tanaAoba*a see 1.

8 Antb* * (tropical:) He went, withdrew, or retired, aside, or apart, from others; separated himself from others. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- Antb*t makaAnFA (Kur, xix. 16,) (tropical:) She withdrew, or retired, to a place apart from her family, (L, Msb,) far away. (Msb.) ― -b3- Ainotaba*a Eano qawomihi He withdrew, or retired, from his people. (M.) ― -b4- Aintb* naAHiyapF He went aside. (T.) See 1. ― -b5- And see Ainotabava in art. nbv.

nabo*N * (tropical:) A little; a small quantity; (S, A, L, K;) mina AlmaAli of wealth, or property; (S, A, L;) as also ↓ nubo*apN [which is a word much used though I find it explained in few lexicons]; (L, TA;) because what is little is thrown away, and disregarded: (A:) and in like manner, of herbage, and of rain, and of hoariness or hoary hair, (S, A, L,) &c: (L:) and a small number of men: (A, L:) and the latter word, a piece, or portion, of a thing, such as a perfume: (L:) pl. of the former, A^anobaA*N: (L, K:) [and of the latter, nuba*N.] ― -b2- A^anobaA*N mina Aln~aAsi (K, * TA) (tropical:) The refuse of the people; (TA;) mixed people of the baser sort. (K, TA.)
bayonanaA wabayona baniY fulaAnK nabo*apN * : see ja*obapN. ― -b2- jalasa nabo*apF, and ↓ nubo*apF, (tropical:) He sat aside, or apart. (S, A, L, Msb, K.)
nubo*apN * : see nabo*N: ― -b2- and nabo*apN.

nabiy*N *
Cast, thrown, or flung, [&c.; see 1;] (K;) i. q. manobuw*N. (L.) But see below. ― -b2- ↓ nabiy*apN The earth or dust that is thrown forth from a hole or the like that is dug; as also nabiyvapN: pl. nabaAy^i*N. (A, * L.) Yaakoob asserts, that the * is a substitute for v. (L.) ― -b3- nabiy*N (tropical:) A kind of beverage, made of dates, and of raisins; i. e., must; and of honey; i. e., mead; and of wheat, and of barley, &c.; i. e. wort: (L:) or made of dates, or of raisins, which one throws (yanobi*u, i. e. yaToraH, whence its appellation,) into a vessel or skin of water, and leaves until it ferments (yafuwr, T, L, or yagoliY, Mgh) and becomes intoxicating, or not so long as to become intoxicating: before it has become so, it is a lawful beverage: (T, L:) whether intoxicating or not, it is thus called: (L:) or it is thus called because it is left (yunoba*u, i. e., yutoraku,) until it becomes strong; (Msb;) being expressed juice, or the like, that is left (nubi*a) [for a time to acquire strength]: (L, K:) it is said that this word is originally of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, but that it has become obsolete in this latter sense, and, applied to the beverage, is used as though it were a primitive substantive, as is shown by the form of its pl., (M, F,) which is A^anobi*apN; (S, L, MF;) for a word of the measure fEyl in the sense of the measure mfEwl has not this form of pl.: (MF:) wine expressed from grapes is also called nabiy*N, like as nby* is also called xamorN: [nabiy*N is a coll. gen. n., and its n. un. is with p:] nabiy*apN signifies some nabiy*; lit., a portion thereof. (Msb, art. xmr.) See also mizorN. (L.)
nabiy*apN * : see nabiy*F, and manobuw*N.
nab~aA*N * [One who throws things away often, or quickly]. See A^ax~aA*N. -A2- nab~aA*N [One who makes, or sells, the beverage called naby*]. (S, K, art. skr.)

minoba*apN *
A pillow, or cushion; (Lh, S, A, L, K;) upon which one reclines, or sits: so called because it is thrown upon the ground to be sat upon: (L:) pl. manaAbi*u. (A.) Ex. tarab~aEuwA EalaY AlmanaAbi*i [They sat cross-legged upon the pillows, or cushions]. (A.)

manobuw*N *
A child cast out by its mother (T, S, L, Msb, K) in the road, (T, S, L, K,) on the occasion of her bringing it forth, and which a Muslim picks up and maintains; whether a bastard or lawfully begotten; (T, L;) a foundling: (L, K:) such may not be called a bastard because its kin may be established: (T, L:) also, (assumed tropical:) a bastard; (L, K;) because such is cast away in the road: (L:) fem. manobuw*apN (L) and ↓ nabiy*apN: (A, L:) pl. masc. manobuw*uwna and manaAbi*apN; (L;) and pl: of nby*p, nabaAy^i*u. (A.) ― -b2- manobuw*apN and ↓ nabiy*apN (assumed tropical:) A ewe or other animal (L) that is not eaten, by reason of its leanness: (L, K:) so called because it is cast away. (L.) ― -b3- Sal~aY EalaY qabori manobuw*K He (Mohammad) prayed upon the tomb of a foundling: or, accord. to another reading ElY qaborK manobuw*K, meaning, upon a tomb apart, (L,) or distant, (K,) from other tombs; (L, K;) like an expression occurring in another trad., ↓ mar~a biqaborK munotabi*K he passed by a tomb apart from other tombs. (L.)

hwa munotabi*u Ald~aAri * (tropical:) He is far from his house. (A.) ― -b2- munotabi*N and ↓ mutanab~i*N [A man &c.,] aside, or apart, or separate, from others; (L;) [See also manobuwdN: and see a verse of Lebeed, voce A^aSolN.]
mutanab~i*N * : see munotabi*N.

1 nabara * , (T, S, A, K,) aor.
nabira , (S, K,) inf. n. naborN, (S,) He, (a man, S, A,) or it, (anything, T,) raised, or elevated, a thing: (T, S, A, K:) or naborN signifies specially the raising of the voice: (MF, from the first part of the Keshsháf:) or the rising of the voice; so with the Arabs; and one says nabara Alr~ajulu, inf. n. naborapN, meaning, the man spoke in a high tone: (IAmb:) and nabara, inf. n. naborapN, he (a man) uttered a sound: (A:) and [the inf. n.] naborapN, signifies the crying out, or shouting, from fright, or fear: (T, K:) and naborapu Almugan~iY, the singer's raising his voice from a low to a high pitch. (S, K.) ― -b2- nabara AlHarofa, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
nabira , (M, K,) inf. n. naborN, (S, M,) He pronounced the letter with hemz (hamoz). (S, M, A, K.) qurayo$N laA tanobiru [The tribe of Kureysh] do not pronounce with hemz. (S.) A man said to the Prophet, yaA nabiYo'a A@ll~`hi [O Prophet of God]; and he said laA tanobiro yiA@somiY, i. e. Pronounce not thou my name with hemz: (M:) for the tribe of Kureysh did not pronounce with hemz. (TA.) And when ElMahdee performed the pilgrimage, he preferred El-Kisáee to recite the prayers in El-Medeeneh, and the people of that city disapproved of his pronouncing with hemz, asking him wherefore he did so in reciting the Kur-án in the mosque of the Apostle of God. (TA.)

8 Antbr *
It (a heap of wheat) rose, by additions. (T.) ― -b2- It (the body, M, K, and a wound, T, A) swelled; became swollen. (T, M, A, K.) ― -b3- It (the mouth, TA,) became blistered, or vesicated. (K, TA.) And Antbrt yaduhu His arm, or hand, became blistered. (S, A.) ― -b4- He (the A^amiyr, M, and the xaTiyb, K) ascended the minobar [or pulpit]. (M, K.)

niborN * sing. of A^anobaArN, (T, S,) which signifies Heaps, syn. A^akodaAsN, (M, K,) or a collection, (M, S,) of TaEaAm, (S, M, K, MS,) meaning of wheat, and of barley, [or other corn,] and of dates: (MS:) or [in the TA, and] granaries (A^ahoraA=') of TaEaAm: (in the present day, a granary:] what is called huroYN being also called niborN because the TEAm, when poured in its place, rises: and the pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of AnbAr] is A^anaAbiyru. (T.) ― -b2- A^anobaArN also signifies A merchant's magazine, or chamber, (bayot,) in which he puts together, in order, or piles up, his goods. (M, K.) [In the K, it is added, that the sing. is niborN: but this addition seems to be misplaced: for AnbAr in the last of the senses here explained, as well as when applied to a granary. and to a collection of TEAm, appears to be a pl. without a sing.]

naborapN *
Anything rising from a thing. (M, A, K.) ― -b2- A swelling in the body. (M, K.) ― -b3- I. q. hamozapN [meaning the sound, or the character, so called]. (T, S, K.)
minobarN * The pulpit of the xaATib [in a mosque]: (M, TA:) so called because of its height: (S, M, A, K:) [pl. manaAbiru.]
munab~arN * : see manobuwrN.
AlmasoA^alapu Alminobariy~apu * : see the first paragraph of art. Ewl.

manobuwrN *
Pronounced with hemz (hamoz). (T.) qaSaAy^idu manobuwrapN, and ↓ munab~arapN, i. q. mahomuwzapN [i. e. Poems of which the verses end with hemz].

1 nabazahu * , aor.
nabiza , inf. n. nabozN, He called him, or named him, by a by-name, surname, or nickname; he by-named him, surnamed him, or nicknamed him; syn. laq~abahu; (S, Msb, K;) mostly signifying he called him, or named him, by a nickname, a name of reproach, or an opprobrious appellation; (TA;) as also ↓ nb~zhu: (K:) or the latter is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects: you say, biAlS~aboyaAni ↓ fulaAnN yunab~izu Such a one by-names, surnames, or [rather] nicknames, the children; syn. yulaq~ibohumo. (S.) ― -b2- Aln~abozu is also syn. with All~amozu; (K;) or is like the latter: (TA;) [i. e., nabazahu also signifies He upbraided, or reproached, him; or the like.]
2 nab~aza see 1, in two places.

6 tnAbzwA * , (Msb, K, *) or tnAbzwA biA@loA^aloqaAbi, (S,) They called one another by by-names, surnames, or [rather] nicknames: (S, Msb, * K:) or they upbraided, reproached, or reviled, one another; (K, TA;) calling one another by names of reproach. (TA.) So in the Kur, xlix. 11; where the doing so is forbidden. (TA.)

nabazN * , [or, accord. to the Msb, it seems to be nabozN, for it is there said to be an inf. n. used as a subst., but this form I have never met with elsewhere,] A by-name; or surname; or nickname; syn. laqabN; (S, Msb, K;) mostly, the latter; i. e., a name of reproach; an opprobrious appellation: (TA:) but Kh, [makes it, contr. to common usage, to signify a proper name; for he] says, that names are of two kinds; A^asomaA='u nabazK, such as zayodN and Eamoruw; and A^asomaA='u EaAm~K, such as farasN and rajulN and the like: (TA:) pl. A^anobaAzN. (S.)

nabizN *
Ignoble, or mean, (Sgh, K,) in his grounds of pretension to respect, or his rank or quality, and in his natural disposition. (K.)

rajulN nubazapN *
A man who is much accustomed to call others by by-names, surnames, or [rather] nicknames. (K.)

1 naba$a * , aor.
nabu$a , (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. nabo$N, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) He took, drew, or pulled, out, or forth, (Mgh, Msb, K,) a thing, (Msb, TA,) [as] a leguminous plant, (S,) or a thing buried, (Mgh,) or a thing after burial, (TA,) [as] a corpse; (S, TA;) whence nab~aA$N, q. v.: (S, Mgh:) he made a thing that was concealed or covered to come out or forth, or to become apparent. (A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa yanobu$u liEiyaAlihi, (A, TA,) inf, n. as above, (K, TA,) (tropical:) He draws forth sustenance hence and thence for his family, or household: (A:) or (tropical:) he gains, or earns, or seeks sustenance, for them. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- And huwa yanobu$u AlA^asoraAra, (A, TA,) and AlHadiyva, inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) (tropical:) He draws forth, or elicits, secrets, and discourse, narration, or information: (K, * TA:) or naba$otu Als~ir~a signifies (assumed tropical:) I divulged the secret. (Msb.) ― -b4- And AlEuruwqa ↓ A_inotaba$a (tropical:) He drew forth, or extracted, the veins. (A.) ― -b5- Also, He removed, a thing from over another thing which it covered or concealed; (A, Msb, * K;) and earth from a thing beneath it: (A, Msb: *) whence nab~aA$N, q. v. (Msb, K.) ― -b6- And hence, naba$a Alqabora [He uncovered, or he rifled, or ransacked, the grave]. (A, Mgh, Msb.) -A2- Also, He dug with the hand; as also nabava. (AZ, in S, art. nbv.)
5 huwa yatanab~a$u Eani AlA^asoraAri * [app. (assumed tropical:) He endeavours to draw forth or elicit, or he searches out, secrets]. (TA.)
8 A_inotaba$a see 1.
nibaA$apN * The trade, or occupation, of the nab~aA$. (TA.)

[
nabiy$apN *
Earth extracted from a well or burrow or the like. Hence,] nabiy$apu AlyarobuwEi [The earth extracted by the jerboa in making its burrow]. (T in art. dm.)

nab~aA$N *
One who rifles, or ransacks, graves; who takes forth the dead from them; or who uncovers graves. (Mgh, Msb.) See 1, in two places.

A^anobuw$N *
A thing that is taken, drawn, or pulled, out, or forth: (Lh:) the lower part of leguminous plants taken, drawn, or pulled, out, or forth: (S, K:) or trees pulled out by the trunk and roots: (K:) as also ↓ A^unobuw$apN: (TA:) or ↓ both signify what is torn out by the rain: (AHeyth:) pl. A^anaAbiy$u, (S, K,) the pl. of both the above words. (AHeyth.) ― -b2- Also, Full-grown unripe dates that are pierced with thorns in order that they may ripen. (TA.) ― -b3- And the pl. signifies Small arrows. (Sgh.) Some say that this pl. has no singular. (MF.)
A^unobuw$apN * : see A^unobuw$N, in two places.

1 nabaDa * , aor.
nabiDa , inf. n. naboDN and nabaDaAnN (S, A, K) and nabiyDN, (so in a copy of the S,) It (a vein, or an artery,) pulsed, or beat, (TA,) [or throbbed;] was, or became, in a state of motion, or agitation. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] mA nabaDa lahu Eiroqu EaSabiy~apK (tropical:) [No party-spirit, or zeal in the cause of his party, became roused, or excited, in him;] he did not aid his people, or party, against oppression; was not angry, or zealous, for them, and did not defend them. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And ↓ nabaDa naAbiDuhu (tropical:) His anger became roused, or excited. (A, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] nabaDati AlA^amoEaA='u, aor. as above, (in the L, written
nabuDa , but this is doubtless a mistake,] (assumed tropical:) The bowels became in a state of commotion. (TA.) ― -b5- And nabaDa Albaroqu (assumed tropical:) The lightning flashed lightly, or slightly, (K, TA,) like the naboD of a vein or an artery. (TA.) -A2- See also 4.
2 nab~aDa see 4, in two places.

4 A^anobaDati AlHum~aY Eiroqahu *
The fever made his vein, or artery, to pulse, beat, (TA,) [throb,] or become in a state of motion or agitation. (A, TA. *) ― -b2- AnbD Alqawosa, (T, S, M, A, Mgh,) like A^anoDabahaA, (Lth, T, M,) but the former is the more approved; (Lth, 'Eyn;) and AnbD EanohaA; (A, Mgh;) or AnbD fiyhaA; (AHn, K;) and fyhA ↓ nb~D, inf. n. tanobyDN; (AHn, TA;) in the K, fiyhaA ↓ nabaDa, which is a mistake; (TA;) [He twanged the bow;] he made the bow to give a sound: (AHn, K:) or he put the string of the bow in motion, [or made it to vibrate,] (A, K,) or pulled it, (T, S, M, Mgh,) and then let it go, (S, Mgh,) in order that it might twang, (S, K,) or produce a sound: (T, M, Mgh:) and AnbD biAlowatari (S, A, Mgh) signifies the same: (S, Mgh:) or he took the string of the bow with the ends of his two fingers, and then let it go so that it might fall against the handle of the bow: (Jm:) and AnbD Alwatara he pulled the string of the bow without an arrow, and then let it go: (Yaakoob:) or he pulled the string of the bow, and then let it go so that he heard it give a sound. (Lh.) Hence the proverb, A_inobaADu bigayori tawotiyri, (S,) or mino Eayori tawotiyrK, (A,) [Twanging the bow without fastening, or binding, or bracing, the string; meaning (tropical:) threatening without the means of execution]: applied to him who pretends to that which he has not the means of performing. (A, TA.) [See also art. wtr.] And a poet says,
↓ laA^aromiyan~aka ramoyFA gayora tanobiyDi
[I will assuredly shoot thee with a shooting, not a mere twanging]: meaning, my pulling [of the bow] shall not be a threatening, but execution. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also, A^anobaDa Aln~ad~aAfu minobaDatahu [The separater and loosener of cotton by means of the bow and mallet made his mallet to cause the string of the bow to vibrate]. (A, TA.)

naboDN * [an inf. n. used as a subst., signifying The pulse]. ― -b2- Also, A pulsing vein, or artery:
as in the saying jas~a AlT~abiybu naboDahu [The physician felt his pulsing vein, or artery: or his pulse]: but it is more chaste to say ↓ manobiDahu q. v. (TA.) ― -b3- See also nabaDN. ― -b4- [It is also used as an epithet. You say,] fuw^aAdN naboDN, as also ↓ nabaDN, and ↓ nabiDN, (Sgh K,) and ↓ nabiyDN, (A, TA,) (tropical:) A heart that is sharp in intellect, clever, acute, (A, Sgh, K,) and very brisk or lively or sprightly or prompt. (A, TA.)

maA bihi HabaDN walaA nabaDN * , (IDrd, S, K,) and HaboDN ↓ wlA naboDN, (Sgh,) There is not in him any motion: (S, Sgh, K:) or sound, or voice, nor pulsation: (AA, in S, art. HbD:) or strength: (IDrd:) with fet-h to the second letter, only used in a negative phrase: (L:) As says, I know not what is AlHabaDu, (S in art. HbD,) or AlHaboDu. (TA.) ― -b2- fuw^aAdN nabaDN: see naboDN.
nabiDN * : see naboDN.
naboDapN * [A single pulsation]. You say, raA^ayotu wamoDapa baroqK kanaboDapi EiroqK [I saw a slight flash of lightning, like a single pulsation of an artery]. (A, TA.)
nabiyDN * : see naboDN.

naAbiDN * [part. n. of 1]. You say, maA daAma fiY~a EurayoqN naAbiDN lamo A^axo*uloka [As long as there remains in me a little artery pulsing, I will not abstain, or hold back, from aiding thee]; i. e., (tropical:) as long as I remain alive. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Anger. (Lth, A, K.) See 1, where an ex. is given. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) An archer: lit. one who has a twanging. (Mgh.)

manobiDu Alqalobi *
The place where one sees the heart pulsing, (TA,) or in motion; (A, K;) and where one perceives the gentle sound of its [pulsation, or] motion. (A, O.) You say, jas~a AlT~abiybu manobiDahu [The physician felt his place of pulsation], and manaAbiDahumo [their places of pulsation]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- maA yuEorafu lahu manobiDu EasalapK means (tropical:) He has no origin [known]; like maDoribu EasalapK; (A, TA;) nor any people [to whom he belongs]. (TA.)
wajaEN munobiDN * [A pain causing pulsation, or throbbing]. (L, TA.)

minobaDN * , (S, K,) or ↓ minobaDapN, (A,) The wooden mallet with which one separates and loosens cotton by striking with it the string of a bow; syn. minodafN, like miHobaDN; (S;) or minodafapN: (A, K:) manaAbiDu is said by Kh to occur in poetry as [its pl.,] meaning manaAdifu. (S.)
minobaDapN * : see what next precedes.

1 nabaTa * , aor.
nabuTa and
nabiTa , inf. n. nubuwTN (S, K) and naboTN, (K,) It (water) welled, or issued forth. (S, K.) -A2- See also 4.
2 nab~aTa see 4.
3 naAobaTa see 10.

4 AnbT *
He (a digger) reached the water: (AA, S:) or reached the first that appeared of the water of a well, (K, TA,) and produced it, or fetched it out, by his labour. (TA.) And AnbT fiY EaDoraA='a He produced, or fetched out, by labour, water from good clay, or from clay containing no sand. (TA.) -A2- [It is also trans.: you say,] AnbT Alr~akiy~apa; and ↓ AstnbThA; (M, K;) and ↓ nb~ThA; (IAar, M, TA;) in the K ↓ tnb~ThA; (TA;) and ↓ nabaTahaA, (M, K [in the CK with teshdeed to the b]) aor.
nabiTa , (TA,) inf. n. naboTN; (M;) He produced, or fetched out, by his labour [in digging], the water of the well; syn. A^amaAhahaA; (M, K;) and of the first, (TA,) and last, (TA,) [or rather of all,] Astxrj maA='ahaA. (K, TA.) And AnbT AlmaA='a, inf. n. A_inobaATN; and ↓ AstnbThu; He (a digger [of a well]) produced, or fetched out, by his labour, or work, the water. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 10, in five places. -A3- A_inobaATN also signifies The producing an effect, or making an impression; syn. taA^vyrN. (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh, K.)

5 tanab~aTa see 4: ― -b2- and 10. -A2- tnb~T also signifies He affected to be like, or imitated, the nabaT [or Nabathæans]: or he asserted himself to be related to them. (K, TA.) [Compare 10, in the last of the senses assigned to it below.]
8 A_inotabaTa see 10.

10 AstnbT * : see 4, in two places: its primary signification is [that mentioned above,] from nabaTN signifying the “ water that comes forth from a well when it is first dug. ” (Zj.) ― -b2- And hence, (Zj,) He drew out, or forth; extracted; educed; produced; elicited; fetched out by labour or art; got out; or extorted; syn. Asotaxoraja; (Zj, S;) a thing: (Zj:) and (assumed tropical:) He made anything to appear after occultation; as also ↓ AnbT; (B;) [i. e. he brought it to light:] and AusotunobiTa (assumed tropical:) it (anything) was made apparent, after occultation; as also ↓ A^unobiTa: (K:) or the latter, [simply,] (assumed tropical:) it was made apparent. (L.) And [hence] (tropical:) He (a lawyer) elicited (Astxrj) an occult, or esoteric, doctrine of law, by his intelligence, and his labour, or study: (K, TA:) or you say AstnbThu, meaning (assumed tropical:) he elicited it (Astxrjhu), namely a judicial sentence, by labour, or study; as also ↓ AnbThu, inf. n. A_inobaATN: (Msb:) or (assumed tropical:) he searched out the knowledge of it. (Jel. iv. 85.) And AstnbT minohu EilomFA, and xayorFA, and maAlFA, (tropical:) He drew forth, elicited, or extorted, (Astxrj,) from him knowledge, and good, or wealth, and property. (TA.) And ↓ nibaATN [app. an inf. n. of naAbaTa] signifies the same as A_isotinobaAT HadiytK (assumed tropical:) The drawing forth, or eliciting, (A_isotaxoraAj) of discourse. (TA.) And AlkalaAma ↓ tnb~T, accord. to the K, or, accord. to Sgh, on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád, ↓ AntbThu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He drew forth, or elicited, (Astxrj,) speech. (Ibn- 'Abbád, Sgh, K.) And AlEiloma ↓ AnbT (tropical:) He revealed knowledge, and spread it among men. (TA.) ― -b3- AstnbT Alfarasa (assumed tropical:) He sought to obtain offspring from the mare: occurring in a trad.: but accord. to one relation, it is A_isotaboTanahaA, meaning, “ he sought what was in her belly. ” (TA.) -A2- He (a man) became a [naturalized] nabaTiY~ [or Nabathæan]. (S, * TA.) It is said by Eiyoob Ibn-El-Kirreeyeh, A^aholu EumaAna EarabN A@sotanobaTuwA waA^aholu AlbaHorayoni nabiyTN A@sotaEorabuwA [The people of 'Omán are Arabs who became naturalized Nabathæans, and the people of ElBahreyn are Nabathæans who became naturalized Arabs]. (S, TA.) [See also 5.]

nabaTN *
What first appears of the water of a well (IDrd, K) when it is dug; (IDrd;) as also ↓ nuboTapN: (K:) or the water that comes forth from a well when it is first dug: (Zj:) or the water that issues forth from the bottom of a well when it is dug; (S, accord. to one copy;) or this is termed ↓ nabiyTN: (S, accord. to another copy; and TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anobaATN and [of mult.] nubuwTN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] fulaAnN qariybu Alv~araY baEiydu Aln~abaTi (assumed tropical:) Such a one's promising is near, [but] his fulfilling is remote: i. e. he promises, but does not fulfil. (IAar.) And flAn laA yudoraku nabaTuhu, (TA,) and laA yudoraku lahu nabaTN, (ISd, TA,) (tropical:) Such a one's depth is not known, (K, * TA,) and the extent of his knowledge: (TA:) or such a one's depth is not known; meaning that he is cunning, or possessing intelligence mixed with craft and forecast. (ISd, TA.) And fulaAnN laA yunaAlu nabaTuhu (assumed tropical:) Such a one is invincible, and inaccessible to his enemy. (TA.) ― -b3- nabaTN also signifies A well of which the water has been produced, or fetched out, by labour [of the digger]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And What oozes, or exudes, from a mountain, as though it were sweat, coming forth from the sides of the rock. (TA.) -A2- Aln~abaTu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ Aln~abiyTu, (S, Msb, K,) and AlA^anobaATu, (K,) the last is a pl. (AAF, S, Msb) of the first, (AAF,) and the second is [a quasi-pl. n.] like kaliybN, (AAF, L,) [The Nabathæans;] a people who alight and abide in the baTaAy^iH [see A^aboTaHu] between the two 'Iráks: (S, K:) or a people (T, M, Mgh, Msb) who alight and abide, (T, TA,) or who used to alight and abide, (Msb,) in the sawaAd (T, M, Mgh, Msb) of El- 'Irák:) (M, Mgh, Msb:) afterwards applied to mixed people; or people of the lowest or basest or
meanest sort; or the refuse of men; and the vulgar sort thereof: (Msb:) the people to whom these appellations properly apply were called nabaT because of their fetching out by labour (liA@sotinobaATihimo) what comes forth from the lands: (TA:) [for they were distinguished for agriculture; and hence their proper appellations are used as equivalent to “ clowns, ” or “ boors: ” but a derivation commonly obtaining with us is that from Nebaioth the son of Ishmael:] the n. un. is ↓ nubaATiY~N, (Yaakoob, IAar, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ nabaATiY~N, (IAar, S, Msb, K,) like yamaAniY~N, (S,) and ↓ nibaATiY~N, (K,) and ↓ nabaATK, (S, K,) like yamaAnK, (S,) and ↓ nabaTiY~N, (S, K,) like yamaniY~N, (S,) but this is disallowed by IAar, (Mgh, TA,) and, accord. to Lth, ↓ nabaTaAniY~N, but this [also] is disallowed by IAar. (Msb.)
nuboTapN * : see nabaTN.
nabaTiY~N * : see nabaTN.
nabaTaAniY~N * : see nabaTN.
nabaATN * : see nabaTN.
nabiyTN * : and Aln~abiyTN: see nabaTN.
nabaATiY~N * and nubaATiY~N and nibaATiY~N: see nabaTN.

div2.head: nbE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

nabahorajN bhrj nbhrj
i. q. bahorajN, q. v. (TA). [The place in which it is mentioned in the K shows that F regards the n as a radical letter; and though it is said in the TA that its being so is doubtful, he is right accord. to those who hold that every letter of an arabicized word is to be regarded as a radical if it, or a letter for which it is substituted, is found in the original.]
See Supplement

1 nat~a * , [aor.
nati3a ,] inf. n. naviytN, i. q. kat~, inf. n. katiytN; (K;) and nafata, inf. n. nafiytN: (L, K:) [It (a cooking-pot) boiled: &c.] ― -b2- nat~a manoxiruhu gaDabFA His nostril became inflated, or swollen, by reason of anger. (K.)

2 nt~t *
He explained news, tidings, or a report. (K.)
5 tanat~a3a See R. Q. 1.
R. Q.1 natonata * (in a MS. copy of the K ↓ tanat~ata, [and so in the CK,] but the former is the more correct, TA) He (a man, L) became dirty (tq*~r) after having been clean. (IAar, L, K.)

nut~apN *
A small hollow, or cavity, in [stones of the kind called] SafowaAnN, (K,) in which the rain-water collects. (TA.)

1 nataA^a * , aor.
nataAa , inf. n. nato'N and nutuwo'N, (S, K,) It swelled; swelled up; rose; grew up. (K.) Said of a plant, &c. (S.) ― -b2- nataA^a, (S, K,) inf. n. nutuwo'N, (TA,) It protruded, or projected, from its place, without becoming separated. (S, K.) ― -b3- nataA^a It (an ulcer, or a wound,) swelled. (S, K.) ― -b4- It (a girl's breast) swelled forth, or became prominent, or protuberant. (TA.) ― -b5- nataA^ato She (a girl) grew up, (S,) and became marriageable. (S, K.) ― -b6- nataA^a Ealayohimo, inf. n. nato'N, He rose, or exalted himself, above them. (TA.) ― -b7- [You say,] taHoqiruhu wayanotaA^u Thou despisest him, and he riseth, or exalteth himself: (S:) or ― -b8- he emulateth thee: or ― -b9- he becometh great. A proverb, said of him who does not manifest his character or design by outward appearance, but keeps it secret: or of him who advances and exalts himself by his cunning, while thou thinkest him senseless, or negligent. Accord. to some, it is tHqrh wyanotuw, without ': see art. ntw. (TA.) -A2- nataA^a He went up from the country or land to another. (TA.) -A3- tanaA^a Ealayohimo He came upon them; syn. A_iT~alaEa. (S, K.)

8 AnttA^ *
He rose, or exalted himself. (K.) ― -b2- AnttA^ lahu He encountered him; met him; opposed himself to him. (K, TA: the verb is explained in the K by A_inobaraY.)

1 nataba * , aor.
natuba , inf. n. nutuwbN, It swelled forth; became prominent, or protuberant. (S, K.) Said of a girl's breast. (S.)

1 nataja * , (S, K, &c.,) aor.
natuja , (as in the L, [but I believe this to be a mistake,]) or
natija , (accord. to the Msb, MS, MF,) inf. n. natojN; (S;) and ↓ Antj; (A;) He assisted a she-camel, (S, K, &c.,) [and a mare, see nutijato,] and a ewe or she-goat (Msb) [or other quadruped], in bringing forth; delivered her of her young one; acting to her as a midwife does to a woman. (T, Msb, &c.) The original form of expression is natajahaA waladFA He assisted her in bringing forth a young one; delivered her of a young one. (Msb.) El-Kumeyt has used the form ↓ Ainotataja in the sense of nataja: but it is not commonly current in Arabic. (TA.) AHn mentions the saying Aln~aAsu ↓ A_i*aA naA='ati Aljabohapu nat~aju wawal~aduwA waA@jotuniYa A^aw~alu AlkamoA^api [When El-Jebhah (the tenth of the Mansions of the Moon) sets antiheliacally, (for the setting, not the rising, is here meant, and this it did, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, in central Arabia, on the 11th of February,) the people assist their beasts, much, or frequently, in bringing forth, and deliver them, and the first of the truffles are gathered]. Thus he relates the saying, with teshdeed to the v of ntj, to denote frequency of the act. (L.) ― -b2- nutijato, pass. in form, [but neut. in signification,] inf. n. nitaAjN (S, K, &c.) and tanojN; (TA;) and ↓ A^unotijato, (K,) also pass. in form; and some say natajato, but this is rare, and not heard by IAar; (TA;) and some, also, say ↓ A^anotajato, (Lth, Kr,) but Az holds this to be a mistake; (TA;) She (a camel, IAar, S, K, &c., and a mare, IAar, and a sheep or goat or other quadruped, Msb) brought forth: (T, Msb, TA:) or one does not say nutijati Al$~aApu unless a man assist at the bringing forth. (Lth.) Thus one suppresses the objective complement of the verb. And one also says tunijati Aln~aAqapu waladFA The she-camel brought forth a young one: and in like manner one says of a ewe or a she-goat: and sometimes, with the same meaning, natajati AlnAqp wldA, in the act. form. (Msb.) One also says AlA_ibilu ↓ tanaAtajati The camels brought forth. (A.) [You say,] nataja Alqawomu, (Lth,) and ↓ A^anotaja, (L,) The people's camels or sheep or goats brought forth: (Lth, L:) or ↓ A^anotajuwA they had pregnant camels bringing forth. (K.) One may also say nutija Alwaladu, meaning The young one of a she-camel &c., [see nutijato, above,] was brought forth, or born. (Msb.) See 4. ― -b3- [Hence,] Alr~iyHu tunotiju Als~aHaAba (tropical:) [The wind assists the clouds in the discharging of their rain; i. e., draws forth the rain from the clouds. (A, L.) ― -b4- [nutija It was produced, it resulted, or was a natural consequence.]
2 nat~aja see 1.

4 A^anotajato *
She (a camel, S, and a mare, S, K, or other solid-hoofed animal, Msb,) became pregnant: (T:) and so ↓ natajato, said of a she-camel, (Msb,) or other beast; but this is rare: (EsSarakustee, Msb:) or attained to the time of bringing forth: (S, K:) or became evidently pregnant: (Yaakoob, S, Msb:) accord. to IAar, A^unotijato, in the pass. form, signifies she (a mare, and a camel,) became near to the time of bringing forth; and he had not heard A^anotajato, in the act. form. (TA.) ― -b2- See 1 and 8. ― -b3- A^anotaja or A^unotija (?) (tropical:) It produced a thing as its fruit, or result. Ex. AlEajozu waAlt~awaAniY tazaAwajaA faA^anotajaA Alfaqora Impotence and remissness combined together, and produced, as
their result, poverty. (A, L.) And h`*ihi Almuqad~imapu laA tunotiju taniyjapF SaAdiqapF This preamble will not produce a praiseworthy result. (A.)

5 tnt~jt *
She (a camel) breathed hard (tzH~rt) that her young one might come forth. (K.)
6 tanaAotaja see 1.

8 Ainotatajato * (L, K, TA: in the CK A^anotajato) She (a camel) went away at random, and brought forth in a place unknown: (K:) or she brought forth by herself, unassisted by any one; (Yaakoob, L;) as also ↓ A^anotajato. (L.)

nitaAjN * : see nutijato. ― -b2- [Also, an inf. n. in the sense of a pass. part. n., like HamolN in the sense of maHomuwlN, &c., What is brought forth by a camel &c.; and what are brought forth by camels &c., collectively; a brood thereof; its, or their, increase, or offspring; as is plainly shown in the lexicons &c., in many passages: for ex., see $aroxN, and difo'N: also applied, in the TA art. bTn, to the young in the belly of a mare].

natuwjN * , (AZ, S, K,) a rare form of epithet from a verb of the measure A^afoEala, (Kr,) and ↓ munotijN, (AZ, TA,) or the latter is not allowable, (S, K,) and ↓ natiyjN, (Kr,) A she-camel, (S, Kr,) or a mare, (S, K,) or other solid-hoofed animal, (Msb,) pregnant: (Lth:) or that has attained to the time of bringing forth: (S, K:) or evidently pregnant: (Yaakoob, S, Msb:) or near to the time of bringing forth, and big-bellied. (AZ.) ― -b2- [See also manotuwjapN.]
natiyjN * : see natuwjN.

natiyjapN *
A young one of a she-camel &c. [see nataja and nutijato] brought forth. (Msb.) ― -b2- ntiyjapN (assumed tropical:) Any produce, fruit, result, or natural consequence, of a thing: (KL:) [the sum of a speech or saying: a necessary inference: the conclusion of an argument or of a syllogism: pl. nataAy^iju.] You say, h`*ihi natiyjapN mn nataAy^ij karamika (tropical:) [This is one of the fruits, or results, of thy generosity]. (A.) [For another ex. see 4.] ― -b3- humaA natiyjapN They are both of one age: said of two sheep. (Yoo, S.) ganamu fulaAnK nataAy^iju The sheep, or goats, of such a one are of one age. (S, K.) h`*aA Alwaladu natiyju waladiY (tropical:) This child is one born in the same month, or year, as my child. (A.)
naAtijN * A man assisting a she-camel &c. [see nataja] in bringing forth; delivering her; or one who assists her in bringing forth; who delivers her. (Msb, TA.)
manotijN * The time at which a she-camel, (S,) or a mare, (K,) brings forth. (S, K.) Ex. A^atati Aln~aAqapu EalaY manotijihaA The she-camel arrived at the time of her bringing forth. (S.)
munotijN * : see natawjN. ― -b2- qaEada munotijFA (tropical:) He sat accomplishing a want of nature. (A.)
minotajapN * The anus; syn. AisotN; as also minovajapN. (K.)

manotuwjapN * A she-camel &c., [see nataja] assisted in bringing forth; delivered. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Also, A she-camel [&c., see nutijato,] bringing forth; (T;) and so, accord. to Kr, ↓ natuwjN, which, he says, is the only epithet of this measure from a verb of the measure fuEila, except batuwlN: (TA:) pl. manaAtiyju: ex. nuwqN mnAtyju she-camels bringing forth. (A.)

1 nataHa * , aor.
natiHa , inf. n. natoHN, He, or it, sweated. (L.) ― -b2- nataHa, aor.
natiHa , inf. n. natoHN and nutuwHN, It (a leathern vessel, or skin,) sweated, or exuded moisture, (S, L,) as when a skin sweats with the butter that is in it. (L.) ― -b3- nataHa, aor. ??, inf. n. natoHN and nutuwjN, It (sweat) exuded (S, L, K) from the skin, (L, K,) or from the roots of the hair; (T, L;) and grease, from a skin; and moisture, from the soil. (L, K.) ― -b4- [And said of moisture, It percolated: see an ex. voce Eariqa.] ― -b5- fulaAnN yanotiHu natiyHa AlHamiyti (tropical:) [Such a one sweats like a butter-skin]: said of one who is fat. (A.) ― -b6- tanaHato *iforaY AlbaEiyri EaraqFA The camel's protuberance behind his ear dripped with sweat, by reason of his journeying during a vehemently hot summer-day.
