[How many a waterless desert glistening with the mirage, in which vows, or things vowed, are vowed, lie in the way to Leylà!]. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) The mulct for an intentional wound; used in this sense by Esh-Sháfi'ee, (T, TA,) and of the dial. of El-Hijáz; (TA;) i. q. A^aro$N, (T, A, K, TA,) which is of the dial. of the people of El-'Irák: (T, TA:) pl. nu*uwrN: (T, A, K:) said by Aboo-Nahshal to be only for wounds, small and great. (T, K. *) You say, liY qibala fulaAnK na*orN, (T, TS, L,) or Einoda fulaAnK, (K,) (tropical:) A mulct for a wound is owed to me. (T, K, &c.) And A^aEoTayotuhu na*ora juroHihi (tropical:) I gave him the mulct for his wound. (A.) Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer says that it is thus called liA^an~ahu nu*ira fiyhi, i. e., because it is made binding, or obligatory, for it; [namely, for the wound;] from the phrase na*arotu ElaY nafosiY. (T, TA.) ― -b3- [A votive offering]. -A2- See also nu*orN.

nu*orN * (M) and ↓ nu*urN (T, S, K) [and ↓ na*orN (see 4)] and ↓ na*iyrN (S, M) and ↓ na*iyrapN (M) and ↓ ni*aArapN (Esh-Sháfi'ee, K) and ↓ nu*oraY (K) are substs. in the sense of A_ino*aArN [meaning An informing, or advising, of a thing: and a warning, or cautioning, and putting one on his guard, against a thing, and putting one in fear of a thing; &c.: (see 4:)] (T, S, M, K:) or a putting one in fear in announcing a thing. (TA.) Eu*orFA A^awo nu*orFA and Eu*urFA A^awo nu*urFA, accord. to different readings, in the Kur, lxxvii. 6, put in the accus. case as causal complements, signify liloA_iEo*aAri waA@loA_ino*aAri [For excusing and warning]. (Zj, T.) [See also art. E*r.] And in like manner, ↓ nu*uri, in the Kur, liv. 16, &c., signifies A_ino*aAriY. (S, K.) And so ↓ na*iyri, in the Kur, lxvii. 17. (T, M.) Hence also the saying of the Arabs, Eu*oraAka laA nu*oraAka, meaning, A^aEo*iru walaA tuno*iro [i. e. Do thou that for which thou wilt be excused, by inflicting punishment when it is deserved, and do not merely warn and put in fear]. (TA.)
nu*urN * : see nu*orN.
nu*oraY * : see nu*orN.

na*iyrN *
i. q. ↓ muno*irN, (T, S, M, A, Msb, K,) as also ↓ na*iyrapN; (M;) i. e. [One who gives information, or advice, of a thing, or things: and one who warns;] one who cautions; (M, TA;) and who puts in fear: (TA:) one who gives notice to a people of an enemy, or other thing, that has come upon them; (TA;) a spy who gives notice, to a people, of an enemy, to put them on their guard; (A;) and in like manner ↓ na*iyrapN, a spy who informs an army of the state of the enemy: (T, K:) na*iyrN is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufoEilN: (M, L:) or its verb was na*ara, but this has become obsolete: (T:) its pl. is nu*urN; (M, Msb, K;) occurring in the Kur, liv. 23, [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Abw muno*irK The cock (Har. p. 644). ― -b3- [And also,] Aln~a*iyru The apostle: (M, K:) so in the Kur, xxxv. 34, accord. to Th: (M:) the prophet Mohammad: (T, K:) so, accord. to most of the expositors, in that verse of the Kur. (T.) ― -b4- Hoariness, or whiteness of the hair: (T, M, K:) so, accord. to some, in the verse of the Kur, last referred to: (T, M:) but the explanation immediately preceding is more probable. (T.) ― -b5- The sound of a bow: (AHn, M, K:) because it warns, or frightens, (yunodiru,) that which is shot at. (AHn, M.) -A2- I. q. mano*uwrN [i. e. Vowed]: pl. nu*urN. (S.) See na*orN. -A3- See also nu*orN.
ni*aArapN * : see nu*orN.

na*iyrapN * [A votive gift;] that which he gives who makes a vow. (M, K.) ― -b2- A child appointed by the father (M, K) and mother (M) [by a vow] to be a minister, or servant to the church, (M, K,) or to a place appropriated to religious services, or exercises, or acts of devotion: (T:) pl. na*aAy^iru. (T.) -A2- See also na*iyrN, in two places. -A3- And see nu*orN.
naA*irN * : see muna*~irN.
muno*irN * : see na*iyrN.
mano*uwrN * : see na*iyrN.
fulaAnN muna*~irN A_ilaY~a biEiyonihi * , and ↓ naA*irN, Such a one is looking at me hard or intently, and making his eye prominent. (T, in TA, art. znr.)

mutanaA*arN * [A thing of which people warn or caution one another, or of which they put one another in fear]: applied to a disease [&c.]. (TA, art. xbr voce xayobaraY.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlmutanaA*aru (assumed tropical:) The lion. (Sgh, K.)
1 na*ula * , inf. n. na*aAlapN, He was, or became, low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, sordid, or contemptible, (S, K,) in all his circumstances. (K.)
na*olN * A man vile, or mean, and despised in all his circumstances. (K.)

Q. Q. 1 Alr~iyHu tunayoribu Alt~uraAba fawoqahu * , or EalaY AlA^aroDi, (TA,) inf. n. nayorabapN, (TA,) The wind lays the dust upon it, or upon the ground, in cross, wavy lines: syn. tanosijuhu. (K.) Hence nayoraba AlkalaAm. (TA.) ― -b2- It has been asserted that n and r do not come together in any [pure] Arabic word; and F has said the same in art. nr$; [or rather he has there said that r does not occur in an Arabic word with n before it;
(meaning a radical n;)] yet he has here mentioned this word as though it were pure Arabic. So says MF. To this it may be replied, that Y is inserted to separate the n and r, as remarked in the L. (TA.) ― -b3- nayoraba He forged [speech, or language]: syn. nasaja. (K.) You say huwa yunayoribu Alqawola. (TA.) ― -b4- nayoraba He mixed, or confounded, speech, [introducing what was false with that which was true]. (K.) ― -b5- nayoraba He uttered a malicious and mischievous misrepresentation, a calumny, or slander. (K.)

nayorabN * (S, K) and ↓ nayorabapN (as in several copies of the K, [and I am inclined to think that this is the correct reading, as it may certainly be correctly used in the sense here given, being properly an inf. n., agreeably with analogy,] or ↓ manorabapN (as in others, which is said in the TA to be the correct word, and to be given on the authority of AA, [but it exhibits an incongruity of letters: see 1:]) Mischief; malicious and mischievous misrepresentation, calumny, or slander. (S, K.) ― -b2- nayorabN, fem. with p; and *uw nayorabK; A mischievous man; (K;) one who utters malicious and mischievous misrepresentations, calumnies, or slanders. (TA.) ― -b3- nayorabN A strong man. (K.)

nayorabaY *
A calamity; a misfortune. (K.)
nayorabapN * and manorabapN: see nayorabN.

1 naraja *
He thrashed wheat, or corn, with a naworaj. (TA.)

naworajN * (L, K) and ↓ nayorajN and ↓ nuwrajN, the last of the dial. of El-Yemen, and a word of which there is not the like in Arabic, (L,) A thrashinginstrument, or that with which heaps of wheat, or corn, are thrashed, whether of wood or of iron; (L, K;) or, of iron and wood; (Sifr es-Sa'ádeh;) [a kind of drag, used, in Egypt and Arabia and some other countries of Western Asia, for the purpose of separating the grain of wheat and barley &c. and cutting the straw, which serves as fodder; it is a machine in the form of a chair fixed upon a sledge, which moves upon small iron wheels, or thin circular plates, generally eleven, fixed to three thick axle-trees, four to the foremost, the same number to the hindmost, and three to the intermediate axle-tree: this machine is drawn, in a circle, by a pair of cows or bulls, their driver being seated upon it, over the corn: pl. [of the first and last words] nawaAriju. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the first and second, A ploughshare. (K.)
nuwrajN * and nayorajN: see naworajN

naAranojN *
A well-known fruit; [the orange; citrus aurantium; of which there are two species common in the gardens of the East, one sweet, and the other bitter:] and arabicized word, from [the Persian] naAranoko [also called naArinoj]. (K.)
narojisN * and nirojisN [The Narcissus]: see art. rjs. The former is mentioned by ISd in art. rjs: the latter, in the present art. (TA.)

narodN * [The game of tricktrack, backgammon, or tables: and, app., a pair of tables and other apparatus with which that game is played:] a certain thing with which one plays; (M, L;) well known: (M, L, K:) a Persian word, (M, L,) arabicized: (M, L:) also called naroda$iyrN, (M, L, K,) because invented (as some say, TA) by Ardasheer the son of Bábak, (K,) a Persian king. (TA.) It is said in a trad., that he who plays at this game is as though he plunged his hand into the flesh and blood of the pig. (L.)
naworuwzN * : see what follows.

nayoruwzN * , an arabicized word, (S, A, Msb,) from naworuwzo, (A, K,) which in Persian; meaning “ new day; ” (TA;) and ↓ naworuwzN; but the former, which is of the measure fayoEuwlN, is the better in repute, because fawoEuwlN is not the measure of an Arabic word; (Msb;) The first day of the year; New-year's-day: (A, Msb, K:) with the Persians, when the sun enters Aries: and with the Copts, the first of [the month] Toot [the ancient Thoth, or the tenth of September, N. S., excepting when immediately following their leap-year, which is when our next ensuing year is a leap-year]. (Msb, TA.) The word nyrwz is said to have been first used in the time of the 'Abbásee Khaleefehs; but it is related to have been used in the time of 'Alee. (TA.)

1 naz~ati AlA^aroDu * , (A, Msb, K,) aor.
nazi3a , inf. n. naz~N; (Msb;) and ↓ Anz~t, (S, A, Msb,) The ground, or land, had water exuding, or oozing, from it: (S, K:) or had much flowing moisture: (Msb:) or became [abundant in] manaAbiE [or places welling forth water], as in the TS and the K, or manaAqiE [or places of stagnant water] by reason of the naz~. (TA.) ― -b2- [naz~ato bihi AlbiTonapu: see niTonap.] -A2- naz~a, aor.
nazi3a , inf. n. naziyzN, He (an antelope, S,) ran: (S, K:) or he (an ostrich, and an antelope,) leaped, jumped, sprang, or bounded. (A.) ― -b2- He (an antelope, S,) uttered a cry, or cries. (Ibn-El-Jarráh, Ks, S, K.)
4 A^anoza3a see 1, first signification.

naz~N * and ↓ niz~N Water that exudes, or oozes, from the ground: (S, K:) or flowing moisture: (Msb:) the latter is the better word; and is [said to be] Persian, arabicized: (TA:) the former is an inf. n. used as a subst. (Msb.) ― -b2- [The pl. is nuzuwzN, occurring in the TA in art. E*w.] ― -b3- [The former is also used as an epithet: fem. with p. You say,] A^aroDN naz~apN Ground, or land, having water exuding, or oozing, from it; syn. *aAtu naz~K; as also ↓ naAz~apN. (Lh, TA.) -A2- [Hence, perhaps,] naz~N also signifies (assumed tropical:) liberal, bountiful, or munificent. (Sgh, K.) -A3- Also, naz~N Much, or many. (K.) -A4- A man (A'Obeyd, S) light, or active, (A'Obeyd, S, K,) or light in spirit, (TA,) sharp in mind, (A'Obeyd, S, K,) clever, or ingenious, (A'Obeyd, K,) and intel-ligent. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b2- Light, inconstant, fickle, or unsteady: (K:) an epithet of dispraise. (TA.) ― -b3- A man (TA) much, or often, in motion; as also ↓ minaz~N: (K:) a man, (A,) and an ostrich, (S, K, TA,) that does not remain still in one place: (S, A, K:) or that is quick, or swift, and does not remain still in one place: (TA:) or an ostrich, and an antelope, that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds: (A:) and a light, or an active, camel; (TA;) and so naz~apN, applied to a she-camel. (S, TA.) ― -b4- Light dust. (TA.) ― -b5- $ar~K ↓ niz~u, and ↓ naziyzuhu, i. q. liz~uhu and laziyzuhu. (TA, art. lz.)
niz~N * : see naz~N.
naziyzN * : see naz~N, last sentence.
naAz~N * : fem. with p: see naz~N.

minaz~N *
A child's cradle: (A, K:) because of its frequent motion. (TA.) ― -b2- See also naz~N.

1 nazaA^a bayonahumo * , (S, K,) aor.
nazaAa , inf. n. nazo'N and nuzuwo'N, (S,) He excited discord between them: (AZ, S, K:) like nazaEa. (TA.) ― -b2- nazaA^ahu EalaY SaAHibihi He incited, or urged, him against his companion. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- maA nazaA^aka EalaY h`*aA What incited, urged, or induced, thee to this? (Ks, S.) ― -b4- nazaA^a Ealayohi, (S, K,) inf. n. nazo'N, (S,) He made an attack, or assault, upon him; syn. Hamala. (Ks, S. K.) ― -b5- nazaA^ahu Eano qawolihi He turned him back from what he had said. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- nuziy^a bihi, like EuniYa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] He was addicted, or devoted, to it; desirous of it. (TA.) ― -b7- A_in~aka laA tadoriY EalaAma yunozaA^u harimuka, (S, K,) thus thou sayest, addressing thyself, when a man has been pursuing a good or an evil way, and turned from it to another way, or accord. to some copies of the S, bima instead of EalaAma, [which is for EalaY maA;] (TA;) Verily thou knowest not to what thing thy mind will become addicted, or devoted: (ISk, S, K:) i. e., to what thy state will come. (K.) In one copy of the K, haramuka thine old age, is put instead of harimuka. (TA.)

naziYo' *
An inciter, instigator, or exciter. (TA.)
rajulN naz~aA='N * [A man much addicted, or devoted, to a thing; very desirous of it]. (TA.) [See naziy^a.]

manozuwo'N bihi *
Addicted, or devoted, to it; desirous of it. (S, K.)

1 nazaba * , aor.
naziba , inf. n. naziybN (S, K) and nazobN and nuzaAbN (K) He (an antelope) uttered a cry, or sound, (S, K,) at rutting-time. (S.) Used with reference to the buck and the doe; (K;) or the buck only. (S, K.)

6 tnAzbwA *
i. q. tnAbzwA. (K.) Accord. to IHsh and others, this verb has not been heard [from the Arabs of the classical ages], but only the subst. nazabN, which is therefore decided to be a transp. form of nabazN. (TA.)

nazabN *
A surname; a nickname; a name of reproach; an opprobrious appellation: syn. laqaba: (K:) i. q. nabazN. (TA.) See 6.

nayozabN *
A buck-antelope; and a bull. (K.) [By the latter is probably meant the kind of antelope called baqaru AlwaHo$i.]

1 nazaHa * , aor.
nazaHa and
naziHa , inf. n. nazoHN and nuzuwHN; (K;) and ↓ AntzH; (TA;) He, or it, (a thing, TA,) became distant, or remote. (K.) ― -b2- nazaHati Ald~aAru, inf. n. nuzuwHN, The house, or dwelling, became distant, or remote. (S.) ― -b3- nuziHa bifulaAnK, (S, K,) a verb like EuniYa, [pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] (K,) Such a one became far removed from his dwelling-place. (S, K.) -A2- nazaHa Albiy^ora, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
nazaHa (Msb) and
naziHa , (TA,) inf. n. nazoHN (S, Msb) and nuzuwHN; (Msb;) and ↓ A^anozaHahaA; (K;) He drew forth all the water of the well; exhausted it entirely: (S, Msb, K:) or he drew from it until little water remained in it; nearly exhausted it. (K.) ― -b2- nazaHati Albiy^oru, (A, Msb, K,) aor.
nazaHa , (TA,) inf. n. nazaHN (K) and nuzuwHN, (TA,) The well became entirely exhausted: (A, Msb, K:) or, became nearly exhausted. (K.) See 4. ― -b3- qado nazaHotaniY (assumed tropical:) Thou hast exhausted me of what I had, or possessed. (L, from a trad.)

4 A^anozaHa Alqawomu * , (L, and so in some copies of the K, [agreeable with analogy,]) or ↓ nazaHa, (so in other copies of the K,) The people had the water of their wells entirely, or nearly, exhausted. (L, K.) See 1.
8 A_inotazaHa see 1.
$ar~uka saroHN waxayoruka nazoHN * (tropical:) [Thy wickedness ranges abroad unrestrained, and] thy goodness is little. (A.)
nazaHN * : see naAziHN. ― -b2- Also, Turbid water. (K.)
nuzuHN * and nazuwHN and naziyHN: see naAziHN.

naAziHN * and ↓ nuzuHN and ↓ nazuwHN and ↓ naziyHN A thing, (K,) or dwelling, (TA,) distant, or remote. (K.) baladN naAziHN A distant, or remote, town, or country: (S:) and daArN naAziHapN a distant, or remote, house, or dwelling. (Msb.) ― -b2- ↓ qawomN manaAziyHu A distant, or remote, people. (S, K.) And A_iyilN mnAzyH Camels from distant regions. (A.) ISd says, that it is pl. of ↓ minozaAHN, meaning That comes to the water from a distant place. (L.) -A2- naAziHN and ↓ nuzuHN and ↓ nazuwHN A well entirely exhausted: or nearly exhausted: (K:) or ↓ biy^orN nazuwHN signifies a well containing little water: pl. nuzuHN: (S:) and biy^orN ↓ nazaHN, nazaHN being of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, a well containing no water; and it is allowable to say manozuwHapN: (Msb:) or a well of which the water has been exhausted: (so in some copies of the S, and the like in the Nh:) or a well of which most of the water has been drawn forth. (So in other copies of the S, and in the K.) See an ex., voce mudaArapN, art. dwr.

minozaHapN *
A bucket (K) with which water is drawn; (TA;) and the like thereof. (K.)
minozaAHN * and manaAziyHu: see naAziHN.

Ant bimunotazaHK mino ka*aA * (tropical:) Thou art far removed from such a thing; (S, K *;) and, by poetic licence, bimunotazaAHK, with A^alif A_i$obaAE. (S.) Ex. A^anota mina Ald~am~i bimunotazaHK (tropical:) Thou art far removed from blame. (A.)

1 nazura * , aor.
nazura , inf. n. nazaArapN (S, A, Msb, K) and nuzuwrN (Msb, K) and nuzuwrapN, (K,) or nuzorapN, as in the M and L, and perhaps one of these last two forms is a mistake for the other, (TA,) It was, or became, little, or small, in quantity or number; (S, A, Msb, K;) paltry, mean, contemptible, or inconsiderable. (S, TA.) See also 5. ― -b2- Also, inf. n. nazaArapN, He (a man) was, or became, possessed of little good, or little wealth. (AZ.) ― -b3- nazarato, inf. n. nazorN, She (a camel) had little milk. (TA.) -A2- nazarahu, aor.
nazura , (TA,) inf. n. nazorN, (K,) He despised, and deemed little, him, or it. (K. * TA.) See also 2. ― -b2- He smote him with the [evil] eye. (Fr, in TA, art. $zr.) -A3- nazarahu, (As, A,) aor.
nazura , (As,) inf. n. nazorN, (As, K,) He drew forth, or got out, what he had, by little and little: (As:) he importuned him, or pressed him, in asking (A, K) a matter of science or a gift. (A.) You say also, fulaAnN laA yuEoTiY Hat~aY yunozara, (A, K,) or ↓ yunaz~ara, (so in two copies of the S,) Such a one will not give until he is importuned, or pressed, (A, K,) and despised. (S, K, TA.)

2 nz~rhu * , inf. n. tanoziyrN; (K;) or ↓ nazarahu, aor.
nazura inf. n. nazorN; (Msb;) He made it little, or small, in quantity; (Msb, K;) namely, a gift; as also ↓ A^anozarahu. (K.) ― -b2- Also nz~rhu He gave him a little, small, paltry, mean, contemptible, or inconsiderable, gift. (TA.) [It seems to be implied in the TA, that ↓ A^anozarahu also has this signification.] -A2- See also 1, last signification.
4 Anzrhu * : see 2, in two places. ― -b2- Also, He (God) caused him to be possessed of little good, or little wealth. (AZ.)

5 tnz~r *
i. q. taqal~ala, (K,) i. e., It became diminished, or rendered little or small in quantity. (TK.) See also nazura. ― -b2- He asserted himself to be related to the tribe of Nizár: (K:) or he made himself like that tribe: or he introduced himself among them, (S, K,) not being one of them. (TA.)

nazorN * , applied to anything, (TA,) little, or small, in quantity or number; (S, A, Msb;) paltry, mean, contemptible, or inconsiderable: (S, TA:) as also ↓ naziyrN (Msb, K) and ↓ nazuwrN (Msb) and ↓ manozuwrN: (K:) or the last signifies little, or small, in quantity, applied to a gift, (S, TA,) and to food; (TA;) or a gift made little, or small, in quantity: (Msb:) and nazorN and ↓ manozuwrN a gift obtained by importunity or pressing: and ↓ gayoru manozuwrN a gift given without its being asked for; without importunity or pressing. (TA.) It is also applied to speech: thus the speech of Mohammad is described as faSolN laA nazorN walaA ha*orN [Distinct;] not little, or scanty, so as to indicate impotence, nor much and corrupt: (K:) or not little nor much. (TA, art. h*r.) ― -b2- A man possessing little, or no, good, or goodness; little, or no, wealth; and so fazorN; as also ↓ manozuwrN. (AZ.) -A2- maA jiy^ota A_il~aA nazorFA Thou hast not come otherwise than slowly, tardily, or late. (K.)
nazirapN * : see nazuwrN.
nizaArN * The quality, in a she-camel, of scarcely ever conceiving except against her will. (TA.)

nazuwrN * Any thing little, or small, in quantity or number. (K.) See also nazorN. ― -b2- A woman having few children; (S, K;) and in like manner applied to a bird; (S, TA;) as also ↓ nazirapN, with kesr to the z, applied to a woman: (K:) pl. of the former, nuzurN: (TA:) or the former epithet signifies having little milk; (K;) applied in this sense to a she-camel. (TA.) A she-camel having wide orifices to her teats. (L, voce ftwH.) ― -b3- Of little speech; that speaks not until importuned, or pressed. (En-Nadr.) ― -b4- A she-camel whose young one has died, and that affects the young one of another, (K,
TA,) but whose milk comes not save scantily. (TA.) ― -b5- A she-camel (TA) that scarcely ever conceives except against her will: (K:) a mare slow to conceive. (L.)
naziyzN * : see nazorN; the latter, in five places.
manozuwrN * : see nazorN; the latter, in five places.

div2.head: nzE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

nasonaAsN * (S, M, Msb, K) and nisonaAsN (K) A kind of creatures (xaloq [an appellation often applied particularly to human beings]) whereof [every] one jumps, or hops, upon one leg: (S, Msb, K:) it is related in a trad., that a tribe of 'Ád disobeyed their apostle, and that God thereupon transformed them into nasonaAs, every man of them having a [single] arm and a [single] leg, [consisting] of one half [of a human being], hopping like as the bird hops, and pasturing like as beasts pasture; (K;) and these are found in the islands of China: (TA:) or, as some say, these have become extinct; (K;) for a transformed being lives not more than three days, as the learned have established; (TA;) and what exist now, of this make, are a distinct class of creatures: (K:) or they are of three kinds; naAsN and nasonaAsN and nasaAnisu; (K;) and the second of these are the baser sort; (TA;) or the nsAns are the females of them, (K,) as Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer says; (TA;) or they are of higher rank than the nsnAs, (K,) as is said in the O: (TA:) or the nsnAs are [the peoples called] Yájooj and Májooj: (IAar, Msb, K:) or a certain people of the sons of Adam: (K:) or certain creatures in the form of men, (M, K,) so called because of the weakness of their make, from nasonasapN, which signifies weakness, (M,) differing from men in some things, and not of them: (K:) or, accord. to what is said [by some], a certain beast, reckoned among wild animals, that is hunted and eaten, having the form of a man with one eye and leg and arm, and that speaks like man: (Kr, M:) or a species of marine animal: (Msb:) or, accord. to El-Mes'oodee, an animal like a man having one eye, that comes forth from the water, and speaks, and, when it gets a man within its power, kills him: or, as is related in the mjAlsp, on the authority of Ibn-Is-hák, certain creatures (xaloqN) in El-Yemen: Abn Alrqys says, that they are of the sons of Sám the son of Sám, brothers of 'Ád and Thamood, not possessing reason, living in the salt-water (AlAjAj) on the coast of the Sea of India: the Arabs hunt them, and speak to them, and they speak the Arabic language, and propagate one with another, and poetize, or versify, and name themselves by the names of the Arabs: (TA:) [in the present day, this appellation is applied to a pigmy: and also, to an ape:] Es-Suyootee says, in the Deewán el-Hayawán, as to the animal which the vulgar call nsnAs, it is a species of apes or monkeys, not living in water, and the eating of which is unlawful: but as to the marine animal, some hold it to be lawful; whereas the sheykh Aboo-Hámid holds the eating of the nsnAs [of any kind] to be unlawful, because it has the form of the sons of Adam. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, *ahaba Aln~aAsu wabaqiYa Aln~asonaAsu [The men have gone, and the nsnAs remain]. Being asked who were the nsnAs, he answered, Those who affect to be like men but are not men. (TA.) [For the verb ns~, &c.: see Supplement.]

1 nasaA^a * , aor.
nasaAa , (S, K,) inf. n. naso'N; (S;) and ↓ ns~A^, (S, K,) inf. n. tanosiy^apN, (S,) He chid (S, K) a camel (S) &c. (L) he urged, or drove, it. (S, K.) ― -b2- nasaA^a, aor.
nasaAa , inf. n. naso'N (S, K) and manosaA^apN (K) [and nasuwo'N, mentioned in the TA, art. wDA^;] and ↓ AnsA^; (S, K;) He postponed, or delayed, a thing. (S, K. Explained in the S, K by A^ax~ara, and in the K by kalaA^a, also, both of which words, accord. to the TA, are syn.) [See an ex. of the use of AnsA, without a final ', in art. Eqb, voce Euqobap.] ― -b3- nasaA^a All~`hu fY A^ajalihi, and All~`hu A^ajalahu ↓ AnsA^, God postponed the end of his life; i. e., prolonged his life: (so in the Fs:) accord. to IKtt, nsA^ All~`hu Ajlh, and fY ↓ AnsA^ Ajlh. (TA.) All of these four modes of expression are allowable: (MF:) as also All~`h ↓ ns~A^ Ajlh: (Z:) and nasaA^ahu All~`h fY Ajlh, and ↓ A^anosaA^ahu All~`h A^ajalahu. (As, S.) ― -b4- A^unosiy^a lahu fiY Eumurihi, His life was prolonged. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b5- nasaA^a AlA_ibila, inf. n. naso'N, He delayed or deferred the watering of the camels; or kept them from water beyond the accustomed time. (L.) ― -b6- nasaA^a fiY Zimo'i AlA_ibili, (S, K,) inf. n. naso'N, (S,) He increased the time between the two drinkings, or waterings, of the camels, by a day: (A:) or by a day, or two days, or more. (A, L, K.) ― -b7- nasaA^a AlA_ibila Eani AlHawoDi He kept back, or put back, or drove back, the camels from the tank, or cistern. (S, L, K. *) ― -b8- maAlahu nasaA^ahu All~`hu What aileth him! May God render him ignominious! (Kr, L,) or put him backward! (L.) Whom he puts backward, He renders ignominious. (L.) ― -b9- nasaA^a, inf. n. naso'N, He sold a thing with postponement of the payment; he sold it upon credit. (TA.) ― -b10- nasaA^ahu AlbayoEa, and AlbyE ↓ AnsA^ahu, He made the sale to him to be on credit. (S, K.) AlmabiyEa ↓ AnsA^ahu He postponed for him the period of the payment of the price of the thing sold. (A.) ― -b11- nasaA^a Eanohu dayonahu, inf. n. nasaA='N; (Akh, S;) and dynh ↓ AnsA^hu, (S, * K,) and Ald~ayona ↓ AnsA^hu; (Akh, S;) He postponed for him the period of the payment of his debt. (S, TA.) ― -b12- nusiy^ato, a verb like EuniYa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in sense,] aor. tunosaA^u, inf. n. naso'N, Her menstrual discharge was later than its usual time, and it was therefore hoped that she was pregnant: (Kh, S, K:) or her menstrual discharge was later than its usual time, and her pregnancy commenced: (TA:) or she began to be pregnant: (As, S:) or she conceived. (As.) -A2- nasaA^a All~abana, (S, K, *) inf. n. naso'N, (TA,) He mixed the milk with water. (S, K. *) ― -b2- nsA^ lahu All~abana, and nsA^hu All~bn, He mixed the milk with water for him. (TA.) ― -b3- nasaA^ahu He gave him to drink naso', q. v.; (K;) i. e. wine, or milk. (TA.) ― -b4- nasaA^ato She (an antelope) licked her young one just after its birth. (K.) -A3- nasaA^a, (S, K,) inf. n. naso'N, (S,) It (a camel, sheep, &c.,) became fat: (TA:) or began to grow fat; when its soft hair (wabar), after falling off, began to grow again. (S, K.)
2 nas~aAa see 1.

4 A^anosaAa see 1. ― -b2- AnsA^hu He granted him a delay of payment, or granted him credit, in a sale, or in the case of a debt. (A.) ― -b3- A^anosaA^otu surobatiY I made my way to lead me far off. (S.) [See art. srb.]
5 tanas~aAa see 8.

8 AntsA^ *
It was postponed, or delayed; syn. taA^ax~ara. (A.) ― -b2- AntsA^ He (a camel, S,) went far off in the pasture. (S, K.) ― -b3- It (a party of people) went far off. (TA.) ― -b4- AntsA^ Eanohu He retired, or withdrew far off, from him or it. (S.) A@notasuwA and tanas~awA occur in two readings of a trad., for A@notasiy^uwA, (which is the correct reading,) in this sense. (TA.) [Hence it appears that ↓ tns~A^, accord. to some, also signifies he retired, &c.]

10 AstnsA^hu *
He asked him to postpone or to grant him a delay in, the payment of his debt. (S, K.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- AstnsA^hu AlbayoEa He asked him to make the sale to be on credit, or for payment at a future period. (A.) ― -b3- AstnsA^ gariymahu He asked his creditor to grant him a delay in the payment of his debt. (A.)

naso'N * and ↓ nuso'N and ↓ niso'N A woman who is supposed to be pregnant; (K;) as also ↓ nasuwo'N (A, K) and ↓ nusuwo'N: (A:) or in whom pregnancy has appeared: (K:) or, naso'N (K) and ↓ nasuwo'N, (TA,) as also ↓ nasiYo'N, accord. to J and IM, but this is rejected by F, (TA,) a woman whose menstrual discharge is later than its usual time, and who is therefore hoped to be pregnant: (S, K:) pl. [of ns'] A^anosaA='N and nusuwo'N: and nisowapN nisaA='N is also said; and sometimes the sing. (naso'N), being originally an inf. n., is used as a pl. (TA.) -A2- naso'N and ↓ nasiYo'N Thin, watery, milk: (K:) or milk mixed with water. (T, S.) [See 1.] ― -b2- Also, both words, (TA,) or the former only; (K, MF;) but ↓ nisiYo'N is quoted in this sense, from IAar, who is said to have pronounced it thus, erroneously, for nasiYo'N; (TA;) Wine;
(IAar;) drink that dispels the reason. (K.) -A3- naso'N Fatness: or its commencement; (K;) its completeness, (consequent upon eating dry food, being called A_iqotiraArN. (S.) ― -b2- jaraY Aln~aso'u fY Ald~awaAb~i, (S,) or maAra, (TA,) [Fatness, or its commencement, ran through the beasts of carriage].

niso'N *
One who mixes, or converses, with others: ex. huwa niso'u nisaA='K He is one who mixes, or converses, with women. (K.) ― -b2- See naso'N.
nuso'N * and nasuwo'N and nusuwo'N and nasiYo'N and nisiYo'N: see naso'N.

nasaA='N *
Length of life. (Akh, S, K.) ― -b2- The Fakeeh of the Arabs [El-Hárith Ibn-Keledeh, as said in the Mz, close of 39th nwE, where the following is quoted,] says, mano sar~ahu Aln~asaA='u walaA nasaA='a faloyuxaf~ifi Alr~idaA='a waloyubaAkiri AlgadaA='a waloyuw^ax~iri AlEa$aA='a waloyuqil~a gi$oyaAna Aln~isaA='i [Let him whom length of life rejoiceth (but there is no long endurance in life) lighten his debts, and make his morning-meal early, and delay his evening-meal, and take little enjoyment in women]: (S, * TA:) AlrdA' here means debt. (T, M, TA, in art. rdY, where this saying is cited with some variations.)

nasiYo'N * , of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (S,) A month which the Arabs, in the time of paganism, postponed: (K:) the doing of which is forbidden in the Kur, ix. 37. (S.) ― -b2- Also, as an inf. n. of nasaA^a, (which it is also said to be in the L,) The postponing of a month: i. e., the postponing of the sacredness of a month; transferring it to another month. When the Arabs returned from Mina, [after the accomplishment of the pilgrimage,] it was customary for a man of the tribe of Kináneh to arise and say, A^anaA Al~a*iY laA yurad~u liY qaDaA='N [“ I am he whose decree is not to be rejected ”]; (S;) or A_in~iY laA A^uHaAbu walaA A^uEaAbu walaA yurad~u qawoliY, or wlA yrd~ maA qaDayotu bihi; [“ Verily I am not to be accused of a sin, nor am I to be charged with a fault, nor is my saying, (or decree,) to be rejected; ”] (TA;) whereupon they would say, A^anosiy^onaA $ahorFA [“ Postpone for us a month ”]; i. e., “ Postpone for us the sacredness of El-Mo- harram, and transfer it to Safar: ” for they disliked that three months during which they might not make predatory expeditions should come upon them consecutively, as their subsistence was obtained by such expeditions: so he made ElMoharram free from restriction to them. (S.) [But this, as appears from what is said in the Kur, ix. 37, was not done every year.] The tribes of Teiyi and Khath'am did not observe the sacred months; therefore the naAsiy^ (or postponer) proclaimed it lawful to slay them therein, when they were aggressors. (TA.) ― -b3- [The term nasiYo' appears also to have been applied to The postponement of the time of the pilgrimage; which was another custom of the Pagan Arabs, mentioned under this word in the TA.] The Arabs, liking that the day of their return from pilgrimage should always be at one season of the year, postponed it every year eleven days; at the same time keeping sacred the two months in which the pilgrimage took place, and the month next after those two, and also the month of Rejeb, at whatever season this fell. (TA.) [For the same purpose, at one time, they used to intercalate a month in the third and sixth and eight of every eight years. See Kur, ix. 36, where the prohibition of this custom is implied; and Sale's Prel. Disc., § vii.]. ― -b4- See naso'N. ― -b5- nasiYo'N (K, TA) and ↓ nasiyoy^apN and ↓ nusoA^apN, (S, K,) like kuloA^apN, (S,) A postponement, or delay, as to the time of the payment of a debt, or of the price of a thing sold, &c. (S, K, TA.) The first is a subst.; (K;) and also an inf. n.; (L;) [and each of the others seems to be sometimes used as such]. ― -b6- ↓ baAEahu binasiyoy^apK, and ↓ binusoA^apK, (as also bikuloA^apK, S,) He sold it on credit; for payment to be made at a future period. (S, K, TA.)

nasiyoy^apN * : see nasiYo'N. ― -b2- Also, A debt of which the payment is deferred by the creditor to a future period. (TA.) ― -b3- A sale upon credit, in which the payment is deferred to a certain, or definite, period. (TA.)

naAsiy^N * , pl. nasaA^apN (S) and naAsiy^uwna, (TA,) One whose office it was to perform the act called nasiYo'; i. e., the postponing of a month: (S, TA:) he was also called qalam~asN, pl. qalaAmisu. (TA.) -A2- naAsiy^N Anything fat: or beginning to grow fat: in the K it is said, kul~u naAsiy^K samiynN: in the L, kl~ smyn nAsy^, which is more proper. (TA.)

manosaA^apN * : see 1. ― -b2- Silapu Alr~aHimi mavoraApN fiY AlmaAli manosaA^apN fiY AlA^avari [Union with kindred is a means of multiplying wealth, a means of prolonging one's memorial]. (TA, from a trad.) -A2- See minosaA^apN.

minosaA^apN * (S, K) and ↓ manosaA^apN, (K,) and also without ', (S, K,) A staff, or stick: so called because a beast is urged or driven with it: (K:) a pastor's great staff. (TA.) For minosaA^atahu, in the Kur, xxxiv. 13, some read mino saA^atihi; i. e. “ from, or of, the end of his staff; ” sA^ap originally signifying the “ bent part at each end of a bow; ” (Fr, TA, &c.;) and being here used tropically. (TA.) This reading is disapproved by the author of the K. but is supported by good authorities. (TA.)

munotasaA^N *
An interval; a distance; a space. (S.) A_in~a liY Eanoka lamunotasaA^N Verily I am far from thee. (S.)

1 nasabahu * , aor.
nasuba , (S, K,) inf. n. nasobN and nisobapN; (S;) and aor.
nasiba , inf. n. nasabN and nisobapN; (K, TA;) He mentioned his [i. e. another's] relationship, [lineage, or genealogy]; (S, K;) saying, He is such a one, the son of such a one; or He is of such a tribe, or city; or of such an art, or such a trade; and the like. (Lb. T.) ― -b2- nasabahu, aor.
nasuba , inf. n. nasobN, He traced up his [i. e. another's] lineage to his greatest ancestor. (TA.) ― -b3- nasabahu, [aor.
nasuba ?,] He asked him to mention, or tell him, his relationship, [lineage, or genealogy]. (K.) ― -b4- A_ilayohi ↓ jalasotu A_ilayohi fanasabaniY qaA@notasabotu (tropical:) [I sat by him, and he asked me to tell him my lineage; so I mentioned my lineage to him]. (A.) ― -b5- lahaA ↓ nasabatonaA faA@notasabonaA [She asked us to tell her our lineage; so we mentioned our lineage to her]. (IAar, from a trad.) ― -b6- nasabahu AlY fulaAnK He asserted him to be related to such a one: and he referred his lineage, or origin, to such a one. ― -b7- He referred the origin or derivation of his name to such a one. ― -b8- He attributed, or ascribed, it to such a one. See, for ex. Sad~aqa and ka*~aba in the Msb. ― -b9- nasabahu A_ilaY ka*aA (tropical:) He referred its origin, or the origin or derivation of its name, to such a thing. ― -b10- He attributed, or ascribed, it to such a thing. ― -b11- ] nasabahu A_ilaY fulaAnK He named him, or called him, in relation, or reference, to such a one; meaning an ancestor: and in like manner, in relation, or reference, to a tribe, a town or district, an art or trade, &c. See nisobapN. ― -b12- nasabahu A_laY k*aA (tropical:) He named it, or called it, in relation, or reference, to such a thing. ― -b13- nasaba A_ilayohi ka*aA, and, by inversion, nasabahu A_ilaY ka*aA, (see S and K, in art. jhl, &c.) (tropical:) He attributed or imputed to him, or charged him with, or accused him of, such a thing; namely, a fault &c. Both phrases are often used as signifying thus by classical writers, and in the present day.] ― -b14- nasaba biAlomaroA^api, (S, K,) aor.
nasiba , (S,) and
nasuba , (L,) inf. n. nasiybN (S, K) and nasabN and manosabapN, (K,) i. q. $ab~aba bihaA; q. v.; (S, K;) He mentioned the woman in an amatory manner, in the beginning [or prelude] of a poem: (TA, voce $b~b:) he mentioned the woman in amatory language, in the beginning of a qaSiydap, and then turned to the object of praise: [for it is a general rule to commence a qSydp in praise of a king, or hero, or the like, with nsyb; the transition from this is termed Alt~axal~uSu: see also AiqotaDaba:] (IKh:) he mentioned the woman in his poem, describing her as characterized by beauty and youth &c.: (Lb:) or describing her as characterized by good qualities, whether truly or falsely. (Z.) This phrase and nasaba Alr~ajula both signify description; the latter signifying “ he described the man with relation to his father, or his city or country, or
the like; ” and the former phrase, he described the woman as characterized by beauty and youth and love or affection &c. (IDrst.) nasiybN is also employed to signify the describing of the places where the objects of love have taken up their abode in the season of the rabiyE and at other times, and the lover's longing to meet them and be united with them, and what else is comprised in the signification of the words ta$obiybN and gazalN. (MF.) [See gazila, and gazalN.]

3 nAsbhu *
He shared with him in relationship. (TA.) ― -b2- fulaAnN yunaAsibu fulaAnFA Such a one is related to, or a relation of, such a one. (S.) ― -b3- nAsbh, inf. n. munaAsabapN, (tropical:) He, or it, bore relation to, resembled, was similar to, conformable to, analogous to, correspondent to, suitable to, befitted, him or it. (S, K, Msb.) See also nisobapN.

4 Ansbti Alr~iyHu *
The wind was violent, and drove along the dust and pebbles: (K:) [as also An$bt].

5 tns~b *
He asserted himself to be a relation, or kinsman, or to be related, [A_ilayoka] to thee. Hence the proverb, Alqariybu mano taqar~aba laA mano tanas~aba: (S, K:) i. e. He is [indeed] an ally who allies himself by affection and friendship: not he who asserts himself to be a kinsman. (TA.)

6 tnAsbwA * (tropical:) They were mutually, or reciprocally, related; resembled one another; were similar, conformable, analogous, correspondent, or suitable, one to another; befitted one another. (TA.) See also nisobapN. ― -b2- [And tnAsb It was suitable in its parts, proportionate, symmetrical, or uniform.]

8 A_inotasaba See 10 and 1. ― -b2- Antsb A_ilaY A^abiyhi He asserted his relationship to his father, whether truly or falsely; (S;) [saying, I am the son of such a one: as was generally done by a champion when he sallied forth to challenge]. ― -b3- Antsb A_ilayohi It (a voice) was attributed, or ascribed, to him. (TA, art. gnv.)

10 Astnsb * (K) and ↓ Antsb (TA) He mentioned his [i. e. his own] relationship, [lineage, or genealogy]. (K.) One says to a man, in asking him respecting his relationship, &c., A_isotanosibo lanaA A^aYo A_inotasibo lanaA Hat~aY naEorifaka [Mention thy relationship, or lineage, to us, that we may know thee]. (AZ.)
Q. Q. 1 nayosaba bayonahumaA * , inf. n. nayosabapN, He went to and fro between them two with malicious and mischievous misrepresentations, calumnies, or slanders, &c. (L, K.)
nasobN * : see nasabN.

nasabN * and ↓ nisobahN and ↓ nusoyapN (S, K) Relationship; relation; kindred; consanguinity; [family; race; lineage; parentage; pedigree; genealogy; origin; reputed relationship or lineage or origin;] (K;) with respect to father and mother; (ISk;) or with respect to fathers only: (K:) pl. of the first, A^anosaAbN; (S;) of the ↓ second, nisabN; and of the ↓ third, nusabN. (Msb.) The first, by poetical license, is contracted into ↓ nasobN. (T.) [You say,] bayonahumaA nasabN Between them is relationship; said whether they may lawfully marry one another, or not. (Msb.) See nasiybN.

nisobapN * (tropical:) Relation; proportion; comparison; with respect to quantity, or measure, and the like. See nasabN. ― -b2- binisobapi ka*aA In proportion to such a thing. ― -b3- nisobapu AlEa$arapi A_ilaY AlmiAy^api The proportion of ten to a hundred is [that of a tenth]. (Msb.) ― -b4- [You also say biAln~isobapi A_ilaY ka*aA In relation to, or in comparison with, such a thing.] ― -b5- nisobapN A name of relation to a father, mother, tribe, town or district, art or trade, &c.: [as EalawiY~N, faATimiY~N, qura$iY~N, mak~iY~N, jawohariY~N:] ending with Y~. A more general name of this kind should precede a more particular one: thus you say Alqura$iY~u AlhaA$imiY~u: and it is better that a name of relation to a tribe should precede one of relation to a town or the like: thus you say Alqura$iY~u Almak~iY~u. It is said that the Arabs originally called themselves by such names only in relation to tribes; and that, when they took up their abodes in cultivated lands and in cities, they borrowed names of relation to towns and the like from the Persians and Copts. (Msb.) ― -b6- nisobapN (TA) and ↓ munaAsabapN (S, K) and ↓ tanaAsubN (TA) (tropical:) Resemblance; similarity; conformity; analogy; correspondence; suitableness; fitness. (S, K, TA.) Ex. bayona Al$~ayoy^ayoni nsbpN, and ↓ mnAsbpN, and ↓ tnAsbN, Between the two things is a resemblance, &c. bayonahumaA nsbpN qariybapN. Between them two is a near resemblance, &c. (TA.) [nisobapN Hukomiy~apN The relation of a predicate to its subject (in books on logic).]
nusobapN * : see nasabN.

nasiybN *
i. q. ↓ munaAsibN, [A sharer in relationship; one who becomes a sharer in relationship by marriage]: (K:) pl. nusabaA'u and A^anosibaA'u.) (TA.) ― -b2- nasiybN (S, K) and ↓ manosuwbN (K) One related; a relation; a kinsman. (S, K, TA.) You say fulaAnN nasiybiY [Such a one is my relation]: and humo A^anosibaAy^iY [They are my relations]. (TA.) ↓ nasabN, also, is used for *uw nasabK [A relation, or kinsman]; and means a male, or female, relation; (Jel, xxv. 56;) and for *awuw nasabK [relations, or kinsmen]. (Bd, ibid.) [See also SihorN.] ― -b3- nasiybN and ↓ manosuwbN A man of rank, or quality, or the like, and of family, or lineage. (TA.) ― -b4- ↓ nasiybN naAsbN [An elegant amatory mentioning of a woman, or of women, in the beginning of a poem] is a phrase like $aEorN $aAEirN. (K.) See A^anosabu.

nas~aAbN * (K) and ↓ nas~aAbapN (S, K.) Skilful in genealogy: (K:) [or rather, the former signifies very skilful in genealogies; or a great genealogist:] the latter, possessing the utmost knowledge in genealogies; or a most skilful genealogist: [this being of a doubly intensive form;] the p being annexed to render the epithet one of excessive praise: (S:) pl. of the former nas~aAbuwna, and of the latter nas~aAbaAtN: (TA:) you say EinodiY valaAvapu ns~AbAtK, meaning vlAvp rijaAlK ns~AbAtK. (S.)
nas~aAbapN * : see nas~aAbN.
naAsibN * : see nasiybN.

nayosabN *
A straight, or direct, and conspicuous, or open, road, or way: (K:) or narrow road, or way: (TA:) as also ↓ nayosabaAnN: (K:) some say nayosamN, which is a dial. form: (TA:) or nysb signifies the traces of a road, or way. (K.) ― -b2- Also nayosabN Ants that appear like a road; (S;) ants following one another uninterruptedly. (K.) Dukeyn Ibn-Rejà says,
EayonFA taraY Aln~aAsa A_ilayohaA nayosabaA
[A source to which thou seest the people (repairing like) ants proceeding in uninterrupted succession]. (S.) ― -b3- Also, the track of ants, (ISd, K,) and of a serpent, and of wild asses going to their watering-places. (TA.)
nayosabaAnN * : see nayosabN.

h`*aA Al$~iEoru A^anosabu *
This poetry is more, or most. elegant in what is termed nasiyb. see 2: (K:) as though they had said nasiybN naAsibN, like $iEorN $aAEirN, to give intensiveness to the signification, and thence formed the word A^anosabu. (TA.)

xaT~N manosuwbN * [A] regular [hand-writing]: syn. *uw qaAEidapK: (TA:) [properly, named in relation to its author &c.] ― -b2- $iEorN manosuwbN Poetry, or a poem, in which is nasiyb, [or an amatory mention of a woman, or women, in its beginning]: pl. manaAsiybu. (K.) See nasiybN.
munaAsibN * : see nasiybN.
munaAsabapN * and tanaAsubN: see nisobapN.

1 nasaja * , aor.
nasija , inf. n. nasojN, He, or it, drew, collected, or gathered, together a thing: drew and joined, or adjoined, one thing to another. This is the primary signification. (L.) ― -b2- nasajati
Alr~iyHu Alwaraqa wAlha$iyma The wind gathered together the leaves and the dry fragments of plants. Hence, accord. to some, nasaja Alv~awoba, because the weaver adjoins the warp to the woof. (TA.) ― -b3- nasajati Alr~iyHu Alt~uraAba (tropical:) The wind drew the dust together. (TA.) ― -b4- nasajati Alr~iyHu AlmaA='a, and Alr~amola, and Alt~uraAba, and rasoma Ald~aAri, (tropical:) The wind made rippling lines, in cross directions, upon the water, and the sand, and the dust, and [with dust] upon the traces of the dwelling. (A.) [And so] TaraAy^iqu kaA@loHubuki ↓ A_inotasajato (tropical:) Rippling lines were made, in cross directions, by the wind, upon the water, (S, * A,) and the sand, and the dust, and the traces of the dwelling. (A.) ― -b5- nasajati Alr~iyHu Alr~aboEa (tropical:) The wind, blowing in cross directions, obliterated the traces of the place where persons had alighted, (S, K,) [by covering it with dust or sand in such a manner as that it might be likened to a web]. ― -b6- nasaja (tropical:) It (a spider) wove, or spun, its web. (A.) ― -b7- nasaja Alv~awoba, aor.
nasija , and
nasuja , (S, K,) inf. n. nasojN, (S,) He wove the piece of cloth, or the garment. (TA, &c.) And nasaja sayorFA He plaited a thong. (TA, in art. nsE.) ― -b8- nasaja Al$~iEora (tropical:) He wove, or composed verses. (TA.) ― -b9- nasaja AlkalaAma (tropical:) He (a liar, TA,) forged speech. (K.) ― -b10- Also, (tropical:) He explained, or expounded, language; syn. lax~aSahu. (K.) ― -b11- nasajati Aln~aAqapu fiY sayorihaA (tropical:) The she-camel moved her legs quickly in going along. (TA.)

8 Antsj *
It became drawn, collected, or gathered, together: became drawn and joined, or adjoined, to another thing. (L.) See 1. ― -b2- Antsj It (a piece of cloth, or a garment,) became woven. (TA.)
nasoju AlEanokabuwti * (tropical:) The spider's web. (A.) ― -b2- See nasyjN.

nusujN *
Prayer-carpets; carpets upon which prayer is performed; syn. saj~aAdaAtN. (IAar, Th, K.)

nasuwjN * (tropical:) A she-camel that moves her legs quickly in going along: (TA:) or a she-camel whose load that she carries does not shake about: (K:) so in all the copies of the K; but accord. to more than one of the leading lexicologists, a she-camel whose load, and saddle, are unsteady upon her, and shaking about: (TA:) and a she-camel that makes her load to shift forward to her kaAhil, [or the part of the back next the neck,] by reason of the vehemence of her pace. (ISh, K.)

nasiyjN * and ↓ nasojN [the latter originally an inf. n.] i. q. manosuwjN, Woven. (Msb, TA.) [And hence both, as substs., signify A web.] So ↓ nasiyjapN a web, a thing woven. (S, K. art. Trq.) ― -b2- huwa nasiyju waHodihi (an indeterminate expression, Hishám and Fr, in L, art. wHd, q. v.,) (tropical:) He is unequalled, unique, or an only one of his kind, in knowledge &c.: for when a garment, or piece of cloth, is of a high quality, no other is woven of exactly the same kind. (S, K, &c.) It is only said in praise of a person. (TA.) [Opposed to Euyayoru waHodihi.] ― -b3- Alyamani ↓ vawobN nasoju A garment, or piece of cloth, the texture of El-Yemen. (Msb.) ― -b4- Algayovi ↓ nasoju (tropical:) [The texture of the rain]; meaning the plants, or herbage. (TA.)

nasaAjapN *
A kind of miloHafap, with which a person envelops himself. App. thus called by what is originally an inf. n. (L, from a trad.).
nisaAjapN * The art of weaving. (S, K.)
nasiyjapN * : see nasiyjN.

nas~aAjN * [in some copies of the K, ↓ naAsijN, the act. part. n. of nasaja,] A weaver. (K.) ― -b2- nas~aAjN also, A manufacturer of coats of mail. (K) ― -b3- nas~aAjN also, (tropical:) A liar; (K;) a forger of lies. (TA.)
naAsijN * : see nas~aAjN.
manosijN * and manosaxN A place where the art of weaving is practised. (S, K.) ― -b2- See minosajN.

minosajN * (S, K) and minosijN (TA) [A weaver's loom;] the apparatus upon which the web is stretched to be woven; (S, K;) the wood and apparatus used in the art of weaving, upon which the web is stretched to be woven: (M:) or, specially, the Haf~; (TA;) i. e. the stay of a weaver's loom; syn. Haf~N: (TK:) [in the present day, applied to a frame for weaving: and to one for embroidering]. ― -b2- minosajN (S, K,) and ↓ manosijN (TA) [The wither of a horse: or the lower part thereof: or the part below the withers:] the prominent part from the branches of the shoulder-blades to the lower part of the neck and to the even part of the back; as also HaArikN: behind it is the kaAhil: (A'Obeyd:) or in a horse, the same as the kAhl in a man, and the HArk in a camel: (TA:) or the part of a horse below the HArk [which latter is the withers, or the upper part thereof]: (S, K:) or the swelling part of the kaAvibap [or withers] of a beast, at the place where the mane terminates, beneath the pommel of the saddle: (T:) said to be so called because the sinews of the neck extend towards the back, and those of the back towards the neck, and are woven together upon the shoulder-blades: (TA:) or the extremity of the mane: (A:) or the part between the mane and the place where the shoulder-blades unite: pl. manaAsiju. (TA.)

1 nasaHa * , aor.
nasaHa , (inf. n. nasoHN, S,) He dispersed and removed dust; syn. A^a*oraY. (K, and some copies of the S.) -A2- nasiHa, aor.
nasaHa , (inf. n. nasaHN, S,) He coveted; syn. TamiEa. (K, and some copies of the S.)

minosaAHN *
A thing with which dust is dispersed and removed. (K.)

1 nasaxa * , aor.
nasaxa , (L, K,) inf. n. nasoxN; and ↓ Antsx; (L;) He, or it, annulled, superseded, obliterated, effaced, or cancelled, (L, K,) a thing, bi$aYo'K A=xara by another thing. (L.) It annulled, or superseded, a thing, and took the place of it. (L.) Ex. nasaxati Al$~amosu AlZ~ila, and ↓ Antsxth, (tropical:) The sun annulled, or superseded, the shade, (S, L,) and took the place of it. (L.) nasaxa Al$~ayobu Al$~abaAba (tropical:) Hoariness took the place of youth. (A, Msb.) Also, nasaxa He annulled, superseded, abolished, or made void, a thing, substituting for it another thing. (K.) Ex. nasaxa A=yapF He (God) abrogated, annulled, or superseded, the verse of the Kur-án, (Lth, Fr, S, L,) substituting for it another; (Lth, Fr, L;) biA@loA=yapi by the [i. e. another] verse: (S:) or he changed it by substituting for it another: nasaxa signifying he changed a thing by substituting for it another thing. (IAar, L.) [See also 4.] Legal nasox, or abrogation, may respect the letter and the force of command, or one of these; whether the command have been performed, as is generally the case, or have not been performed, as in the case of the sacrifice of Ishmael, [or, as some of the Muslims say, agreeably with the Bible narrative, Isaac,] for Abraham was commanded to sacrifice him, and then the command was abrogated before its execution. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, nasaxa He, or it, changed, or altered, a thing. (K.) Ex. nasaxati Alr~iyHu A=vaAra Ald~aAri The wind changed, or altered, [or, it may also be rendered, obliterated, or effaced,] the traces of the dwelling. (S.) ― -b3- nasaxahu He transformed him, or metamorphosed him, into a worse, or more foul, or more ugly, shape; i. q. masaxahu: (K:) ex. nasaxahu A@ll~`hu qirodFA God transformed him into an ape. (Fr, Aboo-Sa'eed.) ― -b4- [Also, as used in post-classical, and perhaps in classical, times, He (God) caused his soul to pass into the body of another man.] The connexion of the soul of a human being, after its departure from the body, with the body of another human being, is termed nasoxN; with the body of
a beast, masoxN; with a plant, fasoxN; and with an inanimate and not-increasing body, rasoxN. (Marginal note in a copy of the KT.) [But see 1 (last sentence) in art. fsx. See also 6.] ― -b5- nasaxa He transferred a thing from one place to another, it remaining the same: (TA:) he transferred what was in a bee-hive to another [hive or place]. (K.) ― -b6- nasaxa AlkitaAba, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
nasaxa , inf. n. nasoxN; (Msb;) and ↓ Antsxhu, (S, Msb, K,) and Astnsxhu; (S, K;) are syn., (S,) signifying He copied, or transcribed, the writing, or book, (T, Msb, K,) letter for letter. (T.) ― -b7- maA nasaxahu waA_in~amaA masaxahu [He has not copied it, but only corrupted it by changing the diacritical points and altering the meanings]. (A.) ― -b8- ↓ nasotanosixu, in the Kur, xlv. 28, signifies We set down, or register, and preserve: (Jel:) or We command to be transcribed and to be set down, or registered. (T.)
3 naAosaxa see 6.

4 Ansx *
He (God) made a verse of the Kur-án to be abrogated, annulled, or superseded, by another verse: (Z, MF:) or found it to be so; like A^aHomadahu “ he found him, or it, to be praised, or praiseworthy. ” (AAF.) In the Kur, ii. 100, Ibn-'Ámir reads maA nunosixo for mA nanosaxo. (TA.) [See also 1.]

6 tnAsxt AlA^a$oyaA='u *
The things succeeded one another, one taking the place of another. (L.) ― -b2- tnAsxt Alquruwnu, (A, Msb,) and AlA^azominapu, (Msb, K,) (tropical:) The times succeeded, one in the place of another; (Msb, K;) one passing away after another. (K.) ― -b3- tnAsxt Alwaravapu, (tropical:) [The heirs died, one after another, and so cancelled their rights to inheritance]. (A.) tanaAsuxN (S, K) and ↓ manaAsuxapN (K) in the case of an inheritance, (S, K,) or with respect to the fixed primary portions of an inheritance assigned by the Kur-án, is The dying of heirs after other heirs while the original inheritance remains undivided. (S, K.) ― -b4- tnAsx It became changed from one state to another. (L.) ― -b5- tnAsxt AlA^arowaAHu (tropical:) [The souls transmigrated]. (MF.) tanaAsuxN, [The transmigration of the soul from one human body to another, is thus explained;] the connexion of the soul with the body after its separation from another body, without the intervention (taxal~ul) of any time between the two connexions, by reason of the essential love subsisting between the soul and the body. (KT; in some copies of which tHl~l is put for txl~l.) [See also 1.]

nusoxapN *
A copy, or transcript: (S, L, Msb, K:) so called because it supplies the place of the original: (L:) pl. nusaxN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, A copy, or an original, from which a transcript is made: (L:) [pl. as above].
nusaxiy~apN * : see nasiyxapN.
balodapN nasiyxapN * , and ↓ nusaxiy~apN, A distant town, or district, or country. (K.) ― -b2- [A transverse or cross wind. See nay~iHap in art. nwH.]

naAsixN * and ↓ munotasixN A copier, or transcriber, of a writing or writings, or of a book or books. (L.) ― -b2- A=yapN naAsixapN A verse of the Kur-án that abrogates, annuls, or supersedes, another verse. (S.) [See 1.] [And so,] ↓ A=yapN manosuwxapN A verse of the Kur-án that is abrogated, annulled, or superseded, by another verse. (S.) ― -b3- [naAsixN An epithet applied to a particle, (namely, A_in~a and the like, and maA and lA,) or a verb, (namely, the abstract kaAn and the like, and kaAda and the like, and Zan~a and the like,) which effects a change of the grammatical form, or of the meaning, in a nominal proposition before which it is placed. Alxuruwfu AlnAsixapu liloA_ibotidaA='i The particles which annul the quality of the inchoative.]
Alt~anaAsuxiy~apu * (K) (tropical:) The sect which holds the doctrine of tanaAsuxu AlA^arowaAHi [or the transmigration of souls], and denies the resurrection. (MF.)
manosuwxN * and ↓ munotasaxN A writing, or book, copied, or transcribed. (Msb.) ― -b2- See naAsixN.
munotasaxN * : see manosuwxN.
munotasixN * : see naAsixN.

1 nasara * , aor.
nasura (S, M, K) and
nasira , (M, K,) inf. n. nasorN, (S, M, K,) He (a bird, M, K, or a hawk or falcon, S, [or other bird, see nasorN below,]) plucked flesh (S, M, K) with his beak. (S, TA.) You say also, nasarahu biminosarihi, meaning, He (a hawk or falcon [or other bird]) plucked his flesh with his beak. (A.) -A2- [Hence,] nasarahu (tropical:) He blamed him; found fault with him; spoke evil of him behind his back, or in his absence, saying of him what would grieve him if he heard it. (A.)

10 Astnsr *
He (the bagaAv [or ignoble bird, or most ignoble of birds,] S, M) became a nasor [or vulture]: (M:) or became like the nasor (S, K) in strength. (K.) Hence the proverb, A_in~a AlbagaAva biA^aroDinaA yasotanosiru [Verily the most ignoble bird, or most ignoble birds, in our land becomes like the vulture, or become like vultures]: (S, M:) meaning, the weak among us becomes strong. (S.) See also art. bgv.

nasorN * (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and sometimes ↓ nisorN [agreeably with the modern general pronunciation] and ↓ nusorN, (Sheykh-el-Islám Zekereeyà, in his Comm. on the Expos. of Bd,) but this is very strange, (MF,) [The vulture; app. any vulture, whatever be its species or variety, known to the Arabs, except the raxam, or aquiline vulture; and said to be applied by some of the Arabs to the eagle; (see also nusaAriy~apN;) agreeing with the Hebrew נֶשֶׁר, which is plainly applied to the former bird in Micah, i. 16, and probably in other instances;] a certain bird, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) well known; (A, Msb;) so called because it plucks (yanosuiru) a thing, and swallows it, (A, and so in some copies of the K,) or, and pulls it out (so in some copies of the K,) or, and chases and captures it; (so in some copies of the K; the various readings being wayabotaliEuhu and wayaqotaliEuhu and wayaqotaniSuhu;) it is said that it has no mixolab [or talon], but only the Zufor [or nail], like that of the domestic cock and hen, and of the crow and the like, and of the raxamap [or aquiline vulture]: (S:) the bird called in Persian karoka$o, which eats carcases until it is unable to fly, and is said to live a thousand years: (Kzw:) AHn asserts, that the nsr is a bird of the description called EitaAq; [which is a term applied to birds of prey, and to noble birds, (in a sense wider than that in which this appellation is used in English falconry,) and especially to eagles;] but [ISd says] I know not how that is: (M:) pl. (of pauc., S) A^anosurN and (of mult., S) nusuwrN. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Aln~asoru AlwaAqiEu (assumed tropical:) [The Falling, or Alighting, Vulture,] and Aln~asoru AlT~aAy^iru (assumed tropical:) [The Flying Vulture,] are two stars or asterisms, (S, * M, A, Msb, K,) well-known, (M,) which together are called Aln~asoraAni [the Two Vultures], (M, A,) and each of which alone is called Aln~asoru (M, Msb, K) and nasorN; (M;) being likened to the bird so named: (M:) the former is the bright star [a] in the constellation Al$~aloyaAqu [or Lyra] likened by the Arabs to a vulture (nsr) that has contracted its wings to itself, as though it had alighted upon something: and the latter consists of the three well-known stars [a and b and g] in the constellation AlEuqaAbu [or Aquila]: (Kzw:) [The former rose heliacally, about the epoch of the Flight, in central Arabia, on the 25th of November, O. S., with the Eighteenth Mansion of the Moon, which is a of Scorpio; and the latter, on the 28th of December, O. S.: and both set, together, anti-heliacally, at that period and in that part, on the 24th of July, O. S. See nawo'N, and dabuwrN.] -A2- nasorN (S, M, Msb) and Aln~asoru, (S, M, K,) the latter occurring in a verse cited in art. Ez, (S,) A certain idol, (S, M, Msb, K,) belonging to Dhu-l-Kelaa, (S, Msb, K,) in the land of Himyer, (S, K,) as yaguwvu did to Medhhij, and yaEuwqu to Hemdán, of the idols of the people of Noah, (S,) all of which are mentioned in the Kur, lxxii. 22 and 23: (S, M:) or a certain good man, who lived between Adam and Noah, and of whom, after his death, was made an image, which, after a long time, became an object of worship; like wad~N and suwaAEN and yaguwvu, and yaEuwqu, mentioned therewith in the Kur,
ubi supra. (Bd.) -A3- Also, nasorN [The frog, or frush, of the hoof of a horse or ass or mule; thus called in the present day;] a portion of tough flesh, [or rather a horny substance,] in the bTon [or sole] of the solid hoof, as though it were a datestone, [which it resembles in substance,] or a pebble: (S:) or the flesh of the solid hoof, which the poets liken to date-stones: (T:) or a portion of flesh, (K,) or of hard flesh, (M,) in the baATin [or sole, or inner part,] of the solid hoof, (M, K, TA,) as though it were a pebble, or a date-stone, (TA:) or what rises in the bATn of the hoof of the horse, from, or of, the upper part thereof: (M, K:) or the bATn itself of the solid hoof: (M:) pl. nusuwrN, (M, K,) which Aboo-Sa'eed explains as signifying the prominences in the baTon [or sole] of the solid hoof, which are likened to date-stones because of their hardness, and which do not touch the ground. (TA.) Hence the saying, HaAfirN Sulobu Aln~usuwri [A solid hoof hard in the frog: the sing. and pl. being used indiscriminately]. (TA.)
nusorN * : see nasorN, first signification.
nisorN * : see nasorN, first signification.

nisoriynN * [The wild rose, dog-rose, eglantine, or sweet brier: so in the present day: and, accord. to Spreng., Hist. Rei Herb., cited by Freytag, the jonquil:] a well-known rose; (K;) a well-known sweet-smelling flower; (Msb;) a species of sweetsmelling flower; (M;) a Persian word, (M, Msb,) arabicized: (Msb:) of the measure fiEoliyl; and, if so, the [final] n is radical: or of the measure fiEliynN; and if so, that letter is augmentative: Az says, I know not whether it be Arabic or not. (Msb.)
nusaAriy~apN * The eagle; syn. EuqaAbN: (IAar, K:) likened to the nasor. (IAar, TA.) [Hence it appears that, accord. to IAar, the nasor is not the eagle.]

naAsuwrN * (also written with S, S, Msb,) A certain disease that happens in the inner angles of the eyes, (S, Msb, K,) with an incessant defluxion therefrom: (S, TA:) and sometimes it happens also in the part around the anus: and in the gum: (S, Msb:) or it signifies also a certain disease in the part around the anus: and a certain disease in the gum: (K:) and is an arabicized word [from the Persian]: (S, Msb:) nawaASiyr, pl. of naASuwrN, accord. to certain of the physicians, is a term applied to deep ulcers in the anus, at the extremity of the gut. (Msb, art. nSr.) ― -b2- Also, A vein constantly becoming recrudescent, (EiroqN gabirN,) with an incessant defluxion; (S, K;) corrupt within; whenever its upper part heals, breaking forth again with corruption. (TA.) See also garobN.

minosarN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ manosirN, (Msb, K,) or the former only, (AZ,) The beak of a bird (S, A, Msb, K) of prey; (S, Msb;) or of a hawk or falcon; (A;) that of any other bird being called minoqaArN. (S, Msb.) -A2- [Hence,] ↓ both words also signify (assumed tropical:) A portion of an army that goes before the main army: (S, K:) [likened to the beak of a bird of prey; as the side bodies are likened to the wings:] and a troop of horse or horsemen in number from thirty to forty: or from forty to fifty: or from forty to sixty: (M, K:) or from a hundred to two hundred: (M, Msb, K:) or a troop of horse or horsemen: (El-Farábee, Msb:) or an army that does not pass by anything without snatching it away. (Msb.)
manosirN * : see minosarN, throughout.

div2.head: nsT &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 na$~a * , aor.
na$i3a , (A, TA,) inf. n. na$iy$N (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and na$~N, (TA,) It (said of water, S, Mgh, Msb, K, and of other things, S, K, such as wine, and flesh-meat, TA) made a sound in boiling, estuating, or fermenting: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and it (anything) made a sound like that of boiling, estuating, or fermenting; or of beginning to do so: and it (water) made a sound in pouring forth. (TA.) You say also, na$~ati Alqidoru, (TA,) inf. n. na$iy$N; (IDrd, K;) and ↓ na$ona$at, (TA,) inf. n. na$ona$apN; (IDrd, K;) The cooking-pot made a sound in boiling: (IDrd, K:) or began to boil, and so made a sound. (TA.) And na$~a AlmaA'u fiY kuwzK jadiydK [The water made a sound in a new earthen mug]: (A:) or na$~a Alkuwzu Aljadiydu fiY AlmaA='i The new [earthen] mug made a sound in the water. (Mgh.) And Ald~iroEu ↓ na$ona$a The coat of mail made a sound, (K,) or clinking. (Fr.) ― -b2- Also, It (wine, A, Mgh, or the beverage called nabiy*, TA,) estuated, or fermented: (A, Mgh, TA:) or na$iy$N signifies the beginning to estuate, or ferment, of the first of expressed juice [of grapes or dates &c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- na$~ati All~aHomapu, inf. n. na$~N, The piece of flesh-meat dripped. (Sh, from certain of the Kilábees.) -A2- Also na$~a, aor.
na$i3a , inf. n. na$iy$N (S, K) and na$~N, (TA,) said of a pool of water left by a torrent, Its water began to sink into the earth: (S, K:) or its water dried up, and sank into the earth. (TA.) It (water upon the surface of the ground) dried up. (TA.) It (a full-grown unripe date) lost its moisture. (TA.) -A3- na$~a Ald~uhona bAlr~ayoHaAni [aor., app.,
na$u3a ,] He infused the oil, or other ointment, with perfume, by boiling it with sweet-smelling plants until it made a sound in boiling. (TA.) [See also saliyxapN.] -A4- na$~a Al*~ubaAba [aor., accord. to analogy,
na$u3a , but vulgarly, in the present day,
na$i3a ,] He drove [or whisked] a way the flies. (TA.)
R. Q. 1 na$ona$a * , see 1. in two places. See also $ino$inapN.

na$~N * The half of an A^uwqiy~ap [or ounce]; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. e., twenty dirhems; (S, Msb, K;) the Awqy~p being forty dirhems; (S, Msb;) and five dirhems being called nawaApN: (S:) or the weight of a date-stone (nwAp) of gold: or the weight of five dirhems: or the quarter of an Awqy~p: (TA:) and the half of anything; (IAar, Sh, Az, Mgh, Msb;) as, for instance, of a dirhem, and of a cake of bread. (IAar, Sh, Az, Mgh.)
na$aA$apN * : see na$~aA$apN.
A^aroDN na$iy$apN * and ↓ na$onaA$apN Salt land that produces no herbage. (IDrd, K.)

sabaHapN na$~aA$apN * , (S, A, K,) and ↓ na$aA$apN, (Az, TA,) A tract of salt land of which the moisture [or, as in a copy of the A, the earth,] does not dry up, nor its pasture, or herbage, grow: (A, K:) or what appears of the water of salt lands, and begins to sink therein, so that it becomes salt. (S.)
na$onaA$apN * : see na$iy$apN.

mana$~u Als~aAHili *
The part of the shore of a sea or great river from which the water has retired. (A.)
mina$~apN * [A fly-whisk;] a thing with which the flies are driven a way. (TA.)

duhonN mano$uw$N *
Oil, or other ointment, infused with perfume, (K, TA,) by boiling it with sweetsmelling plants until it makes a sound in boiling. (TA) [See also saliyxapN.]

1 na$aA^a * , aor.
na$aAa ; and na$uw^a, aor.
na$uAa ; inf. n. na$o'N and nu$uwo'N and na$aA='N and na$oA^apN and na$aA='apN; He lived; (K;) and (accord. to Sh) he rose, or became elevated, or high. (TA.) ― -b2- [It rose.] ― -b3- Aln~a$oA^apu AlA^uxoraY, or Aln~a$aA='apu, [Kur, liii. 48,] The resurrection: [lit., the other life]. (TA.) ― -b4- Aln~a$oA^apu AlA=xirapu, or Aln~a$aA='apu, [Kur, xxix. 19, the same: lit., the latter life]. (TA.) [See also na$oA^apN below.] ― -b5- na$aA^a, (S, K,) inf. n. na$o'N and na$aA='N (TA) and nu$uwo'N; (S;) He grew up, (K,) and became a youth, or young man. (S, K.) [See naA$iy^N.] ― -b6- na$aA^otu fiY baniY fulaAnK, (S,) and mano$ay^iY fY bnY flAn, (TA.) I grew up, and became a young man, among the sons of such a one. (S, TA.) ― -b7- na$aA^a, (S, K,) inf. n. na$o'N and nu$uwo'N, (TA,) It (a cloud) rose, (S, K,) and appeared: said of its first begin-
ning. (TA.) ― -b8- na$aA^a He arose. (TA.) ― -b9- [It became produced; it originated; Eano from another thing. See 4.] ― -b10- It happened, occurred, or came to pass. (TA.) ― -b11- na$aA^a lahu raA^oYN [An opinion occurred to him, or arose in his mind]. (S, K, art. bdw.)
2 nu$~iy^a * and ↓ A^uno$iy^a are syn., (S, K,) [signifying He was reared, made to grow, or grow up, and to become a young man.] See 4.

4 An$A^ *
He (i. e. God) raised the clouds. (S, K.) ― -b2- An$A^ EalamFA He set up a beacon, or sign of the way, in a desert or highway: (TA:) and so EalamFA ↓ Astn$A^ He set up a beacon, or sign of the way. (A.) ― -b3- An$A^hu, inf. n. A_ino$aA='N, He (i. e. God) caused him to attain the age of manhood, or nearly that age. (TA.) See 2. ― -b4- An$A^ and ↓ n$A^ [so TA: app. n$~A^:] He (i. e. God) created; produced; originated. (S.) An$A^ All~`hu Alxaloqa God originated the creation. (TA.) ― -b5- A^ano$aA^otuhu I originated it; brought it into being or existence; made it, or produced it, for the first time, it not having been before. (Msb.) ― -b6- An$A^ He founded or began to build, a house [&c.]. (K.) ― -b7- He framed or constructed, a proverb, or phrase. (TA.) ― -b8- He composed language [such as an ode or the like]. (TA.) ― -b9- He recited poetry, or a xuTobap, well. (IAar.) ― -b10- He forged a tradition, (S, K,) and attributed it [to the Prophet]. (Lth) ― -b11- An$A^, followed by an aor., He began (S, K) to relate, (K,) or say, (TA,) or do. (S.) -A2- An$A^ minohu He went forth from it. (K.) Ex. mino A^ayona A^ano$aA^ota, Whence hast thou come forth? (TA.) -A3- An$A^t Aln~aAqapu The she-camel conceived: (K:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.) -A4- An$A^ Ealayohi He came to, advanced to, or approached him or it. (TA.)

5 tn$~A^ liHaAjatihi *
He rose and went to accomplish his affair, or business. (AA, K.) ― -b2- tn$~A^ EaAdiyFA He arose and went running to accomplish his affair. (AA.)

10 A_isotano$aAa see 4. -A2- yasotano$iy^u Alr~iyHa He scents the wind: said of a wolf: (ISk, S:) and Astn$A^ AlA^axobaAra He sought, or searched after, news: (K, TA:) in both instances, with and without '; (S, * L;) being derived from na$iytu Alr~iyHa (S, L) and rajulN na$oyaAnu liloxabari: [see also musotano$iy^ap.] (L.) -A3- A_isotano$aA^otuhu qaSiydapF [I requested him to compose, or, perhaps, to recite an ode, or the like]. (A.)

na$o'N * and ↓ na$iYo'N Risen clouds: (K:) or the first that rises of them: (S, K:) or their first appearance: (ex. lih`*aA Als~aHaAbi na$o'N HasanN These clouds have a good first appearance:) or clouds when they appear like a piece of drapery (mulaA='ap) spread out. (TA.) ― -b2- na$o'N The exhalation, or odour, of wine. (IAar.) [See 10.] ― -b3- See naA$iy^N. ― -b4- Also, The young ones of camels: (Kr, K:) pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] na$aA^N. (K.)
na$oA^apN * and ↓ na$aA='apN A creation; an original production. (Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Ala, S) [See also 1.] ― -b2- See na$iyoy^apN.
na$aA='apN * : see what precedes.
na$iYo'N * : see na$o'N.

na$iyoy^apN * The first part that is made of a tank, or cistern. (ISk, S, K.) ― -b2- baAdiY Aln~$yoy^p A tank, or cistern, of which the water is dried up, and the bottom apparent. (S.) ― -b3- Also, n$yy^p The stone that is placed in the bottom of a tank, or cistern. (A'Obeyd, S, K.) ― -b4- The earth that is behind the naSaAy^ib, (K,) which are the stones that are set up around the tank, the interstices between which stones are filled up with kneaded clay: (TA:) or it is said to signify what is constructed round the tank; also called A^aEoDaAdN. (TA.) ― -b5- n$yy^pu Albiy^ori The earth that is taken forth from the well. (TA.) ― -b6- na$iyoy^apN What is fresh and green of the plant which is called, when dry, TariyfapN. (K, * TA.) ― -b7- And (which is nearly as above, L,) The plants naSiY~ and Sil~iyaAn: (L, K:) or accord. to AHn, the plant called tafirap, when it has become a little thick, and high, and is yet fresh and green: (TA:) or, (as he says on another occasion, TA,) what has sprung, or sprouted up, of any plant, and not yet become thick; as also ↓ na$oA^apN. (K.) See naA$iy^N, at the end.

naA$iy^N *
A young person past the age of puberty: (TA:) or a boy or girl past the age of childhood: (S, K:) or a comely young man: (IAar:) or a youth who has attained the stature of a man: (AHeyth:) a girl, as well as a boy, is called thus; (TA;) and they also say, jaAriyapN naA$iy^apN. (AA.) Pl. na$o'N and na$aA^N (S, K [or these two are rather quasi-pl. ns.,] or the ↓ former is an inf. n. used as an epithet, Aboo-Moosa,) and naA$iy^uwna (AHeyth) and nawA$iy^u: (TA:) or the last is a pl. of nA$y^ as applied to a girl. (MF.) Lth says that ↓ na$o'N signifies Young people; or youths; and is used in the sing. also: ex. huwa na$o'u sawo'K He is a bad youth: and he says that he had never heard nA$y^ used as an epithet for a girl. Fr says that the ' of the pl. na$o'N is sometimes suppressed, and they say, in the nom. na$uw SdoqK [Excellent youths]; acc., na$aA Sdq; gen. na$iY Sdq. (TA.) ― -b2- naA$iy^N Clouds not completely collected together. Hence, it is said, is derived the expression na$aA^a AlS~abiY~u; which is therefore tropical. (TA.) ― -b3- naA$iy^N Whatever happens (and, perhaps, appears TA,) in the night: pl. naA$iy^apN; (K;) a strange form of pl. of a word of the measure qaAEilN: (M, F:) or naA$iy^apN [see Kur, lxxiii. 6,] is an inf. n. (K) in the sense of qiyaAmN: (TA:) AM says, that nA$y^pu All~ayoli signifies qyAm Allyl the rising in the night: (TA:) or nA$y^p signifies the first part of the night, and of the day: or the first of the hours of the night: (S, K:) or a pious act of the night; i. e., performed in the night: (S:) or every hour of the night in which one rises: (K:) or every hour of the night: (Zj:) or a rising after a sleeping, (K,) in the first part of the night; (TA;) as also ↓ na$iyoy^apN. (K.)

[
mano$aA^N * The place of origination of anything, properly and tropically; its source.]

muno$aA^N * and ↓ musotano$aA^N A beacon, or sign of the way, raised and pointed. (K.) [See the verbs.] ― -b2- Also, the former, An elevated hill. ― -b3- AljawaAriY Almso$aA=tu [Kur, lv. 24,] The ships with elevated sails: (Mujáhid, S, K:) or, accord. to one reading, ↓ Almuno$iy^aAtu, The ships elevating their sails: (TA:) or, advancing and retiring; or coming and going: (Fr:) or, commencing their courses. (TA.)

naAqapN muno$iy^N *
A she-camel that has conceived: (K:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.) ― -b2- See muno$aA^N.
musotano$aA^N * : see muno$aA^N.

musotano$iy^apN * , (K,) also without ', (TA,) A female diviner: (K:) so called because she seeks, or searches after, news: see the verb: or from An$A^ “ he originated: ” (TA:) or musotano$iy^apu, without tenween, is the proper name of a certain female diviner, (T,) one of the Muwelledehs (muwal~adaAt) of Kureysh, in the time of Mohammad. (TA.)

1 na$iba Al$~aYo'u fY Al$~aYo'i * , aor.
na$aba , inf. n. nu$uwbN (S) and na$abN (K, accord. to TA, &c: in the CK na$obN:) and nu$obapN; (K;) and ↓ Ant$b (S, K) [and ↓ tn$~b, q. v.]; The thing stuck fast in the thing. (S.) na$iba AlEaZomu fiyhi The bone stuck fast in him, or it; (TA;) would not pass through. (K.) ― -b2- na$iba, aor.
na$aba , inf. n. na$abN, It became caught, or entangled, fiY $aYo'K in a thing; as game in a net, or snare. (Lth.) ― -b3- A$otarayotu simosimFA fana$iba fiyhi rajulN [I bought some sesame, and a man seized it, or laid hold upon it, for himself]. (TA.) ― -b4- na$ibati AlHarobu bayonahumo, (S, A,) inf. n. nu$uwbN, (A,) (tropical:) The war, or fight, became intricate and entangled (A$tbkt), between them. (TA.) ― -b5- maA na$ibotu A^afoEalu ka*aA (tropical:) I ceased not
to do so. (K.) ― -b6- maA na$ibotu A^aquwluhu like maA Ealiqotu (tropical:) I did not cease saying it. (A.) ― -b7- lamo yano$abo A^ano faEala ka*aA (tropical:) He did not delay to do so; [he did so without delay]. (A.) ― -b8- lamo yano$abo waraqapu A^ano maAta (tropical:) Warakah delayed not to die; [died without delay, or immediately;] lit., did not cling to anything else. Occurring in a trad. (IAth.) ― -b9- na$ibahu AlA^amoru The thing was incumbent upon him: syn. lazimahu. (K.)

2 n$~bwA fiY qatoli EuvomaAna * [They set about, or commenced, the slaughter of 'Othmán]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- n$~b fiY Al$~aYo'i i. q. n$~m: (K:) mentioned by Lh, but as being of weak authority. (TA.) ― -b3- See 4.

3 nA$bh AlHaroba * (assumed tropical:) He waged open war with him; contended with him therein; [app., with pertinacity]. (S.) ― -b2- nA$b Eaduw~ahu, inf. n. munaA$abapN, (tropical:) [He contended with his enemy with pertinacity]. (A.)

4 A^ano$abotuhu fiyhi * , (S, K,) and ↓ na$~abotuhu, (K,) I made it to stick fast in it, (S,) so that it would not pass through. (K.) ― -b2- An$b He (a fowler or the like) had game caught, or entangled, in his snare, or net. (S, K.) ― -b3- He (a hawk) fixed his talons into his prey. (TA.) ― -b4- An$bti Alr~iyHu i. q. Ansbt, The wind was violent, and drove along the dust and pebbles. (K.)

5 tn$~b Al$~awoku biAlv~awobi *
The thorns caught in, or to, or laid hold upon, the garment. (Msb, art. Elq.) ― -b2- tn$~b fiY qalobihi Hub~uhaA (tropical:) [Love of her took fast hold upon, or became fixed in, his heart]. (A.) ― -b3- See 1.

6 tanaA$abuwA Hawolahu *
They drew themselves together, cleaving one to another, around him. (K, * TA.)
8 A_inota$aba See 1. ― -b2- Also, He collected fire-wood. (K.) ― -b3- Ant$b TaEaAmFA He collected together corn, and made for himself property (na$ab) thereof. (K.)

na$abN * (S, K) and ↓ na$abapN and ↓ mano$abapN Moveable and immoveable property; syn. maAlN and EaqaArN: (A'Obeyd, S, Msb:) or the latter only: (Msb:) or fixed property, consisting of animate and inanimate things; [or live stock and land &c.; or land &c. with its live stock;] lit. vocal and mute, naATiq and SaAmit: (K:) or n$b is a term mostly applied to immoveable property, such as houses and land; whereas mAl is a term mostly applied to moveable property, such as silver and gold coin, &c.: but this latter term is sometimes applied to all that a man possesses; and sometimes especially, or particularly, to camels. (TA.) See also 8. [You say,] lkumo nasabN wamaA lakumo na$abN maA A^anotumo A_il~aA xa$abN [Ye have (good) lineage; but ye have not fixed property: ye are nothing but logs of wood]. (A, and in a MS. copy of the K: in the CK, with the pron. of the third pers., and with A_ino in place of the latter mA.) -A2- na$abN A certain tree, of which bows are made, (K,) one of the trees of the desert. (TA.)

entryFree.key: kunotu mar~apF nu$obapF faSirotu Alyawoma EuqobapN

div2.entryFree:
kunotu mar~apF nu$obapF faSirotu Alyawoma EuqobapN *
I was once such that, when I clung to a man, he experienced evil from me; but now I have reverted from being such through weakness. (IAar, K. *) [See also art. Eqb.] A proverb. Said by El-Hárith Ibn-Bedr El-Ghudánee. Applied in the case of him who has become abased after having been great or powerful. MF observes, that n$bp as syn. with EaliqN is properly written ↓ na$abapN; and that it is altered here to assimilate it to Euqobap: but it will be seen that nu$obapN is explained in the K, in another instance in this art. in a sense suitable to it in this proverb. (TA.) ― -b2- nu$obapN [A holdfast. And hence,] (tropical:) A man who, when he is involved, or engaged, in an affair, can scarcely be extricated, or disengaged, from it; (A, K;) or who is unable to accomplish it: (TA:) one who, when charged with, or accused of, a vice, or fault, or the like, will scarcely forsake it. (L.) [See an explanation of a verse cited voce EuSobN.] -A2- nu$obapu a proper name of The wolf. (K.) Imperfectly declinable. (TA.)
na$abapN * : see na$abN, and nu$obapN.

na$~aAbN *
A maker of arrows. (K.) See naA$ibN.
nu$~aAbN * coll. gen. n., Arrows: syn. sihaAmN, (S,) or nabolN: (K:) n. un. with p: (S, K:) pl. na$aA$iybu: (TA:) from na$iba “ it stuck fast ” in a thing. (Msb.)

naA$ibN *
Sticking fast in a thing. (Msb.) ― -b2- Possessing arrows. (S, K.) A word of the same kind as laAbinN and taAmirN: (Msb:) after the manner of a relative noun; having no corresponding verb from which to be formed. (TA.) qawomN naA$ibapN [A people, or party, possessing arrows]. (S.) ― -b3- Also, qawomN naA$ibapN, (TA,) and ↓ na$~aAbapN, (K,) A people shooting, or who shoot, arrows. (K, TA.) ― -b4- naA$ibapu AlmaHaAli The pulley that sticks fast, or will not run. A poet says,
watiloka banuw EadiY~K qado taA^al~awoA
fayaA EajabFA linaA$ibapi AlmaHaAli
[And those, the sons of 'Adee, fell short of what they should do, or delayed: and I wonder at the pulley that sticks fast, and will not run!] He compares them, in their holding back from aiding them, [see art. Alw,] to the pulley that will not run. So explained by IAar, and the L. In the K explained imperfectly. (TA.)

mano$abN *
