A place whence one cannot extricate himself. Ex. na$iba mano$aba sawo'K (tropical:) He fell into an evil, or a misfortune, from which he could not deliver, or extricate himself. (A, K.)

mano$abN * [An instrument by which a thing is made to catch, or stick fast: pl. manaA$ibu]. [Hence,] manaA$ibu qufolK [The catches of a lock]. (A'Obeyd, in TA, voce faraA$N, q. v.) ― -b2- mino$abN Tough, or dry, bad, unripe dates; syn. busorui Alxa$owi: pl. manaA$ibu. (K.) ― -b3- A^atawonaA bixa$owK mino$abK yaA^oxu*u biAloHaloqi [They brought us tough, or dry, bad, unripe dates, that choked, or stuck in the throat]. (IAar.)
mano$abapN * : see na$abN.
muna$~abN * A garment of the kind called burod figured with the forms of arrows: (K:) or figured with a pattern resembling the notches of arrows. (A.)

1 na$aja * , aor.
na$ija , inf. n. na$iyjN and nu$uwjN, It (water) made a sound [in running] upon the ground. (L.) ― -b2- na$aja, aor.
na$ija , inf. n. na$iyjN (S, K) and na$ojN, (S,) He sobbed: (L:) he became choked with weeping, without raising, or prolonging, his voice therein: (S, K:) he wept like a child when he is beaten, when his weeping does not find egress, but is reciprocated in his chest: (A'Obeyd:) he became choked with weeping, on an occasion of fright, or fear. (T.) ― -b3- na$aja, (K,) or na$aja biSawotihi, inf. n. na$iyjN, (S;) (tropical:) He (an ass) made his voice to reciprocate (S, K) in his chest: (S:) he brayed, (A'Obeyd,) on an occasion of fright, or fear. (TA.) ― -b4- na$aja (tropical:) It (a cookingpot, and a skin, S, K, and a jar, or earthen pot, S) made a gurgling noise by the motion of its contents, as in boiling. (S, K.) ― -b5- na$aja, (aor.
na$ija , inf. n. na$iyjN, TA.) He (a singer) made a distinction, or an interval, (faSala,) between two sounds, and prolonged [the same]. (K.) ― -b6- na$aja (assumed tropical:) It (a frog) made a reciprocating croaking. (K.) ― -b7- na$ajati AlT~aEonapu (tropical:) The stab made a [gurgling] sound within, on the coming forth of the blood. (TA.) ― -b8- na$aja. aor.
na$ija , inf. n. na$iyjN, He, or it, uttered, or made, a sound, or noise. (L.)

na$ajN *
A channel in which water flows: pl. A^ano$aAjN (S, K.)

EaborapN nu$ujN *
A weeping that reciprocates in the throat, with sobbing. (L.)
na$iyjN * The channel of a torrent: pl. A^ano$aAjN. (L.)

1 na$aHa * , aor.
nasaHa , inf. n. na$oHN and nu$uwHN, He drank a little, (L,) less than what would satisfy him: (S, L, K:) or, contr., he drank until he was full: (L, K:) as also ↓ Ant$H. (L.) ― -b2- na$aHa He gave his camel a little water to drink: (L:) he watered horses so as to allay the vehemence of their thirst. (T, L, K.)
8 A_inotasaHa see 1.

na$uwHN *
A little water. (S, K.) Abu-n-Nejm says, describing asses,
Hat~aY A_i*aA maA gay~abato na$uwHaA
(S, L,) meaning Until, when they had taken into their bellies a little water: or n$wH signifies a drink less than suffices to satisfy. (L.)

1 na$ada * , (S, K, &c.,) aor.
na$uda , (S, Msb. &c.,) inf. n. na$odN (L, Msb, K) and ni$odapN and ni$odaAnN, (S, M, L, K,) or these two are simple substs., (Msb,) He raised his voice in seeking for, or after, a stray-beast, or beast that had been lost; he called out and inquired respecting it; he cried it: (L:) or he sought for, or after, it: (Lh, A'Obeyd, S, M, L, Msb, K:) and [in like manner] ↓ An$d he asked, or desired, to be directed to it. (M, L, K.) ― -b2- Also, He made known, or gave information of, a stray-beast, or beast that had been lost; (Lh, A'Obeyd, M, L, Msb K;) and so ↓ An$d: (Lh, S, M, IKtt, L, Msb, K:) thus the latter verb [as well as the former] bears two contr. significations. (M, K.) See also naA$idN. ― -b3- na$ada (assumed tropical:) He sought, sought for or after, or desired, a thing. (L.) ― -b4- na$adahu (assumed tropical:) He asked, begged, or besought, him. (L.) ― -b5- nu$ida (assumed tropical:) He was asked, begged, or besought. (S, L.) See 6: and 4. ― -b6- na$adahu, (aor.
na$uda , L,) inf. n. ni$odapN [and na$odapN (see below)] and ni$odaAnN; (L;) and ↓ nA$dhu, inf. n. munaA$adapN and ni$aAdN; (M, L, K;) (tropical:) He adjured him. (M, * L, * K.) ― -b7- na$adahu biA@ll~`hi (tropical:) He adjured him by God; (L, K; *) accord. to most of the grammarians and lexicologists, with a desire of conciliating him. (MF.) ― -b8- na$adahu, (aor.
na$uda , T, S,) inf. n. na$odN, (tropical:) He said to him na$adotuka A@ll~`ha, (S, L, K,) which signifies I conjure, beg, or beseech, thee by God; (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) as though thou remindedst him of God, and he remembered; (S, L;) as also A^ano$uduka A@ll~`ha, and biA@ll~`hi, (L,) and A@ll~`ha ↓ naA$adotuka, (A, Mgh, L,) and bAll~`h: (Mgh, L, Msb:) originally, I conjure thee by God, raising my voice: (Et-Towsheeh:) or it signifies I remind thee of God, conjuring; and originally, I beseech of thee by God; the thing for which one conjures being preceded by A_il~aA or what is syn. therewith, [as lam~aA,] or by an interrogative or imperative or prohibitive: (MF:) or it signifies I remind thee of God, desiring to conciliate thee; as also na$adotuka biA@ll~`hi: (Msb:) or n$dtk All~`h, inf. n. ni$odapN and na$odapN and ni$odaAnN, signifies I adjure thee by God; as also ↓ A^ano$adotuka biA@ll~`hi; (M, L,) or this latter is erroneous: (Mgh, L:) and so signifies na$odaka A@ll~`ha; (M, L, K;) in which na$od is said to be originally na$odap, an inf. n. put in the place of the verb, or n$dk All~`h is a phrase of unpremeditated formation, like qaEodaka A@ll~`ha and Eamoraka A@ll~`ha; or this phrase, which occurs in a trad., may be incorrectly transmitted, and should perhaps be A^ano$uduka A@ll~`ha: (IAth, L:) or na$adahu signifies he said to him na$adotuka biA@ll~`hi wAlr~aHimi [I conjure thee, or adjure thee, by God and relationship; &c.]: (Lth, T, L:) I beg, or beseech, thee by God, and by relationship, raising my voice. (L.) ― -b9- na$ada He remembered God. (S, L.) ― -b10- He knew, or was acquainted with, a person. (L, K.) ― -b11- na$adahu Eahodahu, aor.
na$uda , He reminded him of his compact, covenant, engagement, or promise. (Mgh.)
3 nA$dhu AlA^amora * , and fiY AlA^amori (tropical:) He desired and asked of him the thing. (L.) ― -b2- See 1.

4 An$dhu * , and An$d lahu, (assumed tropical:) He answered him; gave him his assent, or consent, to that which he asked, begged, or besought. The A in this case is called A^alifu AlA_izaAlapi: as though the verb meant he caused his raising of his voice (na$iydahu) to cease. (L.) See also 6: and 1. ― -b2- An$d, (inf. n. A_ino$aAdN, A, Msb,) (tropical:) He recited poetry; (S, * A, L, Msb, * K;) properly, [he chanted it,] with a high voice; (L;) for the reciter [usually] raises his voice in reciting: (A:) he raised it in fame; as also na$ada. (L.) ― -b3- A^ano$adaniY $iEorahu He recited to me his poetry. (S, * A.) ― -b4- An$d (tropical:) [He cited, or quoted, a verse, or verses. (The lexicons, &c., passim.)] ― -b5- An$d bihimo (tropical:) He satirized them. (L, K.) ― -b6- An$d (assumed tropical:) He gave. (S, L.) See 6.
5 tn$~d AlA^axobaAra * (tropical:) He sought to learn news (A, K) without others knowing the same. (A.)

6 tnA$dwA * (tropical:) They recited [poetry] one to another. (L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- El-Aashà, in the following verse,
rab~iY kariymN laA yukad~iru niEomapF
waA_i*aA tunuw$ida fiY AlmahaAriqi A^ano$adaA
[My lord is generous; he does not sully a favour: and when he is asked, or begged, or besought, in papers, he gives], means, accord. to AO, that En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir, when asked, or begged, or besought, to write grants to poets (jawaAy^iz), gave: tnw$d is here for nu$ida, meaning suy^ila. (S, L.)
10 Astn$dhu Al$~iEora * (S, A, * L, K; *) (tropical:) He asked or desired him to recite the poetry. (K.)

ni$odapN * and ↓ ni$odaAnN Search for, or after, a stray-beast. See also 1. (Msb.) Also, A making known, or informing respecting, a stray beast. See also 1. (Msb.) ― -b2- ni$odapN A voice; a cry; a sound. (K.)
ni$odaAnN * : see ni$odapN.

na$iydN *
Elevation of the voice: (L, K:) or the voice itself. (L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Poetry recited (S, A, L, Msb, K) by people, one to another; (S, A, L, K:) as also ↓ A^uno$uwdapN: (K:) pl. of the former, na$aAy^idu; (TA;) and of the latter, A^anaA$iydu. (A, K.)

naA$idN * [act. part. n. of na$ada] in the following verse of Aboo-Du-ád,
watuSiyxu A^aHoyaAnFA kamaA A@so
tamaEa AlmuDil~u liSawoti naA$ido
[And she listens sometimes like as he who has lost a beast gives ear to the voice of a nA$d], signifies a man making known, or giving information of, a stray-best: or, as some say, one seeking for, or after, a stray-beast; for he who has lost a beast desires to find one who, like himself, has lost one, that he may be consoled thereby. (S, M, L.) See art. Swx. ― -b2- naA$iduwna Men who seek after straycamels, and take them, and confine them from their owners. (L.)
A^uno$uwdapN * : see na$iydN.
mutanaA$adN * (tropical:) Poetry recited by people, one to another. (S, L, K.)

1 na$ara * , (S, A, Msb,) aor.
na$ura , (S, TA,) inf. n. na$orN, (S, A, Msb, K,) He spread, spread out, or open, expanded, or unfolded, (S, TA,) a garment or piece of cloth (A, Msb, TA) or the like, (TA,) goods, &c., (S,) and a writing; (A;) contr. of TawaY; (A, K;) as also ↓ n$~r, inf. n. tano$iyrN: (K, TA:) [or the latter is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects, as is shown by an explanation of its act. part. n., which see below. Hence laf~N wana$orN: see art. lf.] ― -b2- [He spread out, or, as we say, pricked up, his ears: and hence the saying,] na$ara li*`lika AlA^amori A^u*unayohi, lit., He spread out his ears at that thing: meaning, (tropical:) he was covetous of that thing, or eager for it. (Har. p. 206.) [See naA$irN, below.] ― -b3- na$ara Alxabara, (S, A, K,) aor.
na$ura and
na$ira , (S, K,) inf. n. na$orN, (K,) (tropical:) He spread, or published, the news. (S, A, K.) ― -b4- Also na$ara, aor.
na$ura , (Msb,) inf. n. na$orN; (Msb, K;) [and ↓ n$~r, or this is with teshdeed for the purpose mentioned above;] He scattered, or dispersed, (Msb, K, TA,) [people, &c.; or] sheep or goats, (Msb, TA,) and camels, (TA,) after confining them in the nightly resting-place. (Msb.) ― -b5- He sprinkled water. (A.) ― -b6- na$arati Alr~iyHu The wind blew in a misty or cloudy day [so as to disperse the mist or clouds]. (IAar, K.) ― -b7- na$ara Eanohu, (A, K,) inf. n. na$orN; (A;) and Eanohu ↓ n$~r, (A, L, TA,) inf. n. tano$iyrN; (S, A, L, TA;) and in like manner ↓ n$~rhu; (S, TA;) (tropical:) He charmed away
from him sickness, (S, * A, L, K, *) and diabolical possession, or madness, (L, K,) by a nu$orap, i. e., a charm, or an amulet; (S, A, L, K;) as though he dispersed it from him: (A:) and in like manner ↓ n$~rhu he wrote for him a nu$orap. (S.) El-Kilábee says, faA_i*aA nu$ira AlmasofuwEu kaAna kaA^an~amaA A^uno$iTa mino EiqaAlK (tropical:) [And when he who is smitten by the evil eye is charmed by a nu$orap, he is as though he were loosed from a bond]: i. e., it [the effect of the eye] departs from him speedily. (S [in two copies of which I find nu$ira, as above; but in the TA, ↓ nu$~ira.]) And in a trad. it is said, biqulo A^aEuw*u birab~i Aln~aAsi ↓ na$~arahu (tropical:) He charmed away the effect of enchantment from him [by the words “ Say I seek refuge in the Lord of men: ” the commencement of the last chap. of the Kur-án]. (S.) -A2- na$ara, (El-Hasan, Zj, A, K.) aor.
na$ura , (TA,) inf. n. na$orN and nu$uwrN; (K, TA;) or ↓ A^ano$ara; (I'Ab, Fr, S, A, Mgh, Msb;) or both; (A, K;) (tropical:) He (God, S, A, &c.) raised the dead to life; quickened them; revivified, or revived, them. (Zj, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) I'Ab reads [in the Kur, ii. 261,] kayofa nuno$iruhaA [How we will raise them to life], and adduces in his favour the words [in the Kur. lxxx. 22,] ↓ vum~a A_i*aA $aA='a A^ano$arahu (tropical:) [Then, when He pleaseth, He raiseth him to life]: El-Hasan reads nano$uruhaA: [and others read nuno$izuhaA, with záy:] but Fr says, that El-Hasan holds it to refer to unfolding and folding, and that the proper way is to use An$r [in this sense,] transitively, and na$ara intransitively. (S, TA.) [See also TawaYa, which has the contr. meaning.] ― -b2- Hence, Alr~aDaAEu AlEaZoma ↓ A^ano$ara: i. q. A^ano$aza, with záy: (Msb:) or (tropical:) The sucking strengthened the bone. (Mgh.) -A3- na$ara, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
na$ura , (S,) inf. n. nu$uwrN (S, A, Msb, TA) and na$orN, (Msb,) agreeably with what Fr says, (S,) signifies (tropical:) He (a dead person) lived after death; came to life again; revived; (S, TA;) or lived; came to life; (A, Msb;) as also ↓ Ant$r. (A.) Hence yawomu Aln~u$uwri (tropical:) The day of resurrection. (S.) ― -b2- na$ara, (TA,) inf. n. na$orN, (K, TA,) (tropical:) It (herbage, or pasturage,) became green in consequence of rain in the end of summer after it had dried up. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a plant) began to grow forth in the ground. (K, * TA.) You say, maA A^aHosana na$orahaA (tropical:) How good is its first growth! (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) It (a tree) put forth its leaves. (K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) It (foliage) spread. (K.) ― -b6- na$arati AlA^aroDu, (S, A, K,) aor.
na$ura , (TA,) inf. n. nu$uwrN, (K,) (tropical:) The land being rained upon in the end of summer, its herbage, or pasturage, became green after it had dried up: (S, TA:) or the land, being watered by the rain called Alr~abiyE, put forth its herbage. (A, K.) See na$orN. -A4- na$ara, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
na$ura , (S,) inf. n. na$orN, (K,) (tropical:) [He sawed wood;] he cut (qaTaEa, S, or naHata, K) wood, (S, A, Msb, K,) with a mino$aAr. (S, A, Msb.)
2 na$~ara see 1, in five places, throughout the former half of the paragraph.
3 nA$rhu Alv~iyaAba * [He spread, or unfolded, with him the garments or pieces of cloth]. (A.)
4 A^ano$ara see 1, after the middle of the paragraph.
5 tana$~ara see 8, in two places.
6 tnA$rwA Alv~iyaAba * [They spread, or unfolded, one with another, the garments, or pieces of cloth]. (A.)

8 Ant$r * [quasi-pass. of 1,] It spread, expanded, or unfolded; it became spread, expanded, or unfolded; as also ↓ tn$~r: (K:) [or the latter, being quasi-pass. of 2, denotes muchness, &c.] ― -b2- Ant$rt Aln~axolapu The branches of the palm-tree spread forth. (K.) [And Ant$rt AlA^agoSaAnu The branches spread forth: and the branches straggled.] ― -b3- Ant$r Alxabaru (tropical:) The news spread, or became published, (S, A, K,) fiY Aln~aAsi among the people. (A.) ― -b4- And Ant$rt Alr~aAy^iHapu (assumed tropical:) [The odour spread, or diffused itself.] (K in art. fwH; &c.) ― -b5- Ant$r Aln~ahaAru (assumed tropical:) The day became long and extended: (K:) and so one says of other things. (TA.) ― -b6- Ant$r AlEaSabu (assumed tropical:) The sinews, or tendons, became inflated, or swollen, (K,) by reason of fatigue: (TA:) A_inoti$aArN is a state of inflation, or swelling, in the sinews, or tendons, of a beast, occasioned by fatigue: (S:) AO says, that the sinew, or tendon, which becomes inflated, or swollen, is the EujaAyap, (S, * TA,) and that what is termed taHar~uku Al$~aZaY is similar to this affection, excepting in its not being so well endured by the horse: by another, or others, it is said, that Ant$Ar of the sinews, or tendons, of a beast, in his fore leg, is a breaking, and consequent displacement, of those sinews. (TA.) ― -b7- Ant$r *akarohu (assumed tropical:) His penis became erect. (TA.) [And hence,] Ant$r Alr~ajulu (tropical:) The man became excited by lust. (S, K.) ― -b8- Ant$r AlmaA='u [In my copy of the A, Astn$r, but this I regard as a mistranscription,] The water became sprinkled; as also ↓ tn$~r: (A:) [or the latter signifies it became much sprinkled.] ― -b9- Ant$rwA fY AlA^aroDi They became scattered, or dispersed, or they scattered, or dispersed, themselves, in the land, or earth. (A.) ― -b10- Ant$rt Alganama, (Msb, TA,) and AlA_ibilu, (K, TA,) The sheep or goats [and the camels] became scattered, or dispersed, after having been confined in their nightly resting-place: (Msb:) or the sheep or goats (TA) and the camels (K, TA) became scattered, or dispersed, through negligence of their pastor. (K, TA.) ― -b11- Ant$r AlA^amoru (assumed tropical:) The state of things, or affairs, became dissolved, broken up, decomposed, disorganized, or unsettled; syn. ta$~atata. (TA, art. $t.) -A2- See also 1, latter part of the paragraph. ― -b2- Ant$r also signifies He put himself in motion, and went on a journey. (TA, in art. bsr.) ― -b3- Ant$r Al*~iy^bu fiY Alganami The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats. (TA in art. $E.)

10 Astn$rhu *
He demanded, or desired, of him that he should unfold (A^ano yano$ura) to him (Ealayohi) [a thing]. (A.)

na$orN * used in the sense of an act. part. n.: see nA$irN. ― -b2- And in the sense of a pass. or quasi-pass. part. n.: see na$arN. ― -b3- A sweet odour: (S, A, K:) [because it spreads:] or odour in a more general sense; (A, K;) i. e., absolutely, whether sweet or stinking: (A'Obeyd:) or the odour of a woman's mouth, (ADk, A, K,) and of her nose, (ADk, TA,) and of her arm-pits (A^aEoTaAf), after sleep. (ADk, A, K.) -A2- (tropical:) Herbage, or pasturage, which has dried up and then become green in consequence of rain in the end of summer or spring (see below, and see simaAkN): (S, K:) it is bad for the pasturing animals when it first appears, and men flee from it with their camels &c.; (S, TA;) which it affects with the [disease called] suhaAm when they pasture upon it at its first appearance: [see remarks on a verse cited in art. byD, voce baADa: and see another verse in art. jrb, voce A^ajorabu:] AHn says, that it does not injure animals with the solid hoof; or if it do so, they leave it until it dries, and then its evil quality departs from it: it consists of leguminous plants and of [the herbage termed] Eu$ob; or, as some say, of the latter only: (TA:) [an ex. of the word is cited in art. jrb, voce A^ajarobu:] or herbage, or pasturage, of which the upper part dries up and the lower part is moist and green: (Lth:) or herbage produced by the rain called Alr~abiyE: (A:) and what has come forth, of plants, or herbage. (TA.) -A3- Life. (K.)

na$arN * is of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Msb, TA,) syn. with mano$uwrN, like as qabaDN is with maqobuwDN, (Mgh,) and syn. with munota$irN, (S, Msb, K,) [therefore signifying Spread, expanded, or unfolded: scattered, or dispersed, &c.: and spreading, or being spread, &c.: being scattered, &c.:] and a thing that one has spread, expanded, or unfolded: &c. (O, voce sabalN, q. v.) ― -b2- You say AikotasaY AlbaAziY riy$FA na$arFA The hawk, or falcon, became clad in spreading and long feathers. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And hence na$arN is applied to People in a scattered, or dispersed, state, not collected under one head, or chief; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ na$orN: (K:) and to sheep or goats in a scattered, or dispersed, state, after having been confined in their nightly resting-place: (Msb:) or sheep or goats, and camels, in a scattered, or dispersed, state, through the negligence of their pastor. (TA.) You say, raA^ayotu Alqawoma na$arFA I saw the people in a scattered, or dispersed, state. (S.) And jaA='a Alqawomu na$arFA The people came in a scattered, or dispersed, state. (TA.) ― -b4- Hence also, na$aru AlmaA=' What is sprinkled, of water, (Mgh, TA,) in the performance of the ablution termed AlwuDuwo'. (TA.) It is said in a trad., A^atamoliku na$ara
AlmaA='i [Dost thou possess what is sprinkled of water?] (S;) or mano yamoliku na$ara AlmaA='i [Who possesseth what is sprinkled of water?] (Mgh;) [app. meaning, that it is gone and cannot be recovered.] ― -b5- And hence, A^all~`hum~a A@Domumo na$ariY (assumed tropical:) O God, compose what is discomposed, or disorganized, of my affairs: (K, * TA:) a phrase like lum~a $aEaviY. (TA.) 'Áïsheh says, in a trad., describing her father, farad~a na$ara AlA_isolaAmi EalaY gar~ihi, meaning, (assumed tropical:) And he restored what was discomposed, or disorganized, [lit., what was unfolded,] of El-Islám, to its state in which it was in the time of the Apostle of God, [lit. to its fold, or plait;] alluding to cases of apostacy, and her father's sufficiency to treat them. (TA.) -A2- See also naA$irN.

nu$orapN * (tropical:) A charm, or an a mulet, (ruqoyapu, S, L, K,) by which a sick person, and one possessed, or mad, is cured; (A, * L, K;) by which the malady is [as it were] dispersed from him. (L.) Mohammad, being asked respecting that which is thus termed, answered, that it is of the work of the devil: and El-Hasan asserted it to be a kind of enchantment. (TA.)
na$uwrN * : see naA$irN.
nu$aArapN * (tropical:) [Saw-dust;] what falls from the mino$aAr [or saw]; (S;) what falls in na$or [or sawing]. (K.)

naA$irN * act. part. n. of na$ara. ― -b2- kaAna yukab~iru naA$ira AlA^aSaAbiEi He (Mohammad) used to say A^all~`hu A^akobaro spreading, or unfolding, his fingers: said to mean not making his hand a clenched fist. (Mgh.) ― -b3- jaA='a naA$irFA A^u*unayohi [He came spreading, or, as we say, pricking up, his ears: meaning,] (tropical:) he came in a state of covetousness, or eagerness. (IAar, L.) [In a copy of the A, TaAy^iEFA is erroneously put for TaAmiEFA.] ― -b4- waA@ln~aA$iraAti na$orFA, in the Kur., [lxxvii. 3,] signifies And the angels, (TA,) or the winds, (Jel,) that do scatter the rain: (Jel, TA:) or the winds that do bring rain. (TA.) And ↓ riyHN na$uwrN, of which the pl. is riyaAHN nu$urN, signifies Wind that spreads [the clouds], or scatters [the rain]; (S; and Bd, vii. 55;) na$uwrN being syn. with naA$irN: (Bd:) or it signifies in a scattered state. (Jel, vii. 55.) [In the Kur, ubi supra,] yurosilu Alr~iyaAHa nu$urFA bayona yadaYo raHomatihi, and nu$orFA, and ↓ na$orFA, and ↓ na$arFA, [Sendeth the winds, &c.,] (K, * TA,) all these being various readings, (TA,) nu$urFA is pl. of na$uwrN, (Bd, K,) in the sense of naA$irN; (Bd;) or the meaning is, in a state of dispersion before the rain; (Jel;) and nu$orFA is a contraction; (Bd, K;) and the third reading means (tropical:) quickening, or making to live, by spreading the clouds wherein is the rain, (K,) which is the life of everything, (TA,) ↓ na$orFA being an inf. n. used as a denotative of state, in the sense of naA$iraAtK, or as an absolute objective complement [of yrsl], for A_irosaAlN and na$orN are nearly alike; (Bd;) and the fourth is extr., (IJ, K,) and is said to mean ↓ muno$irapF na$arFA [which is virtually the same as the third]: [Zj, K:) another reading is bu$urFA, pl. of ba$iyrapN, (TA,) or of ba$uwrN; (TA, in art. b$r;) or nu$orFA, (Bd, Jel,) a contraction of bu$urFA, (Bd,) pl. of ba$iyrN. (Bd, Jel.) -A2- A^aroDN naA$irapN (tropical:) Land having herbage, or pasturage, which has dried up and then become green in consequence of rain in the end of summer: (S:) or having herbage produced by the rain called Alr~abiyE. (A.) See na$orN.
Almano$aru * (tropical:) The place of resurrection. (TA.)
SuHufN muna$~arapN * [Scattered, or much scattered, writings or the like] is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects. (S, TA.)

mino$aArN * (tropical:) [A saw;] a certain instrument for cutting wood. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also, [but less commonly], A wooden implement with prongs, [lit., fingers,] with which wheat and the like are winnowed. (K.)

mano$uwrN *
What is not sealed, [here meaning not closed with a seal,] of the writings of the Sultán [or of a viceroy]; (K;) i. e., what is now commonly known by the name of faromaAn: pl. manaA$iyru. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man whose state of affairs is disorganised, or disordered. (K.)

1 na$azN * , aor.
na$uza and
na$iza , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. na$ozN, (S, K,) or nu$uwzN, (Msb,) He rose, or raised himself, (S, A, Msb, K,) fiY AlmakaAni in the place, (S,) and fiY majolisihi in his sitting-place, (TA,) and Eano makaAnihi, (A,) or mino makaAnihi, (Msb,) from his place: (A, Msb:) or he rose a little in his sittingplace: (TA:) or he stood up after sitting. (TA.) Both forms of the aor. occur, accord. to different readings, (the former being the reading of the people of El-Hijáz, and the latter that of others, Fr, TA,) in the Kur, [lviii. 12,] waA_i*aA qiyla A@no$uizuwA faA@no$uizuwA, (Msb, TA,) meaning, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, And when it is said, Rise ye and stand up, then do ye rise and stand up. (TA.) Accord. to IKtt, na$aza Alqawomu fiY majolisihimo signifies The people drew themselves together [in their sitting-place to make room] for those sitting with them: and also they rose from their sitting-place, and stood up. (TA.) You say also, na$aza biAlqawomi fiY AlxuSuwmapi, inf. n. nu$uwzN, He rose with the people for the purpose of contention, altercation, or litigation. (TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, overtopped, or overlooked, an elevated piece of ground, and appeared. (TA.) ― -b3- [It rose; rose from its place; was, or became, high or elevated, protuberant or prominent; it protruded.] ― -b4- na$azato nafosuhu (tropical:) His soul, or spirit, or stomach, heaved, (A, K,) by reason of fright. (A, TA.) -A2- Hence, from na$aza in the first of the senses explained above, (Msb,) or from na$ozN, signifying “ high, or elevated, ground, ” (Aboo-Is- hák, TA,) na$azati AlmaroA^apu, (S, K,) or na$azato EalaY zawojihaA, (A, Mgh, TA,) or mino zawojihaA, (Msb,) and bizawojihaA, (TA,) aor. ?? and
na$iza , inf. n. nu$uwzN, (S, Msb, K,) (tropical:) The woman, or wife, was, or became, disobedient to her husband, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and exalted herself against him, (TA,) and resisted him, or withstood him, (Msb,) and hated him, (S, Mgh, K,) and deserted him: (TA:) or she disliked him, or hated him, (Zj, Mgh, TA,) and was an evil companion to him. (Zj, TA.) And na$aza baEoluhaA EalayohaA, (S, A, K,) or minohaA, aor.
na$uza and
na$iza , (Msb,) inf. n. nu$uwzN, (TA,) (tropical:) Her husband treated her injuriously, and was unkind to her, or estranged himself from her: (S, K:) or forsook her, and was unkind to her, or estranged himself from her: (Msb:) or disliked her, or hated her, (Zj, Mgh, TA,) and was an evil companion to her. (Zj, TA.)

4 An$zhu *
He raised it, (A, Msb, K,) namely, a place, (Msb,) or a thing, (K,) from its place. (A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] An$z EiZaAma Almay~iti He [God] raised the bones of the dead to their places, and set them, or put them together, one upon another. (S, K.) So in the Kur, [ii. 261,] waA@noZuro A_ilaY A@loEiZaAmi kayofa nuno$izuhaA vum~a nakosuwhaA laHomFA [And look thou at the bones (of thine ass), how we raise them to their places, &c., then we clothe them with flesh], accord. to the reading of Zeyd Ibn-Thábit; (Fr, S, * TA;) but the Koofees read [nuno$iruhaA] with rá: the former reading, however, accord. to Th, is preferred. (TA.) [See art. n$r.] ― -b3- Hence also, An$r Alr~aDaAEu AlEaZoma (tropical:) The sucking of the breast increased, or augmented, the bone: as also An$rhu, with rá. (Msb.)

na$ozN * and ↓ na$azN A high, or an elevated, place; (S, A, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ na$aAzN: (S, K:) or high, or elevated, ground: (Zj, TA:) or high, or elevated, and hard, ground: (M, TA:) or what rises from a valley to the [adjacent] ground, and is not rugged: (TA:) pl. (of the first, S, Msb) nu$uwzN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and (of the second, S, TA, or of the first, Msb) ni$aAzN, (S, Msb, K,) and (of the second, S, Msb,) A^ano$aAzN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, qaEada EalaY na$ozK mina AlA^aroDi, and na$azK, [He sat upon a high piece of ground.] (Msb.) And A^uqoEudo ElY *`lika Aln~a$aAzi Sit thou upon that high place. (S.)
na$azN * : see na$ozN.
na$aAzN * : see na$ozN.

naA$izN *
Rising; or rising from its place; high, or elevated; protuberant, or prominent; protruding. (K, * TA.) You say, qalobN naA$izN A heart rising from its place by reason of fright. (K, TA.) And tal~N naA$izN A high, or an elevated, mound, or hill: pl. [reg. of naA$izapN and irreg. of naA$izN] nawaA$izu. (TA.) And rakabN naA$izN A protuberant, high, pubes, or mons Veneris. (TA.) And laHomapN naA$izapN A piece of flesh elevated, or protuberant, upon the body. (TA.) And EiroqN naA$izN A vein constantly swollen and pulsating (A, K *) in consequence of disease (K, TA) or from some other cause. (TA.) And rajulN naA$izu Aljabohapi A man having a high, or prominent, forehead. (TA.) And A_imoraA^apN naA$izapu AlquSayoraY A woman large in the sides, having the qSyrY [or lowest of the ribs] with the flesh upon it, prominent. (IAar, TA.) -A2- Also, (A, TA,) or naA$izapN, (Mgh,) [but the former is the more common,] (tropical:) A woman disobedient to her husband, (Mgh, TA,) and exalting herself against him, (TA,) and hating him, (Mgh, TA,) and deserting him. (TA.) See 1. [The former epithet is also applied in like manner to a husband.]

1 na$iTa * , aor.
na$aTa , inf. n. na$aATN (S, Msb, K) and mano$aTN, (TA,) He (a man, S, TA, and a beast of carriage, TA,) was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, frisky, active, agile, prompt, and quick; syn. xaf~a, (Msb, TA,) and A^asoraEa; (Msb;) contr. of kasila; (TA;) or pleased, cheerful, happy, or willing; to do work, &c.; (Lth, K;) or by reason of his work; (Msb;) as also ↓ tn$~T, (S, * K,) liA^amori ka*aA [to do, or on account of, such a thing, or such an affair]. (S, TA.) You say also, na$iTa A_ilayohi [He betook himself to him, or it, with briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, or the like]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] na$iTati Ald~aAb~apu The beast of carriage became fat. (K.) -A2- na$aTa, aor.
na$iTa , inf. n. na$oTN, (S, K, TA,) He went forth from a place: (K:) he passed, or crossed, from one country or the like to another: (TA:) said, for instance, of a wild bull: (AO, IDrd, S, K:) and in like manner, a star, [meaning a planet,] from one sign of the zodiac to another. (S, K.) And na$aTati AlA_ibilu, aor.
na$iTa , inf. n. na$oTN, The camels went, either in a right direction or otherwise. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Alhumuwmu tano$iTu biSaAHibihaA (S, TA) (assumed tropical:) Griefs, or disquietudes of mind, lead forth him who has them [from place to place]. (TA.) Himyán Ibn- Koháfeh says,
A^amosata humuwmiY tano$iTu AlmanaA$iTaA
A^al$~aA^oma biY TaworFA waTaworFA waAsiTaA
[meaning tn$T bY AlY AlmnA$T, i. e., (assumed tropical:) My griefs, or disquietudes of mind, became such as to lead me forth to the places to which one goes forth, to Syria at one time, and at one time to Wásit]. (S.) You say also of a road, yano$iTu mina AlT~ariyqi AlA^aEoZami (tropical:) It goes forth from the main road, to the right, and to the left. (Lth, K. *) And na$Ta bihimo TariyqN faA^axa*uwhu (tropical:) [A road led them forth, and they took it]. (TA.) -A3- na$aTa Ald~alowa, (S, K,) aor.
na$iTa (K, * TA) and
na$uTa , (TA,) [inf. n. na$oTN,] He pulled out the bucket, (S, K,) or pulled it up, (TA,) from the well, (S, TA,) without a pulley. (S, K.) ― -b2- And hence, AlmalaAy^ikapu tano$iTu AlA^arowaAHa (assumed tropical:) The angels draw forth the souls like as the bucket is drawn forth from the well: (Zj:) and tano$iTu nafosa Almuw^omini biqaboDihaA (Fr, L, K [in the CK taqobiDuhA]) which means, (K,) accord. to Ibn-'Aráfeh, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) they loose the soul of the believer gently. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] one says of a she-camel, [likening the motion of her fore legs to that of the arms of a man pulling up a bucket from a well without a pulley,] Hasuna maA na$aTati Als~ayora, meaning (assumed tropical:) Good was her wide stretching out of her fore legs (As, S, TA) in her going along. (TA.) -A4- na$aTa AlHabola, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
na$uTa , (K, and so in a copy of the S,) or
na$iTa , (Msb, and so in a copy of the S,) inf. n. na$oTN, (S, Msb,) He tied the cord, or rope so as to form a knot; (K, TA;) as also ↓ n$~aThu, (K,) inf. n. tano$iyTN: (TA:) or he tied it in a knot such as is termed A^uno$uwTap; (AZ, S, Msb;) as also ↓ the latter verb: (Ham, p. 742:) and na$aTa AlEuqodapa he tied the knot so as to form what is thus termed: (Mgh:) and na$aTa AlA^uno$uwTapa he tied the knot thus termed. (TA.) [See also 4.] -A5- na$aTa, and nu$iTa mino EiqaAlK: see 4.

2 n$~Thu * , inf. n. atano$iyTN, He, or it, rendered him na$iyT [i. e. brisk, lively, sprightly, frisky, &c.]; (K;) as also ↓ An$Thu. (Yaakoob, K.) -A2- See also 1, last sentence but one, in two places; and see 4.

4 An$T * , said of a man, (K, * TA,) or of a company of men, (S,) His, or their, beasts, (S, K,) or family, (K,) were, or became, in a state of na$aAT [i. e. briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, friskiness, &c.: see 1]. (S, K.) -A2- As a trans. v.: see 2. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] It (herbage) rendered a beast fat. (S, TA.) -A3- He loosed, untied, or undid, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) a cord, or rope, (S, K,) or a knot such as is termed A^uno$uwTap; (Mgh, Msb,) as also ↓ Ant$T; and ↓ na$aTa; (Mgh;) and in like manner, the bond termed EiqaAl; (Msb;) and so, perhaps, ↓ n$~T: (Ham, p. 165:) he pulled a cord, or rope, until, or so that, it became loosed, untied, or undone; (TA;) as also ↓ Ant$T: (S, K, TA,) he caused the EiqaAl to become loosed, untied, or undone, by pulling its An$wTp: (K, * TA:) he loosed, untied, or undid, a knot by a single pull. (TA.) You say also, An$T AlbaEiyra He loosed, untied, or undid, the An$wTp [of the EiqaAl] of the camel. (TA.) And An$T AlbaEiyra mino EiqaAlihi He loosed the camel from his EiqaAl. (Msb.) [And hence the saying,] kaA^an~amaA A^uno$iTa mino EiqaAlK As though he were loosed [from a bond such as is called EiqaAl]: (S, * Mgh, TA:) a proverb, relating to an event's happening quickly; (Mgh;) or said of him who commences any work quickly; and of the sick when he recovers; and of a person who has swooned when he revives; and of a person sent to execute an affair, hastening his determination respecting it: (TA:) it is often related in a different manner, kAn~mA nu$iTa mn EqAl; but this is not correct. (IAth, TA.) [But see above, in this paragraph; and see 1, where a similar meaning is assigned to the unaugmented verb.] -A4- He bound, or tied, him, or it, firmly, fastly, or strongly: so in the copies of the K; so that, if this be correct, the verb has two contr. significations. (TA.) -A5- See also 8.

5 tana$~aTa see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- tn$~Tt fiY sayorihaA She (a camel) hastened, or was quick, in her going, or pace. (S, K.) -A2- tn$~T AlmafaAzapa (tropical:) He passed through, or over, the desert, (K, TA,) with swiftness, and with briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, or activity. (TA.) And tn$~Thu (assumed tropical:) He traversed it quickly, or swiftly. (IB, in TA, voce hirojaAbN.) And tn$~Tt AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) traversed, or crossed, the land, like the naA$iT in her quickness, or her aim, with briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (TA.)

8 Ant$T *
It (a cord, or rope,) became loosed, untied, or undone. (Har, p. 361.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became loosed from the tie of silence, (Har, p. 360.; Mgh,) and from that of impotence. (Mgh [in which a doubt is expressed as to its being of classical authority].) -A2- As a trans. v.: see 4, in two places. ― -b2- He pulled, or drew, a thing. (TA.) ― -b3- He seized a thing, took it hastily, or snatched it unawares: a meaning wrongly assigned in the K to ↓ An$T. (TA.) You say also, Ant$T AlmaAlu AlmaroEaY, (Sh, K,) and AlkalaA^a, (Sh,) The camels, or sheep or goats, pulled up, or out, the herbage, with the teeth. (Sh, K.) ― -b4- He scaled a fish; (K;) as though meaning he pulled off the scales thereof. (TA.)
nu$uTN * [app. a pl. of ↓ naA$iTN] Persons untwisting cords, or ropes, in the time of undoing them for the purpose of their being twisted or plaited a second time. (IAar, K.)

na$oTapN * as used in the following saying, (Mgh,) Al$~ufoEapu kana$oTapi AlEiqaAli The right termed $fEp is like the loosing of the bond called EqAl, in respect
of the speediness with which it becomes of no effect, (Mgh, Msb,) by delay, (Msb,) is of the measure faEolapN from A^ano$aTa, or from na$aTa in the sense of An$T; or the meaning is, like the tying of the EqAl; i. e., it is of short duration; but the former explanation is the more apparently right. (Mgh.)

biy^orN na$uwTN *
A well from which the bucket does not come forth until it is much pulled, (As, S, TA,) by reason of the distance of its bottom; (TA;) contr. of biy^orN A^ano$aATN. (K.)

na$iyTN * (S, Msb, K) Brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, and quick; (Msb;) or pleased, cheerful, happy, or willing; to do work &c.; as also ↓ naA$iTN; (K;) [see na$iTa;] applied to a man; (S, TA;) and to a beast of carriage; fem. with p: (TA:) pl. ni$aATN (Har, p. 591) [and na$aATaY]. ― -b2- A man (TA) whose family, or beasts, are in a state of na$aAT [i. e. briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, &c.: see 1]; as also ↓ muno$iTN. (K, TA.)

naA$iTN * : see na$iyTN. ― -b2- In a verse of Et-Tirimmáh, [see AstTrb,] naA$iTFA is used for $awoqFA naAziEFA [By reason of yearning, or longing, desire]. (K, in art. dd.) -A2- A wild bull going forth from land to land, (S, K,) or from country to country. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) Aln~aA$iTaAtu, as used in the Kur, lxxix. 2, meaning The stars [or planets] going forth from one sign of the zodiac to another: (S, K:) or it means the stars that rise, then set: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or the angels that draw forth the souls like as the bucket is drawn forth from the well: (Zj, TA:) or the angels that loose the soul of the believer gently: (Fr, * Ibn-'Arafeh, K:) or the believing souls that are brisk, lively, sprightly, or active, at death: (K, * TA:) or, as some say, [too fancifully,] the angels that ratify events; from na$aTa AlEuqodapa, q. v.; and as this signifies the tying of a knot which is easily undone, the thing's easiness to them is thus notified. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A road going forth from the main road, to the right, and to the left: (Lth, K *:) pl. nawaA$iTu: (TA:) which latter word is applied in like manner to water-courses (K, TA) going forth from the main water-course to the right and left. (TA.) -A3- See also nu$uTN.

biy^orN A^ano$aATN * , (K, and so in a copy of the S, as on the authority of As, but in another copy of the S the A is without any vowel,) and biy^orN A_ino$aATN, (K, and, accord. to the TA, on the authority of As, and mentioned by IB on the authority of A'Obeyd,) A well of little depth, from which the bucket comes forth by means of a single pull: (As, S, K:) the latter may be defended on the ground of considering A_ino$aATN as originally an inf. n., of A^ano$aTa signifying “ he loosed, untied, or undid, ” a knot “ by a single pull. ” (TA.)

A^uno$uwTapN * [A knot tied with a bow, or with a double bow, so as to form a kind of slip-knot; whence, in modern vulgar Arabic, Euqodap wa$unayoTap, applied to such a tie; and $unayoTap, applied to a simple slip-knot;] a knot, or tie, which easily becomes undone, or untied, like that of the running band of a pair of drawers; (S, Mgh, K;) a knot, or tie, which becomes undone when one of its two ends is pulled. (Msb, TA.) You say, maA EiqaAluka biA^unosuwTapK, meaning (assumed tropical:) Thy love, or affection, is not weak, or frail. (S.)

mano$aTN *
A thing on account of which, or to do which, one is brisk, lively, sprightly, or active; or pleased, cheerful, or happy; and which one likes, or prefers, to do: opposed to makorahN. (TA.)

[
mano$iTN *
A place to which one goes forth: pl. manaA$iTu. See an ex. of the pl., voce na$aTa.]
muno$iTN * : see na$iyTN.

mino$aTN *
Having much na$aAT [i. e. briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, friskiness, &c.: see 1]. (TA.)

div2.head: n$E, &c
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 naS~a Al$~aYo'a * , (S,) aor.
naSu3a , (Mgh,) inf. n. naS~N, (Mgh, TA,) He raised the thing; syn. rafaEahu [which is here to be understood, like the English equivalent by which I have rendered it, in several senses, as the sequel will show]. (S, Mgh, TA.) This is the primary signification: (TA:) or, accord. to As, it is from naS~a Aln~aAqapa, q. v. infra. (S.) You say, naS~a AlEaruwsa, (M, K,) or naS~atohaA, (A, Mgh,) or naS~ahA Aln~isaA='u, (Msb,) aor. as above, (A, Mgh,) and so the inf. n., (Msb,) He, or she, or the women, raised, (A, Msb,) or seated, (K,) or raised and seated, (Mgh,) or showed, or displayed, (M,) the bride upon the minaS~ap, (M, A, Msb, K,) or upon the manaS~ap. (Mgh.) And naS~ati AlZ~aboyapu jiydahaA The doe-antelope raised, or elevated, her neck. (M, TA.) And nuS~a fulaAnN say~idFA (tropical:) Such a one was set up as a lord, or chief. (A, TA.) And naS~a AlmataAEa, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He put the furniture, or goods, or utensils, one upon another. (M, K.) Hence, (TA,) naS~a AlHadiyva, (M, Msb, TA,) or naS~ahu A_ilaY SaAHibihi, (A,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He traced up, or ascribed, or attributed, the tradition to the author thereof, resting it on his authority, by mentioning him, or mentioning, uninterruptedly, in ascending order, the persons by whom it had been handed down, up to the author; or mentioning the person who had related it to him from the author, if only one person intervened; syn. rafaEahu; (M, TA;) [i. e.] rafaEahu A_ilaY mano qaAlahu: (Msb:) IAar says, (TA,) Aln~aS~u signifies AlA_isonaAdu A_ilaY Alr~ay^iysi AlA^akobari (tropical:) [the tracing up, or ascribing, or attributing, a tradition, in the manner explained above, to the greatest person of authority, here meaning Mohammad, or the author of the tradition]; (K, TA;) [i. e.] naS~u AlHadiyvi signifies A_isonaAduhu warafoEuhu A_ilaY Alr~ay^iysi AlA^akobari. (Mgh.) You also say, naS~a AlHadiyva A_ilayohi, (K,) or A_ilaY fulaAnK, (S,) (tropical:) He ascribed, or attributed, or traced up, the tradition to him, or to such a one, in the manner explained above; syn. rafaEahu. (S, K.) See also A^anaS~u. ― -b2- naS~a Al$~aYo'a (assumed tropical:) He made the thing apparent, manifest, plain, or evident; he showed it, exhibited it, manifested it, evinced it, discovered it, or revealed it. (M, * K.) [The verb seems to be thus used because a thing is rendered conspicuous by being raised. See naS~a AlEaruwsa, above.] ― -b3- [Hence, naS~a EalaY $aYo'K m~aA, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He, or it, (generally said of a passage in the Kur. or a trad.,) made a statement, or a plain, explicit, unequivocal declaration, respecting some, or any, particular thing, not capable of application to any other thing: and he mentioned something, or anything, particularly, or specially; he particularized, or specified it by words; very frequently used in these senses: and such we are to understand from the saying] Aln~aS~u also signifies Alt~awoqiyfu waAlt~aEoyiynu EalaY $aYo'K m~aA: (K:) [for which I would rather read Aln~aS~a EalaY $aYo'K m~aA also signifies Alt~awoqiyfu waAlt~aEoyiynu: adding the observation that Altwqyf as syn. with AlnS~ is restricted in art. wqf in the K to a special relation to the law: and that Aln~aS~u EalaY Al$~aYo'i is often found explained as signifying taEoyiynuhu; as, for instance, in p. 377 of Har.:] these significations of Aln~aS~u are tropical, from that word as denoting “ elevation ” and “ appearance. ” (TA.) See also naS~N below. ― -b4- [From naS~ahu signifying “ he raised it, ” and consequently “ he made it apparent, ” are derived several other significations, here following.] ― -b5- yanuS~uhumo [app. for yanuS~u maA Einodahumo] occurs in a trad. respecting Heraclius, meaning (assumed tropical:) He elicits, and makes apparent, their opinion: (TA:) or naS~a Alr~ajula, (S, M, &c.,) inf. n. as above, (M,) signifies (tropical:) he went to the utmost point in questioning, or asking, the man respecting a thing, (S, K,) so as to elicit what he possessed [of information respecting it]; (S;) i. e. (TA) (tropical:) he importuned the man in questioning, or asking, and urged him to tell the utmost that he knew; (A, TA;) or (assumed tropical:) he questioned, or asked, the man respecting a thing so as to elicit the utmost that he possessed [of information respecting it], (M.) [See also 3.] ― -b6- [In like manner you say,] naS~a Aln~aAqapa, (S, M, Mgh, K,) and Ald~aAb~apa, (M, Msb,) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n., (S, M,) He made the
she-camel, and the beast, to exert herself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond measure, in going, or pace; or to go the pace termed marofuwE; syn. rafaEahaA fiY Als~ayori: (M, Mgh:) or he elicited her utmost pace; (K, TA;) from Aln~aS~u as signifying Alr~afoEu; for the phrase rafaEahaA fiY Als~ayori necessarily implies the eliciting the utmost of her celerity of pace: (TA:) or he went a vehement pace so as to elicit the utmost that she possessed [of celerity[: (As, S:) or he put her in motion so as to elicit her utmost pace: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or he urged, or incited, her, and elicited her pace: (Msb:) naS~a, alone, also occurs in a trad., (M, Msb,) as meaning rafaEa naAqatahu: (M:) and naAqatahu ↓ naSonaSa signifies the same as naS~ahaA. (IKtt, TA.) You do not say of a camel naS~a, making him the agent, and the verb intrans. (O, * TA.) [In the M, however, I find it said, that Aln~aS~u and Aln~aSiySu signify Als~ayoru Al$~adiydu; app. indicating that they are inf. ns., of which the verb is naS~a, aor., accord. to rule,
naSi3a , signifying He went a vehement pace, or vehemently: and Golius says, as on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, that this verb is used intransitively, with naSiySN for its inf. n., as signifying valide incessit: but see naS~N below.] ― -b7- [Hence, app.,] Aln~aS~u also signifies The urging or inciting [a beast]; syn. AlHav~u. (M.) ― -b8- And naS~a Al$~aYo'a, (M, K,) aor.
naSu3a , inf. n. naS~N, (TA,) He moved the thing; put it in motion, or into a state of commotion; agitated it; stirred it; shook it; (M, K;) as also ↓ naSonaSahu. (S, M, K.) Hence the saying, fulaAnN yanuS~u A^anofahu gaDabFA (K, TA [in the CK, incorrectly, yaniS~u,]) Such a one moves about his nose by reason of anger. (TA.) And ↓ naSonaSa lisaAnahu He moved about his tongue; (S, M;) like naDonaDahu; (M;) which is a dial. form; (A'Obeyd, S;) the former being the original; the S not being, as some assert it to be, substituted for the D; for these two letters are not of the same kind so as to be commutable. (M.) -A2- See also 8.
2 naS~a3a see 3.

3 nAS~hu * , (K,) inf. n. munaAS~apN, (TA,) He (a man, TA) went to the utmost length with him, (namely his creditor,) in reckoning, so as to omit nothing therein; (K, TA;) as also ↓ nS~Shu, (K,) inf. n. tanoSiySN. (TA.) He (God) went to the utmost length with him, (namely a man,) in questioning and in reckoning. (TA.) [See also 1.]

6 tnAS~ Alqawomu *
The people, or company of men, crowded, thronged, or pressed, together. (TA.)

8 AntS~ *
He, or it, (said of a camel's hump, Lth, TA,) became raised, or elevated, or high: (K, TA:) or (TA) became even and erect. (Lth, K, * TA.) [In a copy of the A, the verb in these senses, and relating to a camel's hump, is written naS~a.] You say also, AntS~t AlEaruwsu, (M, K,) or AntS~t ElY AlminaS~api, (A,) The bride became raised, (A,) or seated, (K,) or shown or displayed, (M,) upon the minaS~ap. (M, A, K.) -A2- He (a man, TA) drew himself together; contracted himself; or shrank. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.)

R. Q. 1 naSonaSa * , (S, M, K,) inf. n. naSonaSapN, (Sh, M,) He, or it, became in motion, or in a state of commotion; became agitated, stirred, or shaken; moved, or moved about,; bestirred himself or itself; shook. (Sh.) He (a man) shook in his walk, being erect. (M.) He (a camel) shook, or became in a state of commotion, in rising from the ground. (M.) ― -b2- [Also,] said of a camel, it is like HaSoHaSa; (S;) i. e., it signifies (TA) He (the camel) fixed, or made firm or steady, his knees upon the ground, and put himself in motion, or in a state of commotion, previously to rising. (Lth, K, TA.) [See also naDonaDa.] ― -b3- And He (a camel) made a hollow place in the ground with his breast, in order to lie down. (M, TA.) -A2- naSonaSa used transitively, see 1, latter portion, in three places.

naS~N * The end, or extremity, of anything; (Az, S, M;) the utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, point, or reach, of a thing: this is the primary signification. (Az, TA.) It is said in a trad., (S, M,) of 'Alee, (S,) A_i*aA balaga Aln~isaA='u naS~a AlHiqaAqi, faAlEaSabapu A^awulaY bihaA mina AlA^um~i (S, * M, K, *) or naS~a AlHaqaAy^iqi, (K, * TA,) but the former is that which is commonly known; (TA;) i. e. When women attain the period of mature intellect, (Mbr, S, K, TA,) and know the real natures of things, (K, art. Hq,) [then the male relations on the father's side have a better right to dispose of her in marriage than the mother;] meaning, when they attain to that age at which they are qualified to contend for their rights; [accord. to the former reading;] for this is what is termed AlHiqaAq: (K, * TA:) or when they attain to puberty: (Az, TA:) or when they attain to that period at which they become objects of contention for right; when every one of the guardians asserts himself to have the best right: (K:) or AlHqAq in the trad. is a metaphorical term, from the same word as applied to camels [when entering upon the fourth year]; (K, * TA;) and AlHqAy^q, also, in this case, accord. to some, properly signifies the same, being a pl. of Hiq~apN; (TA in art. Hq;) and the meaning is, when they attain to the extreme term of childhood. (M, K.) -A2- In the conventional language of men of science, it signifies (tropical:) A thing [or statement] plainly, or explicitly, declared, or made manifest, by God, and his Apostle; of the measure faEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) or a naS~ of the Kur-án, and of the traditions, is an expression, or a phrase, or a sentence, indicating a particular meaning, not admitting any other than it: (TA:) so in the conventional language of the lawyers and the scholastic theologians: (MF, on the xuTobap of the K:) or a statute, or an ordinance, indicated by the manifest or plain meaning of words of the Kur-án, and of the Sunneh: from Aln~aS~u as denoting “ elevation ” and “ appearance: ” or, as some say, from naS~ahu as signifying “ he elicited, and made apparent, his opinion. ” (TA.) Hence, also, as used by the practical lawyers, it signifies (tropical:) An evidence, or a proof: (TA:) [and particularly a text of the Kur-án, or of the Sunneh, used as an authority in an argument, for proof of an assertion.] The pl. [in all these senses] is nuSuwSN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Also, (assumed tropical:) The text, or very words, of an author, book, writing, or passage: frequently used in this sense.] -A3- Hardness, difficulty, or straitness, of an affair, or a state, or case. (M, TA.) -A4- sayorN naS~N, and ↓ naSiySN, (S, K,) A vehement pace, in which a beast is made to exert itself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond measure; or in which the utmost possible celerity is elicited; [this meaning seems to be indicated, though not expressed, in the S;] syn. jid~N rafiyEN: (K:) or, the former, as Az says, in one place, a kind of swift pace: or, as he says in another place, the utmost pace which a beast of carriage is able to attain: (TA:) or naS~N and ↓ naSiySN signify a vehement pace or going. (M.) See 1.
naSiySN * : see naS~N, last sentence, in two places.

hawu naS~aASu AlA^anofi *
He is one who moves about his nose [much] by reason of anger. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

Hay~apN naSonaASN *
A serpent that moves about much. (K.) [See also naDonaADN.]

A^anaS~u * [a comparative and superlative epithet from naS~a AlHadiyva, q. v.]. 'Amr Ibn-Deenár said, maA raA^ayotu rajulFA A^anaS~a liloHadiyvi mina Alz~uhoriY~i I have not seen a man more skilled in tracing up, or ascribing, or attributing, a tradition to its author, in the manner explained above, (voce naS~a,) than Ez-Zuhree; i. q. A^arofaEa lahu and A^asonada. (TA.)
manaS~apN * : see what next follows, throughout.

minaS~apN * , (S, M, A, Msb, K,) or ↓ manaS~apN, (Mgh,) The thing upon which a bride is raised (S, * A, K) and seated, (Mgh,) or shown or displayed, (M,) or upon which she stands (tqf [but this is probably a mistake for taqoEudu, i. e. sits,]) when displayed to the bridegroom, (Msb,) in order that she may be seen (M, Mgh) [and distinguished] from among the women; (Mgh;) being a chair, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) or couch; (TA;) or consisting of pieces of cloth raised, and carpets laid smoothly for a seat: (M:) written with kesr (Msb, K) as being an instrument, (Msb,) or with fet-h [as being a place]: (Mgh:) accord. to some authorities, minaS~apN and
manaS~apN seem to signify the same thing: (TA:) or the latter is the Hajalap [i. e. a kind of curtained canopy] (K, TA) over the minaS~ap: (TA:) from naS~a AlmataAEa, q. v. (K.) It is said in a proverb, wuDiEa fulaAnN EalaY AlminaS~api (assumed tropical:) Such a one was exposed to disgrace and infamy: (TA:) or to the utmost disgrace and infamy. (M.)

1 naSaA^ahu * , aor.
naSaAa , He took him by the naASiyap [or forelock]: (K:) from naASiyapN: and therefore regarded by some as improperly mentioned in the K in this art. (MF.) ― -b2- naSaA^a, aor.
naSaAa , (S, K,) inf. n. naSo'N, (TA,) He chid, (a camel, TA, or she-camel, S); syn. zajara. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b3- naSaA^a, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He raised, or elevated, a thing: (Ks, AA, S, K:) dial. form of naS~a. (S.)

1 naSaba * , aor.
naSuba , inf. n. naSobN; (S, K;) and ↓ nS~b; (K;) He set up, put up, set upright, erected, a thing: (S:) he elevated, raised, reared, a thing. (K.) ― -b2- He set up, a stone as a sign, or mark. (Msb.) ― -b3- naSaba raA^osahu He raised his head. (TA.) ― -b4- naSiba, aor.
naSaba , inf. n. naSabN, He (a goat) had erect ears. (S: the inf. n. only mentioned.) ― -b5- naSabotu fulAanFA lika*aA I set, or set up, such a one as an obstacle to such a thing, or as a butt for such a thing, like the butt of archers. (TA, art. ErD.) ― -b6- nuSiba fulaAnN liEimaArapi Albaladi (tropical:) [Such a one was set up, or appointed, for the putting, or keeping, of the town, or district, in a flourishing or prosperous state, with respect to building, culture, population, &c.]. (A.) ― -b7- naSaba, aor.
naSuba , inf. n. naSobN, (S, K,) or naSaba naSoba AlEarabi, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He sang, or chanted, a kind of song, or chant, peculiar to the Arabs, (S, K, &c.,) of the description termed HudaA', (K,) [by which camels are urged, or excited,] or a kind of song (K) resembling what is thus termed, (S,) but finer, or more delicate. (S, K.) What is termed naSobN is The kind of singing, or chanting, above described: (S, K:) or a kind of HudaA' resembling singing: (AA:) or a kind of modulation: (Sh:) or a kind of song, or chant, of the Arabs: (ISd:) or, of the Arabs of the desert: (TA:) or poetry such as is commonly recited, well regulated and set to an air: (Nh:) so called because, in [singing or chanting] it, the voice is raised, or elevated. (The Fáïk.) ― -b8- naSaba AlHarofa, [aor.
naSiba , (not
naSuba ,) inf. n. naSobN,] He wrote, or pronounced, the [final] letter with naSob; (S;) which is, in the case of the final inflection of a word, like fatoH in the non-inflection: (S, K:) [i. e., he wrote it, or pronounced it, with BF or
naSaba :) so called because the sound of a word of which the final letter is so pronounced rises to the highest cavity of the mouth. (Lth.) A conv. term of grammar. (S, K.) naSaba Alkalimapa [He wrote, or pronounced, the word with naSob, i. e., making its vowel of inflection BF or
naSaba &c., according to the rules of grammar:] he made the word to have fet-hah as its vowel of inflection. (Msb.) ― -b9- naSaba lah AlHaroba, (inf. n. naSobN, TA,) He made war upon him: syn. waDaEa. (K.) ― -b10- Of anything that is raised, and with which one goes to meet, or encounter, a thing, one says nuSiba, and of the agent, naSaba. (M, K.) ― -b11- naSaba lahu, aor.
naSuba , inf. n. naSobN, (tropical:) He acted with hostility, or enmity, towards him. (S, K.) See also 3. ― -b12- naSabotu lahu raA^oyFA (tropical:) I gave him counsel from which he should not deviate. (A.) ― -b13- naSaba, aor.
naSuba , (inf. n. naSobN, TA,) He put down a thing: syn. waDaEa. Thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b14- [He set, or put, absolutely: often used in this sense.] ― -b15- naSabahu, aor.
naSiba ; and ↓ AnSbh, (inf. n. A_inoSaAbN, TA,) It (disease) pained him; occasioned him pain. (K.) ― -b16- naSaba Als~ayora, aor.
naSuba , (inf. n. naSobN, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He strove, or exerted himself, unusually in his pace: (K:) or naSaba signifies he pursued his journey with diligence, or energy: (TA:) or he travelled on all the day, at a gentle pace: (S, K:) or he journeyed on all the night. (TA.) En-Nadr says, Aln~aSobu is the first pace; then, Ald~ababu, [but see wasaja;] then, AlEanaqu; then, Alt~azay~udu; then, AlEasoju; then, Alr~atoku; then, Alwaxodu; then, Alhamolajapu. (TA.) -A2- naSiba, aor.
naSaba , inf. n. naSabN, He was fatigued, tired, or wearied, (S, K.) ― -b2- naSiba, inf. n. naSabN, He suffered difficulty, trouble, distress, or affliction. (TA.) ― -b3- naSiba He strove; laboured; or toiled. (K.) ― -b4- faA_i*aA faragota faA@noSabo [Kur, xciv. 7,] signifies And when thou shalt have finished thy prescribed prayers, fatigue thyself in supplication: (Katádeh, Jel:) or when thou shalt have finished the obligatory prayers, fatigue thyself in the performance of the voluntary. (TA.) See naASibN.

2 nS~bt Alxayolu A=*aAnahaA *
The horses erected their ears often, or exceedingly. The teshdeed is to render the signification frequentative or intensive. (S.) ― -b2- See 1, and 3.

3 nASbh Al$~ar~a * , (inf. n. munaASabapN, TA,) (tropical:) He made an open show of evil conduct, mischief, or malevolence, to him; (K;) and in like manner, of enmity, (TA,) and of war; (S, TA;) as also ↓ naSabahu, (K,) unaugmented. (TA: in the CK, ↓ nS~bh.) See also naSaba lahu.

4 AnSbh *
He fatigued, tired, or wearied, him: (S, K:) it (an affair) fatigued him, &c.: (TA:) it (grief, or anxiety,) fatigued, tired, or wearied, him; (CK, TA;) as also ↓ naSiba lahu; (TA;) and perhaps ↓ naSabahu is also used in this sense, with reference to grief, or anxiety. (K.) See 1. -A2- AnSb AlHadiyva A_ilaY rasuwli All~`hi He ascribed, or attributed, the tradition to the Apostle of God; syn. A^asonadahu A_ilayohi and rafaEahu. (TA.) -A3- AnSbh He assigned him, or gave him, a naSiyb; i. e., a lot, or portion. (K.) -A4- AnSb Als~ik~iyna He made, or put, a handle (niSaAb) to the knife. (S, K.)

5 tnS~bti AlA^utunu Hawola AlHimaAri *
The she-asses stood round the he-ass. (S, K.) ― -b2- See 8.

6 tnASbwh *
They divided it into lots, or portions, among themselves. (TA.)

8 AntSb * and ↓ tnS~b, quasi-pass. of naSaba and naS~aba, He, or it, became set up, put up, set upright, or erected; stood up, or upright, or erect; became elevated, raised, or reared: (K:) became even and erect. (TA, art. nS.) ― -b2- He stood erect, raising his head. (TA.) ― -b3- [It was, or became, erect, vertical, or perpendicular.] ― -b4- [AntSb $aEaruhu His hair, being full-grown, stood out: see munotaSibN.] ― -b5- AntSb (TA) and ↓ tnS~b (K) (tropical:) It (dust) rose high. (K, TA.) ― -b6- A_inotaSibo Set up thy cooking-pot [upon the minoSab, or trivet,] to cook, said to a cook. (IAar.) ― -b7- AntSbt A^a$onaAnuhu A_ilaY qud~aAmK [Its teeth stood out forwards: see munotaSibN:] said of a mouth. (TA, art. dfq.) ― -b8- [AinotiSaAbN is often used absolutely as meaning An erection of the penis.] ― -b9- AntSb AlHarofu The letter [meaning the final letter of a word] was written, or pronounced, with naSob: [see naSaba AlHarofa]. (S.)

naSobN * : see naSaba, (of which it is the inf. n.,) throughout. ― -b2- naSobN and ↓ naSaba and ↓ nuSubN and ↓ naSiybapN A sign, or mark, set up to show the way; or a standard set up: syn. EalamN manoSuwbN: (K:) i. e., set up [as a sign] to a people: (TA:) or nuSubN is pl. of naSiybapN, like as sufunN is of safiynapN. (Lth, TA.) Also, ↓ nuSobapN, A pole, or mast; syn. saAriyapN; (K;) set up to show the way: (TA:) also, ↓ A^anaASiybu and ↓ tanaASiybu (pls. which have no sings., TA,) Signs, or marks, or stones, set up to show the way; syn. A^aEolaAmN and SuwFY: (K:) stones set up on the tops of isolated small mountains, whereby travellers are to be directed: (TA:) also, ↓ yanoSuwbN [pl. yanaASiybu] signifies A sign, or mark, set up to show the way in a desert. (Fr.) In the Kur, lxx., last verse but one, some read naSobK, meaning as above: others nuSubK, meaning “ idols. ” (Zj.) ― -b3- naSobN also signifies A goal; or limit; syn. gaAyapN: (K:) or rather, some say that
it has this signification [in the verse of the Kur. above referred to]; but the former meaning, of “ a sign, &c., ” is the more correct. (TA.) ― -b4- See also nuSobN and nuSubN, below. ― -b5- naSobN, with respect to rhyme in a verse, is The being free from anything that would mar it, (Akh, K,) when the verse itself is not curtailed; for when the verse is curtailed, the term nSb is not applicable, though the rhyme be perfect: accord. to an explanation received from the Arabs: not one of the terms of Kh. (Akh.) Derived from AlAinotiSaAbu, as signifying “ the standing erect; being tall; making one's self tall, by stretching the neck; ” and therefore not applied to verse that is curtailed. (IJ, ISd.) ― -b6- naSobN One who is set, or set up, as an obstacle to a thing, or as a butt for a thing, like the butt of archers. (TA, art. ErD.) See 1. ― -b7- naSobN [A peculiar mode of singing, or chanting: or a peculiar kind of song, or chant]: (See 1.)

h`*aA nuSobu EayoniY * , and EynY ↓ naSobu, or the latter is a barbarism, (K,) disallowed by Kt; but it is allowed by Mtr; and said to have been heard from the Arabs [of the classical ages]; This is a conspicuous object of my eye; a thing in full view of my eye: said of a thing that is manifest, or conspicuous, [standing before one,] and even when it is lying, or thrown down. (TA.) ― -b2- jaEalotuhu nSba EynY I made him, or it, a conspicuous object, or a thing in full view, of my eye. (TA.) ― -b3- Mtr says, that naSob, in this case, is an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n., and means an object [as it were set, or set up,] conspicuously seen of the eye, so as not to be forgotten, nor to be unheeded, nor to be placed behind the back, or uncared for, or disregarded. (MF.) ― -b4- nuSobN (S, K) and ↓ naSobN and ↓ nuSubN (K) Evil; (S;) trial; affliction; misfortune: (S, K:) so in the Kur, xxxviii., 40: (S:) disease: (K:) affliction occasioned by disease. (Lth.) See also naSab.
niSobN * : see naSiybN.
naSabN * [as a subst.] Fatigue; weariness; toil. ― -b2- Difficulty; trouble; distress; affliction. (TA.) See the verb: and see naSobN.

naSibN *
Diseased; sick; and in pain. (K.)

nuSubN * : see naSobN. ― -b2- nuSubN (K, Msb) and ↓ nuSobN (K: accord. to the S, the latter is sometimes written nuSubN: [but it seems that nuSubN is the more common of the two words:]) and ↓ naSobN (S, Msb) What is set up and worshipped to the exclusion of, or in preference to, the true God: (S:) or anything that is so worshipped: (K:) or a stone that is set up and so worshipped: (Msb:) the pl. of nuSubN is A^anoSaAbN: (S, Msb:) or nuSubN is a pl. of naSobN, like as suqufN is of saqofN: (Msb:) or it is a pl. of which the sing. is niSaAbN; and it may be a sing., the pl. of which is A^anoSaAbN: (Zj:) which last word, accord. to some, is syn. with A^aSonaAmN: but others deny this; because ASnAm are figured and sculptured or painted; whereas AnSAb are of an opposite description. (Msb.) [See a verse cited in art. mwr.] ― -b3- Also, AlA^anoSaAbu Certain stones which were set up around the Kaabeh, over which it was customary for the name of some deity to be pronounced in the killing of animals (yuhal~u EalayohaA), and upon which victims were slain in sacrifice to another, or others, than the true God: (ISd, K:) pl. of nuSubN, as A^aEonaAqN is of EunuqN; or of nuSobq, as A^aqofaAlN is of qufolN. (TA.) ― -b4- nuSubN, as occurring in the Kur, v. 4, signifies An idol; or a stone which the pagan Arabs set up, to sacrifice, or slay animals, before it, or by it, and which became red with the blood: (Kt:) or pl. of niSaAbN, and signifying idols. (Jel.) ― -b5- A^anoSaAbu AlHarami The limits of the sacred territory [of Mekkeh]; (K;) i. e., signs, or marks, set up there, whereby it might be known. (TA.) See also naSobN.

naSobapN *
A laying of a snare; meaning a plot, a stratagem, or an artifice. (TA.)
nuSobapN * : see naSobN.

niSaAbN * The place of sun-set; magiybu Al$~amosi; (K;) the place to which it returns. (TA.) ― -b2- See manoSibN: and nuSubN ― -b3- niSaAbN The handle of a knife; (S, K;) in which the siylaAn is set: (TA:) pl. nuSubN. (K.) ― -b4- niSaAbN, of property, (tropical:) The amount which renders it incumbent on the possessor to pay the alms, or tax, called Alz~akaAp: (S, K:) as two hundred dirhems, or five camels, (S,) [or twenty deenárs, or forty sheep or goats. (IbrD.)] So called as being the “ source ” whence the tax comes. (Msb.)

naSiybN * (S, K) and ↓ niSobN (K) (tropical:) A share, or portion, or lot, syn. HaZ~N; (S, K;) of a thing; (S;) or of anything; (TA;) a set portion: (A:) [hence it appears to be in the sense of manoSuwbN what is set:] pl. of the former A^anoSibaA='u and A^anoSibapN (K, Msb) [the latter a pl. of pauc.], and nuSubN. (Msb.) ― -b2- naSiybN A tank, or cistern. (S, K.) ― -b3- A snare, or fowler's net, set, or set up: (S, K:) thus in the sense of manoSuwbN. (TA.) See also manoSuwbapN.

naSiybapN * , (S,) or naSaAy^ibu, (K,) which latter is the pl. of the former, (TA,) Stones which are set up around a tank, or cistern, and the interstices of which are filled up with kneaded clay. (S, K.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
haraqonaAhu fiY baAdiY Aln~a$iyoy^api dAvirK
qadiymK biEahodi AlmaA='i buqoEK naSaAy^ibuho
[We poured it out into an old cistern of which the water was dried up and the bottom apparent, which for a long time had contained no water, the stones set up around which, having their interstices filled up mith kneaded clay, were black and white]. (S.) The pron. in hrqnAh refers to a large bucket mentioned before. (TA.) ― -b2- naSaAy^ibu is also explained by A'Obeyd as signifying Stones that are set up around a tank, or cistern, to mark the quantity of water with which the camels will be satisfied. (TA.) See naSobN.

ham~N naASibN *
i. q. munoSibN, Grief, or anxiety, that fatigues, tires, or wearies: (K:) after the manner of a rel. n.: (Sb, K:) meaning *uw naSabK; like taAmirN and laAbinN: or nASb is here an act. part. n. used in the sense of the pass. part. n. [manoSuwbN] followed by fiyhi; i. e. yunoSabu fiyhi, in which one is fatigued, tired, or wearied; like layolN naAy^imN, meaning yunaAmu fiyhi, &c.: (S:) or the phrase naSabahu Alham~u, in the sense of A^atoEabahu, has been heard; (K;) and nASb is its act. part. n. (TA.) ― -b2- naSabN naASibN is also said to be a phrase of the same kind as mawotN maAy^itN, and $iEorN $aAEirN; [therefore meaning Severe fatigue, or difficulty, or trouble, and the like]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Eayo$N naASibN, and ↓ *uw manoSabapK, A fatiguing, laborious, or troublesome, life. (K.) ― -b4- Aln~awaASibu, and ↓ Aln~aASibiy~apu, and A^aholu Aln~aSobi, Appellations of a sect who made it a matter of religious obligation to bear a violent hatred to 'Alee (K) the son of Aboo-Tálib: (TA:) [so called] liA^an~ahumo naSabuwA lahu because they acted with hostility, or enmity, towards him, (K,) and openly opposed him: they were a sect of the Khawárij, AlxawaAriju. (TA.)

naASibapu Al$~ujaAEi *
The eye of the serpent called $jAE, which it raises to look. (TA in art. $jE.) ― -b2- By the expression kanaASibapi Al$~ujaAEi in the following words of the poet,
baSarN kanaASibapi Al$~ujaAEi AlmuroSidi
is meant Like the eye of the brave man, which he raises (yanoSubuhaA) to look at, or see, something. (TA.)
Aln~aASibiy~apu * : see naASibN.

A^anoSabu * A goat having erect horns: (S, K:) fem. naSobaA='u. (S.) ― -b2- naSobaA='u A she-camel having an elevated breast. (S, K.) ― -b3- A^a*unN naSobaA='u An ear that is erect, and approaches the other ear. (TA.)

manoSibN * [so accord. to the copies of the S and K in my hands, and the Msb, which states it to be of the same measure as masojidN, and the TA: written by Golius and Freytag manoSabN:] and ↓ niSaAbN (tropical:) Origin; source; (S, K, Msb;) of anything; (TA;) that to which a person or thing is referred, as his or its source; syn.
marojiEN; (K;) place where, or whence, a thing grows; (Msb;) place where a person or thing is set, or set up. (TA.) Pl. [of the former, manaASibu, and] of the latter, nuSubN and A^anoSibapN. (Az, Msb.) ― -b2- lahu manoSibu SidoqK He has an excellent origin. (Msb.) ― -b3- huwa yrojiE A_ilaY mnSbi SidoqK and ↓ niSAbi Sdq, He traces back his lineage to an excellent origin. (TA.) ― -b4- manoSibN (assumed tropical:) Rank, or quality, nobility, or eminence, and the like, absolutely, or derived from ancestry: syn. HasabN and $arafN: from the same word as signifying “ origin, source, &c. ” (Esh-Shiháb.) ― -b5- lifulaAnK manoSibN To such a one pertains eminence of rank or station. (Msb.) ― -b6- A_imoraA^apN *aAtu mnSbK A woman of rank or quality &c., (Hasab,) and of beauty: or of beauty alone; because alone it exalts her. (Msb.) ― -b7- manoSibN, in the language of those of post-classical times, [and commonly pronounced, in the present day, manoSabN,] (assumed tropical:) A post, an office, a function, or a magistracy; as though meaning the place in which a man is set, set up, or elevated; (Shifà el-Ghaleel;) or in which he is set, or set up, to see, or observe, [or supervise]: (MF:) pl. manaASibu. (TA.) ― -b8- [A^arobaAbu AlmanaASibi (assumed tropical:) Functionaries; magistrates.] ― -b9- See minoSabN.

minoSabN *
An iron thing (an iron trivet, TA,) upon which a cooking-pot is set up: (IAar, K:) as also ↓ manoSibN. (MF.)

manoSabapN *
Fatigue, labour, or trouble: [or a cause of fatigue, &c.]. (K.) See naASibN.

manoSuwbapN * , as an epithet, applied to a $abakap or HibaAlap (A net or snare) set, or set up. And hence, as a subst., like daAb~apN and EajuwzN, (assumed tropical:) An artifice, a stratagem, a trick, a plot, a resource, or an expedient: or a stratagem in the game of chess. You say saw~aY fulaAnN mnSwbpF [Such a one framed a stratagem, or plot]. (Z.)

munaS~abN * A horse of which the prevailing characteristic of his whole make is the erect position of his bones, so that he stands erect without needing to bend [his joints]. (TA.) ― -b2- SafiyHN munaS~abN [Broad and thin stones] set up, one upon another. (S.) ― -b3- vagorN munaS~abN Teeth, or fore teeth, of even growth; (K;) as though set up and made even. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce $anabN.] ― -b4- varFY munaS~abN, accord. to the K, i. q. mujaE~adN; but this is a mistake; and the correct word is jaEodN, Soft moist earth; as in other books. (TA.)

munotaSibN * (tropical:) Dust rising high. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Hair full grown, and standing out. (TA, art. sbkr.) ― -b3- A^asonaAnN munotaSibapN A_ilaY xaArijK (S in art. dfq) or AlY qud~aAmK (JK in that art.) Teeth standing out or forwards].
yanoSuwbN * : see naSobN.
A^anaASiybu * : see naSobN.
tanaASiybu * : see naSobN.

1 naSata * , aor.
naSiba , (L, K,) inf. n. naSotN; (L;) and ↓ AnSt, inf. n. A_inoSaAtN, (S, L, K) which latter is the more approved; (L;) and ↓ AntSt; (L, K;) He was silent: (L, K:) or he was silent and listened: (S:) or he was silent to listen: (L:) or he was silent as one listening: (Er-Rághib:) or he listened: (Msb:) or AntSb signifies he stood, or paused, listening. (Msb.) ― -b2- ↓ A^anoSatahu, and AnSt lahu, (S, K,) and A_ilayohi, (Z,) and naSata lahu, (L,) He was silent, and listened to his speech. (S, K, &c.)

4 AnSthu *
He made him silent; silenced him. (Sh, K.) ― -b2- AnSthu Ean~iY He made him to be silent, [and to abstain] from [speaking of, or to,] me. (As.) ― -b3- See 1. -A2- AnSt lil~ahowi He inclined to play, or sport. (IAar, K.)
8 A_inotaSaba see 1.

10 AstnStpu *
He asked him, or desired him, to be silent: (K:) or, to be silent and to listen to him. (TA.)

nuSotapN *
Silence: [or silence and listening, &c.] (K.)

1 naSaHa lahu * , and naSaHahu, (S, K, &c.,) but the former is the original mode of expression, (Lb,) and is the more chaste, (S, Msb,) and the latter was scarcely ever used by the Arabs, (Fr,) aor.
naSaHa , inf. n. nuSoHN and naSaAHapN (S, K,) and naSiyHapN, (A, L, Msb,) or this last is a simple subst., (S, K,) and niSaAHapN and naSoHN (L) and nuSuwHN (TA) and naSaAHiyapN; (K;) and ↓ nASHhu, inf. n. munaASaHapN; (MF;) He advised him, or counselled him, [in an absolute sense,] sincerely, honestly, or faithfully: and he so acted towards him: (Msb:) he directed him to that which was for his good, by words, or speech, which is the proper signification; or otherwise, which is a tropical signification: (Lb:) or he gave him good advice, or counsel; directed him to what was good: or he advised him, or counselled him, sedulously, or earnestly: or he acted sincerely, or honestly, to him, (MF,) or he was benevolent towards him; desired what was good for him. (Nh, MF.) ― -b2- naSaHato lahu naSiyHatiY, inf. n. nuSuwHN, My advice, or counsel, or conduct, was sincere, honest, or faithful, to him. (L.) ― -b3- naSaHato tawobatuhu, inf. n. nuSuwHN (tropical:) His repentance was, or became, true, or sincere, [&c.: see naSuwHN]. (A.) ― -b4- jiy^onaAka liln~aSaAHapi lamo naA^oti lilr~aqaAHapi [We have come unto Thee for the purpose of sincere worship: we have not come for gain, or traffic: see art. rqH]. (S, art. rqH.) ― -b5- naSaHa It (anything, S) was, or became, pure, unadulterated, or genuine. (S, K.) -A2- naSaHa, (S, K,) aor.
naSaHa , inf. n. naSoHN; (S;) and ↓ tnS~H; (K;) (tropical:) He sewed a garment, (S, K,) or a shirt: (TA:) or he sewed it well. (A.) -A3- naSaHa Alr~iY~a, (inf. n. naSoHN, TA,) (tropical:) He (a man, TA,) drank until he was satisfied. (K.) ― -b2- naSaHati AlA_ibilu Al$~uroba, aor.
naSaHa , inf. n. nuSuwHN, (tropical:) The camels drank in good earnest. (IAar, S.) ― -b3- naSaHa Algayovu Albalada, (inf. n. naSoHN, TA,) (tropical:) The rain watered the district so that its herbage became close, without any bare part: (En-Nadr, K:) or, watered it abundantly. (TA.) -A4- naSaHa, aor.
naSaHa , inf. n. naSoHN, He clarified honey. (MF.) But this is rejected by the author of the K in [the work entitled] the Basáïr. (TA.)
3 nASHhu * , inf. n. munaASaHapN, [He advised him, or counselled him, with sincerity or faithfulness, &c., reciprocally: see also 1]. (A.)

4 AnSH *
He watered camels so as to satisfy them with drink. (IAar, S, K.)

5 tnS~H *
He was prodigal of nuSoH [i. e., sincere or faithful advice or counsel, &c.] Hence the saying of Aktham Ibn-Seyfee, A_iy~aAkumo wakavorapa Alt~anaS~uHi faA_in~ahu yuwrivu Alt~uhamapi [Beware ye of being prodigal of sincere or faithful advice or counsel, for it occasions doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion]. (L.) ― -b2- tnS~H He affected to be like, or imitated, nuSaHaA=' [i. e., those who advise, or counsel, sincerely, honestly, or faithfully, &c.: see naASiHN]. (S, K.) ― -b3- See 1.
6 tnASHwA * [They advised or counselled one another sincerely or faithfully, &c.: see 1]. (A, art. fDH.)

8 AntSH *
He accepted naSiyHap, (S, K, *) or nuSoH, (TA,) [i. e., sincere, honest, or faithful, advice or counsel, &c.]. As an ex. of this signification the following is cited
yaquwlu A@notaSiHoniY A_in~aniY laka naASiHN
[He says, Accept my sincere advice, for I am to thee a sincere adviser]: (TA:) and A_inotaSiHN kitaAba A@ll~`hi Accept the sincere or faithful advice or counsel of the Book of God. (A.) But IB says, that the verb in this sense is intrans.; and that, when trans., it signifies He took a person as a naSiyH [a sincere or faithful adviser or counsellor, &c.]; whence the saying laA A^uriydu minoka
nuSoHFA walaA A@notiSaAHA, i. e. laA A^uriydu minoka A^ano tanoSaHaniY walaA A^ano tat~ax*aniY naSiyHFA [I do not desire of thee sincere or faithful advice, nor thy taking me as a sincere or faithful adviser]. (L.) ― -b2- See 10
10 AstnSHhu * , (S, L,) and ↓ AntSHhu, (L,) He reckoned him, or deemed him, nSiyHa, (S, L,) i. e., a sincere, faithful, or honest, adviser, or counsellor, or actor. (L.)

niSaAHN * (tropical:) Thread (S, K) with which one sews: (S:) pl, nuSuHN (K, TA; in the CK nuSoHN;) and niSaAHapN: (K:) the kesreh and A in the latter are not those which are in the sing., and the p is added as a fem. sign of the pl. (TA.) [See also xayoTN.]

niSaAHaAtN *
Skins. (S, K.) As cites as an ex this verse of El-Aasha,
fataraY Alqawoma na$aAwaY kul~ahumo
mivolamaA mud~ato niSaAHaAtu Alr~ubaHo
(S, &c.) rbH here signifies, accord. to some, a young camel such as is called rubaEN: (Az;) or a lamb, or kid: (ISd:) or the bird called in Persian zAg. (TA.) [But see what follows.] ― -b2- Also, (accord. to El-Muärrij, TA.) Snares, (as in some copies of the K, and in the TA) or cords, (as in other copies of the K) having loops (Halaq) made to them, which are set, and with which apes (qurwud) are caught; (K;) one of these animals being attached to one of the cords to attract others. (TA.) Agreeably with this signification some explain the verse of El-Aasha cited above; rubaHN, originally rubaAHN, signifying apes. (TA.)

tawobapN naSuwHN * (tropical:) True, or sincere, repentance: (S, K:) from naSaHati AlA_ibilu Al$~uroba: (IAar, S:) or [repentance that mends one's life;] form naSaHa Alv~awoba, agreeably with the saying of Mohammad, “ He who traduces the absent rends, and he who begs forgiveness of God mends: ” [see rafaA^a:] (S:) or such repentance that one returns not after it to that of which he repents: (K:) sincere repentance, after which one returns not to sin: so explained by Mohammad himself: (TA:) or very sincere, or very honest repentance: (Zj:) faEuwlN being a measure of an intensive epithet, applicable alike to the masc. and fem.: (TA:) or repentance in which one does not purpose to return (K) to the sin of which he repents. (TA.) The people of El-Medeeneh read [in the Kur, lxvi., 8,] naSuwHFA: but some read nuSuwHFA, which is an inf. n. (Fr.)
naSiyHN * : see naASiHN.

naSiyHapN * , and inf. n., (L, Msb,) or a simple subst., (S, K,) Sincere, honest, or faithful, advice, or counsel, and conduct: (Msb:) direction to that which is for the good of the person who is the object, by words, or speech, which is the proper signification; or otherwise, which is a tropical signification: (Lb:) or good advice or counsel; direction to what is good: or sedulousness, or earnestness, in advice or counsel: or sincere or honest conduct: (MF:) or benevolence; desire for what is good for the person who is the object: (Nh, MF:) [pl. naSaAy^iHu]
naS~aAHN * : see naASiHN.

naASiHN * (act. part. n. of naSaiHa) and ↓ naSiyHN are syn., (S, K,) signifying One who advises, or counsels, sincerely, honestly, or faithfully: and who so acts; (Msb:) [who directs another to that which is for the good of the latter, by words, or speech; or otherwise: or who gives good advice, or counsel: or who advises, or counsels, sedulously, or earnestly: or who acts sincerely, or honestly: or benevolent; who desires what is good for another: see naSaH luha;] pl. of the former nuS~aHN and nuS~aAHN; (K;) and of the latter, nuSaHaA='u. (S.) ― -b2- rajulN naASiHu Aljayobi (tropical:) A man pare, or sincere, of heart; (S;) in whom is no deceit, dishonesty, insincerity, or dissimulation: (K:) said to be an expression similar to TaAhiru Alv~awobi [q. v.]. (TA.) [See also art. jyb.] -A2- naASiHN (S, K) and ↓ naS~aAHN and naASiHiY~N (K) (tropical:) A sewer; a worker with the needle; a tailor. (S, K.) -A3- naASiHN (tropical:) Pure, or clear, honey, (As, S, K,) &c., like naASiEN (As, S). saqaAniY naASiHa AlEasali (tropical:) He gave me to drink white honey; or fine, or thin, white honey. (A.) -A4- guyuwtN nawaASiHu (tropical:) Rains succeeding one another. (A.)
minoSaHN * and minoSaHapN (tropical:) A needle, with which one sews. (L, K.) If thick, it is called $agiyzapN. (L.)
