munoSaAHN * : see manoSuwHN.

qamiySN manoSuwHN * , (A, L,) and ↓ munoSaAHN, (A,) (tropical:) A shirt that is rent (A) and sewed. (L.) [See also mutanaS~aHN.] -A2- A^aroDN manoSuwHapN (tropical:) A land plentifully watered by rain, (K.) having its herbage closely conjoined, (ISd, K,) as though the spaces which were between the several portions of the herbage were closed up by sewing. (ISd.)

mutanaS~aHN * (tropical:) Well sewed. (AA, K.) [See also manoSuwHN.] ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A place, in a garment, repaired and sewed: (TA:) a patched place, or place of patching: (K:) a place for sewing; similar to mutaraq~aEN, q. v. (TA in art. rqE.)

1 naSarahu * , (M, A, K,) aor.
naSura , (M,) inf. n. naSorN (M, A, K) and nuSorapN, (A,) or this is a simple subst., (S, Msb,) and nuSuwrN, (K,) [but see the verse of Khidásh in what follows,] He aided or assisted him, (M, K,) namely, a person wronged, misused, or treated unjustly or injuriously, (M. A, K,) against his enemy: (TA:) [he avenged him: (see the verse here following, and see 8:) he supplied his want, or somewhat thereof (TA.) Kidásh Ibn-Zuheyr says.
faA_ino kunota ta$okuw mino xaliylK maxaAnapF
ftiloka AljawaAziY EaqobuhaA wanuSuwruhaA
[And if thou complain of treachery from a friend. those requitals are its result and its avengers, or avengement]: here nuSuwr may be a pl. of naASirN. like $uhuwdN is of $aAhidN; or it may be an inf. n., like duxuwlN and xuruwjN. (M.) You say, taSarahu EalaY Eaduw~ihi, (S, A, Msb,) and mino Eaduw~ihi, (A, Msb,) aor.
naSura , (S, Msb,) inf. n. naSorN (S, A, Msb) and nuSorapN, (A,) or this, as remarked above, is a simple subst., (S, Msb.) He (namely, God. S, A, or a man, Msb,) aided or assisted him, and strengthened him, against his enemy: (Msb:) [he avenged him of his enemy. (See 8.)] And naSarahu A@ll~`hu God made him to be victorious, to conquer, or to overcome: so in the Kur, xxii. 15, where the pronoun relates to Mohammad. (TA.) In the Kur, xlvii. 8. A_ino tanoSuruwA A@ll~`ha yanoSurokumo means, If ye aid God's religion and his apostle, He will aid you against your enemy: (Bd, Jel) or if ye aid his servants, &c.: or if ye keep his ordinances and aid his orders and comply with his commands and shun the things which He hath forbidden, &c. (El-Basáïr.) And the trad. A^unoSuro A^axaAka ZaAlim~aA A^awo maZoluwmFA is explained as meaning, Prevent thou thy brother from wronging when he is a wronger, and aid him against his wronger when he is wronged. (TA.) Also, naSarahu minohu, (K,) inf. n. naSorN and nuSorapN, (TA,) [or the latter in this sense, as in the cases above mentioned, is a simple subst.,] He served or Preserved him from him or it. (K.) ― -b2- naSaraA@ll~`hu AlA^aroDa God gave rain to the earth or land. (A.) And naSara Algayovu AlA^aroDa (S, M, K,) [aor.
naSura ,] inf. n. naSorN, (M,) (tropical:) The rain aided the earth or land: (S:) or watered it: (M:) or watered it generally and copiously, (K, TA,) and caused it to produce herbage: (TA:) and naSara Albalada (tropical:) it assisted the country to produce abundance of herbage: (TA:) and nuSirati AlA^aroDo (tropical:) the earth or land was watered by rain. (S.) ― -b3- Hence, naSarahu, aor.
naSura , inf. n. naSorN, (tropical:) He gave to him. (M.) An Arab of the desert [in the A a beggar] accosted a people saying, A^unoSuruwniY naSarakumu A@ll~`hu, meaning, (tropical:) Give ye to me: may God give to you.
(M, A.) ― -b4- naSarahu A@ll~`hu also signifies (assumed tropical:) God bestowed upon him the means of subsistence, or the like; syn. razaqahu. (IKtt.)

2 nS~rhu * , (inf. n. tanoSiyrN, K,) He made him a Christian. (S, M, K.) It is said in a trad., [relating to the natural disposition of a child to adopt the true faith,] faA^abawaAhu yuhaw~idaAnihi wayunaS~iraAnihi [But his two parents make him a Jew or make him a Christian]. (S.)
3 naAoSara [nASrhu He rendered reciprocal aid to him. See an ex. voce EaASara.]

5 tnS~r *
He laboured, or strove, to aid, or assist; syn. EaAlaja Aln~aSora: (M, K:) not of the same category as taHal~ama [he endeavoured to acquire Hilom] and tbr~r [he endeavoured to characterize himself by bir~]. (M.) -A2- He became a Christian. (M, K.)

6 tnASrwA *
They aided or assisted one another: (S, Msb, TA:) they assisted one another to aid. (M, A, K, TA.) ― -b2- tnASrt AlA^axobaAru (tropical:) The accounts, or tidings, confirmed, or verified, one another. (M, K, TA.)

8 AntSr *
He defended himself: (Bd, Jel, lv. 35:) he defended himself against his wronger, or injurer. (TA.) ― -b2- AntSr minohu He exacted, or obtained, his right, or due, completely, from him, so that each of them became on a par with the other: (Az, TA:) he revenged himself upon him. (Az, S, M, * Msb, K.)

10 AstnSr *
He asked, sought, or desired, aid, or assistance. (M, K.) And AstnSrh He asked him to aid him, (S, Msb, K,) Ealayohi against him, (S, K,) i. e. against his enemy. (S, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He begged; (K;) as though he asked for a gift, which is termed naSor. (TA.)

naSorN * [used a subst.,] Aid or assistance, rendered to another, especially against an enemy: [avengement or another:] victory or conquest: (Bd, xxix. 9:) and ↓ nuSorapN is a subst. from naSarahu [and therefore signifies the same]: (S, Msb:) or the ↓ latter signifies good aid, or assistance: (M, K:) and this ↓ same word, when the object is God, signifies aid of God's servants; &c.; as explained above: see 1. (El-Basáïr.) ― -b2- Spoil; plunder; booty. (Bd, ubi supra.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Rain; (A, TA;) as also ↓ nuSorapN: (TA:) in like manner as it is called fatoH: (A, TA:) or the ↓ latter signifies a complete rain. (IAar.) ― -b4- [Hence,] (tropical:) A gift: (S, TA:) and naSaAy^iru gifts. (M.) ― -b5- See also naASirN.
nuSarN * : see naASirN.
nuSorapN * : see naSorN, in five places.
naSoriY~N * : see naSoraAniY~N.
naSoraAnN * : see naSoraAniY~N.

naSoraAniY~N * , (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ naSoraAnN, (M, A,) or this latter has not been used without the addition of the relative Y, (S,) or it has been sometimes used, (M,) and ↓ naSoriY~N, (M, Msb, K,) but we have not heard this used, (M,) [A Christian: or this is a secondary application, and the original meaning is a Nazarene:] fem. naSoraAniy~apN, (S, A, Msb, K,) and naSoraAnapN, (S, A, K,) or the latter is used only by poetic licence: (IB:) ↓ naSaAraY [applied to the Christians] is a rel. n. from naASirapu, [or Nazareth,] a town of Syria, (S, M, K,) also called naSoraAnapu, (Lth, IDrd, K,) or naSoraAnu, (S, Msb,) and naSuwriyapN, (M, Sgh, K,) without teshdeed, accord. to Sgh, (TA,) and nuSoriY~N and nuSoraY, (as in a copy of the M,) or naSoraY and naSorawapu: (TA:) so originally, and then applied to such as hold the religion of its inhabitants: (Msb:) this is the opinion of the lexicologists; but it is of weak authority, though admissible as there are other anomalous rel. ns.: (M:) or [so in K, but in the S, and] naSaAraY is pl. of naSoriY~N, (Kh, M, Msb, K,) like as mahaAraY is pl. of mahoriY~N; (Msb, K;) or of naSoraAnN (Kh, S, M) and naSoraAnapN, (S,) like as nadaAmaY is pl. of nadomaAnN (Kh, S, M) and nadomaAnapN; (S;) but more probably of naSoraAnN, because this word has been sometimes used, whereas we have not heard naSoriY~N used: (M:) and it is implied in the copies of the K, that A^anoSaArN is pl. of naSoraAniY~N; but correctly, it is a pl. of naSoraAnN, without Y, as is said in the TS, and the L, in both of which is mentioned the saying of the poet,
lam~aA raA^ayotu nabaTFA A^anoSaAraA
[When I saw Nabatheans, Christians], meaning naSaAraY. (TA.)

Aln~aSoraAniy~apu *
The religion of the naSaAraY [or Christians]. (K, TA.)
naSuwrN * One who aids, or assists, much or well. (TA in art. Eqrb.)

naSiyrN * : see naASirN. It has the signification of the measure faAEilN or of the measure mafoEuwlN; for A^axawaAni naSiyraAni, occurring in a trad., means Two brothers, aiders of, and aided by, each other. (TA.)
naSaAraY * : see naSoraAniY~N.
naSaAy^iru * : see naSorN.

naASirN * act. part. n. of naSara, An aider or assister, especially against an enemy; &c.; as also ↓ naSiyrN, (S, * M, A, Msb, K,) and ↓ naSarN: (Sgh, K:) pl. (of naSiyrN, (S, M, Msb, and of naASirN, M,) A^anoSaArN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and (of naASirN, M) nuS~aArN, (M, K,) and nuSuwrN may also be a pl. of the same, as occurring in the verse of Khidásh, cited above: (M:) and A^anaASiyru is a pl. pl., being pl. of A^anoSaArN: (TA:) and ↓ naSorN is used as sing. and pl., (M, K,) being an inf. n. employed as an epithet, like EadolN. (M.) ― -b2- AlA^anoSaAru also signifies The Assistants of the Prophet; (M, K;) of [the tribes of] El-Ows and El-Khazraj; (TA;) being an epithet applied to them especially, (M, K,) and used as a subst., as though it were the name of a tribe, wherefore the rel. n. A^anoSaAriY~N [which is used as sing.] is formed from it. (M.)
naASuwrN * : see naAsuwrN.
A^anoSaArN * : see naSoraAniY~N: ― -b2- and nASirN.
A^anoSaAriY~N * : see naASirN.
manoSuwrN * [Aided or assisted, especially against an enemy, &c.]. ― -b2- A^aroDN manoSuwrapN (tropical:) Land watered by rain; rained upon. (S, A.)
musotanoSirN * [Asking, seeking, or desiring, aid, or assistance]. ― -b2- (tropical:) A beggar. (M.)

div2.head: nSE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 naD~a * , aor.
naDi3a , inf. n. naDiyDN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and naD~N, (K,) It (water) welled from a source, or spring: (TA:) or flowed: (TA:) or flowed, (S, Mgh, K,) or came forth, (Mgh, Msb,) by little and little, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) from stone or the like; (Mgh;) like baD~a: (A:) or exuded; or oozed forth, (A, K,) [like baD~a;] like as it does from stone. (TA.) You say also, saHaAbapN taniD~u biAlomaA='i A cloud flowing with water. (TA.) And riyHN taniD~u biAlomaA='i [app. A wind bringing rain]. (K.) And naD~ati Alqirobapu mino $id~api Almalo'i, (K,) aor.
naDi3a , inf. n. naDiyDN, (TA,) The water-skin slit, or burst, (K, TA,) and its water came forth, (TA,) in consequence of being very full. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] naD~a A_ilayohi mino maEoruwfihi $aYo'N, aor.
naDi3a , inf. n. naD~N [and naDiyDN], (assumed tropical:) Somewhat flowed to him from his bounty: but the verb is mostly thus used in negative phrases. (TA.) You say also, naD~a mino maEoruwfika nuDaADapN (assumed tropical:) A little of thy bounty [flowed forth]. (TA.) And naD~a lahu bi$aYo'K (assumed tropical:) He did him a small benefit; as also baD~a. (As.) ― -b3- Hence too, (Mgh,) naD~a, (IKoot, S, A, &c.,) aor.
naDi3a , inf. n. naDiyDN, (K,) also signifies (tropical:) It (a thing, IKoot, Msb, or an affair, K)
was, or became, within the power or reach; or possible; or easy of obtainment or attainment; or prepared, or ready; or produced; or apparent; or it presented itself; syn. A^amokana; (K, TA;) and tayas~ara; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA;) and HaSala; (IKoot, Mgh, Msb, TA;) and Zahara. (Mgh.) You say, xu*o maA naD~a (tropical:) Take thou, or receive thou, what hath become easy of obtainment or attainment: or prepared, or ready; or produced; or apparent; or what hath presented itself; syn. tayas~ara; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA;) and HaSala; (Mgh, TA;) laka to thee, or for thee; (S, A, Mgh, TA;) mino dayoni of a debt; (S;) or mn Ald~ayoni of the debt; (Msb;) or mn dayonika of thy debt; (A, Mgh;) or mn gariymika from thy debtor. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., xu*uwA Sadaqapa maA naD~a mino A^amowaAlihimo (tropical:) Take ye the poor-rate of what hath appeared, or presented itself, of their possessions; syn. Zahara, and HaSala. (Mgh.) You say also. naD~a Alv~amanu (assumed tropical:) The price was, or became, produced, or apparent, or prepared, or ready: was, or became, given in ready money, or promptly, or quickly, or in advance: syn. HaSala: and taEaj~ala. (Msb.) And maA taD~a biyadiY minohu $aYo'N, (S, Msb,) i. e. mA HaSala (assumed tropical:) [Nothing became produced, or apparent, &c., by my hand therefrom: or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, or As, (see naD~a,) the verb in this instance seems to have the signification here next following] (Msb.) naD~a maAluhu also signifies (tropical:) His property became converted into money, or cash, after it had been a commodity, or commodities. (A, Mgh. *)
2 naD~a3a see R. Q. 1, in two places.

4 AnD~ *
He (a pastor, S) gave lambs or kids to drink a small quantity of milk. (S, K, TA.) -A2- (assumed tropical:) He accomplished a want. (K.)
5 tanaD~a3a see 10, in two places. -A2- tanaD~aDotu fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) I excited, incited, urged, or instigated, such a one. (Sgh, K, TA.) [In one copy of the K, ↓ tanaDonaDotu.]
8 A_inotaDa3a see 10.

10 AstnD~ Alv~imaAda *
He sought repeatedly and perseveringly the [small quantities, or remains, termed] vimaAd of water, and took of them little by little. (TA [in which, however, Alv~imaAra is erroneously put for Alv~imaAda].) ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa yasotaniD~u maEoruwfFA (tropical:) He seeks, or demands, bounty, or a benefit, as it were drop by drop; syn. yasotaqoTiruhu: (K, TA:) or extracts, or elicits, it: (TA:) or seeks, or demands, its accomplishment. (A, TA.) And huwa yasotaniD~u Haq~ahu, (S, K,) or Hq~h ↓ yanotaD~u, (so in a copy of the Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He seeks, or demands, the accomplishment of his right, or due, (S, Msb, K,) and takes, or receives, (S,) part after part, (S, Msb,) mino fulaAnK from such a one: (S:) or extracts, or elicits, it, part after part. (K.) And manohu Haq~iY ↓ tanD~aDotu [in one copy of the K ↓ tanaDonaDotu] (assumed tropical:) I took, or exacted, or received, fully, or wholly, from him, my right, or due, (K, TA,) part after part: (TA) [as also tanaD~aDotuhu minoh.] And AlHaAjapu ↓ tanaD~aDotu [in one copy of the K ↓ tanaDonaDotu] A I sought, or demanded, the accomplishment of the want. (K.)

R. Q. 1 naDonaDa * , (K, TA,) or ↓ naD~aDu, (so in the CK,) said of a man, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) His naAD~, (K, TA,) i. e. what was apparent of his property, (TA,) became much, or abundant. (K, TA.) -A2- He moved about his tongue; as also taSonaSa; but the D in the former is not a substitute for the S in the latter, as some assert it to be: (L, TA:) the verb is used in this sense in speaking of a man; (TA:) and of a serpent; (S *, A, K;) inf. n. naDonaDapN: (S, but in one copy naDiyDapN:) and accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, naDonaDapN [the inf. n.] signifies the making, or uttering, of a sound: or the sound itself; (Sawot;) [app. by a motion of the tongue;] of the serpent; and hence, [accord. to some,] the epithet naDonaADN, as applied to a serpent: (TA:) or this epithet is from the phrase, (IAar.) naSonaDa fulaAnFA, (IAar, K,) ↓ naD~aDahu, (so in the CK,) He put such a one in motion, (IAar,) and he disquieted, disturbed, or unsettled, him; or removed him from his place. (IAar, K.) [In one place, in the TA, AsnD~ minohu $ayoy^FA is made to signify the same; but this is doubtless a mistake, arising from an omission in transcription.] You say also, naDonaDa AlbaEiyru vafnaAth The camel moved about his vafinaAt [q. v.], and made them to be in contact with the ground; or this is [naSonaSa,] with S. (TA.)

R. Q. 2
see 5: ― -b2- and see also 10, in two places.

naD~N * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ nAD~N (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) (tropical:) Gold and silver coin or money; or deenárs and dirhems: (S, A, Mgh, Msb:) such are called AlmaAl ↓ naAD~N: (A, TA:) or the dirhem and deenár: (K:) of the dial. of El-Hijáz: (As, S, Mgh, Msb:) but accord. to A 'Obeyd, (S, Msb,) or As, (TA,) these are called ↓ naAD~N only when converted into such after having been a commodity, or commodities; (S, Msb, K;) because one says, maA naD~a biyadiY minohu $aYo'N, (S, Msb,) i. e. maA HaSala: (Msb:) naD~N also signifies what is apparent, or produced, or prepared, or ready; and so ↓ naAD~N, particularly of property: (TA:) and ↓ the latter, what has continuance, or endurance, of property, (Msb.) A man of much property is described as being A^akovaru Aln~aAsi ↓ naAD~FA (tropical:) [The most abounding of men in gold and silver coin]. (TA.) -A2- See also naDiyDN.

naDaDN *
Water upon sand beneath which is hard ground, from which whenever any exudes and collects, it is taken. (TA.)

biy^orN naDuwDN *
A well of which the water flows by little and little: or oozes forth. (K, TA.)

naDiyDN * Water little in quantity: (S, O, L, K.) pl. niDaADN; (S, O, L, TA; in the K, naDaAy^iDu, which is a mistake. TA.) Also, A small quantity of milk. (S. K.) ― -b2- rajulN naDiyDN All~aHomi (assumed tropical:) A man having little flesh; (K;) as also ↓ naD~uhu, and ↓ naDonaADuhu. (TA.) -A2- jaAw^wA biA^aquSaY naDiyDihimo, and ↓ naDiyDatihimo, They came with the most remote of their company; (O, K;) from Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

nuDaADapN *
A remainder, (S, K,) or small remainder, (A,) of water, (S, A, K,) &c.: (S, K:) the last thereof: pl. naDaAy^iSu and niDaADN. (TA.) [Hence,] nuDaADapu waladi Alr~ajuli (tropical:) The last of the children of the man: (AZ, S, A, K:) applied alike to the male and female and to two and more; (S, K;) like EijozapN and kiborapN. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A small thing: (A) what comes into one's hand, of a thing: a small benefit. (TA.)

naSiyDapN *
A small quantity of rain: (AA, S, K:) or a weak rain: or a weak cloud: or one flowing with water: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aniD~apN and [of mult.] naDaAy^iDu. (S, K.) ― -b2- A wind that brings rain. (taniD~u biAlomaA='i,) so that it flows: or a weak wind. (A 'Obeyd, K.) ― -b3- lqadN tarakovi AlA_ibilu AlmaA='a wahiYa *aAtu naDiyDapK, and *aAtu naDaAy^iDa, The camels have left the water, having thirst; (S, K.; *) not having satisfied their thirst. (S.) -A2- The sound of the roasting of flesh-meat upon heated stones: pl. naDaAy^iDu: (S, K:) ISd, however, says, I think that naDaAy^Du is a sing., like xa$aArimu; but the sing. may be naDiyDapN. (TA.) [It seems to me not improbable that naDaAy^iDu may in a mistranscription, for naDaAy^iDu, pl. of the inf. n. naDonaDapN used as a subst.] -A3- See also naDiyDN.

naDonaADN * : see naDiyDN. -A2- Hay~apN naDonaADN, (IAar, S, K,) and naDonaADapN, (S, A, K,) A serpent that remains not still in a place, (IAar, K,) by reason of its malignity and liveliness: (IAar:) or that, when it bites, kills immediately: (K:) or that moves about its tongue, (S, A, K,) having put it forth; (K;) as also with S: [see naSonaASN:] (TA:) or that utters a sound, or sounds. (TA.) It is said that Dhu-r-Rummeh, being asked respecting the meaning of naDonADN, did nothing more than move about his tongue in his mouth; (S:) or put forth his tongue, and move it about, (IJ, O,) in his mouth, making a sign with it to him who asked him. (O.)
naDonaADapN * : see faDofaADapN.
naADN * (tropical:) A thing, or an affair, within one's power or reach [&c.: see 1, of which it is the part. n.]. (K.) ― -b2- See also naD~N in six places.

1 naDaba * , aor.
naDuba (S, K, &c.) and also
naDiba , (Msb,) which latter is strange, (MF,) inf. n. nuDuwbN; (S, K, &c.;) and ↓ nD~b; (K;) It (water) sank into the earth; disappeared in the earth: (S, M, K, &c.:) and became low: (S:) became remote. (S, M.) ― -b2- naDaba AlHawoDu, occurring in a verse cited by Th, [The water of the tank or cistern, sank into the earth]. (TA.) ― -b3- naDabato Euyuwnu AlT~aAy^ifi [The sources of El-Táïf became dried up]. (A.) ― -b4- maA naDaba Eanohu AlbaHoru wahuwa HaY~N famaAta fakuluwhu That from which the water of the sea has become exhausted, and has dried up, it being alive, and which has then died, eat ye it. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b5- kun~aA EalaY $aATiy^i Aln~ahori biAloA^ahowaAzi waqado naDaba Eanohu AlmaA'u [We were on the bank of the river in El-Ahwáz, and the water had sunk, or receded, from it, leaving it dry]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- naDabato Eayonuhu, (aor.
naDuba , inf. n. nuDuwbN, TA,) (tropical:) His eye sank, or became depressed, in the socket: or it is only said of the eye of a she-camel. (K.) ― -b7- naDaba It (herbage and the like, that had been abundant,) became little, or scanty: (K:) or failed altogether. (TA.) ― -b8- naDaba is met. used with reference to accidents [as it is properly with respect to substances]: thus it is said in a trad., naDaba Eumoruhu (tropical:) His life passed away, or ended. (IAth.) This is what F means by saying naDaba fulaAnN signifies maAta, (tropical:) Such a one died. (TA.) ― -b9- naDaba xayoruhu, inf. n. nuDuwbN, (tropical:) His goodness, or beneficence, became little. (AZ.) ― -b10- naDaba maA'u wajohihi (tropical:) He was not ashamed. (TA.) -A2- naDaba, (inf. n. nuDuwbN, TA,) (tropical:) It (a desert) was far-extending. (K.) ― -b2- naDaba, inf. n. nuDuwbN, (tropical:) It (a people, or party,) was, or became, distant. (S.) ― -b3- naDaba (tropical:) It (a people, or party,) strove, or used exertion, [app., in a journey.] (TA.) -A3- naDaba, aor.
naDuba , It (a thing, TA,) flowed, and ran (K.) By our saying “ a thing, ” we mean to exclude water, though water is included in the definition of a thing: so that we need not infer from what is said in the K that the verb bears two contr. significations. (TA.) [But this observation appears to me to be scarcely admissible.] ― -b2- naDabati Ald~abarapu [in the copies of the K in my hands, written daborap] The sore on the back of a camel &c. became severe. (K.) naDaba Ald~abaru (tropical:) The scar of the sore became severe and deep in the back. (A.) -A4- naDaba Alv~awoba He pulled off the garment. (Msb.)

2 naD~aba see 1 ― -b2- nD~bt, inf. n. tanoDiybN, She (a camel) had little milk; and her flow thereof became slow; (K;) and her milk was long in flowing again into her udder after each previous milking. (TA.)

4 AnDb Alqawosa *
He pulled the string of the bow, in order that it might make a sound: like A^anobaDahaA: (K:) the former verb is [said to be] an original syn. of the latter; (TA;) [and if so, it has an inf. n., as shown below:] or he pulled the string of the bow, and then let it go, to make it twang: or he pulled the string of the bow without an arrow, and then let it go, to make it twang: (TA:) or he caused the bow to make a sound, or twang: (AHn, L:) AnDb watara Alqawosi is the same as A^anobaDahu, of which it is a transp. syn. (S.) AHn, gives to it the inf. n. A_inoDaAbN; and yet asserts it to be formed by transposition: but this is absurd; for verbs so formed have not inf. ns.; as mentioned by Sb and Aboo- 'Alee and the rest of the skilful grammarians. (Abu-l-Hasan.) See qalaba.

gaDiyrN naADibN *
A pool of which the water has sunk into the earth. (A.) ― -b2- [So] ↓ Eyn munaD~ibapN A source of which the water has sunk into the earth; [a source that has become dried up]. (A.) ― -b3- xaroqN naADbN (tropical:) [A deep hole: or a far extending desert]: syn. baEiydN. (S, TA.) ― -b4- A_in~a fulaAnFA lanaADibu Alxayori (tropical:) Verily such a one is a person of little good, or beneficence. (AZ.) ― -b5- naADibN (tropical:) Distant; remote: (As, S:) an epithet applied to water and anything. (TA.) ― -b6- jaroYN naADibN (assumed tropical:) A far-extending run. (TA.)

tanoDubN * , a coll. gen. n., [I find it said to have been written with tenween by J himself: but it appears to have been also used as a generic proper name; and as such, having the measure of a verb, it must be written tanoDubu, being imperfectly declinable:] A certain tree: the t is augmentative, because there is no word of the measure faEolulN; whereas there are words of the measure tafoEulu, as taqotulu and taxoruju: n. un. tanoDubapN: (S:) a certain tree of El-Hijáz: (K:) it grows large, in the form, or manner, of the saroH, having white and thick branches; and folds, such as are called HaZaAy^ir, are made of it: [this is the only meaning I can assign to the words whw mHtZr, supposing bihi to be omitted after mHnZr, though yuHonaZaru would be better:] its leaves are contracted; and it always appears as though it were dry and dusty, though growing: (TA:) its thorns are like those of the Eawosaj: (K, TA:) and it has a fruit [called magodN (L, K, art. mgd)] like small grapes, which is eaten, of a reddish colour: AHn says, that its smoke is white, of the colour of dust; and that poets therefore liken dust to it: and in one place he says, that it is a large tree, without leaves [properly so called], which has a trunk, and from which grow thick boughs, with many branches; its leaves [if such they may be called] being only shoots, which are eaten by the camels and sheep and goats: Aboo-Nasr says, that it is a tree having short thorns: not of the trees that grow on lofty mountains; frequented by chameleons: [see HirobaA'N, in art. Hrb: and see an ex. in a verse cited voce saAqN:] ISd thinks that it is thus called because of its little sap: AM says, that it is a large tree, from which are cut tentpoles: (TA:) and Ibn-Selemeh says, that it is a tree from which arrows are made. (S.) ― -b2- nuwqN kaqidaAHi Alt~anoDubi [She-camels like arrows made of the wood of the tendub]. (TA).
munaD~ibapN * : see naASibN.

1 naDija * , aor.
naDaja , inf. n. nuDojN and naDojN, (S, K, &c.,) or these are [properly] simple substs., (the former accord. to the L, and both accord. to the Msb,) and the inf. n. is naDajN, (Msb,) It (fruit, Alv~amaru, S, K, [in the CK Alt~amoru, or dates,] as grapes, and dates, TA, and flesh-meat, S, K, whether dried in the sun or roasted, TA, [or cooked in any way,]) attained to a perfect state of fitness for being used, or for being eaten: it (fruit) became ripe, or mature: it (flesh-meat) became thoroughly cooked. (S, K, &c.) See 2. [And It (the skin of one tormented in Hell) became thoroughly burned: see Kur iv. 59.] ― -b2- It (an ulcer or the like) became ripe, or suppurated.]

2 naD~ajati Aln~aAqapu biwaladihaA * , (S, K,) and bihi ↓ naDajato, (K,) and naD~ajato waladahaA, (L,) (tropical:) She (a camel) exceeded the usual period of gestation by a month, or thereabout: (L:) or exceeded the year and did not bring forth: (S, K:) was pregnant, and exceeded the year, counting from the time when she conceived, and did not bring forth. (As.) Th uses the expression nD~jt wldhA as signifying She (a woman) exceeded the usual period of gestation, namely nine months; or did so by a month: in which case the child is more strong for the delay. (TA.) ― -b2- naD~ajati Aln~aAqapu bilabanihaA (tropical:) The she-camel attained the utmost point with her milk: but ISd thinks it a mistake for nD~jt bwldhA. (L.) -A2- See 4.

4 AnDj *
He rendered fruit, or flesh-meat, (whether dried in the sun or roasted, TA, [or cooked in any way],) perfectly fit for being used, or for being eaten: rendered ripe, or mature: thoroughly cooked: (S, K:) it (the proper time) rendered fruit ripe, or mature; ripened, or matured it. (TA.) ― -b2- AHn uses this verb in a strange manner, explaining the expression nabaAtN mahoruwo'N by the words A^al~a*iY qado A^anoDajahu Albarodu [meaning, a plant, or herbage, that is nipped, shrunk, shrivelled, or blasted, by the cold]: this is strange because A_inoDaAj is an effect
of heat; not of cold. (M.) [See A^aHoraqa.] ― -b3- A^anoDijo raA^oyaka (tropical:) Mature thy judgment, or thine opinion]. (A.) ― -b4- laA yunoDiju AlskuraAEa, (L,) or kuraAEFA ↓ laA yasotanoDiju, (A,) [He does not thoroughly cook the slender part of the leg of a sheep, or the like]: i. e., he is weak, and of no use, or does not possess a competence. (L.) ― -b5- [AnDj also signifies It matured, or caused to suppurate, an ulcer or the like; as also ↓ nD~j.]
10 A_isotanoDaja see 4.
naDoxN * : see nuDojN.

nuDojN * and ↓ naDojN: see 1. ― -b2- As simple subst., in relation to fruit, or to flesh-meat. A perfect state of fitness for being used, or for being eaten. ripeness, or maturity: the state of being thoroughly cooked. (L, Msb.)

naDiyjN * and ↓ naADijN (S, K) and ↓ munoDajN (TA) Fruit, and flesh-meat, (whether dried in the sun or roasted, TA, [or cooked in any way,]) in a perfect state of fitness for being used, or for being eaten: ripe, or mature: thoroughly cooked: (S, K, &c.:) pl. [of the first, and perhaps of the second also,] niDaAjN. (TA.) ― -b2- naDiyju Alr~aA^uy (tropical:) A man of sound, [or mature] judgment. (S, K.) ― -b3- ↓ A^amorN munoDaju (tropical:) [A matured affair; and affair soundly, or thoroughly, managed] (A.)
naADiju * : see naDiyjN.
munoDajN * : see naDiyjN.
munoDijN * : see what follows.

munaDi~jN * (S, L, K) and ↓ munoDijN and each with p (L) (tropical:) A she-camel that exceeds the usual period of gestation by a month, or thereabout: (L:) or that exceeds the year and does not bring forth: (S, K:) pl. munaDijaAto (S) and munoDijaAtN. (L.) See an ex. voce qiraAbN. ― -b2- [Also both, but the latter the more common, A suppurative medicine.]

minoDaAjN *
An iron instrument for roasting flesh-meat; syn. saf~awdN. (K.)

1 naDaHa * , aor.
naDiHa , (S, K,) and
naDaHa , (Msb, MF,) inf. n. naDoHN, (S,) He sprinkled a house, or chamber, [with water]: (S, K:) or he sprinkled it lightly: (TA:) naDoHN is like naDoxN; and sometimes these two words agree, and sometimes they differ: (Lth:) some say that they both signify any sprinkling: (TA:) or the former signifies what is intentional; and the latter, what is unintentional. (IAar.) [See naDaxa.] ― -b2- naDaHotu Ealayohi AlmaA='a, inf. n. naDoHN, [I sprinkled water, or the water, upon him]. (As.) ― -b3- naDaHa, aor.
naDiHa , and ??, inf. n. naDoHN, He moistened, or sprinkled, a garment, or piece of cloth. (Msb.) ― -b4- A^aSaAbahu naDoHN mino ka*aA [A sprinkling of such a thing came upon him]. (TA.) ― -b5- naDaHato biyawolihaA She (a camel) sprinkled her urine. (TA.) ― -b6- naDaHa EaTa$ahu, (S, K,) aor. ??, inf. n. naDoHN, (S,) (tropical:) It (water, TA,) moistened [or allayed] his thirst, (S, TA,) and allayed it: (K. TA:) took it away: or almost took it away: (TA;) also (K) or naDaHa Alr~iYa, (TA,) he satisfied his thirst with drink: (K:) or he drank less than what would satisfy his thirst. (S, K.) ― -b7- naDaHa AlmaA='u AlmaAla The water took away the thirst of the camels &c.: or nearly did so. (T.) ― -b8- naDaHa AlmaA='a He (a camel) carried water from a river or canal or well to irrigate standing corn or the like. (Msb.) ― -b9- naDaHa He moistened a skin, in order that it might not break. ― -b10- naDaHa Aljul~apa, aor.
naDaHa , inf. n. naDoHN, He sprinkled the palm-leaf date-basket with water, in order that its dates might stick together: (L:) or he scattered forth its contents. (L, K.) ― -b11- naDaHa (inf. n. naSoHN, S,) He watered palm-trees, (K,) and standing corn &c., (TA,) by means of a camel carrying the water. (K.) ― -b12- suqiY Alz~aroEu naDoHA The standing corn &c. was watered by means of buckets, (dilaA='a and guruwb,) and camels carrying the water; not by means of a channel opened for that purpose. (TA.) ― -b13- h`*ihi naxolu tunoDaHu These are palm-trees that are watered [by the means above mentioned]. (S.) ― -b14- fulaAnN yasoqiY biAln~aDoH [Such a one waters palm-trees &c. by the means above mentioned]. (S.) ― -b15- yanoDiHu EalaY AlbaEiyri He drives the camel that carries the water for irrigation, watering palm-trees [&c.] (S) ― -b16- naDaHuwhumo biAln~aboli, (inf. n. naDoHN, TA.) (tropical:) They shot at them [or sprinkled them] with arrows: (S, K:) they scattered arrows among them. like as water is sprinkled. (TA.) Mohammad said to the archers at the battle of Ohod, AinoDiHuwA Ean~aA Alxayola (tropical:) Shoot ye at the horses and their riders with arrows [and so repel them from us]. (S, * TA.) ― -b17- naDaHa farojahu, aor.
naDiHa and
naDuHa , (TA;) and ↓ AntDH and ↓ AstnDH [both of which are thus used as intrans.]: (K;) He sprinkled some water upon his pudendum after the ablution called AlwuDuwo': (K:) as also AinotafaDa. (TA.) ― -b18- naDaHa biAlbawoli EalaY faxi*ayohi He made [a little sprinkling of] urine to fall upon his thighs. (K.) Hence the saying in a trad., Aln~aDoxu mina Aln~aDoHi, meaning, that he upon whom falls a little sprinkling of urine, like the heads of needles, as explained by Z, must sprinkle the part with water, and is not required to wash it. (TA.) ― -b19- naDaHatonaA Als~amaA='u The sky rained upon us. (L.) ― -b20- naDaHa, [aor.
naDaHa ,] He (a horse) sweated. (Msb.) naDaHa biAlEaraqi, inf. n. naDoHN and naDaHaAnN, He (a man, and a horse,) broke out with sweat: and in like manner, the protuberance behind a camel's ear ; and the arm-pit or the like. (L) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. Edw, conj. 3.] ― -b21- yanoDaHu TybFA He diffuses the odour of perfume: lit., sweats it. (L, from a trad.) ― -b22- naDaHa It (sweat) exuded, or came forth. (Msb.) ― -b23- naDaHati Alqrobapu. (S, K,) and AlxaAbiyapu, (S,) aor. ??, inf. n. naDoHN and tan~aDaAHN, (S, K,) [the latter of an intensive form, The water-skin, and the jar. (being thin, TA,) sweated, (ISk, S, K,) or exuded its water. (TA.) ― -b24- naDaHa Aljabalu The mountain sweated water between its masses of rock. (TA) ― -b25- naDaH Al$~ajaru, inf. n. naDoHN, TA,) (tropical:) The trees began to break out with leaves. (As, S, K.) ― -b26- naDaHa Alz~aroEu, and ↓ AnDH, (assumed tropical:) The standing corn became thick in its body, (TA,) and began to have the farinaceous substance in its grains, yet moist, or succulent, or tender. (K.) ― -b27- taDaHati AlEayonu, (L, K,) aor.
naDiHa , inf. n. naDoHN: (L.;) and ↓ AntDHt, (L, K,) and ↓ nnD~Ht; (K;) The eye overflowed with tears: (L, K:) the eye filled with tears and the overflowed without stopping. (L.) ― -b28- naDaHa, aor. (??) It (a sea, or great river,) flowed. (TA, art. tbr.) ― -b29- AinoDaHuwA Alr~aHima bibilaAlihaA: see bilaAlN. -A2- naDaHa Eano fulaAnK, (S, K,) aor.
naDiHa ; (S;) and Eanohu ↓ bADH, (K,) inf. n. munaADaHapu and niDaAHN; (TA;) (tropical:) He repelled from, and defended, such a one: (S, K:) as also maDaHa: (Shujáa:) and naDHa Alr~ajula he repelled from the man. (Kr.) ― -b2- naDaHa Eano nafosihi (tropical:) He defended himself with an argument. a pled. or an allegation. (S.)
3 naAoDaHa see 1.
4 A^anoDaHa see 1 ― -b2- AnDH EiroDahu (assumed tropical:) He aspersed his honour, or reputation: (K:) marred it; as also A^amoDaHahu: (Shujáa Es-Sulamee:) made people to carp at it. (Khaleefeh.)

5 tanaD~aHa see 1 and 8. ― -b2- raA^ayotahu yatanaD~aHu mim~aA qarifa bihi (tropical:) I saw him deny, (S, K,) and declare himself clear of, (S,) that of which he was accused, or suspected. (S, K. *) ― -b3- tnD~H mino A^amorK (tropical:) He pretended to be clear, or quit, of the thing. (TA.)

8 AntDH Ealayohimu AlmaA='u *
The water became sprinkled upon them. (S.) ― -b2- AntDH Albawolu EalaY Alv~awobi The urine became sprinkled upon the garment. (Msb.) ― -b3- AntDH biAln~aDuwHi He sprinkled himself with the kind of perfume called naDuwH. (L.) [And ↓ tnD~H is used in similar sense in art. gsl in the K.] See 1.
10 A_isotanoDaHa see 1.

naDoHN *
A rain between two rains; better than what is called Tal~; (L;) i. q. naDoHN, with respect to rain. (Sh.) ― -b2- naDoHaAtN [or naDaHaAtN?] A slight, or scanty, scattered shower of rain. (L.) ― -b3- Also ↓ naADiHN Rain. (L.) ― -b4- naDoHN (assumed tropical:) Perfume that is thin, like water: pl. nuDuwHN and A^anoDiHapN: [see also naDuwHN:] what is thick, like xaluwq and gaAliyap, is called naDoxN. (L.) ― -b5- A mark left by water, or anything thin, such as vinegar and the like: differing from naDoxN [q. v.]. (AA, in TA, art. nDx.)

naDaHN * and ↓ naDiyHN (tropical:) A watering-trough or tank; or so called because it moistens [or allays] the thirst of camels: (IAar, S:) or a small watering-trough or tank: (TA:) or the latter a watering-trough or tank that is near to the well, so as to be filled with the bucket; and it may be large: (Lth:) pl. of the former A^anoDaAHN; and of the latter nuDuHN. (S.) ― -b2- naDaHu AlwuDuwo'i What is sprinkled in the performance of the ablution called AlwDw'. (L.) [See naDaHa farojahu.]
nuDaHiy~apN * : see naDuwHN.

mazaAdapN naDuwHN *
A mzAdp that sweats, or exudes its water. (TA.) ― -b2- naDuwHN (tropical:) A certain kind of perfume. (S, K.) [See also naDoHN.] ― -b3- qawosN naDuwHN, and ↓ nuDaHiy~apN, A bow that impels the arrow with force, or sends it far, and that scatters the arrows much; expl. by ↓ TaruwHN naD~aAHapN liln~aboli. (AHn, K.) ― -b4- Aln~aDuwHu One of the names of The bow. (TA.)

naDiyHN *
Sweat. (S.) ― -b2- See naDaHN.
naD~aAHN * He who drives the camel that carries water from a well &c., for irrigating land, (S, K,) and waters palm-trees [&c.]. (S.) ― -b2- See qawosN naDuwHN.
naD~aAHapN * : see minoDaHapN

naADiHN * (tropical:) A camel (S) or an ass or a bull (TA) upon which water is drawn (yasotaqaY Ealayohi) [from a well &c.]: (S, TA:) a camel that carries water (yaHomilu AlmaA='a) from a river or canal or well to irrigate seed-produce; so called because it is a means of moistening [or allaying] thirst by the water which it carries: (Msb:) the female is called naADiHapN (S, Msb) and saAniyapN [q. v.]: (S:) pl. nawaADiHu. (Msb.) ― -b2- Afterwards applied to Any camel: as in the following instance, occurring in a trad., A^aToEimohu naADiHaka Give him thy camel to eat. (Msb.) ― -b3- See naDoHN.

minoDaHapN * (L, K) as also minoDaxapN, (IAar, L,) vulg. ↓ naD~aAHapN, (Az,) i. q. zar~aAqapN, (IAar, L, [in some copies of the K zur~aqp; in the CK zarAfap] i. e. An instrument made of copper or brass for shooting forth naphtha [into a besieged place: mentioned in several histories]. (L.)

1 naDaxahu * , aor.
naDaHa , [and
naDiHa , see below], inf. n. naDoxN, He sprinkled him, or it, [with water &c.]: or i. q. naDaHahu: (K:) AZ says, naDoxN signifies the act of sprinkling, like naDoHN; these two words being syn.: you say naDaxotu, aor. A^anoDaxu: (S:) or the former signifies less than the latter: (K:) so most say: (L:) or the former signifies what is unintentional; and the latter, what is intentional: (IAar, L:) As says, that the latter is the act of man: (L:) and the former, he says, signifies more than the latter, and has no pret. nor aor.: and Aboo-'Othmán Et-Towwazee says, that the former signifies the mark, or effect, that remains upon a garment or other thing, and that the act is termed naDoHN, with H unpointed: (S:) As says, that naDoxN has no verb nor act. part. n.; and A'Obeyd says, that it has no pret. nor aor. ascribed to any authority: or you say naDaxotu Alv~awoba, aor.
naDaHa and
naDiHa , inf. n. naDoxN, I wetted the garment; and it signifies more than naDaHotu. (Msb.) nuDixato magaAbinuhaA, inf. n. naDaxaAnN, Her (a she-camel's) armpits were sprinkled with pitch. (S, L, from a verse of El-Katámee.) A^aSaAbahu naDoxN mino ka*aA A sprinkling, more [or less] than what is termed naDoHN, came upon him. (As, S.) ― -b2- naDaxonaAhumo biAln~abol, (Yz, S,) and nDHnA Aln~abola fiyhimo, (K,) i. q. nDHnAhm, (Yz, S,) We [shot at them and] sprinkled them with arrows; or scattered arrows among them; (Yz, S, K;) meaning, our enemies. (K.) ― -b3- naDaxa, (inf. n. naDoxN, L,) It (water) boiled forth vehemently (in gushing, L,) from its source, (L, K,) or boiled up vehemently. (Aboo- 'Alee, L, K.)
3 nADxA * , inf. n. munaADaxapN and niDaAxN, They sprinkled each other. (S, K.)

8 AntDx *
It (water) became sprinkled. (S, K.)
9 AnDx~ * and ↓ AnDAx~ It (water) poured out, or forth. (TA.)
11 A_inoDaAoH~a see 9.

naDoxN *
A mark, or effect, that remains upon a garment or other thing, (Aboo-'Othmán EtTowwazee, S, K,) as the body, (TA,) from perfume, (K,) or mire, or a soil or pollution: (TA:) or from blood, and saffron, and mud, and the like: naDoHN being with water, and with anything thin, such as vinegar and the like. (AA.) [See also naDoHN.]

naDoxapN *
A rain; a shower of rain. (S, K.)

gayovN naD~aAxN *
A copious rain. S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- EayonN naD~aAxapN A copious spring of water: (S:) or a spring that boils forth, or gushes forth (S, Msb) copiously. (Msb.) ― -b3- naD~aAxapu Al*~iforaY A she-camel that sweats copiously in the part called *frY, behind the ear. (L.)
minoDaxapN * , [in the TA mnDx,] vulgo naD~aAxapN, i. q. zur~aAqapN: (K, TA:) [in the CK, zaraAqap, which is a mistake: see minoDaHapN].

1 naDada * , aor.
naDida , (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. naDodN; (S, L, Msb;) and ↓ nD~d, (L, K,) inf. n. tanoDiydN; (S, L;) or the latter has an intensive signification; (S, L;) He put goods, household-goods, or commodities, (mataAE, S, L, K,) one upon another: (S, L, Msb, K:) or put, or set, them together, (T, A, L,) in regular order, or piled up: (A:) both verbs signify the same: (L, K:) or the latter, he put them one upon another [or side by side] compactly. (S, L.) ― -b2- [You say,] naDadotu Allabina EalaY Almay~iti [I placed the crude bricks in order against the corpse, to support it; as it is laid upon its right side, or so inclined that the face is towards Mekkeh]. (L.)
2 nD~d * , inf. n. tanoDiydN, He [God] made a person's teeth to be disposed in regular order. (A.) ― -b2- See 1.

5 tnD~dt AlA^asonaAnu *
The teeth were disposed in regular order. (A.)

8 AntDd * , [quasi-pass. of 1, It was put, or set, one part upon, or beside, another, in regular order; was piled up, or became piled up]. (K, art. fqr.) ― -b2- AntDd (tropical:) It (a people, A) remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in a place; (A, K;) and collected there. (A.)

naDadN *
Goods, household-goods, or commodities, put one upon another: (S, L, K:) or, put, or set, together, (A, L,) in regular order, or piled up: (A:) or the best thereof: (L, K:) or such things in general: but the first meaning is the most appropriate: (L:) pl. A^anoDaAdN. (S, L.) ― -b2- raA^ayotu naDadFA mina Alv~iyaAbi wAlfuru$i I saw a number of garments, or pieces of cloth, and of beds, or the like, put together in regular order, or piled up. (A.) ― -b3- See naDiydapN. ― -b4- naDadN A couch-frame, or a raised couch, (sariyr,) upon which goods, householdgoods, or commodities, are put one upon another, (S, L, K,) or put, or set, together, in regular order, or piled up: (A, L:) or simply, a couchframe, or raised couch; (sryr;) so called because the things so termed are generally put upon it: (L, Msb:) or a mi$ojab, or a thing resembling this, upon which garments and household-goods are put, one upon another, or together. (L.) ― -b5- naDadN (tropical:) Glory; honour; dignity; might; or power; (A;) eminence; or nobility. (K.) ― -b6-
naDadN (tropical:) Eminent; or noble: (L, K:) applied to a man: pl. A^anoDaAdN. (L.) ― -b7- Also, (A, L,) and the pl., (S, A, L,) (tropical:) A man's paternal and maternal uncles (S, A, L) preëminent in nobility. (S, L.) ― -b8- Also, the pl., (tropical:) The party, or company, (L, K,) and number, (A, L, K,) and auxiliaries, or assistants, (A,) of a people, (L, K,) or of a man: (A:) and the sing. and pl., companies, or congregated bodies, of men. (A.) ― -b9- naDadN (tropical:) A fat she-camel; (K;) likened to a couch-frame, or a raised couch, upon which are the things termed naDad; (TA;) as also ↓ naDuwdN. (K.) ― -b10- A^anoDaAdN, of mountains, Stones, such as are called janaAdil, one upon another. (S, L, K.) Also, of clouds, Portions piled up, one above another: (S, L, K:) sing. naDadN. (L.)
naDuwdN * : see naDadN and naDiydN.

naDiydN * and ↓ manoDuwdN (Msb, K,) and ↓ munaD~adN, [or the last has an intensive signification, as is shewn above,] Goods, household-goods, or commodities, (K,) put one upon another: (Msb, K:) [or put, or set, together, in regular order, or piled up: and the last, put one upon another, or side by side, compactly: see 1]. ― -b2- TaloEN naDiydN, in the Kur, [l. 10.] Spadices of palm-trees [having their flowers] compacted, or compactly disposed; (L;) yet in their envelopes; (Fr, L;) for when they have come forth therefrom they cease to be nDyd. (L.) ― -b3- ↓ TaloHN manoDuwdN, in the Kur, [lvi. 28,] Gum-acacias having fruit or leaves closely set, one above another, from bottom to top, without their trunks being apparent below. (L.) ― -b4- $ajaru Alxan~api naDiydN mino A^aSolihaA A_ilaY faroEihaA The trees of paradise are closely set with leaves and fruit, one above another, from bottom to top, without having trunks apparent: (L, from a trad.:) and similarly ↓ naDuwdN (Jel, lvi. 20.)

naDiydapN *
A pillow: and any stuffed article of household furniture: (L, K:) pl. naDaAy^idu: and ↓ naDadN is used as a coll. n. (L.)
manuDuwdN * : see naDiydN.

dur~N munaD~adN *
Pearls arranged, or put together, in regular order. (A.) ― -b2- See naDiydN.

1 naDura * , aor.
naDura ; (IAar, S, A, Msb, K;) and naDara, aor.
naDura ; and naDira, aor.
naDara ; (IAar, S, A. K;) the last [also] mentioned by A'Obeyd; (S;) inf. n. naDaArapN, (S, A, Msb, K,) of the first; (S, Msb;) and nuDuwrN (K) and naDorapN, (S, A, K,) of the second, (S,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and naDorN, (TA,) [also of the second;] and naDarN, (K;) [of the third;] and ↓ A^anoDara; (IAar, L, K, TA;) It (a tree, A, K, and a plant, A, and foliage, TA, and a colour, K, and a face, IAar, S, Msb, K, and anything, TA,) was, or became, beautiful (S, Msb, K,) and bright: (S * [see naDorapN below] or, when said of a face, tropically used, (A,) signifying as above: (TA:) or (tropical:) it was, or became, beautiful and fresh: or beautiful and fine-skinned, so that the blood appeared [through the skin]: syn. Hasuna wagaD~a: (A:) or pleasant: (Fr:) and ↓ AnDr, said of a tree, its foliage became green. (TA.) ― -b2- [When said of a man, sometimes signifying He was, or became, in a state of enjoyment, or in a plentiful and pleasant and easy state of life; agreeably with a usage of naDara and ↓ naD~ara and ↓ A^anoDara to be mentioned below. And in like manner, when said of life, it signifies It was, or became plentiful and pleasant and easy.] -A2- naDarahu All~`hu, (IAar, S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
naDura , (Msb,) inf. n. naDorN; (TA;) and ↓ nD~rhu, (S, A, K,) or this has an intensive signification; (Msb;) and ↓ AnDrhu; (IAar, S, A, K;) when the pronoun relates to the face, (IAar, S, A,) in which case it is tropical, (A,) [or to a tree, or colour, as is implied in the K,] God made it beautiful (S, A, K,) and bright. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- When the pronoun relates to a man, the meaning (of the first of these three forms, as mentioned by En-Nadr and Sh and in the Mgh and TA, and of the ↓ second, as mentioned by As, and En-Nadr and Sh, &c., and of the ↓ third, as mentioned in the TA,) is God made him to have enjoyment, or plentiful and pleasant and easy life; syn. naE~amahu; (S, Mgh, Msb, TA;) or jaEalhu naADirFA [which signifies the same]: (A'Obeyd:) or naDarahu All~`h, (El-Azdee, Mgh,) and All~`h ↓ nD~rhu, (El-Hasan El-Muäddib, TA:) signifies (assumed tropical:) God made his rank, or station, good (El-Azdee, El-Hasan El-Muäddib, Mgh, TA,) among mankind: (El-Hasan El-Muäddib, TA:) not relating to beauty of the face; (ElAzdee, El-Hasan El-Muäddib, Mgh, TA:) but is similar to the saying, A^uTolubuwA AlHawaAy^ija A_ilaY HisaAni Alwujuwhi [which see explained in art. wjh]. (El-Hasan El-Muäddib, TA.) As cites this verse:
naD~ara A@ll~`hu A^aEoZumFA dafanuwhaA
bisijisotaAna TaloHapa AlT~alaHaAti
[May God grant enjoyment to bones which they have buried in Sijistán: (I mean) Talhat-et- Talahát]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., naDara A@ll~`hu EabodFA samiEa maqaAlatiY fawaEaAhaA vum~a A^ad~AhaA A_ilY mano yasomaEahaA, (Sh, S, * A, * Mgh, * TA,) or ↓ naD~ara, (Sh, S, in which latter we read A@moraA^a in the place of EbdA, and A, in which we find mano in the place of EbdA, and Mgh; the reading ↓ nD~r alone being given in the copies which I have of the S and A;) May God cause to have enjoyment, or a plentiful and pleasant and easy life, [the servant, or man, who hears what I say, and keeps it in mind, then conveys it to him who hears it:] (S, Mgh, in explanation of the latter reading, and TA, in explanation of both readings:) or (assumed tropical:) may God make to have a good rank or station &c. (Mgh, in explanation of the former reading.)
2 nD~rhu A@ll~`h * : see naDarahu, throughout.
4 AnDr * : see naDura, in two places. -A2- AnDrhu A@ll~`hu: see naDarahu, throughout.

naDorN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ nuDaArN (S, A, K, [in the CK naDaAr] and TA) and ↓ naDiyrN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ A^anoDaru (K [without tenween, though this is not shown in the K, as it is originally an epithet, though it may be obsolete as an epithet,]) Gold: (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ niDaArN: (Es-Sukkaree:) or silver; (K;) as also ↓ niSaArN: (Es-Sukkaree:) or generally the former: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] (of the first, S.) A^anoDurN, (S, K,) and [of mult.] niDaArN: (K:) or (so accord. to the S and A, but in the K, and) ↓ nuDaArN signifies what is pure, (S, A, K,) of gold &c., (A,) or of native or unwrought gold or silver, (Lth, K,) and of wood, (Lth,) or of anything: (S:) and is used as an epithet, applied to gold (TA:) and ↓ naDorapN [n. un. of naDorN] signifies a molten piece of gold. (TA.)
naDirN * : see naADirN.

naDorapN *
Beauty (S, Msb, K,) and brightness: (S, TA:) so in the Kur, lxxvi. 11. (Jel.) [The above explanation in the Msb and K, “ beauty, ” is evidently imperfect. Accord. to the Msb, the word is a simple subst., not an inf. n.] (assumed tropical:) Pleasantness of countenance. ― -b2- naDorapu ln~aEiymi (assumed tropical:) The beauty and brightness of aspect characteristic of enjoyment, or of a plentiful and pleasant and easy state of existence: so in the Kur, lxxx ii: 24: (Bd, Jel:) or the brightness, or glistening, and moisture (nadaA) [upon the skin] characteristic thereof. (Fr.) ― -b3- Enjoyment; or a plentiful and pleasant and easy life; syn. naEomapN [in the CK niEomap]. (A, K.) ― -b4- Richness; or competence or sufficiency. (A, K.) ― -b5- Life. (A, K.) -A2- See also naDorN.
nuDaArN * : see naDorN; each in two places. See also garabN.
niDaArN * : see naDorN; each in two places. See also garabN.
naDiyrN * : see naADirN, in two places: -A2- and see naDorN.

naADirN * (A, L, K) and ↓ naDiyrN (A, L, Msb, K) and ↓ naDirN, (A, L,) [being epithets from naDara and naDura and naDira, respectively,] and ↓ A^anoDaru, accord. to the K, but in the place of this we find in the corresponding passage in the L the verb A^anoDara, with the addition “ is like naDara, ” (TA,) Beautiful
(Msb, K) and bright. (TA.) So in the Kur, lxxv. 22, wujuwhN yawomay^i*K naADirapN (assumed tropical:) Faces on that day shall be beautiful and bright: (Bd, Jel:) or shining by reason of enjoyment, or of a beautiful and pleasant and easy state of existence. (Fr.) [These epithets have also other, similar, significations, shown by explanations of naDura and its variations.] naADirN is coupled with gaD~N, as an epithet applied to a boy, (A,) and so ↓ naDiyrN; (TA,) and naADrapN with gaD~apN, applied to a girl, (A,) and so naDiyrapN; (TA;) and thus used are tropical. (A.) ― -b2- naADirN also signifies Intense in greenness: (K:) you say A^axoDaru naADirN [intense, or bright, green], (S, K,) like as you say A^aSofaru faAqiEN and A^aboyaDu naASiEN: (S:) and in like manner it is used as an intensive epithet applied to any colour: you say A^aHomaru naADirN [intense, or bright, red], and A^aSofaru naADirN [intense, or bright, yellow]: (K:) so says IAar: (TA:) or A^axoDaru naASirN signifies smooth green, accord. to A'Obeyd, and Az adds, glistening in its clearness. (TA.)
A^anoDaru * : see naDorN: -A2- and see naADirN.

div2.head: nDf &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement
1 naTaA^a bisaloHihi * : see vTA^.]

1 naTabahu * (aor.
naTuba , inf. n. naTobN, TA,) He struck [or fillipped] his ear with his finger. (K.) ↓ AnTb A^u*unahu, and A^anoqara, and bal~aTa, signify the same. (AA.)
3 naATabahumo * , (inf. n. munaATabapN, TA,) He incited them against each other, (K,) and acted in an evil or mischievous manner towards them. (TA.)
4 A^anoTaba see 1.

naTobapN *
i. q. naTomapN, i. e., A single act of piercing, or pecking, with the beak, of a cock, &c. (Az.)

niTaAbN * The head. (Th, K.) Respecting the saying of El-Jo'eyd El-Murádee,
naHonu DarabonaAhu ElY niTaAbihi
ISk says, No one has explained it, and the reading better known is ElY taToyaAbihi, meaning “ notwithstanding the sweetness (Tiyb) that was in him: ” for the man spoken of was going in to a bride of the tribe of Murád: but accord. to some, nTAb here signifies The tendon of the neck; syn. Habolu AlEunuqi; so in the K, on the authority of Aboo- 'Adnán alone; or Hbl AlEaAtiqi, accord. to IAar, who cites this verse:
naHonu DarabonaAhu EalaY niTaAbihi
qulonaA bihi qulonaA bihi qulonaA bihi
[We smote him on the tendon of the upper part of his shoulders: we slew him: we slew him: we slew him]. qlnA bh signifies qatalonaAhu. (TA.)

naATibpN * , and naATibN, sing. of nawaATibu in the following sense: (TA:) The holes that are made in a thing with which one clears, or clarifies, [i. e. strains, or filters], and through which what is cleared [or strained] passes forth: (K:) the holes of a strainer for wine, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- See minoTabN.
minoTabN * and minoTabapN and ↓ naATibN A strainer; a colander. (K.)

manoTabapN *
Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (K:) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)

1 naTaHahu * , aor.
naTiHa and
naTaHa , (S, K,) inf. n. naToHN, (S,) He (a ram, S, L, and the like, L) smote him with his horn. (K.) ― -b2- maA naTaHato fiyhi jam~aA='a *aAtu qaronK [A horned animal did not smite with its horn for him a hornless ewe]: a proverb, said of him who has perished unavenged. (L.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 507.] ― -b3- naTaHahu Eanohu (tropical:) He pushed him, or thrust him, away from him, and removed him. (A.)

3 naATaHaA * , inf. n. niTaAHN (L, Msb) and munaATaHapN, (Msb,) They two (rams or he-goats) smote each other with their horns. (L.) ― -b2- bayonahumaA niTaAHN (tropical:) [Between them two is a contention like that of two rams]; said of two learned men, and of two merchants. (A.) ― -b3- jaraY lanaA fiY Als~uwqi niTaAHN (tropical:) [There happened to us in the market a contention like that of two rams]. (A.) ― -b4- [naATaHahu He, or it, faced, or was or came opposite to him, or it]: niTaAHN is syn. with muqaAbalapN in the dial. of El-Hijáz. (TA.)
6 tanaAoTaHa see 8. ― -b2- tanaATaHati AlA^amowaAju, and Als~uyuwlu, (tropical:) [The waves, and the torrents, conflicted, or dashed together.] (A.)

8 AntTHti AlkibaA$u * , and ↓ tnATHt, (S, K,) The rams smote one another with their horns. (K.) ― -b2- laA yanoTiHu fiyhaA EanozaAni [Two she-goats will not, in it, smite each other with their horns]: i. e., two weak persons will not encounter each other in it: alluding to a case in which there will not happen any discord or contention. (L, from a trad.)
naTuwHN * : see naT~aAHN.

naTiyHN *
Smitten with the horn and so killed: fem. with p: (L, K:) pl. naToHaY (L) and naTaAy^iHu: (Lh, L:) you say also naEojapN naTiyHN, as well as nTyHp. (L.) ― -b2- Also naTiyHapN A sheep or goat (Az) smitten with the horn and so killed. (Az, S,) and of which the flesh is therefore unlawful to be eaten: (Az:) the p is added because it is made a subst., not an epithet: (Az:) or because the quality of a subst. predominates in it, as in the case of fariysapN and A^akiylapN and ramiy~apN. (S.) ― -b3- naTiyHN and ↓ naATiHN (tropical:) What comes to thee from before thee, (or faces thee, L,) of birds and wild animals (S, L, K) &c., which one rouses by throwing a stone or by crying out, and from the course of which one augurs evil or good: (L:) contr. of qaEiydN. (S.) [The nTyH or ↓ nATH is of evil omen.] ― -b4- Hence, (TA,) naTiyHN (tropical:) An unfortunate, or unlucky, man. (K.) ― -b5- naTiyHN A horse having a blaze, or white mark on his face, extending to one of his ears, which is deemed unlucky: (L:) or a horse having on his forehead two circular or spiral curls of hair (daAy^irataAni), which are disliked: (S, L, K:) if there be but one, it is called daAy^irapu All~aTaApi; and this is not disliked; (S;) or it is called laTomapN; and the horse, laTiymN. (L.)

kabo$N naT~aAHN * [A ram that smites much with his horn]: (S:) and ↓ naTuwHN [signifies the same: and] is applied to a man [app. as meaning who pushes, thrusts, or repels, much, or vehemently]. (IAar, TA in art. rds.)

daAy^irapu Aln~aATiHi *
A certain circular or spiral curl of hair on a horse, which is deemed unlucky. (L.) [See naTiyHN.] ― -b2- naATiHN (tropical:) A difficulty; a distressing event; an affliction; a calamity: pl. nawaATiHu. (S, K.) Ex. A^aSaAbahu naATiHN A difficulty, or distressing event, befell him. (S.) nawaATiHu Ald~ahori The difficulties, &c., of fortune. (S.) ― -b3- Aln~aToHu waAln~aATiHu (tropical:) [The two stars called] Al$~araTaAni, [q. v.,] which are [the two stars in] the two horns of Aries: (S, K:) [the first of the Mansions of the Moon: the latter is b, and the former a:] ISd says, that ↓ Aln~aToHu is a star which is one of the Mansions of the Moon, and from [the auroral rising of] which one augurs evil: and IAar says, that one says, naToHN and Aln~aToHu, without and with Al; and the like in the case of the name of any of the Mansions of the Moon. (TA.) The Arabs said A_i*aA TalaEa Aln~aToHu TaAba Als~aToHu (tropical:) [When En-Nat-h rises aurorally, the house-top becomes pleasant as a place on which to sit in the evening, or on which to sleep]. (A.) ― -b4- maA lahu naATiHN walaA xaAbiTN He has neither sheep, or goat, nor camel. (S, K.)

1 naTara * , (IKtt, Msb,) aor.
naTura , (TA,) inf. n. naTorN
(IKtt, Msb, K) and niTaArapN, (Sgh, K,) He kept, or watched, vines, (IKtt, Msb, K,) and palmtrees, (K,) and seed-produce. (TA.) See naTorapN and naATuwrN.
naTorapN * , with the unpointed T, signifies The act of guarding, or watching with the eyes: and hence the word ↓ naATuwrN. (IAar, Msb, TA.)

naToruwnN * , with fet-h, [Natron;] the Armenian baworaq, or buwraq; (thus differently written here in different copies of the K;) or [rather] the Egyptian buwraq: (K, art. brq:) the best kind [of bwrq] is the Armenian, which is soft, or fragile, light, and white: then the rose-coloured: and the strongest is the Ifreekee: there is a kind found in Egypt, in two places: one of these is in the western part of the country, in the neighbourhood of a district called Et-Tarráneh; and it is transparent, green and red; the green being the more in request; the other is in [the district called] El-Fákooseeyeh; and this is not so good as the former. (TA.) [See also baworaqN.]

nuT~aArN *
A scarecrow (xayaAlN) set up in the midst of seed-produce. (Sgh, K.)
naATirN * : see naATuwrN.

naATuwrN *
A keeper, or watcher, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) of vines, (S, K,) and of palm-trees, (K,) and of seed-produce: (Msb, TA:) as also ↓ naATuwrapN (ElBári', Msb) and ↓ naATirN: (S, K:) pl. (of the first, TA) nawaATiyru (Az, S, A, Msb, K) and (of the last, TA) niTaArN and nuTaraA='u and naTarapN: (K:) it is a foreign word, (A^aEojamiY~N, K,) not pure Arabic, (TA,) of the dial. of the people of Es-Sawád: (Lth, Msb, TA:) Az says, I know not whether it be taken from the language of the people of Es-Sawád or be Arabic: (TA:) accord. to AHn, it is Arabic: (TA:) and IAar says, that it is from naTorapN, meaning as explained above: (Msb, TA:) IDrd says, that it is with Z, (A, Msb,) from Aln~aZaru; (A;) but in the language of the Nabatheans with T; (Msb;) that the Nabatheans change the former letter into T. (A.)
naATuwrapN * : see naATuwrN.

1 naTisa * , aor.
naTasa , (S, K,) inf. n. naTasN, (S,) He was, or became, learned, or knowing, (K,) in affairs, and skilful therein: (TA:) or he exa mined things minutely, and attained the utmost knowledge of them. (S.)

4 maA A^anoTasahu *
How intelligent and knowing is he in affairs! (TA.)

5 tnT~s *
He took extraordinary pains, or exceeded the usual bounds, in cleansing or purifying himself, or in removing himself far from unclean things or impurities: (As, S:) or he shunned, or removed himself far from, unclean things: (M, A, K:) and he was dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice, and exact, syn. taA^at~aqa, (As, M, A, K,) in cleanliness; (K;) and in speech, (A, K,) so as never to speak otherwise than chastely; (TA;) and in diet and apparel, (A, K,) so as never to eat or wear anything but what was clean, (A,) or so as never to eat anything but what was clean nor wear anything but what was good; (TA;) and in all affairs. (K.) It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, lawo laA Alt~anaT~asu maA baAlayotu A^al~aA A^agosila yadiY, (S, M,) i. e., Were it not for the being scrupulously nice and exact, I had not cared for my not washing my hand. (M.) ― -b2- tnT~s fiyhi He examined it (anything) minutely. (A.) ― -b3- tnT~s AlA^axobaAra, (S,) or Eani AlA^axobaAri, (M, A,) He searched, or sought, for, or after, news, or tidings; searched or inquired into, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, news, or tidings. (S, M, A.)
naTosN * : see naTisN; the former, in two places; and the latter, in four.
naTusN * : see naTisN; the former, in two places; and the latter, in four.

naTisN *
Learned, or knowing; (A, K;) as also ↓ naTusN (K) and ↓ naTosN (A, K) and ↓ niTaAsiY~N and ↓ naTaAsiY~N: (K:) or learned, or knowing, in affairs, and skilful therein: as also ↓ naTusN and ↓ naTosN: (ISk, TA:) intelligent, or skilful, and scrupulously nice and exact (mutanaw~iqN), in affairs: (A:) or one who examines things minutely, and attains the utmost knowledge of them: as also ↓ naTusN and ↓ mutanaT~isN: (S:) or learned, or knowing, in affairs: skilful in physic &c.: as also ↓ naTusN and ↓ niT~iysN and ↓ niTaAsiY~N: (M:) or ↓ niT~ysN (S, A, K, TA) and ↓ niTaAsiY~N (S, TA) and ↓ naTaAsiY~N, (A'Obeyd, S,) a student of physic, (S, K, TA,) who examines it minutely; (TA;) or learned, or knowing, in physic; in Greek nusoTaAs [ γνώστης]: (A, TA: *) and ↓ mutanaT~isN one who is dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact (mutanaw~iqN), and who chooses or selects [what is best]; (IAar;) or any one who takes extraordinary pains, or exceeds the usual bounds, in a thing: (M:) also ↓ naTiysN, [without teshdeed,] a skilful man: (TA:) and ↓ nuTusN, [pl. of naTisN or naTusN or naTosN,] skilful physicians. (A, K.) ― -b2- Also, One who shuns, or removes himself far from, unclean things; (K, TA;) who is scrupulously nice and exact (mutaA^an~iqN) in affairs: (TA:) and naTisapN a woman who shuns, or removes herself far from, foul, evil, or unseemly, things: (AA, TA.) and nuTusN, [pl. of naTisN,] men who do thus: (K, TA:) and ↓ nuTasapN a man who shuns much, or removes himself very far from, unclean things, and is very dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact (kaviyru Alt~A^an~uqi) in cleanliness, and in speech, and in diet and apparel, and in all affairs. (K, * TA.) See 5.
nuTusN * : see naTisN, throughout.
nuTasapN * : see naTisN, throughout.
naTiysN * : see naTisN, throughout.
niaTaAsiY~N * : see naTisN, throughout.
niT~iysN * : see naTisN, throughout.

naATisN * , (accord. to one copy of the S, and the L, and the CK, and a MS. copy of the K,) or ↓ naATuwsN, (accord. to the TA. as from the K,) or both, (accord. to one copy of the S,) A spy, who searches for news, or tidings, and then brings them. (S, L, K, TA.)
naATuwsN * : see naATsN.
mutanaT~isN * : see naTisN, in two places.
naTo$aAnu * an imitative sequent to EaTo$aAnu; (S, K;) not used alone. (S, art. ET$.)

div2.head: nTE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 naZara A_ilayohi * , (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and naZarahu, (M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
naZura , (M, A, &c.,) and A^anoTuwrN is substituted for A^anoZuru in the dial. of certain Arabs, (IDrd, TS, K,) or, accord. to Lb, in the Bughyetel-Ámál, the w is here added only [by poetic license,] to make the sound of the dammeh full, agreeably with other instances; (TA;) and naZira A_ilayohi, and naZirahu, aor.
naZara , (A, K,) the verb being like samiEa accord. to the correct copies of the K, [and so in the A,] but in one copy of the K, like Daraba; (TA;) inf. n. naZarN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and naZorN is allowable, as a contraction of the former, (Lth,) and naZaraAnN (S, K,) and manoZarN (M, A, K) and manoZarapN and tanoZArN, (M, K,) [which last is an intensive form; He looked at, or towards, in order to see, him, or it;] he considered, or viewed, him or it with his eye; (S, A, K;) with the sight of the eye; (Msb;) [i. e. looked at him or it;] as also ↓ tnZ~rhu: (K:) and ↓ AntZrhu signifies the same as tnZ~rhu and naZarahu [but app. in another sense, to be mentioned below, and not in the sense explained above, though the latter is implied in the TA; and the same may be meant when it is said that ↓ tnZ~r is syn. with naZara, if this assertion, which I find in the M, have been copied
without consideration, and be not confirmed by an example]: (TA:) or naZara A_ilayohi signifies he extended, or stretched, or raised, [or directed,] his sight towards him or it, whether he saw him or did not see him. (TA.) The usage of Aln~aZarN as relating to the sight is most common with the vulgar, but not with persons of distinction, who use it more in another sense, to be explained below. (TA.) You say, naZara A_ilayohi naZorapF HulowapF [He looked at him, or towards him, with one sweet look.] (A.) And naZara fiY AlminoZaAri [He looked in the mirror]. (A.) And naZara fiY AlkitaAbi [He looked into, or inspected, the writing or book], (A, Msb,) which is for naZara Almakotuwba fiY AlkitaAbi [he looked at what was written in the writing or book], or has a different meaning to be explained below. (Msb.) And huwa yanoZuru Hawolahu [lit., He looks around him; meaning,] he looks much. (A.) [See also naZarN below.] ― -b2- naZarati AlA^aroDu, (Sgh, K,) and naZarati AlA^aroDu biEayonK, and biEayonayoni, (A,) (tropical:) The earth, or land, showed (A, Sgh, K) to the eye (Sgh, K) its plants or herbage. (A, Sgh, K.) ― -b3- naZara A_ilayohi (tropical:) It looked towards, meaning faced, him or it. So in the Kur, [vii. 197,] wataraAhumo yanoZuruwna A_ilayoka wahumo laA yuboSiruwna (tropical:) Thou seest them look towards thee, i. e., face thee, but they see not; referring to idols, accord. to A'Obeyd. (TA.) And you say, daAriY yanoZuru A_ilaY daAri fulaAnK (tropical:) My house faces the house of such a one. (S.) And naZara A_ilayoka Aljabalu (tropical:) The mountain faced thee: (A:) as in the following ex.: A_i*aA A^axa*ota fiY Tariyqi ka*aA fanaZara A_ilayoka Aljabalu faxu*o Eano yamiynihi A^awoyasaArihi (tropical:) [When thou takest such a road, and the mountain faces thee, then take thou the way by the right of it or the left of it.] (S.) ― -b4- [Hence, perhaps,] naZara Ald~ahoru A_ilaY baniY fulaAnK faA^aholakahumo [app. meaning, (assumed tropical:) Fortune opposed the sons of such a one and destroyed them]: (S [immediately following there the ex. which immediately precedes it here:]) or naZara A_ilayohimu Ald~ahoru signifies (tropical:) Fortune destroyed them: (M, A:) but (says ISd) I am not certain of this. (M.) ― -b5- Aln~aZaru also signifies (assumed tropical:) The turning the mind in various directions in order to perceive a thing [mentally], and the seeing a thing: and sometimes it means (assumed tropical:) the considering and investigating: [and as a subst., speculation, or intellectual examination:] and sometimes, (assumed tropical:) the knowledge that results from [speculation or] investigation. (El-Basáïr.) It is mostly used as relating to the intellect by persons of distinction; and as relating to the sight, most commonly by the vulgar. (TA.) [It is said that] when you say naZarotu A_ilayohi, it means only [I looked at, or towards, him or it] with the eye: but when you say naZarotu fiY AlA^amori, it may mean [(assumed tropical:) I looked into, inspected, examined, or investigated, the thing or affair] by thought and consideration, intellectually, or with the mind: (TA:) [this remark, however, is not altogether correct, as may be seen from what follows: the truth seems to be, that naZarahu and naZaraA_ilayohi may be used in the latter of these two senses, though naZara fiyhi is most common in this sense.] It is said in the Kur, [x. 101,] quli A@noZuruwA maA *aA fiY Als~am`waAti (assumed tropical:) Say, Consider ye what is in the heavens. (TA.) And you say, naZara A_ilayohi He saw it, and (assumed tropical:) thought upon it, and endeavoured to understand it, or to know its result. (TA.) [And He looked to it, or at it, or examined it, intellectually; regarded it; had a view to it.] And naZara fiyhi (assumed tropical:) He considered it: (TA:) or thought upon it; namely a writing or book; or when such is the object it may have another meaning, explained before; and an affair: and with this is held to accord the saying wafiyhi naZarN, q. v. infrà, voce naZarN: (Msb:) and (tropical:) he though upon it, measuring it, or comparing it. (M, K, TK. In the M and K, only the inf. n., naZara fiY A^amowaAli AlA^ayotaAmi, of the verb in this sense is mentioned.) And fanaTara naZorapF fiY Aln~ujuwmi (assumed tropical:) He considered, or examined, [or estimated,] the possessions of the orphans, in order to know them. (Msb.) And similar to this is the phrase [in the Kur, xxxvii. 86,] Aln~aZaru, meaning, (assumed tropical:) And he examined the science of the stars: (Msb:) [or he took a mental view of the stars, as if to divine from them.] AlAiEotibaAru when used unrestrictedly by those who treat of scholastic theology means AlAiEotibaAru [(assumed tropical:) The thinking upon a thing, and endeavouring to understand it, or to know its result; or judging of what is hidden from what is apparent; or reasoning from analogy]. (MF.) ― -b6- naZara bayonahumo, inf. n. naZarN, [app. for naZara fiY maA bayonahumo,] (assumed tropical:) He judged between them. (K.) ― -b7- naZarato, (TA,) inf. n. naZarN, (assumed tropical:) She practised divination; (K, * TA;) which is a kind of examination with insight and skill. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b8- A^unoZuro liY fulaAnFA (tropical:) [look thou out for such a one for me;] seek thou for me such a one. (A, TA.) ― -b9- A^unoZuroniY (assumed tropical:) Listen thou to me. (M, K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, A^unoTironiY.]) The verb [says ISd] has this meaning in the Kur, ii. 98. (M.) ― -b10- A^anaA A^anoZuru A_ilaY A@ll~`hi vum~a A_ilayoka [lit., I look to God, then to thee; meaning,] (tropical:) I look for the bounty of God, then for thy bounty. (A.) ― -b11- naZara A@ll~`hu A_ilayohi (tropical:) God chose him, and compassionated him, pitied him, or regarded him with mercy; because looking at another is indicative of love, and not doing so is indicative of hatred: (IAth:) or (assumed tropical:) God bestowed benefits upon him; poured blessings, or favours, upon him: (El-Basáïr:) and naZara lahumo (tropical:) he compassionated them, and aided them; (Sgh, K;) and simply, he aided them: (K, * TA:) and naZara lahu (assumed tropical:) he accomplished his want, or that which he (another) wanted. (Msb.) -A2- naZarahu is also syn. with ↓ A_itonaZarahu, q. v. ― -b2- Also syn. with A^anoZarahu, q. v. ― -b3- Also naZarahu, (K, TA,) inf. n. naZorN; (TA;) or ↓ naZ~arahu; (so in a copy of the M, and in the CK; but from the mention of the inf. n. in the TA, the former seems to be the right reading;) He sold it (a thing, M) with postponement of the payment; he sold it upon credit. (M, * K, * TA.) See also 4. ― -b4- [In these last three acceptations, accord. to the A, the verb is used properly, not tropically.] -A3- nuZira He was, or became, affected by what is termed a naZorap; (K, TA;) i. e., a stroke of an [evil] eye; (TA;) [or of an evil eye cast by a jinnee;] or a touch, or slight taint of insanity, from the jinn; (K;) or a swoon. (K, TA.)
2 naZ~ara see 1, last signification but one. ― -b2- nZ~r fiyhi [He said of it fiyhi naZarN, q. v.]. (TA passim.)

3 naAZarahu fiY A^amorK * , inf. n. munaAZarapN, (T, S, *) (tropical:) He considered, or examined, or investigated, with him a thing or an affair, to see how they should do it: (T, TA:) he investigated, or examined, with him a thing, and emulated him, or vied with him, in doing so, each of them adducing his opinion: (TA:) [he held a discussion with him respecting a thing:] or naAZarahu is syn. with jaAdalahu: (Msb:) or mnAZrp signifies the examining mentally, or investigating, by two parties, the relation between two things, in order to evince the truth; (KT; and Kull, p. 342;) and sometimes with one's self; but mjAdlp signifies the disputing respecting a question of science for the purpose of convincing the opponent, whether what he says be wrong in itself or not. (Kull.) ― -b2- Also nAZrhu [(tropical:) He, or it, looked towards, or faced, him, or it; was opposite, or corresponded, to him or it. (See naZiyrN.)] ― -b3- (tropical:) He was, or became, like him: (A, K:) or like him in discourse or dialogue. (TA.) ― -b4- jayo$N yunaAZiru A^alofFA (tropical:) An army that is nearly equal to a thousand. (A.) ― -b5- naAZara fulaAnFA bifulaAnK (tropical:) He made, or called, such a one like such a one. (K.) Hence the saying of Ez-Zuhree, (K,) Mohammad Ibn-Shiháb, (TA,) laA tunaAZiro bikitaAbi A@ll~`hi walaA bikalaAmi rasuwli A@ll~`hi, i. e., Thou shalt not call anything like the book of God, nor like the words of the apostle of God: (A'Obeyd, T, K:) or thou shalt not compare anything, nor call anything like, to the book of God, &c.: (A,) or thou shalt not apply [aught of] the book of God, nor the words of the apostle of God, as a proverb to a thing that happens: (A'Obeyd, T, K; in which last, we read li$aYo'K ligaraDK, in the place of the right reading, li$aYo'K yaEoriDu: TA:) for, as Ibráheem En-Nakha'ee says, they used to dislike the mentioning a verse of the Kur-án on the occasion of anything happening, of worldly events; (T;) as a person's saying to one who has come at a time desired by the former, (TA,) or to one named Moosà, who
has come at a time desired, (K,) jiy^ota EalaY qadarK yaA muwsaY [Thou hast come at a time appointed, O Moosà: (Kur, xx. 42:)] (T, K:) and the like: (T:) but the first explanation is the most probable (TA, as from Az; but I do not find it in the T)

4 A^unoZira bihi * (tropical:) [He, or it, was made like]. You say, maA kaAna h`*aA naZiyrFA lih`*aA walaqado A^unoZira bihi (tropical:) [This was not like this, but has been made like]. (T, K:) like as you say, maA kaAna xaZiyrFA lahu walaqado A^uxoTira bihi. (T.) -A2- AnZrhu He postponed him; delayed him: (M, A, Msb, K:) he granted him a delay or respite; let him alone, or left him, for a while: (T, TA:) as, for instance, a debtor, (T, Msb, TA,) and a man in difficult circumstances: (TA:) and ↓ naZarahu signifies the same. (Msb.) You say, biEotuhu $ayoy^FA faA^anoZarotuhu I sold to him a thing, and granted him a delay. (T.) And a person speaking says to him who hurries him, A^anoZironY A^abotaliEo riyqiY Grant me time to swallow my spittle. (T.) And it is said in the Kur, [xv. 36 and xxxviii. 80,] faA^anoZironiY A_ilaY yawomi yuboEavuwna Then delay me until the day when they shall be raised from the dead. (TA.) See also 8. ― -b2- He sold to him a thing with postponement of the payment; he sold to him a thing upon credit. (M.) See also 1 last signification but one.
5 tanaZ~ara see 1, first signification. -A2- See also 8.

6 tnAZrA * (tropical:) They faced each other. (K.) You say, tnAZrt Ald~aAraAni (tropical:) The two houses faced each other. (M.) And duwrunaA tanaAZaru, (S,) or tatanaAZaru, [which is the original form,] (A,) (tropical:) Our houses faced one another. (S, A.) ― -b2- See also taraAwaDaA.

8 AntZrh * : see 1, first sentence. -A2- He looked for him; expected him; awaited him; waited for him; watched for his presence; syn. Airotaqaba HuDuwrahu; (TA;) and taA^an~aY Ealayohi; (M, K;) and ↓ naZarahu (aor.
naZura , T &c., inf. n. naZarN S, K) signifies the same; (T, M, A, Msb, K;) and so ↓ tnZr~hu, (M, A, K,) and ↓ A^anoZarahu; (Zj, TA;) [but respecting the last two, see what is said below:] but when you say AntZr without any objective complement, the meaning is, [he waited; or] he paused, and acted or behaved with deliberation, or in a patient, or leisurely, manner. (Lth, T.) It is said in the Kur, [lvii. 13,] AunoZuruwnaA naqotbiso mino nuwrikumo Wait for us (AinotaZiruwnaA) that me may take of your light: and accord. to Zj, A^anoZiruwnaA [which is another reading] is said to mean the same: or the latter means delay us: accord. to Fr, however, the Arabs say A^anoZironiY meaning Wait thou for me (AinotaZironiY) a little, (T.) ↓ Alt~anaZ~uru also signifies The expecting, or waiting for a thing: (TA:) or the expecting, or waiting for, a thing expected: (M, K, TA:) or ↓ tnZ~rhu signifies he expected, or waited for, (AntZr,) him, or it, leisurely, and so ↓ AstnZrhu. (S.) You say also, AntZr bihi xayorFA A^awo $ar~aA (M, A, K, in art. rbS, in the last of which is added yaHul~N bihi) [He looked for expected, awaited, or waited for, something good or evil to befall him, or betide him]
10 AstnZrhu * : see 8, last signification but one ― -b2- He asked of him, or desired of him, a postponement, or delay. (M, A, K.)

niZorN * : see naZiyrN. -A2- A man says to another, bayoEN, [or perhaps biyEN, like the word used in reply to it. here following and like xiTobN and nikoHN meaning, I sell and the other says, niZorN, meaning, Grant me a delay (A^anoZironiY) that I may buy (A^a$otariY) of thee. (M, TA.)

naZarN * : see 1. [Used as a subst., as well as when used as an inf. n.,] it has no pl. (Sb, in TA, voce fikorN.) ― -b2- DarabonaAhumo binaZar, and mino naZari, (tropical:) We saw them. (A, TA.) ― -b3- bayonanaA naZarN (tropical:) Between as is the extent of a look in expect of ?? (A, TA.) ― -b4- HaY~N naZarN, (K, * TA,) and HaY~N jilaAlN wanaZarN, (S,) and HaY~N HilaAlN wariyaA='N wanaZarN, (A,) (tropical:) A tribe went together, (S, A, K, *) of which the several portions see one another. (S, A.) ― -b5- wafiyhi naZarN (assumed tropical:) But it requires consideration, by reason of its want of clearness, or perspicuity: (Msb:) [a phrase used to imply doubt, and also to insinuate politely that the words to which it relates are false, or wrong:] like fiyhi taA^am~ulN. (MF, art. SfH.) ― -b6- huwa bixayori Aln~aZaryoni, said in a trad., of one who has purchased a ewe or she-goat that has been kept from being milked for some days; meaning, (assumed tropical:) He has the option of adopting the better of the two things; he may either retain it or return it. (TA.)

naZorapN *
A look: a quick look or glance: (T:) pl. naZaraAtN. (A.) Hence the trad., laA tutobiEi Aln~aTorapa Aln~aZorapa faA_in~a laka AlA^uwolaY walayosato laka AlA=xirapu [Thou shalt not make a look to follow a look; for the former is thine or right, lad the latter is not thine: i. e., when thou hast once looked at anything forbidden, unintentionally, thou shalt not look at it a second time]. (T, TA.) And the saying of a certain wise man, mano lamo taEomalo naZoratuhu lamo yaEomalo lisaAnuhu [He whose look does not produce an effect, his tongue does not produce an effect]; (T;) meaning, that he who is not restrained from a fault or offence by being looked at is not restrained by speech. (TA.) ― -b2- A stroke of an [evil] eye: (TA:) a stroke of an [evil] eye by which one is affected from the jinn's looking at him; (T, S; *) as also safoEapN: (T;) or a touch, or a slight taint or infection of insanity. (TaAy^ifN,) from the jinn: or a swoon. (M, K.) ― -b3- An alteration of the body or complexion by emaciation or hunger or travel &c. (S, M, K.) ― -b4- Foulness; ugliness: (AA, TA:) evilness; or badness, of form or appearance; a fault: a defect; an imperfection. (M, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Reverence, veneration, awe, or fear, (I Aar, T, K,) ― -b6- (tropical:) Compassion, pity, merry. (I Aar, T, K,)

naZirapN *
A postponement; a delay. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur. [ii. 280.] fanaZrapN A_ilaY mayosarapK [Then let there be a postponement, or delay, until he shall be in an easy state of circumstances]; (T, M, Msb) a. c., faA_inoZaArN, (T,) or fataA^oxiyrN: (Msb) and accord. to another reading, ↓ fanaAZirapN, like kaA*ibapN, in the Kur, lvi. 2. (M.) You say also, baAEa minohu Al$~aYo'a binaZirapK He sold to him the thing with postponement of the payment, he sold to him the thing upon credit. (M.) And Ai$otarayotuhu minohu binaZirapK, and biA_inoZaArK, I bought a of him with postponement of the payment; I bought a of him upon credit. (T.)
