naZariY~N * (assumed tropical:) [Speculative knowledge or science; such as is acquired by study;] that of which the origination rests upon speculation. and acquisition by study; as the conception of the intellect or mind, and the assent of the mind or the position, that the world has had a ??? (K, T.) [It is opposed to badiyhiYN and to SrwriY~N.]
sumoEun~apN nuZorun~apN * , and vars. thereof, see in art. smE.
naZaAri * , like qaTaAmi, (S, K,) an imp. n., (T.) meaning, Wait thou: syn A_inotaZiro. (T, S, K.)

naZuwrN * and ↓ naZuwrapN and ↓ naAZuwrapN and ↓ nuZiyrapN A chief person, whether male or female, to whom one looks. (M, K.) You say, ↓ fulaAnN naZiyrapN qawomihi, and qawomihi ↓ naZuwrapu, Such a one is the person to whom his people look, (Fr, T, S,) and whom they imitate, or to whose example they conform. (Fr, T.) All these words are also used in a pl. sense: (M, K:) or [so in some copies of the K; but in others, and,] nZyrp and nZwrp have naZaAy^iru for their pl., (S, K,) sometimes. (K.) ― -b2- Also, naZuwrN A man who neglects not to look at, (M, L, K,) or to consider, (A,) that which, (M, A, L,) or him who, (K,) disquiets him, or renders him solicitous. (M, A, L, K.)

naZiyrN * (tropical:) Looking to, or facing, another person or thing; opposite or corresponding to another person or thing; as also ↓ munaAZirN; syn. muqaAbilN. (A.) [Hence, naZiyru Als~amoti, and Aln~aZiyru, (tropical:) The nadir; the point opposite to the zenith.] naZiyruka signifies A^al~a*iY yunaAZiruka, (M,) or Al*Y tunaAZiruhu wayunaAZiruka, (T,) [which I suppose to mean (tropical:) He who looks towards, or faces, thee; who is opposite, or corresponds, to thee; or he towards whom thou lookest, &c., and who looks towards thee, &c.: though susceptible of other interpretations: see 3.] ― -b2- (tropical:) Like; a like; a similar person or thing: (AO, T, S, M, A, K;) equal; an equal: (Msb:) applied to anything: (TA:) as also ↓ niZorN; (AO, S, K;) like nadiydN and nid~N; (AO, S;) and ↓ munaAZirN: (K:) fem. naZiyrapN: (T, M, A:) pl. masc., nuZaraA='u: (M, A, Msb, K:) and pl. fem. naZaAy^iru, (T, A,) applied to words and to all things. (T.) You say, fulaAnN naZiyruka (tropical:) Such a one is thy like. (T.) And h`*aA naZiyrN lih`*aA, (T,) or naZiyru h`*aA, (Msb,) (tropical:) This is the like of this, (T,) or the equal of this. (Msb.) And Eadadotu A_ibila fulaAnK naZaAy^ira (tropical:) I counted, or numbered, the camels of such a one in pairs, or two by two; (As, T, K; *) if by looking at their aggregate, you say, EadadotuhaA jamaArFA. (As, T.)
naZuwrapN * : see naZuwrN, in two places. ― -b2- See also naZiyrapN.

naZiyrapN * : see naZuwrN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, A scout, or scouts; (T, Sgh, K;) and so ↓ naZuwrapN: (Sgh, K:) pl. of both, naZaAy^iru. (TA.) ― -b3- Fem. of naZiyrN, q. v. (T, &c.). [And hence,] Aln~aZaAy^iru [the pl.] The more excellent of men: (K, * TA:) because they resemble one another in dispositions and actions and sayings. (TA.)
naZ~aArN * (tropical:) A horse (A, K) that raises his eye by reason of his sharpness of spirit: (A:) or sharpspirited, and raising his eye. (T, K.)

naZ~aArapN *
A people looking at a thing; (S, K;) as also ↓ manoZarapN. (K.) ― -b2- See also minoZaArN.

naAZirN * act. part. n. of naZara; Looking; &c.: pl. nuZ~aArN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Aln~aAZiru [The pupil, or apple, of the eye, the smallest black of the eye, (S, Msb,) in which is [seen] what is termed A_inosaAnu AlEayoni, (S,) [and] with which the man sees; (Msb;) the black spot in the eye; (M, K;) the clear black spot that is in the middle of the [main] black of the eye, with which the looker sees what he sees: or that part of the eye which resembles a mirror, in which, when one faces it, he sees his person: (TA:) or a duct (Eiroq) in the nose, wherein is the water of sight: (M, K:) [app. a loose description of the optic nerve:] or the sight itself: (M, K:) or the eye: (K:) or the eye is called ↓ Aln~aAZirapu; (S, A; *) the pl. of which is nawaAZiru. (A.) ― -b3- $adiydu Aln~aAZiri, (so in a copy of the M and of the A and in some copies of the K,) or sadiydu Aln~aAZiri, (so in some copies of the K and in the TA,) A man clear of suspicion, who looks with a full gaze: (M, K:) or clear of that with which he is upbraided. (A.) ― -b4- Aln~aAZiraAni Two veins at the two edges of the nose, commencing from the inner angles of the eyes, towards the face. (Zj, in his Khalk el-Insán.) ― -b5- Also, naAZirN (assumed tropical:) A guardian; a keeper; a watcher: (S, Msb:) and, as also ↓ naAZuwrN, i. q. naATuwrN, (K, TA,) [which last is] a word of the Nabathean dialect. (TA.) ― -b6- [The dim. is nuwayoZirN.] You say, EuyayonatiY nuwayoZirapN A_ilaY A@ll~`hi vum~a A_ilayokumo (tropical:) My eye (lit. my little eye) is looking to God for His bounty, then to you for your bounty. (A.) -A2- In the Kur, [lxxv. 23,] the words A_ilaY rab~ihaA naAZirapN have been explained as signifying Waiting for (munotaZirapN) their Lord: but this is a mistake; for the Arabs do not say naTarotu A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i in the sense of A_inotaZarotuhu, but they say naZarotu fulaAnFA in that sense. (T.)
naAZirapN * : see naAZirN. -A2- See also naZirapN.
naAZuwrN * : see naAZirN.
naAZuwrapN * : see naZuwrN.
A^anoZuwru * for A^anoZuru: see 1.

manoZarN * [A place in which a thing is looked at]: a place, or state, in which one likes to be looked at. (T, A, TA.) You say, fulaAnN fiY manoZarK wamasomaEK wafiY riY~K wma$obaEK (tropical:) Such a one is in a state in which he likes to be looked at and listened to [and in a state in which he is satisfied with drink and food]. (T, A, TA.) And laqado kunota Eano h`*aA AlmaqaAmi bimanoZarK (tropical:) Thou wast in a state [in] which thou likedst [to be looked at], away from this place of abode. (T, TA.) ― -b2- The aspect, or outward appearance, of a thing; opposite of maxobarN: (S, art. xbr:) [when used absolutely, a pleasing, or goodly, aspect; or beauty of aspect; as also ↓ manoZarapN: this is implied by the usage of manoZaraAniY~N, q. v., and is well known:] or what one looks at and is pleased by or displeased by; as also ↓ manoZarapN: (M, K:) or the former, a thing that pleases and rejoices the beholder when he looks at it: (T:) and the ↓ latter, the aspect (manoZar) of a man when one looks at it and is pleased by it or displeased by it. (T, TA. *) You say, lahu manoZarN HasanN [He has a goodly aspect]. (A.) And AimoraA^apN Hasanapu AlmanoZari, and ↓ AlmanoZarapi, [A woman goodly of aspect.] (S.) And manoZaruhu xayorN mino maxobarihi [His aspect is better than his internal state]. (S.) And A_in~ahu la*uw manoZarK bilaA maxobarK, (T,) and balaA maxobarapK ↓ *uw manoZarapK, (A,) [Verily he has a pleasing aspect without a pleasing internal state.]

manoZarapN *
A high place on which a person is stationed to watch; (S;) a place on the top of a mountain, where a person observes and watches the enemy: (T:) and manaAZiru [the pl.] eminences; or elevated parts of the earth; or high grounds: (M, K:) because one looks from them. (M.) ― -b2- Its application to A certain separate place of a house, [generally an apartment on the groundfloor overlooking the court, and also a turret, or rather a belvedere, and any building, or apartment, commanding a view,] is vulgar. (TA.) ― -b3- See also naZ~aArapN. ― -b4- And see manoZarN, in five places.
manoZariY~N * : see what next follows.

manoZaraAniY~N * (S, M, A, K) and ↓ manoZariY~N, (M, K,) the latter contr. to analogy, (M,) A man (M,) of goodly aspect. (M, K.) You say, rajulN manoZaraAniY~N maxobaraAniY~N [A man of goodly aspect and of pleasing internal, or intrinsic, qualities]; (S, A;) i. e., *uw manoZarK and *uw maxobarK. (TA, art. xbr.)

minoZaArN *
A mirror (A, K) in which the face is seen. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, A telescope; a thing in which what is distant is seen [as though it were] near: vulgarly, ↓ naZ~aArapN. (TA.)

manoZuwrN * A man looked at with an evil eye: (A, TA;) affected by what is termed a naZorap; (T, TA;) i. e., a stroke of an [evil] eye; [or of an evil eye cast by a jinnee; or a touch, or slight taint of insanity, from the jinn;] or a swoon. (TA.) ― -b2- A person, (T,) or chief person, (A,) whose bounty is hoped for, (T, A,) and at whom eyes glance. (A.) ― -b3- manoZuwrapN A woman in whom is a naZorap, meaning, a fault, defect, or imperfection. (K, * TA.)
munaAZirN * : see naZiyrN.

div2.head: nZf &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 naEaba * , aor.
naEaba and
naEiba , inf. n. naEobN and naEiybN (S, K) and nuEaAbN (K) and naEabaAnN and tanoEaAbN (S, K) He (a raven, or crow, guraAb,) uttered a cry, cried out, or croaked: (S:) or uttered the cry, or croak, that is asserted to be ominous of separation: [but see below:] or moved about his head without crying: (Msb:) he (a raven, or crow, or other animal,) cried out: or stretched out his neck, and moved about his head, in crying out. (K.) The naEiyb of the raven, or crow, is said to be ominous of good; and its naEiyq, of evil. (Kifáyet el-Mutahaffidh.) ― -b2- naEiybN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The neighing of a horse. (TA.) ― -b3- naEaba Ald~iyku (tropical:) [The cock crowed] is sometimes said, metaphorically. (S.) ― -b4- naEaba Almuw^a*~inu (tropical:) The chanter of the call to prayer
stretched out his neck, and moved about his head, in his cry. (A, L, K.) ― -b5- naEaba, aor.
naEaba , inf. n. naEobN, He (a camel, K) went with a quick pace: (S, K:) or, with a certain kind of pace; (K:) or he (a camel) moved about his head, in proceeding at a quick rate; like a buxotiY camel, raising his head: (TA:) or, inf. n. naEabaAnN, he stretched out his neck. (A.) Accord. to some, naEobN signifies The moving of a she-camel's head forwards in her march, or pace. [S, accord to an excellent copy, in which the original words are thus given: yuqaAlu A_in~a Aln~aEoba taHar~uku raA^osihaA Alx: in another copy tuHar~ku raA^osahaA; making naEob an epithet of a she-camel that so moves her head.]
4 AnEb * (assumed tropical:) He (a man) cried out, or stretched out his neck and moved about his head, in disturbances, broils, or the like: syn. naEaba fiY Alfitani. (TA.)

riyHN naEobN *
A rapid wind. (K.)
naEuwbN * : see naAEibapN.

naE~aAbN * The young one of a raven, or crow: syn faroxu guraAbK: or a raven, or crow, [absolutely]: syn. EuraAbN. In a prayer of David occur the words yaA raAziq Aln~aE~aAbi fiY Eu$~ihi [O Sustainer of the young raven (or young crow) in his nest!]. It is said that the young raven (or young crow), when it comes forth from its egg, is white, like a lump of fat, and that the old bird, on seeing it, dislikes and abandons it; that thereupon God sends to it gnats, which light upon it on account of its foul greasy smell, and that it lives upon them until it is fledged and becomes black, when its parents return to it. (L.)
naE~aAbapN * : see naAEibapN.

naAEibapN * (K) and ↓ naEuwbN and ↓ naE~aAbapN (S, K) and ↓ minoEabN (so in the correct copies of the K: in the L, minoEabapN: accord. to MF, munoEibN: TA) A swift she-camel: (S, K:) pl. of the first, and of [the masc. epithet] nawaAEibu, naAEibN and nuE~abN: and of nEwb, nuEubN. (TA.) [The last pl. is the only one mentioned in the S, K, which do not point out its proper sing.] See also naEobN in 1.

minoEabN * An excellent, fleet horse, (S, K,) that stretches out his neck like the raven, or crow: and (or accord. to some, TA) one that follows his own way, heedless of the bridle, [app., lowering his head, and stretching out his neck,] syn. Al*Y yasoTuw biraA^osihi, (K,) without any increase in the rate of his run. (TA.) ― -b2- See naAEibapN. ― -b3- A stupid, or foolish, and clamourous man. (K.)

1 naEata * , aor.
naEata , inf. n. naEotN; and ↓ AntEt; He described, or characterized, or designated, (S, K,) a thing; (S;) syn. waSafa: (S, K:) or he described a thing by mentioning what was in it, or what it possessed; whereas, in the waSof of a thing one may exaggerate: (L;) (??) distinguished a person or a thing by an epithet: and hence, he qualified a substantive by an epithet: and he used a word as an epithet] or he described a thing by mentioning what was in it that was good, or goodly; not with reference to what was bad. or foul, or ugly; unless by a straining of the meaning one say naEotN sawo'N; whereas waSafa is said with respect to what is good, or goodly and what is bad, or foul, or ugly: (IAth: or naEata signifies he described by mentioning the make, or form, or other outward characteristic, as tallness and shortness; and waSafa respects action, as beating: or, accord. to Th, naEata signifies he described by mentioning something in some particular place in the body, such as lameness; whereas waSafa is used with respect to what is common to the whole, as greatness, and generosity; therefore God is an object of waSof, but not of naEot. (TA.) ― -b2- naEata nafosuh bAloHayori [He described himself as possessing, or characterized by, or distinguished by, goodness.] (Msb.) ― -b3- naEata, aor
naEuta , inf. n. naEaAtapN, He (a man) was naturally endowed with powers of description, and skilful in the use of those powers. (TA.) ― -b4- naEut, aor.
naEuta , inf. n. naEaAnapN, He (a horse) was, or became, what is termed naEotN, i. e., generous, or fleet, &c. (L, K.) ― -b5- naEata, (L,) or naEita, of the same measure as fariHa, (K,) He (a horse) affected, or endeavoured, or constrained himself, to be, or become, what is termed naEotN, i. e., generous, or fleet, &c. (L, K.) MF remarks that naEita, in this sense, is strange, as faEila is not a measure denoting takal~uf. (TA.)

4 AnEt *
His face became beautiful, or goodly, so that he was described (K) as characterized by beauty, (TA,) [or, so that he became distinguished by an epithet].

8 AntEt *
He, or it, was, or became, described: (TA:) [he, or it, was, or became, distinguished by an epithet: he, or it, was, or became, characterized, or distinguished, by that which made him to excel others of his kind: see naEotN]. See 1.

10 AstnEthu *
He asked him to describe him, or it. (T, K.)

naEotN *
An epithet; or that whereby a person or thing is described: [hence, an epithet whereby a substantive is qualified:] (TA:) pl. nuEuwtN: it has no other pl. than this. (ISd.) [Respecting distinctions said to exist between naEotN and waSofN or SifapN, see 1.] [You say,] lahu nuEuwtN wamanaAEitu jamiylapN [He has goodly epithets applied to him, and goodly qualities, or properties. which are causes, or occasions, of epithets]. (A.) ― -b2- [kanaEoti ka*aA, a phrase similar to kamaval ka*aA, meaning Like such a thing. See an ex. voce sab~E.] ― -b3- naEotN Anything excellent. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] farasN naEotN, and ↓ munotaEitN, and ↓ naEotapN, [in the CK, naEotat,] and ↓ naEytN, and ↓ naEiytpN, A generous, or a fleet, or swift, horse, that (??) in running, and outstrips others. (K.) And (??) ↓ munotaEitN A beast of carriage, or a man, characterized, or distinguished, by that which makes him to excel others of his kind. a horse at scribed as distinguished by generousness, or by fleetness, or swiftness, and by outstripping others (TA.)
naEotapN * : see naEotN.
Eaboduka nuEotapN * , or A^amatuka nuEotapN, Thy male slave or thy female slave, is of the highest quality. (K.) But in the A it is said, Eabaduka naEotN, and A^amatuka naEotapN. (TA.)
naEiytN * A generous, excellent, surpassing, man. (TA.) See also naEotN.
naEiytapN * : see naEotN,

naAEitN *
Describing; a describer: pl. nuE~aAtN. (TA.)

manoEuwtN * [A person or thing described; distinguished by an epithet: and hence, a substantive qualified by an epithet]. ― -b2- manoEuwtN biAlokarami [Described as possessing, or characterized by, or distinguished by, generosity; distinguished by the epithet of generous]. (A.)
munotaEitN * : see naEotN.

1 naEavahu * , aor.
naEava ; and ↓ AntEvhN; He took it. (K.)

4 AnEv fiY maAlihi *
He was prodigal of his wealth: (K:) or he scattered it: or it signifies qad~ama fiyhi. (L.) -A2- AnEv He set about, or commenced fitting himself out, or equipping himself for journeying. (K.) ― -b2- humo fiY A_inoEaAv (??) the CK, and in a MS. copy of the K, A^anoEaAvK,) They have striven, laboured, or exerted themselves, in their affair. (K.)
8 A_inotaEava see 1.

1 naEaja * , aor.
naEuja , inf. n. naEajN (S, K) and nuEuwjN, (K,) a verb similar to TalabN, (S, K,) aor.
naEuja , inf. n. TalabN; (S;) so in the handwriting of J; (IB;) or, with reference to a colour, naEija, aor.
naEaja , inf. n. naEajN, a verb like Saxiba, aor.
naEaja , inf. n. SaxabN: (accord-to an insertion in a copy of the S read
to IB, TA, [and so in one of M. Fresnel's copies of the S, and in a copy in my possession, and so in the L, in which both forms of the verb are given,]) He, or it, [a colour,] was of a clear, or pure white. (S, L, K.) -A2- naEija, aor.
naEaja , inf. n. naEajN, He (a man, Az, or a camel, S) became fat: (T, S, K:) said by AA to occur in a poem of Dhu-r-Rummeh, but not found in his poetry by Sh, who deems it strange: Az, however, confirms it by the authority of an Arab of the desert; and adds, that it signifies he (a man) became fat and in good condition: and he increased, and became swollen, or inflated: and nahija is said to signify the same. (TA.) ― -b2- naEija, aor.
naEaja , inf. n. naEajN, He (a man, S) became heavy in the stomach (Alqalob) from eating mutton. (S, K.) -A3- naEajato fiY sayorihaA, (inf. n. naEojN, L.) She (a camel) was quick, or swift, in her pace: (S, L:) she went with a certain pace: (L:) a dial. form of maEajato. (S.)

4 A^anoEaja Alqawomu *
The people's camels became fat. (S, K.)

naEijN * [and ↓ A^anoEaju] Of a pure white colour: (L:) [pl. of the latter nuEojN]. ― -b2- nisaA='N nuEoju AlmaHaAjiri duEoju Aln~awaAZiri [Women of a clear white colour in the parts around the eyes; intensely black and wide, in the eyes]. (A.) -A2- naEijN A man heavy in the stomach (Alqalob) from eating mutton: pl. naEijuwna. (S, TA.)

naEojapN * , (S, K,) and ↓ niEojapN, accord. to a reading of El-Hasan, waliY niEojapN waAHidapN, [Kur, xxxviii. 22,] (TA,) A ewe; the female of the sheep: (L, K:) also, the female of the wild bull: and, of the gazelle: and, of the wild sheep: (TA:) [but see below:] pl. niEaAjN and naEajaAtN. (S, K.) ― -b2- naEojapu Alr~amoli The [wild] cow: pl. niEaAju Alr~amoli: no other wild animal but the cow (accord. to A 'Obeyd, S,) is thus called: (S, K:) [but see above]. The Arabs speak of gazelles as though they were goats, terming the male tayosN; and of wild bulls or cows as though they were sheep, terming the female naEojapN. (AAF.) ― -b3- Also naEojapN (tropical:) A woman; as likewise $aApN. (TA.)
niEojapN * : see naEojapN.

naAEijN * A camel of beautiful colour, and highly esteemed. (TA.) naAEijapN A she-camel of beautiful colour: (TA:) or a white she-camel, (S, K,) of generous race: (TA:) a swift she-camel: a she-camel upon which one hunts wild cows: (S, K:) such is of the kind called mahoriy~apN: (IJ:) or one that is light, or active: (TA:) pl. nawaAEiju. (S.) ― -b2- naAEijapN also A woman of beautiful complexion, or colour. (TA.) -A2- A^aroDN naAEijapN Plain, or even, land, (S, K,) fertile, and producing the kind of tree called rimov. (Aboo-Kheyreh.)
A^anoEaju * : see naEijN.

1 naEara * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
naEira (S, K) and
naEara , (K,) [in the Msb,
naEura , but this I suppose to be an error in transcription,] the first of which is the most common, (K,) or the most common when the verb relates to a vein, accord. to Fr, as cited by Sgh, (TA,) inf. n. naEiyrN (S, A, Msb, K) and nuEaArN, (A, K,) or this latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and naEorapN, (A,) [or this also is a simple subst.,] He (a man, K, or a beast of carriage, Msb,) uttered a sound, or noise, (S, A, Msb, K,) with, (A, K,) or in, (S,) his xayo$uwm [or the innermost part of his nose]: (S, A, K:) but Az, says, I have not heard this explanation from any of the leading authorities. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (TA,) inf. n. naEiyrN, (K,) He called out, or cried out vehemently, in war, or in some evil case. (K, * TA.) And naEarato, inf. n. naEiyrN, She (a woman) clamoured, and acted in a foul or immodest manner. (TA.) ― -b3- naEara AlEiroqu, (S, K,) or naEara AlEiroqu biAld~ami, (A,) aor.
naEira , (Fr, Sgh, K,) and
naEara , (S, K,) the former of which is the more common, (Fr, Sgh,) inf. n. naEorN, (S, TA,) or naEiyrN and nuEaArN, (as app. implied in the K, but perhaps not intended to be so,) (tropical:) The vein gushed with blood: (S, K:) or, (aor.
naEara , inf. n. nuEuwrN and naEiyrN, TA,) made a sound by reason of the blood coming forth: (K:) or gushed with blood, and made a sound at the coming forth of the blood. (A.)

naEorapN *
A sound, or noise, in the xayo$uwm [or innermost part of the nose]; (S, K;) [as also ↓ nuEaArN. (See 1.)] ― -b2- naEaraAtN [the pl.] is also applied to The call of the muw^a*~in. (S.)
nuEoraY * : see naAEirN.
nuEaArN * : see naEorapN.
naEuwrN * : see naAEirN.
naE~aArN * and naE~aArapN: see naAEirN.

naAEirN *
Uttering a sound or noise [with, or in, the xayo$uwm, or innermost part of the nose]. (Sh.) And ↓ naE~aArN Clamorous: (K, TA:) ↓ p, applied to a woman, and signifying the same: (A:) or, so applied, it signifies clamorous and foul, or immodest: (K:) and ↓ A_imoraA^apN gayoraY naEoraY a [very jealous] clamorous woman; (K;) in which phrase, nErY may not be regarded as fem. of naEoraAnu, because [epithets of the measures] faEolaAnu and faEolaY come from verbs of the class of fariHa; not from those of the class of manaEa [or that of Daraba]. (Az, K.) ― -b2- [And so] ↓ naE~aArN One who drives away the beasts and cries out after them. (TA, art. zgq.) ― -b3- You say also, A^aToratu bih`*aA ↓ SawotFA naE~aArFA [lit., I made a clamorous voice to fly with this; meaning,] (tropical:) I published this. (A.) ― -b4- Also naAEirN (tropical:) A vein flowing with blood: (Sh:) [or gushing with blood; &c. (See its verb, above.)] And ↓ naE~aArN (tropical:) A vein gushing with blood; and so ↓ naEuwrN: (S:) that does not cease to flow with blood; as also ↓ naEuwrN (TA) and ↓ naAEuwrN: (K, TA:) and ↓ naE~aArN applied to a wound signifies the same; as also taE~aArN, with t and E, and ↓ tag~aArN, with t and g: (IAar, Az:) and ↓ naEuwrN applied to a wound signifies (tropical:) making a sound by reason of the vehemence with which the blood comes forth. (TA.)

naAEuwrN * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) or ↓ naAEuwrapN, (K,) A [machine of the kind called] duwlaAb [q. v.], (A, K,) or manojanuwn [q. v.], (Mgh, Msb,) with which water is drawn [for irrigation], (S,) and which is turned by water, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and makes a noise, or [creaking] sound by [its revolving]: (S:) so called because of its naEiyr [or sound]: (A, Mgh, Msb:) [app. also any rotary machine for raising water to irrigate land: see Niebuhr's ' Voyage en Arabie, ' tome i., p. 220 et seq.:] it is used on the banks of the Euphrates (A, TA) and the 'Ásee: (TA:) pl. nawaAEiyru. (S, A, Msb.) ― -b2- And the former, The wing (janaAH) of a mill or mill-stone. (K.) ― -b3- Also ↓ naAEuwrapN A bucket with which water is raised. (K.) ― -b4- See also naAEirN.
naAEuwrapN * : see naAEuwrN.

1 naEasa * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
naEusa , (S, M, and so in a copy of the B by the author of the K,) or
naEasa , (A, K,) [the latter being agreeable with analogy,] inf. n. nuEaAsN, (S, A, K, * TA,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) [He drowsed; he was, or became, drowsy, or heavy with sleepiness: or he slumbered, or dozed:] the inf. n. is syn. with wasanN: (S, A, K:) or ↓ nuEaAsN signifies languor in the senses, (K, TA,) arising from the heaviness [which is the prevenient sign] of sleep: (TA:) or the beginning of sleep: (M, art. wsn:) or its proper signification is, accord. to Az, (Msb, TA,) wasanN (Msb) or sinapN (TA) without sleep: (Msb, TA,) or sinapN is in the head, and nuEaAsN is in the eye: or snp is the vapour (ryH) of sleep which begins in the face, then is transmitted to the heart, and you say, of a man, yanoEasu, and then, yanaAmu. (Msb, art. nwm.) It is said in a proverb,
maTolN kanuEaAsi Alkalobi [A delaying of the payment, of a debt, or the like, like the drowsing, or slumbering, of the dog:] i. e. continual: (S, TA:) for the dog is characterized by much nEAs, and, as is said in the B, is accustomed to open his eyes [only] sufficiently for the purpose of guarding, and this he does time after time. (TA.) ― -b2- naEasa, (TK,) inf. n. naEosN, (IAar, K,) (assumed tropical:) It (a man's judgment, and his body,) was soft, and weak. (IAar, K, TK.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (a market) was, or became, stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (K, TA.)
4 AnEs * (assumed tropical:) He begat heavy, sluggish, lazy, indolent, or torpid, sons. (AA, K.)

6 tnAEs *
He feigned himself [drowsing, or slumbering, or] sleeping. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (lightning) became faint. (A, TA.)

naEosapN * [A single fit of drowsiness: or of slumber:] a single movement of the head in drowsing or slumbering. (TA.) You say, rakabatohu naEosapN $adiydapN [A vehement fit of drowsiness, or of slumber, came upon him]. (A.) And naEasotu naEosapF waAHidapF [I drowsed, or slumbered, once]. (S.)
naEosaAnN * : see naAEisN.
nuEaAsN * : see 1.

naEuwsN * A she-camel bountiful in yielding milk; (S, A, K;) that drowses, or slumbers, in yielding milk; (A;) or because, in yielding milk, she drowses, or slumbers: (S:) or having much milk, that drowses, or slumbers, when milked: (M:) or that closes her eyelid on being milked. (Az, TA.)
naE~aAsapN * : see naAEisN.

naAEisN * , part. n. of naEasa, [Drowsing, drowsy, or heavy with sleep: or slumbering, or dozing:] (S, Msb, K:) as also ↓ naEosaAnN; (Lth, Fr, Th, Msb, K;) but this latter is rare; (Fr, Th, Msb, K;) and by some disallowed: (TA:) fem. of the former with p: (Msb, TA:) and of the latter naEosaY, made to accord. with wasonaY, fem. of wasonaAnN; and this is best in poetry: (Lth, Msb, TA:) and ↓ naE~aAsapN is also used as an epithet [in an intensive sense] applied to a female: (TA:) the pl. of naAEisN is nuE~asN; like rak~aEN, pl. of raAkiEN: and that of naAEisapN is nawaAEisu. (Msb.) ― -b2- jad~uhu naAEisN (tropical:) [His good fortune is slumbering]. (A, TA.)

1 naEa$ahu * , aor.
naEa$a , (S, K,) inf. n. naEo$N, (S,) He (God) raised him; lifted him up; (S, K;) as also ↓ AnE$hu; (Lth, Ks, K;) which is disallowed by ISk, who says that it is a vulgar word, and by J after him, but is correct; (TA;) and ↓ nE~$hu, (AA, K,) inf. n. tanoEiy$N: (AA, TA:) or He (God) set him up, or upright; as also ↓ AnE$hu: (Msb:) [see an ex. in a verse cited voce $amolN:] or be [app. a man] raised him, or lifted him up, after a stumble, or trip. (Sb.) You say also, naEa$otu Al$~ajarapa I set the tree upright, when it was leaning. (TA.) And naEa$a Tarufhu He raised his eye, or eyes. (S, * K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He recovered him from his embarrassment, or difficulty: (A:) (tropical:) he restored him from a state of poverty to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency: (K, TA;) as also ↓ AnE$hu: (TA:) and (tropical:) he recovered him from a state of perdition or destruction. (TA.) And naEa$aka A@ll~`hu (tropical:) May God restore thee from poverty to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency: or make thee to continue in life; preserve thee alive. (A.) And ↓ AnE$hu (assumed tropical:) He set him up, and strengthened his heart. (TA.) And Alr~abiyEu yunoE$u Aln~aAsa (tropical:) (A, TA,) [The spring, or spring-herbage, or the season, or rain, called AlrbyE,] makes men to live and enjoy plenty of herbage or the like. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] naEa$a Almay~ita, (Sh, K,) aor. as above, (Sh,) and so the inf. n. (TA) (tropical:) He eulogized, or praised, the dead man, (Sh, K,) and exalted his praise, or fame, or honour. (Sh.) ― -b4- naEa$uwA Almay~ita also signifies They carried the dead man upon the naEo$, q. v. (A [where this signification is indicated, but not expressed: it is shown, however, by an explanation of pass. part. n. (q. v. infra) in the TA.]) ― -b5- nuEi$a EalaY jinaAratihaA A naEo$ [q. v.] was made for her bier. (Mgh, from a trad. of, or relating to, Fátimeh.)

2 naE~$hu * : see 1. -A2- Also, (K,) or nE~$ lahu, (S,) inf. n. tanoEiy$N, (K,) He said to him naEa$aka A@ll~`hu [which see above, in 1, and also below, in 8]: (S, K:) in [some copies of] the S, naE~a$aka Allh. (TA.)
4 A^anoEa$a see 1, in four places.

8 AntE$ *
He rose; or became raised, or lifted up: (TA:) he rose after his stumble, or trip: (S, A, Msb, K:) and in like manner you say of a bird, (A, TA,) meaning it rose [after falling or alighting], (TA,) and he raised his head. (TA.) Hence the saying, taEasa falA A@notaEa$a May he fall, having stumbled, or stumble and fall, and not rise [again]: a form of imprecation. (TA.) And hence the saying of 'Omar, AinotaEi$o naEa$aka A@ll~`hu Rise thou: may God raise thee: or nE$k All~`h has here one of the two meanings assigned to it before, in 1. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (tropical:) He recovered, or became recovered, from his embarrassment, or difficulty. (A, TA.)

naEo$N *
A state of elevation, or exaltation. (Sh.) See 1. ― -b2- A state of remaining; lastingness; endurance; permanence; or continuance; syn. baqaA='N. (Sh, K.) -A2- [A kind of litter, or] a thing resembling a miHaf~ap, upon which the king used to be carried. when sick: (IDrd, Msb, K:) not the naEo$ of a corpse. (IDrd, Msb.) This is said to be the primary application. (TA) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) A bier, (S, A, Msb, K,) when the corpse is upon it. for otherwise it is called sriyrN: (S, IAth, Msb:) it is called by the former name because of its height, or its being raised: (S, TA.) pl. nuEuw$N: (Msb:) also, a reticulated thing. (Az. Mgh, TA,) resembling a mHaf~p, (Mgh,) which is put as a cover over a [dead] woman when she is placed upon the bier; (Az, Mgh, TA;) but this is properly called HarajN, though people called is naEo$N, which is properly only the bier itself. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence,] banaAtu naEo$i AlkuboraY [or banaAtu naEo$a AlkuboraY, together with naEo$N or naEo$u, constitute (assumed tropical:) The constellation of Ursa Major: or the principal stars thereof:] seven stars; whereof four [which are in the body] are called naEo$N [or naEo$u], and three [which are in the tail] are called banAtN, (S, K,) i. e., bnAt nE$ (TA:) and to like manner AlS~ugoraY, (K,) or bnAt nE$ AlS~ugoraY [together with nE$ AlS~ugoraY constitute [the constellation of Ursa Minor: or the principal stars thereof; seven in number; whereof the four in the body are called nE$, and the there in the tail are called bnAt]: (S:) [the former four] said to be likened to the bearers of a bier, because they form a square: (IDrd, TA:) [the bnAt being so called as being likened to damsels or to men for bnAt is pl. of AibonN applied to an irrational thing as well as pl. of binotN) following a bier:] Sb and Fr agree that nE$ is imperfectly decl. because determinate and of the fem. gender: (S:) or it is perfectly decl. when indeterminate, but not when determinate [by having the epithet AlkuboraY or AlS~ugoraY added to it]: (Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid, K:) banw naEo$i also occurs, in poetry; (Sb, S, K;) because a single one [of the stars thereof] is called Abonu naEo$i, (Lth, K,) being made to accord. in gender with kawokabN; but when they say valaAv or A^arobaE, they say banaAt: (Lth, TA:) [this is agreeable with a general rule; accord. to which, banaAtN is the pl. of AibonN applied to anything but a human being:] the pl. of bnAt nE$ is Aln~awaAEi$u; like as A^abaAriSu is pl. of saAm~u A^abaraSa. (L, TA.) See also nuEayo$N. ― -b4- Also naEo$N A piece of wood, (K, TA,) of the length of twice the stature of a man, (TA,) upon the head of which is a piece of rag, (K, TA,) called HarajN, (TA,) with which young ostriches are hunted or captured. (K, TA.)

nuEayo$N * [or nuEayo$u (assumed tropical:) The small star called] Als~uhaY, which is [by the star (??)] in the middle of banaAt naEo$. So in the saying, huwa A^axofaY mino nuEayo$ fiY banaAti naEo$ [He, or it, is more obscure than No'eysh among the Bená Naash]. (A, TA.)
Aln~awaAEi$u * : see naEo$N, near the end.
manoEuw$N * A corpse carried upon a naEo$, or bier. (S, A, * Msb.)

div2.head: nEZ &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 nagaba * , aor.
nagaba and
naguba , (inf. n. nagobN, TA,) He (a man, TA) swallowed saliva. (K.) ― -b2- nagaba, (inf. n. nagobN, TA,) It (a bird) sipped water: you do not say of a bird $ariba. (K.) ― -b3- nagaba He (a man) took in gulps, or gulped, in drinking: (K:) and likewise an ass. (TA.) ― -b4- nagibotu mina AlA_inaA'i nugabFA, with kesr, I drank in gulps from the vessel. (ISk, S.)

nagobapN *
A hungering. (K.) A tribe's wanting food, or hungering: syn. A_iqafoAru AlHaY~i. (K, as in some copies: [app. the right reading:] in other copies, A^aqofaAr, which is pl. of qaforN. TA.) ― -b2- See nugobapN.

nugobapN * and ↓ nagobapN A gulp; or as much as is swallowed at once; of water &c.: (S, K:) or the ↓ latter signifies a single act of gulping: (K:) differing from the former like as [its syn.] jaroEapN does from juroEapN: (TA:) pl. of the former nugabN: (S:) for which nugamN occurs in a verse. (TA.) ― -b2- Ex. waAhFA maA A^aboradahaA mino nugobapK maA A^aboradahaA EalaY Alfuw^aAdi taEosFA liloyadayoni waAlfami (tropical:) [Excellent! How cool a gulp is it! How cool is it to the heart! May the hands and mouth perish!] said on hearing of the death of an enemy, or of any trial or affliction that has befallen him. (A.) -A2- nugobapN A foul action. (S, K.) So in the following saying, maA jur~ibato Ealayohi nugobapN qaT~u [A foul action was never found to be chargeable upon him.] (S.)

1 nagata * , aor.
nagata , inf. n. nagotN, He pulled hair; syn. ja*aba. (K.)

nagovN *
Lasting and vehement evil. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- waqaEonaA fiY nagovK We fell into lasting and vehement evil. (L.)

1 nagirati Alqidoru * , (S, K, TA,) aor.
nagara ; and nagarat (K, and so in a copy of the A,) aor.
nagira ; and nagarat, aor.
nagara ; (K;) inf. n. nagarN (IKtt, K) [of the first] and nagorN (IKtt, TA) and nagaraAnN (K, TA) and nagiyrN, (TA,) The cooking-pot boiled; estuated; became in a state of violent commotion; syn. galat, (As, S, IKtt, A, L,) and faArat. (As, K.) -A2- Hence, (TA,) nagira Alr~ajulu, (S,) or nagara, (so in a copy of the A,) (tropical:) The man became angry, or vehemently or most vehemently angry, or affected with latent anger without power to exercise it: (S, A:) or his inside boiled by reason of such anger: (As, S:) and nagira Ealayohi, aor.
nagara ; and nagara, aor.
nagira ; and nagara, aor.
nagara ; (K;) the first of which is the most common; (TA;) inf. n. nagarN [of the first] and nagarAnN; and ↓ tanag~ara; (K;) [after which last, in the CK, the word galaY, commencing the explanation, is omitted;] his inside boiled against him by reason of anger: (K:) or by reason of vehement or most vehement anger, or latent anger without power to exercise it: (TA:) or (so accord. to the TA; but in the K, and) Ealayohi ↓ tng~r he became changed, or altered, to him, and threatened him with evil: (ISk, S, K, TA:) and nagira, aor.
nagara , inf. n. nagarN, also signifies he held enmity in his heart, watching for an opportunity to indulge it; or he hid enmity and violent hatred in his heart; or he bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (TA.)
5 tanag~ara see 1, in two places.

6 tanaAEurN *
i. q. tanaAkurN [app. meaning, (tropical:) The behaving with mutual enmity or hostility]. (K.)

nagirN * (tropical:) [Angry or vehemently or most vehemently angry, or affected with latent anger without power to exercise it: as is implied in the S: or] having his inside boiling by reason of anger: (S, * K:) and [it is said that] A_imoraA^apN nagirapN signifies a woman very jealous; syn. gayoraY: (K:) [but] it is related in a trad. of 'Alee, that a woman came to him and told him that her husband had illicit intercourse with her female slave; whereupon he said, “ If thou be speaker of truth, we stone him; and if thou be a speaker of falsehood, we whip thee: ” and she said, rud~uwniY A_ilaY A^aholiY gayoraY nagirapF, (S, TA,) meaning, [Restore ye me to my family, very jealous,] with my inside boiling by reason of anger, or vehement or most vehement anger, or latent anger without power to exercise it: this is the explanation given by As: and ISd says, that he holds ngrp to signify here angry, not very jealous; since it is related that an Arab said to a woman, A^agyoraY A^anoti A^amo nagirapN [Art thou very jealous or angry?] (TA.)

nugarN *
Certain birds like sparrows, (S,) or a species of sparrows, (Msb,) with red beaks: (S, Msb:) n. un. with p: (S:) or the young ones of sparrows: (K:) n. un. as above: (TA:) or the young ones of the sparrows; (Sh, Msb;) which you always see in a lean state: (Sh:) or [a species] of young sparrows: (TA:) or the bird called bulobul: (Msb, K:) it is said that the people of El-Medeeneh call the bulobul by the names of nugarN and Hum~arapN; and it is said to resemble the sparrow; and the fem. is with p: (Msb:) or (TA; in the K, and) a species of the Hum~ar, (K, TA; in the CK, erroneously, Humur;) red in the beaks and in the lower parts of the A^aHonaAk [or portions beneath the beaks]: (TA:) or the males thereof: (K:) pl. nigoraAnN, (S, Msb, K,) like as SirodaAnN is pl. of SuradN. (S, Msb.) Its dim. is nugayorN (S, Msb, K) occurring in a trad.; yaA A^abaA Eumayoro maA faEala Aln~ugayoro [O Aboo-'Omeyr, what did the little nughar?]; (S, K;) said by Mohammad to a little child of Aboo-Talhah El-Ansáree, who had a bird, or birds, of this name, which died. (TA.)

1 nagiSa * , aor.
nagaSa , (S, K,) inf. n. nagaSN, (S,) He (a man, S,) failed of having his desire fully accomplished: (S, K:) but Lth says, that it is more commonly with teshdeed, i. e. ↓ nag~aSa, [unless this be a mistake for nug~iSa,] inf. n. tanogiySN. (TA.) ― -b2- And in like manner, (S,) He (a camel) failed of having his full, or complete, draught, or drink. (S, K.) ― -b3- And It (beverage) was imperfect, or defective. (K.) ― -b4- See also 5. -A2- nagaSN (L, K) and nagoSN (L, TA) [both inf. ns., the verb of the former being app. nagiSa, used intransitively, and that of the latter nagaSa, used transitively, followed by A_ibilahu,] also signify The bringing one's camels to the drinking-trough, and, when they have drunk, turning them back, and bringing others; (K;) taking forth, from every two camels, a strong camel, and putting in its place a weak camel; and thus as it were, making their drinking troublesome. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, nagaSa Alr~ajulu Alr~ajula The man prevented the man from obtaining his share of water by interposing to hinder his camels from drinking: and in like manner, raEoyahu ↓ A^anogaSahu [He prevented him from obtaining his share of pasturage for his camels]: the verb in the latter instance being with A. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2.

2 ng~S EalayonaA *
He cut short a thing of which we loved to have much, or abundance. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- ng~S Ealayohi; and Elyh ↓ nagaSa, inf. n. nagoSN; but the former is the more common; He rendered [an affair, or circumstances, or a state,] troublesome, or perturbed, to him; syn. kad~ara. (IKtt, TA.) You say, ng~S A@ll~`hu Ealayohi AlEayo$a, (S, K,) inf. n. tanogiySN; (S;) and ng~Shu (S, K) and Elyh AlEy$ ↓ AngS; (K;) God rendered life troublesome, or perturbed, to him; syn. kad~arahu: (S, K:) the first of these is the most common:
(TA:) the second occurs in poetry; the pronoun in this relating to a man. (Akh, S, TA.) -A2- See also nagiSa.
4 A^anogaSa see 1, last sentence: ― -b2- and see also 2.

5 tng~St Eiy$atuhu * , (S,) or maEiy$atuhu, (K,) His state of life, (S,) or his means of subsistence, (K,) became troublesome, or perturbed, or attended with trouble; syn. takad~arato. (S, K.) You say also, nagiSa A^amoruhu, inf. n. nagaSN, [His affair, or case, became troublesome, &c.;] (A;) [for] ↓ nagaSN is syn. with tanag~uSN as signifying takad~urN (Har, p. 273).

6 tnAgSt AlA_ibilu EalaY AlHawoDi *
The camels crowded, or pressed, together to the drinkingtrough. (Ks, K. *)
nugaSN * is said to signify Things that prevent one from attaining an object of desire. (Har, p. 273.)
munag~iSN * Any one who cuts short a thing of which one loves to have more. (IAar, TA.)

1 nagaDa * , aor.
nagiDa , (Ks, S, A, Msb, K,) and
naguDa , (S, A, K,) inf. n. nagoDN (S, Msb, K) and nuguwDN (S, K,) and nagaDaAnN and nagaDN, (K,) It was or became, in a state of motion, commotion, agitation, or convulsion; it shook; shook about; wabbled; tottered; wagged; nodded; syn. taHar~aka, (S, A, Msb, K,) and AiDoTaraba, (A, K,) fiY A@rotijaAfK; (TA;) as also ↓ AngD (Msb, K) and ↓ tng~D: (K:) it is said of a man's head; (S, TA;) and also, (S, A,) with nagoDN and nagaDaAnN for its inf. ns., (S,) of a camel's saddle, (S, A,) and of the central incisor (S, TA) of a child, (S,) or of any tooth, as also ↓ the last of the verbs above mentioned; (A;) and of other things; (Msb, TA;) nagoDN signifying any moving in a shaking or tremulous or convulsive manner (fiY A@rotijaAfK); (S, TA;) and nagaDato and ↓ tanag~aDato, said of a tooth, being syn. with rajafato. (A.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. nagaDaAnN, He, or it, was, or became, disquieted, agitated, or violently agitated. (TA.) ― -b3- nagaDuwA A_ilaY AlEaduw~i (tropical:) They rose and hastened and went forth to, or towards, the enemy. (A, TA.) ― -b4- nagaDa also signifies (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, TA) was, or became, dense: (so in some copies of the K) or much in quantity: (so in other copies of the K:) or much in quantity, and dense. (TA.) And (tropical:) It (a cloud) was, or became, dense, and then became ready to rain, and was seen to move about, one part into another, without its going along: (S:) or was seen to become ready to rain, without motion, not travel-ling along: (A:) or it travelled along. (IF.) [See naAgiDN, below.] ― -b5- nagaDa A^amoruhu (assumed tropical:) His affair, or case, was, or became, in a weak, or unsound, state; syn. wahaY. (TA.) -A2- See also 4, in two places.

4 ngD * : see 1. -A2- AngDh He put it in a state of motion, commotion, agitation, or convulsion: shook it; shook it about; made it to wabble, or totter; wagged it; nodded it; as also ↓ nagaDahu; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and bihi ↓ nagaDa: (A:) namely a thing: (Msb:) or his head; (S, A, TA;) in wonder; (A;) or as one in wonder at a thing; (S, TA;) or in disapproval of a thing told him; (AHeyth, TA;) or in derision; or as though asking the meaning of what was said, inclining to the speaker. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur, [xvii. 53,] fasayunogDuwna A_ilayoka ruw^uwsahumo (S, TA) And they will shake, or wag, their heads at thee, in derision. (TA.)
5 tanag~aDa see 1, in three places.

nagoDN * One who shakes his head, and trembles in his gait: (K:) an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA.) ― -b2- A male ostrich that shakes his head: (S:) or nagoDN, as also ↓ nigoDN, is a name of the male ostrich; determinate; (K;) being a name of the species; like A^usaAmapu: (TA:) so called because, when he hastens his gait, he moves up and down: (Lth:) or a name of the male ostrich that has a habit of going round about: (AHeyth, K:) and ↓ nagoDapN [is the n. un., signifying] an ostrich. (TA.) ― -b3- See also naAgiDN.
nugoDN * : see naAgiDN, in three places.
nigoDN * : see nagoDN.

nagoDapN *
A tree. (IKt.) ― -b2- See also nagoDN.
naguwDN * A she-camel having a large hump: because, when it is large, it shakes, or quakes. (IF, K.)

nag~aADN * [In a state of much motion, commotion, agitation, or convulsion; shaking, shaking about, wabbling, tottering, wagging, or nodding, much]. You say, A_ibilN nag~aADapN biriHaAlihaA [Camels jogging much with their saddles; or jogging much their saddles]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also naAgiDN. ― -b3- nag~aADu AlbaToni Wrinkled in the belly: an expression applied to Mohammad, (K,) by 'Alee, who thus explained it: because of the elevation of the wrinkled parts above the even surface of the belly: or it may be derived from guDuwnN, meaning “ wrinkles ” in the belly, by transposition of letters. (TA.)

naAgiDN * [In a state of motion, commotion, or agitation, or convulsion; shaking; shaking about; wabbling; tottering; wagging; nodding: pl. nug~aDN]. You say, maHaAlN nug~aDN [Great pullysheaves in a state of motion, &c.]. (S, TA.) And gayomN naAgiDN (K) and ↓ nag~aADN (S, K) (tropical:) A cloud, or clouds, becoming dense, and then ready to rain, and seen to move about, one part into another, without going along: (S:) or in a state of motion, or commotion, one part after another, (K, TA,) not travelling along: (TA:) or seen to move about, one part into another, without going along. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (S, E,) or ↓ naAgiDapN. (so in a copy of the A,) and ↓ nugoDN and ↓ nugoSN (A, K,) but this is rare, (TA,) A cartilage (S:) or the cartilage of the shoulder-blade: (A, K:) or the part thereof where it mores to and fro: (K:) or the upper part of the end of the cartilage of the shoulder-blade: (TA.) or the ↓ nugoD of the shoulder-blade is the thin bone at the extremity thereof: (Sh:) or the ↓ nugoDaAni are the parts of the root of the shoulder blade that move about in walking: (L:) and the naAgiD of a man is the base of the neck, where he moves about his head, (Sh)
naAgiDapN * : see naAgiDN.

div2.head: ngf &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

nufoA^apN *
One of several parts, or portions, of scattered herbage: or one of several adjacent meadows (riyaAD), separated from, and rising above, the greater part of the pasture. pl. nufFA (K.)

1 nafatati Alqidoru * , (S, K,) aor
nafita , inf. n. nfiytN (S) and nafotN and nafataAnN, (L,) The cooking-pot boiled: (K:) or threw forth what resembled arrows, by reason of [its vehement] boiling: (S, L:) [see also nafavat, and nafaTato] or [boiled so that] the broth, or gravy, stuck to its sides: (K:) or the broth boiled in the cooking pot, and what dried thereof stuck to the sides of the pot: L:) you say [also] ↓ Alqidoru tanaAfatu, and tanaAfaTu, [for tatanaAftu and tatanaAfaTu]. (S, L [but in the latter, these two verbs are written without the syll. points].) ― -b2- yanofitu gaDabFA, as also yanofiTu, (assumed tropical:) He boils with anger. (S:) ― -b3- yanofitu Ealayohi gaDabFA, as also ynfT, (assumed tropical:) He boils against him with anger. (TA.) ― -b4- Sadoruhu yanofitu biAloEadaAwapi (tropical:) [His breast boils with enmity]. (A.) [See also nafava.] ― -b5- nafata, aor.
nafita , inf. n. nafotN and nafataAnN (L, K) and nafiytN and nafaAtN, (L,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, L) was angry: (K, L:) or nafataAnN resembles coughing: [so that the verb seems to signify he made a noise like coughing, by reason of anger:] (L:) or he blew in anger: (L:) or he blew, (nafaxa, as in the copies of the K in my hands,) or swelled, or became inflated, (Antfx,
as in the TA,) by reason of anger. (K.) ― -b6- nafata, (aor.
nafita , L,) inf. n. nafotN, It (flour or the like) had water poured upon it, and swelled, or became inflated, (tanaf~axa,) in consequence. (L, K.)
6 tanaAofata see 1.

mirojalN nafuwtN *
A cooking-pot throwing forth what resembles arrows, by reason of [its vehement] boiling: &c. (S, L.)

nafiytapN *
A certain kind of food, thicker than what is called saxiynapN; (K;) i. q. HariyqapN; made by sprinkling flour upon water or milk, (fresh milk, L,) until it becomes swollen or inflated, (yanofit,) (S, L,) when it is supped, or sipped (ytHs~aY); (L;) it is thicker than saxiynap; the master of a family uses it plentifully for his household in times of scarcity: (S, L:) they only eat nfytp and sxynp in a time of straitness, and dearness, and leanness of the cattle: Az says, in art. H*rq, sxynp is flour thrown upon water or milk, and cooked, and then eaten with dates or [here a word in the L is illegible; after which we read] and it is [what is called] HasaA'; and it is also called saxuwnapN: and nafiytapN and HariyqapN and HariyrapN and nafiyvapN are a kind of HsA, between thick and thin. (L.) [See also xaziyrN, and HariyqapN.]

1 nafava * , aor.
nafiva and
nafuva , inf. n. nafovN (S, K) and nafavaAnN, (TA,) [He puffed; or blew, without spitting: or he sputtered, or blew forth a little spittle in minute scattered particles: or] he spat: or he [did as though he] spat without ejecting spittle: and nafava fY AlEuqodapi signifies he spat, ejecting a little spittle, upon the knot, in enchantment: (Msb:) or Aln~afovu is like Aln~afoxu, or blowing, and less than Alt~afolu, or spitting, or ejecting spittle from the mouth: (S, K:) or like blowing, with [the emission of] spittle: (Keshsháf;) or like blowing, as done in enchantment, without spittle: the action, if accompanied by spittle, being termed Altfl: this is the most correct explanation: ('Ináyeh:) or gentle blowing without spittle: (AlA*kAr:) or more than blowing; or like blowing; but less than spitting: sometimes without spittle, thus differing from Altfl; and sometimes with a little spittle, thus differing from Alnfx: or the emitting wind from the mouth, together with a little spittle. (MF.) ― -b2- laA bud~a lilomaSoduwri A^ano yanofiva [He who has a disease in his chest must spit]. A proverb. (S.) ― -b3- nafavahu mino fiyhi, aor.
nafiva , inf. n. nafovN, He ejected it from his mouth. (Msb.) ― -b4- [Hence,] nafava All~`hu Al$~aYo'i fiY Alqalobi (tropical:) God cast, or put, the thing into the heart. (Msb) ― -b5- nafiva fiY ruwEiY ka*aA (tropical:) Such a thing was inspired, or put, into my mind. (A.) ― -b6- nafava fiY ruwEiY (tropical:) He (the Holy Spirit [Gabriel]) inspired, or cast, or put, into my mind, or heart. (Nh, from a trad.) ― -b7- [You say,] lawo nafava Ealayoka fulaAnN qaT~araka [If such a one blew, or spat, upon thee, he would throw thee down upon thy side.]. Said to one who tries his strength with one superior to him. (A.) ― -b8- nafava EalaY~a gaDabFA as though meaning He blew at me by reason of the violence of his anger. (L.) [See also nafata.] ― -b9- AlHay~apu tanofivu Als~am~a A_i*aA nakazato [The serpent ejects venom from its mouth when it inflicts a wound with its nose]. (S.) ― -b10- nafava It (a wound) emitted blood. (TA.) ― -b11- [From the blowing or spitting upon the knots:] nafavahu, inf. n. nafovN, He enchanted him. (Msb.) ― -b12- nafavati Alqidoru, aor.
nafiva , inf. n. nafiyvN and nafovN, The cooking-pot boiled: or, boiled, and threw forth what resembled arrows, by reason of the vehemence of its boiling. (Msb.) [See also nafatat.] It is when it begins to boil. (TA.)

nafovu Al$~ayoTaAni *
Poetry: (K, from a trad.:) called nfv because it is like a thing which a man spits, or blows, (yanofivu,) from his mouth, like incantation. (A 'Obeyd.) ― -b2- *aA mino nafavaAti fulaAnK This is of the poetry of such a one. (TA.)

damN nafiyvN *
Blood emitted by a wound (S, K) or vein. (TA.)

miy^onaAvN kaA^an~ahaA nufaAvN * [A plain land that produces many plants, or herbs, or much herbage,] as though blowing forth, or spitting forth, the pleats, or herbs. (L, from a trad.) [The correctness of nufaAvN is questioned by El-Khattábee. May it not be a mistake for naf~aAvN?]

nufaAvapN *
What one blows, or spits, (yanofivu,) from his mouth. (S.) ― -b2- What a person having a disease in his chest blows forth or spits out, yanofivu. (K.) ― -b3- What remains in one's mouth, of a siwaAk, or tooth-stick, and is spit out: (S:) a particle broken off ($aZiy~apN: so in the L &c.: in the K, $aTiybapN:) from a swAk, or tooth-stick, remaining in the mouth, and spit out. (L, K.) One says, lawo saA^alaniY nufaAvapa siwaAkK maA A^aEoTayotuhu If he asked me for a particle of a tooth-stick, remaining in my mouth, I would not give him (it). (S.)

nafiyvapN *
A certain kind of food. (See nafiytap and waTiyoy^ap.)

naf~aAvN *
An enchanter; one who is in the habit of enchanting: fem. with p. (Msb.) ― -b2- Aln~af~aAvaAtu fiY AlEuqadi [Kur, cxiii. 4,] The women who blow, without spitting, saying something at the same time, upon the knots which they tie in a thread, or string: (Jel:) meaning the enchantresses. (S, K, Jel.) [See a verse cited voce EaADihN.]

naAfivN *
Enchanting. (Msb.)
manofuwtN * A man enchanted. (A.)

1 nafaja * , (S, K,) aor.
nafuja , inf. n. nufuwjN; (Msb;) and ↓ Antfj; (TA;) It (a hare, S, K, or other animal, Msb) sprang up (S, K) from its hole; or leaped. (TA.) ― -b2- nafaja; (TA;) and ↓ Anfj, (S,) inf. n. A_inofaAjN; (Msb;) and ↓ Antfj; (TA;) He made a hare to spring up (S, &c.) from its hole; or to leap. (TA.) ― -b3- nafaja, aor.
nafija and
nafuja , inf. n. nufajN; and ↓ Antfj; It (a jerboa) ran: (M:) or slackened his run. (A.) ― -b4- nafaja, and ↓ Antfj, and ↓ tnf~j, It (anything) rose; or became elevated, or exalted. (TA.) ― -b5- nafaja, aor.
nafuja , inf. n. nafojN, He made anything to rise; or to become elevated, or exalted. (TA.) ― -b6- nafajati Alfar~uwjapu The chicken came forth from its egg. (S, K.) ― -b7- nafaja, (aor.
nafuja , inf. n. nafojN, S,) It (a woman's breast) heaved up her shift. (S, K.) ― -b8- nafajati Alr~iyHu (tropical:) The wind came with force: (S, K:) or, suddenly. (TA.) ― -b9- nafaja, inf. n. nafojN, He magnified, or made great, him, or it. (Msb, TA.) [And so,] ↓ Antfj It became great. (TA.) ― -b10- nafaja, aor.
nafuja , inf. n. nafojN; (Msb;) and ↓ Antfj, (TA,) and ↓ tnf~j; (K;) He boasted of that which he did not possess, (Msb,) and which was not in him: (TA:) or, of more than he possessed. (K.)
4 A^anofaja see 1, and 10.
5 tanaf~aja see 1, in two places.

8 A_inotafajaA HanobaA AlbaEiyri *
The sides of the camel became elevated, (S, K,) [or bulging,] and great, naturally. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the expression A_inotifaAju AlA^ahil~api (assumed tropical:) [The swelling out of the new moons], in a trad. respecting the signs [of the last day]. (TA.) ― -b3- See 1 throughout.

10 Astnfj * (IAar, M) and ↓ Anfj, (M,) He (a sportsman) drew forth a jerboa [&c. from its hole]. (M.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He drew forth, and caused to appear, the anger of a person. (K.)
nafojN * and ↓ nafaAjapN (tropical:) [A boasting of that which one does not possess, or the like: see 1, and naf~aAjN]. (A.) [See also nafoxN.]
nufoju AlHaqiybapi * A woman, (K,) and a man, (TA,) large in the buttocks: (K, TA:) or prominent therein. (TA in art. Hqb.)

nafojapN *
A single leap of a hare from the place where it has been lying. In a trad., a sedition, or disturbance, is likened to this in regard of the shortness of its duration. (TA.)
nafaAjapN * : see nafojN and naf~aAjN.

nafiyjapN *
A bow (S, K) made of a piece of wood of the kind of tree called naboE; not known by Aboo-Sa'eed with H [in the place of j]. (S [so in the copies of that work which I am using, three in number: but in one copy, “ except with H ”].)

naf~aAjN * (tropical:) A proud man; as also ↓ munotafijN: (K:) a boastful and proud man: (ISk, S:) a man who praises himself for that which is not in him: one who says that which he does not, and who boasts of that which does not belong to him and which is not in him; as also ↓ *uw nafojK (and ↓ *uw nafaAjapK, A): or one who boasts of that which he does not possess: and said to be not of high repute. (TA.) [See also naf~aA$N.]
naAfijN * : see naAfijapN.

naAfijapN * The commencement of anything, (so in two copies of the S, and so in the Msb,) or of any wind, (so in one copy of the S,) that begins with vehemence, or violence: (S, Msb:) or a wind that begins with vehemence: (K:) or, that comes with vehemence: (A:) As thinks it to be attended by cold: AHn says, that sometimes the north wind rises upon people when they have been sleeping, and almost destroys them with cold at the close of the night, when the former part of the night has been warm: (TA:) or a wind that rises upon one suddenly and vehemently, when he is not aware: (Sh:) pl. nawaAfiju. (A.) ― -b2- naAfijapN (tropical:) A cloud abounding with rain: (S, K:) so called from the same word as signifying “ a wind that comes with vehemence: ” (TA:) thus called by the name of the thing which is its cause. (S.) -A2- naAfijapN The hinder part of a rib: (S:) or, of the ribs: (K:) as also ↓ naAfijN: (TA:) pl. nawaAfiju. (S.) -A3- naAfijapN (assumed tropical:) Camels which a man inherits, and whereby his camels are increased in number. (TA.) ― -b2- naAfijapN (tropical:) A daughter: so called because she in creases the property of her father by her dowry: (K:) or, that increases the property of her father: for he takes her dowry (consisting of camels, TA) and adds it to his property, (or camels, TA,) so that the amount becomes raised. (S.) The Arabs used to say, in the time of paganism, when a daughter was born to one of them, haniyoy^A laka Aln~aAfijapu May she who is to increase thy property by her dowry be productive of enjoyment to thee! (S.) -A4- naAfijapN A bag, follicle, or vesicle, of musk: (K:) pl. nawaAfiju: (S:) an arabicized word, (S, K,) from [the Persian] naAfaho; and therefore some say that it is properly written naAfajapN: or, accord. to the Msb, it is Arabic, and a bag of musk is so called because of its high value, from nafajahu “ he magnified him, or it: ” but this requires consideration. (TA.) See faA^orapu Almisoki, voce faA^orN.
A^nofajaAniY~N * One who exaggerates, or exceeds the due bounds, in speech; (K;) and who boasts of that which he does not possess. (TA.)

manaAfiju *
Pieces of stuff with which women make their buttocks to appear large; syn EuZ~aAmaAtN. (K.)
munotafiju Aljanobayoni * A man having elevated, [or bulging,] sides. (A.) ― -b2- munotafijN A camel having prominent flanks. (TA.) See naf~aAjN.

1 nafaHa * , aor.
tafaHa , (S, L, K,) inf. n. nafoHN (L, K) and nufuwHN (L) and nufaAHN and nafaHaAnN, (K,) It (perfume) diffused its odour. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- nafaHati Alr~iyHu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
tafuHa , inf. n. nafoHN, (Msb,) (tropical:) The wind blew: (S, Msb, K:) or blew gently; began to be in a state of commotion: (A:) nafaHato and lafaHato are syn., except that the effect of Aln~afoH is greater than that of All~afoH: (Zj:) or, accord. to As, (S,) or IAar, (TA,) nafoHN relates to a cold, or cool, wind; and lafoHN, to a hot wind: (S, TA.) [but see nafoHapN]. ― -b3- nafaHatohu Aljnwb bibarodihaA (tropical:) The south wind blew upon it with its cold, or coolness. (IB.) ― -b4- nafaHa AlEiroqa, (aor.
tafaHa , inf. n. nafoHN, S,) (tropical:) The vein ejected, or spirted forth, blood. (S, K.) And in like manner, nafaHati AlT~aEonapu biAld~ami (tropical:) The stab ejected, or spirted forth, blood. (TA.) ― -b5- nafaHa All~abana nafoHapa (tropical:) He churned the milk once. (A.) -A2- nafaHahu bAls~ayofi (tropical:) He struck him, or it, lightly, or slightly, with the sword: (A:) he reached, or hit, him, or it, (tanaAwalahu,) with the sword (S, L, K) from a distance, (S, L,) by a side-blow, $azorFA. (L.) ― -b2- nafaHa, inf. n. nafoHN, He struck, smote, or beat. (L.) See 3. ― -b3- nafaHa, inf. n. nafoHN, He threw, or cast. (L.) ― -b4- nafaHa $ayoy^FA (assumed tropical:) He thrust, or pushed, or repelled, a thing from him. (L.) ― -b5- nafaHati Ald~aAb~apu, aor.
tafaHa , inf. n. nafoHN, The horse, or the like, kicked, or struck, with its hind leg: (L:) or, with its hoof: (Msb:) or, with the extremity of its hoof: Aln~afoHu is said to be with one hind leg: and Alr~amoHu, with both hind legs together. (L.) nafaHati Aln~aAqapu The she-camel struck, or kicked, with her hind leg. (S.) A^aboTala nafoHa Ald~aAb~api He made the kicking of the horse, or the like, with its hind leg, to be of no account; not to require anything to be paid by its owner. (L.) [See 3 in art. Eqb.] -A3- nafaHahu bi$aYo'K, (inf. n. nafoHN, Msb,) (tropical:) He gave him a thing. (S, K.) ― -b2- nafaHahu nafoHapF (tropical:) He gave him a gift; or conferred upon him a favour]. (S.) [See an ex. voce Earabap.]

3 naAfaHuwhumo * (inf. n. munaAfaHapN, TA) (tropical:) They contended with them with swords face to face; or encountered them in war face to face, having before their faces neither shields nor anything else; syn. kaAfaHuwhumo: (S, K:) originally signifying they approached them in fight so near that the breath of each party reached the other (TA.) ― -b2- nAfHhu (tropical:) He contended with him. (K.) ― -b3- nAfH Eanohu; (S, A;) and Eanohu ↓ nafaHa, (A,) inf. n. nafoHN. (IAar;) (tropical:) He contended for him, or in defence of him; (S;) repelled from him, and defended him: (IAar, A:) as also nADH. (TA.)

nafoHapN *
An odour, whether good or bad: or a plenteous odour; differing from nafoxapN, which is a slight odour: (AHn, in L, art. nfx:) pl. nafaHaAtN. (L.) You say lahu nafoHapN Tay~ibapN, (S, L.) and xabiyvapN, (L,) It has a good, or sweet, and a bad, or foul, odour. (L.) ― -b2- nafoHapN (tropical:) A blast, or breath, of wind. (K.) ― -b3- nafoHapN mina AlS~abaA (tropical:) A pleasant and fragrant blast of the east wind. And nfHpN mino samuwmK (tropical:) A grievous blast of hot wind. (AHeyth.) ― -b4- nafoHapN mina AlEa*aAbi (assumed tropical:) A part, or portion, of punishment: (S, K:) or a grievous blast of punishment: (AHeyth:) or a most violent infliction of punishment. (L.) ― -b5- nafoHapN Ald~ami (tropical:) The first gush of blood from a wound. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, L.) ― -b6- nafoHapN (tropical:) A single churning (maHoDapN so in the A and TA: in. the CK and a MS copy of the K. maHoDap, with H unpointed:) of milk. (A, K.) ― -b7- [See 1.] ― -b8- nafoHpN (tropical:) A gift: (Msb:) [pl. nafaHaAtN]. ― -b9- lA tazaAlu lifulaAn nafaHaAtN mna AlmaEoruwfi (S, L) There cease not to be attributable to such a one acts of kindness, or favours. (L.) ― -b10- tEar~aDuwA linafaHaAti raHomapi A@ll~`hi (tropical:) (TA:) see art. ErD, ?? taEar~aDa.

riyHN nafuwHN * (tropical:) A wind that blows violently, and raises the dust. (L.) ― -b2- yamaAniy~apN nafuwHN (tropical:) A south wind (S, IB) that blows coldly, or coolly (IB.) ― -b3- daAb~apN nafuwHN A horse, or the like, that kicks with its kind leg: or, with the extremity of its hoof. (L.) [See 1.] ― -b4- nafuwHN (tropical:) A she-camel whose milk comes forth without its being drawn from the teat: (S, K:) and an udder that does not retain its milk. (AZ.) See naf~aAHN. -A2- qawosN nfuwHN (tropical:) A bow that sends the arrow far; or that impels the arrow with force: (S, A, K:) as also ↓ nafiyHapN (K) and ↓ minofaHapN: (TA:) each of which two words is a name for a bow: (S, with respect to the former, and TA, with respect to the latter:) pl. of the former nafuAy^iHu: (S:) and ↓ nafyHpN signifies a branch of the tree called naboE, of which a bow is made. (ISk, S, K.) [See also nafiyjapN, with H.]
nafiyHapN * : see nafuwHN.

misokN naf~aAHN * [Musk that diffuses much odour or fragrance]. (A, art. xTr.) -A2- TaEonapN naf~aAHapN (tropical:) A
stab that ejects, or spirts forth, blood, much, or vehemently. (TA.) ↓ TaEonapN nafuwHN (tropical:) A stab that ejects its blood quickly. (T.) -A3- naf~aAHN (tropical:) One who gives many gifts. (TA.) ― -b2- Aln~af~aAHu, (K,) or Aln~af~aAHu biAlxayori, (TA,) The Bestower of [many] benefits upon mankind, or the creation: (K:) an epithet applied to God; but disapproved by some, because not so applied in the Kur-án or the traditions.

naAfiHN *
Diffusing odour; fragrant. Ex. naAfijapN naAfiHapN A bag, or vesicle, of mush diffusing odour, or fragrant: pl. nawaAfiHu. (A.)

A_inofaHapN * (S, K, &c.) said to be the most common form of the word, (TA,) for which one should not say A^anofaHapN, (ISk,) but this is mentioned by Ibn-Et-Teiyánee and the author of the 'Eyn, (MF,) and sometimes it is written and pronounced A_inofaH~apN, (K,) or this is the most common form, (Msb,) and most approved, (ISk,) and sometimes A_inofiHapN, (K,) and ↓ minofaHapN, (IAar, S, K,) and binofaHapN, (IAar, K,) with b in the place of the m, (TA,) [The rennet, or rennet-bag, of a kid or lamb; i. e.] A substance that comes forth from the belly of a kid, containing coagulated milk which is termed libaA^o, used as a means of converting fresh milk into cheese: (IDrst:) or a thing that is taken forth from the belly of a sucking-pig, (or lamb, Msb,) of a yellow colour, and squeezed in some cotton, (which is soaked, into milk, L, Msb,) whereupon it (i. e. the milk, MF) becomes thick, like cheese: (L, Msb, K:) or the stomach (kari$) of a lamb or kid before it eats: (AZ, S, Msb:) when it eats, it is called kari$. (AZ, S.) F imputes inadvertence to J in his explaining AnfHp by the term kari$; but he does not explain it by this term absolutely; and F adds to his own explanation what makes it exactly the same as that of J, [except that he makes it relate to a kid only,] saying “ when the kid eats, it, ” that is the AnfHp, “ is called kari$. ” (MF.) None but a ruminating animal has an AnfHp. (Lth.) The pl. is A^anaAfiHu. (S, K.) Any AnfHp, especially [that of] the hare, if hung upon the thumb of a person suffering from a fever, cures him. (K.) ― -b2- A_inofaHapN also signifies A kind of tree ($ajar) resembling the baA*inojaAn. (K.)
minofaHapN * : see nafuwHN and A_infaHapN.

1 nafaxa bifamihi * , (K,) aor.
nafuxa , [accord, to Golius and Freytag, incorrectly,
nafaxa ; see Kur, iii. 43, &c.] inf. n. nafoxN; (Msb;) and ↓ nf~x, (K,) inf. n. tanofiyxN; (TA;) He blew with his mouth; sent forth wind from his mouth; (K;) this is done in taking rest, and in labour or exertion, and the like. (L.) nafaxa is mostly used as a neut. v.; but sometimes it is trans., as many have asserted: you say nafaxa AlS~uwra, as well as nafaxa fiyhi, He blew the trumpet, or blew into the trumpet: (MF, TA:) nafaxahu is a dial. form of nafaxa fiyhi: (S:) also, nafaxa fiY Aln~aAri [he blew the fire; or blew into the fire]: [see 8 (last sentence) in art. qwt:] and nafaxa fY Alz~iq~i [he blew into, or inflated, the skin]: and sometimes one says nafaxahu. (Msb.) nufoxuwA occurs in a verse of El-Katámee for nufixuwA. (S.) ― -b2- nafaxa Al$~ayoTaAnu fiY A^anofihi (assumed tropical:) [The devil blew into his nose]: said of him who aspires to that which is not for him. (TA.) ― -b3- nafaxa $idoqayohi (tropical:) [He inflated, or puffed out, the sides of his mouth; meaning] he was proud, or affected pride. (A.) ― -b4- nafaxahu, aor.
nafuxa , inf. n. nafoxN, It (food) inflated him, or filled him. (L.) ― -b5- nafixa, aor.
nafaxa , inf. n. (L) nafaxN, (S, L,) He (a man, S, and a horse, L) had inflated testicles. (S, L.) ― -b6- Also, He (a beast of carriage) had his pasterns inflated with wind. When a beast thus affected walks, the humour subsides. (L.) ― -b7- nafaxa nihaA Pepedit; crepitum ventris emisit. (S, K.) ― -b8- nafaxati Alr~iyHu The wind came suddenly. (L.) ― -b9- nafaxato bihimu AlT~ariyqu (tropical:) The road cast [or brought] them suddenly [to a place]: from nfxt AlryH. (L.) -A2- nafaxati AlD~uHaY, inf. n. nafoxN, (tropical:) The morning became advanced, and the sun high. (L, K.) You say also Aln~ahaAru ↓ Antfx (tropical:) The day became advanced, the sun being high, (S, L,) an hour before noon. (L.)
2 naf~axa see 1.
5 tanaf~axa see 8.

8 Antfx *
It (a thing, S, as a skin, Msb,) became inflated, or puffy; (S, A, Msb;) as also ↓ tnf~x: (A:) also, it became swollen; i. q. warima. (K, art. wrm.) ― -b2- Antfx He became inflated, or filled, by food. (L.) See 1. ― -b3- A_inotifaAxu AlA^ahil~api (tropical:) The bigness [or swelling] of the new moons. Occurring in a trad. respecting the signs of the last day. (L.) [See Antfj.] ― -b4- Antfx EalaY~a (assumed tropical:) [He became inflated against me; i. e.] he was angry with me. (TA.) And Antfx lahu (assumed tropical:) [He behaved angrily to him]. (TA in art. zHr.)

nafoxN * [Flatulence. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) Boastfulness; arrogance; pride; (S, K;) [inflation with pride]: pride was termed by Mohammad nafoxu Al$~ayoTaAni. (TA, art. hmz.) ― -b3- rajulN *uw nafoxK, as also *w nafoji, (tropical:) A boastful, arrogant, proud man; (S;) [a man inflated with pride].
nufuxN * (assumed tropical:) A young man (TA) full of youthfulness [or youthful plumpness or vigour]; (K;) and so, without p, a damsel. (TA.)

nafoxapN * and nufoxapN and nifoxapN Inflation of the belly (S, K) by food &c. (TA.) You say bihi nfxpN He has an inflation of the body: (K:) and A^ajidu nfxpF I experience an inflation of the body. (S.) ― -b2- [And A flatulent humour of any kind: a meaning well known.] ― -b3- Aln~afoxapu The blast [of the horn] of the day of resurrection. (L.) ― -b4- nafoxapN A slight odour: differing from nafoHapN, which is a plenteous odour. (L.) ― -b5- nafoxapu Al$~abaAbi (tropical:) The chief part of youth. (L.) nafoxapu Alr~abiyEi (tropical:) The time of the season called AlrbyE when the earth produces herbs, or herbage: (A:) or nufoxapu AlrbyE, and nifoxatuhu, the time of that season when vegetation has ended. (AZ:) ― -b6- nufoxapN A disease that attacks a horse, and makes his testicles to swell. (L.) ― -b7- See nuf~aAxN.

nafoxaA='u * (applied to land, or ground, S) i. q. naboxaA='u: (S, L, K:) or elevated and good or fertile ground, in which is no sand nor stones, producing a few trees; and so nahodaA='u, except that this latter is more flat and extensive: or soft land, in which is elevation: (L:) or tumid earth, that breaks in pieces when trodden upon: (TA, voce rax~aA='u:) pl. nafaAxiY~u: it has a form of pl. proper to substs, because it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (L.) ― -b2- nafoxaA='u The upper part of the bone of the sAq [or shank, or tibia]. (K.)
nafiyxN * One who is employed to blow a fire. (K.)

nuf~aAxN *
An inflation of a humour occasioned by disease, (T, K,) arising in any part: (T:) a humour; as also ↓ nafoxapN. (L.) ― -b2- See nuf~aAxapN.

nuf~aAxapN *
A bubble upon water. (L, K [but in some copies of the K, for AlHajaApu is erroneously put AlHjArp.]) ― -b2- [The air-bladder of a fish;] an inflated thing in the belly of a fish, which is (as they assert, L,) its niSaAb [app. meaning its most essential part, or element,] by means of which it rises in the water, and moves to and fro. (L, K.) ― -b3- A bladder of a plant (S, O, L, voce qataAdN, &c.) N. un. of nuf~aAxN (AHn, in TA, voce Eu$~arN.) [And in anatomy, A cell.]

maA biAld~aAri naAfixu DaramapK * [There is not in the house a blower of a fire; i. e.,] there is not in the house any one. (S.) ― -b2- naAfixN HiDonayohi [A man inflating, or puffing out, his sides;] inflated, and ready to do mischief, or evil. (L, from a trad.)

A^anofaxu * A man, (S, L, K,) and a horse, (L,) having inflated testicles: (S, L, K:) syn. of A=daru. (Mgh, in art, Adr.) ― -b2- Also, A beast of carriage having his pasterns inflated with wind: see nafixa. (L.)

rajulN A^unofuxaAnN * , and A_inofixaAnN, and A^unofuxaAniY~N, and A_inofixaAniY~N, fem. with p, (assumed tropical:) A man full of fat; (K;) inflated with flaccid fat, and so ↓ rHl manofuwxN; pl. manofuwxuwan. (TA.)
minofaxN * : see what follows.

minofaAxN * (S, L, Msb, K) and ↓ minofaxN (Msb) The instrument with which a fire is blown; (Msb, K:) a blacksmith's bellows: the thing with which a fire or other thing is blown: (L:) the thing into which one blows. (S.) See also kyrN ― -b2- minofaAxu Alr~aAEiY The instrument [i. e. reed-pipe] of the pastor, with which he calls together the camels. (A, TA, voce $iyaAEN.)
manaAfixu Al$~ayoTaAni * (assumed tropical:) The suggestions of the devil (TA.)

manofuwxN * (assumed tropical:) Big-bellied; (K, TA;) [inflated in the belly]. ― -b2- Also, (K,) ↓ munotafixN, (TA,) (tropical:) Fat; as an epithet; (A, K;) [inflated, or swollen, with fat]. See A^unofixaAnN. ― -b3- manofuwxN (tropical:) A coward: so called because he swells out his lungs. (L.)
munotafixN * (tropical:) A man inflated, or puffed, or filled, with pride, and with anger. (L.) See manofuwxN.

1 nafida * , aor.
nafada , inf. n. nafaAdN (S, A, L, Msb, K) and nafadN, (L, K,) It (a thing, S, &c.) passed away and came to an end; became spent, exhausted, or consumed; failed entirely; ceased; syn. faniY (S, A, L, Msb, K) and *ahaba (S, L, K) and AinoqaTaEa. (L, Msb.)

4 Anqdhu * (S, A, L, Msb, K) and ↓ Astnfdhu (A, L, K) and ↓ Antfdh (K) He caused it to pass away or come to an end; spent, exhausted, or consumed, it; caused it to fail entirely; caused it to cease; made an end of it. (S, A, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- AnfdwA maA Einodahumo, and ↓ Astnfdwhu, They spent, exhausted, or consumed, what they had. (A, L.) ― -b3- wusoEahu ↓ Astnfd He spent, exhausted, or exerted, to the utmost his ability or power (S, L, Msb.) ― -b4- Anfd Alaqowum The people came to that state that their travelling-provisions were exhausted, or had come to an end: (S, A, L, K:) or, (in the K, and,) their property had passed away and come to an end. (S, L, K.) ― -b5- Anfdt Alr~akiy~apu The well lost its water. (L, K.)

3 nAfdhu * , (inf. n. munaAfadapN, L,) [He exerted his whole power, or ability, in contention, dispute, or litigation, with him: see munaAfidN:] he contended with him in arguments, pleas, or allegations, so as to put an end to his argument, and overcome him: (L:) or he contended with him before a judge; (IAth, L, K;) contended, disputed, or litigated with him. (K.) It is said in a trad., A_ino naAfadotahumo naAfaduwk (S, L) If thou contend with them before a judge, they will so contend with thee: or if thou allege to them, they will allege to thee: (IAth, L;) but accord. to one relation, the verb is with q (S, L.) and accord. to another, the latter verb is with *, nAf*wk. (L.)

6 tnAfdwA *
They contended, disputed, or litigated, together. (A.) See 3, and see also tnAf*wA, with *.]

8 Antfdhu * : see 4, ― -b2- He exacted, took, or received, it fully, or wholly (K) ― -b3- Antfd mino Eadowihi He exacted the full, or utmost, rate of his running. Said with reference to a horse. (M, L.) ― -b4- Antfd All~abana He drew forth the milk. (K.)
10 A_isotanofada see 4.

munaAfidN * A man who exerts his whole power, or ability, in contention, dispute, or litigation, (S, L,) and who does so well, so as to put an end to the arguments, pleas, or allegations, of his adversary, and overcome him: (L:) who contends with his adversary in arguments, pleas, or allegations, so as to put an end to his argument. (A, L.) One says, layo$a lahu raAfidN walaA munaAfidN He has not an aider, or assistant, nor one who contends &c. (A, TA.)

fiyhi munotafadN Eano gayorihi *
In him is that which renders thee in no need of any other. (Aboo-Sa'eed, T, L, K. *) ― -b2- A_in~a fiY maAlihi lamunotafadN Verily in his wealth is ample provision. (AZ, T, L, K *) ― -b3- tajadu fiY AlbilaAdi munotafadFA (in the TK mutanaf~adFA) Thou wilt find in the countries, or towns, a place to which to flee and in which to seek gain; syn. muraAgamFA wamuDoTarabFA (K.) See also munotafa*N.

qaEada munotafidFA *
He set aside, or apart. (IAar. L, K.)

1 nafa*a * , aor.
nafu*a , (M, L,) inf. n. nafaA*N and nufuw*N, (M, L, K,) It went, or passed, through: (L:) or it went, or passed, through a thing, and became clear of it. (M, L, K.) ― -b2- nafa*otu I went, or passed, through. (L.) ― -b3- nafa*a Als~ahomu, aor.
nafu*a , inf. n. nufuw*N and nafaA*N, The arrow perforated, transpierced, or pierced through, the animal at which it was shot, and went forth from it: (Msb:) or nafa*a Als~ahomu Alr~amiy~apa, (M, L,) and nafa*a minohaA, (S, L,) and fiyhaA, (M, A, L,) aor.
nafu*a , (M, L,) inf. n. nafaA*N (M, A, L, K) and nufuw*N (A) and nafo*N, (M, L, K,) the arrow penetrated into the inside of the animal at which it was shot, and its extremity went forth from the other side, or protruded from it, the rest remaining therein; the extremity of the arrow passed through the animal at which it was shot, the rest remaining therein; (M, L, K;) a part of the arrow passed through, or went forth or protruded from, the animal at which it was shot. (A, art. Srd.) See shomN naAfi*N ― -b4- nafa*ati AlT~aEonapu The wound made by a spear or the like passed through, or beyond, the other side (T, L.) ― -b5- Aunofu*o Eanoka Go thou from thy place; pass thou from it. (L.) [See also Eano.] ― -b6- nafa*a liwajohihi He went his way. (TA.) ― -b7- nafad AlT~ariyqu (tropical:) The road was [a thoroughfare (see naAfi*N)] pervious, or passable, to every one in common. (Msb.) ― -b8- h`*aA AlT~ariyqu yanofudu A_ilaY makaAni ka*aA [This road is a thoroughfare, along which every one may pass, to such a place]. (T, M, * L.) ― -b9- nafa*a Alamonzilu A_ilaY AlT~ariyqi (tropical:) The house, or abode, [was a thoroughfare, and] communicated with the road. (Msb.) ― -b10- nafa*a Alqawoma He passed through the people, and left them behind him; (T, M, L, K;) as also ↓ A^anofa*ahumo; (L, K;) or only the former is used in this sense (L.) See also the latter. ― -b11- naf*ahumu AlbaSaru (tropical:) The sight reached them, and extended beyond them: (Ks, L:) or, extended over them all: (A'Obeyd, L:) you say also, AlbaSaru ↓ A^anofa*ahumu in the former sense (L:) [or The sight penetrated into the midst of them: see A^anofa*a Alqawoma.] ― -b12- nafa*a raA^oyuhu (assumed tropical:) His judgment was penetrating; syn. vafaba. (K in art vfb) ― -b13- nafa*a fiY AlA^amori (tropical:) He acted, or went on, with penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in the affair; syn. maDaY (S, K, art. mDY.) ― -b14- nafa*a AlkitaAbu A_ilaY fulaAnK, inf. n. nafaA*N and nufuw*N, (tropical:) [The letter passed to, came to, or reached, such a one]: (S, L:) [and in like manner, Alr~asuwlu the messenger: see 4.] ― -b15- nafa*a AlA^amoru,and Alqawolu, (assumed tropical:) The command, or order, and the saying, was effectual; had effect; was, or became, executed, or performed; syn. maDaY. (Msb.) ― -b16- nafa*a AlEitoqu (assumed tropical:) [The act of emancipation had, or took effect; was, or became, executed. or performed; and in like manner, a covenant, contract, sale, &c.: see 4]. App. a met. expression, from nufuw*u Als~ahomi; because there is no retracting it. (Msb.) ― -b17- yanofudu bayonanaA (tropical:) He shall judge between us, and make his command or order to have effect, or execute or perform it. (L.) ― -b18- lahu nafaA*N fiY AlA^umuwri (tropical:) [He has ability in affairs, to execute, or perform]. (A.)
2 naf~a*a see 4.

3 nAf*hu * (assumed tropical:) He cited him before a judge. It is said in a trad., An naAfa*otahumo naAfa*uwka If thou cite them before a judge, they will do the same to thee; meaning, If thou say to them, they will
say to thee. Accord. to one relation, the verb is with q and d. (L.) [Accord. to another, it is with f and *.]

4 Anf* Als~ahoma * , (A, Msb,) and ↓ nf~*hu, (Msb,) He made the arrow to pierce, and go forth from, or to pass through, the animal at which it was shot: (Msb:) [or, to penetrate within the animal at which it was shot, and to protrude its extremity from the other side, the rest remaining within; accord. to the explanation of nafa*a Als~ahomu in the M, L, K: or to penetrate the animal at which it was shot, and to protrude a part of it from the other side; accord. to the explanation of sahomN naAfi*N in the A, art. Srd.] You say also, A^anofa*otu fiyhi Als~ahoma [I made the arrow to pierce, or penetrate, him, &c.] (A.) ― -b2- ramayotuhu faA^anofa*otuhu I shot, or cast, at him, and pierced, or made a hole, through him. (Mgh.) ― -b3- See 1. ― -b4- Anf* AlA^amora (assumed tropical:) [He brought to pass the command, or order; made it effectual; made it to have effect; executed or performed it: and in like manner, the saying: see 1]. ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He executed, performed, or accomplished, the affair. (M, L, K.) ― -b6- Anf* Alqawoma He became [or entered] among the people: (M, L:) in the copies of the K, explained by SaAra minohumo; but the correct reading is bayonahumo [as in the M and L]: (TA:) or he penetrated into them, and went, or walked, in the midst of them. (T, L, K.) See also nafa*a Alqawoma. ― -b7- Anf* kitaAbFA A_ilaY fulaAnK; (S, L;) and ↓ nf~*hu, (A,) inf. n. tanofiy*N; (S, L;) (tropical:) [He sent, or transmitted, a letter to such a one; caused it to pass to or to reach him]: and in like manner, rasuwlFA a messenger. (A.) ― -b8- Anf* Eahodahu, inf. n.
