A_inofaA*N (assumed tropical:) He made his covenant, or contract, or the like, to take effect; executed or performed it: [and in like manner, an act of emancipation: see 1.] (L, TA.)

6 tanaAfa*uwA A_ilayohi * (assumed tropical:) They came to him, (namely, a judge,) and referred to him their cause, or suit, for judgment. When each party adduces his plea, or allegation, one says tnAfdwA, with d, unpointed. (Aboo-Sa'eed, T, L, K. *)

TaEonapN lahaA nafa*N *
i. q. TaEonapN naAfi*apN; (S;) A wound having a passage through the other side; by nafa*N being meant manofa*N, or nufuw*N: (T, L:) pl. A^anofaA*N. (A.) Keys Ibn-El-Khateem says (see Ham. p. 85),
TaEanotu A@bona Eabodi Alqayosi TaEonapa vaAy^irK
lahaA nafa*N lawolaA Al$~aEaAEu A^aDaA'ahaA
(T, S, L) I pierced the son of 'Abd-El-Keys with the wound of one making an angry assault, that had a passage through, which, but for the spirtling blood, would have made it show the light through him. (T, L [See also $uEaAEN.]) See also manofa*N. ― -b2- nafa*N (tropical:) A place, or way, or means, of exit, escape, or safety; syn. maxorajN (T, S, A, L, K.) So in the saying A^ataY binafa*i maA qaAla (tropical:) He effected a means of escape from [the natural consequences of] what he had said; i. e., biAlmaxoraji minohu. (T, S, A, L, K.) It occurs in a trad., where it is said, that unless a man who has published against a Muslim a charge of which he is clear do this, he is to be punished. (T, L.) ― -b3- nafa*N a subst., (M, L,) used in the sense of A_inofaA*N: (T, M, L, K: *) nafa*N A^amorK signifying (assumed tropical:) [The making a command, or order, effectual; making it to have effect; to be executed or performed;] i. q. A_inofaA*uhu: (T, L:) you say, A^amara binafa*ihi (assumed tropical:) He commanded that it should have effect, or be executed or performed;] i. e., biA_inofaA*ihi: (M, L:) and qAm Almusolimuwna binafa*i AlkitaAbi (assumed tropical:) [The Muslims accomplished the execution, or performance, of what was in the Scripture:] i. e. bA_infaA*i maA fiyhi. (T, A, L.)
nafuw*N * : see naAfi*N.
A^amorN nafiy*N * (assumed tropical:) An affair arranged, or made easy. (L.) See also naAfi*N.
naf~aA*N * : see naAfi*N.

sahomN naAfi*N * [An arrow that perforates, transpierces, or pierces through, and goes forth from, or passes through, the animal at which it is shot; accord. to the explanation of the verb in the Msb: or, that penetrates into the inside of the animal at which it is shot, and of which the extremity goes forth from the other side, or protrudes from it, the rest remaining therein; accord. to the explanation of the verb in the M, L, K: or,] of which a part has passed through the animal at which it is shot: when the extremity only has passed through, it is termed SAridN; and when the whole of it has passed through, maAriqN. (A, art. Srd.) ― -b2- TaEonapN naAfi*apN A wound made by a spear or the like passing through both sides: (M, L:) pl. TaEanaAtN nawaAfi*u. (A.) See also nafa*N. ― -b3- TariyqN naAfi*N (tropical:) A road which is a thoroughfare; (T, M, L, K;) [pervious;] not stopped up; (T, L;) along which every one may pass. (T, A, L, Msb.) See also manofa*N. ― -b4- naAfi*N sing. of nawaAfi*u, (Msb,) which signifies All the holes, or perforations, by which joy or grief is conveyed to the mind (of a man, Msb); as the two ear-holes, (IAar, on the authority of Abu-l-Mekárim, T, L, Msb, K,) and the two nostrils, and the mouth, and the anus: (IAar, T, L, K: *) called by the doctors of practical law manaAfi*u, which is contr. to analogy: see manofai*N. (Msb.) ― -b5- naAfi*N and ↓ nafuw*N and ↓ naf~aA*N [but the second and third are intensive epithets] (tropical:) A man (M, L) penetrating, or acting with a penetrative energy, or sharp, energetic, vigorous, and effective, (maADK,) in all his affairs. (M, L, K.) ― -b6- rajulN naAfi*N fiY A^amorihi (tropical:) A man penetrating, or acting with a penetrative energy, or sharp, vigorous, and effective, in his affair; (S, L;) and fY AlA^umuwri in affairs. (A.) ― -b7- A^amoruhu naAfi*N (assumed tropical:) His command, or order, is effectual; has effect; is executed, or performed; syn. maADK (K;) and obeyed; (S, L, Msb, K; *) as also ↓ nafiy*N. (K.) ― -b8- daAy^irapN naAfi*apN A feather, or curl of hair in a horse's coat, of the kind which, when it is only on one side, is called haqoEapN, but which is on both sides. (AO, T, L.)

*aA manofa*u Alqawomi * , and ↓ nafa*uhomu; and h`*ihi manaAfi*uhumo, and A^anofaA*uhumo, [This is the place of passage of the people, and these are their places of passage]. (A.) ― -b2- h`*aA AlT~ariyqu manofa*N limaHal~i ka*aA (tropical:) This road is a way along which every one may pass to such a place. (A.) ― -b3- fiyhi manofa*N llqawomi (tropical:) In it (the road) is a [free, or an open,] passage to, or for, the people. (T, L.) See also naAfi*N.

manofi*N * , in measure like masojidN, [or manofa*N, agreeably with analogy, as it is written in copies of the T, A, L,] A place by which a thing passes through; [a thoroughfare; an outlet; a place of egress:] pl. manaAfi*u. (Msb.) See also naAfi*N.

munotafa*N * (assumed tropical:) Ample room, space, or scope, or liberty to act &c.: (syn. saEapN, (M, L, K, TA,) and manoduwHapN: (TA:) [ample means of escape: see also nafa*N:] you say, A_in~a fiY *`lika lamunotafa*FA Verily in that there is ample room, scope, or means [for action, or for escape]. (TA.) See also munotafadN.

1 nafara * , (T, M, L, Msb, K,) aor.
nafira , (T, M, K,) and
nafura , (M, K,) inf. n. naforN and nafaraAnN (M, K) or nufuwrN, (Msb,) said of a wild animal, (T, Msb,) a gazelle, (M, K,) or other beast, (M,) He took fright, and fled, or ran away at random; or became refractory, and went away at random; or ran away, or broke loose, and went hither and thither by reason of his sprightliness; syn. $arada; (M, K;) as also ↓ Astnfr; (T, Msb, K;) and so the former verb in speaking of a camel, or a beast: (L, art. $rd:) you say, nafarati Ald~aAb~apu, (T, S, M, A, K,) aor.
nafira and
nafura , (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. nufuwrN and nifaArN (T, S, M, A, K) and naforN: (A:) or this signifies the beast was, or became, impatient (A, K, TA) of or at a thing, (TA,) [or shied at it,] and retired to a distance; (A, K, TA;) and ↓ A_isotinofaArN signifies the same as nufuwrN: (S:) or nafara, inf. n.
nifaArN [and nufuwrN], signifies he fled, and went away or aside or apart or to a distance. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence, nafara, aor.
nafira and
nafura , inf. n. nufuwrN and nifaArN and naforN and nafiyrN, as used in the following phrases.] nafarotu mino h`*aA AlA^amori (tropical:) I shrank from this thing or affair; was averse from it; did not like or approve it. And nafara fulaAnN mino SuHobapi fulaAnK (tropical:) [Such a one shrank, or was averse, from the companionship of, or the associating with, such a one]. And nafarati AlmaroA^apu mino zawojihaA (tropical:) [The woman was averse from her husband; or shunned or avoided him]. (All from the A.) And you say of a man's disposition, Eani AlHaq~i ↓ tanaf~ara (tropical:) [It shunned, or was averse from, the truth] (Bd, lxvii. 21.) ― -b3- A_il~aA nufuwrFA, in the Kur, [xvii. 43, and xxxv. 40,] means (tropical:) Save in aversion and nafiyrN is like nufuwrN: and the subst. is nafarN, with two fet-hahs. (Msb) ― -b4- nafara Al$~aYo'u mina Al$~aYo'i inf. n. nifaArN [and nufuwrN], The thing receded, withdrew, removed, or became remote or aloof, from the thing. (A'Obeyd, T, S.) [See also 3.] ― -b5- Hence it is, I think, that nafara is used as signifying (tropical:) It became swollen, in the following words of a trad. of 'Omar: taxal~ala rajulN fiY zamaAnihi biAlqaSabi fanafara fuwhu (tropical:) A man, in his time, picked his teeth with reeds, and in consequence his mouth became swollen: as though the flesh, disliking the disease, receded from it, and so became swollen. (A'Obeyd, T, S. *) You say also, nafarati AlEayonu, aor.
nafira and
nafura , inf. n. nufuwrN. (tropical:) His eye became inflamed and swollen: and so you say of other parts of the person. (M, K. *) And nafara AljuroHu, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) The wound became swollen: (T, Msb:) or it became so after healing. (W, i. 42.) And nafara Aljilodu (tropical:) The skin became swollen, (S, A,) and the flesh receded from it. (A.) [All these significations seem to be derived from the first in this art.: and so several others which follow.] ― -b6- nafarotu A_ilaY A@ll~`hi, inf. n. nifaArN, I betook myself to God by reason of fear, seeking protection. (IKtt) ― -b7- nafaruwA, (Msb,) inf. n. naforN, (M, Msb, K,) They became separated, or dispersed: (M, * Msb, K: *) and so nafarto, said of camels. (TA.) Hence, (M,) the saying, laqiytuhu qabola kul~i SayoHK wanaforK, (S, M, A.) a proverb, in which the last word is used tropically; (A;) explained in art. SyH, q. v. (S.) [And gaDiba mino gayori SayoHK walaA nafKro; explained in the same art.] ― -b8- nafara AlHaAj~u mino minFY, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
nafira , (S, M, K,) inf. n. naforN (M, Msb, K) and nafarN (M) and nufuwrN (K) [and nafiyrN], The pilgrims removed from Minè. (Msb.) Hence, yawomu Aln~afori, and Aln~afari, and Aln~afuwri, and Aln~afiyri, (S, M, K,) and layolapu Aln~afori, (S, TA,) and Aln~afari, (TA,) [The day of, and the night immediately preceding, the removing from Minè]; after the day called yawomu Alqar~i: (S;) [therefore. the twelfth of Dhu-l-Hijjeh:] or there are two days thus called: (Msb:) yawomu Aln~afori AlA^aw~alu is [the day above mentioned,] the second of the days called A^ay~aAmu Alt~a$oriyqi; (IAth, Msb;) and yawomu Aln~afor AlA~xiru, (IAth,) or Alv~aAniY, (Msb,) is the third thereof: (IAth, Msb:) the order is this; yawomu Aln~aHori, then yawomu Alqar~i, then yawomu Aln~afor AlA^aw~alu then yawomu Aln~afori AlA=xiru. (T, L) ― -b9- nafaruwA fiY AlA^amori, (S, M.) or liloA^amori, (K,) aor.
nafira , (M, K.) inf. n. nufuwrN (S, M, K) and nifArN (M, K) and nafiyrN; (Zj, M, K;) and ↓ tnAfrwA; (M, K;) They went, or went away, to execute the affair: (M, K:) and in like manner, fiY AlqitaAli to fight. (M.) And naqaruwA, alone, They went forth to war against unbelievers or the like. So in the Kur, is 82. waqaAlwA laA tanofiruwA fY AlHr~i qulo naArN jahan~ama A^a$adN Har~aA [And they said, Go not ye forth to war against the unbelievers in the heat: say, The fire of hell is hotter]: and so in the same chap. v. 39: (Jel:) and in the same book, iv. 73. (Bd.) You say also, nafaruwA lahumo They went forth to fight them. (TA, from a trad.) And tafaruwA A_ilY AlHarob They hastened to the war, or to war. (Msb.) ― -b10- [Hence,] nafawuA maEahu; and ↓ A^anofaruwhu, (M, K,) inf. n. A_inofaArN; (TA;) They aided and succoured them: (M, K:) or the former verb, alone, they, being asked to do so, complied, and went forth to aid. (TA.) ― -b11- nafrabinaA: see 2.

2 naf~r * , (T, M, A, Msb,) inf. n. tanofyrN; (Msb;) and ↓ Anfr; (T, K;) and ↓ A$tnfr; (T, M, A, Msb;) He made (wild animals, T. Msb, or an antelope. K, or a beast of carriage. M,) to take fright, and flee, or run away at random: (K, TA:) or he made a beast of carriage to become impatient, and to retire to a distance: (A:) or he scared away; or made to flee, and go away, or aside, or apart, or to a distance: (so accord. to an explanation of the intrans. v. from which it is derived, in the M:) you say naf~arotuhu and ↓ Aisotanofarotuhu and ↓ A^anofarutuhu: and in like manner, naf~ara Eanohu, and A^anofara Eanohu, [meaning, he scared away, or made to take fright and flee, &c., from him or it:] (TA:) AlA_inofaAru Eani Al$~aYo'i, and Alt~anofiyru Eanohu, and AlAisotinofaAru, all signify the same, [i. e., the scaring away, &c. from a thing.] (S.) It is said in a trad. of Zeyneb, the daughter of Mohammad, faA^anofara bihaA Almu$orikuwna baEiyrahaA Hat~aY saqaTato And the polytheists made her camel to take fright and run away at random with her, so that she fell. And in like manner you say, A^unofirabinaA, and nufirabinaA, [or nuf~arabinaA Our camels were scared away with us; or made to take fright and run away at random with us: or] we were made to be persons having camels taking fright and running away at random. And tanofiyrN signifies The chiding camels or sheep or goats, and driving them from the pasturage. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] ba$~irwA walA tunaf~iruwA (assumed tropical:) [Rejoice people by what ye say. and] do not encounter them with [roughness and violence and] that which will incite them to nufuwr [i. e. flight or aversion]. (TA.) See the act. part. n., below. ― -b3- [Hence also,] naf~iro Eanohu, (S, K,) inf. n. tasnofiyrN. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) Give thou to him a laqab [meaning a nickname or name of reproach], (S,) or a laqb that is disliked: (K:) as though they held such to be tasofiyrN lilojin~i waAlEayoni Eanohu [a means of scaring away the jinn, or genii, and the evil eye, from him]. (S, K.) An Arab of the desert said, When I was born, it was said to my father, naf~iro Eanohu: so he named me qunofud [hedge-hog], and surnamed me A^abw AlEad~A='i [father of the quick runner]. (S.)

3 naAofara [naAfaraA, inf. n. munaAfarapN, (tropical:) They shunned or avoided each other; regarded each other with aversion. But perhaps this signification is only post-classical. ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) They (two things) were incongruous, or discordant, each with the other. But perhaps this signification, also, is only post-classical. See also 6.]

4 A^anofara see 2, in several places. ― -b2- A^anofaruwA Their camels took fright and ran away at random, (nafarat, K, TA,) and became separated or dispersed. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, last signification.
5 tnf~r Eani AlHaq~i * : see 1.

6 tanaAofara [tnAfrwA (tropical:) They shunned or avoided one another; regarded one another with aversion. But perhaps this signification is only post-classical. ― -b2- And hence, tnAfrt AlA^a$oyaA='u (tropical:) The things were incongruous, or discordant, one with another. But perhaps this signification, also, is only postclassical. See also 3.] ― -b3- tnAfrwA fiY AlA^amori, or liloA^amori: see 1, towards the end. See also tanaAfaraA in the K: and compare 6 in arts. nfd and nf*.

10 A_isotanofarahumo *
He (the Imám) incited, and summoned or invited them to go forth, lijihaAdi AlEaduw~i to war against the enemy: (T, Mgh:) or imposed upon them the task of going forth to war, light and heavy: [see Kur, ix. 41:] (A:) or he demanded, sought, or desired, of them aid. (M, * K, TA.) ― -b2- See also 2. in three places. ― -b3- And see 1, in two places, near the beginning.
naforN * : see naAfirN, of which it is a quasi-pl.: ― -b2- and nafiyrN: ― -b3- and nafarN.

niforN * an imitative sequent to EiforN, (T, M, K,) and so is ↓ nafirN to EafirN, (Sgh, K, but omitted in some copies of the K,) and ↓ niforiyapN to EiforiyapN, (T, M, K,) and ↓ niforiytN to EiforiytN, (T, S, M, K,) and ↓ nufaAriyapN to EufaAriyahN, (T, M, K,) and ↓ niforiytapN to EifriytapN; (K;) denoting corroboration. (S.)

nafarN *
A number of men, from three to ten; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ naforN and ↓ naforapN and ↓ nafiyrN: (S:) or to seven: (so in a copy of the Msb, [but probably sbEp is a mistake for tsEp nine: this appears likely from what here follows:]) or a number of men less then ten; (AZ, T, M, K;) as also ↓ nafiyrN; (K;) and so rahoTN; (AZ, T;) and some add, excluding women: (TA:) accord. to Fr, (S,) a man's people or tribe consisting of his nearer relations; as also ↓ naforapN; syn. rahoTN, (S, IAth,) and Ea$iyrapN: (IAth:) [see also naforapN:] accord. to Kr, (M,) all the men or people: (M, K:) accord. to Lth, you say, h`w^ulaA='i Ea$arapu nafarK, i. e. these are ten men: but one does not say, Ei$oruwna nafarFA, nor more than Ea$arap: and Abu-l- 'Abbás says, that nafarN, like qawomN and rahoTN, has a pl. signification, without any proper sing.; and is applied to men, exclusively of women: (T:) it is a quasi-pl. n.: (TA:) and its pl. is A^anofaArN; (M, K;) occurring in a trad., in the phrase A^aHadN mino A^anofaArinaA, which IAth explains as meaning any one of our people; syn. qawominaA: (TA:) and ↓ nafiyrN, occurring, in the accus. case, in the Kur, xvii. 6, is, accord. to Zj, a pl. [or rather quasipl. n.] of nafarN, like EabiydN and kaliybN. (M.) [See also nafiyrN, below.] Imra-el-Keys says, describing a man as an excellent archer,
fahowa laA tanomiY ramiy~atuhu
maA lahu laA Eud~a mino nafariho
(S,) And he is such that the animal shot by him does not go away after it has been shot and then die. What aileth him? May he be killed, so as not to be numbered among his people. The latter hemistich is a proverb. (Meyd.) The poet here utters an imprecation against the man, but in so doing praises him; as when you say, of a man whose action pleases you, maA lahu qaAtalahu A@ll~`hu and A^axozaAhu A@ll~`hu [q. v.]. (S.) The rel. n. is ↓ nafariY~N. (Sb, M.) -A2- [Accord. to the Msb, it is also a simple subst. from nafara: and app. as signifying especially Aversion.]
nafirN * : see niforN.

naforapN * : see nafiyrN. ― -b2- A man's near kinsmen; syn. A^usorapN (T, K) and faSiylapN; (K;) who are angry on account of his anger; (K;) as also ↓ nuforapN, mentioned by Sgh and others, (TA,) and ↓ nufuwrpN (T. K) and ↓ naAfirapN (A, * K) and ↓ nafarN: (T:) and nufuwrapN signifies a man's near kinsmen (A^usorap) who go forth with him to war when an event befalls him or oppresses him severely or suddenly. (TA.) You say, jaA='anaA fiY naforatihi and ↓ nafarihi, (T, TA,) &c., (TA,) He came to us among his near kinsmen, (T, TA,) &c. (TA.) And, galabato nufuwratunaA nufuwratahumo Our near kinsmen overcame their near kinsmen. (T, TA.) See also nafarN, in two places: and see nafiyrN.
nuforapN * (Sgh, K) and ↓ nufarapN (K) A thing that is hung upon a child for fear of, (K,) or to repel, (Sgh,) the evil eye. (Sgh, K.) -A2- See also naforapN.
nafariY~N * : see nafarN, last sentence but one.
niforiyapN * and niforiytN and niforiytapN: see niforN.

nifaArN * a subst. from nafarati Ald~aAb~apu. Ex. fiY Ald~aAb~api nifaArN [In the beast of carriage is a disposition to take fright and run away at random]. (S.) And in like manner, from nafara said of a wild animal. (Msb.)
nafuwrN * : see naAfirN.

nafiyrN *
A people hastening to war, or to some other undertaking: an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Msb:) or a people going to execute an affair: (S:) or a people going with one to fight; as also ↓ naforapN [q. v.] and ↓ naforN: (M, K:) each is a noun having a pl. signification: (M:) or the first and last signify a company of men: and the pl. of each is A^anofaArN: (M:) or the first, (S,) or all, (K,) a people, (S,) or company, (K,) preceding in an affair: (S, K:) or the first, those of a man's people who go forth with him to war: or it is a pl. [or quasi-pl.] of nafarN, signifying men assembled to go to the enemy: (Bd, xvii. 6:) or aiders, or assistants. (M.) [See nafarN, in two places.] You say, jaA='ato naforapu baniY fulaAnK, and nafiyruhumo, The company of the sons of such a one, that came forth to execute an affair, arrived. (S, TA.) nafiyru qurayo$K means Those of Kureysh who went forth to Bedr to defend the caravan of Aboo-Sufyán, (M,) which was coming from Syria. (T.) Hence the proverb, fulaAnN laA fiY AlEiyri walaA fiY Aln~afiyri [Such a one is neither in the caravan nor in the company going forth to fight]: applied to him who is not regarded as fit for a difficult undertaking: because none held back from the caravan and the fight except him who was crippled by disease and him in whom was no good; (TA:) or the original words of the proverb are lA fiY AlEiyri walaA fiY Aln~afiyri: and these words were first said by Aboo-Sufyán, with reference to the Benoo-Zuhrah, when he found them turning back towards Mekkeh; and, accord. to As, are applied to a man who is held in low and little repute. (Mgh.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 500.]
nufuwrapN * : see naforapN, in three places.
nufaAriyapN * : see niforN.

naAfirN * [and ↓ nafuwrN] and ↓ musotanofirN signify the same; [i. e., Taking fright, and fleeing, or running away at random: or being, or becoming, impatient, of or at a thing, and retiring to a distance: or fleeing, and going away or aside or apart or to a distance: or the second, being of an intensive form, signifies, as also ↓ yanofuwrN, that does so much or often; or wont or apt to do so:] (TA:) and naforN is a pl. of naAfirN, (K,) or [rather] a quasi-pl., like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, and zaworN of zaAy^irN. (M.) You say, daAb~apN naAfirN, and ↓ nafuwrN, [A beast that takes fright and runs away at random: &c.:] (M, K:) accord. to IAar, one should not say naAfirapN (M) [unless using it as an epithet applied to a broken pl. of a subst., as will be seen below]. It is said in a proverb, ↓ kul~u A^azab~a nafuwrN [Every one, of camels, that is hairy on the face is wont to take fright and run away at random: see art. zb]. (M.) You say also ↓ ZaboYN yanofuwrN, (M, K, *) in some copies of the K, nyfwr, (TA,) A gazelle that takes fright and flees much or often; or that is wont to do so. (M, K. *) And it is said in the Kur, [lxxiv. 51,] far~ato mino ↓ kaA^an~ahumo HumurN musotanofirapN qasowarapK, i. e., naAfirapN, [As though they were asses taking fright and running away at random, that have fled from a lion:] and (accord. to one reading, T) ↓ musotanofarapN, (T, S,) meaning, made to take fright and run away at random; (T;) or frightened, or scared. (S.) ― -b2- A^anaA naAfirN mino h`*aA AlAmr (tropical:) I shrink from this thing or affair; am averse from it; do not like or approve it. And hiYa naAfirapN mino zawojihaA (tropical:) [She is averse from her husband; she shuns or avoids him]. (A.)
nawofarN * : see art. nylwfr.
naAfirapN * : see naforapN.
munaf~irN * act. part. n. of 2, q. v. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) One who encounters people with roughness and violence [and that which incites them to flight or aversion: see 2]. (TA, from a trad.)
musotanofirN * : see naAfirN; the first and third in two places.
musotanofarN * : see naAfirN; the first and third in two places.
yanofuwrN * : see naAfirN; the first and third in two places.

1 nafaza * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
nafiza , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. nafazaAnN (S, K) and nafozN (Msb, TA) and nufuwzN, (TA,) He (an antelope) leaped, jumped, sprang, or bounded; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ nf~z: (A:) or did so in his running: (As, TA:) or did so and alighted with his legs spread: when he alights with his legs together, the action is termed qafozN: (TA:) or did so after putting his legs together: (AZ, TA:) or leaped upwards with all his legs at once and put them down without separating them: (Msb:) or raised his legs together and put them down together: or ran at the utmost vehement rate of the running termed A_iHoDaAr. (TA.)
2 naf~aza see 1. -A2- nf~zhu, (K,) or nf~zthu, (S, A,) He, or she, danced, or dandled, him, (S, A, K,) namely, a child; (S, A;) as also nq~zth. (TA, art. nqz.)

6 tnAfzwA *
They (children) contended together in leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding, in play. (A, K.)
nafozapN * An antelope's running by reason of fright. (AA, TA.)
nafuwzN * (S) and ↓ yanofuwzN (K) An antelope that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, (S, K,) [in one or other of the manners described above,] much, or vehemently. (TA.)
naAfizapN * , sing. of nawaAfizu, (TA,) which signifies The legs of a beast of carriage: (K, TA:) but the word commonly known is nawaAqizu, with q. (TA.)
yanofuwzN * : see nfwz.

1 nafusa * , aor.
nafusa , inf. n. nafaAsapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and nifaAsN and nafsN (K) and nufuwsN; (TA;) and ↓ A^anofasa, (M, A, Msb,) inf. n. A_inofaAsN; (A, Msb;) It was, or became, high in estimation, of high account, or excellent; (M, Msb, TA;) [highly prized; precious, or valuable;] and therefore, (TA,) was desired with emulation, or in much request: (S, K, TA:) and the ↓ latter verb, said of property, it was, or became, loved, and highly esteemed. (TA.) -A2- nafisa bihi, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
nafasa , (K,) inf. n. nafasN (M) [and app. nafosN as will be shown below] and nafaAsapN and nafaAsiyapN, which last is extr., (M, TA,) He was, or became avaricious, tenacious, or niggardly, of it, (S, M, Msb, K,) because of its being in high estimation, or excellent. (Msb.) Hence the saying in the Kur, [xlvii. 40,] faA_in~amaA yaboxalu Eano nafosihi [app. meaning He is only avaricious from his avarice.] (TA.) You say, nafisa Ealayohi biAl$~aYo'i, (M,) or Eanohu [in the place of Elyh], (TA,) He was, or became, avaricious, &c., of the thing, towards him, or withholding it from him. (M, TA.) And nafisa Ealayohi Al$~aYo'a, (S, M, K, TA,) and biAl$~aYo'i, (M,) inf. n. nafaAsapN. (S, K, TA,) He was, or became, avaricious, &c., of the thing, towards him, and thought him not worthy of it, and was not pleased at its coming to him: (TA:) or [simply] he thought him not worthy of it: (S, M, K;) as also fiyhi ↓ nAfshu; of which last verb we have an ex. in the phrase tunaAfisu dunoyaA, used by a poet in speaking of the tribe of Kureysh, meaning either tunaAfisu fiY dunobaA [they think others not worthy of worldly good]. or tunaAfsu A^ahola dunoyaA [they think the possessors of worldly good unworthy thereof]. (M.) [See also 3, below.] You say also, nafisota EalaY~a bixayorK, (A, K,) or bixayorK qaliyl, (S,) and nafisota EalaY~a xayorFA kaviyrFA, (A,) inf. n. nafosN and nafaAsapN, (A,) Thou enviedst me (S, A, K) good, (A, K,) or a little good, (S,) and much good, (A.) and didst not consider me worthy of it. (A.) And fulaAnN maA yatanag~asu EalayonaA Alganiymapa waAlZ~afara [app. meaning Such a one does not envy us the spoil and the victory.] (A, in continuation of what here immediately precedes.) And maA h`*aA Aln~afasu What is this envying? (A, TA.) -A3- nufisato; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) and nafisato, (S, M, Msb, K,) as some of the Arabs say, (Msb.) aor. ??, (Msb, K:) inf. n. nifaAsN and nifaAspN (S, M) and nafasN, (M, TA,) or the first of these ns. is a simple subst.; (Msb;) (tropical:) She (a woman) brought forth; (S, M, K;) and nufisato waladFA [she brought forth a child]: (Th, M:) and nufisato biwaladihaA [she brought forth her child]. (A.) You say also, wariv fulaAnN h`*aA qabola A^ano yanofasa fulaAnN, meaning, Such a one inherited this before such a one was born. (S.) ― -b2- Also, both these verbs, (Msb, K,) or the latter, nafisato, only, (Az, Mgh, TA,) or the latter is the more common, (K.) the former, which is related on the authority of As, not being well known, (Msb,) (tropical:) She (a woman) menstruated. (Az, Mgh, Msb, K.) [In the CK, a confusion is made by the omission of a w before the verb which explains this last signification.] This signification and that next preceding it are from nafosN meaning “ blood. ” (Mgh.) -A4- nafasotuhu binafosi (tropical:) I smote him with an [evil or envious] eye. (S, K, TA.)

2 nf~shu fiyhi * , or bihi: see 4. -A2- nf~s kurobatahu, (A, Mgh, Msb, K, *) and nf~s Eanohu kurobatahu, (S,) inf. n. tanofiysN (S, Msb, K) and [quasi-inf. n.] nafasN, (K,) (tropical:) He (God) removed, or cleared away, his grief, or sorrow, or anxiety: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K *:) and nf~s Eanohu signifies the same; (M, Mgh;) and He made his circumstances ample and easy; (M, TA;) and he (a man) eased him, or relieved him, syn. raf~aha: (S, TA:) and also, this last phrase, he granted him a delay: the objective compliment being omitted: and naf~isoniY is used as meaning grant thou to me a delay: or, elliptically, naf~iso karobiY or gam~iY [remove thou my grief, &c.]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence] Harofu tanofiysK, applied to the prefix sa [and its variants sawofa &c.], meaning A particle of amplification; because changing the aor. from the strait time which is the present, to the ample time, which is the future. (Mughnee, in art. s.) -A3- nf~s Alqawosa (tropical:) He cracked the bow: (Kr. M:) [see 5:] accord. to ISh, he put (HaT~a) its string [upon the bow]. (TA.)

3 nAfs fiY Al$~aYo'i * , (S, K. *) inf. n. munaAfasapN and nifaAsN, (S,) He desired the thing, [or aspired to it.] with generous emulation; (S, K;) as also ↓ tnAfs: (K:) and nAfs SaAHibahu fiyhi [he vied with his companion in desire for it]: (A:) or fyh ↓ tnAfswA signifies they desired it [or aspired to it]: (S:) or they vied, one with another, in desiring it: or they desired it with emulation; syn. farAgabawA: (A, TA:) [and yunanaAfsu fyh it is emulously desired, or in request; or in great request:] or munaAfasahN and ↓ tanaAfusN signify the desiring to have a thing, and to have it for himself exclusively of any other person; from nafiysN, signifying a thing “ good, or goodly, or excellent, in its kind: ” (TA:) and tanaAfasonaA *`lika AlA^amora and tnAfsnA fyh we envied one another for that thing, and strove for priority in attaining it. (M.) See also tafisa Ealayohi Al$~aYo'a, with which naAfasahu fiyhi is syn. (M.)

4 Anfs * : see nafusa, in two places. -A2- Anfshu It (a thing, TA) pleased him, (K, TA,) and made him desirous of it: (TA:) or became highly esteemed by him. (IKtt.) ― -b2- A^anofasanY fiyhi He made me desirous of it; (S, M, A, K:) as also taf~asaniY fyh, (IAar, M, TA,) or bihi. (So in my copy of the A.) -A3- maA A^anofasahu How powerful is his evil, or envious, eye! (Lh, M.)

5 tnf~s * [He breathed] is said of a man and of every animal having lungs: (S:) [or it signifies] he drew (Aisotamad~a) breath: (M:) or [he respired, i. e.] he drew breath with the air-passages in his nose; to his inside, and emitted it. (Msb.) You say also, tnf~s AlS~uEadaA='a [He sighed: see also art. SEd]. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a man) emitted wind from beneath him. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (TA,) or tnf~s fiY AlA_inaA='i, (K,) (tropical:) He drank (K, TA) from the vessel (TA) with three restings between draughts, and separated the vessel from his mouth at every such resting: (K, TA.) and, contr., the latter phrase, (assumed tropical:) he drank [from the vessel] without separating it from his mouth: (K, TA:) which latter mode of drinking is disapproved. (TA.) ― -b4- Also tnf~s (assumed tropical:) He lengthened in speech; he spoke long; for when a speaker takes breath, it is easy
to him to lengthen his speech; and tnfs fiY AlkalaAmi signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) It (said of the day, M, A, and of the dawn, A, and of other things, M) became extended; (M;) it became long; (M, A;) or, said of the day, accord. to Lh, it advanced so that it became noon: (M:) or it increased: (S:) and it extended far: and hence it is said of life, meaning either it became protracted, and extended far, or it became ample: (M:) and, said of the dawn, it shone forth, (Akh, S, K, TA,) and extended so that it became clear day: (Fr, TA:) or it broke, so that things became plain in consequence of it: (TA:) or it rose: (Mujáhid:) or its dusty hue shone at the approach of a gentle wind. (Bd, lxxxi. 18.) You say also, tnf~s bihi AlEumuru (tropical:) [Life became long, or protracted, &c., with him]. (A.) And tnf~st dijolapu (assumed tropical:) The water of the Tigris increased. (TA.) ― -b6- tnf~s Almawoju (tropical:) The waves sprinkled the water. (S, K.) ― -b7- tnf~st Alqawosu (tropical:) The bow cracked. (S, M, K.) It is only the stick that is not split in twain that does so; and this is the best of bows. And tnf~s in the same sense is said of an arrow. (M.) -A2- [tnf~s Ealayohi Al$~aYo'a app. signifies the same as nafisa Elyh Al$Y', q. v.]
6 tanaAofasa see 3, throughout.

nafosN * The soul; the spirit; the vital principle; syn. ruwHN: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) but between these two words is a difference [which must be fully explained hereafter, though ISd says, that it is not of the purpose of his book, the M, to explain it]: (M:) in this sense it is fem.: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anofusN and [of mult.] nufuwsN. (M, Msb.) You say, xarajato nafosuhu [His soul, or spirit, went forth]; (Aboo-Is-hák, S, M, Msb, K;) and so jaAdato nafosuhu. (Msb.) And a poet says, not Aboo-Khirásh as in the S, but Hudheyfeh Ibn-Anas, (IB,)
najaA saAlimN wAln~afosu minohu bi$idoqihi
walamo yanoju A_il~aA jafona sayofK wamiy^ozaraA
i. e., [Sálim escaped when the soul was in the side of his mouth; but he escaped not save] with the scabbard of a sword and with a waist-wrapper. (S.) In the same sense the word is used in the saying. fiY nafosi fulaAnK A^ano yafoEala ka*aA waka*aA [but this seems rather to mean, It is in the mind of such a one to do so and so]. (Aboo-Is-hák, M.) Some of the lexicologists assert the nafos and the ruwH to be one and the same, except that the former is fem., and the latter [generally or often] masc.: others say, that the latter is that whereby is life; and the former, that whereby is intellect, or reason; so that when one sleeps, God takes away his nfs, but not his rwH, which is not taken save at death: and the nafos is thus called because of its connexion with the nafas [or breath]. (IAmb.) Or every man has nafosaAni [two souls]: (I'Ab, Zj:) nafosu AlEaqoli [the soul of intellect, or reason, also called Aln~afosu Aln~aATiqapu (see ruwHN)], whereby one discriminates, [i. e., the mind,] (I'Ab,) or nafosu Alt~amoyiyzi [the soul of discrimination], which quits him when he sleeps, so that he does not understand thereby, God taking it away: (Zj:) and nafosu Alr~uwHi [the soul of the breath], whereby one lives, (I'Ab,) or nafosu AlHayaApi [the soul of life], and when this quits him, the breath quits with it; whereas the sleeper breathes: and this is the difference between the taking away of the nfs of the sleeper in sleep and the taking away of the nfs of the living [at death.] (Zj.) Much has been said respecting the nafos and the ruwH; whether they be one, or different: but the truth is, that there is a difference between them, since they are not always interchangeable: for it is said in the Kur, [xv. 29 and xxxviii. 72,] wanafaxotu fiyhi mino ruwHiY [And I have blown into him of my spirit.]; not mino nafosiY: and [v. 116,] taEolamu maA fiY nafosiY [to be explained hereafter]; not fiY ruwHiY, nor would this expression be well except from Jesus: and [lviii. 9,] wayaquwluwna fiY A^anofusihimo [And they say in their souls, or within themselves]: for which it would not be well to say fiY A^arowaAHihimo: and [xxxix. 57,] A^ano taquwla nafosN [That a soul shall say]; for which no Arab would say A^ano taquwla ruwHN: hence, the difference between them depends upon the considerations of relation: and this is indicated by a trad., in which it is said that God created Adam, and put into him a nafos and a ruwH; and that from the latter was his quality of abstaining from unlawful and indecorous things, and his understanding, and his clemency, or forbearance, and his liberality, and his fidelity; and from the former, [which is also called Aln~afosu AlA^am~aArapu, q. v., in art. A^mr,] his appetence, and his unsteadiness, and his hastiness of disposition, and his anger: therefore one should not say that nafosN is the same as ruwHN absolutely, without restriction, nor ruwHN the same as nafos. (R.) The Arabs also make the discriminative nafos to be two; because it sometimes commands the man to do a thing or forbids him to do it; and this is on the occasion of setting about an affair that is disliked: therefore they make that which commands him to be a nfs, and that which forbids him to be as though it were another nfs: and hence the saying, mentioned by Z, fulaAnN yuw^aAmiru nafosayohi (tropical:) [Such a one consults his two souls, or minds]; said of a man when two opinions occur to him. (TA.) [binafosiY fulaAnN is an elliptical phrase sometimes used, for binafosiY fulaAnN mafodiY~N, which see in art. fdY.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A thing's self; (S, M, A, K, TA;) used as a corroborative; (S, TA;) its whole, (Aboo-Is-hák, M, TA,) and essential constituent: (Aboo-Is-hák, M, A, K, TA:) pl. as above, A^anofusN and nufuwsN. (M.) You say, raA^ayotu fulaAnFA nafosahu (assumed tropical:) I saw such a one himself, (S,) and jaA='aniY binafosihi [or, more properly, HaA='aniY huwa binafosihi (see, under the head of bi, a remark on that preposition when used in a case of this kind, redundantly,)] He came to me himself. (S, K.) And waliYa AlA^amora binafosihi [He superintended, managed, or conducted, the affair in his own person]. (K, in art. b$r, &c.) And Had~ava nafosahu [He talked to himself; soliloquized]. (Msb, in art. blw; &c.) And qatala fulaAnN nafosahu (assumed tropical:) [Such a one killed himself]: and A^aholaka nafosahu (assumed tropical:) made his whole self to fall into destruction. (Aboo-Is-hák, M.) And hence, (TA,) from nafosu Al$~aYo'i signifying *aAtuhu, (M,) the saying mentioned by Sb, nazalotu binafosi Aljabali (assumed tropical:) [I alighted in the mountain itself]: and nafosu Aljabali muqaAbiliY (assumed tropical:) [The mountain itself is facing me]. (M, TA.) [Hence also the phrase] fiY nafosi AlA^amori [meaning (assumed tropical:) in reality; in the thing itself]: as in the saying, qal~alahu fiY nafosihi waA_ino lamo yakuno qaliylFA fiY nafosi AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) [He held it to be little in his mind though it was not little in reality]. (Msb, art. ql.) The words of the Kur, [v. 116,] taEolamu maA fiY nafosiY walaA A^aEolamu maA fiY nafosika mean (assumed tropical:) Thou knowest what is in myself, or in my essence, and I know not what is in thyself, or in thine essence: (Bd, K:) or Thou knowest what I conceal (M, Bd, Jel) in my nfs [or mind], (Bd, Jel,) and I know not what is in thyself, or in thine essence, nor that whereof Thou hast the knowledge, (M.) or what Thou concealest of the things which Thou knowest; (Bd, Jel;) so that the interpretation is, Thou knowest what I know, and I know not what Thou knowest: (M:) or nfs is here syn. with Einod; and the meaning is, taEolamu maA EinodiY walaA A^aEolamu maA Einodaka; (K, * TA;) [i. e., Thou knowest what is in my particular place of being, and I know not what is in thy particular place of being; for] the adverbiality in this instance is that of makaAnap, not of makaAn: (TA:) but the best explanation is that of IAmb, who says that nfs is here syn. with gayob; so that the meaning is, Thou knowest gayobiY [my hidden things, or what is hidden from me, and I know not thy hidden things, or what Thou hidest]; and the correctness of this is testified by the concluding words of the verse, A_in~aka A^anota Eal~aAmu Alguyuwbi [for Thou art he who well knoweth the hidden things]: (TA:) [and here it must be remarked that] AlEayobu, which occurs afterwards in the K as one of the significations of Aln~afosu, is a mistake for Algayobu, the word used by IAmb in explaining the above verse. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A person; a being; an individual; syn.
$axoSN; (Msb;) a man, (Sb, S, M, TA,) altogether, his soul and his body; (TA;) a living being, altogether. (Mgh, Msb.) In this sense of $xS it is masc.: (Msb:) or, accord to Lh, the Arabs said, raA^ayotu nafosFA waAHidapF (assumed tropical:) [I saw one person], making it fem.; and in like manner, raA^ayotu nafosayoni vinotayoni (assumed tropical:) [I saw two persons]; but they said, raA^ayotu valaAvapa A^anofusK (assumed tropical:) [I saw three persons], and so all the succeeding numbers, making it masc.: but, he says, it is allowable to make it masc. in the sing. and dual., and fem. in the pl.: and all this, he says, is related on the authority of Ks: (M:) Sb says, (M.) they said valaAvapu A^anofusK, (S, M,) making it masc., (S,) because they mean by nfs “ a man, ” (S, M,) as is shown also by their saying nafosN waAHidN: (M:) but Yoo asserts of Ru-beh, that he said valaAvu A^anofusK, making nfs fem., like as you say valaAvu A^aEoyunK, meaning, of men; and valaAvapu A^a$oxuSK, meaning, of women: and it is said in the Kur, [iv. l, &c.,] Aal~a*iY xalaqakumo mino nafosK waAHidapK (assumed tropical:) [who created you from one man], meaning, Adam. (M.) You also say, maA raA^ayotu vam~a nafosFA (assumed tropical:) I saw not there any one. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A brother: (IKh, IB:) a copartner in religion and relationship: (Bd, xxiv. 61:) a copartner in faith and religion. (Ibn-'Arafeh.) (assumed tropical:) It is said in the Kur, [xxiv. 61,] faA_i*aA daxalotumo buyuwtFA fasal~imuwA EalaY A^anofusikumo And when ye enter houses, salute ye your brethren: (IB:) or your copartners in religion and relationship. (Bd.) And in verse 12 of the same chapter. biA^anofusihimo means (assumed tropical:) Of their copartners in faith and religion. (Ibn-'Arafeh.) ― -b5- (tropical:) Blood: (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) [or the life-blood: in this sense, fem.:] pl. [of pauc. A^anofusN and of mult.] nufuwsN: (IB:) so called [because the animal soul was believed by the Arabs, as it was by many others in ancient times, (see Gen. ix. 4, and Aristotle, De Anim. i. 2, and Virgil's Æn. ix. 349.) to diffuse itself throughout the body by means of the arteries: or] because the nafos [in its proper sense, i. e. the soul,] goes forth with it: (TA:) or because it sustains the whole animal. (Mgh, Msb.) You say, saAlato nafosuhu (tropical:) [His blood flowed]. (S.) And nafosN saAy^ilapN (tropical:) [Flowing blood]. (S, A, Mgh.) And dafaqa nafosahu (tropical:) He shed his blood. (A, TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) The body. (S, A, K.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) [Sometimes it seems to signify The stomach. So in the present day. You say, laEibato nafosuhu, meaning He was sick in the stomach. See gavato nafosuhu, in art. gvY; and ma*irato maEidatuhu and nafosuhu, in art. m*r.] ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) [The pudendum: so in the present day: in the K, art. H$w, applied to a woman's vulva.] ― -b9- [From the primary signification are derived several others, of attributes of the rational and animal souls; and such are most of the signification here following.] ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) Knowledge. (A.) [See, above, an explanation of the words cited from ch. v. verse 116 of the Kur-án.] ― -b11- (assumed tropical:) Pride: (A, K, TA:) and self-magnification; syn. Eiz~apN. (A, K.) ― -b12- (assumed tropical:) Disdain, or scorn. (A, K.) ― -b13- (assumed tropical:) Purpose, or intention: or strong determination: syn. him~apN. (A, K.) ― -b14- (assumed tropical:) Will, wish, or desire. (A, K.) ― -b15- [Copulation: see 3, art rwd.] ― -b16- [(assumed tropical:) Stomach, or appetite.] ― -b17- (tropical:) An [evil or envious] eye, (S, M, A, K, TA,) that smites the person or thing at which it is cast: pl. A^anofusN. (TA.) [See 1, last signification.] So in a trad., in which it is said, that the namolap and the Humap and the nafos are the only things for which a charm is allowable. (TA.) You say, A^aSaAbato fulaAnFA nafosN (tropical:) [An evil or envious eye smote such a one]. (S.) And Mohammad said, of a piece of green fat that he threw away, kaAna fiyhaA saboEapu A^anofusK, meaning, (tropical:) There were upon it seven [evil or envious] eyes. (TA.) ― -b18- (assumed tropical:) Strength of make, and hardiness, of a man: and (assumed tropical:) closeness of texture, and strength, of a garment or piece of cloth. (M.) -A2- Punishment. (A, K.) Ex. wayuHa*~irukum A@ll~`hu nafosahu, (K,) in the Kur, [iii. 27 and 28, meaning, And God maketh you to fear his punishment]; accord. to F; but others say that the meaning is, Himself. (TA.) -A3- A quantity (S, M, K,) of qaraZ, and of other things, with which hides are tanned, (S, K,) sufficient for one tanning: (S, M, K:) or enough for two tannings: (TA:) or a handful thereof: (M:) pl. A^anafusN. (M.) You say, habo liY nfosFA mino dibaAgK [Give thou to me a quantity of material for tanning sufficient for one tanning, or for two tannings, &c.]. (S.)

nafasN * [Breath;] what is drawn in by the airpassages in the nose, [or by the mouth,] to the inside, and emitted, (Msb;) what comes forth from a living being in the act of tanaf~us. (Mgh:) or the exit of wind from the nose and the mouth: (M:) pl. A^anofaAsN. (S, M, A. Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- A gentle air: pl. as above. (M, Msb.) You say also, nafasu Alr~iyHi [The breath of the wind]: and nafasu Alr~awoSapi the sweet [breath or] odour [of the meadow, or of the garden, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, app., its application in the phrase] nafasa Als~aAEapi [The blast of the last hour; meaning,] the end of time. (Kr, M.) ― -b4- [Hence also, (assumed tropical:) Speech: and kind speech: (see an ex. voce A^amolaHa:) so in the present day.] ― -b5- [And (assumed tropical:) Voice, or a sweet voice, in singing: so in the present day.] ― -b6- A gulp. or as much as is swallowed at once in drinking: (S, L, K:) but this requires consideration; for in one nafas a man takes a number of gulps, more or less according to the length or shortness of his breath, so that we [sometimes] see a man drink [the contents of] a large vessel in one nafas, at a number of gulps: (L:) [therefore it signifies sometimes, if not always, a draught, or as much as is swallowed without taking breath:] pl. as above. (S.) You say, A_ikoraEo fiY AlA_itaA='i nafasFA A^awo nafasayoni (tropical:) [Put thou thy mouth into the vessel and drink] a gulp, or two gulps: [or a draught, or two draughts:] and exceed not that. (S; And $arbotu nafasFA waA^anofaAsFA (tropical:) [I drank a gulp, and gulps: or a draught, and draughts]. (A.) And fulaAnN $ariba AlA_inaA='a kul~ahu EalaY nafasK waAHidK (tropical:) [Such a one drank the whole contents of the vessel at one gulp or at one draught]. (L.) ― -b7- (tropical:) Every resting between two draughts: (M, TA:) [pl. as above.] You say, $ariba binafasK waAHidK (tropical:) [He drank with one resting between draughts]. (A.) And $arba bivalaAvapi A^anofaAsK (tropical:) [He drank with three restings between draughts]. (A. K.) [And hence,] $araAbN *uw nafasi (tropical:) Beverage in which is ampleness, [so that one pauses while drinking it, to take breath,] and which satisfies thirst. (IAar, K.) And $araAbN gayoru *iY nafasK (tropical:) Beverage of disagreeable taste, (A, K, *) changed in taste and odour, (K,) in drinking which one does not take breath (A, K) when he has tasted it; (K;) taking a first draught, as much as will keep in the remains of life, and not returning to it. (TA.) ― -b8- [And hence it is said that] nafasN signifies (assumed tropical:) Satisfaction, or the state of being satisfied, with drink; syn. diY~a. (IAar, K.) ― -b9- [Hence also.] (tropical:) Plenty, and redundance. So in the saying A_in~ fiY AlmaA='i nafasFA liY walaka [Verily in the water is plenty, and redundance, for me and for thee]. (Lh, M.) ― -b10- (tropical:) A wide space: (TA:) (tropical:) a distance (A.) You say, bayona Alfar yqayon nafasN (tropical:) Between the two parties is a wide space. (TA.) And bayoniY wabayonahN nafasN (tropical:) Between me and him is a distance. (A.) ― -b11- (tropical:) Ample scope for action &c.; and a state in which is ample scope for action &c., syn. sEpN, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) and fusoHapN, (A, K,) in an affair. (S, M, A, K.) You say, lak fiY h`*aA nafasN [There is ample scope for action &c. for thee in this. (Mgh.) And A^anota fiY nafis mino A^amorika (tropical:) [Thou art in a state in which is ample scope for action &c. with respect to thine affair. (S, M.) And A_iEomlo waA^anota fiY nafasK mino A^amorika (tropical:) Work thou while thou art in a state in which is ample scope for action &c. (fiY fusoHapK wasaEap) with respect to thine affair, before extreme old age, and diseases, and calamities. (TA.) See also nufosapN. ― -b12- (tropical:) Length. (M.) So in the saying zidonY nafasFA fiY A^ajaliY (tropical:) [Add thou to me length in my term
of life]: (M:) or lengthen thou my term of life. (TA.) You say also, ↓ fiY Eumurihi mutanaf~asN (tropical:) [In his life is length: see 5]. (A, TA.) ― -b13- The pl., in the accus. case, also signifies (assumed tropical:) Time after time. So in the saying of the poet,
EayonaY~a juwdaA EaborapF A^anofaAsaA
[O my two eyes, pour forth a flow of tears time after time]. (S.) -A2- nafasN is also a subst. put in the place of the proper inf. n. of naf~asa; and is so used in the two following sayings, (K, TA,) of Mohammad. (TA.) laA tasbuw~uA Alr~iyHa faA_in~ahaA mino nafasi Alr~aHom`ni, i. e. (tropical:) [Revile not ye the wind, for] it is a means whereby the Compassionate removes grief, or sorrow, or anxiety, (K, TA,) and raises the clouds, (TA,) and scatters the rain, and dispels dearth, or drought. (K, TA.) And A^ajidu nafasa rab~aikumo mino qibali Alyamani (tropical:) I perceive your Lord's removal of grief, &c., from the direction of El-Yemen: meaning, through the aid and hospitality of the people of El-Medeeneh, who were of El-Yemen; (K, TA;) i. e., of the Ansár, who were of [the tribe of] El-Azd, from ElYemen. (TA.) It is [said by some to be] a metaphor, from nafasu AlhawaA='i, which the act of breathing draws back into the inside, so that its heat becomes cooled and moderated: or from nafasu Alr~iyiH, which one scents, so that thereby he refreshes himself: or from nafasu Alr~awoDapi. (TA.) You also say, maA liY nafasN, meaning, (tropical:) There is not for me any removal, or clearing away, of grief. (A.) -A3- It is also used as an epithet, signifying (assumed tropical:) Long; (AZ, K;) applied to speech, (K,) and to writing, or book, or letter. (AZ, K.)

nufosapN * , (S, Mgh, K,) with damm, (K,) [in a copy of the S, nafosapN,] (assumed tropical:) Delay; syn. maholapN; (S, Mgh, K;) and ample space, syn. mut~asaEN. (TA.) Ex. laka fiY h`*aA AlA^amori nufosapN (assumed tropical:) [Thou shalt have, in this affair, a delay, and ample space]. (S, Mgh, * TA.) See also nafasN.

[
nafosiYN *
Relating to the nafos, or soul, &c.: vital: and sensual; as also ↓ nafosaAniY~N.]

nufasaA='u * (Th, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and nafasaA='u and nafosaA='u (M, K) (tropical:) A woman in the state following childbirth: (S, M, * Mgh, * Msb, * K:) or bringing forth: and pregnant: and menstruating: (Th, M:) and naAfisN signifies the same; (Msb;) and so ↓ manofuwsapN: (A:) [see nufisato:] dual nufasaAwaAni; the fem. ' being changed into w as in Eu$araAwaAni: (S:) pl. nifaAsN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) like as Ei$aArN is pl. of Eu$araA='u, (S, Msb, K,) the only other instance of the kind, (S, K,) and nufaAsN, (M, K,) which is also the only instance of the kind except Eu$aArN, (K,) and nuf~aAsN, and nuf~asN and nufasN (M) and nufusN (M, K) and nufosN (K) and nufasaAwaAtN (S, M, K) and [accord. to analogy, of naAfisN,] nawaAfisu. (K.)
nafosaAnN * , or nafosaAniY~N: see nafuwsN.
nafosaAniY~N * : see nafosiY~N: ― -b2- and nafuwsN.

nifaAsN * (tropical:) Childbirth (S, K) from nafosN signifying “ blood. ” (Msb, TA.) See nufisato. ― -b2- [And The state of impurity consequent upon childbirth. See 5, in art. El.] ― -b3- Also, (tropical:) The blood that comes forth immediately after the child: an inf. n. used as a subst. (Mgh.) ― -b4- A poet says, (namely, Ows Ibn-Hajar, O, in art. Trq,)
lanaA SaroxapN vum~a A_isokaAtapN
kamaA Tar~aqato binifaAsK bikiro
[We utter a cry; then keep a short silence; like as when one that has never yet brought forth experiences resistance and difficulty in giving birth to a child, or young one]; meaning, biwaladK. (S.)
nafuwsN * An envious man: (M, TA:) (tropical:) one who looks with an evil eye, with injurious intent, at the property of others: (M, A, * TA:) as also ↓ nafosaAnN, (TA,) or ↓ nafosaAniY~N. (A.)

nafiysN * A thing high in estimation; of high account; excellent; (Lh, M, Msb, TA;) [highly prized; precious; valuable; and therefore (TA) desired with emulation, or in much request; (S, K, TA;) good, goodly, or excellent, in its kind; (TA;) and ↓ naAfisN signifies the same, (M,) and so does ↓ munofisN, (Lh, M, A, Msb, K,) and ↓ manofuwsN: (K:) it signifies thus when applied to property, as well as other things; as also ↓ manofisN: (Lh, M:) and, when so applied, of which one is avaricious, or tenacious: (M:) or ↓ munofisN, so applied, abundant; much; (K;) as also ↓ munofasN: (Fr, K:) and ↓ naAfisN, a thing of high account or estimation, and an object of desire: (TA:) this last is also applied, in like manner, to a man; as also nafiysN: and the pl. [of either] is nifaAsN (M, TA) You also say, ↓ A^amorN manofuwsN fiyhi, meaning, A thing that is desired. (M.) And fiyhi ↓ $aYo'N mutanaAfasN A thing emulously desired, or in much request. (A.) ― -b2- Also, [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] Much property; (S, A, K;) and so ↓ munofisN. (S.) You say, lifulaAnK munofisN and nafiysN Such a one has much property. (S.) And maA yasur~uniY bih`*aA AlA^amori manofisN and nafiysN [Much property does not rejoice me with this affair]. (S.)

naAfisN * : see nafiysN, in three places. -A2- See also nufasaA='u. -A3- (tropical:) Smiting with an evil, or envious, eye. (S, M, K.) -A4- The fifth of the arrows used in the game called Almayosir; (S, M, K;) which has five notches; and for which one wins five portions if it be successful, and loses five portions if it be unsuccessful: (Lh, M:) or, as some say, the fourth. (S.)

h`*aA A^anofasu maAliY *
This is the most loved and highly esteemed of my property. (S, TA.) -A2- bal~agaka A@ll~`hu A^anofasa AlA^aEomaAri (tropical:) [May God cause thee to attain to the most protracted, or most ample, of lives: see 5]. (A, TA.) And daAruka A^anofasu mino daAriY (tropical:) Thy house is more ample, or spacious, than my house: (M:) and the like is said of two places: (M:) and of two lands. (A.) And h`*aA Alt~awobu A^anofasu mino h`*aA (tropical:) This garment, or piece of cloth, is wider and longer and more excellent than this. (M.) And vawobN A^anofasu Alv~awobayoni (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, the longer and wider of the two garments, or pieces of cloth. (A.)
munofasN * : see nafiysN; for the latter, throughout.
munofisN * : see nafiysN; for the latter, throughout.

manofuwsN * : see nafiysN, in two places. -A2- (tropical:) Brought forth; born. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., maA mino nafosK manofuwsapK A_il~aA waqa*o kutiba makaAnuhaA mina Aljan~api A^awi Aln~aAri (tropical:) [There is not any soul born but its place in Paradise or Hell has been written]. (S.) ― -b2- manofuwsapN applied to a woman: see nufasaA='u. -A3- (tropical:) Smitten with an evil, or envious, eye. (M.)

[
mutanaf~asN *
A place of passage of the breath.] ― -b2- fY Eumurihi mutanaf~asN: see nafasN. ― -b3- See also saHarN.

mutanaf~isN * [Breathing;] having breath: (TA:) or having a soul: (so in a copy of the M:) an epithet applied to everything having lungs. (S, TA.) ― -b2- gaAy^iTN mutanaf~isN (tropical:) A depressed expanse of land extending far. (A, TA.) ― -b3- A^anofN mutanaf~isN (tropical:) A nose of which the bone is wide and depressed; or depressed and expanded; or a nose spreading upon the face: syn. A^afoTasu. (A, TA.)
$aYo'N mutanaAfasN fiyhi * : see nafiysN.

1 nafa$a * , (S, A,) aor.
nafu$a , (S,) inf. n. nafo$N, (S, A, K,) He separated, or plucked asunder, or loosened, a thing, with his fingers, so that it became spread, or sparse, or dispersed; (A, K;) as also ↓ nf~$, inf. n. tanofiy$N: (S, K:) or the latter has an intensive signification: and accord. to some, the former signifies he separated a thing not difficult to separate, such as cotton and wool: or he pulled
wool until its parts became separated, or plucked asunder, or loosened: (TA:) or he spread, or dispersed, a thing. (MF.) You say, nafa$otu AlquTona and AlS~uwfa [I separated or plucked asunder, or loosened, with my fingers, &c., the cotton and the wool]. (S, A.) nafo$N is likewise syn. with nadofN [the separating and loosening cotton by means of a bow and a wooden mallet]. (TA.) You also say, nafa$a Alr~aTobapa, inf. n. as above, meaning, He separated what was collected together, or compacted, in the [kind of trefoil called] rTbp. (TA.) And, of a cock, (T, S, in art. bwl.) or of a HubaAraY, (K, in that art.,) when about to fight, (T, K. ibid.,) nafa$a buraAy^ilahu [He ruffled the feathers around his neck]. (T, S, K, ibid.) -A2- It is also intrans syn. with Antf$, q. v. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] nafa$ati Alganamu, (S, A, K,) and AlA_ibilu, (S, Msb, K,) accord. to IDrd the former only, but accord. to others the latter also, and in like manner one says of all beasts, though mostly of ganam, (TA,) aor. (S, Msb, K) and
nafi$a , (S, K,) inf. n. nafo$N, (Msb, K,) or nufuw$N, (S,) or both: (TA;) and naf$t, aor.
nafa$a ; (IAar. Sgh, K;) The sheep or goats, and the camels, pastured by night without a pastor: (S, Msb, K:) or without the knowledge of a pastor (TA:) or dispersed themselves by night: (A:) or dispersed themselves and pastured by night without knowledge [of the pastor]: or the sheep or goats entered among seed-produce: (TA:) occurring in the Kur, xxi. 78: (S, TA:) the subst. is nafa$N, signifying their dispersion of themselves and pasturing by night without a pastor. (Msb.)
2 naf~a$a see 1, first signification.

4 Anf$ Alganama * , (S, A, K.) and AlA_ibila, (S, K,) He (the pastor) sent the sheep or goats, and the camels, (K, * TA,) or left them, (S, TA,) to pasture by night without a pastor; (S, K, TA,) neglecting them: (TA:) or to disperse themselves by night. (A.)

5 tanf~$t Alhir~apu * , (S, A, K,) and ↓ Antf$t, (S, A,) The cat bristled up her hair. (S, A, K.) And in like manner you say of a hyena. (A, TA, *) And tnf~$ Ald~iyku, (A,) or AlT~aAiy^ru, (K,) and ↓ Antf$, (A, TA,) The cock, (A,) or bird, (K,) ruffled, (A,) or shook, (K,) his feathers, as though he feared, (A, K,) or threatened, (A,) or trembled. (K.)

8 Antf$ *
i. q. nafa$a used intransitively. [signifying It (a thing, or cotton, and wool, and the like,) became separated, or plucked asunder, or loosened, with the fingers, so that it became spread, or sparse, or dispersed; &c., being] quasi-pass. of nafa$a used transitively. (TA.) See also munotafi$N. And see 5, in two places.

nafa$N *
Wool. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, app., the saying,] A_ino lamo yakuno $aHomN fanafa$N, [lit., If there be not fat, then let there be wool;] meaning, (assumed tropical:) If there be not action, then [let there be] a show of action: (IAar, Az, L:) or the last word signifies a little milk. (Meyd, cited by Freytag: see his Arab Prov., i. 70:) it also signifies, [and perhaps in the above saying,] (tropical:) abundance of speech or talk, and of pretensions. (MF.) -A2- See also 1, at the end. -A3- And see: naAfi$N.

naf~aA$N * (assumed tropical:) Proud and boastful. or one who praises himself for that which is not in him; or who says that which he does not. (TA.) -A2- A kind of layomuwn or citron; the limon sponginus sugosus Ferrari; (Delile, Floræ Aegypt. Illustr., no. 749)] of the largest size, (TA.)

naAfi$N * , applied to a camel [and to a sheep or goat]. fem. naAf$pN, Msb, part. n. of 1. (Msb, TA.) You say, A_ibilN naAfi$apN, Msb, and nafa$N [quasi-pl. p. of naAfi$N] (S, K) and nifaA$N (Msb) and nuf~aA$N (S, K) and nuf~$N [pls. of naAf$N] (TA) and nawaAfi$N [pl. of naAfi$pN], (S, K,) [and in like manner EanamN,] Camels [and goats] pasturing by night without a pastur: (S, Msb, K; or dispersing themselves and pasturing by ?? without knowledge [of the pastor] (TA:) nafa$N are only by night; but hamalN, by night and by day (S,)

EihonN manofuw$N * (S) Wool of ramous colours separated and loosened by means of bow wooden mallet: (Bd, Jel, ei. 4.) and in like manner, ↓ quTonN musotafi$N [cotton that is separated, or plucked asunder, or loosened, with the fingers, so that it becomes spread, or dispersed. &c., See 1 and 8]. (TA, voce hay~baAnN,) See also musotaf$N, below.

munotafi$N * : see manofuw$N.― -b2- ?? A female slave having shaggy or dishevelled hair: (A;) $aEotA='u. (K) ― -b3- ?? is likewise applied to anything Swollen, or humid, and loose or flaccid or soft within; as also ↓ mutaE~$N. (Az, K.) ― -b4- You say also A^anofN munotfi$N (tropical:) A nose short in the maArin [is soft part], and spreading upon the face, like the nose of the zanojiY~] (A;) and ?? has the like signification; as also ↓ ??; (TA;) or in means are cad of a nose spreading upon the face: (K:) and ↓ mutabaf~$u Almunoxiryoni, in like manner, wide in the two nostrils. (TA.) See also munataf~sN.
mutanaf~i$N * : see munotafi$N, in three places.

1 nafaDa * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
nafuDa , (S, Msb,) inf. n. nafoDN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He shook (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) a thing, (Mgh, Msb,) or a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, A, K,) in order that what was upon it, of dust &c., might fall off (S, * A, * Mgh, K, *) or to remove from it dust and the like; (Msb:) he took a thing with his hand, and shook it, or shook it violently, to remove the dust from it: (TA:) and in like manner a tree, in order that what was upon it [of face or of leaves] might fall of; (S, A;) ?? instance,] a tree of the kind called EiDAh, to shake off its leaves. (TA) You say also, nafaDa Eanahu AlgubaAra and Alt~uraAba [He shook off from it the dust (A.) And nafaDatu Alwaraqa mino Al$~ajarap. inf. n. ?? above, [He shook off the leaves from the tree;] be made the leaves to fall from the tree. (Msb,) And nafoDN also signifies The sprinkling or ?? tering in drops, (syn. ra$~N,) water and blood. ?? K, in art. r$,) and tears, (K, ??: &c. ?? bid.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ?? (S, A, K) (tropical:) The fever made him to shiver, or tremble (As, TA ― -b3- And nafaDati AlmaroA^apu, (K,) or nafDatN kar$ahaA (??) or nafaDato waladahaA mino baTonhA, (A,) The woman have many children; was prolific (S, K. TA) And nafaDat AlA_ibilu (assumed tropical:) The she-camels brought forth, (S, L, K,) all of them: (L;) and ↓ AnEDt signifies the same. (IDrd, S, K.) And ?? bayoDahA (tropical:) [The ?? la?? hen eggs. or all ?? A. TA.) ― -b4- Hence also,] faAma yanafuDu AlkraY, He arose, shaking off drowsiness]. (A. TA.) And nafaDa AlA^asofaAma Eanohu waA@sotaSaH~; [He shook off water-dust from him, and ?? ?? from his ?? i. e. his health became in a ?? state (A. TA.) And nafaDa mino maraDihi (A,) inf. n. nufuwDN, (TA, K,) (tropical:) He recovered, or became free, from his ?? (A, K, * TA.) ― -b5- And ?? ?? shored him what was in my heart (?? R ?? TA, in art. $kw and $kY ― -b6- And ?? (tropical:) He cleared the road of robbers, and ?? of travellers: (tropical:) he guarded the road ?A. TA [The latter signification is shown by an explanation or the act. part. n.] It is said in the trad. of Aboo-Bekr and the cave [in which Mohammad was hiding himself], A^anaA A^anafuDu maA Hawolaka ?? guard what is around thee, and go round ?? to try if I can see a pursuer. (TA.) You say also, nafaDa AlmakaAn, (S, K,) aor. as above, (TA.) inf. n. nafaDN (S, TA.) and ↓ ??, and ↓ tnf~Dhu; (S, K;) (tropical:) He looked trying to see all that was in the place: (S;) or he looked at all that was in the place so as to know it. (K) And hence nafaDa signifies (tropical:) He searched to the at most. (L.) And A_i*aA takal~amut nahaArFA faA@nofuDo waA_i*aA takal~amota layolFA faA@xofiDo (S, K, * TA) (tropical:) When thou speakest by day, look aside, or about, to try if thou see any one whom thou dislikest; (S, K, TA;) and when thou speakest by night, lower thy voice. (TA.) And Alqawoma ↓ AstnfD (tropical:) He looked at the people, or company of men, endeavouring to obtain a clear
knowledge of them; or considered, or examined, them repeatedly, in order to know them. (TA.) The saying of El-'Ojeyr Es-Saloolee,
Alqawoma Tarofuhu ↓ A_ilaY malikK yasotanofiDu
means (tropical:) [To a king whose eye] looks at the people, or company of men, and knows who among them has the right on his side: or looks to see in whom among them is mental perception, sagacity, intelligence, forecast, or skill in affairs, and which of them is of the contrary description: (TA:) [or] Tarofuhu Alqawoma ↓ fulaAnN yasotanofiDu means (tropical:) [The eye of] such a one makes the people, or company of men, to tremble, by reason of his awfulness. (A, TA.) ― -b7- You also say, AlA_ibilu tanofuDu AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) The camels traverse the land. (IAar.) ― -b8- And nafaDa AlquroA=na, (IAar,) or Als~uwara, (K,) aor.
nafuDa , inf. n. nafoDN, (IAar,) (tropical:) He read, or recited, (IAar, K,) the Kur-án, (IAar,) or the chapters thereof. (K.) ― -b9- And nafaDonaA HalaAy^ibanaA, inf. n. nafoDN; and ↓ AisotanofaDonaAhaA; (tropical:) We milked our milch beasts to the uttermost, not leaving any milk in their udders: (TA:) and AlfaSiylu maA fiY AlD~aroEi ↓ AntfD (tropical:) the young camel sucked out all that was in the udder. (A, TA.) -A2- [It is also used intransitively in the following exs., as well as in some instances given above. Thus nafaDa Al$~ajaru app. signifies The trees shook off, or dropped, their leaves or fruit. (See an ex. voce EatiyqN, last sentence but one.) ― -b2- And hence] one says, nafaDa maA fiY Aljul~api [app. meaning What was in the palm-leaf basket became exhausted; like nafida; or it may be syn. with AntfD]; (A, K;) or jamiyEu maA fiyhaA [all that was in it; which shows that mA in the former instance is virtually in the nom. case]. (TA.) See also 4, in two places. ― -b3- And nafaDa AlS~ibogu, (ISh, Mgh, K,) inf. n. nafoDN, (ISh, TA,) or nufuwDN, (TA,) (tropical:) The dye (ISh, K, TA,) of a red or yellow garment, or piece of cloth, (ISh, TA,) lost somewhat of its colour. (ISh, K, TA.) And hence, (Mgh,) nafaDa Alv~awobu, (A, Mgh,) aor.
nafuDa , (A,) inf. n. nufuwDN, (A, Mgh,) (tropical:) The garment, or piece of cloth, lost its dye: (A:) or lost somewhat of its colour, of redness, or yellowness: (Mgh:) or the colour of its dye faded away so that there remained nothing but the trace. (TA.) nafoDN, accord. to the lawyers, signifies (assumed tropical:) The being scattered, strewn, strewed, or dispersed: and accord. to [the Hanafee Imám] Mohammad, the non-transition of the trace of the dye to another thing: or its exhaling a sweet odour. (Mgh [but it seems that the particle lA, which I have rendered “ non, ” is inserted by mistake in my copy of the Mgh.]) ― -b4- nafaDa Alz~aroEu, (K,) or nafaDa Alz~aroEu sabalFA, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The seed-produce put forth the last of its ears. (K, TA.) And nafaDa Alkaromu (assumed tropical:) The grape-vine opened its bunches, or racemes. (K.) [See also 8.]

2 nf~D * , (S, TA,) inf. n. tanofiyDN, (TA,) He shook a garment, or piece of cloth, and a tree, much, or vehemently, in order that what was upon it might fall off. (S, TA. *) ― -b2- Said of a horse, i. q. raf~aDa, q. v. (TA in art. rfD.)

4 A^anofaDati Aljul~apu *
i. q. maA fiY Aljul~api ↓ nafaDa, (A, K,) or jamiyEu maA fiyhaA: (TA:) see 1. ― -b2- AnfDwA originally signifies They shook their provision-bags, in order that the dust or the like might fall from them. (A.) And hence, (A,) (tropical:) Their travellingprovisions became consumed, (S, M, A, K, TA,) and their wheat, or food; (M, TA;) like A^aromaluwA; (S, M, K, * TA;) as though they shook their provision-bags in order that the dust or the like might fall from them, because of their being empty; (TA;) as also ↓ nafaDuwA: (K:) or AnfDwA, (K,) or, as IDrd says, AnfDwA zaAdahumo, making the verb trans., (TA,) They consumed their travellingprovisions. (IDrd, K.) And (tropical:) Their camels, or the like, (A^amowaAluhumo,) died, or perished. (S, K.) A_inofaADN [the inf. n.] also signifies (assumed tropical:) The suffering hunger, or famine: and want. (TA.) ― -b3- AnfDt AlA_ibilu: see nfDt.
5 tnf~D AlmakaAna * : see 1.

8 AntfD *
It (a thing, Mgh, Msb, or a garment, or piece of cloth, S, A, K, and a tree, S, A) shook, or became shaken, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) so that what was upon it, of dust &c., fell off, (Mgh,) or so that the dust and the like became removed from it. (Msb.) Hence the saying in a trad., yanotafiDu bihi AlS~iraATu, i. e. [The bridge extending over hell will shake with him so that he will fall from it: or] will shake him, or shake him violently, or [app. a mistake for and] make him to fall. (Mgh.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He trembled, quaked, or shivered: said of a man, and of a horse. (A, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (a grapevine) became beautiful and bright in its leaves: (K:) [as though its dust became shaken off.] -A2- It is also used transitively: see 1, latter half: and see 10, in three places.

10 AstnfD Alqawomu * (tropical:) The people, or company of men, sent forth a nafiyDap, (S, K, * TA,) or party of scouts: (TA:) or sent forth nafaDap, or persons to clear the roads of robbers and of intercepters of travellers, or to guard the roads. (A, L, TA.) ― -b2- AstnfD AlmakaAna: and Alqawoma: see 1, in four places. ― -b3- AstnfDhu also signifies (tropical:) He extracted, educed, or elicited, it. (A, Mgh, * K.) You say, AisotanofaDotu maA Einodahu (tropical:) I extracted, educed, or elicited, what he had. (A, TA. *) ― -b4- And hence, (Mgh,) AstnfD (tropical:) He performed the act of cleansing termed AisotinojaA=', (Mgh, K,) with three stones, (Mgh,) or with the stone: (K:) or this is from nafaDa Alv~awoba; because the person who performs this act shakes off from himself what is annoying, with the stone; i. e., removes it. (TA.) You say also, AstnfD Al*~akara (tropical:) He took extraordinary pains in cleansing, or he cleansed entirely, (A_isotaboraA^a,) the penis from the remains of the urine; as also ↓ AntfDhu; (K;) and ↓ AntfD [alone]: (TA:) and ↓ this last, he sprinkled some water upon his pudendum after the ablution termed wuDuwo'. (TA in art. nSH.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] AstfDnA HalaAy^ibanaA: see 1.

nafaDN *
What has fallen, of the produce of a tree; (TA;) what has fallen, of leaves, and of fruit: (S, Msb, K:) or a thing that one shakes [or has shaken] off: (T in art. *rY:) of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (S, Msb, TA,) like qabaDN in the sense of maqobuwDN, (S, TA,) and hadamN in the sense of mahoduwmN: (TA:) and (K, TA) what has fallen, (TA,) of grapes, [in the CK we find Hab~u AlEinabi for Hab~i AlEinabi, the reading in other copies of the K,] when they are found (yuwjadu [in the CK yuw^oxadu, thus, with x, and with the unpointed d,]) one with another, (K. TA,) or cleaving one to another: (L, TA:) or what has fallen, of dates, at the feet of the palm-trees: (M, TA:) or what has fallen, of fruit, at the feet of trees; as also ↓ A^anaAfiyDu: (A:) or ↓ this last signifies leaves that are shaken off upon the nifaAD, q. v.; as also ↓ nifaADN [which is app. pl. of nafaDN, like as jibaAlN is pl. of jabalN]: (Sgh, K:) the sing. of AnAfyD is ↓ A^unofuwDapN. (TA.) [See also nufaADapN.] -A2- qwomN nafaDN [app. quasi-pl. of ↓ naAfiDN, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN,] (tropical:) A people, or company of men, whose travelling-provisions have become consumed. (ISh.)

nufoDapN * (tropical:) The shivering, or trembling, attending a fever termed Aln~aAfiD; (S, K;) as also ↓ nufaDahN (Sgh, K) and ↓ nufaDaA='u. (S, K.) [See also nif~iDaY.] The subst. [from these words, which seems to indicate that they are inf. ns. or from nafaDatohu AlHum~aY, which precedes them in the K,] is ↓ nafaADN [app. signifying (tropical:) A shivering, or tremour, attending that fever]. (K.) -A2- (assumed tropical:) A rain which falls upon a piece of land and misses another piece. (S.) [In the O and K in art. Ehd, written nafoDap.]
nafaDapN * : see nafiyDapN, in two places.
nufaDapN * : see nufoDapN.
nafaDaY * : see nif~iyDaY.
nufaDaA='u * : see nufoDapN.
nafaADN * : see nufoDapN: -A2- and see nufaADN.

nufaADN * : see nufaADapN. -A2- Also, and ↓ nafaADN, (tropical:) The
failure of travelling-provisions; i. e. their being consumed: or dearth, or drought: (S, K:) the latter of the words, and of the explanations, on the authority of Th. (S.) Hence, AlnfADu yuqaT~iru Aljalaba, (S, K,) a proverb, meaning, (tropical:) The failure of provisions, (TA,) or dearth, or drought, (S, K, TA,) causes the camels, driven or brought from one place to another, to be disposed in files for sale, (S, K, TA,) in order that their owners may buy provisions with their price. (TA.)

nifaADN * : see nufaADapN: and nafaDN. -A2- A piece of cloth upon which the leaves of the samuru and the like fall, it being spread, (K, TA.) and the tree being beaten with a staff, or stick: (TA:) pl. nufuDN: (K:) and [in like manner] ↓ minofaDN and ↓ minofaADN signify a garment of the kind called kisaA=', upon which the nafaD [or leaves or fruit of a tree] fall: (A, TA:) or ↓ minofaDN signifies i. q. minosafN, (S, K,) i. e. a vessel (wiEaA=') in which dates [and grain] are shaken to remove the dust &c. (TA.) ― -b2- A garment of the kind called A_izaAr worn by boys: (S, K:) pl. as above. (TA.) You say also, maA Ealayohi nifaADN, (S, K,) meaning He has not upon him any clothing. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

nafuwDN * (tropical:) A woman having many children: prolific. (S, A, K.) -A2- rajulN nafuwDN lilokalaAmi (tropical:) A man who considers, examines, or studies, speech, or language, or does so repeatedly, in order to obtain a clear knowledge of it. (TA.)

nufaADapN *
What has fallen in consequence of shaking to cause something upon it to fall; (S;) what has fallen from a thing so shaken; (IDrd, K;) whatever it be; as, for instance, of leaves; and mostly, of leaves of the samur in particular, when collected and beaten off [or rather beaten off and collected] in a garment, or piece of cloth; (IDrd, L, TA;) [like nafaDN, q. v.;] and ↓ nufaADN signifies the same; (S, K;) and ↓ nifaADN also. (K.) And What remains in one's mouth, of a siwaAk [or tooth-stick], and is spit out; or a particle broken off therefrom, remaining in the mouth, and spit out; i. q. nufaAvapu siwaAkK, (IAar, K,) and DuwaAzatuhu. (IAar.)

nafiyDapN * (tropical:) A company sent forth into the land to see whether there be in it an enemy, (S, K,) or not, (K,) or any [cause of] fear; (S;) like TaliyEapN; (S, TA;) as also ↓ nafaDapN; [pl. of ↓ naAfiDN, like as TalabapN is of TaAlibN:] (S, K:) or the former signifies men going before an army as scouts, or explorers: (As, in TA, voce HaDiyrapN:) or men who explore a place thoroughly: and also, a single person: (A 'Obeyd, in TA, ibid.:) or a scout, or scouts, stationed on a mountain or other elevated place: (TA:) or one who guards the road: (A, TA:) or a company [of men]: (TA:) and ↓ the latter, persons who clear the roads of robbers and of intercepters of travellers; or who guard the roads; (A, TA:) the pl. of the former is nafaAy^iDu; (S;) which also signifies persons who throw pebbles in order to know if there be behind them anything that they dislike, or an enemy. (K.) ― -b2- Also, the pl., (assumed tropical:) Lean, or emaciated, camels; (S, K:) accord to AA, as occurring in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, in which he says,
tuloqiY Aln~afaAy^iDu fiyhi Als~ariyHaA
(S, TA,) In which the lean, or emaciated, camels cast the shoes; meaning that these have become dissundered; or, as Akh says, the thongs so called [by which their shoes are fastened], these being dissundered; fyh referring to the road; but some read, fiyhaA, referring to the roads, mentioned before: (TA:) As reads nfAy^D, as well as AA: (S, TA:) but others read the word with q, as pl. of niqoDN, and signifying “ jaded ” camels: (so in a copy of the S:) or nfAy^D signifies camels which traverse the land. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- The sing. is also said to signify Waters where there is not any one. (IAar, Sh; both in the TA. voce HaDiyrapN, q. v., and the former also in this art.)

nif~iDaY *
Motion: and tremour; or shivering; as also ↓ nifiD~aY and ↓ nafaDaY. (O, K.) [See also nufoDapN.]

naAfiDN * (assumed tropical:) A fever attended with shivering, or trembling: (S, A. * K:) of the masc. gender: (ISd, K:) but applied as an epithet to Hum~aY [which is fem.] (TA.) Contr. of SaAlibN. (S, in art. Slb.) You say, A^axa*atohu Hum~aY naAfiDK, (S, K,) and Hum~aY binaAfiDK, (K,) which is the more approved form, (TA,) and Hum~aY naAfiDN, (K,) the latter word being sometimes thus used as an epithet; the second meaning (tropical:) Fever took him, or affected him, with [a shivering, or trembling, or] violent shivering or trembling; (TA;) [and the first and third, fever attended with shivering, or trembling, took him, or affected him.] -A2- See also nafiyDapN -A3- and nafaDN -A4- vawobN naAfiDN (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, which has lost its dye: (A:) or which has lost somewhat of its colour, of redness, or yellowness. (Mgh.)
A^unofuwDapN * : pl. A^anaAfiyDu: see nafaDN, in three places.
dajaAjapN munofiDN * , (A,) or mnfDp [i. e. munofiDapN], (TA,) (tropical:) A hen that has laid her eggs, or all her eggs, (nafaDato bayoDahaA, A, TA,) and desisted, (A,) or become weary. (TA.)
minofaDN * : see nifaADN; for the former, in two places.
minofaADN * : see nifaADN; for the former, in two places.
manofuwDN * (tropical:) Made to shiver, or tremble, by fever (S, K.)

1 nafiTato yaduhu * , (S, Msb,) or kaf~uhu, (K,) aor.
nafaTa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. nafaTN and nafiyTN (S, Msb, K,) and nafoTN; (K;) or, accord. to AZ, nafaTto, aor. 2, inf. n. nafoTN and nafiyTN; (TA;) His hand became blistered, or vesicated; it had water, or fluid, between the skin and the flesh; (AZ, Msb;) i. q. majilato; (S, K;) as also ↓ tnf~Tt: (S:) or it became ulcerated by work. (K.) -A2- nafaTato aor.
nafiTa , inf. n. nafiyTN (ADk, S, K) and nafoTN. (TA,) She (a goat) did what was like sneezing (navarato [app. meaning scattered forth moisture or the like]) with her nose: (ADk, S, K:) or sneezed. (K.) It is said in a proverb, laA tanofiTu fiyhi EanaAqN meaning (assumed tropical:) Blood-revenge will not be taken for him; i. e. for this slain person. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) aor.
nafiTa , inf. n. nafiyTN, (S,) It (a cookingpot, qidorN,) boiled, (S, K,) and poured forth [some of its contents], (S,) or so that it threw forth what resembled arrows; (TA;) a dial. var. of nafatato. (S.) ― -b3- nafaTa, aor.
nafiTa , (assumed tropical:) He was angry: or he burned with anger: as also ↓ tnf~T. (K, TA.) You say, A_in~a fulaAnFA layanofiTu gaDabFA, (S, TA,) (tropical:) Verily such a one burns with anger: (TA:) or it is like yanofitu [meaning boils with anger; or makes a noise like coughing, in anger; or blows, in anger]: (S:) [for the inf. n.] nafaTaAnN signifies the doing what resembles coughing: and blowing, on an occasion of anger: and so nafataAnN. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) aor.
nafiTa , inf. n. nafiyTN, said of an antelope; AlS~abiY~u in the K, being a mistake for AlZ~aboYi, as in the TS and L, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He uttered a sound, or cry. (TS, L, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) spoke, or talked, unintelligibly; (K, TA;) as though by reason of his anger. (TA.) ― -b6- nafaTati A@sotuhu (assumed tropical:) His anus emitted wind with a sound. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
3 naAofaTa see 6.

4 AnfT *
It (work) caused the hand to become blistered, or vesicated: or caused it to become ulcerated. (K.) [See 1, first sentence.]
5 tanaf~aTa see 1, in two places.
6 Alqidoru tanaAfaTu * [for tatanaAfaTu, in the CK ↓ tunAfiTu,] The cooking-pot throws forth foam; (K;) a dial. var. of tanaAfatu [q. v.] (TA.)

nafoTN * , accord. to the T, Pustules which come forth upon the hand, in consequence of work, full of water, or fluid; (Mgh;) blisters, or vesicles, upon the hand; a contraction of ↓ nafiTN; which is pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of ↓ nafiTapN, sometimes contracted into ↓ nafoTapN; and sometimes nafiTaAtN is used as pl. of nafiTapN: (Msb:) or ↓ nafiTapN signifies [simply] a pustule; as also ↓ nafoTapN and ↓ nifoTapN; (K;) and the lawyers call it ↓ naf~aATapN, from this word as signifying “ a place whence nifoT issues, ” or it may be [originally] an intensive act. part. n. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ nafiTN, (Msb,) or ↓ nafiTapN and ↓ nafoTapN and ↓ nifoTapN, (Mgh, Sgh, K,) The small-pox: (Mgh, Sgh, Msb, K:) accord. to Z, ↓ nfZ [so in the TA, without any syll. signs,] signifies, in the dial. of Hudheyl, the small-pox in children and in sheep or goats. (TA.) -A2- See also what next follows.
