nifoTN * and ↓ nafoTN, (S, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (ISk, S, Msb, K, *) or, as some say, the latter, (Msb,) or the latter is a mistake, (As, K,) [Naphtha: and petroleum: both so called in the present day:] a certain oil, (S,) well known, (K,) with which camels are smeared for the mange, or scab, and galls on the back, and tikes; it does not include what is termed kuHayol: (ISd, TA:) or, accord. to AHn, i. q. kuHayolN: accord. to A'Obeyd, i. q. qaTiraAnN; but AHn denies this; and says that it is an exuding fluid (HilaAbap) of a mountain, [found] in the bottom of a well, with which fire is kindled: (TA:) the best is the white: it is a dissolvent; and opens obstructions; removes the colic; and kills worms that are in the vulva, when used in the manner of a suppository. (K.)
nafiTN * : see nafoTN, throughout: ― -b2- and for the last, see also nafiyTapN.
nafoTapN * : see nafoyTN, throughout: ― -b2- and for the last, see also nafiyTapN.
nifoTapN * : see nafoTN, throughout: ― -b2- and for the last, see also nafiyTapN.
nafiTapN * : see nafoTN, throughout: ― -b2- and for the last, see also nafiyTapN.
nafaATapN * [accord. to the CK, but erroneously, nafaATN]: see naf~aATapN, in two places.

kaf~N nafiyTapN *
A hand ulcerated by work: or blistered, or vesicated; having water or fluid, between the skin and the flesh: and ↓ naAfiTapN signifies the same; and so ↓ manofuwTapN; (K;) of which last, however, ISd says, it is thus related by the lexicologists; but there is no way of accounting for it in my opinion; for it is from A^anofaTa. (TA.) [Golius also mentions ↓ nafiTapN as signifying A hand affected with pustules; on the authority of Meyd; and it is agreeable with analogy.]

naf~aATN *
A thrower of nifoT [or naphtha]: pl. ↓ naf~aATapN, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] (Msb,) and naf~aATuwna. (Mgh.)

naf~aATapN *
A place whence nifoT [or naphtha] is extracted; (El-Fárábee, Msb, K;) as also ↓ nafaATapN; (K;) but the former is the more known; (TA;) a place where it is generated; a mine, or source, thereof; a word similar to mal~aAHapN (Mgh, Msb) and qay~aArapN: (Mgh:) pl. naf~aATaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- A kind of lamp made to give light by means thereof; as also ↓ nafaATapN; (K;) but the former is the more known. (TA.) ― -b3- An instrument with which nifoT is thrown; (Mgh;) an instrument of copper, or brass, in which nifoT is thrown, (K, TA,) and fire; (TA;) a qaAruwrap of nifoT, which is thrown: (Msb:) pl. as above. (Mgh.) You say, xaraja Aln~af~aATuwna biA^ayodiyihmu Aln~af~aATaAtu [The throwers of naphtha went forth, having in their hands the instruments with which to throw it]. (Mgh.) ― -b4- See also naf~aATN. ― -b5- And see nafoTN.
kaf~N naAfiTapN * : see nafiyTapN. ― -b2- ragowapN naAfiTapN Froth, or foam, having bubbles: (Az, Msb:) pl. nawaAfiTu (TA.)
kaf~N manofuwTapN * : see nafiyTapN.

div2.head: nfE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 naqaba * , aor.
naquba , inf. n. naqobN, He perforated, pierced, bored, or made a hole through, or in, or into, anything: like vaqaba. (TA.) He made a hole through a wall. (S.) ― -b2- naqaba sur~apa Ald~aAb~api, aor.
naquba , He (a farrier) perforated the navel of the beast in order that a yellow fluid might issue forth. (S.) See manoqabN. ― -b3- naqaba AlEayona, aor.
naquba , inf. n. naqobN, He performed, upon the eye, what is called AlqadoHu in the language of the physicians; i. e., a remedial operation for the black fluid that arises in the eye: from the phrase next following: (IAth:) [but this is not a good explanation: the meaning is he performed upon the eye the operation of couching, for the cataract: so in many Arabic works, ancient and modern: (IbrD:) the couching-needle is called miqodaHN, and A_iborapu AlqadoHi, in the present day]. ― -b4- naqaba HaAfira Ald~aAb~api He (a farrier) pierced a hole in the hoof of the beast, in order to extract what had entered into it. (IAth.) ― -b5- naqabatohu nakobapN, (aor.
naquba , inf. n. naqobN, TA,) A misfortune, an evil accident, or a calamity befell him, (K,) and overcame him, or afflicted him; like nakabatohu. (TA.) [In the CK, for A^aSaAbatohu, is put AvAbth.] ― -b6- naqaba fiY AlA^aroDi, aor.
naquba , and ↓ Anqb and ↓ naq~b, He went, or went away, through the land, or country: (K:) [in the CK and some MS. copies of the K, we afterwards find naqiba fiY AlbilaAdi with kesr to the q, explained as signifying he proceeded, or journeyed, through the lands:] ↓ Anqb he proceeded, or journeyed, through the country: (IAar:) nq~bwA fiY AlbilaAdi [Kur, l. 35,] they proceeded, or journeyed, through the lands, seeking for a place of refuge: (S:) or they traversed the lands, and journeyed through them, much, &c.: (Fr.:) or they went about and about, and searched, &c. (Zj.) fiY AlA=faAqi ↓ naq~abotu, in a verse of Imra-el-Keys, I journeyed through the tracts of the earth, and came and went. (TA.) ― -b7- naqiba AlbaEiyru, aor.
naqaba , or naqiba Huf~u AlbEyri, (L, TA,) and ↓ Anqb, (L,) The camel walked barefooted, syn. HafiYa, (L, K,) until his feet became worn in holes: (TA:) or naqiba AlbEyr, (S, K,) and ↓ Anqb, (K,) the camel's feet became thin, [or were worn thin; which is also a signification of HafiYa]. (S, K.) ― -b8- naqibato A^aqodaAmunaA Our feet became thin in the skin, and blistered, by reason of walking. (L.) ― -b9- naqaba Alxuf~a, aor.
naquba , He patched the boot; repaired it by patching. (K.) Also, He made the boot thin: he made [or wore] holes in it. (Msb.) ― -b10- naqiba Alxuf~u, aor.
naqaba , (inf. n. naqabN, TA,) The boot became lacerated, or worn through, in holes. (S, K, TA.) [And in like manner The sole of the foot of a camel or of a man: see below: and see an ex. voce A^aZal~u.] ― -b11- naqaba, aor.
naquba , inf. n. naqobN, He (a horse) put his feet together in his running (fiY HuDorihi, [for which Golius and Freytag appear to have read fY xaSorihi,] K,) not spreading his fore feet, his running being [a kind of] leaping. (TA.) -A2- naqaba Eani AlA^axoboAri, aor.
naquba , He scrutinized, investigated, searched into, examined into, or inquired into, the news; (K;) and, in like manner, anything else: (MF:) [as also ↓ nq~b: see the phrase nq~bwA fY AlblAd, explained above:] or he told, announced, or related, the news. (K.) ― -b2- A_in~iY lamo A^uw^omaro A^ano A^anoquba Eano quluwbi Aln~aAsi Verily I have not been commanded to scrutinize and reveal what is in the hearts of men. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- naqaba EalaY qawomihi, aor.
naquba , inf. n. niqaAbapN, He acted as the naqiyb over his people; was their nqyb: (S, K:) but of a man who was not nqyb, and has become so, you say naquba, with damm, aor.
naquba , inf. n. naqaAbapN, with fet-h, He became nqyb; (Fr., S, K;) as also naqiba, aor.
naqaba : (IKtt, K:) or nqAbp with kesr is a subst.; and with fet-h, an inf. n.; (S, K;) like wilaAyapN and walaAyapN: so says Sb. (S.) -A3- naqaba Alv~awoba, aor.
naquba , inf. n. naqobN, He made the piece of cloth into a nuqobap. (S.)
2 naq~aba see 1.

3 naAqabotuhu * , inf. n. niqaAbN; as also laqiytuhu; I met him face to face: or without appointment, (K,) and unintentionally: (TA:) or unexpectedly. (S.) nqAbFA is in the accus. case as an inf. n.; or as a word descriptive of state. (TA.) ― -b2- waradotu AlmaA'a niqaAbFA, (S,) or laqiytu AlmA' nqAbA, (K,) I came upon the water unexpectedly, without seeking for it. (S, K.)

4 A^anoqaba see 1. ― -b2- Anqb His camel's feet became thin; [or were worn thin;] (S, K;) or were worn in holes by walking. (TA.) -A2- He became a door-keeper, or chamberlain; Arab. HaAjib: (K:) or he became a naqiyb. (L, K, &c.)
5 tanaq~aba see 8.
8 Antqbt * (S, K, Msb) and ↓ tnq~bt (Msb) She (a woman) veiled her face with a niqaAb (S, K, Msb.) ― -b2- bEmaAmath ↓ tnqb: see txt~m.

naqobN * (S, K) and ↓ nuqobapN (S) A hole, perforation, or bore, (K,) in, or through, a wall, (S,) or anything whatever: (TA:) or a large hole, perforation, or bore, passing through a thing; such as is small being termed vaqobN, with v: (Mgh, in art. vqb:) pl. of the former nuquwbN (Msb) and A^anoqaAbN and niqaAbN. (TA, and some copies of the K.) ― -b2- naqobN (K) and ↓ naAqibapN (S) An ulcer that arises in the side, (S, ISd, K,) attacking the inside of the body, (S, ISd,) and having its head inwards; (ISd;) [as also ↓ naq~aAbapN, for] naq~aAbaAtN signifies ulcers that come forth in the side and penetrate into the inside. (TA voce *ubaAlN.) See nuqobN. ― -b3- naqobN (S, K) and ↓ nuqobN (K) and ↓ manoqabN and ↓ manoqabapN (S, K) A road (or narrow road, TA,) in a mountain: (ISk, S, K:) a road between two mountains: (IAth:) pl. (of the first and second, TA,) A^anoqaAbN (a pl. of pauc., TA,) and niqaAbN; (K;) and of the third and fourth, manaAqibu. (TA.) See also manoqabapN.

nuqobN * (S, K,) and ↓ naqobN (K: but the former is the more common: TA) and ↓ nuqabN (K) [the first is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is nuqobapN [q. v.], of which it is called in the S the pl.: but nuqabN is the pl. of nuqobapN:] Scab, [or scabs,] (K,) absolutely: (TA:) or scattered scabs (S, K,) when they first appear: (S:) Aln~uqobapu is the first that appears of the scab; and is so called because the scabs perforate the skin: you say, of a camel, bihi nuqobapN: (As:) the first that appears of the scab, in a patch like the palm of the hand, in the side of a camel, or on his haunch, or his lip: then it spreads over him until it covers him entirely. (ISh.) Mohammad, denying that any disease was transmitted from one thing to another, and being asked how it was that a nuqobap spread in camels, asked what transmitted the disease to the first camel. (TA.) ― -b2- fulaAnN yaDaEu AlhinaA='a mawaADiEa Aln~uqobi (tropical:) [Such a one puts the tar upon the places of the scabs]: said of one who is clever, or skilful, and who does or says what is right. (A.) [See also qaAlabN]

naqibN * , and, as a fem. epithet, ↓ naqobaA'u, A camel whose feet have become worn in holes, [or worn thin,] by walking. (TA.) See the verb. ― -b2- The former may also signify Having the scab, or what first appears thereof. (TA.) See nuqobN.
nuqabN * : see nuqobN.

nuqobapN * A mark, trace, or vestige: ex. Ealayoh nuqobapN Upon him, or it, is a mark, &c. (T.) ― -b2- See naqobN. ― -b3- nuqobapN (assumed tropical:) Rust, (K.) upon a sword or the head of an arrow or a spear: (M:) or naqb [i. e. ↓ nuqobN, q. v., a coll. gen. n., of which nuqobapN is the n. un.; or nuqabN, pl. of nuqobapN;] signifies (tropical:) traces of rust upon a sword or an arrow head or a spear-head, likened to the first appearances of the scab. (A.) -A2- nuqobapN The face: (S, K:) or the parts surrounding the face. (L:) pl. nuqabN. (TA.) ― -b2- nuqobapN A garment resembling an A_izAr, having a sewed waistband or string, (HujozapN maxiyTapN: so in the S, M, L: whence it appears that the reading in the K, Hjzp muTyfapN, is erroneous: TA: [F having, it seems, found muHiyTapN written in the place of muHiyTapN:]) without a nayofaq which is the part turned down at the top, and sewed, through which the waistband passes], (S, K,) tied as trousers, or drawers, are tied: (S:) or a pair of trousers, or drawers, having a waistband, but without a part turned down at the top, and sewed, for the waistband to pass through: if it have this, (i. e, a. nyfq,) it is called sarAwiylu: (TA;) or a piece of rag of which the upper part is made like drawers, or trousers: (L;) or a pair of drawers, or trousers, without legs. (M, voce A_inobN, TA,) -A3- nuqobapN The state, or condition; quality, mode, or manner; state with regard to apparel &c.; external form, figure, feature, or appearance; of any thing: syn. hayoy^apN. (T.) -A4- nuqobapN Colour. (S, K.) ― -b2- farasN Hasanu Aln~aqobapi A horse of beautiful colour. (TA.) ― -b3- See also naqiybapN.

niqobapN *
A mode of veiling the face with the niqaAb: (K:) pl. niqabN. (TA.) ― -b2- A_in~ahaA laHasanapu Aln~iqobapi (S) Verily she has a comely mode of veiling her face with the nqAb. (TA.)

niqaAbN * [A woman's face-veil;] (S, K;) a veil that is upon [or covers] the soft, or pliable, part of the nose; (AZ;) [not extending higher:] a woman's veil that extends as high as the circuit of the eye: (Msb:) it is of different modes: Fr says, When a woman lowers her nqAb to her eye, it [the action] is termed waSowaSapN; and when she lowers it further, to [the lower part of] the circuit of the eye, it [the veil] is called nqAb; and if it is on the extremity of the nose, it is [properly] called lifaAmN: (T:) the nqAb, with the Arabs, is that [kind of veil] from out of which appears the circuit of the eye: and the meaning of the saying in a trad. Aln~iqaAbu muHodavN is, that women's shewing the circuits of the eyes is an innovation; not that they used not to veil their faces: the [kind of] nqAb which they used reached close to the eye, and they showed one eye while the other was concealed; whereas the [kind of] nqAb, which only shows both the eyes [without their circuits] was called by them waSowaSapN [a mistake for waSowaASN] and turoquEN: [in the original, wAlnqAb lA ybdwmnh Al~A AlEynAn wkAn Asmh Alx: but the w before kAn is erroneously introduced, and perverts the sense, which is otherwise plain, and agreeable with what is said before:] then they innovated the [veil] properly called] nqAb: (A'Obeyd:) pl. naqubN. (Msb.) -A2- niqaAbN and ↓ minaqabN A road through a rugged tract of ground: (K:) the former word used both as a sing and a pl. (TA.) -A3- niqaAbN (a strange form of epithet, MF,) (tropical:) A man of great knowledge; very knowing: (S, K:) or possessing a knowledge of things, or affairs: or, as also ↓ minEqabN, mentioned by I Ath and Z, a man possessing a knowledge of things, who scrutinizes or investigates them much; who is intelligent, and enters deeply into things. (TA.) -A4- nqaAbN The bello, Hence the proverb, faroxaAni fiY niqaAbK [Two young birds in one belly]: applied to two things that resemble one another, (K.) In like manner one says kaAnaA fiY nqAb waAHd [They were in one belly]; meaning they were like each other, (A.)

naqiybN * i. q. manoquwbN, A thing perforated, pierced, bored. or having a hole made through, or in. or into it. (TA.) ― -b2- naqiybN A musical reed, or pipe. (K.) ― -b3- The tongue of a pair of scales, or balance (K.) ― -b4- A dog having the upper part of his mindpipe (galoSamatuhu: so in the S, K or having his windpipe, Hanojaratuhu: so in the A) perforated, (S, K,) in order that his cry may be weak: a base man performs this operation on his dog, in order that guests may not hear its cry. (S: and the like is said in the L.) -A2- naqiybu quwomK The intendant, superintendent, overseer, or inspector, of a people; he who takes notice, or cognisance, of their actions, and is responsible for them; i. q. Eariyfuhumo and $aAhiduhumo and Damiyuhumo: (S, K:) like A^amiynN and kafiylN: (Zj:) their head, or chief: (TA:) like EariyfN [q. v.]; i. e., one who is set over a people, and investigates their affairs: (L:) or, as some say, the greatest, or supreme, chief of a people: so called [from naqaba “ he scrutinized, or investigated, ”] because he is acquainted with the secret
affairs of the people, and knows their virtues, or generous actions, and is the way by which one obtains knowledge of their affairs: (TA:) pl. nuqabaA'u. (S.)
niqaAbapN * The office of naqiyb. (Sb: see 1.)

naqiybapN *
Mind: syn. nafosN. (S, K,) You say fulaAnN mayomuwnu Alnqybpi Such a one is of a fortunate mind, (A'Obeyd, S,) when the person referred to is fortunate in his affairs, succeeding in what he seeks after, or strives to accomplish: (ISk, S:) or when he is fortunate in his counsel, or advice: (Th, S:) or the phrase signifies such a one is fortunate in his actions, and in gaining what he seeks. (TA.) See also what follows. naqiybapN is also said, in the K, to signify the same as EaqolN (understanding, intellect, or intelligence); but, says SM, I have not found this in any other lexicon: only I have found the word explained in the L as signifying yumonu AlfiEoli (good fortune attending, or resulting from, an action): so probably EaqolN is a mistake for fiEolN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, Counsel, or advice. (K.) See above. ― -b3- Also, Penetration of judgment; acuteness; sagacity. (Ibn-Buzurj, K.) ― -b4- Also, Nature; or natural, or native, disposition, temper, or other quality: (K:) i. q. naqiymapN and EariykapN and TabiyEapN. (T, art. Erk.) Agreeably with this explanation, the phrase above mentioned is rendered in the T, in art. Erk, Such a one is of a fortunate nature, or natural disposition: (TA:) or it signifies, in this phrase, as also nqymp, i. q. lawonN, Colour, complexion, species, &c. (IAar.) Also huwa Hasanu Aln~aqiybapi He is of a good nature, or natural disposition: and in like manner, jamiylapK ↓ fulaAnN fiY manaAqiba Such a one is a person of good dispositions, or natural qualities. (L.) -A2- naqiybapN A she-camel having a large udder: (ISd, K:) having her udder bound up with a cloth or the like, on account of its greatness and excellence: but AM says this is a corruption, and that the correct word is vqybp, with v, meaning a she-camel “ abounding with milk. ” (TA.)
naq~aAbapN * : see naqobN.

naAqib * and naAqibapN [the former omitted in some copies of the K] A disease that befalls a man in consequence of long sluggishness, or indolence: (K:) or, as some say, the ulcer that arises in the side. (TA.) See naqobN.

A^anoqaAbN * , a pl. without a sing., The ears: (M, K,) or, accord. to some, its sing. is nuqobN. (TA.) El-Katámee says,
kaAnato xuduwdu hijaAnihin~a mumaAlapF
A^anoqaAbuhun~a A_ilaY HudaA='i Als~uw~aqi
[The cheeks of their white camels were with their ears inclined to the singing of the drivers]. But A^anaqFA bihin~a, “ by reason of their pleasure, ” is also read, for A^anoqaAbuhun~a: (TA:) [so that the meaning is The cheeks of their white camels were inclined, by reason of their pleasure. to the singing of the drivers].
manoqabN * The navel: or [a place] before it: (K:) where the farrier makes a perforation in order that a yellow fluid may issue forth: (S:) so in a horse. (TA.) ― -b2- See naqobN.

minoqabN *
An iron instrument with which a farrier perforates the navel of a beast of carriage (S, K) in order that a yellow fluid may issue forth. (S.) See manoqabN, and niqaAbN.

manoqabapN * : see naqobN. ― -b2- A narrow way between two houses, (L, K,) along which one cannot pass. (L.) It is said in a trad., that one does not possess the right of pre-emption (Al$~ufoEap) with respect to a mnqbp; and this word is explained as signifying a wall: syn. HaAy^iTN: [and so in the K:] or a way between two houses, as though it were perforated from one to the other: or a road, or way, over an elevated piece of ground. (L.) -A2- manoqabapN A virtue; an excellence; contr. of mavolabapN: (S:) a cause of glorying: (K:) generosity of action, or conduct: (L:) a [good disposition, or natural quality: [see naqiybapN:] (TA:) a memorable, or generous action, and [good] internal quality: (A:) pl. manaAqibu: (TA:) rjulN *uw manaAqiba A man of memorable, or generous, actions, and [good] internal qualities. (A.)

1 naqata * , [aor.
naquta ,] inf. n. naqotN, He took out, or extracted, marrow [from a bone]. (K.) Az, quotes, from Aboo-Turáb, on the authority of Aboo-'Ameythel, nuqita AlEaZomu, and nukita, The marrow of the bone was taken out, or extracted. (L.) And J says, naqat~u Almux~a aor.
naquta , inf. n. naqotN, is a dial. form of naqawotuhu, meaning, I took out, or extracted the marrow [from a bone]: as though they had changed the w into t. (L.) But it is said in a marginal note in the S, Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee says, What I remember to have heard is naqavotu AlEaZoma, aor.
naquta , inf. n. naqovN, I took out, or extracted, the marrow from the bone; and so A_inotaqavotuhu, with the three-pointed v; and naqayotuhu, and A_inotaqayotuhu, and naquwotuhu. (TA.)

1 naqava * , aor.
naquva ; and ↓ nq~v, (inf. n. tanoqiyvN, S,) and ↓ Antqv; He hastened, was quick. (S, K.) ― -b2- xarajotu A^anoquvu I went forth hastening. (S.) ― -b3- xaraja yanoquvu Als~ayora, and ↓ yanotaqivu, He went forth hastening in his pace. (TA.) ― -b4- naqava, Hadiyvahu [aor.
naquva ,] He mixed, or confounded, his discourse, like as one mixes food. (K.) -A2- naqavahu biAlkalaAmi, [aor.
naquva ,] (and ↓ Antqvhu, TA,) He hurt him by words. (K.) -A3- naqava AlA^aroDa, aor.
naquva , inf. n. naqovN. He dug up the earth with a hoe or shovel. (AZ.) ― -b2- naqava $ayoy^FA; (or, accord. to the TA. Eano $aYo'K,) and ↓ Antqv, He dug up the earth from a thing. (K.) ― -b3- naqava AlEaZoma (aor.
naquva , inf. n. naqovN, TA;) and ↓ Antqvhu; and ↓ tnq~vh; (TA;) He took out, or extracted, the marrow from the bone. (K.) See also naqata. (TA.) ― -b4- naqava, inf. n. naqovN; and ↓ nq~v, inf. n. tanoqiyvN; He removed a thing. Ex. laA tunaq~ivu miyrtanaA She used not to remove our wheat, or provision, nor to take it forth, nor scatter it; but kept it faithfully. (TA, from a trad.)
2 naq~ava see 1.

5 tnq~v *
He endeavoured to make a woman incline to him, and to render her affectionate to him: (K:) as though he drew forth her love, like as one draws forth the marrow from a bone. (TA.) ― -b2- tnq~v DayoEatahu i. q. taEah~adahaA. (TA.) ― -b3- See 1.
8 A_inotaqava see 1.

naqovN *
Malicious, or mischievous, misrepresentation; calumny; slander. (IAar.)
naqaAvi * (in measure like qaTaAmi) The hyena. (K.)

naqiyvapu Albiy^ori *
i. q. nabiyvatuhaA. (TA voce qaAHapN, in art. qwH.)

1 naqaHa $ayoy^FA * , aor.
naqaHa , (inf. n. naqoHN, TA,) He peeled, or barked, a thing; peeled off, stripped off, or removed, its outer covering. (K, TA.) naqaHa AlEuwda, (Msb,) or AlEaSaA, (T,) aor.
naqaHa , inf. n. naqoHN, (Msb,) He pared, or trimmed, the stick, or staff, by cutting off its knots: (T, Msb:) and in like manner you say of anything from which you pare off somewhat. (T.) ― -b2- naqaHa Alji*oEa, inf. n. naqoHN; (K;) and ↓ nq~Hhu, (K,) inf. n. tanoqiyHN; (S;) He pared off the knots of the palm-trunk: (K:) or he pruned, or trimmed, the trunk of the palm-tree, by cutting off the stumps of the branches, or by cutting off the superfluous branches. (S.) ― -b3- naqaHa, (TA,) and ↓ AnqH, (K,) He stripped off the ornaments of his sword [to sell them] in a time of dearth and poverty. (K, TA.) ― -b4- naqaHa AlEaZoma, aor.
naqaHa , (K,) inf. n. naqoHN; (TA;) and ↓ nq~Hhu, (inf. n. tanoqiyHN, S;) and ↓ AntqHhu; (S, K;) He extracted the marrow from the bone: (S, K:) or
nq~Hh * has an intensive signification. (Msb.) ― -b2- naqaHa $ayoy^FA He separated what was good from what was bad of the thing. (Msb.)

2 nq~H Al$~iEora * , inf. n. tanoqiyHN; (S, K;) and ↓ AnqHhu, inf. n. A_inoqaAHN; (K;) (tropical:) He trimmed, pruned, or put into a right or proper state, poetry, or verses. (S, K.) ― -b2- nq~H AlkalaAma (tropical:) He scrutinized the language, and examined it well: or he put it to rights, or trimmed it, and removed its faults, or defects. (TA.) ― -b3- See 1.
4 A^anoqaHa see 1 and 2.

5 tnq~H $aHomuhu * , (K,) or $aHomu Aln~aAqapi, (S,) or $aHomu naAqatihi, (TA, &c.,) (tropical:) His fat, (K,) or the fat of the she-camel, (S,) or the fat of his she-camel, (TA, &c.,) became little in quantity, or diminished, (S, K, &c.,) or partially went away. (A.)
8 A_inotaqaHa see 1.
xayoru Al$~iEori AlHawoliY~u Almunaq~aHu * (tropical:) [The best of poetry is that which is a year old, and trimmed, or pruned]. (S.)

1 naqaxa * , aor.
naqaxa , (S, L, K,) inf. n. naqoxN (S, L) and nuqaAxN, (L,) He struck, smote, or beat. (K.) naqaxa raA^osahu He struck his head with a staff, or sword, or some other hard thing: or he struck his head so that the brain came forth: (L:) or he broke his head so as to disclose the brain; as also naqafa. (S, L.) naqaxa dimaAgahu He broke his brain. (K.) ― -b2- Also, naqaxa (L) and ↓ Antqx (L, K) He extracted marrow (L, K) from a bone. (L.) ― -b3- naqaHa AlEaTa$a bibarodihi (assumed tropical:) It (sweet water) broke, [or abated, or allayed,] thirst, by its coolness, or coldness. (L, from a trad.)
8 A_inotaqaxa see 1.

nuqaAxN *
Sweet water; that has no saltness; (AO, Th, S;) that strikes (yanoqaxu) the heart (or almost does so, L) by its coldness: (S:) or cold, or cool, and sweet, and clear, water: (K:) or sweet water, that breaks [or abates or allays] (yanoqaHu, i. e. yakosiru,) thirst by its coolness, or coldness: (L, from a trad.:) or abundant water which a man makes to well forth in a place where was no water. (ISh.) ― -b2- Also, Pure, mere, unadulterated, or genuine. (T, K.) ― -b3- h`*aA nuqaAxu AlEarabiy~api (Fr) (tropical:) This is pure Arabic; or the purest, choicest, best, or most excellent, of Arabic. (Fr, A.) ― -b4- Also nuqaAxN Sleep in health and safety. (Abu-l-'Abbás, K.)

1 naqada Ald~araAhima * (S, A, L, Msb) aor.
naquda , (L, Msb,) inf. n. naqodN (L, Msb, K) and tanoqaAdN; (L, K;) and ↓ AntqdhA (S, L, Msb, K) and ↓ tnq~dhA; (L, K:) He picked, or separated, the money, or pieces of money, (Lth, L, K,) and put forth the bad; (S, L, K;) he picked, or separated, the good money from the bad: (A:) he examined the money, or pieces of money, to pick, or separate, the good from the bad: (Msb:) and the verbs are used in the same sense with respect to other things than pieces of money. (K.) ― -b2- [naqada, aor.
naquda , inf. n. naqodN, q. v. infra, He gave cash, or ready money; paid in cash, or ready money. Often used in this sense.] ― -b3- naqadahu Alv~amana, aor.
naquda , inf. n. naqodN; He gave him the price in cash, or ready money: (L:) or simply he gave him the price; as also naqada lahu Alv~amana: (A:) and naqadahu Ald~araAhima, and naqada lahu Ald~araAhim, he gave him the money, or pieces of money. (S, L, Msb.) ― -b4- [Hence, from the first meaning,] naqada AlkalaAma, [and Al$~iEora,] and so He picked out the faults of the language, [and of the poetry;] syn. naAqa$ahu. (TA.) ― -b5- ↓ Ainotaqada Al$iEora EalaY qaAy^ilihi (tropical:) [He picked out the faults of the poetry and urged them against its author.] (A.) ― -b6- naqadahu binaZarihi, and naqada A_ilayohi, aor.
naquda , (L,) inf. n. naqodN (L, K) (tropical:) He looked furtively at, or towards it: (L, K: *) and so nqdh biEayobihi: (L:) and nqd biEayonihi Alyh he continued looking furtively at, or towards, it: you say also, maA zaAla baSaruhu yanoqudu A_ilaY *`lika [his gaze ceased not to be furtively directed at, or towards, that]: as though likened to the look of a man picking, or separating, what is good from what is bad: (A:) and maA zaAla yanoqudu baSarahu A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i he ceased not to look at, or towards, the thing. (S, L.) -A2- yaqida, (S, L,) [aor.
naqada ,] inf. n. naqadN; (S, L, K;) and, as some say, naqada; (S, L;) It (a tooth, S, L, K, and a horn, T, L, and a hoof of a horse or the like, L,) became eroded, (T, S, L, K,) and much broken: (L, K:) and it (the hoof of a horse or the like) sealed off, part after part: (S, L:) it (the trunk of a tree) became wormeaten. (L.)
3 nAqdhu * (tropical:) He reckoned with him to the utmost, syn. naAqa$ahu, (S, A, L, K,) fiY A^amorK in, or respecting, an affair, (S, L,) [picking out his faults].

4 Anqd *
It (a tree) put forth its leaves. (L, K.)
5 tanaq~ada see 1.

8 Antqd Ald~araAhima *
He received the money, or pieces of money; (Lth, S, L, Msb, K;) and Alv~amana the price. (A.) ― -b2- See 1. -A2- Antqd It (a worm) ate the trunk of a tree, and rendered it hollow. (L.) -A3- He (a boy) grew up into manhood. (K.)

naqodN * [properly an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n., and thus signifying “ paid, ” Cash, or ready money: or simply money]. You say naqodN jay~idN [Good cash, or ready money: or good money]: pl. nuquwdN jiyaAdN. (A.) Alt~aqodaAni signifies Silver and gold money; dirhems and deenárs. (TA in art. ErD.) ― -b2- naqodN Payment in cash, or ready money; contr. of nasoyy^apN: (L, K:) the giving of naqod [i. e., cash, or ready money]: (K:) [an inf. n.: see 1]. ― -b3- Ald~irohamu naqodN The piece of money is of full weight, (S, L, K, *) and good. (S, L.) ― -b4- h`*ihi miAy^apN naqodu Aln~aAsi [This is a hundred, ready money of the people] is a phrase used by the Arabs, in which l is meant to be understood [before Aln~As: i. e. AlnAs is for liln~aAsi; and naqodu for naqodN, as an epithet of mAy^p; you may also say naqoda AlnaAs, making nqd a denotative of state; but] the epithetic mode of construction is that which prevails in this case. (Sb, L.) ― -b5- naqodN. ― -b6- The saying of the poet,
latunotajan~a waladFA A^awo naqodaA
means She will certainly bring forth a she-camel, which shall be a permanent acquisition for breeding, or a male, which shall be sold: for they seldom kept the male camels. (Th, L.)

nuqodN * (Lh, L, K,) and ↓ nuqudN (K) and ↓ nuqadN. (Lh, Az, L,) the form most frequently heard by Az from the Arabs, (L,) or ↓ naqadN, (K,) [coll. gen. n.] A certain kind of tree, (Lh, L, K,) accord. to AA, of the description termed xuwSap, having a blossom resembling the bahoramaAn, i. e. the EuSofur [or bastard-saffron]; (AHn, L;) its blossom is yellow, and it grows in plain, or soft, grounds: (Az, L:) n. un. with p; (K;) nuqodapN (Lh, S, L) and nuqudapN (TA) and nuqadapN (Lh, L) and naqadapN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also ↓ nuqodapN, (L,) or ↓ niqodapN, (IAar, L, K,) The karawoyaA=' [or caraway]. (IAar, L, K.) ― -b3- See naqidN.
niqodN * : see naqidN.

naqadN * [a coll. gen. n.] A kind of sheep, of ugly form; (K;) a kind of sheep of El-Bahreyn, having short legs and ugly faces: (S, L:) or a kind of small sheep of El-Hijáz: (L:) or, simply, lambs: (A, L:) [see an ex. in a prov. cited voce $aAma in art. $ym:] n. un. with p: (S, L:) applied alike to the male and female: (L:) pl. niqaAdN, and [quasi-pl. n.] niqaAdapN. (L, K.) As says, that the best of wool is that of naqad. And one says, A^a*al~u mina Aln~aqadi [More abject, or vile, than
the sheep called nqd]. (S, L.) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) The lower sort of people. (L.) ― -b3- See nuqodN and naqidN.

naqidN * , (L,) or ↓ niqodN, (K,) Slow in growing up into manhood, and having little flesh: (L, K:) [and so ↓ nuqodN, accord. to the CK: but wyuDm~ is there put by mistake for wbiDam~K: and the former, (S, L,) or ↓ naqadN, (K,) a boy despised and little in the eyes of others, that scarcely grows up into manhood; (S, L, K;) sometimes thus applied. (S, L.) ― -b2- naqidN A horn eaten, or eroded, at the root. (L.) See also naqida.
nuqudN * and nuqadN and nuqodapN and niqodahN: see nuqodN.
nuqaAdapN * The choice part of a thing. (JK.) ― -b2- huwa mino nuqaAdapi quwomihi (tropical:) He is of the best of his people. (A.)

naq~aAdN *
A shepherd who tends the kind of sheep called naqad: (L, K:) or a possessor of skins of that kind of sheep. (Th, L.) ― -b2- See naAqidN.

naAqidN * [One who picks, or separates, money, and puts forth the bad; who picks, or separates, good money from bad:] who examines money, to pick, or separate the good from the bad: [as also ↓ naq~aAdN:] pl. nuq~aAdN (Msb) [and naqadapN]. ― -b2- [naAqidu $iEorK, and ↓ naq~aAduhu (tropical:) One who picks out the faults of poetry; and, the ↓ latter, one who is accustomed to do so.] ― -b3- huwa mino naqadapi Al$~iEori and mino nuq~aAdihi, (tropical:) [He is one of those who pick out the faults of poetry]. (A.)

A^anoqadu *
The hedge-hog; Alqunofu*u; (S, L, K;) a proper name, like A^asaAmapu applied to the lion: (S:) as also AlA^anoqadu; (K;) but some disallow the prefixing of the art.; (TA;) and AlA^anoqa*u. (L.) Hence the saying, baAta bilayoli A^anoqada, (S, L,) or bilayolapi A^anoqada, (A, L,) He passed the night of the hedge-hog; i. e. sleepless: (L:) because the hedge-hog remains sleepless (and sees, L) all night: (S, L, K:) and A^asoraY mino A^anoqada [A greater journeyer by night than the hedge-hog]. (A, L.) ― -b2- A^anoqadu layolK A calumniator; a slanderer; as also qunofu*u layolK. (L, art. qnf*.) ― -b3- Also, AlA^anoqadu [L, K,) and ↓ AlA_inoqidaAnu (K) The tortoise: (L, K:) or the latter, the male tortoise: (Lth:) as also with *. (TA.)
AlA_inoqidaAnu * : see preceding sentence.

1 naqi*a * , aor.
naqa*a , inf. n. naqa*N; (Msb, K;) or naqa*a, (A, L,) aor.
naqu*a , (L,) inf. n. naqo*N; (A, L;) He became safe, in safety, saved, or liberated; he escaped. (A, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- naqo*FA laka Safety to thee! Said to a man stumbling. (A, K.) ― -b3- See also 4.
2 naq~a*a see 4.

4 Anq*hu * , (S, A, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_inoqaA*N; (K;) and ↓ Astnq*hu; and ↓ tnq~*hu; (S, A, L, K;) and ↓ nq~*N, inf. n. tanoqiy*N; and ↓ naqa*ahu, [aor.
naqu*a ,] inf. n. naqo*N; (K;) He saved, rescued, or liberated, him or it, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) from such a one, (S, L,) and from evil. (Msb.)
5 tanaq~a*a see 4.
10 A_isotanoqa*a see 4.

naqa*N * A thing that one has saved, rescued, or liberated; (S, L, Msb, K;) of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like nafaDN and qabaDN; (S, L;) as also ↓ naqiy*N and naqiy*apN: (L:) a man saved, or rescued, or liberated: (L:) also, a horse taken from another people: (L:) or a camel &c. taken by, and then recovered from, the enemy; as also naqiy*apN and naqiy*N; pl. naqaAy^i*u: (A:) or ↓ naqiy*apN signifies a horse saved, or rescued, or liberated, (S, L, K,) and taken, (S, L,) from the enemy; (S, L, K;) pl. naqaAy^i*u: (S, L;) or the sing. of nqAy^*, signifying horses saved, or rescued, or liberated, from the hands of men, or of the enemy, is ↓ naqiy*N, without p: (IAar, L:) and, accord. to El-Muffaddal, (L,) ↓ naqiy*apN signifies a coat of mail, diroEN; (L, K;) because it saves the person wearing it from the sword: (L:) and Az says, I have read in the handwriting of Shemir, that it signifies a coat of mail saved, or rescued, from the enemy. (L.) You say also, huwa naqiy*apu buw^osK, and humo naqaAy^*u buw^osK, He is saved, or rescued, from distress, or adversity; and they are &c. (A.) ― -b2- maA lahu $aqa*N walaA naqa*N He possesses not anything. (K.)
naqiy*N * and naqiy*apN: see naqa*N. ― -b2- Also the latter, A woman having had a husband. (K.)
AlA^anoqa*u * [or A^anoqa*u, without the art.,] The hedgehog; Alqutofu*u: (K;) as also with d. (TA.)

1 naqara * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
naqura , inf. n. naqorN, (S, Msb,) He (a bird) pecked, or picked up, (S, A, Msb, K,) a grain, (S,) or grains, (A, Msb,) from this place and that, (A, K,) biminoqaArihi with his beak. (A.) [Accord. to the TA, the addition “ from this place and that, ” which is found in the K and A, and in one place in the S, seems to be unnecessary. And ↓ Antqr signifies the same: see 8, in art. qb.] ― -b2- [Hence, because of the sure aim with which a bird pecks a thing,] the same verb, having the same [aor. and] inf. n. signifies, (tropical:) It (an arrow) hit the butt. (Msb.) And He (an archer) hit the butt, without making his arrow to pass through, partly or wholly. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) He took [or picked] a thing, as, for instance, food, with the finger. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, TA,) He struck a thing (IKtt, K, * TA,) with a thing: (IKtt, TA:) [generally, he struck, knocked, or pecked, a thing with a pointed instrument, like as a bird strikes a thing with its beak:] he struck [or pecked] a mill-stone, or a stone, &c., with a minoqaAr [which is a pick, or a kind of pickaxe; i. e., he wrought it into shape, and roughened it in its surface, with a pick]. (M, TA.) ― -b5- [Hence,] (tropical:) He wrote [or engraved writing] fiY HajarK upon a stone. (A, K.) Whence the saying, Alt~aEoliymu fiY AlS~igari kaAln~aqori EalaY AlHajari [or, as in a verse of Niftaweyh, fiY AlHajari, i. e., Teaching in infancy is like engraving writing upon stone]. (TA.) ― -b6- He struck [or fillipped] a man's head, and in like manner a lute, and a tambourine, with his finger. (TA.) You say also A^u*unahu ↓ A^anoqara, meaning, He struck [or fillipped] his ear with his finger. (AA, in TA, art. nTb.) ― -b7- [Hence,] naqara, [aor.
naqura , inf. n. naqorN, as appears from what follows;] and ↓ A^anoqara; (tropical:) [He made a snapping with his thumb and middle finger;] he struck his thumb against the end of the middle finger and made a sound with them. (A.) [And in like manner the former verb used transitively; as in the following instance:] waDaEa Tarafa A_ibohaAmihi EalaY baATini sab~aAbatihi vum~a naqarahaA [(tropical:) He put the end of his thumb against the inner side of his first finger, then made a snapping with it]. (TA.) See also naqorN, below. ― -b8- [Hence also,] naqara biAld~aAb~api, (T, A, TS,) or biAlfarasi, (S,) aor.
naqura , (TA,) inf. n. naqorN; (T, S, TS;) and ↓ A^anoqara, (A, TS,) inf. n. A_inoqaArN; (TS;) (tropical:) He made a [smacking or] slight sound, to put in motion the [beast or] horse, by making his tongue adhere to his palate and then opening [or suddenly drawing it away]: (S:) or he struck with his tongue the place of utterance of the letter n and made a [smacking] sound [by suddenly withdrawing his tongue]: (A:) naqorN signifies the making the end of the tongue to adhere to the palate, then making a sound [by suddenly withdrawing it]: (M, K:) or one's putting his tongue above his central incisors, at the part next the palate, then making a smacking sound [so I render vum~a yanoqur]: (TA:) [the sounds thus described, which are nearly the same, are commonly made by the Arabs in the present day, in urging beasts of carriage:] or an agitation of the tongue (K, TA) in the mouth, upwards and downwards: (TA:) or a sound, (so in some copies of the K and in the TA,) or slight sound, (so in the TS [as mentioned in the TA] and in some copies of the K) by which a horse is put in motion: (TS, K:) or naqara bilisaAnihi, accord. to IKtt, signifies he struck his palate with his tongue to quiet the horse: but this is at variance with what is said by Az, J, and ISd, and requires consideration. (TA.) A poet, (S,) Fedekee El-Minkaree, (K,) i. e., 'Obeyd
Ibn-Máweeyeh, of the tribe of Teiyi, (TA,) uses Aln~aquro for Aln~aqoro, meaning Aln~aqoru biA@loxayoli [The smacking with the tongue to urge the horses]: pausing after the word, at the end of a hemistich, he transfers the vowel of the r to the q, (S, K,) agreeably with the dial. of certain of the Arabs, (TA,) that the hearer may know it to be the vowel of the [final] letter when there is no pause; (S;) like as you say, h`*aA bakoru and mararotu bibakiro: but this is not done when the word is in the accus. case (S, K:) and if you choose, you may make the final letter quiescent in pausing, though it is preceded by a quiescent letter. (S.) ― -b9- Hence also, faA_i*aA nuqira fiY Aln~aAquwri [Kur, lxxiv. 8,] (tropical:) For when the horn shall be blown: (S, * A, * Bd, K:) from naqorN signifying (tropical:) the making a sound: originally, striking, which is the cause of sound. (Bd.) See also naAquwrN, below. ― -b10- Also, naqara He bored, perforated, or made a hole through or in or into, a thing: (TA:) or he did so with a minoqaAr: (S:) and, inf. n. naqorN, he hollowed out, or excavated, a piece of wood. (Mgh, Msb.) nuqirN and ↓ Ainotaqara, (so in some copies of the K,) or ↓ A^unotuqira, (so in other copies of the K and in the TA,) both in the pass. form, (TA,) said of stone and of wood and the like, signify alike, (K,) It was bored, or perforated, or it had a hole made through or in or into it: (TA:) [and it was hollowed out.] You say, naqara AlbayoDapa Eani Alfaroxi, (K,) aor.
naqura , inf. n. naqorN, (TA.) He made a hole in the egg [so as to disclose the young bird]. (K.) And naqarat Alxayolu, (A,) and bHwAfrhA nuqarFA ↓ Antqrt, (Lth, K,) The horses made hollows in the ground with their hoofs. (Lth, A, K.) And in like manner, ↓ Antqrt Als~uyuwlu nuqarFA The torrents left hollows in the ground, in which water was retained. (TA.) ― -b11- Hence, naqara Eani AlA^amori; (Msb;) and Eanohu ↓ nq~r, (S, K,) inf. n. tanoqiyrN; (S;) and ↓ nq~rhu; and ↓ tnq~rhu: and ↓ Antqrhu; (K;) (tropical:) He searched or inquired into the thing; investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and endeavoured to know it: (TA;) and so naqara Eani lxabari (tropical:) he investigated the news, and endeavoured to know it. (A.) [And hence,] Als~ahoma bayona A_iSobaEayohi ↓ nq~r. (K, in art. Hn,) or EalaY AlA_ibohaAmi, inf. n. tanoqiyrN, (K, in art. dwm,) [He tried the sonorific quality of the arrow by turning it round between his fingers, or upon his thumb: see Han~aAnN, and dar~a Als~ahomu, and see also 4, in art. dwm: or] nq~r Als~ahoma signifies he made the arrow to produce a sharp sound [by turning it round between his fingers, or] upon his thumb. (TK, in art. dwm.)
2 naq~ara see 1, last two sentences.

4 A^anoqara see 1, in three places, in the first half. -A2- Anqr Eanohu, (S, K,) inf. n. A_inofaArN, (TA,) He refrained, forbore, abstained, or desisted, from it or him; he left or relinquished, it or him. (S, * K.) Hence the saying, Darabahu famaA A^anoqara Eanohu Hat~aY qatalahu He beat him and left him not until be killed him. (TA.) And hence the saying of I'Ab, maAkaAna A@ll~`hu liyunoqira Eano qaAtili A@lomuw^omini, i. e., God will not leave the slayer of the believer until He destroy him (S, TA.)
5 tanaq~ara see 1, last signification
8 A_inotaqara see 1, latter part, in four places.

naqorN * (tropical:) A slight sound that is heard in consequence of striking the thumb against the middle finger [and then letting them fly apart in opposite directions, passing each other]: (S, K:) [or the snapping with the fingers or with the thumb and middle finger, or with the thumb and first finger; as also ↓ naqyrN: n. an. of the former with p.] One says, maA A^avaAbahu naqorapN (tropical:) [He did not reward him with even a snap of the fingers;] meaning, with anything: (S, K [in the former of which it is implied that nqrp thus used is from naqorN in the first of the senses explained above;]) not used thus save in [a negative phrase. (S.) A poet says,
wahun~ HaraY A^al~aA yuvibonaka nqorapN
waA^anota HaruY biAln~aAr Hiyna tuviybu
(tropical:) [And they are fit, or worthy, not to reward thee with anything, and thou art fit for, or worthy of, the fire of hell when thou rewardest]. (S.) Or the right reading in both these instances is ↓ nuqorapF, with damm. (TA.) [See nuqorapN.] One says also, lamo yakotarito liY biqadur naqorap A_iSobaEK (tropical:) [He did not care for me so much as a snap of a finger]. (A.) [See also an (??) in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. $A^w.] I'Ab, in explanation of the words of the Kur, [iv. 123,] walaA yuZolamuwna naqiyrFA, put the end of the thumb against the inner side of his first finger, then made a snapping with it (vum~a naqarahaA), and said, This is what is termed ↓ naqiyrN; [denoting the lit. meaning to be (tropical:) And they shall not be wronged a snap of the fingers.] (TA.) But see nuqorapN, below. ― -b2- Also, A sound, or slight sound, by which a horse is put in motion: (TS, K:) as also ↓ naqiyrN: (TA:) or the former has one or other of the different significations assigned to it above, in the explanations under the head of naqara biAld~aAb~api. (K, &c.)
niqorN * : see nuqorapN.
naqorapN * : see naqorN, in four places.

nuqorapN *
A small hollow or cavity in the ground: (S:) or a hollow or cavity in the ground, not large: (Msb:) or a hollow or cavity in the ground in which water stagnates: (TA:) or a round wahodap [or hollow] in the ground, (K, TA,) not large, in which water stagnates: (TA:) pl. nuqarN (A, K) and niqaArN: (K:) ↓ naqiyrN also signifies a hollow, or cavity, in the ground; and its pl. is A^anoqirapN. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (S.) The place where the qamaHoduwap [or occiput] ends, in the back part of the neck; (K;) i. e., the hollow in the back of the neck; (TA;) what is called nuqorapu AlqafaA; (S, A, Msb;) i. e., the hollow where (??) brain ends: the cupping in that part occasions forgetfulness: (Msb.) [and any similar hollow as the pit of the stomach: and a dimple: accord. to present usage; and in this sense it is used in the A, K, and TA, voce faHoSapN ― -b3- The cavity, or socket, of the eye. (K.) ― -b4- Foramen and; syn. vaqobu AlAisoti: (K:) but in the (??) it is said that nuqorapu Alwariki signifies the hole, or perforation, that is the middle of the haunch; [app. meaning the sacro-ischiatic foramen: see AlfaAy^ilu, in art. fyl: but perhaps it may sometimes mean the socket of the thigh-bone; for nuqorpN signifies any socket of a bone.] (TA.) ― -b5- The little spot [or embryo] upon the back of a date stone, (AHeyth, K,) which is as though it were hollowed. (TA,) and from which the palm-tree grows forth: (AHeyth;) as also ↓ naqyrN (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ niqorN (K) and ↓ A^unoquwrN. (Sgh, K) You say, maA A^avaAbahu nuqorapN, (El-Basáir, TA,) and ↓ naqiyrFA, (A,) lit., [He did not reward hour] (??) even a little spot on the back of a date-stone; (A, El-Basáïr;) meaning, (tropical:) with the meanest thing. (El Basáïr.) In the S and K, mA AvAbh naqorapN: see naqorN.] And maA A^aEonaY Ean~iY nuqorapN (tropical:) He did not stand me in stead of the meanest (??) (A.) Lebeed says, bewailing the death of his brother Arbad.
↓ walayosa Aln~aAsu baEodaka fiY naqiyrK
lit., [And the people, after thee, are not worth] a little spot on the back of a date-stone; meaning, labosuwA baEodaka fiY $aYo'K (tropical:) [after thee they are not worth anything]. (S.) And hence, accord. to ISk [and the Jel], the saying in the Kur, [iv. 123.] walaA yuZolamuwna naqiyrFA [And they shall not be wronged even as to a little spot on the back of a date-stone.] (TA.) Hence also, [in verse 56 of the same chap.,] laA yuw^otuwna Aln~aAsa naqiyrFA (tropical:) They would not give men a thing as inconsiderable as the little hollow in the back of a date-stone. (Jel.) See also naqorN. ― -b6- The place in which a bird lays its eggs: (K:) pl. nuqarN. (TA.)

naqiyrN * : see naqorN, in three places. -A2- What is bored, or perforated; and what is hollowed out, or excavated; (maA nuqiba, TA, and maA nuqira, K, TA;) of stone, and of wood, and the like. (K, TA.) ― -b2- A piece of wood, (Msb,) or a block of wood, (A^aSolu xa$abapK, S, K,) or a stump, or the lower part, (A^aSol,) of a palm-tree, (T,)
which is hollowed out, and in which the beverage called nabiy* is made; (T, S, Msb, K;) the nby* whereof becomes strong: (S, K:) or a stump, or the lower part, (ASl,) of a palm-tree, which it was a custom of the people of El-Yemámeh to hollow out, then they crushed in it ripe dates and unripe dates, which [with water poured upon them] they left until fermentation had taken place therein and subsided: (A 'Obeyd:) or a stump, or the lower part, (ASl,) of a palm-tree, whereof the middle was hollowed out, then dates were put in them, with water, which became intoxicating nby*: (IAth:) the word is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., that Mohammad forbade Aln~aqiyr, (S, * Msb, * TA,) meaning, the nby* thereof. (TA.) ― -b3- A trunk of a palm-tree, hollowed out, and having the like of steps made in it, by which one ascends to gurf [or upper chambers]. (K. [See also EajalapN.]) ― -b4- See also nuqorapN, throughout.

nuqaArapN * The quantity [of grain] which a bird pecks, or picks up. (K.) See 8, in art. qb. ― -b2- What remains from the boring, or excavating, (naqor,) of stones: like nujaArapN and nuHaAtapN. (TA.)

naq~aArN *
An engraver: or, accord. to Az, one who engraves stirrups and bits and the like: and one who bores (yanoquru) mill-stones. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) One who investigates, scrutinizes, or examines, and endeavours to know, affairs, and news. (TA.)

nAaqirN * act. part. n. of naqara. ― -b2- (tropical:) An arrow that hits, (Msb,) or has hit, (S, A, K,) the butt, (S, K,) or the eye of the target: (A:) if it do not hit the butt it is not so called: (S, TA:) [but see a phrase following:] pl. nawaAqiru. (A, Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence,] A^axoTaA^ato nawaAqiruhu (tropical:) [lit., His arrows that were wont to hit the butt missed]; meaning, he did not continue in the right course. (TA.) [And hence,] naAqirapN (tropical:) A calamity; (K, TA;) pl. nawaAqiru. (TA.) One says, ramaAhu Ald~ahoru binaAqirapK, and binawaAqira, (tropical:) Fortune smote him with a calamity, and with calamities. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, naAqirapN (tropical:) A right argument, allegation, evidence, or the like; syn. Huj~apN muSiybapN: in the K, a w is incorrectly inserted between these two words: but the pl., nawaAqiru, is afterwards correctly rendered in the K. (TA.) One says, A^atatoniY Eanohu nawaAqiru (tropical:) There came to me, from him, speech which displeased me, or grieved me: or right arguments, or the like, (K, TA,) like arrows hitting the mark. (TA.) In the L, ramaAhu binawaAqira (tropical:) He cast at him words that hit the mark. (TA.)

naAquwrN * (tropical:) A horn in which one blows; syn. SuwrN: (S, K:) in the Kur, lxxiv. 8, the horn in which the angel shall blow for the congregating at the resurrection: the blast there mentioned is said to be the second blast: Fr. says that it is the first of the two blasts. (TA.)
A^uinoquwrN * : see nuqorapN.
minoqarN * : see minoqaArN.
munaq~aru AlEayoni * , (K,) and ↓ munotaqaruhaA, (Sgh, K,) or ↓ munotaqiruhaA, (CK,) Having the eye sunken. (K.)

minoqaArN * The beak of a bird; that which is to a bird as the mouth to a man; (Msb;) because it pecks, or picks up, with it: (TA:) or of a bird which is not one of prey; that of a bird of prey being called minosarN: (Fs, and S in art. nsr, and MF:) therefore the explanation in the K, which is, the minosar of a bird, is incorrect: (MF:) [and the dual signifies the two mandibles of a bird; used in this sense in the TA, art. Sgw:] pl. manaAqiyru. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) The fore part of the xuf~ [app. meaning the foot of a camel, not a boot]. (K.) ― -b3- [A kind of pickaxe; or a pick, by which a mill-stone, or the like, is pecked, or wrought into shape, and roughened in its surface; (see 1;)] an iron instrument like the faA^os, (A, K,) slender, round, and having a xalof [or pointed head], (TA,) with which one pecks, (yunoqarubihaA, A, K, TA,) and cuts stones, and hard earth; (TA;) used [also] by a carpenter: (S:) and ↓ minoqarN signifies [app. the same, or nearly the same,] i. q. miEowalN: (S, K:) [the former is applied in the present day to a chisel:] pl. of the former, manaAqiyru; (S;) and of the latter, manaAqiru. (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
kaA^aroHaA='i raqodK zal~amatohaA AlmanaAqiru
[Like mill-stones of Rakd (a mountain so called) which the minkars have rounded]. (TA.) See zal~ama.
munotaqaru AlEayoni * , or munotaqiruhaA: see munaq~ar.

niqorisN * [Arthritis, or gout: or, specially, podagra, or gout in the foot or feet:] a certain disease, well known; (S, Msb;) a swelling and pain in the joints: (Az, TA:) or in the leg or foot: (TA:) or in the joints of the ankles and the toes: (K:) or a swelling in the joints of the foot, and mostly in the great toe, a property of which is that it does not collect thick purulent matter, nor exude moisture, because it is in a member not fleshy: and of the same kind are arthritis, or pain of the joints, (wajaEu AlmafaASili,) and sciatica, or hip-gout, (Eiroqu Aln~asaA,) but differing in name because differing in state. (Msb.)

1 naqaza * , (S, A,) aor.
naquza , (S, TA,) and
naqiza , (TA,) inf. n. naqozN and naqazaAnN (S, K,) and nuqaAzN, (TA,) He (an antelope, S and A) leaped, jumped, sprang, or bounded, (S, A, K,) as also ↓ nq~z, (M, TA,) in his running, (S,) or on his nawaAqiz, i. e., his legs: (A:) or he (generally referring to a raven or crow, or a sparrow, or locust, or the like,) leaped, jumped, sprang, or bounded, upwards; he hopped: (TA:) or he put his legs together in leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding: when the legs are spread, the action is termed nafozN. (IDrd, TA.)
2 naq~aza see 1. -A2- Also, inf. n. tanoqiyzN, He made to leap, jump, spring, or bound: (S:) and nq~zt she (a woman) danced, or dandled, her child; (K, * TA;) as also nf~zt. (S, &c., art. nfz.)
nawaAqizu * , [pl. of naAqizapN,] The legs of an antelope, (A,) or of a beast of carriage. (K.) See also naAfizapN.

1 naqasa *
It (a naAquws) sounded. (TA.) -A2- naqasa, (S, A, Msb,) or naqasa Aln~aAquwsa, (Mgh, K,) aor.
naqusa , inf. n. naqosN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He struck, or beat, the nAqws, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) biAlowayiyli with the wbyl. (Mgh, K.) You say, naqasati Aln~aSaAraY and ↓ Antqst The Christians struck, or beat the nAqws. (A.) It is said in a trad., that the Muslims were near to doing so, (kaAduwA yanoqusuwna, S, TA,) or used to do so, (kaAnuwA yanoqusuwna, Mgh,) until 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Zeyd dreamed of the [mode of calling to prayer termed] A^a*aAn. (S, Mgh, TA.)
2 nq~s dawaAtahu * , inf. n. tanoqiysN, He put ink (niqos) into his receptacle for ink. (S, * K.)
8 A_inotaqasa see 1.

niqosN *
Ink; syn. midaAdN [which is a more common term]; (A, K;) that with which one writes: (S, TA:) pl. A^anoqusN (S, K) and A^anoqaAsN. (S, A, K.)

naAqwusN * The thing which the Christians strike, or beat, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) to notify the times of prayer, (S, A, Mgh, K,) as a sign for commencing their prayer; (Msb;) being a piece of wood, long, (A, Mgh, K,) and large (K,) [suspended to two cords, (Golius,)] with another which is short, [with which the former is struck, or beaten,] and which is called wabiylN: (A, K:) pl. nawaAqiysu (S, TA) and nuqusN, as though the A in the sing. were imagined to be suppressed in forming the latter pl. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, in the present day, applied to A bell: and particularly to the bell of a church or convent.]

1 naqa$a * , (S, M, Msb,) aor.
naqu$a , (M, Msb,) inf. n. naqo$N. (S, M, A, Msb, K,) He variegated a thing; or decorated or embellished it; syn. namonama; as also ↓ Antq$: (M:) [he charactered in any manner a coin &c.:] and he engraved, agreeably with modern usage: he coloured a thing with two colours, (K,) or with colours; (A, K;) and ↓ nq~$, (S,) inf. n. tanoqiy$u, (S, K,) signifies the same. (S, K.) ― -b2- naqa$a fY xaAtamihi ka*aA, and EalaY faS~i xaAtamihi, (A,) inf. n. as above, (K,) [He engraved upon his signet-ring such a thing, and upon the stone of his signet-ring: and naqa$a also signifies he marked with a cutting or a pointed instrument: he sculptured a thing in any manner.] ― -b3- naqa$a Alr~aHaA (tropical:) He pecked the mill-stone with a minoqaAr; syn. naqarahaA. (A, TA.) ― -b4- naqa$a, inf. n. as above, also signifies He, or it, scratched, lacerated, or wounded in the outer skin. (TA.) They said, kaA^an~a wajohahu nuqi$a biqataAdapK [As though his face were scratched, or lacerated, by a tragacanth-bush]; syn. xudi$a: relating to hatefulness, and austerity or moroseness of countenance, (M, TA,) and anger. (M.) ― -b5- naqo$u AlEi*oqi signifies The striking the raceme of dates with thorns, in order that the dates may ripen: (S, K:) or and their consequently ripening. (AA.) And one says, nuqi$a AlEi*oqu, meaning, The raceme of dates had specks apparent in it, in consequence of ripening. (S.) ― -b6- And [hence, perhaps,] naqo$N is used as (tropical:) syn. with jimaAEN (S, A, Sgh, K,) accord. to AA, (S,) or IAar; (Sgh;) naqa$a signifying (tropical:) Inivit puellam. (T, K.) [This signification is mentioned in the A among those which are proper; but in the TA it is said, to be tropical.] -A2- Also naqa$a, (S, M, A, Msb,) aor. as above, (M, TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, M, Msb, K,) He extracted, or drew, or pulled, out, or forth, a thorn (S, M, A, Msb, K) from his foot, (S, M,) with the minoqa$ or minoqaA$; (Msb, K; *) as also ↓ Antq$: (S, M, A, K:) thought by A 'Obeyd to be from AlmunaAqa$apu; but others say the reverse: (TA:) and in like manner, bones from a wound in the head: (S, K:) and he plucked out (S, A,) hair, (A,) with the minoqaA$; (S, A;) as also ↓ Antq$. (A.) A certain poet says, (namely, Yezeed Ibn-Maksam [?] EthThakafee, O in art. $wk,)
laA tanoqu$an~a birijoli gayorika $awokapF
fataqiY birijolika rijola mano qado $aAkahaA
[Do not thou by any means extract from the foot of another a thorn, and so preserve, by (risking) thy foot, the foot of him who has pierced himself therewith]: the [former] b is put in the place of Eano: he says, do not thou extract from the foot of another a thorn and put it in thy foot ?? (TA:) or mano $aAkahaA means who has entered among the thorns. (S and O, in art. $wk.) And it is said in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, Eavara falaA A@notaEa$a wa$iyka falaA A@notaqa$a [May he stumble, and not rise again; and may he be pierced with a thorn, and not extract the thorn]: (M, TA: *) the words meaning an imprecation. (TA.) See also 8, below. ― -b2- [Hence,] naqa$a, aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (K,) He cleared the nightly resting-place of sheep or goats from thorns and the like, (K,) or from what might hurt them, of stones and thorns and the like. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, naqa$a Eani Al$~aYo'i, (TK,) inf. n. as above, (IDrd, K,) He explored the thing to the utmost. (IDrd, K, TK.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] maA naqa$a minohu $ayoy^FA (assumed tropical:) He did not obtain from him anything: but the word commonly known is nata$a. (M, TA.) See also 8.
2 naq~a$a see 1, first sentence.

3 nAq$hu * , (Msb,) or nAq$hu AlHisaAba, (S, * M, A,) and fiY AlHisaAbi, (A,) inf. n. munaAqa$apN (S, M, Msb, K) and niqaA$N, (M, TA,) He did the utmost with him, or went to the utmost length with him, in reckoning, (S, M, Msb, K,) so as to omit nothing therein: (A 'Obeyd:) A 'Obeyd thinks that naqo$N signifying the “ extracting ” a thorn from the foot is from this; but others say the reverse; that the primary signification of munaAqa$apN is the extracting a thorn from the body with difficulty; and that it then became [conventionally regarded as] a proper term in the sense of doing the utmost, or going to the utmost length, in reckoning; as observed by MF. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mano nuwqi$a AlHisaAba Eud~iba, (S,) or halaka, (M,) He with whom the utmost is done in reckoning (S, M,) is punished, (S,) or perishes. (M.) See also 4. ― -b2- [Hence,] nAq$ AlkalaAma (assumed tropical:) He picked out the faults of the language; syn. naqadahu. (TA, art. nqd.)

4 Anq$ ElY gariymihi *
He went to the utmost length against his debtor. (IAar, K.) See also 3.
5 tanaq~a$a see 8, last signification.

8 Antq$ * : see 1, first signification. ― -b2- Also, (K,) or Antq$ EalaY faS~ihi, (Lth, A,) He ordered (Lth, A, K) the naq~aA$ [or engraver], (Lth, K,) to engrave upon the stone of his signet-ring. (Lth, A, K.) -A2- He extracted, or drew, or pulled, out, or forth, a thing; (K;) such as a thorn and the like: (TA:) syn. with naqa$a, as shewn above; see 1, in three places. (S, M, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] He (a camel) struck the ground (S, K) with his fore leg, (S,) or with his foot, (K,) on account of something entering into it; (S, K;) [i. e., to beat out a thorn or the like.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] (tropical:) He chose, or selected, a thing. (M, A, K.) You say, of a man who has chosen (A, L) a man, (A,) or a thing, (L,) for himself, jaAda maA A@notaqa$ahu linafosihi (tropical:) Good, or excellent, be that which he has chosen for himself: (A, L:) or, accord. to the O, when a man has chosen for himself a servant (xaAdimFA [which suggests that this may be a mistranscription for jaAda maA]) A_inotaqa$ota h`*aA linafosika [thou hast chosen this for thyself]. (TA.) [Hence also.] Antq$ minohu Haq~ahu (tropical:) [He took from him his right, or due]. (A.) And Antq$ jamiyEa Haq~ihi, and ↓ tnq~$hu, (tropical:) He took from him the whole of his right, or due, not leaving thereof anything. (M, TA.) See also 1, last signification.

naqo$N * [an inf. n. (see 1) used as a simple subst.: or in the sense of a pass. part. n. in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: Variegation; or variegated work: decoration, embellishment, a picture; or decorated, or embellished, or pictured, work: broidery: tracery: (significations well known: see naq~aA$N:)] engraved work upon a signet: [and any sculptured work:] pl. nuquw$N. (A.) Also The impress of a signet. (Mgh, in art. xtm.) And A mark, or trace, upon the ground; as, for instance, of ashes. (AHeyth.) -A2- See also manoquw$N.
nuqo$N * : see manoquw$N.

niqaA$apN * The art, or occupation, of the naq~aA$, (M, K, TA,) who does variegated, or decorated or embellished, work; (M;) of him who does what is termed naqo$: (TA:) [and of him who engraves upon signet-rings: and of him who does any sculptured work.]

naq~aA$N *
One who does variegated, or decorated or embellished, work; (M;) who does what is termed naqo$: (TA:) and one who engraves upon the stones of signet-rings: (Lth, K:) [and one who does any sculptured work.]
minoqa$N * : see minoqA$N.
munaq~a$N * : see manoquw$N, first sentence.
$aj~apN munaq~i$apN * : see manoquw$N, last signification.

minoqaA$N *
An instrument with which variegated, or decorated or embellished, work is done: pl. manaAqiy$u: (M:) [and an instrument with which engraving, or any sculptured work, is done: so in the present day.] ― -b2- Also, [A kind of tweezers;] an instrument with which one extracts, or draws or pulls out or forth, thorns; as also ↓ minoqa$N; (Msb, K;) [of which latter the pl. is manaAqi$u, occurring below:] and with which one plucks out (S, A) hair. (A.) [Hence the saying,] Aisotaxorajotu Haq~iY minohu biAlmanaAqi$i (tropical:) I wearied myself in extorting my right, or due, from him. (A.)

manoquw$N * A garment, or piece of cloth, (A,) or other thing, (TA,) [variegated; or decorated, or embellished: charactered in any manner, as a coin &c.: (see 1:)] coloured (A, TA) with two colours, (TA,) or with colours; (A, TA;) as also ↓ munaq~a$N. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [A signet-ring engraved: and anything sculptured. (See 1.)] ― -b3- Ei*oqN manoquw$N A raceme of dates struck with thorns, and consequently ripened: (AA:) [or having specks apparent in it, in consequence of ripening: (see nuqi$a AlEi*oqu:)] and busorN manoquw$N full-grown unripe dates pricked with thorns in order that they may ripen: (M, TA:) and ruTabN manoquw$N fresh ripe dates soaked with water; syn. rabiyTN: (Sgh, TA:) called by the vulgar mE*b [app. muEa*~abN]; (TA;) as also naqo$N. (K [accord. to some copies; and in the TA: accord. to other copies of the K, nuqo$N; but expressly said in the TA to be with fet-h.]) -A2- $aj~apN manoquw$apN A wound in the head from which bones are extracted: (S, K:) and $aj~apN ↓ munaq~i$apN a wound in the head from which bones are removed; (AA, El-Ghanawee, Aboo-Turáb;) i. q. munaq~ilapN. (K.)

laTamahu laToma Almunotaqi$i * , (S,) or laTomapa Almunotaqi$i, (K,) [He gave him a violent slap, like the slap of the camel striking the ground with his fore-leg, or with his foot, on account of something entering into it:] from A_inotaqa$a, said of a camel, as explained above. (S, K.)

1 naqaSa * , (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
naquSa , (M, Msb,) inf. n. nuqoSaAnN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and naqoSN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) or the former of these two only, the latter being the inf. n. of the trans. verb, (MS,) and naqiySapN (M) and tanoqaASN, (K,) [which last is an intensive form,] said of a thing, (S, M,) intrans., (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) It lost somewhat, decreased, diminished, lessened, wasted, waned, or became defective or deficient or incomplete or imperfect, after having been whole or complete or perfect: (IKtt, Msb, TA:) or he, or it, lost, or suffered loss or diminution, (A, K,) with respect to lot or portion: (K:) and ↓ AntqS signifies the same; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and so does ↓ tnq~S; (TK, [probably from the TA,] art. A^afn;) and so does ↓ tnAqS: (TA:) [or this last signifies it lost somewhat, decreased, &c., gradually; contr. of tzAyd.] It is said in a trad., (Mgh,) $ahoraA EiydK laA yanoquSaAni, (Mgh, K,) i. e. Ramadán and Dhu-l-Hijjeh, (Mgh,) meaning, Two months of festival are not defective virtually (fiY AlHukomi) though they be defective in number [of days]; (K;) i. e. let no doubt occur in your hearts when ye fast nine and twenty days [instead of thirty]; nor if there happen a mistake respecting the day of the pilgrimage, will there be any deficiency in your performance of the rites thereof: (TA:) or, as some say, two months of festival will not be defective in one and the same year; but Et- Taháwee disapproves of this explanation: some say that the meaning is, that though they be defective, or one of them be so, yet their recompense will be complete. (Mgh.) It is also said in a trad., A_in~a AlEamala fiY Ea$ori *iY AlHij~api laA yanoquSu vawaAbuhu Eam~aA fiY $ahori ramaDaAna [Verily the deed that is done on the tenth of Dhu-l-Hijjeh, the recompense thereof will not fall short of that which is in the month of Ramadán: for naqaSa Eano ka*aA means It fell short of such a thing.] (Mgh.) [On the expression fiY Aln~uqoSaAni, as used in grammar, see gafiyrN.] -A2- naqaSahu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
naquSa , (Msb,) inf. n. naqoSN, (MS,) [and accord. to the TK tanoqaASN and nuqoSaAnN also, which last, however, is said in the MS to be an inf. n. of the intrans. verb only,] He made it to lose somewhat, decreased it, diminished it, curtailed it, lessened it, wasted it, impaired it, took from it, or made it defective or deficient or incomplete or imperfect, after it had been whole or complete or perfect; (Msb;) he made it (i. e. a share, or portion) defective or deficient: (K:) [the pronoun often relates to a man: see an ex. in art. Dwz, and another in art. wks:] this is the [most] chaste form of the verb, and is that which occurs in the Kur.: (Msb:) ↓ AnqShu also signifies the same; (M, Msb, K;) and so does ↓ nq~Shu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. tanoqiySN: (TA:) but these two are of weak authority, and do not occur in chaste language: (Msb:) and ↓ AntqShu signifies the same: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or this last signifies he took from it by little and little; as also ↓ tnq~Shu. (M, * TA [in the latter of which this is plainly said of both of the last two verbs; but in the M, it seems rather to be said of tnq~Sh only.]) [See an ex. of the verb followed by mn voce TarafN. You say also, naqaSa minohu ka*aA He cut off from it such a thing.] ― -b2- naqaSa is doubly trans.: (Msb:) you say naqaSahu Haq~ahu, (A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) inf. n. naqoSN; (A, Mgh;) and in like manner, Haq~ahu ↓ AntqShu; (M, A, * Mgh, * TA; *) He diminished, or impaired, to him his right, or due; endamaged him; or made him to suffer loss, or damage, or detriment, in respect of it; curtailed him, abridged him, deprived him, or defrauded him, of a portion of it; (Msb, * TA;) contr. of A^awofaAhu: (TA:) [and he abridged him, deprived him, or defrauded him, of it altogether; for naqaSahu A^aholahu wamaAlahu signifies sometimes He deprived him of his family and his property altogether: as appears from the following ex.:] nuqiSa A^aholahu wamaAlahu wabaqiYa farodFA [He was deprived of his family and his property, and remained alone]. (T, art. wtr.) AlHaq~i ↓ AinotiqaASu also signifies The denying, or disacknowledging, the right, or due. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 5.
2 naq~aSa see naqaSahu.
4 A^anoqaSa see naqaSahu.

5 tnq~S * : see naqaSa. -A2- tnq~Shu: see naqaSahu. ― -b2- He attributed to him defect, or imperfection; i. e. to a man; (M;) as also ↓ AntqShu, and ↓ AstnqShu: (M, TA:) he attributed or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, fault, or the like; detracted from his reputation; censured him; reproached him; spoke against him; impugned his character; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ AntqShu: (A:) [and naqaSahu signifies the same; for] IKtt says, that ↓ nqS [app. nuqiSa], inf. n. naqiySapN, signifies TEn Elyh [app. TuEina Ealayohi]. (TA.)
6 tanaAoqaSa see naqaSa, where two meanings are assigned to it.
8 AntqS * : see naqaSa. -A2- AntqShu: see naqaSahu, in four places. ― -b2- See also 5, in two places.

10 AstnqS Alv~amana *
He (the buyer, S) asked, demanded, or desired, a diminution, a lessening, a lowering, or an abatement, of the price. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- See also 5.

naqoSN * : see 1. ― -b2- [Used as a subst., Loss, or loss of somewhat, decrease, a state of diminution or lessening or washing or waning, defect, defectiveness, deficiency, incompleteness, or imperfection, after wholeness or completeness, or perfectness; as also ↓ nuqoSaAnN; and ↓ manoqaSapN signifies the same as naqoS] as here rendered, agreeably with the explanation (i. e. of mnqSp) in the PS., which is kamiYo: or, accord. to the A, manoqaSapN seems to be syn. with naqiySapN in the sense assigned to this last in the S, or in certain senses assigned to it in the K, which see below; and thus to be more restricted in application than naqoSN]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Weakness of intellect: (M, TA:) and weakness with respect to religion and intellect. (TA.) You say, daxala Ealayohi naqoSN fiY diynihi waEaqolihi [There came upon him a weakness in his religion and his intellect]: but one should not say ↓ nuqoSaAnN [in this case]: (K:) app. because Aln~aqoS is “ weakness; ” whereas Aln~uqoSaAnu is only “ a going away [of part of a thing] after [its having been in] a state of completeness. ” (TA.)

nuqoSaAnN * : see 1: ― -b2- see also naqoSN, in two places. ― -b3- It also signifies The quantity that is gone, or lost, of a thing that is decreased or diminished or lessened. (Lth, A, K.) You say, nuqoSaAnuhu ka*aA waka*aA The quantity that is gone, or lost, of it is such and such. (TK.)

naqiySapN * : see 1. ― -b2- A defect, an imperfection, a fault, a vice, or the like; syn. EayobN: (S, TA:)
or a low, or base, quality, property, natural disposition, practice, habit, or action; (K, TA;) of a man: (TA:) or a weak quality, &c.: (IDrd, K, TA:) but the attribution of weakness to a quality, &c., requires consideration: and it seems that what is meant by lowness, or baseness, is what leads to naqoS: (TA:) [↓ manoqaSapN, also, accord. to the A, seems to be syn. with naqiySapN in one or another of the senses explained above; but its primary signification is probably a cause of naqoS, like as that of maboxalapN is a cause of buxol, and that of majobanapN a cause of jubon: the pl. of naqiySapN is naqaAy^iSu: and that of manoqaSapN is manaAqiSu.] You say, maA fiyhi naqiySapN and ↓ manoqaSapN [There is not in him any defect, imperfection, fault, or vice, &c.]: and fulaAnN *uw naqaAy^iSa and manaAqiSa [Such a one has defects, &c.]. (A, TA.) -A2- As a subst. from tanaq~aSahu and AinotaqaSahu and AisotanoqaSahu, [or, accord. to IKtt, as an inf. n. from nuqiS, and therefore from naqaSahu also, (see 5,)] it signifies The attributing to a man defect, or imperfection: (M:) the attributing or imputing to men, charging them with, or accusing them of, vices, faults, or the like; censuring them; reproaching them; speaking against them; impugning their characters. (K.) A poet says,
falawo gayoru A^axowaAliY A^araAduwA naqiySatiY
jaEalotu lahumo fawoqa AlEaraAniyni miysamaA
[But if others than my maternal uncles had desired to attribute to me defect, &c., I had set a brand upon them above the noses]. (M, TA.)

naAqiSN * act. part. n. of 1. ― -b2- dirohamN naAqiDN signifies A dirhem deficient in weight; (Msb;) light and deficient: and nuq~aSN occurs as pl. of nAqS thus applied, agreeably with analogy. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [Hence, fiEolN naAqiSN meaning An incomplete, i. e. a non-attributive, verb: opposed to fiEolN taAm~N.]
manoqaSapN * : pl. manaAqiSu: see naqiySapN, in four places: ― -b2- and see also naqoSN.
manoquwSN * pass. part. n. of naqaSahu. (A, K.)

1 naqaDahu * , (M, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
naquDa , (M, Msb, TA,) inf. n. naqoDN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) He undid it; took it; or pulled it, to pieces: untwisted it: unravelled it: unwove it: dissolved it: broke it: or rendered it uncompact, unsound, or unfirm,: after having made it compact, sound, or firm: (JK, M, A, Msb, K, TA:) namely a building, or structure: and a rope, or cord: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA:) and silk, or flax: (TA:) and cloth: (L:) and (tropical:) a compact, contract, or covenant; (S, A, Msb, K, TA;) and (assumed tropical:) a sale: (Mgh:) and (assumed tropical:) other things; (A, K, TA;) such as (assumed tropical:) an affair, or a case; and (assumed tropical:) the state of a place through which the invasion of an enemy is feared: (TA:) contr. of A^aboramahu, (M, A, K, TA,) as relating to a building or structure, and to a rope or cord, (A, K, TA,) and to a compact or contract or covenant, &c.: (K, TA:) or i. q. Hal~a baromahu, as relating to a rope or cord, and to a compact or contract or covenant: (Msb:) or i. q. hadamahu, as relating to a building or structure: (TA:) or the inf. n. signifies A_ifosaAdu maA A^aboramota, as relating to a building or structure. (JK, TA,) and to a rope or cord, (JK,) and to a compact or contract or covenant. (TA.) [It is said in the K, that Aln~aqoDu is the contr. of AlA_iboraAmu, like AlA_inotqaADu and Alt~anaAquDu: but this is a glaring mistake; and seems to be a corruption of the following passage in the M: Aln~aqoDu Did~u AlA_iboraAmi naqaDahu yanoquDuhu naqoDFA waA@notaqaDa watanaAqaDa, which is meant indicate that AntqD and tnAqD are quasi-passives of naqaDahu: and in like manner, the passage in the A, Aln~aqoDu fiY AlbinaA='i waAlHaboli wagayorihi Did~u AlA_iboraAmi waA@notaqaDa wanataq~aDa, indicates that AntqD and tnq~D are quasi-passives of naqaDahu. Further. it should be observed that naqaDahu, as relating to a building, is not well explained by hadamahu; for you say, naqaDa AlbinaA='a mino gayori hadomK, (mentioned in the S and A, &c., in art. qwD,) meaning He took to pieces the building without demolishing, or destroying.] ― -b2- [Hence,] naqaSa fulaAnN watarahu [lit. Such a one undid, or untwisted, his bow-string]; meaning (tropical:) such a one took, or had taken, his blood-revenge. (A, TA.) And Ald~ahoru *uw naqoDK waA_imoraArK [lit. Time, or fortune, has a property of untwisting and twisting tightly]; meaning (tropical:) that which time, or fortune, [as it were] twists tightly, [or makes firm.] it, at another time, [as it were] untwists, or undoes. (TA.) And naqaDotu maA A^aboramahu (tropical:) I annulled [what he confirmed, or made firm]. (Msb.) And yanoquDu Ealayohi (tropical:) [He undoes, or annuls, or contradicts, what he (another) has said]; said of a poet replying to another poet. (Lth, A, K.) ― -b3- nqD Alsqf, [i. e., app., naqoDu Als~aqofi,] also signifies tHryk x$bh [i. e. taHoriyku xa$abihi, The moving, or shaking, of the pieces of wood, or rafters, of the roof]. (TA. [But perhaps the phrase to be explained is Als~aqofu ↓ naq~aDa, and the explanation, correctly, taHar~aka xa$abuhu, i. e. The pieces of wood, or rafters, of the roof moved, or shook, (for this, I am informed, is agreeable with modern usage,) app. so as to produce a sound: see also 5.]) -A2- See also 4.
2 naq~aDa see 4, in two places: ― -b2- and 5; and see 1, next before the last break.

3 AlmunaAqaDapu fiY Alqawoli * is (tropical:) The saying that which is contradictory in its meaning [or meanings; as though one of its meanings undid, or annulled, the other]: (S, * K, TA:) from naqoDu AlbinaA='i: and meaning (tropical:) the contending with another in words, [or in contradiction,] each rebutting what the other said. (TA.) You say, nAqDhu fiY Al$~aYo'i, inf. n. munaAqaDapN and niqaADN, (tropical:) He contradicted him in, or respecting, the thing. (M, TA. *) And qulotu lahu niqaADFA (tropical:) I contradicted him with respect to his saying, and his satirizing of me. (M, TA.) And nAqD A^aHadu Al$~aAEirayoni AlA^axara (tropical:) [One of the two poets contradicted the other]. (A.) And nAqD qawoluhu Alv~aAniY AlA=w~ala (tropical:) [His second saying contradicted the first]. (A, TA.) And nAqD A=xiru qawolihi AlA^aw~ala (tropical:) [The last part of his saying contradicted the first]. (Mgh.) [See also 6.]

4 AnqD AlkamoA^apa * , (M, K, TA.) and AnqD EanohaA. (M, TA,) He removed the crust of earth from over the truffles: (M:) or he extracted, or took forth, the truffles from the earth. (K, TA.) -A2- AnqD Alkamo'u The crusts of earth ??? up (taqalofaEato) from over the truffle; as also ↓ naq~aDa. (M, TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- AnqDt AlA^aroDu The earth showed [or put forth] its plants, or herbage. (M, TA.) -A3- AnqD also signifies It produced, made, gave, emitted, or uttered, a sound, noise, voice, or cry: (S, M, K, TA:) and [particularly] a slight sound like what is termed naqorN: (S, TA:) said of a joint of a man, (M, K,) and of the fingers [when their joints are made to crack], and of the ribs, (A,) [see also 5,] and of a camel's saddle, (A, TA.,) and of a cupping-instrument when the cupper sucks it, (TA,) [&c., (see naqiyDN,)] and of an eagle, (S, M, K,) and of a hen (S, A) on the occasion of her laying eggs, (A,) and of a chicken, (M, A, K,) and of an ostrich, and of a quail, and of a hawk, and of a scorpion, and of a frog, and of the [kind of lizard called] wazag, and of the wabor [or Syrian hyrax], (M, K,) and of a young camel, the sounds of which are denoted by A_inoqaADN and katiytN, as those of a camel advanced in age are by qaroqarapN and hadiyrN: (S:) or A_inoqaADN relates to animate things; and ↓ naqoDN, inf. n. of naqDa, aor.
naquDa and
naqiDa , to inanimate things. (M, K.) [Accord. to the A, whether said of animate things or of inanimate, it is proper, not tropical, but accord. to what is said in the TA voce naqiyD, it is properly said of animate things, and tropically of inanimate; though, if any such distinction exist, the reverse seems to me to be more probable.] ― -b2- You say also, AnqD biAld~aAb~api, (K,) or biAloHimaAri. (Lth,) or, as As says, (M, TA,) biAlEayori, (M,) or biAlbaEiyri, (TA,) and biAlfarasi, (M, TA,) He made a sound to the beast of carriage, (M, K,) or to the ass, (Lth, As, M,) or to the camel, (As, TA,) and to
the horse, (As, M, TA,) at the two sides of his tongue, after making it cleave to the roof of his mouth, (Lth, M, K, TA,) without removing its extremity from its place, (Lth, TA,) in order to chide the beast: (L:) or AnqD bihi signifies i. q. naqara bihi [q. v.]; (As, M, A, TA;) the object being a [camel such as is called] qaEuwd; (A;) or whatever be the object. (As, M, TA.) And AnqD biAlomaEozi, (S, Sgh, K,) or biAlEanozi, (M, A,) He called the goats, (S, Sgh, K,) or the she-goat; (M, A;) accord. to AZ, (S, Sgh,) or Ks. (M, L.) And AnqD bihi He made a sound to him like as when thou makest a smacking with the tongue to a sheep or goat, [in the TA, kmA tnqr Al$Ap, for which I read kamaA tanoquru biAl$~aApi,] deeming him ignorant. (TA.) And He made a clapping to him with one of his hands upon the other, so as to cause a [sound such as is termed] naqiyD to be heard. (El-Khattábee.) -A4- AnqD A^aSaAbiEahu (M, A, K) He made a sound, or sounds, [app. a cracking of the joints,] with his fingers: (M:) [and so ↓ naq~aDahaA, inf. n. tanoqiyDN: (see faroqaEa:)] or he struck with his fingers in order that they might make a sound, or sounds: (K:) if it mean cracking of the joints (faroqaEap), it is disapproved; but if clapping, it is not. (TA.) And AnqD AlEiloka He caused the [kind of gum called] Elk to make a sound, or sounds; [i. e., in chewing it, as many women do;] the doing of which is disapproved. (S, L, K. [But in the S and L, it said that A_inoqaADu AlEiloka signifies taSowiytuhu, which does not necessarily indicate that the former verb is transitive.]) ― -b2- Hence, (S, M, TA,) AnqD AlHimolu Zahorahu (S, M, A, Msb, K *) The load made his back to sound by reason of its weight: (M:) or pressed heavily upon him, (S, M, Msb, K,) so that his back was heard to make a sound such as is termed naqiyD; (M, K; * i. e. the sound of the camel's saddle when it becomes infirm by reason of the weight of the load; (Bd, xciv. 3;) or a slight sound, as when a man makes a smacking with his tongue (yunoqiDu) to his ass, in driving him: (TA:) or oppressed his back by its weight: (Msb:) or rendered him lean, or emaciated; jaEalahu niqoDFA, i. e. mahozuwlFA. (Ibn- 'Arafeh, K.) Thus in the phrase Al~a*iY A^anoqaDa Zahoraka, (S, M, K,) in [xciv. 3, of] the Kur. (S, M.)

5 tnq~D * : see 8. ― -b2- AlA^aroDu Eani AlkamoA^api The earth clave, or cracked, or burst, from over the truffles; (S, A, * TA;) syn. tafaT~arato. (S, TA.)
