In all the copies of the K, we find tnq~D Ald~amu, explained by taqaT~ara; [as though meaning The blood was made to drop, drip, or fall in drops;] but how likely is this to be a mistranscription. (TA.) [The right reading of the phrase is probably tnq~D Alkamo'u; and of the explanation, tafaT~ara; and if so, the phrase is like A^anoqaDa Alkamo'u, and naq~aDa, explained above: see 4, second sentence.] ― -b3- tnq~D Alaboytu The house, or chamber, became cleft, or cracked, in several places, so as to cause a sound to be heard (K, TA.) And tnq~D is also said of a building, [app. in the same sense,] like ↓ naq~aDa. (TA.) [See naq~aDa Als~aqofu, in 1, next before the last break.] You say also, tnq~Dt EiZaAmuhu (tropical:) His bones made a sound [app. in being broken]. (IF, K, TA.) [See also 4.]

6 tnAqD * : see 8. ― -b2- tanaAquDN also signifies (tropical:) Mutual contradiction, or repugnancy; contr. of tawaAfuqN. (O, TA.) You say, fiY kalaAmihi tanaAquDN (A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) (tropical:) [In his speech is contradiction, or repugnancy, between different parts;] one part of his speech necessarily implies the annulment of another part; (Msb;) his second saying contradicted (naAqaDa) his first. (TA.) And tanaAqaDa AlqawolaAni, (A, Mgh,) or AlkalaAmaAni, (Msb,) (tropical:) The two saying, or sentences, contradicted each other; or were mutually repugnant; as though each undid the other; (Msb;) [they annulled each other.] And tnAqD Al$~aAEiraAni (tropical:) [The two poets contradicted each other.] (A, TA.) And tnAqD maEonaAhu (tropical:) Its meaning was contradictory. (S, * K, TA.) -A2- [It is also used transitively:] you say, tanaAqaDaA AlbayoEa (assumed tropical:) They two mutually dissolved the sale: as though compared with the saying taraA='awuA AlhilaAla, meaning “ they [together] saw the new moon; ” and tadaAEawuA Alqawoma, meaning “ they [together] called the people; ” and tasaA='aluwhumo, meaning “ they [together] asked them; ” notwithstanding that tnAqD is [properly] intransitive. (Mgh.) And tanaAqaDuwA Euhuwdahumo (assumed tropical:) [They mutually dissolved, or broke, their compacts, contracts, or covenants]. (T, voce tnAkvwA.)

8 AntqD * quasi-pass. of naqaDahu [It became undone; taken, or pulled to pieces: untwisted: unravelled: unwoven: dissolved; broken: or rendered uncompact, unsound, or infirm, after it had been made compact, sound, or firm]: (M, A, Mgh, Msb, TA:) as also ↓ tnq~D, (A,) and ↓ tnAqD: (M, TA:) [respecting the first and last, see a remark upon a mistake in the K, following the first sentence in 1: but AntqD afterwards occurs in the K used properly in the phrase maA A@notaqaDa mina AlbunoyaAni:] i. q. Ainotakva: (S:) said of a building, or structure: and of a rope, or cord: (A, Mgh, Msb, TA:) [and of silk, or flax: and of cloth: (see 1:)] and (tropical:) of a compact, contract, or covenant: (TA:) [and of a sale: (see 1:)] and (tropical:) of other things. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AntqDt AlqaroHapu (tropical:) The wound, or ulcer, became recrudescent. (IF, * A.) And AntqD AljuroHu baEoda buroy^ihi (assumed tropical:) The wound became in a bad, or corrupt, state, after its healing. (Msb.) And AntqD AlA^amoru baEoda A@lotiy^aAmihi (A, * Msb, TA) (tropical:) The affair, or case, became in a bad, or unsound state, after it had been in a sound state. (Msb.) And AntqD A^amoru Alv~agori baEoda sad~ihi (assumed tropical:) [The state of the place through which the invasion of an enemy was feared became unfortified, after its being fortified, or closed]. (TA.) And AntqDt AlT~ahaArapu (assumed tropical:) The state of purity became annulled. (Msb.) And AntqD Ealayohi Al$~iEoru (tropical:) [The poetry became undone, annulled, or contradicted, by a reply against him: see yanoquDu Ealayohi]. (A, TA.)

11 AnqAD~ *
It (a wall) cracked, without falling down; like A_inoqaD~a. (K in art. qD.) See also A_inoqaADa, in art. qyD.]
nuqoDN * : see niqoDN, in two places.

niqoDN *
i. q. ↓ manoquwDN [Undone; taken, or pulled, to pieces: untwisted: unravelled: unwoven: dissolved; broken: &c. (see 1:)] (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) like nikovN (S, TA) in the sense of manokuwvN: (TA:) as also ↓ nuqoDN; (Mgh, Msb;) and ↓ naqaDN: (Sgh:) but El-Ghooree allows only the first: (Mgh:) Az, however, mentions only the second; (Msb;) which signifies as above, applied to a building, or structure; (M, Mgh;) or what has become taken, or pulled, to pieces, (maA A@notaqaDa,) of a building, or structure; (K;) as also the first: (TA:) or naqoDN signifies maA naqaDota what thou hast undone; taken, or pulled, to pieces; untwisted; &c.]: (M:) and what is undone, of [the stuff of the tents called] A^axobiyap, and of [the garments called] A^akosiyap, and twisted a second time; (M, K;) as also ↓ naqaDN; (K;) and ↓ nuqaADapN: (L:) or this last signifies what is undone of a hair-rope: (S, O, K:) the pl. of niqoDN is A^anoqaADN [a pl. of pauc.], (M,) and of the same, (Msb,) or of ↓ nuqoDN, (Mgh, Msb,) nuquwDN. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Emaciated, or rendered lean, (S, M, K,) by travel; (S, K;) upon which one has journeyed time after time: (O:) Seer says, as though travel had unknit its frame; (M, TA;) thus indicating it to be tropical: (TA:) applied to a male camel, (S, M, K,) and to a horse, (M.) and to a female camel, (S, K,) or the female is termed niqoDapN: (M, K:) pl. A^anoqaADN, (Sb, S, K,) only, (Sb, M,) both of the masc. and fem.; in the latter, the p being imagined to be elided; (M;) and naqaAy^iDu is [also said to be] a pl. of niqoDN signifying jaded, applied to a she-camel. (So in a copy of the S in art. nfS.) ― -b3- [See an ex. in a verse cited voce sad~N.] ― -b4- The place, (S,) or crust of earth, (M, K,) that becomes broken from over truffles; (S, M, K;) for when they are about to come
forth, they break asunder the surface of the earth: (O:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anoqaADN and [of mult.] nuquwDN. (M, K.) ― -b5- Accord. to the K, i. q. nifoDN; but the latter is a mistranscription; (TA;) Honey that has in it [worms of the kind called] suws; wherefore it is taken, (M, K in art. nfD,) and pounded, (K, ubi supra,) and the place of the bees is smeared (yulaT~axu [in a copy of the M yuTobaxu, which is doubtless a mistranscription,]) therewith, together with myrtle (A=s) and the bees then come to it, and deposit their honey in it; (M, K, ubi supra;) on the authority of El-Hejeree: (M:) or the dung of bees in the place where they deposit their honey: (IAar, AHn, K, ubi supra:) or the bees that have died therein. (Sgh, K, ubi supra.) -A2- See also naqiyDN.
naqaDN * : see niqoDN, in two places.

naqiyDN * (tropical:) A contradictor: applied to a man: fem. with p. (M, TA.) You say [also], *aA nqyDu *aAka (tropical:) This is a contradictor [i. e. the contrary] of that: (A, TA:) [or this is inconsistent with that: for] Aln~aqiyDaAni laA yajotamiEaAni walaA yarotafiEaAni [what are termed nqyDAn cannot be coëxistent in the same thing, nor simultaneously nonexistent in the same thing]; as existence itself and nonexistence, and motion and rest. (Kull, pp. 231, 232) You say also, h`*ihi qaSiydapN naqiyDu qaSiydapi fulaAnK (tropical:) [This poem is a contradictor of the poem of such a one]. (A.) And Aln~aqiyDapu in poetry is (tropical:) That by which one undoes or annuls or contradicts [what another poet has said]: (S:) or naqiyDapu Al$~iEori consists in a poet's putting forth poetry, and another poet's undoing or annulling or contradicting it, by putting forth what is different therefrom: (Lth, K, * TA:) the subst is naqiyDN: [or rather this seems to be an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, and syn. with naqiyDapN:] and the act of the two is termed ↓ munaAqaDapN: the pl. of naqiyDapN is naqaAy^iDu: (TA:) you speak of the naqaAy^iD of Jereer and El-Farezdak. (A, TA.) -A2- A sound, noise, voice, or cry; (Lth, S, M, O, K:) as also ↓ niqoDN accord to the K; but this is an enormous error: (TA:) the former, of the joints (Lth, M, K) of a man, (M,) [a meaning also assigned to niqoDN in the K,] and of the fingers, and of the ribs, (Lth, M, A,) and of camels' saddles, (S, K,) or of a camel's saddle, (M, O, K, [but in CK, for Alr~aHol, we find Alr~ijol, the foot,]) and of camels' litters, (S, K,) and of tanned skins, (K,) or of a tanned skin, (M,) and of a bow-string, (M, K,) and of nisoE [q. v.] (O, K,) when new, (O,) and of the sucking of a cupping-instrument; (K;) [in all these senses said in the TA to be tropical; but see 4;] and also the former, (S, M, TA,) in the K, erroneously, the latter word, (TA,) of an eagle, (S, M, K,) and of chickens, and of an ostrich, and of a quail, and of a hawk, and of a scorpion, and of a frog, and of the [kind of lizard called] wazag, and of the wabor [or Syrian hyrax; &c., see 4] (M,)
nuqaADapN * : see niqoDN.
naqiyDapN * : see naqiyDN.
manoquwDN * : see niqoDN.
munaAqaDapN * : see naqiyaDN.

munotqiDN *
i. q. mutray~iEN, [Refraining.] see art. ryE.

1 naqaTa AlkitaAba * , (S, Msb,) or AlHarofa, (K,) aor.
naquTa , inf. n. naqoTN, (S, Msb,) He pointed, or dotted. [the book, or writing, or] the letter, or word, with the diacritical points or point; and with the syllabical points or point, by which are shown the pronunciation and division of syllables and the desinential syntax; syn. A^aEojamahu; as also ↓ nq~Thu: (K:) and AlmSaAHifa ↓ nq~T, inf. n. tanoqiyTN, [he so pointed the copies of the Kur-án.] (S.)

2 naq~aTa see 1, in two places. ― -b2- nf~T vawobahu biAlz~aEofaraAni waAlmidaAdi, inf. n. tanoqiyTN, [He made speaks, or small spots, upon his garment, with saffron, and ink;] (Lth;) and nq~T EalaY vawobihi [signifies the same]. (A, TA, in art. rqT.) And naq~aTati AlmaroA^apu wajohahaA waxad~ahaA biAls~awaAdi tataHas~anu bi*`lika [The woman made specks, or small spots, upon her face, with black, beautifying herself thereby]. (TA.)
5 tnq~T * [quasi-pass. of 2; It became pointed, &c. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) It (a place) became seattered with spots, or portions, of herbage. (K, TA.)
naqoTapN * inf. n. un. of 1, [A single act of pointing, &c.] (Msb.)

nuqoTapN *
A diacritical point of a letter or word: a syllabical point thereof: see 1:] (K:) [a point, dot, speck, speckle, or small spot: a mathematical point; i. e.] the extremity of a line: (TA:) pl. nuqaTN (S, Msb, K,) and niqaATN. (AZ, S, K.) Hence, one says, maA A@xotalafaA fY nuqoTapK They two did not differ respecting so small a thing as a point of a letter or word. (TA.) And [hence] the vulgar say, when they admire one, huwa nuqoTapN fiY muSoHafK (assumed tropical:) [He is like a point, or stop, in a copy of the Kur-án; because the stops in the Kur-án are generally ornamented, and often very beautifully, with gold and colours]. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) [Any very small thing, that may be likened to a point, dot, or speck. Hence,] 'Alee is related to have said, AlEilomu nuqoTapN A_in~amaA kat~arahaA AljaAhiluwna (assumed tropical:) [Science, or knowledge, is a very small thing: only the ignorant have made it to be much]. (TA.) And you say, A^aEoTaAhu nuqoTapF mino EasalK (tropical:) [He gave him a drop, or very small quantity, of honey]. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) [A portion of a thing, or some of a number of things, in a separate, or scattered, state, here and there] You say, maA baqiYa mino A^amowaAlihimo A_il~aA nuqoTapa (tropical:) There remained not of their possessions [aught] save some palm-trees and a portion of seed-produce here and there. (IAar, TA) And fiY AlA^aroDi niqaATN mina AlkalaA_i, and nuqaTN minohu. (tropical:) In the land are scattered spots, or portions, of herbage. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A thing: an affair; a matter: a case; an event; an action. (TA.)
nuqayoTapN * dim. of nuqoTapN. (TA.)

naq~aATN *
One who points copies of the Kur-án &c.; i. e. adds the diacritical and other points. (S, * TA.)
kitaAbN manoquwTN * (Msb, TA) A book, or writing, pointed with the diacritical, or other, points. (TA.)

div2.head: nqE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 nakaA^a AlqaroHapa * . (S, K,) inf. n. nako'N, (S,) He peeled off the scab from the sore (S, K,) before it was healed, and it became moist in consequence. (K.) [See also nakaY.] -A2- nakaA^a AlEaduw~a, and fiY AlEaduw~i, dial. form of nakaY [q. v.] (K.) By some rejected. (TA) -A3- nakaA^ahu Haq~ahu (like rakaA^hu, TA), inf. n. nako'N, He paid him his due. (K.) ― -b2- hun~iy^ta walaA tunokA^o, (S,) and tunoka, (TA,) and tunokhu (S, for tunoka or tunokA^o, TA), Mayest thou be made to have enjoyment in that which thou hast received, and not experience pain! (S) Mayest thou gain what is good, and may harm not befall thee! (T:) or, with the latter of the two verbs without
nakuAa (tnk), may God not make thee discomfited (AHeyth, L.) [Accord. to AHeyth. as mentioned in the TA, the latter verb in this proverb is written tanokaho and tunokaho; but the right reading is doubtless tunoka and tunokaho: this is shown by the explanation there following.]

8 AntkA^t AlqaroHapu *
The scab peeled off from the sore before it was healed, and it became moist in consequence. (A, TA.) -A2- AntkA^ minohu Haq~ahu (like AzdkA^, TA) He received from him his due. (K, TA.)
nukaA^apN * and zukaA^apN One who pays his debts, and does not put off. (K.) -A2- nakaA^apu AlT~urovuwvi, and nukaA^apu, dial. form of nakaEap [q. v.]. (K.)

1 nakaba Eanohu * , aor.
nakuba , inf. n. nukuwbN (S, K) and nakobN; and nakiba, aor.
nakaba , inf. n. nakabN: (M, L, K;)
and ↓ nk~b, (inf. n. tanokiybN, TA;) and ↓ tnk~b; (K;) He deviated, or turned aside, or away, from it, (K,) from the road, (S,) or from another thing. (TA.) [You say] AlT~ariyqa ↓ nk~bhu, (AlTryq being put in the accus. case, inf. n. tanokiybN, TA,) and [Eani AlTryqi] nk~b bihi, He deviated, or turned aside, or away, with him from the road; led him, or caused him to turn, aside, or away, from the road. (K.) ― -b2- [So] ↓ nk~bh, inf. n. tanokiybN, He turned aside, or away, from him, and separated himself from him. (S.) ― -b3- ↓ tnk~bh He went. or turned, aside, or away, or apart, from him; avoided him; went, or removed, to a distance, from him. (S.) ― -b4- Ean~aA ↓ tnk~b He turned aside, or away, from us. (TA.) ― -b5- nakaba Eano Tariyqi AlS~awaAbi, aor.
nakuba , inf. n. nukuwbN; and Eani ↓ nk~b AlSwAb; (assumed tropical:) He deviated from the right course of action &c. (Az.) ― -b6- nakabati Alr~iyHu, aor.
nakuba , inf. n. nukuwbN, The wind blew obliquely, in a direction between [the directions of] two [cardinal] winds. (K.) See nakobaA'u. -A2- nakaba, aor.
nakuba , inf. n. nakobN, He threw, cast, or flung. (K, TA.) ― -b2- nakaba bihi He threw him down (K) EalaY AlA^aroDi upon the ground. (TA.) ― -b3- nakabahu Ald~ahoru, aor.
nakuba , inf. n. nakobN and nakabN, (assumed tropical:) Fortune overcame him, or afflicted him: or smote him with an evil accident, a disaster, an affliction, or a calamity. (K.) ― -b4- nukiba (assumed tropical:) He was overcome, or afflicted, by fortune: or was smitten by fortune with an evil accident, a disaster, or the like. (S, TA.) See nakobapN. ― -b5- nakaba AlA_inaA'a, (aor.
nakuba , inf. n. nakobN, TA,) He [threw down, i. e.] poured out the contents of the vessel: (K:) but only said of what is not fluid; as dust and the like. (TA.) ― -b6- nakaba kinaAnatahu, inf. n. as above, He inverted, or inclined, his quiver, (S,) so as to pour out the arrows contained in it: (TA:) or he scattered the contents of his quiver. (K.) [See also nakata.] ― -b7- nakabatohu AlHijaArapu, aor.
nakuba , inf. n. nakobN, The stones wounded him, and made him bleed, [in the foot]. (S.) nkbt AlHjArp rijolahu The stones wounded his foot, and made it bleed: or hit, or struck, or hurt, it. (K.) Aln~akobu is when a stone wounds, &c., a nail, a hoof, or a camel's foot. (TA.) ― -b8- nukibato A_iSobaEuhu His toe was hit, or hurt, by the stones. (TA.) -A3- nakiba, aor.
nakaba , inf. n. nakabN, He (a camel) had a disease in the shoulder-joint, or in the shoulder-blade, and in consequence halted. (S.) See nakabN. ― -b2- nakiba, aor.
nakaba , inf. n. nakabN, He (a man) had a pain in his shoulder-joint. (TA.) -A4- nakaba EalaY qawomihi, aor.
nakuba , inf. n. nikaAbapN (S) and nukuwbN, (Lh, K,) (tropical:) He was, or acted as, manokibN over his people: (S, K:) or was Eariyf over them. (M.)

2 nik~bh * , inf. n. tanokiybN, He removed, or put aside, or away, or out of the way, him, or it. Thus it is both trans. and intrans. (K.) See 1. ― -b2- nak~ibohu Ean~aA Put him away from us; put him out of our way. (TA.)

5 tnk~b * (S, K) and ↓ Antkb (K) He threw his bow, (S, K,) or his quiver, (K,) upon his shoulder; he shouldered it. (S, K.) ― -b2- tnk~b EalaY qawosK He leaned upon a bow: and, in like manner, upon a staff. (TA, from a trad.) -A2- See 1.
8 A_inotakaba see 5.

nakobN *
i. q. nakobaA'u, q. v. ― -b2- See also nakobapN.

nakabN *
An inclining in a thing: (S:) or what resembles an inclining in a thing. (M, K.) ― -b2- A halting in a camel (ISd, K) by reason of a pain in his shoulder-joint: (ISd:) or a disease which attacks camels in the shoulder-joints, in consequence of which they halt: (S, K:) or only in the shoulder-joint. (El-'Adebbes, S, K.)

nakobapN *
A hurt [of the foot] by a stone, causing a bleeding: or a hit by a stone [upon the foot]. Ex. layosa duwna h`*aA AlA^amori nakobapN walaA *ub~aAHN There is not in the way of the attainment of this thing a hurt [of the foot] by a stone, &c., nor a crack in the inside of the foot. (IAar, ISd.) [See also *b~AH.] Hence nakobapN in the sense immediately following. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A misfortune; an evil accident; a disaster; an affliction; a calamity: (S, K, TA:) as also ↓ nakobN: (K:) pl. of the former nakabAatN; (S;) and of the latter, nukuwbN. (K.)

nukobapN *
A heap of corn, not measured nor weighed: syn. SuborapN. (K.)

nakiybN * The circuit (daAy^irap: in some copies of the S, dAbrp: but this, as IKtt says, is a mistake; and the former is the correct word: TA) of a hoof, (S, K,) and of a camel's foot. (S.) See manokawbN.
Aln~ukayobaA'u * : see A^anokabu.

A^anokabu Eani AlHaq~i * , and Eanohu ↓ naAkibN, (tropical:) A man deviating from the right course of action &c. (A.) ― -b2- nakobaA'u [fem. of A^anokabu] an epithet applied to Any wind that blows obliquely, taking a direction between [the directions of] two [cardinal] winds: (TA:) a wind that blows obliquely, deviating from the direction whence blow the right (Alquw~am [or the cardinal]) winds: (S:) or a [particular] wind that blows obliquely, and takes a direction between [the directions of] two [cardinal] winds; (K;) which destroys the camels and sheep &c., and restrains the rain: (TA:) or a wind that blows in a direction between that of the east, or easterly, wind, (AlS~abaA,) and that of the north, or northerly, wind, (Al$~amaAl): (AZ, K:) that between the south, or southerly, and east, or easterly, winds, being called jirobiyaA'u: (AZ:) [but see this word, and see below:] or what are termed nukobu Alr~iyaAHi [nukobN being pl. of nkbA'] are four: (IAar, Th, S, K:) namely, first, the nkbA'u AlS~abaA waAljanuwbi the wind that blows in a direction between that of the east, or easterly, and that of the south, or southerly, wind; also called AlA^azoyabu; (S, K;) which is a very thirsty wind, that dries up much the leguminous plants; but Et-Tará- bulusee, in the Kf, and Mbr and IF, assert that the Azyb is the jnwb; not its nkbA': (TA:) second, the nkbA'u AlS~abaA waAl$~amaAli the wind that blows in a direction between that of the east, or easterly, and that of the north, or northerly, wind; also called AlS~aAbaypu, and called also ↓ Aln~ukayobAa'u, (S, K,) a diminutive meant to convey the opposite of a diminutive sense; for they find this wind to be very cold; (S;) it is very boisterous and very cold; unattended by rain or by any good: (TA:) third, the nkbA'u Al$~amaAli waAld~abuwri the wind that blows in a direction between that of the north, or northerly, and that of the west, or westerly, wind; also called AljirobiyaA'u; and termed nay~iHapu AlA^azoyabi the opposite wind to the Azyb; (S, K;) a cold wind; (S;) and sometimes attended by a little rain; but Ibn-El-Ajdábee asserts that the jrbyA' is the $mAl: (TA:) fourth, the nkbA'u Aljanuwbi wAld~abuwri the wind that blows in a direction between that of the south, or southerly, and that of the west, or westerly, wind; also called Alhayofu; (in the CK, Alhayafu;) and termed nay~iHapu Aln~ukayobAa'i the opposite wind to the nkybA'; (S, K;) a hot wind (S) and very thirsty. (TA.) Accord. to Ibn-Kubás, the tract whence blows the nkbA' [by which he means only the wind that blows from the north-east or thereabout] is that extending between the point where rises the *iraAE [or the asterism composed of the stars a and b of Gemini, E. 33 degrees N., in central Arabia; or a and b of Canis Minor, E. 7 degrees N., in the same latitude] and the pole-star: and the tract between the pole-star and the point where sets the *rAE is the tract whence blows the $mAl. Sh says, Each of the four [cardinal] winds has its nkbA', which is called in relation to it: that of the SbA is that which is between it and the $mAl; [blowing from the north-east, or thereabout;] and it resembles it in gentleness; sometimes having sharpness, or vehemence; but this is seldom; only once in a long space of time: that of the $mAl is that which is between it and the dbwr; [blowing from the north-west, or thereabout;] and it resembles it in coldness: it is called Al$mAlu Al$~aAmiy~apu: each of them is called by the Arabs $Amy~p: that of the dbwr is that which is between it and the jnwb; blowing from the point where sets suhayol [or Canopus; i. e., S. 29 degrees W., in the latitude of central Arabia]; and it resembles it in its violence and boisterousness: and that of the jnwb
is that which is between it and the SbA; [blowing from the south-east, or thereabout;] and it is the wind most resembling it in its softness and in its gentleness in winter. (L.) The pl. of nkbA' is nukobN, as shown above. (S, K &c.) [See also tab~uwEu Al$~amosi, in art. tbE.] ― -b3- dabuwrN nkb [app. ↓ nakobN, originally an inf. n., used as an epithet, and therefore applicable without p to a fem noun] i. q. nakobAa'u; [app., The nkbA' of the dbwr, a southwesterly wind]. (TA.) ― -b4- A^anokabu A camel having a disease in the shoulder-joint, or in the shoulderblade, and in consequence halting: (S:) a camel that walks on one side, or inclining, or as though he walked on one side. (L.) ― -b5- faAmapN nakobaA'u An inclining pulley: and qiyamN nukobN inclining pulleys. (TA.) ― -b6- A^anokabu (assumed tropical:) Overpowering, or oppressive; unjust, or tyrannical. (S, TA.) ― -b7- Ald~ahoru A^anokabu laA yulib~u (assumed tropical:) Fortune abounds with evil accidents, or disasters, or afflictions, or calamities; i. e. it deviates much, or often, from the right course: it will not remain in one state: or, accord. to one relation, Aldhr Ankv Alx. A proverb. (TA.) -A2- A^anokabu A man not having with him a bow. (S, K.)

manokibN * (masc., Lh, K) The shoulder; i. e. the place of junction of the os humeri and the scapula, (S, K.) in a man &c; (ISd:) the place of junction of the os humeri and the scapula and the [tendon called] Habolu AlEaAtiqi, in a man and a bird and any other thing. (TA.) [It seems to be regarded by some as originally signifying “ a place of deflection: ” but] Sb denies its being a noun of place, because, were it so, it would be manokabN: he does not allow it to be included in the class of maToliEN, because this is extr. Pl. manaAkibu. rajulN $adiydu AlmanaAkibi, signifies A man having a strong shoulder: as though the sing. were applied to denote each part of the joint, and the pl. to denote the whole. (TA.) ― -b2- haz~uwA manaAkibahumo (tropical:) [They shook their shoulderjoints;] i. e., they rejoiced, or were joyful, or happy. (TA.) ― -b3- xiyAarukumo A^alayonukumo manaAkiba fiY AlS~alaApi (assumed tropical:) [The best of you are the most easy of you in the shoulder-joints in prayer:] meaning. those of you who keep [most] still therein: or, as some say, those who [most readily] give room to such as enter the rank in prayer. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- manokibu Alfarasi The star β in Pegasus. (El-Kazweenee &c.) ― -b5- manokibu AljawozaA'i The bright, and very great star, a, in the right shoulderjoint, of Orion. (El-Kazweenee &c.) ― -b6- manokibN (tropical:) The side of anything; or a lateral, or an adjacent, part, quarter, or tract, thereof: (K:) pl. manaAkibu: ex. sironaA fiY mnkbK mina AlA^aroDi We proceeded, or journeyed, along a side, or lateral part, of the land: and, in like manner, mina Aljabali of the mountain: (TA:) so in the Kur, lxvii. 15, the pl. signifies the sides, &c., of the earth: (Fr:) or its roads, accord. to some: (TA:) or its mountains: (Zj:) which last signification in this case is preferred by Az: (TA:) or the sing. signifies an elevated place, or part, of the earth or land. (S.) ― -b7- AlmanaAkibN (tropical:) The feathers next after the qawaAdim; [which latter are the anterior, or primary, feathers of a bird's wing;] (K;) the feathers of the wing of a vulture or an eagle that are next after the qwAdm, which are the strongest and most excellent of the feathers; (TA:) four [feathers] in the wing of a bird, next after the qwAdm (S.) [the four secondary feathers of the wing:] in the wing of a bird are twenty leathers: the first of them are those called AlqwAdm; the next, AlmnAkb; the next, AlxawaA fiY: the next, AlA^abAhiru; the next, AlkulaY. (L.) It is a word without a sing. (K.) ISd says, I know not a sing. ?? it; but by analogy it should ?? ??. (TA.) ― -b8- rAa$a ?? (tropical:) He feathered his arrow with feathers such as are described above. (TA.) -A2- manokibN (tropical:) EariyfN i. q. The intendant, superintendent, &c., of a people or an aider, helper, or assistant, of a people: (K:) or the assistant of an Eryf: (Msb:) one below an Eryf: (IAth:) or the chief of the EurafaA'u [pl. of Eryf]; (Lth, S:) there being over so many ErfA' a mnkb. (Lth [see EariyfN.]) pl. manaAkibu. (TA.)
minokaAbN Eani AlHaq~i * [(assumed tropical:) One who deviates much from the right course of action &c.] (TA.)

manokuwbN * and nakibN, accord. to the copies of the K, but the latter word is a mistake for ↓ nakiybN, Having the foot wounded, and made to bleed, by stones: or hit, or struck, or hurt, by stones. (K.) See 1. ― -b2- manokuwbN (assumed tropical:) Overcome or afflicted, by fortune: or smitten with an evil accident, or the like. (S, TA.) See nukiba.
yanokuwbN * [like yaHomuwrN in measure: in the CK, manokuwbN:] A road deviating from the right course or direction. (K.)

1 nakata * , aor.
nakuta , inf. n. nakotN, (or nakata AlA^aroDa biqaDiybK, [&c.,] TA.) He struck the ground with a stick, (S, M, K,) or with his finger, (M,) so that it made a mark, or marks, upon it, (S, K,) with its extremity; an action of one reflecting, or meditating, and anxious. (TA.) [Thus our Saviour seems to have done in the case of the woman taken in adultery: see S. John viii. 6 and 8.] ― -b2- Also, He struck the ground with pebbles. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (tropical:) He reflected, or meditated, and talked to himself (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- nakata, aor.
nakuta , (S, K,) inf. n. nakotN, (K,) He (a horse) bounded (nabaA, S, K) from the ground, (S,) in running. (TA.) ― -b5- nakatahu He threw it down upon the ground. (TA.) ― -b6- nakata kitaAbatahu He scattered the contents of his quiver. (TA.) See nkb.] ― -b7- TaEanahu fanakatahN He thrust him, or pierced him, and threw him down upon his head. (As, S, K. *) ― -b8- nukita It (a cooked bone, containing marrow,) was struck with the edge of a cake of bread, or with some other thing, to cause the marrow to fall out. (TA.) nukita AlEaZomu The marrow to the bone was taken out, or extracted. (Aboo-'Ameythel.) Mentioned in art. bqt, q. v. (TA.) -A2- nakata fiY kalAamihi and fiY qawolahi, [aor, ?? inf. n. nakotN? (in the TA, the verb is written without the syll points, but the form commonly known in the present day, and occurring in many late works, is ↓ nk~t, inf. n. nanokiytN; (tropical:) He made use of nice, or subtile, sayings, ?? sions, such as are termed nukat, pl. of nukotap)] (A.) ― -b2- nakatu fiY AlEilomi bimuwaAfqahi fulaAnK A^awo muxaAlafapi fulaAni He alluded (A^a$aAra) (with respect to science, to the agreement of such a one, or the di?? ment of such a one]. (L)
2 nk~t Alr~uTabu * , inf. n. tanokiytN, The dates began to ripen [and to become speckled]. (Msb.) ― -b2- See 1.

8 Antkt *
He was thrown down upon his head; or fell down upon his head, having been thrust, or pierced. (S, K *)
nakotN * : see nukoyapN.

nukatapN *
A point; a dot; a speck; a minute spot; i. q. nuqoTapN: (S, K:) pl. nukatN, (Msb, &c) agreeably with analogy, (TA,) and nikaAtN, (K,) deviating from analogy, and, accord. to some, nukaAtN, in which the A is said to be added liloA_i$obaAEi, or to render the sound of the fet-hah full, like ruxaAlN (TA:) the last of these pls. has been heard [from the classical Arabs]; (Esh-Shiháb, in the Expos. of the Shifà;) or it is vulgar. (Msb.) ― -b2- nukotapN [A small spot, or mark,] resembling dirt upon a mirror: (K:) nukotapN sawodaA'u A small [black] mark, like a spot, or dot, resembling dirt upon a mirror or a sword or the like (L, from a trad.) ― -b3- nukotapN [A spot in the eye;] what resembles a waqorap in the eye. (L.) ― -b4- [↓ nakotN seems to be a quasi-pl. of nukotapN, like as naqoTN is said to be (by some persons in the present day) of nuqoTapN, and to signify Any small spots, or specks, in a thing, differing therefrom in colour. Such I suppose to be meant by the words in the L, kl~ naqoTK fY $Y' xAlf lwnh nakotN.] -A2- nukotapN (tropical:) A nice, subtile, subtilely excogitated, quaint,
facetious, or witty, saying, expression, or allusion, (laTiyfap) that makes an impression upon the heart; from Aln~akotu [the striking the ground with a stick &c., so as to make a mark, or marks, upon it with its extremity]: also, a question educed by reflection, [biAlt~afak~uri, as the passage here translated is given in the Kull, p. 362, but in the TA bAlnql, which is an evident mistake, as might be shown by many authorities,] which makes an impression upon the heart, on hearing or considering which one generally makes marks upon the ground with the finger or the like: (El-Fenáree's Expos. of the Telweeh:) a nice, or subtile, saying, expression, or allusion, that requires one to reflect, and [induces one] to make marks upon the ground with a stick or the like: (from a scholium quoted by De Sacy, Anthol. Gr. Ar., 303:) [a nice, subtile, abstruse, or mystical, point, or allusion: the point of a saying or sentence, especially one that is difficult to be understood: a conceit expressed in words difficult to be understood: a quaint conceit: a point of wit: a facetious saying or allusion: pl., generally, nukatN]. ― -b2- jaA'a binukotahK (tropical:) [He uttered a nice, or subtile, saying, expression, or allusion, &c.]. (A.)

nakiytN *
Spoken against; having his reputation wounded. (TA.)

nak~aAtN * (and ↓ munak~itN TA) (tropical:) One who speaks much, or frequently, against others; who wounds the reputations of others, much, or frequently. (K.) ― -b2- zayodN nak~aAtN fiY AlA^aEoraADi Zeyd is one who wounds the reputations of others much, or frequently. (TA.)

naAkitN *
A distortion in a camel's elbow, so that it lacerates his side: (El-'Adebbes El-Kinánee, S, K:) or the cutting of a camel's side by his elbow: (L:) or [that fault in a camel] when his elbow makes a mark, or marks, upon his side: in this case you say, bihi nAktN: but when it makes an incision, or incisions, in his side, you say bihi HaAz~N: (IAar) or nAkt is similar to naAHizN, i. e. the elbow's striking, and making a mark, or marks, upon the edge of the callous lump beneath his breast; in the case of which you say bh nAkt: (Lth:) and nearly the same is said in the A. (TA.)
manokuwtN * A cooked bone, containing marrow, that is struck with the edge of a cake of bread, or with some other thing, to cause the marrow to fall out. (TA.)
munak~itN * : see nak~aAtN. ― -b2- ruTabapN munak~itapN, A date beginning to ripen [and to become speckled]. (S, K.)

ZalafapN manotakitapN * The extremity of the curved piece of wood termed Hinow in the kind of saddle called qatab, and in that called A_ikaAf, when it is short, and wounds the side of the camel. (TA.)

1 nakava * , (S, K,) aor.
nakuva , (K, Msb,) and
nakiva , (K,) inf. n. nakovN, (TA,) He undid [the threads of] a garment of the kind called kisaA', &c.: (Msb:) he undid, or untwisted, a rope. (S, K.) ― -b2- nakava Als~iwaAka, aor.
nakuva , inf. n. nakovN; He, or it, made the head of the tooth-stick to be uncompacted, disintegrated, disunited, or seperated, in its fibres: and so the verb signifies with respect to other things. (TA.) [See also 8.] ― -b3- nakava, (aor.
nakuva , and
nakiva , K, inf. n. nakovN, TA,) (tropical:) He dissolved, violated, or broke, a covenant, or compact, (S, K,) or an act of inauguration, &c. (TA.) ― -b4- nakava Eani AlA^amori i. q. nakaSa (Aboo-Turáb, in TA, art. nkS.)
5 tanak~ava see 8.
6 tanaAkavuwA Euhuwdahumo * (tropical:) They mutually dissolved, or broke, their covenants, or compacts; syn. tanaAqaDuwhaA. (K.)

8 Antkv *
It (a garment of the kind called kisaA', &c., Msb, or a rope, S, K) was undone, or untwisted. (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- Antkv Als~iwaAku [so accord. to the TA: in the K, ↓ nakava:] (TA:) and ↓ tnk~v, (TA, in art. $Ev,) The head of the tooth-stick became uncompacted, disunited, or separated, in its fibres. (TA.) ― -b3- Antkv [He was, or became, emaciated, or lean; he (a camel) became lean after having been fat. See 4, in art. rA^Y.] ― -b4- Antkv (tropical:) It (a covenant, or compact, S and K, or an act of inauguration, &c., TA,) was dissolved, violated, or broken. (S, K, &c.) ― -b5- Antkv mino HaAjapK A_ilaY A^uxoraY, (K,) or liA^uxoraY, (S,) (tropical:) He turned from a thing that he wanted to another thing, (S, K,) having desired, or sought, the former. (TA.)

nikovN *
What is undone, to be spun again, (A, Msb,) of the garments called A^akosiyap, and of the stuff of the tents called A^axobiyap: (A:) pl. A^anokaAvN: (Msb:) or threads of an old and worn-out stuff, of wool or hair, untwisted, and mixed with new wool [or hair], and beaten with maTAariq, and spun a second time: or old and worn-out thread of wool or common hair or the soft hair called wabar; so called because it is untwisted, and twisted again: (TA:) it is when the old and worn-out materials of the garments called Aksyp (and of the tents called Axbyp, S) are undone, to be spun again. (S, K.) [SM seems to have understood, from the expl. in the S and K, that nikovN is an inf. n.; for he adds,] the subst. is ↓ nakiyvapN: (TA:) [i. e., this last word has the signification assigned above to nikovN, from the A and Msb]. ― -b2- haYi tagozilu Aln~ikova, and nakiyvN, She spins what has been undone, to be spun again, &c. (A.) ― -b3- HabolN nikovN, and ↓ nakiyvN, (TA,) and A^anokaAvN, and ↓ manokuwvN, (K,) A rope undone, or untwisted, (K, TA,) at its end. (TA.)

nukaAvN *
Pustules which come forth in the mouths of camels: (K:) as also lukaAvN. (TA.) ― -b2- A disease in the nakafataAni of a camel, which are two prominent bones by the fat parts of the two ears: it is also called nukaAfN. (TA.)
nakiyvN * : see nikovN.
nukaAvapN * The broken particles of the end of a siwaAk [or tooth-stick], remaining in the mouth. (K.) ― -b2- Also, What is undone, or untwisted, of the end of a rope, (K,) &c. (TA.)

nakiyvahN * : see nikovN. ― -b2- Subst. from Antkv AlHabolu [What is undone, or untwisted, of a rope]. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Breach of promise; syn. xulofN. (S, K.) Ex. qaAla fulaAnN qawolFA laA nakiyvapa fiyhi Such a one said a saying in which was [intended] no breach of promise. (S.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A difficult, or an arduous, affair, or case, in which a people dissolves, or breaks, (tanokuvu) [its covenants, or compacts]. (S, K.) ― -b5- A great affair. (TA.) ― -b6- The utmost of one's endeavour, or effort: (S, K:) power, or strength: (K:) pl. nakaAy^ivu. (TA.) Ex. balaga fulaAnN nakiyvapa baEiyrihi Such a one exerted the utmost endeavour, or effort, [or power, or strength,] of his camel, in journeying. (S.) [See also najiyvapN.] ― -b7- nakiyvapN Nature; natural, or native, disposition, temper, or other property. (K.) ― -b8- Alnakiyvahu (assumed tropical:) The mind; the soul; syn. Aln~afosu: (S, K:) so called because the vexation of those things of which it is in need dissolve (tanokuvu) its powers, and old age destroys it: the p is added because it is a subst. (TA.) Ex. fulAanN $adiydu Aln~akiyvapi Such a one is strong in mind. (S.) Pl. nakaAy^ivu. (TA.)

nak~aAvN *
One who undoes, or untwists, thread, and twists it again, or, to twist it again. (TA.) [See nikovN.] ― -b2- nak~aAvN liloEahodi (tropical:) One who is wont to dissolve, violate, or break, his covenant, or compact. (TA.)
manokuwvN * : see nikovN.

manotakivN *
Emaciated; lean: (K:) a camel that has been fat, and has become lean. (TA.)

1 nakaHa kH nkH , (S, K, &c.,) aor.
nakiHa , (Msb, K,) and
nakaHa , (K,) the latter agreeable with analogy, but by some rejected, and the former contr. to analogy, but more common, and the form used
in the Kur, (TA,) the only instance of an aor. of this form from a verb having H for its last radical letter, except ynTH and ymnH and ynDH and ynbH and yrjH and yA^nH and yA^zH and ymlH, (ISd,) [and yDH] inf. n. nikaAHN (S, K, &c.) and nakoHN; (ISd, K;) Inivit feminam: and (sometimes, S) he married, took in marriage, or contracted a marriage with, a woman: as also ↓ AstnkH (S, K, &c.) [and ↓ nAkH, inf. n. munaAkaHapN:] used only with reference to a man: (ISd:) but Th uses it with reference to flies: (TA:) J says, that it is sometimes used in the latter sense; but accord. to the Msb it is more commonly so used; (MF;) and it is used only in this sense in the Kur: (TA:) IF and others say, that it signifies coitus; and coitus without marriage; and marriage without coitus: (Msb:) [but] in the Time of Ignorance, when a man demanded a woman in marriage he said, AinokiHiyniY; and when he desired fornication, he said, saAfiHiyniY. (TA, in art sfH.) It is disputed whether it be proper or tropical in these two senses; or proper in one, and tropical in one: (MF:) it is said to be from nakaHahu Ald~awaY, or from tanaAkaHati AlA^a$ojaAru, or from nakaHa AlmaTaru AlA^aroDa; and if so, it is tropical in both the above senses; and the opinion that it is so is confirmed by this, that the signification of marriage is not understood unless by a word or phrase in connexion with it, as when you say nakaHa fiY baniY fulaAnK [he took a wife from among the sons of such a one]; nor is that of coitus unless by the same means, as when you say nakaHa zawojatahu [inivit conjugem suam]; and this is one of the signs of a tropical expression. (Msb.) ― -b2- nakaHato She married, or took a husband. (S, K.) ― -b3- nakaHa AlmaTaru AlA^aroDa The rain became commingled with the soil: (Msb:) or, rested upon the ground so as to soak it; syn. A_iEotamada EalayohaA: (K:) as also ↓ naAkahaA. (L.) ― -b4- nakaHahu Ald~awaY The disease infected him (xaAmarhu), and overcame him. (Msb.) ― -b5- nakaHa Aln~uEaAsu Eayonahu (tropical:) Drowsiness overcame his eye; (K;) as also naAkahaA: and in like manner ↓ AstnkH Aln~awomu Eayonahu sleep overcame his eye. (TA.)
3 naAokaHa see 1.

4 AnkHhu AlmaroA^apa *
He married the woman to him. (TA.) ― -b2- A^anokaHahaA He married the woman; i. e. gave her in marriage. (S, K.) ― -b3- A^anokiHuwA AlHaSaY A^axofaAfa AlA_ibili (tropical:) [Accustom ye the feet of the camels to pebbles]. (A.)

6 tnAkHwA *
They intermarried; contracted marriages together. (Commencing a trad. in the Jámi' es-Sagheer.) [And tanaAkaHaA Se invicem futuerunt: see 6, in art. rdf] ― -b2- tanaAkaHati AlA^a$ojaAru The trees became drawn, or connected, together. (Msb.)
10 A_isotanokaHa see 1.

nikoHN * and ↓ nukoHN substs. from A^anokaHahaA, [The act of giving a woman in marriage]. (K.) ― -b2- [These two words are properly quasi-inf. ns, of A^anokaHa, signifying as explained above; and, like inf. ns., may be used as epithets, meaning A giver of a woman in marriage, correlative to xuiTobN.] It was a custom, in the time of paganism, for a man to come to a tribe asking for a woman in marriage; and he would stand up in their assembly, and say xiTobN, i. e., I have come as an asker of a woman in marriage; whereupon it would be said to him nikoHN, meaning We marry her to thee, or give her to thee in marriage, [or, more lit., we are givers of her in marriage: for an inf. n. or quasi-inf. n. used as an epithet is used without variation as sing., dual., and pl.; and masc. and fem.]. ↓ nukoHN was also said: but nikoHN is here said for the sake of resemblance to xiTobN. (L.) You say hw nikoHuhaA He is the person who gives her in marriage: and hiYa nikoHatuhu She is the person whom he gives in marriage. (Lh, L) ― -b3- nikoHN and ↓ nukoHN, [and, accord. to Lth and ISh, nikiHN: see A_ibidN:] are also two words by which the [Pagan] Arabs used to take women in marriage: (S:) [meaning A giver of a woman in marriage]. (MF, in art. xTb.) A man used to say to Umm-Khárijeh, in asking her in marriage, xuiTobN, and she used to reply nukioHN: hence the saying A^asoraEu mino nikaAHi A^um~i xaArijapa [Quicker than the marriage of Umm-Khárijeh]. (S, K.) [See xiTobN].
nukoHN * : see nikoHN.
nukaHN * : see nakaHupN.

rajulN nukaHapN * , (S, K,) and ↓ nukaHN (K) A man who marries much, or often: (S, K, TA:) AZ explains the former by $adiydu Aln~ikaAHi, [app. meaning vehement in coitus,] and mentions as its pl. nukaHaAtN: (TA:) [and ↓ nak~aAHN (A, TA, art. tys, &c.) signifies the same.]
nak~aAHN * : see nukaHapN.

naAkiHN * (S, K) and naAkiHapN, (K,) the latter occurring in poetry, (TA,) A woman married; (TA;) having a husband. (S, K, TA.) Ex. hiYa naAkiHN fiY baniY fulAanK She has a husband among the sons of such a one. (S.)
manokiaHN * and manokuwHapN: see manaAkiHu.

manaAkiHu *
Women, or wives; syn. nisaA='N: (K:) a pl. having no sing.; or its sing. is ↓ manokaHN; [or ↓ manokiHN, which occurs in the S and K, art. Elv, evidently as signifying a wife; as though being a place of nikaAH;] or ↓ manokuwHapN. (TA.) ― -b2- A_in~a AlmanaAkiHa xayorahuA AlA^abokaAru [Verily the best of women to take in marriage are virgins]. A proverb. (TA.)

1 nakida * , aor.
nakada , (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. nakadN, (S, L, Msb,) It (a man's life) was, or became, hard, or strait, and difficult. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- nakida It (a she-camel's milk) became deficient. (R.) ― -b3- nakida It (water) became exhausted. (A.) ― -b4- nakidati Alr~akiy~apu The well came to have little water. (S, L, K.) ― -b5- nakida, aor.
nakada , inf. n. nakadN, He was, or became, unpropitious, and mean: (L:) he became hard, or difficult: (Msb:) he gave little: or gave not at all: you say also nakida biHaAjatinaA he was niggardly of that which we wanted. (L.) ― -b6- nakada HaAjatahu, aor.
nakuda ; (K;) or nakadahu HaAjatahu, (L,) He withheld from him, or refused him, his want. (L, K.) ― -b7- nakadahu, aor.
nakuda , He withheld from him, or refused him, what he asked: or [in the CK, and] the same, (K,) or nakadahu maA saA^alahu, aor.
nakuda , inf. n. nakodN, (L,) he gave him not save the least of what he asked. (L, K.) ― -b8- nukida, [in measure] like EuniYa, He had many askers and gave little. (K.) ― -b9- nakada, aor.
nakuda , He (a raven or crow) croaked with his utmost force; (A, K;) as though vomiting; as also ↓ tnk~d. (A.)

2 nak~ada EaTaA='ahu biA@loman~i *
He impaired his gift by reproach. (A.) ― -b2- nk~d wasoqahu He spent, or exhausted, what he possessed, in consequence of frequent petitions. (A.) ― -b3- nk~dhu He vexed, distressed, or troubled, him; (Gol, from Meyd.) [as also nk~d Ealayohi].

3 nAkdhu *
He treated him, or behaved towards him, with hardness, harshness, or ill-nature. (S, L, K.)

4 saA^alahu faA^anokadahu *
He asked of him, and found him hard, or difficult, (A, L,) and mean, or niggardly: (L:) or found him to have only what was scanty, or little. (L.) ― -b2- Talaba minohu HaAjapF faA^anokada He sought, or desired, of him a thing that he wanted, and he was niggardly. (A.)
5 tnk~d * [He became vexed, distressed, or troubled]. (A.) See Bd, in lxviii. 25: and see 1.

6 tnAkdA *
They treated each other with hardness, harshness, or ill-nature. (S, L, K.)
nakodN * : see nukodN, and nakidN.
nukodN * and ↓ nakodN Scantiness of a gift; (L, K;) and its not being enjoyed, or found pleasant, by the receiver. (L.) ― -b2- See what follows.

nakadFA lahu wjaHadFA * , and lh wjuHoduA ↓ nukodFA, [May God decree straitness, or difficulty, to him, and
poverty]: forms of imprecation. (L.) ― -b2- nakadN Anything that brings evil upon the person whom it affects. (L.) See nakidN.

nakidN * [Hard, strait, or difficult; applied to a man's life; (see 1;) and to fortune, as in an ex. voce A_ibidN.] ― -b2- Water little in quantity. (L.) ― -b3- laA yaxoruju A_il~aA nakidFA, in the Kur, [vii. 56,] accord. to the common reading, or ↓ nakadFA, accord. to the reading of the people of El-Medeeneh, or, as it may be read, accord. to Zj, ↓ nakodFA and ↓ nukodFA, means, accord. to Fr, It [the herbage] will not come forth save with difficulty: (L:) or, scantily and unprofitably. (Beyd.) ― -b4- nakidN (S, A, L, Msb, K,) and ↓ nakadN and ↓ nakodN and ↓ A^anokadu (L, K) A man who is unpropitious, (L, K,) and mean, (L,) and hard, or difficult: (S, A, L, Msb, K:) and a people you term A^anokaAdN and manaAkiydu (S, L, K) and nukudN and nukodN. (A.) ― -b5- nakidN and ↓ A^anokadu A man that brings evil upon others. (L.)

nakaAdN *
Hardness, or difficulty, in a man. (A.) See nakida.

A^araDuwna nikaAdN *
Lands possessing little goods. (L.)
naAkidN * : see A^anokadu.

A^anokadu * . ― -b2- nakodaA='u A she-camel abounding with milk; (IF, L, K;) as also ↓ naAkidN: (L:) a she-camel that has no young one living, and therefore abounding with milk, because she does not suckle; (L; K;) so nakodaA='u miqolaAtN, of which the pls. occur in a verse of El-Kumeyt cited voce $axaba: (S:) also, contr., a she-camel having no milk: (IF, A, K:) or having little milk; as also ↓ naAkidN: and both words, a she-camel whose young one has died: (L:) pl. (of both words, L) nukodN (S, L, K.) See also makodaA='u. ― -b3- A^anokadu Unfortunate; unlucky. (S.) See nakidN.
munak~adN * : see manokuwdN.

manokuwdN * A small, or scanty, gift; (A, L, K;) as also ↓ munak~adN (A.) ― -b2- manokuwdN A man having many askers and giving little: (TA:) or a man pressed with petitions; as also maEoruwkN and ma$ofuwhN and maEojuwzN. (IAar, L.)

jaA='ahu munokidFA *
He came to him unwelcomely: or, empty: or, as Th says, it is correctly munokizFA, from nakarati Albiy^oru, though A^anokaza as meaning “ his wells became exhausted, ” has not been heard. (L.)

1 nakirahu * : see 4, in several places. -A2- nakura, inf. n. nakaArapN, [He was, or became, ignorant: or perhaps only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is used: see nakaArapN, below. ― -b2- And, contr., He possessed cunning; meaning both intelligence with craft and forecast; and simply intelligence, or skill and knowledge: or perhaps only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is used: see nakorN. ― -b3- ] It (a thing, or an affair,) was, or became, munokar [app. here meaning disapproved; or bad, evil, abominable, or foul; or disallowed]. (A.) ― -b4- Also, (S, K,) inf. n. nakaArapN, (TK,) or nukorapN, (TA,) It (a thing, or an affair,) was, or became, difficult, hard, arduous, or severe. (S, K. *)

2 nk~rhu * , (inf. n. tanokiyrN, Msb,) He changed, or altered, him or it, (S, A, Msb, TA,) to an unknown state, (S, TA,) so as not to be known; (TA;) [he disguised him or it.] It is said in the Kur, [xxvii. 41,] nak~iruwA lahaA Earo$ahaA Alter ye her throne so that it may not be known to her. (TA.) See also 4, last signification but one. ― -b2- [In grammar, He made it (a noun) indeterminate.]

3 nAkrhu * , (S, TA,) inf. n. munaAkarapN, (A, K,) He strove, or endeavoured, to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent, him; or he practised with him mutual deceit, guile, or circumvention; syn. xaAdaEahu and daAhaAhu: the inf. n. is also explained by muraAwagapN as well as muxaAdaEapN [both of which signify the same]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) He contended with him in fight; (S, K;) and in war, or hostility. (A, K.) It is said of Mohammad, by Aboo-Sufyán (S, TA) Ibn- Harb, (TA,) lamo yunaAkiro A^aHadFA A_il~aA kaAnato maEahu AlA^ahowaAlu, (S, TA,) meaning, He did not war with any one without being aided by terror [cast into the hearts of his opponents]. (TA.) And one says, bayonahumaA munaAkarapN Between them two is war, or hostility, (A, TA, *) and fighting. (TA.)

4 Ankrhu * , (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. A_inokaArN; (Msb, &c.;) and ↓ nakirahu, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
nakara , (L,) or it does not admit the variations of tense like other verbs, (IKtt, Msb,) it is not used in the future tense, nor in commanding nor in forbidding, (Lth,) inf. n. nakarN (K) and nukorN and nukuwrN (S, K) and nakiyrN; (K;) and ↓ Astnkrhu; (S, M, A, K;) and ↓ tnAkrhu; (M, K;) signify the same; (S, A, Msb, K, &c.;) i. e., He ignored, was ignorant of, did not know, failed to know, or [rather] was unacquainted with, it (i. e. a thing, or an affair, IKtt, K) or him (a man, S); syn. jahilahu; (Kr, K;) or contr. of Earafahu: (S, * IKtt, Msb:) [see also nakaArapN:] some, however, say, the nakira has a more intensive signification than A^anokara: and some, that nakira has for its objective complement an object of the mind; and A^anokara, an object of the sight: (A, TA:) or [the converse is the case;] nakira has for its objective complement an object of the sight; and A^anokara, an object of the mind: (Kull, p. 81:) [but both forms seem to have been generally used indiscriminately.] ElAashà says,
waA^anokaratoniY wamaA kaAna Al~a*iY nakirato
mina AlHawaAdivi A_il~aA Al$~ayoba waAlS~alaEaA
[And she did not know me; and the accidents which she did not know were none others than hoariness, and baldness of the fore part of the head]. (S, TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [xi. 73,] waA^awojasa minohumo xiyfapN ↓ nakirahumo [He knew not what they were, and conceived a fear, or a kind of fear, of them]: (TA:) nakirahumo here signifies A^anokarahumo: (Jel:) or it means A^anokara *`lika minohumo [q. v. infra]. (Bd.) ― -b2- A^anokarahu also signifies He denied, or disacknowledged, it; (L, art. jHd; [and this signification, as well as the first, may be meant to be indicated by those who say that A^anokarahu signifies the contr. of Earfahu;]) [and so ↓ nakirahu; for] A_inokaArN signifies i. q. juHuwdN, (S, TA,) and so nukoraAnN [which is an inf. n. of nakirahu]. (TA.) [In this sense it is doubly trans.:] you say, A^anokarotuhu Haq~ahu, meaning, I denied, or disacknowledged, to him his right. (Msb.) The cause of A_inokaAr with the tongue is A_inokaAr with the mind, but sometimes the tongue denies, or disacknowledges, (yunokiru,) a thing when the image thereof is present in the mind; and this is lying; as is the case in the following passage of the Kur, [xvi. 85,] yaEorifuwna niEomapa A@ll~`hi vum~a yunokiruwnahaA [They confess, or acknowledge, the favour of God; then they deny, or disacknowledge, it]. (B.) See also nakiyrN. -A2- Also, He deemed it strange, extraordinary, or improbable. (MF, voce EajabN.] ― -b2- [Also He denied, or negatived, it. ― -b3- He disbelieved it. ― -b4- And He disapproved it; he disliked it; he deemed it, or declared it to be, bad, evil, abominable, or foul; he disallowed it: so accord. to explanations of the pass. part. n., q. v. infra; and accord. to common usage of classical and of modern times.] It is said of Abraham, when the angels came to him, and he saw that their hands did not touch the meat which be had brought to them, nakirahumo, meaning, A^anokara *`lika minohumo [He deemed that conduct of their's evil, or disapproved it: or, perhaps, he did not know what that conduct of their's was, or what it indicated]: ↓ nakira and A^anokara and ↓ Astnkr [of which last see an ex. voce tahima] signify the same. (Bd, xi. 73.) And you say, A^anokarotu Ealayohi fiEolahu, meaning, I blamed, or found fault with, his deed, and forbade it; I disapproved and disallowed his deed. (Msb:) [and I manifested, or showed, or declared, disapproval, or disallowance, of his
deed: and in like manner, A^anokarotu Ealyohi, elliptically; fiEolahu, (his deed,) or qawolahu, (his saying;) or the like, being understood; like Eay~ara Ealayohi for Eay~ara Ealayohi fiEolahu or the like: see nakiyrN.] ― -b5- A_inokaArN also signifies The changing [a thing; like tanokiyrN]: (T, Msb, TA:) or the changing what is munokar [here app. meaning disapproved: see nakiyrN, which is syn. with it, but is a simple subst.]. (S, TA.) ― -b6- maA A^anokarahu How great it his cunning! meaning both his intelligence, and craft, and forecast; and simply, his intelligence, or skill and knowledge. (TA.) And maA kaAna A^anokarahu How great was his cunning, &c. (TA.)

5 tnk~r *
He, or it, changed, or altered, himself, or itself; or became changed, or altered; (S, A, Msb, TA;) to an unknown state: (S, TA:) [he assumed an unknown appearance: he disguised himself; or became disguised:] he became changed or altered in countenance by anger so that he who saw him did not know him: (Har, p. 144:) or tanak~urN signifies the changing, or altering oneself, or itself; or becoming changed, or altered; from a state which pleases one to a state which one dislikes. (T, K.) ― -b2- A_iy~aAka waAlt~anak~ura Avoid thou evil disposition. (Mgh.) ― -b3- tanak~ara liY fulAanN Such a one [became changed, or altered, in countenance to me by anger so that I did not know him; or] met me in a morose manner (A, TA.) [In art. $nf in the K, tanak~arahu occurs.]
6 tnAkrhu * : see 4, first signification. ― -b2- tnAkr He feigned ignorance. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- tnAkrwA They acted with mutual hostility. (TS, A, K.)

10 A$tnkrhu * : see 4, first signification, and also in the latter part. ― -b2- AisotinokaArN also signifies The inquiring respecting, or seeking to understand, a thing, or an affair, which one disapproves; (K, TA;) when one disapproves confirming, or establishing, the opinion expressed by an inquirer, or disapproves that his opinion should be contrary to what he has expressed. (TA.)
nakorN * : see nukorN. -A2- See also nakirN.

nukorN * (S, K) and ↓ nakorN [but the former is the more common] and ↓ nakaArapN (S, A, K) and ↓ nakoraA='u (A, K) Cunning; meaning both intelligence mixed with croft and forecast; and [simply] intelligence, or sagacity, or skill and knowledge; syn. dahaA='N; (S, A, K;) and fiTonapN. (A, K.) See also nakura. You say of a man who is intelligent and evil, or cunning, maA A^a$ad~a nukorahu, and ↓ nakorahu [How great is his cunning, &c.!] (S.) And faEalahu mino nukorihi, and ↓ nakaAratihi, He did it of his cunning, &c. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, A_in~iY laA^akorahu Aln~akaArapa fiY Alr~ajuli Verily I hate cunning (Ald~ahaA='a) in the man. (TA.) -A2- nukorN, as an epithet, applied to a thing, or an affair, Difficult, hard, arduous, or severe; as also ↓ nukurN (M, A, K) and ↓ nakiyrN: (TA:) and i. q. munokarN, q. v. (S, A, K.)
nakarN * [app. Difficulty, hardness, arduousness, or severity;] a subst. from nakura, in the sense of SaEuba [It was difficult, &c.]. (IKtt, TA.)
nakurN * : see nakirN, in two places.

nakirN * and ↓ nakurN (S, K) and ↓ nukurN and ↓ munokarN, (K,) epithets applied to a man, Possessing cunning; or intelligence mixed with cunning and forecast; (S, K;) and [simply] intelligent, or skilful and knowing: (K:) and so, applied to a woman, ↓ nukurN (K) and ↓ nakorN (L, TA [but this is probably a mistake for ↓ nukurN]) and ↓ nakoraA='u, but A^anokaru is not applied to a man in this sense, (Az, TA,) nor is munokarapN to a woman: (TA:) pl. of the first and second (S, K,) and third, (K,) A^anokaArN: (S, K:) and of the last, manaAkiyru: (Sb, S, K:) or, applied to men, munokaruwna; and to other things, manaAkiyru [which is irreg.]. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- Also, nakirN and ↓ nakurN One who disapproves what is bad, evil, abominable, or foul; expl. by A^al~a*iY yunokiru A@lomunokara: pl. as above. (S.)
nukurN * : see nukorN, and munokarN. -A2- See also nakirN, in two places.

nakarapN * a subst. from A_inokaArN, (K,) with which it is syn., [app. signifying (like nakirapN) Ignorance: or denial: or disapproval, or the like]. (TK,) like nafaqapN from A_inofaAqN. (K.) It is said, in a certain trad, kunota liY A^a$ad~a nakarapF, (TA,) i. e. A_inokaArFA, (TK,) [Thou wast to me most ignorant. &c.]

nakirapN *
Ignorance, &c., (A_inokaAr,) of a thing; (TA;) contr. of maEorifapN; (S, K;) and so ↓ nakaArapN; syn. jahaAlapN; as in the phrase fiyhi nakaArapN [In him is ignorance]. (A.) See also nakarapN. ― -b2- [As contr. of maEorifapN, it is also, in grammar, an epithet applied to a noun, signifying Indeterminate, or indefinite.]
nakoraA='u * : see munokarN. ― -b2- A calamity: (K:) rigour, or severity, of fortune; (A, TA;) as also [its dim.] nukayoraA='. (TA.) -A2- See also nukorN. -A3- And see nakirN.

nakiyrN *
i. q. A_inokaArN [in the sense of Denial]. (K.) It is said in the Kur, xlii. 46. famaA lakumo mino nakiyrK And there shall be for you no [power of] denial of your sins. (Bd, Jel.) And one says, $utima fulaAnN famaA kaAna Einodahu nakiyrN [Such a one was reviled and he had no denial to make]. (A.) ― -b2- [Also, i. q. A_inokaArN in the sense of Disapproval, or the like: and manifestation thereof. See what here follows.] ― -b3- Also, i. q. A_inokaArN in the sense of The changing [a thing]: (T, Msb, TA:) or the changing what is munokar [here app. meaning disapproved]: (S, TA:) a simple subst. (T, TA.) The words of the Kur, [xxii. 43 and lxvii. 18,] fakayofa kaAna nakiyri are explained as signifying And how was my changing [of their condition]! (TA:) or the meaning is, and how was my manifestation of disapproval of their conduct, (A_inokaAriY Ealayohimo,) by changing favour into trial, and life into destruction, and a flourishing condition into a state of ruin! (Bd, xxii. 43.) In [some of] the copies of the K, it is said that nakiyrapN [but in a MS. copy I find nakiyrN and so in the CK] is a subst. from tanak~urN as signifying the changing, or altering, oneself, or itself; or becoming changed, or altered; from a state which please one to a state which one dislikes: but a different statement is found in the T: [see above.] and nkyrp is not mentioned by any authority. (TA.) -A2- A strong fortress. (Sgh, K.) See nukorN. -A3- See also munokarN.
nakaArapN * : see nakirapN. -A2- See also nukorN.

A^anokaru *
Worse, and worst; more, and most, evil, abominable, or foul. So it is explained as occurring in the Kur. [xxxi. 18,] A_in~ A^anokara A@loA^aSowaAti laSawotu AlHamiyri [Verily the most abominable of voices is the voice of asses]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also nakirN: and the fem., nakoraA='u, see above.

munokarN * contr. of maEoruwfN: (K:) [an explanation including several significations, here following.] ― -b2- [Ignored, or unknown; as also ↓ manokuwrN, for manokuwrN is syn. with majohuwlN [the pass. part. n. of the verb by which A^anokarahu is explained by Kr and in the K]; (TA;) and ↓ musotanokarN signifies the same. (L.) For the pls. of munokarN, see nakirN. ― -b3- [Denied, or disacknowledged. (See the verb.) ― -b4- Deemed strange, extraordinary, or improbable, (See again the verb.)] ― -b5- Any action disapproved, or disallowed, by sound intellects; or deemed, or declared, thereby, to be bad, evil, hateful, abominable, foul, unseemly, ugly, or hideous; or pronounced to be so by the law because the mind deliberates respecting the regarding it as such: and thus it is used in the Kur, ix. 113 [and other places]: (B, TA:) or anything pronounced to be bad, evil, hateful, abominable, or foul, and forbidden, and disapproved, disliked, or hated, by the law: (TA:) a saying, or an action, unapproved, not approved, unaccepted, or not accepted, by God: (KT:) unbecoming, indecent, or indecorous. (KL.) See maEoruwfN, voce EurofN. munokarN and ↓ nukorN and ↓ nukurN (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ nakoraA='u (S, Msb K) are all syn., (S, A, Msb, K,) [and are used as epithets in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] signifying a bad, an evil, a hateful, an abominable, a foul, an unseemly, an ugly, or a hideous, [and a formidable,] thing or
affair [or action or saying or quality, &c.]: (Msb:) [in this sense, its pl. is munokaraAtN and manaAkiyru; as will be seen below:] ↓ nukorN is contr. of EurofN [which is syn. with maEoruwfN]. (TA.) You say fiyhimu A@lomaEoruwfu waA@lomunokaru, and AlEurofu wAln~ukoru, [In them are good and evil qualities.] And humo yarokabuwna A@lomunokaraAti, and AlmanaAkiyra, [They commit bad, evil, abominable, or foul, actions.] (A.) And it is said in the Kur, [xviii. 73,] laqado jiy^ota $ayoy^FA nukorFA [Verily thou hast done a bad, an evil, an abominable, or a foul, thing]. (S.) -A2- The name of one of two angels, the other of whom is named nakiyrN; (S;) who are the two triers of [the dead in] the graves. (ISd, K.) -A3- See also nakirN.

manokuwrN * : see munokarN, first signification. The pl. is manaAkiyru, [which is also a pl. of munokarN,] accord. to Sb, who mentions it because, accord. to rule, the pl. of a sing. of this class is formed by the addition of w and n for the masc., and A and t for the fem. (Abu-l-Hasan, TA.)

xaraja mutanak~ir~FA *
He went forth disguised; or changed in outward appearance, or state of apparel. (TA.)
musotanokarN * : see munokarN, first signification.

TariyqN yanokuwrN *
A road, or way, in a wrong direction. (S, K.)
See Supplement

1 nakasahu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
nakusa , inf. n. nakosN, (S, Msb,) He turned it over, or upside down; inverted it; reversed it; changed its manner of being, or state: (Sh, Msb: *) he turned it over upon its head: (S, A, K:) and he turned it fore part behind; made the first part of it to be last; or put the first part of it last: (Sh:) and ↓ nk~shu, (S, A, K) inf. n. tanokiysN, (S,) signifies the same; (S, * A, K;) or has an intensive sense. (TA.) You say, nukisa Als~ahomu fiY AlkinaAnapi The arrow was turned, or put, upside down in the quiver. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [xxxvi. 68,] wamano nuEam~irohu nanokusohu fiY Alxaloqi, or, accord. to the reading of 'Ásim and Hamzeh, ↓ nunak~isohu; meaning, And him whom We cause to live long, We cause him to become in a state the reverse of that in which he was, in constitution; so that after strength, he becomes reduced to weakness; and after youthfulness, to extreme old age. (TA.) ― -b2- nakasotu fulaAnFA fiY *`lika AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) I made such a one to enter again into that affair, or state, after he had got out of it. (ISh.) [Hence the saying in the Kur, xxi. 66,] vum~a nukisuwA EalaY ruw^uwsihimo (assumed tropical:) Then they were made to return to their disbelief: (Jel:) or (tropical:) then they reverted to disputation, after they had taken the right course by means of consulting together; their return to falsity being likened to a thing's becoming upside down: and there are two other readings; ↓ nuk~isuwA, and nakasuwA; the latter meaning nakasuwA A^anofusahumo: (Bd;) or (assumed tropical:) then they reverted from what they knew, of the evidence in favour of Abraham. (Fr.) ― -b3- [And hence,] nakasahu, and nakasahu A_ilaY maraDihi, (tropical:) It made him to fall back into his disease.] (TA, in art. hyD.) And nukisa, (S, Msb, K,) or nukisa fiY maraDihi, (A, TA,) inf. n. nukosN (S, Msb, K) and nakosN (TA, [but see what is said of this below]) and nukaAsN, (Sh, K,) (tropical:) He relapsed into his disease, after convalescence, or after recovery, but not complete, of health and strength: (S, A, K:) or the disease returned to him; [he relapsed into the disease;] as though he were made to turn back to it. (Msb.) You say, A^akala ka*aA fanukisa (tropical:) [He ate such a thing, and relapsed into his disease]. (A, TA.) And taEosFA lahu wanukosFA, and sometimes one says, nakosFA, (S, K,) in this case, (S,) for the sake of mutual resemblance, (S, K,) or because nakosFA is a dial form [of nukosFA], (S,) [meaning, (assumed tropical:) May he fall upon his face, or the like, (see art. tEs,) and relapse into disease: or] may he fall upon his face, and not rise after his fall until he fall a second time: and in like manner you say, ↓ taEasa waA@notakasa. (Msb, art. tEs.) [See also 8.] You say also, nukisa AljuroHu (assumed tropical:) [The wound broke open again; or became recrudescent]. (S, in arts. Erb and HbT, &c.) ― -b4- And nakasa AlT~aEaAmu wagayoruhu daA='a AlmariyDi (tropical:) The food, &c., made the disease of the sick man to return. (K.) And nakasa AlxiDaAba EalaY raA^osihi (tropical:) He put the dye upon his head repeatedly, or several times. (A, TA. *) ― -b5- Also nakasa [or more probably nukisa] (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became weak and impotent. (Sh, in TA.) And nukisa Eano nuZaraAy^ihi, like EuniYa, (assumed tropical:) He fell short of his fellows; was unable to attain to them. (TA.) ― -b6- nakasa raA^osahu, and ↓ nk~shu, (TA,) [and nakasa alone, (see naAkisN,)] and ↓ nk~s, (L, TA, art. bqr,) and ↓ Antks, (TA,) [and in like manner ↓ tnk~s, said of a flower-stalk in the M and K, voce qi$obN,] He bent, or inclined, his head; (TA;) he lowered, or stooped, his head; bent, or hung, it down towards the ground; absolutely; or by reason of abasement. (So accord. to explanations of the act. part. n., below.)
2 nak~asa see 1, throughout.
5 tanak~asa see 1, last sentence.

8 Antks * quasi-pass. of nakasahu; (S, A, TA;) [and therefore signifying It became turned over, or upside down; became turned over upon its head; became inverted; became reversed; became changed in its manner of being, or state; it became turned fore part behind; its first part was made to be last, or was put last:] he fell upon his head. (K.) This last signification [understood figuratively] it is said to have in the phrase taEasa waA@notakasa, a form of imprecation, meaning, (assumed tropical:) May he be disappointed, or fail, of attaining his desire: for he who is overthrown in his affair (man A@notakasa fiY A^amorihi) is disappointed of attaining his desire, and suffers loss. (TA.) [See also 1, where this form of imprecation is differently explained.] ― -b2- Also, i. q. nak~asa raA^asahu. (TA.) [See 1, last signification.]

nikosN * An arrow having its notch broken, and its top therefore made its bottom: (S, A, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anokaAsN (A, TA) and [of mult.] nukusN. (A.) ― -b2- A head, or blade, of an arrow &c., having its tongue (sinox) broken, and its point therefore made its tongue: (K:) pl. A^anokaAsN. (TA.) ― -b3- A bow of which the foot is made [of] the head of the branch; as also ↓ manokuwsapN. This peculiarity is a fault. (K.) ― -b4- A child such as is termed yatonN [born preposterously, feet foremost; but yatonN is an inf. n., and I have not found it used as an epithet anywhere but in this instance]; (K;) i. q. manokuwsN; and mentioned by IDrd; but he says that it is not of established authority. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) Low, or ignoble; base; vile; mean, or sordid: See a verse cited voce A^a$~aEala: (A:) (tropical:) one who falls short of the utmost point of generosity; (K;) or of courage and generosity: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) weak; (S, K;) applied to a man: (S:) (assumed tropical:) short: (AHn:) pl. A^anokaAsN. (A, K.) ― -b6- See also munak~isN: ― -b7- and nukusN.
nukasN * , [app. pl. of nikosN,] (assumed tropical:) Old men tottering by reason of age (mudorahim~uwna) after attaining to extreme old age. (K.)

naAkisN *
Lowering his head; bending, or hanging, down his head towards the ground; [absolutely;] (S, K;) [or] by reason of abasement: (TA:) pl. [properly naAkisuwna; (see Kur, xxxii. 12;) and sometimes] nawaAkisu, (S, K,) used [only] in poetry, (S, TA,) by reason of necessity, (TA,) and anomalous, (S, K,) like fawaArisu. (S.) ElFarezdak says,
waA_i*aA Alr~ijaAlu raA^awoA yaziyda raA^ayotahum
xuDuEa Alr~iqaAbi nawaAkisa AlA^aboSaAri
[And when the men see Yezeed, thou seest them depressed in the necks, lowering the eyes]: (S:) thus the verse is related by Fr and Ks: Akh says, that it is allowable to say nawaAkisi AlA^aboSaAri, after the manner of the phrase Hujoru Dab~K xaribK; [see art. xrb;] and Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà adds
Y in relating it; saying nawaAkisiY AlA^aboSaAri. (TA.) [See the remarks on fawaArisu, pl. of faArisN.]

munak~isN * A horse that does not raise, or elevate, his head, (S, IF, K,) nor his neck, when running, by reason of weakness: (IF, K:) or that has not reached the other horses (Lth, K) in their heat, or single run to a goal; (Lth;) i. e., by reason of his weakness and impotence; as also ↓ nikosN. (TA.)

waladN manokuwsN *
A child [preposterously brought forth; whose feet come forth before his head. (A, Msb, and so in a copy of the S.) See also nikosN. ― -b2- wilaAdN manokuwsN [Preposterous childbirth] is when the feet come forth before the head; (K, and so in a copy of the S, [and that this is what was meant by the author of the S seems to be indicated by what immediately follows]) i. q. yatonu. (S.) ― -b3- TawaAfN manokuwsN A circuiting of the Kaabeh performed in a way contrary to the prescribed custom, by saluting the black stone and then going towards the left. (Mgh.) ― -b4- qaraA^a AlquraA=na manokuwsFA He read or recited, the Kur-án, beginning from the last part thereof, (K,) i. e. from [the commencement of the latter of] the muEaw~i*ataAni [or last two chapters], (TA,) and ending with the faAtiHap [or first chapter]; contrary to the prescribed mode: (TA:) or beginning from the end of the chapter, and reading it, or reciting it, to its beginning, invertedly; (K;) a mode which A 'Obeyd thinks impossible; and therefore he holds the former explanation to be the right: (TA:) each of these practices is disapproved, excepting the former in teaching children, [in which case it is generally adopted in the present day,] (K,) and [in teaching] the foreigner the [portion of the Kur-án called the] mufaS~al; an indulgence being granted to these two only because the long chapters are difficult to them: but if any one knows the Kur-án by heart, and intentionally recite it from the last part thereof to the first, this is forbidden: and if we disapprove this, still more is the reciting from the end of the chapter to the beginning disapproved, if the doing this be possible. (TA.) ― -b5- manokuwsN also signifies (tropical:) Suffering a relapse into disease, after convalescence; or after recovery, but not complete, of health and strength. (K.) ― -b6- manokuwsapN applied to a bow: see nikosN.

1 naka$a Albiy^ora * , (S, A,) or Alr~akiy~apa, (K,) aor.
naki$a (Az, S, ISd, K) and
naku$a , (IDrd, K,) inf. n. nako$N, (A,) He entirely exhausted the water of the well: (Az, S, A:) and (A) he extracted what was in the well, of black fetid mud (HamoA^ap [in some of the copies of the K, xabiyoy^ap, which is a mistranscription,]) and of clay: (A, K;) as also ↓ A_inotaka$ahaA (Sgh, K.) Hence the saying, falaAnN baHorN laA yunoka$u (S, K *) (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is] a sea, or great river, which will not be entirely exhausted, nor will diminish. (K.) And Einodahu $ajaAEapN laA tunoka$u (S, TA.) (tropical:) He has courage which will not be exhausted: said of 'Alee, by a man of Kureysh. (TA.) ― -b2- And naka$a Al$~aYo'a He consumed the thing; made it come to an end, fail, cease, perish, or come to nought: (A, K:) and the same, (ISd, A,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) or naka$a minohu, (Lth, K,) he made an end of the thing; or ceased from it, having finished it. (Lth, ISd, A, K; but in [some of] the copies of the K, faziEa is put by mistake for faraga, in this explanation. TA.) One says, A_inotahawoA A_ilaY Eu$obK fanaka$uwhu They came at last to herbage, and consumed it. (S, * TA.) And lumoEapN maA tunoka$u [A piece of herbage beginning to dry up] that is not extirpated, or cut off entirely with its roots. (K.) ― -b3- nako$N also signifies (assumed tropical:) The scrutinizing or investigating, or searching or examining or inquiring into, affairs. (TA.) [You say, app., naka$a Eani AlA^umuwri, meaning, He scrutinized, &c., affairs.] ― -b4- And naka$aAnN is like nako$N [but in what sense is not said]. (TA.)
8 A_inotaka$a see 1, first sentence.
nak~aA$N * (assumed tropical:) A man who scrutinizes or investigates, or searches or examines or inquires into, affairs; (TA;) as also ↓ minoka$N. (IDrd, K.)
minoka$N * : see nak~aA$N.

minokaA$N *
a dial. form of minoqaA$N, but of weak authority. (TA.)

manokuw$N * A receptacle of the kind called safaT of which the contents have been taken out. (TA.) ― -b2- huwa manokuw$N mina AlmanaAkiy$i (assumed tropical:) [He is one of those who are empty, or devoid of good]: a phrase denoting vituperation. (TA.)

1 nakaSa Eani AlA^amori * , (A, K,) [aor.
nakiSa , and sometimes
nakuSa , as will be shown below,] inf. n. nukuwSN (S, IF, A, Msb, K) and nakuSN (A, K) and manokaSN (K) and nakaSaAnN, (MA,) He receded, retired, or drew back from the thing, or affair, refrained, forbore, abstained, or desisted, from it; recoiled from it, shrank from it, or drew back from it in awe or fear; (S, IF, A, Msb, K;) as also nakava Eanohu. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.) You say also, nakaSa EalaY Eaqibayohi, (S, Msb, K,) or ElY Eaqibihi, (A,) aor.
nakuSa (S, Msb) and
nakiSa , (S,) or the latter only, (Sgh, TA,) or the former is allowable, (Zj, TA,) He turned back from a thing to which he had applied himself; (IDrd, S, * A, * Msb, * K, TA;) meaning a good thing; and sometimes an evil thing; (IDrd, TA;) or meaning particularly a good thing; or extr. with respect to an evil thing. (K.) [See the Kur, xxiii. 68.] Hence ↓ AntkS [as syn. with nkS], though we have not heard it. (Mgh.)
8 A_inotakaSa see above.
HaZ~uhu naAqiSN wajad~uhu naAkSN * (tropical:) [His lot, or portion, is decreasing, or deficient, and his good fortune is receding]. (A, TA.)

manokaSN * , (O, B, K,) like maqoEadN, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, munak~aS,] A place to which one removes, withdraws, or retires afar off, syn. mutanaH~FY. (O, B, K.) El-Aashà says, praising 'Alkamah Ibn-'Olátheh,
A^aEaloqamu qado jabaratoniY AlA^umuwru
A_ilayoka wamaA kaAna liY manokaSu
[O 'Alkamah, affairs have compelled me to have recourse to thee, and there was not for me any place to which to retire. (TA.)

div2.head: nkZ &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement
namaA^N * and namo'N Little live. (Kr, K.) [See also nim~apN.]

namotN *
A certain plant, having a fruit that is eaten. (L, K.) The only explanation given by several lexicographers. (TA.)

namuw*ajN * (K, Msb &c.) and A^anomuw*ajN; which latter is said to be a corruption in the TS and the K; but this is denied by El-Khafájee and by Mtr; and learned men, in early and in late times, have constantly used the word Anmw*j without any expression of disapproval; Z and El-Hasan Ibn-Rasheek El-Keyrawánee, two leading lexicologists, having even named thereby books written by them; (MF;) vulgo namuwnah [which is a Persian word]; (TA;) A model, an exemplar, a pattern, or a likeness of a thing, after the similitude of which a thing is made: (Msb:) a model, or likeness, of a thing; (K;) i. e., a thing that is made in the form, or after the fashion, of another thing, that the mode of the latter may be known thereby: (TA:) a thing which shows the mode, or quality, or qualities, of another thing: (Msb:) an arabicized word, (K,) from [the Persian] namuwdaho.

1 namira * , aor. ??, (S, K,) inf. n. namarN, (S,) [It was,
or became, spotted like a leopard or panther: see also 5:] it (a cloud, or collection of clouds,) became of the colour of the namir [leopard or panther], (S, K,) spots being seen in their interstices. (S.) -A2- See also 5, in three places.
2 nm~r * , inf. n. tanomiyrN, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, changed, or altered, and rendered morose, his face. (T.) -A2- See also 5, in two places.

5 tnm~r * [He made himself like a leopard or panther, in diversity of colours: see also 1]. 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib says,
qawomN A_i*aA labisuwA AlHadiy
da tanam~aruwA HalaqFA waqid~aA
[A people who, when they put on armour of iron mail,] make themselves like the leopard or panther (namir) in the diversity of colours of the iron [rings] and the thongs. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He made himself like the leopard or panther (namir, K, TA) in ill-nature: (TA:) (tropical:) he became angry; as also ↓ namira, (M,) aor.
namara , inf. n. ↓ namarN; (TA;) and ↓ nm~r: (M:) (tropical:) he became evil in disposition; as also ↓ namira: (T:) (tropical:) he became angry and evil in disposition; as also ↓ namira and ↓ nm~r; (IKtt, Sgh, K;) like the namir: (TA:) (tropical:) he strained the voice in threatening: (Sgh, K:) and tnm~r lahu (assumed tropical:) he became ill-natured and altered to him, and threatened him; because the namir is never met otherwise than angry and illnatured. (As, S, K.)
nimorN * : see namirN.

namirN * : see A^anomaru, throughout. ― -b2- namirN (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and nimorN, (M, A, Msb, K,) which is a contraction of the former, (Msb,) or a dial. form, (TA,) [The leopard;] a certain wild beast, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) well known, (A, K,) more malignant than the lion, (T, M, Mgh, Msb,) and bolder, (Msb,) so called because of his numar [or spots], (M, K,) being of divers colours, (M,) called in Persian Palanoko: (Mgh:) fem. with p: (S, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anomurN (M, K) and A^anomaArN, (M, Msb, K,) and [of mult.] numuwrN, (S, M, Msb, K,) held by Th to be pl. of nimorN, (M,) and numuwrapN (Msb, and so in some copies of the K) and numurN, (S, M, K,) which occurs in poetry, and is anomalous, perhaps a contraction of numuwrN, (S,) and not mentioned by Sb, (M,) and numorN, (M, K,) which is the most common in occurrence, but, accord. to Th, he who uses it makes the sing. A^anomaru, (M,) and nimaArN, (M, K,) held by Th to be pl. of nimorN, (M,) and nimaArapN. (K.) As the namir is one of the most abominable and malignant of wild beasts, one says, labisa fulaAnN lifulaAnK jiloda Aln~amiri, meaning, (tropical:) Such a one became changed, or altered, to such a one; or met him in a morose manner: (IB:) or became very rancourous, or malicious, towards him. (TA.) The kings of the Arabs, when they sat [in judgment] to slay a man, used to attire themselves in skins of the namir, and then give orders for the slaying of him whom they desired to slay. (IB.) -A2- See also namiyrN, throughout.

numorapN *
A spot, or speck, of any colour whatever: pl. numarN. (M, K.)

namirapN *
A garment of the kind called burodap, of wool, (S, K, TA,) striped, (TA,) worn by the Arabs of the desert: (S, K, TA:) or a garment of the kind called $amolap, (M, K,) or kisaA=', (A, Mgh, Msb,) having white and black stripes, or lines, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) worn by the Arabs of the desert: (A, Msb:) and a garment of the kind called Hibarap; (M, K;) so called because of the diversity of the colours of its stripes: (M:) or any my^ozar, of those worn by the Arabs of the desert, that is a striped $amolap: (IAth:) or a striped A_izaAr of wool; (TA;) pl. nimaArN: (IAth, Msb:) it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Saad, nabaTiY~N fiY Hubowatihi A^aEoraAbY~N fiY namiratihi A^asadN fiY taA^omuwratihi [A Nabathean in his hubweh (a long piece of cloth, or the like, wound round the back and legs of a person sitting with his thighs against his belly); an Arab of the desert in his nemireh; a lion in his den]. (S.) ― -b2- See also A^anomaru.
