maA='N namiyr * (T, S, M, A, K) and ↓ namirN, (M, K,) Wholesome water, whether sweet or not sweet: (S, K:) or sweet and wholesome water: (T, A:) or wholesome in satiety: (TA:) or copious: (Ibn-Keyrán, M, K:) or increasing in quantity, syn. naAmK, (As, T, TA,) or zaAkK, (K,) whether sweet or not sweet: (T, TA:) or increasing in quantity in the beasts [app. meaning while they drink], (zaAkK fiY AlmaA$iyap naAmK, T, M,) whether sweet or not sweet. (M.) [As zaAkK is coupled with naAmK, app. as an explicative adjunct, in the T and M, I think that I have here rendered it correctly: otherwise I should have supposed it to mean, perhaps, pure.] ― -b2- HasabN namiyrN, (S, M, A, K,) and ↓ namirN, (M, K,) (tropical:) i. q. zaAkK [see above]: (S, M, A, K:) pl. A^anomaArN. (M.)

A^anomaru *
Spotted white and black: (M, K:) or in which is black and white; applied to a wild beast; as also ↓ namirN: (A:) fem. namoraA='u; (M, A, K;) applied to a ewe or she-goat: (A:) pl. numorN: (A:) also A^anomaru a horse, (S, K,) and an ostrich, (K,) variegated like the namir, (S, K, TA,) having one spot white and another of any colour: (S, TA:) pl. as above: (TA:) or, applied to an ostrich, in which is blackness and whiteness: pl. as above: (S:) and a lion in which is dust-colour and blackness: and ↓ munam~arN a bird having black spots; also sometimes applied as an epithet to a horse such as is termed biro*awon. (TA.) Also, A collection of clouds of the colour of the namir, spots being seen in their interstices: (S:) or having black and white spots: (TA:) and ↓ namirN signifies a collection of clouds having marks like those of the namir: or small portions near together: n. un. with p: (M:) or ↓ namirapN signifies a small portion of a cloud: and its pl. [or rather the coll. gen. n.] is namirN. (K.) It is said in a proverb, A^ariniyhaA namirapF A^urikahaA maTirapF [Show thou it to me spotted like the leopard, I will show it to thee raining]: (S, K:) alluding to an event which one certainly knows will happen when the symptoms thereof appear: (Meyd, K, TA:) originally said by Aboo-Dhueyb El-Hudhalee: (TA:) namirap is here like xaDirFA in the Kur, vi. 99, for A^axoDara: (Akh, S:) by rule, it should be namoraA='a, (K, TA,) fem. of A^anomaru. (TA.) ― -b2- See also namirN.

munam~arN * : see A^anomaru. [In the TA, voce HibarapN, it is applied as an epithet to a garment of the kind called burod: and in the K, voce HabiyrN, to a cloud, or collection of clouds: in the former case, it app. signifies striped, (see namirapN,) or, as in the latter case, spotted.]

1 namasahu * , aor.
namusa , inf. n.namosN, He concealed it; namely, a secret. (S.) See also 2. ― -b2- He spoke, or discoursed, secretly to him, or with him; he acquainted him with a secret; (S;) as also ↓ naAmsahu, (S, M, A, K,) inf. n. munaAmasapN (M, A) and nimaAsN. (M.) You say, maA A^a$owaqaniY A_ilaY munaAmasatika [How great is my desire, or longing, for thy secret discourse!] (A, TA.) -A2- [And it seems to be indicated in the M, that namasa, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies He became a confidant, or acquainted with another's secrets.] -A3- [Hence, perhaps,] namasa bayonahumo, inf. n. as above; (IAar:) and bynhm ↓ A^anomasa, (IAar, K,) inf. n. A_inomAsN; (IAar;) He created discord, or dissension, among them, (IAar, K,) and incited them one against another, or went about among them with calumnies. (IAar.) See also 2. -A4- namisa, aor.
namasa , inf. n. namasN, It (clarified butter, S, A, K, or oil, M, and perfume, and the like, A, and anything sweet or good, M) became bad, or corrupt, (S, A, K,) so as to be slimy, ropy, or viscous; (TA;) became altered (M, TA) and bad, in the manner described above: (TA:) and ↓ nam~asa, said of [the preparation made of churned milk called] A^aqiT, it became stinking, or fetid. (TA.) See also 2, below.

2 nm~s Ealayohi AlA^amora * , (A, * TA,) inf. n. tanomiysN,
(A, K,) He concealed from him the thing, or affair; or made it dubious, or confused, to him; syn. lab~asahu. (A, K, * TA.) See also 1, first signification. -A2- nm~s biSaAHibihi He calumniated his companion; syn. nam~a bihi. (A.) See also 1. -A3- nm~s $aEaruhu His hair became befouled by oil. (M) See also 1, last sentence.

3 naAms *
He (a hunter) entered a naAmuws. i. e., lurking-place, or covert. (K.) See also 7. -A2- nAmshu: see namasahu.
4 Anms bayonahumo * : see lamasa bynhm.

5 tnm~s *
He (a hunter) made for himself a naAmuws, i. e., lurking-place, or covert. (A.) ― -b2- tunum~isa bihi: see naAmuwsN.

7 A_in~amasa * , of the measure A_inofaEala, (S, CK [in some copies of the K, AftEl, which is a mistake.]) He concealed himself: (S, K:) or An~ms fiY Al$~aYo'i signifies he entered into the thing (M, IKtt) and concealed himself. (IKtt.) See also one of the explanations of naAmuwsN, in which this verb occurs. and see 3.

nimosN * [The ichneumon; so called in the present day;] a certain small beast. (IKt, El-Fárábee, S, M, Msb, K,) broad, as though it were a piece of qadiyd [or salted or sun-dried flesh-meat]. (S) found in the land of Egypt, (S, K, *) one of the most malignant of wild animals, (M,) that kills the [kind of serpent called] vuEobaAn: (IKt. ElFárábee, S, M, Msb, K:) the keeper of vines or palm-trees or seed-produce (Aln~aAZirN) takes it for his use, when he is in vehement fear of serpents of the kind above mentioned: for it attacks them, making itself thin and slender as though it were a piece of rope; and when it winds itself upon them, they draw back their breath vehemently, and it take their breath; thus the serpent becomes inflated in its inside, and is cut asunder: (TA.) or i. g. Aibonu EirosK [the weasel]: (IKt, TA:) or a certain small beast, resembling the cat, generally frequenting gardens; accord. to IF, also called dalaqN [q. v.]; (Msb;) the beast called dalaho [the Persian original of dalaqN]; [see Aibonu miqoraDK, in art. qrD;] called nms from nam~asa in the first of the senses explained above: (A;) or i. q. ZaribaAnN: (El-Mufaddal Ibn-Selemeh, TA:) from these various sayings, it appears that several species are called by this name: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anomaAsN (TA) and [of mult.] numuwsN. (Msb.) You say, fiY Aln~aAsi A^anomaAsN [app. meaning, Among men are some that are malignant as the animals called AnmAs]. (A. TA.)
namasN * The odour of milk, and of grease or gravy; as also nasamN. (M.)

namisN * , applied to clarified butter, (A,) or oil, (M,) and perfume, and the like, (A,) and anything sweet or good, (M,) Bad, or corrupt, (A, TA.) so as to be slimy, ropy, or viscous; (TA;) altered. (M, TA.) and had, in the manner described above: (TA:) and ↓munam~isN, applied to A^aqiT, [see 1, last signification,] stinking, or fetid. (TA,)
nam~aAsN * : see naAmuwsN.

naAmuwsN *
A secret: (Seer, M:) [pl. nawaAmiysu.] ― -b2- [Hence, app., rather than from the Greek νόμος as some have supposed,] Revelation. So in a trad respecting fines for bloodshed: in which it is said, qaDayota fiynaA biAln~aAmuwsi [Thou hast pronounced judgment respecting us according to revelation]. (Mgh.) [Bat see a remark on this signification in what follows.] ― -b3- [And hence,] The law of God. (KT.) ― -b4- [And from the first,] An evasion, artifice, or expedient, by which a man conceals himself; expl. by maA yan~amisu bihi Alr~ajulu mina AlA_iHotiyAli; (S;) or maA tunum~isa bihi mina AlA_iHotiyaAli (K [but here, app., tunum~sa is a mistake for tan~amisu:]) deceit; guile; circumvention. (A, TA.) You say, fulaAnN SaAHibu naAmuwsK, and nawaAmiysa, Such a one is a person of deceit, &c., and of deceits. &c. (A, TA.) And hence the phrase nawaAmiysu AlHukamaA='i [app. meaning The artifices of the wise men]. (TA) ― -b5- [Also, in post classical writings, A man's honour, or reputation which should be preserved inviolate; syn EiroDN.] ― -b6- [The remaining significations I regard as being derived from those above mentioned; supposing a prefixed noun to be understood; in some instances, SaAHib, or *uw; in others, makaAn, or maHal~] ― -b7- A confidant; one who possesses, or is acquainted with, secrets, or private affairs; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) of a king, (Mgh, TA,) or governor, or prince, (A,) or other man; (A'Obeyd, S, M, Msb, TA;) whom are acquaints with his private affairs, and distinguishes by revealing to him what he conceals from others: (A'Obeyd, S:) or one who possesses, or is acquainted with, secrets, or private affairs, of a good nature: (K, TA:) and jaAsuwsN signifies one who possesses, or is acquainted with, secrets, or private affairs of an evil nature. (TA.) [The author of the Mgh thinks that the second of the significations mentioned above, i. e. “ revelation, ” is derived from this; a prefixed noun [such as kitaAb, perhaps,] being understood.] Hence, (Mgh,) Aln~Amuwsu, (A'Obeyd, S, M, Msb, K,) or Aln~aAmuwsu AlA^akobaru, (A, TA,) is applied to [The angel] Gabriel; (A'Obeyd, S, M, A, &c.) by the people of the scriptures; [meaning, the Christians, and perhaps, the Jews also;] (S, Mgh;) because God has distinguished him by communicating to him revelations and hidden things with which no other is acquainted. (TA.) ― -b8- A repository (wiEaA=') of knowledge. (M.) ― -b9- Skilful; intelligent. (K, * TA.) ― -b10- One who enters into affairs with subtle artifice. (As, K. *) ― -b11- A calumniator: syn. nm~aAmN; (K;) as also ↓ nam~aAsN. (A, K.) ― -b12- A liar. (M.) ― -b13- The burking-place, or covert. (qutorap, q. v.,) of a hunter, (S, M, A, K,) in which he lies in wait for the game: (TA:) sometimes written with ' [naA^omuwsN;] but for what reason [says ISd] I know not. (M.) ― -b14- A snare: syn. $arakN: (K:) because it is concealed beneath the ground. (TA.) ― -b15- The covert. or retreat. of a lion; as also ↓ naAmuwsapN. (K.) ― -b16- The chamber. or cell, of a monk. (TA, K, * voce taA^umuwrN)
naAmuwsapN * : see naAmuwsN, last signification but one.

A^anomasu *
Of a dusky, or dingy, colour, (K,) [like the nimos, or ichneumon.] ― -b2- Hence, [its pl.] numosN is applied to [A certain species (namely the kudoriY~)of] the kind of birds called qaTFA. (K.)
munam~isN * : see namisN.

munaAmisN *
Entering a naAmuws [or hunter's lurking. place]. (S.)

1 nami$a * , aor.
nama$a , (K,) inf. n. nama$N. (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, speckled with white and black: or marked with sports upon the skin differing from it in colour. (K.) See nama$N below. -A2- nama$ahu, inf. n. namo$N, He variegated it; or decorated, or embellished, it: (TA;) [as also ↓ nm~$hu, but app. in an intensive sense, for its inf. n.] tanomy$N is syn. with tadobiyjN. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) He mixed, or confounded, it, e. g., good speech with bad; as also the ↓ latter of these two words. (TA.)
2 nam~a$a see 1, in two places.

namo$N *
A mark, trace, vestige, or relic. (TA.)

nama$N *
White and black specks (S, A, Mgh, K) in a colour: (TA:) or spots in the skin differing from it in colour; (IDrd, A, K;) sometimes in horses, and mostly in such as are of a sorrel colour. (TA.) ― -b2- Lines, or streaks, of variegations or decorations in variegated or figured cloth, &c. (K.) ― -b3- Whiteness in the roots, or lower parts, of the nails, which goes away and returns. (TA.)

nami$N *
Speckled with white and black; applied to a bull; (TA:) and so ↓ A^anoma$u; (Mgh, TA;) applied to a man. (Mgh.) You say, vaworN nami$N, meaning, A wild bull, which has specks (S, TA) and lines. or streaks. (TA.) And vaworN nami$N
AlqawaAy^imi A bull having black lines, or streaks, in the legs. (A.) And ↓ EanozN namo$aA='u A she-goat that is black speckled with white, or white speckled with black. (TA.) ― -b2- sayofN nami$N (tropical:) A sword in which are diversified wavy streaks. (A, K, * TA.) ― -b3- baEiyrN nami$N A camel having in his foot a mark that becomes distinctly shown upon the ground, without any mark thereon made artificially; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) and so bEyr nahi$N. (Ibn-'Abbàd, TA.)
A^anoma$u * : fem. namo$aA='u: see nami$N, in two places.

2 tanomiyTN * signifies The directing, or guiding, to a thing. (K.) You say, mano nam~aTaka EalaY h`*aA Al$~aYo'i Who directed thee, or guided thee, to this thing? syn. dal~aka Ealayohi. (Ibn-'Abbád.)

namaTN * The facing, or outer covering, (ZihaArap,) of a bed (T, Mgh, K) upon which one sleeps, (Mgh,) or of a thing that is spread upon the ground to sit or lie upon, (T, K,) whatever it be: (K:) or a sort of carpet or other thing that is spread upon the ground: (S, K:) and a woollen cloth (Mgh, Msb, K) which is thrown over the [kind of vehicle called] hawodaj, (Mgh, K,) having a fine nap, or pile, (TA,) of some colour; what is white being seldom or never so called: (Msb:) or a sort of dyed cloth, like zawojN, these names being seldom or never applied but to what is coloured red or green or yellow; what is white not being called namaTN: (Az, L:) and a cloth that is spread beneath a horse's saddle: (Meyd, as cited by Golius:) some say, that it is a receptacle like the safaT: (Har, p. 273 [but this I think doubtful:] pl. A^anomaATN [properly a pl. of pauc. but used also as one of mult.] (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and nimaATN. (IB, K.) -A2- A body of men (S, Mgh, Msb, K) whose case is one; i. e. a class of men. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., (S, Mgh,) of 'Alee, (Mgh,) xayoru h`*ihi AlA^um~api Aln~amaTu AlA^awosaTu The best of this people is the middle body thereof (S, Mgh) whose case is one; i. e. the middle class thereof: (S, in which is added, yuloHaqu bihimu Alt~aAliY wayurojaEu A_ilayohimu AlgaAliY [he who falls short shall be made to reach them, and he who exceeds the due bounds shall be brought back to them:]) A 'Obeyd says, (Mgh, TA,) the meaning of this saying of 'Alee is, (TA,) that he disliked the exceeding of the due bounds and the falling short (Mgh, TA) in religion. (TA.) -A3- A way: (Msb, TA:) a way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, conduct, or the like; (Mgh, K;) as also ↓ AnmT: (TA [so there written, without any syll. points:]) a tenet, or body of tenets, belief, creed, opinion, or persuasion, which one takes to, or holds: (Mgh, TA:) a kind, or way, of speech. (TA.) You say, A_ilozamo h`*aA Aln~maTa keep thou to this way. (TA.) And takal~amuwA EalaY namaTK waAHidK They spoke according to one way, course, mode, or manner, &c. (Mgh.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A sort, or species, (Mgh, Msb, K,) of a thing, (K,) of goods or commodities, of learning or. science, &c. (TA.) You say, EinodiY mataAEN mino h`*aA Aln~amaTi (tropical:) I have goods of this sort, or species. (Mgh.) And h`*aA mino namaTi h`*aA (tropical:) This is of the sort, or species, of this. (Msb.)
namaTiY~N * : see A^anomaATiY~N.
AnmT * : see namaTN.

A^anomaATiY~N * [A maker, or seller, of A^anomaAT, pl. of namaTN:] a rel. n. from namaTN; as also ↓ namaTiY~N: (K, TA:) the former [from the pl.,] like A^anoSaAriY~N: the latter from the sing., agreeably with analogy. (TA.)

div2.head: nmq &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 nahiy^a * , aor.
nahaAa ; and nahuw^a, aor.
nahuAa ; (S, K;) and nahuw^a; (as in one copy of the S;) inf. n. naho'N (S, K) and nahaA^N (S) and nahaA='ap' (S, K) and nuhuwo'apN (K) and nuhuwo'N (S, K) and nahaAwapN, (the last dev. from rule); (K;) It (flesh-meat) was not, or did not become, thoroughly cooked. (S, K.) ― -b2- maA A^ubaAliY maA nahiy^a mino Dab~ika walaA maA nDija [I care not what is insufficiently cooked, of thy Dab~, nor what is thoroughly cooked: i. e. I care not whether evil or good befall thee]. (S, * TA,) A proverb. (TA.) -A2- $ariba Hat~aY nahaA^a, aor.
nahaAa , He drank till he was full. (K, * TA.)
4 AnhA^ * (S, K) inf. n. A_inohaA='N, (S,) He insufficiently cooked flesh-meat. (S, K.) ― -b2- He did a thing not firmly, not soundly, not thoroughly. (K.)
nuhuwo'N * The state of being not thoroughly cooked. (TA.)
nahiYo'N * (S, K) and ↓ munohaA^N (S) Insufficiently cooked flesh-meat. (S, K.)

naAhiy^N *
Satiated with food and with drink. (IAar.)
munohaA^N * : see nahiYo'N.

1 nahaba Aln~ahoba * aor.
nahaba , and
nahuba ; and nahibahu, aor.
nahaba ; (inf. n. nahobN; TA;) and ↓ Anthbh; [and ↓ nAhbh;] He took the spoil, plunder, or booty. (K.) ↓ AlAinotihaAbu is The taking of spoil, plunder, or booty, by whomsoever will: you say ↓ A^anohaba Alr~ajulu maAlahu [the man allowed, or gave, his property to be taken as spoil], ↓ faA@notahabuwhu, and nahabuwhu, and ↓ naAhabuwhu, which all signify the same, [and they took it as spoil]. (S.) ― -b2- nahabahu Alkalobu, aor.
nahaba , The dog seized him (a man) by the tendon of his heel. (S, K.) ― -b3- nahabuwhu; (S, K;) and ↓ nAhbwh, (K,) inf. n. munaAhabapN; (TA;) (tropical:) They carped at him in their speech, (S, K,) or, with their tongues, and spoke roughly, harshly, or coarsely, to him: [as though they plundered him of his good name]. (A.)

3 naAohaba see 1. ― -b2- nAhb Alfarasu Alfarasa, inf. n. munaAhabapN, (tropical:) The [one] horse emulated, or contended with, the [other] horse in running. (TA: and agreeably with this the inf. n. is explained in the S and K.) ― -b3- Used not only with reference to a horse. The Rájiz says,
naAhabotuhumo binayoTalK jaruwfi
[I emulated them, or contended with them, with a bucket that took up much water]. (S.) See also 6.

4 Anhb Alr~ajulu maAlahu * (S) The man allowed, or gave, his property to be taken as spoil, plunder, or booty. (TA.) It is doubly trans.: you say A^anohabotu zabodFA AlmaAla [I allowed Zeyd to take the property as spoil]. (Msb.) See 1. Anhbhu fulaAnFA He offered it, or exposed it, to such a one, [to be taken as spoil]. (TA.)

6 tnAhb AlfarasaAni * (tropical:) The two horses emulated, or contended with, each other. (TA.) See also 3. ― -b2- tanaAhabaA AlmaA='a i. q. tajaA$aEaAhu, q. v. (TA, in art. j$E.) ― -b3- tanaAhabati AlA_ibilu AlA^aroDa (tropical:) The camels took much of the ground with their legs: (K:) [app. meaning, took wide strides over it: not, as rendered by Golius, “ multum pulveris pedibus suis rapuerunt; ” nor, as rendered by Freytag, “ multum terræ pedibus abstulerunt ”]. ― -b4- AlA_ibilu yanohabona Als~uraY, and yatanaAhabonahu, [The camels perform the night-journey with large strides]: and [in like manner] tnAhbti AlA^aroDa. Camels that do so are termed A_ibilN nawaAhibu. (A.)
8 A_inotahaba see 1. ― -b2- Anthb Alfarasu Al$~awoTa (tropical:) The horse gained the winning-post; or won the race. (K, TA.)

nahobN *
Spoil; plunder; booty; (S, K;) as also ↓ nuhobapN: (TA, art. xls:) ex. A^ataY lahu binahobK he came to him with, or brought to him, spoil:
(TA:) pl. nihaAbN (S, K) and nuhuwb: (Nh, &c:) ↓ nuhobaY also signifies the same; and thus is similar to nuHolaY, meaning EaTiy~apN: and also signifies what is allowed, or given, to be taken as spoil, plunder, or booty; and thus is similar to EumoraY and ruqobaY; (IAth;) and so ↓ nuhobapN (Msb) [and ↓ nuhayobaY and ↓ nuh~ayobaY:] a man, named Fizr, said of some goats which he drove forth, hiYa Aln~uh~ayobaY, or Aln~uhayobaY, accord. to different readings; meaning that it was not allowable to any one person to take of them more than one (TA:) or nahobN signifies what is taken as spoil, plunder, or booty; or so taken by whomsoever will, of what is allowed to be so taken: syn. maA A@notuhiba: (Lh, K:) and ↓ nuhobaY, what is allowed to be so taken; syn. A_isomu maA A^unohiba: (S:) or what is taken as spoil, plunder, or booty; syn. A_isomu maA nuhiba. (So in one copy of the S.) ― -b2- [Hence] nahobN An incursion made into an enemy's territory for the sake of acquiring spoil, plunder, or booty; and a spoiling, or plundering. (TA.) -A2- A^aHorazotu nahobiY waA^abotagiY Aln~awaAfila, in a trad. of Aboo-Beker, means I have accomplished what I had to perform of the prayers termed Alwitoru before my sleeping, lest the occasion for my doing so should slip from me; and when I awake, I perform the prayers termed AlnwAfl. (TA.) [He termed the wtr prayers nahobN because he performed them before the right time.] -A3- nahobN (tropical:) A kind of rakoD [i. e., app., of running, with reference to a horse]. (Lh, K.)

nuhobapN * and ↓ nuhobaY (Lh, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ nuhayobaY and nuh~ayobaY (K) Spoil, plunder, or booty; a thing taken as spoil: (Mgh, Msb:) and also Spoliation; a taking of spoil, plunder, or booty: (Mgh:) substs. from nahaba: (K:) and substs. in the sense of AinotihaAbN: (Lh, Mgh:) ↓ nuhobaY is explained in the Towsheeh as signifying the taking of a Muslim's property by force: it is said, [of Mohammad,] in a trad., that he seattered some articles of property, and the people did not take them; so he asked them why they did not take; and they replied A^awalayosa qado nahayota Eani Aln~uhobaY [Hast thou not forbidden spoliation?]; but he said A_in~amaA nahayotu Eano nuhobaY AlEasaAkiri [I have only forbidden soldiers' spoliation]. (TA.) See nahobN.
nuhobaY * : see nahobN and nuhobapN.
nuhayobaY * : see nahobN and nuhobapN.
nuh~anobaY * : see nahobN and nuhobapN.
A_ibilN nawaAhibu * [pl. of naAhibN and naAhibahN]: see 6.
minohabN * A horse that excels in running: (K:) and in like manner an ass. (TA.)

manohuwbN *
What is sought, or sought after, quickly: syn. maToluwbN muEaj~alN. (K.)

1 nahata * , aor.
nahita , [cont? to analogy,] inf. n. nahiytN (S, K) and nuhaAtN (K) He cried out, or uttered a cry: (TA:) [see A_inohatiY EalayohaA voce bahata:] he uttered the kind of sound termed zay^iyr; [i. e., he (a lion, TA) uttered a sound from his chest; or roared:] (K:) or he uttered a sound lower than that which is termed zy^yr: (S:) or he breathed hard; or emitted the voice, or the breath, with a moaning; i. q. zaHara, (K,) and TaHara: (TA:) or he uttered a sound from his chest on an occasion of distress. (TA.)

Aln~ah~aAtu * and ↓ Alminohatu and ↓ Almunohitu (thus the last is written accord. to the K, but it occurs in a verse written ↓ Almunah~itu, TA, and in this latter manner it is written in the L,) The lion. (K.) ― -b2- A^asadN nah~aAtN, (S, L,) and ↓ munah~itN, (L,) [A lion uttering frequently a low growl]. (S, L.) ― -b3- HimaArN nah~aAtN (tropical:) An ass that brays much, or frequently. (S, K.) ― -b4- rajulN nah~aAtN (tropical:) A man that breathes hard; or emits the voice, or the breath, with a moaning. (S, K, *) See muTal~iHN.

Aln~aAhitu *
The throat; the guttur: (K:) so called because the sound termed nahiyt proceeds from it. (TA.)
Alminohatu * , and Almunohitu, and Almunah~itu: see Alnah~aAtu.

1 nahaja * , (K, Msb,) aor.
nahaja , inf. n. nuhuwjN; (Msb;) and ↓ Anhj; (S, K;) It (a road, or way, S and Msb, and an affair, TA,) became manifest, plainly apparent, or open; (S, K, Msb,) and so, with respect to a road, ↓ Astnhj. (K.) ― -b2- nahaja, (S, K, Msb,) and ↓ Anhj, (K, Msb,) He, or it, rendered (a road, S and Msb, and an affair, TA,) manifest, plainly apparent, or open: (S, K, Msb:) ― -b3- A_iEomalo EalaY maA nahajotuhu laka Do according to that which I have made manifest to thee. (S.) -A2- nahaja, aor.
nahaja , (inf. n. nahojN; TA,) and ↓ Anhj, It (attrition, TA) wore out, or rendered worn out, a garment. (K.) ― -b2- nahija, aor.
nahaja ; (A 'Obeyd, S, K;) and nahaja, (K,) but this is disallowed by A 'Obeyd, (S,) and nahuja, and ↓ Anhj; (K;) It (a garment) became old and worn out: (K:) or ↓ Anhj signifies it began to become warn out: (S:) and it became old and worn out, but without being rent in several parts. (TA.) Anhj fiyhi AlbilaY [The effect of] attrition spread through it. (IAar.) -A3- nahaja AlT~ariyqa He went along the road. (S, K.) -A4- nahija, aor.
nahaja , inf. n. nahaju; (S, K;) and nuhija, inf. n. nahojapN; (ISh;) this inf. n. also mentioned by Lth, who knew no verb belonging to it; (L;) and nahaja, aor.
nahija , (K,) inf. n. nahiyjN; (L, in art. A^nH;) and ↓ Anhj, inf. n. A_inohaAjN; (L;) He was out of breath; breathed short, or unintermittedly; panted: (S, L, K;) by reason of violent motion: said of a man, and of a beast of carriage, (L,) and of a dog. (T.) One says, fulaAnN yanohaju fiY Aln~afasi ↓ famaA A^adoriaY maA A^anohajahu Such a one is out of breath. or breathes short, or unintermittedly, or pants for breath, and I know not what hath caused him to be so, or to do so. And it is said in a trad., raA^aY rajulFA yanohaju He saw a man breathing short, or unintermittedly, or panting for breath, by reason of fatness, and putting forth his tongue, from fatigue or the like. (S.)

4 Darabahu Hat~aY Anhj *
He beat him until he became stretched along: or, until he wept: (TA:) [but probably bkY “ he wept ” is a mistake for baliYa he became worn with the beating]. -A2- Anhj He, or it, caused him (a man, S, and a beast of carriage, TA) to be out of breath, or to breath short, or unintermittedly, or to pant for breath. (S, TA.) [See an ex voce nahija.] He rode a beast of carriage so as to cause it, or until he caused it, to be out of breath, &c., (S, K,) and to become fatigued, or jaded. (TA.) -A3- See 1, throughout.
10 A_isotanohaja see 1. ― -b2- fulaAnN yasotanohiju sabiyla fulaAnK, (S.) or Tariyqa fulaAnK, (K.) Such a one follows the way of such a one. (S, K.)

nahojN * (S, K,) and ↓ nahjN (L) and ↓ manohajN and ↓ minohaAjN (S, K) A manifest, plainly apparent, or open, road, or way: (S, L, K:) and so TariyqN ↓ naAhijapN: (TA, from a trad.:) pl. of the ?? nahojaAtN and nuhujN and nuhuwjN: (L:) [and of the third manaAhij]. ― -b2- TuruqN nahojahN Manifest roads, or ways. (L.) ― -b3- And nahoju AlT~ariyqi [The plain, or open, track of the road]. (M, K, in art. sn.)
nahajN * : see nahojN.
TariyqN naAhijapN * : see nahojN.
manohajN * and minohaAjN: see nahojN.

1 nahada * , aor.
nahuda , (S, L, Msb, K,) and
nahada , (Msb, K,) inf. n. nuhuwdN, (S, L, &c.,) It (a girl's or woman's breast) was, or became, swelling, prominent, or protuberant: (S, L, Msb, K:) or became full. (Munjid of Kr.) [See also kaEaba, and faluka;
and see also naAhidN.] ― -b2- nahadato, aor.
nahuda , and
nahada ; and ↓ nh~dt, (inf. n. tanohiydN, TA,) She (a woman [or girl]) came to have swelling, prominent, or protuberant, breasts. (L, K.) ― -b3- nahadati Alqirobapu The skin became nearly full. (A.) ― -b4- nahadati Ald~alowu Almilo'a, inf. n. nahodN, The bucket became nearly full. (A 'Obeyd, L, TA.) ― -b5- nahada, (M, L, K,) aor.
nahada , (L,) inf. n. nuhuwdN, (M, L,) and nahodN, (L,) He (a man) rose; (M, L;) i. q. nahaDa; (K;) or the latter signifies “ he rose from sitting; ” whereas the former signifies “ he rose under any circumstances. ” (M, L.) ― -b6- nahada lahu, (L,) and A_ilayohi, (Th, L,) He rose to him. (Th, L.) ― -b7- nahada liloEaduw~i, (A 'Obeyd, L, K,) and A_ilaY AlEaduw~i, (S, L, Msb,) aor.
nahada , (S, L, Msb,) and
nahuda , (Msb,) inf. n. nahodN (Msb, K) and nahadN, (K,) He attacked, or assaulted; or rose and hastened and went forth to, or towards, the enemy; (S, * L, Msb;) i. q. nahaDa: (S, L:) he directed his course towards the enemy, and commenced fighting with them. (A 'Obeyd, L, K.) ― -b8- nahada, (IKtt,) inf. n. nuhuwdN, (K,) It (a thing, IKtt) went, or went away, (maDaY,) in any case. (IKtt, K.) -A2- nuhuwdN also signifies The being strong. (TA.) ― -b2- nahuda, aor.
nahuda , inf. n. nuhuwdapN, He (a horse) was, or became, large and tall: (S, L:) or bulky and strong: or goodly in body and limbs, and tall: (L:) or goodly, large in body and limbs, fleshy and tall. (K.) -A3- nahada, and ↓ Anhd, He honoured (EaZ~ama) a gift. (IKtt, K.)
2 nah~ada see 1, near the beginning.

3 nAhdhu * , inf. n. munaAhadapN, i. q. naAhaDahu; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) He attacked or assaulted him, or rose and hastened and went forth to or towards him, in war; he directed his course towards him, and commenced fighting with him. (M, L.) ― -b2- nAhdhu, inf. n. munaAhadapN, He contended or disputed with him, in an absolute sense. (TA.) -A2- naAhadahumo, [inf. n. munaAhadapN,] He contributed with them to the expenses of a journey or an expedition, clubbing with them, i. e. sharing equally with each of them. (L.) See also 6. -A3- nAhdhu, inf. n. munaAhadapN, He played with him at the game in which one puts forth as many of his fingers as he pleases, and the other does the like; he played with him at the game of morra; the inf. n. expl. by musaAhamapN biAlA^aSaAbiEi, (S, L, K,) and muxaArajapN, q. v. (TA.)

4 Anhd *
He filled a tank or cistern, (S, L,) and a drinking-bowl, (A,) and a vessel, (L, K,) so that it overflowed: (L:) or nearly filled it. (A, L, K.) ― -b2- naAqapN tunohidu AlA_inaA='a A she-camel that fills the vessel [with her milk]. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- Anhdhu He made him, or it, to rise. (L.) -A2- See 1.

5 tnh~dt *
He sighed; breathed with an expression of pain, grief, or sorrow; or uttered a prolonged breathing. (TA.)

6 tnAhdwA *
They attacked or assaulted one another, or rose and hastened and went forth to or towards one another, in war; they directed their courses one towards another, and commenced fighting. (A, Msb.) -A2- tnAhdwA; (S, Mgh, L, K;) and ↓ nAhdwA, (L, Msb,) inf. n. munaAhadapN; (Msb;) They clubbed, i. e. contributed equally to, the expenses which they had to incur, (S, Mgh, L, K,) on the occasion of a journey, (K,) or an expedition against an enemy; (L;) or contributed equal shares of food and drink: (ISd, L:) the first who instituted this practice is said to have been Hudeyn Er-Rakáshee: (TA:) or they contributed, each giving his share, for the purchase of wheat, or food, for their eating in common. (Msb.) ― -b2- tnAhdwA Al$~aYo'a They took the thing and shared it between them. (L.) -A3- tnAhdwA They played together the game of morra, described in one of the explanations of naAhadahu. (S, TA, art. xrj.)

nahodN * A high, or elevated, thing: (L, K:) as a shoulder-joint, (L,) and a horse. (TA.) ― -b2- A girl's or woman's breast: so called because of its prominence, or protuberance: (Msb:) [pl. nuhuwdN]. ― -b3- kaEovabN nahodN A pubes swelling forth, or prominent: opposed to hayodabN. (L.) ― -b4- $aAb~N nahodN A strong, bulky, youth, or young man. (L, from a trad.) ― -b5- nahodN A generous man, (S, K,) who aims at means of acquiring eminence, or nobility. (S.) ― -b6- nahodN A horse large and tall: (Lth, S, L:) or bulky and strong: or goodly in body and limbs, and tall: (L:) or goodly, large in body and limbs, fleshy, and tall: (K:) fem. with p. (L.) ― -b7- nahodu Alqa*aAli, and AlquSayoraY, A horse large and prominent in the back of the head, and, in the short ribs. (Lth, L.) ― -b8- Aln~ahodu and ↓ Aln~aAhidu The lion: (K:) from nuhuwdN in the sense of nuhuwDN and quw~apN. (TA.) -A2- nahodN Aid; assistance. (L.) See nihodN. ― -b2- TarHa nahodahu maEa Alqawomi He aided, or assisted, the people. (L.) ― -b3- Also, He contributed with the people to the expenses of a journey or expedition, sharing equally with each of them. (L.) See also 3. -A3- And see nahiydN.

nihodN * (L, K) and sometimes ↓ nahodN, (K,) or the latter signifies the action described in the following explanation, (L,) A contribution, or that which is contributed, to the expenses of a journey, equally shared by each member of the party: (L, K:) or a contribution that is made for an expedition against an enemy, by a clubbing, i. e. an equal sharing of the expenses, so that there shall be no defrauding of one by another, and no obligation of one to another. (IAth, L.) See 3 and 6. You say, haAti nihodaka Give thou thy contribution to the expenses of the journey, or expedition, equally with thy companions. (L.)

nahodaAnu * or nahodaAnN, (S, L, K,) fem. nahodaY and nahodaAnapN, (L,) A tank or cistern, (S, L, K,) and bowl, (S, A, L,) or vessel, (L, K,) full, but not yet overflowing: (S, L, K:) or full so as to overflow: (L:) or nearly full: (A, L:) or filled high: (L:) or two-thirds fall. (K.)

nuhaAdu miAy^apK *
The amount, or number, of a hundred. (K.)

nahiydN * Fresh butter that is not thin: (S, L:) or thin butter: (K:) or fresh butter of which the milk has not been quite thick and fit for churning: or a large lump of fresh butter; as also ↓ nahiydapN and ↓ nahodN: (L:) or ↓ nahiydapN signifies fresh butter made of milk that has not become thick and fit for churning, and which is therefore little in quantity, and sweet: (AHát, L:) or zubodapN nahiydapN fresh butter expressed from a skin by squeecing it. (L, art. zgd.)

nahiydapN * : see nahiydN. ― -b2- The hearts of the grains of colocynths, boiled until thoroughly cooked and thick, and then having a little flour sprinkled upon them, after which they are eaten. (S, L, K. *)

naAhidN * A girl's breast that is swelling, prominent, or protuberant: pl. nawaAhidu; which denotes more than fawaAliku. (A 'Obeyd, L.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ naAhidapN (S, L, Msb, K) and ↓ munah~idN, (L, K,) or munah~idapN, (as in the TA,) A girl, or woman, having swelling, prominent, or protuberant, breasts: (S, L, Msb, K:) or a woman whose breasts have become full: (Munjid of Kr:) pl. nawaAhidu. (Msb.) ― -b3- naAhidN A boy nearly come to the age of puberty. (A.) ― -b4- naAhidN Attacking or assaulting, or rising and hastening and going forth to or towards an enemy: pl. nuh~aAdN. (Msb.) ― -b5- See nahodN.
naAhidapN * : see naAhidN.

nahodaA='u * [fem. of A^anohadu] An elevated sand, (S, L, K,) like a compact hill, fertile, producing trees: (L:) or a tract of ground such as is called nafoxaA='u, but more flat and extensive: (L, art. nfx:) it is used as an epithet; but not the masc. A^anohadu. (L.) ― -b2- huwa A^anohadu Alqawomi He is the strongest and hardiest of the people. (R.)
munah~idN * : see naAhidN.

1 nahara * , (S, Msb,) aor.
nahara , (Msb,) It (water) ran upon, or along, the ground, (S, TA,) and made for itself a nahor [or channel like that of a river]. (S.) See also 10. ― -b2- It (anything, as in one copy of the S, or anything copious, as in another copy of the S and in the TA) ran, or flowed; (S, TA;) as also ↓ Astnhr, (S,) or ↓ Anthr. (TA.) ― -b3- It (blood) flowed with force: (Msb:)
and ↓ A^anohara it (blood) flowed (K, TA) like a river: (TA:) and the latter also, it (a vein) flowed and would not stop; (K, TA;) meaning, it flowed like a river; (TA;) as also ↓ Anthr: (Sgh, K, TA:) and ↓ Anhr also signifies the same said of the belly; (TA;) or it (the belly) became loose, or relaxed; or it discharged itself; (JK;) as also ↓ Anthr. (JK, K.) -A2- nahara, (S, K.) aor.
nahara , (K,) inf. n. nahorN, (TA,) He (a man, S) dug a nahor [or channel for a river]: (S, TA:) he made a nahor [or river] to run, or flow. (K, TA.) -A3- nahra, inf. n. nahorN, He made an inroad or incursion, or inroads or incursions, into the territory or territories of enemies, in the day-time. (TA.) -A4- naharahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
nahara , inf. n. nahorN; (TA;) and ↓ Anthrhu; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.;) He chid him; he checked him, restrained him, or forbade him, with rough speech; syn. zajarahu, (Mgh, Msb, K, and so in a copy of the S,) or zabarahu, (as in another copy of the S,) bikalaAmK galiyZK: (Mgh:) be addressed him with chiding speech, (JK, A,) forbidding him from doing evil. (JK. [in the TA, citing the last explanation from the T, Eano xayorK is erroneously put for Eano $ar~K.]) It is said in the Kur, [xciii. 10,] waA^am~aA A@ls~aAy^ila falaA tanoharo [And as for the beggar, thou shalt not chide him, or address him with rough speech]. And in a trad., mani A@notahara SaAHiba bidoEapK malaA^a A@ll~`hu qalobahu A^amonFA wiA_iymaAnFA waA^am~anahu A@ll~`hu mina AlfazaEi A@loA^akobar [Whoso chideth, or checketh with rough speech, the author of an innovation in religion, God will fill his heart with security and faith, and God will preserve him from the greatest terror]. (TA.)

4 Anhr * : see 1. in three places. -A2- (tropical:) He made blood to flow: (S:) or to appear and flow: (K:) or to flow amply and copiously: (Mgh:) or to flow with force: (Msb:) or he poured it forth copiously. (TA.) It is said in a trad., A^anohiri Ald~ama bimaA $iy^ota A_il~aA maA kaAna mino sin~i A^awo ZufurK [Make thou the blood to flow, &c., with what thou pleasest, except with what is made of a tooth or a talon.] (Mgh, Msb.) The issuing forth of the blood from the place of slaughter is likened to the flowing of water in a river. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He made it wide; (S, K;) namely, a spear-wound or the like, (S, TA,) or a nahor [or channel of a river], as is implied in the K, but in other lexicons as in the S. (TA.) -A3- He was, or became, in day-time: (S, * K, * TA:) he entered upon day-time: (MS:) from Aln~ahaAru. (S.)
8 A_inotahara see 1, in five places.

10 A_isotanohara see 1. ― -b2- It (a river [in the CK Aln~ahora is put by mistake for Aln~ahoru]) took a place, (JK,) or a settle place, (K,) for its channel. (JK, K.) ― -b3- It (a thing) became wide. (S.)

nahorN * and ↓ naharN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) A channel in which water runs: (A, K:) so most say: or the water itself [that runs therein; i. e., a river; a rivulet; a brook; a canal of running water]: (TA:) or a wide channel in which water runs: originally, the water [that runs therein]: (Mgh:) or properly, wide running water: and by a secondary application, which is tropical. (tropical:) the trench or channel [in which it runs]: (Msb, TA *:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anohurN, (Msb, K,) a pl. of the former, (Msb,) and A^anohaArN, (S, Msb, K,) a pl. of the latter, (Msb,) [but used as a pl. of either, both of pauc. and of mult. and the most common of all the pls.,] and nuhurN, (Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) with two dammehs, a pl. of the former, (Msb,) or nuhorN, (as in some copies of the K and in the TA,) and nuhuwrN, (IAar, K.) You say, jaraY Aln~ahoru [The river ran, or flowed]; like as you say, jaraY AlmiyzaAbu. (Msb.) And nahorN kaviyr AlmaA='i [A channel of running water having much water]. (A.) And ↓ naharN is also used in a pl. sense: as in the Kur, [liv. 54], fiY jan~aAtK wanaharK [In gardens and among rivers], i. e., A^anohaAri; like the phrase in the Kur, (same chap. verse 45,] wayuwal~uwna Ald~ubora, (Fr, S.) meaning AlA^adobaAra, (Fr, TA:) but it is otherwise explained. (S.) See naharN below.

naharN * : see nahorN, in two places. -A2- Amplitude: (K:) or light and amplitude: so, accord. to some, in the Kur, liv. 54, differently explained above: see nahorN, (S, TA.) or, accord. to Th, nahar is a pl. [or rather quasi pl.] of nuhurN, which is a pl. of nhaArN. (TA.)

nahirN *
Much, (TA;) as also ↓ nahyrN; (K, TA;) both applied to water. (TA.) ― -b2- A wide nahor [or river, or channel in which water runs]. (K.) -A2- raxulN nahirN A man of day-time; syn. SaAHibu nahaArK; (S, K;) who makes inroads or incursions into the territories of enemies therein: (S:) or who works therein: (A:) a kind of rel. n.; as is shown by the ex.
lasotu bilayoliY~K wal`kin~iY nhirN
laA A^udoliju All~ayola wal`kino A^abotakiro
[I am not one of the night-time, but I am one of the day-time; I do not journey in the night, but I go forth early in the morning]: as though he said ↓ nahaAriY~. (Sb.) The verse is correctly related as above; not as it is given in the S. (IB.) ― -b2- See also A^anoharu.

nahaArN *
Day; or day-time; contr. of layolN: (S, TA:) or broad daylight, (Mgh,) from sunrise to sunset: (Mgh, Msb, K:) this is the original signification: (TA;) or this is the signification in the vulgar conventional language: but in the classical language it signifies the time from the rising of the dawn to sunset: (Msb:) or the light between the rising of the dawn and sunset: (K:) and so accord. to the lawyers: (TA:) in the trads., it is the whiteness of the nhAr, and the blackness of the lyl; and there is nothing intervening between the lyl and the nhAr: but sometimes the Arabs amplified, and applied nhAr to the time from the clear shining of the dawn to the setting [of the sun]: (Msb.) or (so accord. to the TA. but in some copies of the K, and the spreading of the light [which is a cause] of sight and its dispersion: (K:) in this explanation in the L, in the place of waA@fotiraAquhu we find waA@jotimaAEuhu [and its collecting together]: (TA:) it is also syn. with yawomN; and is so when used without restriction in the non-fundamental sciences of religion, (AlfuruwE,) as in the phrases Sumo nahaArFA [fast thou a day] and A_iEomalo nahaArFA [work thou a day]: and it may be so used, or in its proper classical sense, when prefixed to yawom, governing the latter in the gen. case: (Msb:) it has no proper dual, (Mgh, Msb,) and no proper pl., (S, Mgh, Msb, K, (like Ea*aAbN and saraAbN; (S, K;) the former of which, however, has a pl. assigned to it [by Zj and] in the K, namely, A^aEo*ibapN; (MF;) [and respecting the latter see $araAbN, with $;] [for] nhAr is a name applied to every yawom [or day]; and layolN, to every layolap [or night]: one does not say nahaArN wanahaAraAni, nor layolN walayolaAni: but the sing. of nhAr is yawomN (TA.) and the dual, yawomaAni, (Msb, TA:) and the pl., A^ay~aAmN. (Msb:) and the contr. of ywomN is layolapN, so says Az, on the authority of AH(??) (TA:) or it has pls.: namely, A^anohurN, (IAar, S, K,) a pl. of pauc., (S,) in some lexicons A^anohirapN, (TA,) also a pl. of pauc.,] and nuhurN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) a pl. of mult. (S) [See also naharN.] Ibn-Keys(??) cites the following ex.,
lawolaA Alv~ariydaAn lamutonaA biAlD~umuro
variydu layolK wavriydN biAln~ahuro
[Were it not for the two thereeds (or messes of crumbled bread moistened with broth), we had died of leanness: the thereed of night, and thereed in the day-times]. (S.)
nahiyrN * : see nahirN.
nahaAriY~N * : see nahirN. ― -b2- Food that is eaten in the beginning of the day. (TA.)
nahaArN A^anoharu * , and ↓ nahrN, [A bright day:] in each of these phrases the epithet has an intensive effect, (K, * TA,) as the epithet in layolN A^aloyalu. (TA.)

manoharN * The place of a river. (T, TA.) ― -b2- A place which the water hollows out in a nahor [or channel of a river]. (K.) ― -b3- A cleft, (K, TA,) or hole, (TA,) in a fortress, passing through [the wall], whence water runs. (K, TA,) or by which water enters: (TA:) pl. manaAhiru. (TA.)

1 nahaza * , aor.
nahaza , (Msb,) inf. n. nahozN, (Msb, TA,) He rose to take a thing with his extended hand. (Msb, JK, TA.) He took a thing with his extended hand. (JK, TA.) See also 3 and 8. -A2- nahaza Al$~aYo'u The thing became near. (K.) See also 3, in two places.

3 nAhzhu * , inf. n. munaAhazapN, He strove with him, or made haste, to outstrip him; to be, or get, before him; to precede him. (TA.) You say, nAhz AlS~ayoda He made haste to get before the game, or object of the chase, (K, TA,) and seized it before its escape. (TA.) And naAhazotuhumu AlfuraSa [I strove with them, or made haste, to be before them in taking, or seizing, the opportunities, or the turns for drawing water or the like]. (S, A.) A poet says,
naAhazotuhumo binayoTalK jaruwfi
[I strove with them, or made haste, to be before them in drawing water with a capacious bucket]. (S.) -A2- Also, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He approached it; drew near to it; nearly attained to it; (K, TA;) as also ↓ nahazahu. (TA.) You say, nAhz Albuluwgu, (S, Msb,) and AlHuluma, (A, TA,) He (a boy, S, Msb) approached, drew near to, or nearly attained to, puberty. (S, A, Msb.) And nAhz Alxamosiyna [He approached, or nearly attained to, the age of fifty]. (A, TA.) And nAhz lilofiTaAmi, (A, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (Msb,) He (a child) approached, or drew near to, the [time of] weaning; (A, Msb;) as also ↓ nahaza lahu, (Msb, TA,) aor.
nahaza . (Msb.) -A3- See also 8.

6 tnAhzA *
They strove together, or made haste, each to be, or get, before the other. (K.) You say, humaA yatanaAhazaAni A_imaArapa baladi ka*aA They strive together, or make haste, each to be before the other in obtaining the government of such a town, or country. (S, * TA.) And tanaAhazuwA AlfuraSa [They strove together, or made haste, to be before one another in taking, or seizing, the opportunities, or the turns for drawing water or the like: see 3.] (A.)

8 Anthz AlfuroSapa *
He took, or seized, [or availed himself of,] the opportunity; syn. AigotanamahaA: (S, A, K:) or he arose and hastened to be before another, or others, in taking, or seizing, the opportunity; or simply he hastened to take it. (Msb.) You say, AnotahizohaA qado A^amokanatoka qabola Alfawoti [Take thou, or seize thou, it; (meaning the opportunity;) for it hath become within thy power; before the escape thereof]. (TA.) And Ainotahizo faqado A^aEoraDa laka [Take thou, or seize thou, the opportunity; for it hath offered itself to thee]. (A, TA.) Also, AnotahazahaA He took it, or them, [but to what the pronoun refers is not shown,] with his extended hand, from a near spot; and so ↓ naAhazahaA. (TA.) And Anthz Al$~aYo'a He accepted the thing, and hastened to take it with his extended hand. (TA.)

nuhozapN *
An opportunity; a time at which, or during which, a thing may be done or had; syn. furoSapN. (S, K.) ― -b2- A thing that offers itself to one as a prey, or spoil. (JK, L. *) You say, fulaAnN nuhozapu Almuxotalisi [Such a one is the prey of the snatcher]; meaning, such a one is the prey of every one. (L.) And h`*ihi nuhozapN faA@xotalisohaA [This is a thing that offers itself as a prey, therefore snatch thou it.] (A.)

naAhizN *
Approaching, or near, to the time of weaning; applied to a boy; (JK, Msb, TA;) and to a girl; (TA;) or the epithet applied to the latter is with p. (JK, Msb.)

1 nahasahu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
nahasa (Msb, K, MS) and
nahisa ; (Msb;) and nahisahu, aor.
nahasa ; (Fr, K;) inf. n. nahosN (S, Msb, TA) and nuhosN; (TA;) He (a man, S, Msb) took it (namely flesh or flesh-meat) with his fore teeth, (S, A, Msb, K,) to eat it, (Msb,) and plucked it off; (A, K;) as also ↓ Anthshu: (S:) and he ate it off from a bone (taEar~aqahu) with his fore teeth: (Lh, TA:) or he pulled it off with the central incisors, to eat it: (TA:) and he took it with the fore part of his mouth; as also ↓ Anthshu: (A:) or he took it with his mouth: (IAth, TA:) or he took it with his mouth to bite it and make a mark upon it without wounding it: (TA, art. nh$:) and he (a dog, and any animal having a canine tooth,) bit it: or seized it, and then pulled it, or pulled it vehemently, or rent it with his teeth: but there is a difference of opinion respecting this verb in all its significations: some say that it is with the unpointed s; and thus, only, it is mentioned by ISk, who says, I heard El-Kilábee say, of a dog and of a wolf and of a serpent, ↓ Anthshu and nahasahu; (Msb;) [and J says, the nahos of the serpent is the same as its naho$; (S;) you say nahasatohu AlHay~apu in the sense of naha$atohu [the serpent bit him]: (Z, Sgh:) others say that the verbs are with s and $ throughout; and thus says IF on the authority of As: Az cites Lth as saying that naho$N, with the pointed $, signifies taking, or reaching, from a distance, like the nh$ of the serpent; and nahosN, with the unpointed letter, the seizing upon flesh, or flesh-meat, and pulling it, or pulling it vehemently, or rending it with the teeth: Th says that the latter is with the extremities of the teeth; and the former, with the teeth [absolutely], and with [those that are termed] the A^aDoraAs: IKoot says, like Lth, that one says of the serpent (AlHay~ap), naha$atohu, with the pointed $; and of the dog and wolf and hyena, nahasahu, with the unpointed letter. (Msb.)
8 A_inotahasa see 1, in three places.
nuhuwsN * : see nah~aAsN, in two places.
nahiysN * : see manohuwsN, in two places.

nah~aAsN * A dog that is wont to bite; (Msb;) and ↓ nahuwsN, applied to a she-camel, signifies the same; (TA;) and the latter, a lion that bites a thing when able to do so: (IKh:) or the former, a dog that is wont to seize, and then pull, or pull vehemently, or rend with his teeth. (Msb.) ― -b2- A lion; as also ↓ nahuwsN and ↓ minohasN. (K.) ― -b3- A wolf. (TA.)

manohasN *
A place from which a thing [such as herbage &c.] is taken with the mouth and eaten: (K, * TA:) pl. manaAhisu. (TA.) You say, A^aroDN kaviyrapu AlmanaAhisi Land abounding in such places. (TA.)
minohasN * : see nah~aAsN.

manohuwsN * A man having little flesh; (S, A, K;) [as though it were partly eaten off the bones;] as also ↓ nahiysN. (TA.) You say also, manohuwsu Alqadamayoni, (A, K,) or AlkaEobayoni, (TA,) A man (TA) having little flesh upon the feet, (A, * K, * TA,) or upon the ankles. (TA.) And waZyfN ↓ nahiysN [A shank of a quadruped] light of flesh. (TA.) See also manohuw$N.

1 naha$ahu * , (S, K,) aor.
naha$a , (K,) inf. n. naho$N, (S,) i. q. nahasahu; (S, K;) i. e. He took it with his mouth to bite it and make a mark upon it without wounding it: [&c.:] (TA:) or he took it (namely flesh or flesh-meat) with his fore teeth: (S:) and so accord. to some, ↓ Anth$hu. (S.) And It [a serpent or scorpion] bit him; or stung him; syn. lasaEahu: (K:) you say, naha$atuhu AlHay~apu the serpent bit him. (S.) And He (a dog, TA) bit him, or it; (K;) as also nahasahu. (TA.) Or He took it with his [teeth that are called] A^aSoraAs: whereas nahasahu signifies he took it with the extremities of the teeth: (K:) or naho$N is less then nahosN; the latter signifying the taking, or reaching, with the mouth; but the former, the taking, or reaching, from a distance, like the nh$ of the serpent. (Lth, TA.) [For other observations on these two verbs, see art. nhs.] ― -b2- naha$ahu Ald~ahoru faA@HotaAja (IAar, S, K) (tropical:) Time, or fortune, bit him, so that he became in want. (TA.) ― -b3- naha$ato wajohahaA She (a woman) seized the flesh of her face with her nails. (TA.) ― -b4- naha$ahu
also signifies (assumed tropical:) He, or it, harassed, distressed, fatigued, or wearied him. (IAth.) ― -b5- nuhi$a, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He became emaciated, or lean: and A^aEoDaAdunaA ↓ A^unotuhi$ato (assumed tropical:) our arms from the elbow upwards became emaciated: (TA:) and nuhi$ato EaDudaAhu (assumed tropical:) his arms from the elbow upwards became slender, (ISh, K, [but in the CK duq~atA is put by mistake for daq~ataA]) and their flesh became little. (ISh.)
8 A_inotaha$a see 1, in the first and last sentences.
naho$N * : see manuhuw$N.
nahi$N * : see manohuw$N, in five places. ― -b2- As an epithet applied to a camel, i. q. nami$N, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) as explained in art. nm$. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)
nahiy$N * : see manohuw$N.

manohuw$N * (assumed tropical:) A man harassed. distressed, fatigued, or wearied: (S, IAth, K:) (tropical:) bitten by time, or fortune, so as to be in want, (IAar, S, K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) and emaciated, or lean: or having little flesh, even if fat: or light; as also ↓ naho$N and ↓ nahi$N and ↓ nahiy$N. (TA.) Applied to the pudendum muliebre, (assumed tropical:) Having little flesh; as also ↓ nahi$N. (TA.) And in like manner, manohuw$u Alfaxi*ayoni (assumed tropical:) Emaciated, or lean, in the thighs. (TA.) And manohuw$u Alqadamayon (assumed tropical:) A man having little flesh upon the feet. (IAar, K.) And Alyadayoni ↓ nahi$u (tropical:) A man, (TA,) or a beast of carriage, (S,) light in the arms, or fore legs; (S, K, TA;) as though from AlHay~api ↓ naho$u: (S:) and so ↓ nahi$u AlqawaAy^imi (tropical:) light in the legs, (K, TA,) in passing along, and having little flesh upon them; (TA;) as also ↓ nahi$u Almu$aA$i. (S * TA.) [But see also mu$aA$N.]
munotahi$apN * A woman scratching her face in affairtion or misfortune. (K, TA.) Such Mohammad cursed. (TA.)

1 nahaDa * , aor.
nahaDa , inf. n. nuhuwDN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and nahoDN, (S, A, K,) He rose, or stood up. syn. AirotafaEa, (Msb,) or qaAma, (S, Mgh, O, K,) Eano makaAnihi from his place; (Msb;) as also ↓ AnthD, syn. qaAma: (IAar:) or the former, he quitted a place: and he rose from it: (M, TA:) or he rose from sitting; thus differing from nahada, which signifies “ he rose ” under any circumstances: (M, L, in art. nhd:) [and he rose and went: or he rose and hastened, as shown below:] and ↓ AnthD, he was, or became, made, or excited, to rise, or stand up; quasipass. of A^anohaDahu. (S.) You say, nahaDa A_ilayohi He rose, or stood up, to him: (Mgh.) and liA^amorK [to do, or perform, an affair] (S, K. *) And nahaDa A_ilaY AlEaduw~i He [rose and] sped, or hastened. to, or towards, the enemy. (Msb.) [See also ??.] And nahaDonaA A_ilaY Alqawomi and nagaDonaA A_ilayohimo [We rose and sped, or hastened, to. or towards, the people, or company of men:] both signify the same. (Abu-l-Jahm El-Jaafaree.) And ↓ AnthDwA and ↓ tnAhDwA signify the same as nahaDuwA liloqitaAli [They rose and sped, or hastened, to fight, or to the fight]. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (a plant) stood erect; or became strong and erect. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a bird) spread, or expanded, its wings to fly. (S, A, Mgh, K.) You say, faroxN EaAjizu Aln~uhoD [A young bird lacking the power of spreading its wings to fly, (A, TA.) [See an ex. in a verse of El- Hoteíäh cited in the first paragraph of art. xlf.] ― -b4- nahaDato nafosuhu (K in art. j$A^. &c.) and nahaDato nafosuhu A_ilayohi (S in the same art, and A in art. jh$, &c.) signify [the same. i. e.] ja$A^ato (assumed tropical:) [His said, or stomach, heaved, &c.] (S, A, K. in the arts. above mentioned.) ― -b5- nahaDa Al$~ayobu fiY Al$~abaAbi (tropical:) [Hoariness a rose in youth] (A, TA.) As cites the following verse from an anonymous poet:
Alor~iEodapu fiY ZuhayoriY ↓ tanotahiDu
mino laduni AlZ~uhori A_ilaY AlEuSayori
(assumed tropical:) [Tremor arises in my little back from the time of noon to the little evening.). (TA.)
3 nAhDhu * , (S, A, &c.,) inf. n. munaAhaDapN, (TA,) He rose with him, or against him, and withstood him, or opposed him, in contention; syn. qaAwamahu; (S, Mgh, K;) namely his adversary. (A, Mgh.)

4 AnhDhu *
He made him, or excited him, to rise, or stand up. (S, A, * K, TA:) or he roused him. or put him in portion to rise. (TA.) You say also, liloA^amori ↓ A_inotahaDotuhu, [if this be not a mistranscription for ??,] I made him to rise to (do, or perform,] the affair. (Msb,) And AnhDhu EalaY Al$~aYo'i (assumed tropical:) He strengthened him to rise, and do, or perform, the thing. (TA.) ― -b2- AnhD Alqirobapa: He nearly filled the water-skin [so as to make it rise]. (K. TA.) ― -b3- A^anohaDati Alr~iyHu Als~aHaAba (tropical:) The wind bore and drove along the cloud, or clouds. (TA.)

6 tnAhDwA fiY AlHarobi * (S, A, Mgh, K) They rose, one with another, or one against another, and withstood, or opposed, one another. in war. or battle: (Mgh,) or each party of them rose and hastened (nahaDa) to, or towards, the other, in war. or battle. (S, K. *) See also 1.
8 A_inotahaDa see 1. in four places: -A2- and see 4.

10 AstnhDhu liA^amori ka*aA *
He ordered him, or commanded him, to rise to [do, or perform,] such an affair. (S, K. *) [And AstnhDhu fiY A^amorK] He sent him on an affair, to perform it.]

nahoDapN * [inf. n. of un. of 1, A single act of rising, &c.: and] a motion, or movement: pl. nahaDaAtN. (Msb.) You say, jaA='ato minohu nahoDapN, (A, TA,) or kaAnato minohu nahoDapN, There was (a rising, or) a motion, or movement, on his part. (Msb,) limHal~ ka*aA [to such a place], (A TA,) or A_ilaY ka*aA (to, or towards, such a thing]. (Msb.) And huwa kviyru Aln~ahaDaAti [He is a person of frequent risings, or motions or movements]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) Power, or ability; and strength. (TA.)
nuhoDapN * [The act of rising, or standing up: or the state of being made, or excited, to rise, or stand up] a subst. from AlA_inotihaADu (TA.)

nah~aADN * [One who frequently rises; or who frequently rises from, or quits, his place:] quick on motion. (Expos. of the Mo'allakát, printed at Calcutta, p ??) ― -b2- huwa nah~aADN nih`w^ulaA='i (tropical:) [app. He is wont to rise with these, for their assistance. see naAhiDapN]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- huwa nah~ADN bibazolaA='a: see art. bzl.

naAhiDN * [act. part. n. of 1, Rising, or standing up: &c.]. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Energetic, sharp, vigorous, or effective in his agency, or work. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A young bird whose wings have became complete, (S, A, Mgh.,) or whose wing has became complete, (K,) and which has risen, (S,) or is able. (A, Mgh,) or ready, (K,) to fly: (S, A, Mgh, K:) (??) has spread its wings to fly: or that has raised itself to quit its place applied by some particularly to the young or the eagled. (TA.) pl. nawaAhiDu. (A, Mgh.) [See also EaAtiqN.]

naAhiDapu rajulK * (tropical:) A man's people, (L,) or the sons of his father or ancestor, (S, O, K,) who rise for him, (O,) or with him. (K,) or with whom he rises, in a case that grieves him, (L,) or who are angry for him, (S,) or who are angry by reason of his anger, and rise to aid him: (TA:) and his people, (A,) or servants, (K,) or those, (S,) who undertake, or manage, his affairs: (S, A, K:) or his aiders, or assistants. (A, in art. Zhr) You say, maA lifulaAni naAhiDapN (tropical:) Such a one has not any (S, A) people, (A,) or servants, (TA,) who undertake, or manage, his affairs. (S, A, TA.)

div2.head: nhl &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 naA='a * , aor. yanuwo'u, inf. n. nawo'N (S, K) and tanowaA='N, (K,) He rose, or arose, with effort and difficulty. (S, K.) ― -b2- naA='a biHimolihi He rose with his burden with effort and difficulty. (TA:) he rose with his burden oppressed (??) its weight. (S, K.) ― -b3-
tanuwo'ubiEajiyzatihaA She rises with her buttocks oppressed by their weight: said of a woman. (S.) ― -b4- naA='a biSadorihi He arose. [App. said originally, if not only, of a camel.] (TA.) ― -b5- naA'a bihi and ↓ AnA'hu, It (a burden) oppressed him by its weight, and bent him, or weighed him down. (S, K,) ― -b6- tanuwo'u bihaA EajiyzatuhaA Her buttocks oppress her by their weight: said of a woman. (S.) ― -b7- naA='a He was oppressed by weight, (K,) and fell down: (S, K:) thus the verb bears two [partially] opposite significations. (K.) ― -b8- naA='a bijaAnibihi (assumed tropical:) He behaved proudly. (TA, art. mT.) ― -b9- naA='a Aln~ajomu, aor. yanuwo'u, inf. n. nawo'N; and ↓ AstnA' and A_isotanoA^aY (K; the latter being formed by transposition, TA) The star, or asterism, [generally said of one of those composing the Mansions of the Moon,] set (accord. to some), or rose (accord. to others), aurorally, i. e. at dawn of morning. (TA.) See nawo'N. [It seems that nA' is used in both these senses because the star or asterism appears as though it were nearly overcome by the glimmer of the dawn.] -A2- naA='a, (K,) formed by transposition from naA^aY, (TA,) or a dial. form of this latter, (S, TA,) He, or it, was, or became, distant; removed to a distance; went far away. (S, K.) ― -b2- nA' bihi [It rendered him distant, or removed him to a distance]. (TA.) -A3- maA saA='aka wanaA='aka (S) [see explained in art. swA^]: nA'k is here used for A^anaA='aka, in order to assimilate it to sA'k; (S;) like as they say hanaA^aniY wamaraA^aniY, for A^moraA^aniY. (TA.)

3 nAwA^hu * , inf. n. munaAwaA^apN and niwaA='N, He contended with him for glory; vied with him. (K.) ― -b2- He acted hostilely towards him. (S, K.) Sometimes without '; but originally with '; being derived from naA='a A_ilayoka and nuw^otu A_ilayohi. (S.)
4 A^anowaAa see 1.

10 AstnA' binajomK * [He prognosticated rain &c. by reason of the rising or setting of a star or an asterism aurorally, i. e., at dawn of morning: or he regarded a star or an asterism as a nawo']. (L.) It is said, laA tasotaniY'u AlEarabu biAln~uHuwmi kul~ihaA [The Arabs do not prognosticate rain &c. by reason of the auroral rising or setting of all the stars, or asterisms: or do not regard all the stars or asterisms as A^anowaA. (Sh, L.) A_isotanoA^awoA AlwasomiY~a, the ' being transposed, They expected, or looked for, the rain called AlwsmY, [from the auroral rising or setting of a star or an asterism]. (AHn.) -A2- A_isotanaA='ahu (assumed tropical:) He sought, or asked a gift, or present of him. (K.)

nawo'N * , pl. A^anowaA='N and nuwA=nN, (S, K,) A star, or an asterism, verging to setting: or the setting of the star, or asterism, in the west, aurorally, i. e., at dawn of morning, and the rising of another, opposite to it, at the same time, in the east: (K:) or the setting of one of the stars, or asterisms, which compose the Mansions [of the Moon (see manaAzilu Alqamari)], in the west, aurorally, i. e., at dawn of morining, and the rising of its raqiyb, which is another star, or asterism, opposite to it, at the same time, in the east, each night for a period of thirteen days: thus does each star, or asterism, of those Mansions, [one after another,] to the end of the year, except Aljabohap, the period of which is fourteen days: (S:) [or it signifies the auroral rising, and sometimes the auroral setting, of one of those stars, or asterisms; as will be shown below: I do not say “ heliacal ” rising because the rising here meant continues for a period of thirteen days]. Accord. to the T, nw' signifies the setting of one of the stars, or asterisms, above mentioned: and AHn says, that it signifies its first setting in the morning, when the stars are about to disappear; which is when the whiteness of dawn diffuses itself. (TA.) A'Obeyd says, I have not heard nw' used in the sense of “ setting, ” “ falling, ” except in this instance. (S.) It is added, [whether on his or another's authority is doubtful,] that the [pagan] Arabs used to attribute the rains and winds and heat and cold to such of the stars, or asterisms, above mentioned as was setting at the time [aurorally]; or, accord. to As, to that which was rising in its ascendency [aurorally]; and used to say, muTironaA binawo'i ka*aA [We have been given rain by such a nw']; (S;) or they attributed heat [and cold] to the rising or the star or asterism, and rain [and wind], to its nawo' [meaning its setting]. (AHn, Har, p. 216.) This the Muslim is forbidden to say, unless he mean thereby, “ We have been given rain at the period of such a nw'; ” God having made it usual for rain to come at [certain of] the periods called AnwA'. Again, A'Obeyd says, The AnwA' are twenty-eight stars, or asterisms; sing. nw': the rising of any one of them in the east [aurorally] is called nw'; and the star, or asterism, itself is hence thus called: but sometimes nw' signifies the setting. Also, in the L it is said, that each of the abovementioned stars, or asterisms, is called thus because, when that in the west sets, the opposite one rises; and this rising is called Aln~w'; but some make nw' to signify the setting; as if it bore contr. senses. (TA.) [El-Kazweenee mentions certain physical occurrences on the occasions of the AnwA' of the Mansions of the Moon; and in each of these cases, except three, the nw' is the rising, not the setting. Two of the excepted cases are doubtful: the passage relating to the third plainly expresses an event which happens at the period of the auroral setting of AlS~arofap; namely the commencement of the days called A^ay~aAmu AlEajuwzi; corresponding, accord. to ElMakreezee, with the rising of Alfarogu Almuqad~amu, the rqyb of AlSrfp: and it is said in the S, art. Ejz, on the authority of Ibn-Kunáseh, that the Ay~Am AlEjwz fall at the period of the nw' of AlSrfp. (The auroral setting of AlSrfp, at the commencement of the era of the Flight, in central Arabia, happened about the 9th of March O. S.; and this is the day of the N. S., the 26th of February O. S., on which commence the Ay~Am AlEjwz accord. to the modern Egyptian almanacs.) Hence it appears, that sometimes the setting, but generally the rising, was called the nw'. Moreover, the ancient Arabs had twenty-eight proverbial sayings (which are quoted in the Mir-át ez-Zemán, and in the work of El-Kazweenee) relating to the risings of the twenty-eight Mansions of the Moon: such as this: A_i*aA TalaEa Al$~araTaAno A_isotawaY Alz~amaAno “ When Esh-Sharatán rises, the season becomes temperate: ” or, perhaps, “ ― -b2- the night and day, become equal. ” (If this latter meaning could be proved to be the right one, we might infer that the Calendar of the Mansions of the Moon was in use more than twelve centuries B. c.; and that for this reason Al$rTAn was called the first of the mansions; though it may have been first so called at a later period as being the first Mansion in the first Sign of the Zodiac. But I return to the more immediate object which I had in view in mentioning the foregoing sayings.) I do not find any of these sayings (though others, I believe, do) relating to the settings. Hence, again, it appears most probable, that the rising, not the setting, was generally called nw'.] ― -b3- [In many instances,] AlA^anowaA='u signifies The Mansions of the Moon [themselves]; and nawo'N, any one of those Mansions: and they are also called nujuwmu AlmaTari [the stars, or asterisms, of rain]. (Mgh, in art. xTA^.) IAar says that the term nw' was not applied except in the case of a star, or asterism, accompanied by rain: (TA:) [see exs. under xaT~a and xaT~aA^a: but most authors, it seems, apply this term without such restriction: it is sometimes given to certain stars or asterisms, which do not belong to the Mansions of the Moon; as will be seen below: and it is applied, with the article, especially to Alv~uray~aA]. ― -b4- Accord. to AZ, as cited by AM, the first rain is that called AlwasomiY~u: the AnwA' of which are those called AlEaroquwataAni Almuw^ax~arataAn, the same, says AM, as Alfarogu Almuw^ax~aru, [the 27th Mansion of the Moon, which, about the period of the commencement of the era of the Flight, (to which period, or thereabout, the calculation of AZ, here given, most probably relates,) set aurorally, (for by the term nw' AZ means a star or asterism, at the setting of which rain usually falls,) in central Arabia, on the 21st of Sept. O. S, as shewn in the observations on
the mnAzl Alqmr in this lexicon]: then, Al$~araTu, [one of the $araTaAni, the 1st Mansion, which, about the period above mentioned, set aurorally on the 17th of Oct.]: then, Alv~uray~aA, [the 3rd Mansion, which, about that period, set on the 12th of Nov.]. Then comes the rain called Al$~atawiY~u: the AnwA' of which are AljawozaA'u [meaning AlhaqoEapu, the 5th Mansion, which, about the period above mentioned, set aurorally on the 8th of Dec.] then, Al*~iraAEaAni, [i. e. Al*~iraAEu AlmaqobuwDapu and Ald~iraAEu AlmabosuwTapu; the former of which, about the same period, set anti-heliacally on the 3rd of January, the proper relative time of the setting of the 7th Mansion; and the latter, on the 16th of January, the proper relative time of the setting of the 8th Mansion;] and their navorap, [the 8th Mansion, which, about that period, set aurorally on the 16th of Jan.]: then, Aljabohapu, [the 10th Mansion, which set aurorally, about that period, on the 11th of Feb.] In this period the $twY rain ends; and that called Ald~afay^iY~u (q. v.) begins, and [after this] AlS~ayofu. All the rains from the wsmY to the dfy^Y are called rabiyEN. Then, [after the dfy^Y,] comes the Sayof: the AnwA' of which are Als~imaAkaAni (AlA^aEozalu and Alr~aqiybu); [the former of which is, accord. to El-Kazweenee, the 14th Mansion, which, about the period above mentioned, set aurorally on the 4th of April: the latter seems to be the rqyb of Alvry~A (see rqyb): i. e. AlA_ikoliylu, the 17th Mansion, which, about the same period, set aurorally on the 13th of May; a period of about forty days. Then comes AlHamymu. [see this word, said by some to be] a period of about twenty nights, commencing at the [auroral] rising of Ald~abaraAn, [at the epoch of the Flight about the 26th of May, O. S.,] which has [little rain, or none, and is therefore said to have] ?? nw'. Then comes Alxaryfu [a period of little rain the AnwA' of which are Aln~asoraAni [or the two vultures, Aln~asoru AlwaAqiEu and Aln~asoru AlT~aAy^iru, which, in central Arabia, about the period above mentioned, set aurorally on the 24th of July, O. S., both together]: then, AlxDr, [which I have not been able to identify with any known star or asterism, in the TT with SH written above it, to denote its being correctly transcribed]: then, AlEaroquwataAni AlA^uwlayAni, the same says AM, as Alfarogu Almuqad~amu, the 26th Mansion, which, about the same period, set on the 8th of Sept.]. (T, TT, TA. *) ― -b5- [Hence,] nawo'N [also means (assumed tropical:) The supposed effect of a star or asterism so termed in bringing rain &c.: whence the phrase laA nawo'a lahu It has no effect upon the weather; said of a particular star or asterism: see AlbuTayonu. ― -b6- Also. Rain consequent upon the annual setting or rising of a star so termed (assumed tropical:) so in many instances in Kzw's account of the Mansions of the Moon.] And (tropical:) Herbs, or herbage: so called because regarded as the consequence of what is [more properly] termed nw': [i. e., the auroral setting or rising of a star or asterism, or the rain supposed to be produced thereby.] Ex. jaf~u Aln~awo'u The herbage dried up. (IKt.) Also, (tropical:) A gift, or present. (K.)

A^anowaA^u *
More, or most, acquainted with the A^anowaA=' (K, and some copies of the S) [See nawo'N, It is an anomalous word, though of a kind of which there are some other examples, for it has no verb] and, by only, a noun of this class is not formed but from a verb. (TA)
musotabaA='N * (assumed tropical:) One of whom a gift, or present, is sought, or asked, (K.)

1 nubotuhu * , aor. yanuwbu inf. n. nawobN; and ↓ Ainotabotuhu; I came to him by turns, (TA,) ― -b2- * AinonaAbahumo, inf. n. AinotiyaAbN, He came to them time after time, (S, K.) The Hudhalee (Aboo-Sahm Usámeh, TA,) says,
??
??
(S) Slender in the belly, an object of the chase, in a part of the desert far from roster and pasture; he will not come to the water otherwise than time after time. The port is describing a wild ass. (IB.) Accord to one relation, the last word is Aiy^otiyaAbaA. meaning “ coming by night. ” (S,) ― -b3- [Also, ↓ AntAb, app., He did a thing time after time; did a thing by turns. (See munotaAbN.] ― -b4- naAba, aor. yanowbu inf. n. nawobN, He drove camels early in the morning to the water, and was [again] at the water in the evening, going to it thus] time after time (IAar) ― -b5- naAba A_ilaY All~`h; (K;) and ↓ AnAb A_ilayohi, (S, K,) inf. n. A_inaAbapN; (TA:) obedience He returned from disobedience to obedience to God, he returned unto God [repenting]: he repented; (S, K:) or the latter, he returned unto God; syn. rajaEa (Msb:) or nAb signifies he kept to obedience unto God: [this is given in the K as another and distinct signification of nAb ?? and AnAb signifies as before explained or he returned to the performance of God, command; not departing from anything thereof: or be returned time after time: the In. signification, accord. to the Kesh-sháf and AHei, is he entered upon the good turn. (TA, where for Alxyl read Alxyr.) ― -b6- naAba Ean~iY, aor. yanuwbu, inf. n. nawobN and manaAbN (S, K: but the former inf. n. which is mentioned by Th, is omitted in some copies of the S) and niyaAbapN (Msb: [the only inf. n. there mentioned:] but this last, though also mentioned in the L, is rejected by Th and the other early authorities as not belonging to the classical language of the Arabs: TA) He supplied my place; served for me; acted in my place or stead, or as my substitute, lieutenant, deputy, factor, or agent; (S, K, &c.: fiY ka*aA in such an affair. (Msb.) ― -b7- naAba Eanohu [and naAba manaAbaha] It (a thing) supplied its (another thing's) place. (TA.) ― -b8- naAbahu A^amorN, aor. yanuwbu. (S.) inf. n. nawobN and nawobapN; (K, TA;) and ↓ A_inotaAbahu; (S;) a thing, or an event, [generally a misfortune, or an evil accident,] befell him; betided him; happened to him. (S, K.)

3 nAwbhu * , (inf. n. munaAwabapN, TA,) He did [or tock] a thing with him, each taking his turn ?? EAqbh. (K.) ― -b2- naAwabotuhu, inf. n. manaAwabapN i. q. ?? [q. v., here signifying I shared with him. ?? (Msb.)

4 A^anabotuhu Eanohu * . (K,) and ↓ Asotanabotuhu, (TA.) I made him to supply his [another's] place to act in him place or stead, or as his substitute, lieutenant, deputy, factor, or agent; (K, Msb;) fiY ka*aA in such an affair. (Msb.) ― -b2- See 1. ― -b3- A^ataAniY fulaAnN famaA A^anabotu lahu Such a one came to me, and I cared not for him, or paid any regard to him. (A.)

6 tanaAwabonaA AlxaToba * , and AlA^amora, We performed the affair, or business, by turns; or turn after turn. (T.) humo yatanaAwbuwna Aln~awobapa fiymaA bayonahumo fiY AlmaA'i wagayorihi [They took turns in the case of a thing that was between them; in the case of water &c.] (S.) ― -b2- tanaAwabuwA Ealayohi They did it by turns; this person doing it one time: and that, another. (Msb.) ― -b3- tanaAwabuwA, as also tnAzlwA and tTAEmwA, They (a people on a journey ate with or of the tent of, [meaning, of the food of.] this man on one occasion of alighting, and another man on another occasion of alighting; each one of them having his tarn to supply the food of one day. (ISh.) ― -b4- tanaAwabawA EalaY AlmaA'i, (K,) or tnAwbwA AlmA'a, (L,) They shared the water among themselves [by turns] by means of the HaSaAp Alqasomi, (K,) or Almaqolpu: (L;) which is a pebble that is put into a vessel: then as much water as will come the pebble is poured into the vessel: this is done by persons on a journey when they have little water; and thus they divide it into shares. (K, arts. qsm and mql.) ― -b5- AlmanaAyaA tatanaAwabunaA Deaths come to us by turns; to each of us in his turn. (TA.)
8 A_inotawaba see 1.
10 A_isotanowaba see 4.

Aln~awobN *
What is a day's and a night's journey distant from one: (S, K:) what is a night's journey distant is called Alqarabu: originally in the
case of going to water: (S:) or what is three days' journey distant: or what is two leagues (farosaxaAni) distant; or three. (TA.) Lebeed says,
A_iHodaY baniY jaEofarK kalifotu bihaA
lamo tumosi min~iY nawobFA walaA qarabaA
[I have become enamoured of one of the descendants of Jaafar: she has not become a day's and a night's journey (or three days' journey or two eagues,) distant from me, nor a night's journey distant]. (S.) Or nwb signifies [in these words of the poet] near, so that he might visit her repeatedly; and qrb and nwb are synonymous: (IAar:) or qrb [is used by him to signify that at such a distance] he might come to her once in three days. (AA.) -A2- nawobN Strength: (K:) as also ↓ nawobpN: ex. A^aSobaHota laA nawobapN laka Thou hast become without strength: and tarakotuhu laA nawobN lahu I left him without strength. (TA.) ― -b2- nawobN Nearness. (ISk, S, K.) -A3- nawobN a pl. (or rather a quasi. pl. n., TA) of naAy^ibN: (RA, K:) [but in what sense I do not find: app., as the act. part. n. of naAba “ it befell, &c. ”]

nubN *
Bees: pl. of naAy^ibN: (S, K:) from nawobapN “ a turn that falls to a man at a certain time, ” accord. to As: or so called because they feed and return to their place: (S:) and if so, the sing. is nAy^b: (TA:) or so called because they are of a colour inclining to black; (S, from A'Obeyd; or, as in some copies of the S, A'Obeydeh;) or as likened to the nation of negroes called Aln~uwbapu: and if so, the word has no sing. (TA.) See also luwbN. -A2- Aln~uwbu (S, K) and ↓ Aln~uwbapu (S) [The Nubians;] a nation of the Negroes [or rather Ethiopians]: (S, K:) or the latter is the name of their country; an extensive country south of Upper Egypt. (K, TA.) ― -b2- ↓ nwbiY~N [A Nubian;] an individual of the nation above mentioned. (S.) See luwbapN. ― -b3- ↓ A^asowadu nuwbiY~N: see luwbiY~N.

nawobapN *
A turn which comes to one, or which one takes; the time at which, or during which, anything is, or is to be, done, or had, in succession; an opportunity: (S, * K, MF:) pl. nuwabN, (S,) which is extr. [with respect to analogy.] (TA.) See nawobN. ― -b2- nawobapN and ↓ niyaAbapN A coming to water, &c., one time, or turn, after a former time, or turn. This is the meaning of the words in the following phrases, mentioned [but not explained] in the S and K: jaA'ato nawobatuka and jA't niyaAbatuka, Thy time, or turn, to came to water, &c., in succession, has arrived: (TA:) pl. of the former word nuwabN. (S, K.) ― -b3- nawobapN An assembly, a company, troop, or congregated body, of men. (K.)
nuwbapN * : see nuwbN and naAy^ibapN.
niyaAbapN * : see nawobahN.

xayorN naAy^ibN *
Abundant good, (K,) that comes again and again [by turns]. (A.) ― -b2- Hum~aY naAy^ibapN A quotidian fever. (S.) ― -b3- naAy^ibapN Guests coming time after time. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- See nuwbN. ― -b5- naAy^ibN One who supplies the place of another; who acts in his place or stead, or as his substitute, lieutenant, deputy, factor, or agent: pl. nuw~aAbN. (Msb.) ― -b6- naAy^ibapN What befalls, betides, or happens, that is afflictive, distressing, difficult, or unfortunate: pl. nawaAy^ibu and nuwabN; the latter of which is extr.: (TA:) or rather this latter is pl. of nuwbapN, which is syn. with nAy^bp, (MF,) a subst. from naAbahu A^amorN, (S,) [and therefore signifying an accident, or a casualty, &c.; and as such this pl. is not extr., but analogous:] an evil accident; a misfortune; a disaster; a calamity; an affliction: pl. nawaAy^ibu: (S:) only signifying what is evil: (Msb:) or, accord. to some, an accident, whether good or evil: ex. Lebeed says,
nawaAy^ibu mino xayorK wa$ar~K kilaAhumaA
falaA Alxayoru mamoduwdN walaA Al$~ar~u laAzibu
[Accidents of a good nature, and of an evil, both of them; and neither is the good prolonged, nor the evil constant]: or what befalls, betides, or happens, to a man, of difficult, arduous, distressing, or afflictive, events, or affairs, and accidents: [a difficulty, or difficult affair] in a trad. respecting Kheyber it is said, qasamahaA nuSofayoni nuSofFA linawaAy^ibihi waHaAjaAtihi wanuSofFA bayona Almusolimiyna [He divided it into two halves; half for his own difficulties, or difficult affairs, and wants, and half among the Muslims]. (TA.)

manaAbN *
A road to water. (K.) ― -b2- manaAbN (tropical:) i. q. marojiEN: ex. A_ilayohi manaAbiY (tropical:) [To him is my recourse]. (A.)

munaAbN * pass. part. n. of 4, A person made to supply another's place; &c. (Msb.) ― -b2- A^amoru munaAbN fiyhi An affair in which a person is made to supply another's place; in which a person is made to act in the place or stead of another person; or as another's substitute. (Msb.) See the verb.

manuwbN Eanohu * A person whose place is supplied by another; in whose place or stead, or as whose substitute, another person acts. (Msb.) ― -b2- A^amorN manuwbN fiyhi An affair in which a person supplies the place of another; in which a person acts in the place or stead of another, or as another's substitute. (Msb.) See the verb.

muniybN * , from AnAb AlY All~`h, Repenting, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- muniybN act. part. n. of 4, A person making another to supply his or another's place; &c. (Msb.) ― -b3- See the verb. ― -b4- muniybN Copious rain: and good rain, of the [rain termed] rabiyEN: (K:) or, accord. to En-Nadr Ibn-Shumeyl, copious rain (maTarN jawodN) is termed mnyb: and you say, A^aSaAbanaA rabiyEu SidoqK mnybN [There fell upon us an excellent, copious rain, of such as is termed rbyE; meaning] good rain, but inferior to what is termed jwd; but this is an excellent rain if followed by other rain. (TA.)
munotaAbN * act. part. n. of 8. ― -b2- [Coming by turns: &c.] ― -b3- Visiting. (RA.) ― -b4- Doing a thing time after time: doing a thing by turns. (TA.)

1 naAta * , aor. yanuwtu, inf. n. nawotN, He (a man) moved from side to side in walking; as also naAta, aor. yaniytu: (L:) or he so moved by reason of weakness, or infirmity: (K:) or, by reason of drowsiness, like as the sailor turns the vessel from side to side. (L.)

naAtN *
i. q. naAsN Mankind; or men: (S, K:) like A^akoyaAtN for A^akoyaAsN; the s being changed into t [see art. s], accord. to the dial. of certain of the Arabs; as related by Az. (S.)

nuwtiY~N * [and ↓ naw~aAtN] A sailor upon the sea, (S, K,) who turns about the ship in the sea: (TA:) pl. of the former nawaAtiY~u, (S, K,) [and of the latter] naw~aAtuwna. (TA.) Accord. to J, from the language of the people of Syria: accord. to others, an arabicized word [from the Greek nau/ths]. (TA.)
naw~aAtN * : see nuwtiY~N.

nawovapN *
i. q. HamoqapN. (L.)
