1 naAHati AlmaroA^apu * , aor. tanuwHu, inf. n. nawoHN and niyaAHN (S, K) and nuwaAHN, (L, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and niyaAHapN, (A, L, K,) or this also is a simple subst., (S, Msb, [and as such it is also mentioned in the K,]) and manaAHN (K) and manaAHapN, (L,) [The woman wailed]. You say naAHato EalaY Almay~iti, (Msb,) and EalaY zawojihaA, and naAHatohu, (L, K,) but nAHt Ealayohi is preferred, (TA,) [She wailed for, or bewailed, the dead, and, her husband]. Also, naAHa ElY Almy~t. (A.) naAHa and ↓ AstnAH are syn. (L, K.) [In the S it is implied that it is tropical: see naAy^iHap: but in the A it is said to be proper.] ― -b2- naAHati AlHamaAmapu, (L,) inf. n. nawoHN, (L, K,) The pigeon cooed (L, K) in a plaintive or wailing manner. (L.) Some say that this is tropical; but most, that it is proper. (MF.) ― -b3- AlT~ayoru tanuwHu [The birds warble plaintively.] (A.)

3 nAwH baEoDuhaA baEoDFA *
One of them was opposite
to, or faced, another. Said of mountains, and in like manner of winds. (S, L.)

5 tnw~H *
It (a thing) moved about, hanging down; it dangled. (S, K.)

6 AlT~ayoru tatanaAwaHu * [The birds warble plaintively, one to another]. (A.) See an ?? in art. fwH, conj. 6. ― -b2- tnAwHti Alr~iyaAHu The winds blew violently [as is generally the case when they blow from opposite directions]. (TA.) See an ex. voce shw. ― -b3- tnAwHA They two were opposite, one to the other; they faced each other. (S, K.) You say so of two mountains, and of two winds. (S, L.)

10 A_isotanowaHa see 1. ― -b2- AstnAH He (a wolf) howled, (L, K,) and was listened to and followed by other wolves. (L.) ― -b3- He (a man) wept and induced another, or others, to weep: (K:) or he wept so as to induce another, or others, to weep. (L.)
nawoHN * : see naAy^iHapN.
nawoHapN * and ↓ nayoHapN Strength; force. (L.)
nayoHapN * : see nawoHapN.
nuwaAHN * : see niyaAHapN.
niyaAHapN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ nuwaAHN (Msb) substs. from naAHati AlmaroA^apu, q. v. [A wailing, or bewailing a dead person].
nuw~aHN * : see naAy^iHapN.

nay~iHapu riyHK A^uxoraY *
A counterwind, or wind which is the opposite, of another wind. (S, A. L.) One that blows transversely with respect to another is called the nasiyjap of the latter. (S, L.)
naw~aAHapN * : see nAy^iHapN.
Aln~awaAHiY * : see naAy^iHapN.

naAy^iHapN * [A wailing woman]: (Msb:) pl. nawaAy^iHu and naAy^iHaAtN: and you also say ↓ nisaA='N nawoHN, and A^anowaAHN, and ↓ nuw~aHN: (S, K:) nawaAy^iHu is an epithet applied to women who assemble in a manaAHap: and ↓ manaAHapN (also) and ↓ nawoHN signify women who assemble together for the purpose of mourning. (L.) nawaAy^iHu are so called from Alt~anaAwuH, signifying “ the being opposite, one to another: ” (S:) [if so, it is app. a tropical term: but accord. to the A, AltnAwH, as above explained, is tropical]. Also ↓ naw~aAHapN [A woman who wails much, or frequently; who is in the habit of wailing: a professional wailing woman]. Ex. hiYa naw~aAHapu baniY fulaAnK [She is the professional wailing woman of the sons of such a one]. (A.) ― -b2- HamaAmapN naAy^iHapN. and ↓ naw~aAHapN, A pigeon that cooes in a plaintive or wailing manner. (L.) ― -b3- nawaAy^iHu also signifies Standards, or ensigns, opposite one to another, in battle. (L.) ― -b4- Also, Swords. In this sense, it occurs written ↓ Aln~awaAHiY, by transposition. (Ks, L.)

manaAHapN *
A place of nawoH [or wailing for a dead person]: (Msb:) pl. manaAHaAtN and manaAwiHu. (A, L.) Ex. kun~aA fiY manaAHapi fulaAnK [We were in the place of wailing of, or for, such a one]. (S, K.) ― -b2- See naAy^iHapN.

Alr~iyaAHu AlmutanaAwiHapu *
The winds called Aln~ukobu: [see nakobaA='u:] so called because they are opposite, one to another: they blow in times of drought, when rains are scanty, and when the air is dry, and the cold severe. (L.)
1 nAxa * : see 10.

2 naw~axa A@ll~`hu AlA^aroDa TaruwqapF lilomaA='i * (assumed tropical:) God made, or may God make, the land capable of receiving the water [of the rain so as to be impregnated, or fertilized, or soaked, thereby]: expl. by jaEalahaA mim~aA tuTiyquhu. (S.) ― -b2- See 4.

4 AnAx * (S, L, Msb) and ↓ nw~x (L, Msb) He (a man) made a camel to lie down upon his breast [with his legs folded, as is done on the occasions of mounting and dismounting, &c.] (S, L, Msb.) Also, ↓ tnw~x (S, L, K) and AnAx (K) and ↓ AstnAx (L) He (a stallion-camel) made a she-camel to do so in order that he might (??) (S, K.) or made her do so and then covered her. (L.) ― -b2- AnAx bihi AlbalaA='u waAl*~ul~u (tropical:) [Trial, or affliction, and abasement, befell him]. (A.)
5 tanaw~axa see 4. ― -b2- and 10.

10 A_isotanowaxa see 4. ― -b2- Also, AstnAx (S, L, Msb) and ↓ tnw~x (L, Msb) He (a camel) lay down upon his breast [with his legs folded]. (S, L, Msb.) Also, AstnAxt and ↓ tnw~xt She (a camel) did so in order to be covered by the stallion. (K.) It is said that one should not use, in the sense of the quasi-pass. of the trans. v. AnAx, the form ↓ naAxa, nor ↓ AnAx: (Msb:) but the authors on verbs mention AnAx in a neuter sense; and IAar says, that one says AnAx, but not nAx: (MF:) or IAar says, AlbaEiyru ↓ tnw~x, but not nAx nor AnAx: (L:) [and F says, that] one should not say, in the sense of AstnAxt and ↓ tnw~xt as explained above, either nAxt or AnAxt. (K.)

nawoxapN *
A remaining, staying, abiding, or dwelling, in a place. (L, K.)
naAy^ixapN * A distant land: (K:) or it is [correctly] naAy^ixapN, with b. (TA.)
manaAxN * : see munaAxN.

munaAxN *
A place in which camels are made to lie down upon their breasts, [with their legs folded]; (Msb:) a place where they so lie; (K;) a nightly resting-place of camels. (Msb, voce muraAHN) to a trad. in which it occurs, accord to one relation it is ↓ manaAxN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, A time at which camels so lie. (MF.) ― -b3- Also, pass. part. n. of AnAx; and used as an inf. n. of that verb, like A_inaAxapN. (MF.) ― -b4- h`*aA munaAxu sawo'K (tropical:) This is a disagreeable place. (A.)

Almuniyxu *
The lion. (K)

1 naAra * intrans., in the sense of A^anaAra: see the latter, in two places. -A2- naAruwA Aln~aAra: see 5. -A3- nurotu AlbaEiyra (tropical:) I made a mark upon the camel with a hot iron. (M, K.) See naArN.

2 nw~r * , intrans., in the sense of A^anaAra, from Aln~uwru: see 4, in two places. ― -b2- nw~r biAlfajori, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. tanowiyrN, (Msb,) He performed the prayer of daybreak when the dawn had become light (Mgh, Msb:) (tropical:) or when the horizon had become bright: (TA:) tanowiyru Alfajori, without bi is an amplification. (Mgh.) tanowiyrN as a subst. from this verb, see below. -A2- nw~r, trans. in the sense of A^anaAra, from Aln~uwru: see 4. in three places. -A3- nw~r, (S, A, Msb, K.) inf. n. tanowiyrN, (S, K,) It (a tree. S, A, Msb, K, and a plant, Msb) blossomed, or flowered it put forth its nawor; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^anaAra, (S, Msb, K,) originally A^anowara, (TA,) See also 4. ― -b2- It (seed-produce) attained to maturity: (K:) [see an ex. in a verse cited in art. smw, conj. 3:] tanowiyrN, the inf. n. of the verb in this sense, has a pl. tanaAwiyru. (TA.) -A4- nw~rhu He smeared him or it with nuwrap. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- nw~r *iraAEahu, (S, K,) inf. n. tanowiyrN, (TA,) He pricked his fore-arm with a needle, and then sprinkled nawuwr, [q. v.] upon it. (S, K.)

4 AnAr * , (inf. n. A_inaArapN, Msb,) It (a thing) (S, Msb) gave light; or shone; or shone brightly; (S, A, * Msb, K; *) as also ↓ nw~r, (Lh, S, * A, Msb, K,) inf. n. tanowiyrN; (S, Msb;) and ↓ AstnAr; (S, A, Msb, K;) and ↓ naAra, (A, Msb, K,) aor. yanuwru, (Msb,) inf. n. naworN, (K, TA,) or nuwrN, (as in a copy of the A,) or niyaArN: (Msb;) and ↓ tnw~r: (K:) nw~r (S, * Mgh, Msb, K) and AnAr (Mgh, Msb) and AstnAr, (Msb,) said of the dawn, signify as above; (Mgh, Msb;) or its light appeared. (S, * K) ― -b2- [Hence,] Alfitonapu ↓ naArati, aor. tanuwru, Sedition, or discord, or the like, happened and spread. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AnAr and A^anowara, (K.) the latter being the original form;
said of a plant; (TA;) It became beautiful: and it became apparent. (K, TA.) And A^anowarati Al$~ajarapu The tree became beautiful in its verdure: or, as some say, put forth its blossoms or flowers. (TA.) See also 2. -A2- AnAr and ↓ nw~r He made to give light; to shine; or to shine brightly. (Msb.) ↓ Alt~anowiyru and AlA_inaArapu signify the same. (S.) You say, AnAr Als~iraAja, and ↓ nw~rhu, (A,) and AlmiSobaAHa ↓ nw~r, (Msb,) He made the lamp to give light; or to become bright. (Msb.) ― -b2- AnAr AlmakaAna He illumined, or lighted, the place; (K;) i. e., put light [or a light] in it. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AnArhu (tropical:) He elucidated it; rendered it apparent or plainly apparent, conspicuous, manifest, or evident; (TA;) as also ↓ nwr~hu. (A, TA. *) ― -b4- And hence, AnAr A@ll~`hu burohaAnahu (tropical:) God taught him, or dictated to him, his proof. (TA.) 7:17 AM 30/01/035: see 4, first signification. -A3- tnwr~wA Aln~aAra mino biEiydK, (S, K,) and ↓ naAruwhaA, (K,) They looked at the fire, or endeavoured to see it (tabaS~aruwhaA,) from afar: (S, K:) or tnw~r Aln~aAra he looked at the fire, or endeavoured to see it, (tabaS~arahaA) and repaired towards it: (A:) or he came to the fire: it has this signification as well as the first. (TA.) ― -b2- tnw~r Alr~ajula, and AlmaroA^apa, He looked at the man, and the woman, at or by a fire, from a place where the latter did not see him; he stood in the dark to see the man, and the woman, by the light of the latter's fire, without the latter's seeing him; tanaw~urN being like taDaw~uw^N. (TA.) -A4- See also 8.

8 AntAr * , (Th, T, S, M, K,) imp. A_inotaro; (T;) and A_inotawara, (T, K,) imp. A_inotawiro; (T;) and ↓ tnw~r; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) or only AntAr and Antwr; not tnw~r; (T;) or some say AntAr; [implying that most say tnw~r;] (S;) He smeared himself with nuwrap [which is differently explained in the lexicons, so that these verbs are made to bear different meanings by different lexicons]. (Th, T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K.)
10 A_isotanowara see 4, first signification. -A2- AstnAr bihi He sought the aid of its light: (TA:) or of its rays. (M, K.)

naArN * a word of which the meaning is well known; (M, K;) [Fire; not well explained as signifying] the flaming, or blazing, (lahiyb,) that is apparent to the sense: (TA:) its A is originally nuwayorapN: (S, TA:) it is fem.: (S, M, Msb:) and sometimes masc.: (AHn, M, K:) and the dim. is A^anowaArN, with w because it is the original medial radical, (S,) and with p because nAr is fem.: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anowurN, (S, M, L,) in the K A^anowaArN, [which is a mistake, though this is also said to be a pl. of nAr,] (TA,) and [of mult.] niyraAnN [which is the most common form] (S, M, K) and nuwrN (AAF, S, M, Msb, K) and niyarapN and niyaArN, (M, K,) and A^anoyaArN also occurs, in the phrase naAru AlA^anoyaAri, in a trad. respecting the prison of hell; this phrase, if correctly related, perhaps meaning naAru Aln~iyiraAni, and AnyAr being originally A^anowaAr. (IAth.) Aln~aAru is also applied to The fire of hell. (TA:) The Arabs say, in cursing their enemies, A^aboEada A@ll~`hu daArahumo waA^awoqada naArFA A^avarahumo [May God make their abode distant, and kindle a fire after them!] And it was a custom of Arab women, as related by IAar, on the authority of El-'Okeyleeyeh, when they feared evil from a man, and he removed from them, to kindle a fire behind him, with the view of causing his evil to depart with him. (T.) ― -b2- naAru A@lomuhaw~ili A fire which the Arabs used to kindle, in the time of ignorance, on the occasion of entering into a confederacy: they threw into it some salt, which crackled (yufaq~iEu) when the fire burned it: with this they frightened [one another] in confirmation of the swearing. (T.) ― -b3- naAru AlHubaAHibi has been explained in art. Hb. ― -b4- naArN also signifies simply Heat. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, (tropical:) [The fire, meaning] the evil, and excitement, or rage, or war; as also ↓ naAy^irapN. (TA.) You say, A^awoqada naAra AlHarobi (tropical:) [He kindled the fire of war]. (A.) ― -b6- Also, (tropical:) Opinion; counsel; advice. (IAar, T, K.) So in the trad., laA tasotaDiyw^uwA binaAri Almu$orikiyna, (T,) or bnAr A^aholi Al$~iroki, (K,) (tropical:) [Seek ye not to enlighten yourselves by the counsel of the polytheists; i. e.,] seek ye not counsel of the polytheists. (IAar, T, A. *) ― -b7- Also, (tropical:) Any brand, or mark, made with a hot iron, upon a camel; (As, T, S, M, A, K;) as also ↓ nuwrapN (M, K) and ↓ nuwrN: (TA:) pl. as above: (M:) or the pl. is niyaArN, and the pl. of the nAr that burns is niyraAnN. (IAar, Th, T.) The Arabs say, maA naAru h`*ihi Aln~aAqapi (tropical:) What is the brand, or mark, of this she-camel, with which she is burned? (T, S, A. *) And they say, in a proverb, bijaAruhaA naAruhaA (T, S) Their origin is indicated by their mark with which they are burned. (T.) The Rájiz says,
Hat~aY saqawoA A=baAlahumo biAln~aAri
waAln~aAru qado ta$ofiY mina AlA^uwaAri
[Until, or so that, they watered their camels because of the brand that they bore: for the fire, or the brand, sometimes cures of the heat of thirst]: (T, S: *) he means, that, when they saw their marks with which they were burned, they left the water to them. (S. For another reading of this verse, see bi.) See also najorN.

naworN *
Blossoms, or flowers, (M, Msb, K,) of a tree, and of a plant: (Msb:) or white blossoms or flowers; the yellow being called zahorN; (M, K;) for they become white, and then become yellow: (M:) and ↓ naworapN and ↓ nuw~aArN signify the same as naworN: (M, K:) or [rather] naworN and nuw~aArN signify the same; (S, Msb;) [but the former is often used as a generic n., signifying a kind of blossom or flower: though both are coll. gen. ns.;] and naworapN is the n. un. of naworN, like as tamorapN is of tamorN; (Msb;) and nuw~aArapN is the n. un. of nuw~aArN: (S, M, L:) and the pl. of naworN is A^anowaArN. (M, Msb, K.)

nuwrN *
Light; syn. DiyaA='N, (S,) or Dawo'N; (M, A, Msb, K;) whatever it be; (M, A, K;) contr. of ZulomapN: (Msb:) or the rays thereof: (M, A, K:) accord to Z, DiyaA='N [with which Dawo'N is syn.] is more intense than nuwrN: in the Kur, x. 5, the sun is termed DyA', and the moon nwr: and it is said that DyA' is essential, but nwr is accidental [light]: (TA:) it is of two kinds, the light of the present world and that of the world to come; and the former is either perceived sensibly, by the eye, and this is what diffuses itself from luminous bodies, as the sun and moon and stars, and is mentioned in the Kur, x. 5, referred to above; or perceived by the eye of the intellect, and this is what diffuses itself of the divine lights, as the light of reason and the light of the Kur-án; of which divine light mention is made in the Kur, v., former part of verse 18, and xxiv., latter part of verse 35; and both of these in common are spoken of in the Kur, vi. 1 and xxxix. 69: that of the world to come is mentioned in the Kur in lvii. 12 [and lxvi. 8]: (B:) the pl. is A^anowaArN (S, M, Msb, K) and niyraAnN; (M, K;) the latter mentioned by Th: (M:) and ↓ naworaAny~apN signifies the same as nuwrN. (TA.) As nwr is a convenience of the pious in the present world and the world to come, it is said in the Kur, [lvii. 13,] AunoZuruwnaA naqotabiso mino nuwrikumo [Wait ye for us that we may take of your light]. (B.) [See also ZulamopN.] ― -b2- It is also applied to Mohammad: (T, M, K:) it is said by Aboo-Is-hak to be so applied in the Kur, v. 18. (T.) ― -b3- And That which manifests things, (K, TA,) and shows to the eyes their true or real state: and therefore Aln~uwr is applied in the Kur, vii. 156, to (tropical:) that [revelation] which the Prophet brought. (TA.) ― -b4- Aln~uwru is also one of the names of God; meaning, accord. to IAth, He by whose light the obscure in perception sees, and by whose guidance the erring is directed aright: or the Manifest, by whom is every manifestation. And A^all~`hu nuwru Als~am`waAti waA@loA^aroDi [in the Kur, xxiv. 35,] means God is the enlightener of the heavens and of the earth: like as fulaAnN giyaAvunaA means mugiyvunaA: (TA:) or, as some say, the right director of the inhabitants of the heavens and of the inhabitants of the earth. (T.) ― -b5- See also naArN, last signification.
naworapN * : see naworN.

nuwrapN * : see naArN, last signification. -A2- I. q. hinaA='N [a word well known to mean Tar, or liquid pitch, or a kind thereof; but I do not know this signification as applying to nuwrapN, nor, app., did SM, for he has made it to be the same with that which here next follows, from the T]. (M, K:) or a kind of stone burned and made into kilos [or quick-lime] and used as a depilatory for the pubes: (T:) or lime-stone; syn. Hajaru Alkilosi: and by a secondary and predominant application, a mixture of quick lime (kls) with arsenic, or orpiment, (zironiyx,) and other things, used for removing hair: (Msb:) [a depilatory composed of quick lime with a small proportion (about an eighth part) of orpiment: it is made into a paste with water, before application; and loosens the hair in about two minutes; after which it is immediately washed off: thus made in the present day:] some say that it is an Arabic word; and others, that it is arabicized. (Msb) See 8.
naworaAniy~apN * : see nuwrN.

nay~irN *
Giving light, shining, bright, or shining brightly; (A, Msb;) as also ↓ muniyrN and ↓ musotaniyrN (A) [and ↓ naAy^irN.] ― -b2- Beautiful in colour, and bright; as also ↓ muniyrN and ↓ A^anowaru: (TA:) or the last signifies [simply] beautiful; (K;) or conspicuous and beautiful. (TA.) It is said of Mohammad. Almutajar~adi ↓ kaAna A^anowara: He was beautiful and bright in the colour [of what was unclad] of his body. (TA.)

nawuwrN * , (S, Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) or naw^uwrN, (T, M, and so in some copies of the K,) or both, the former being the original form, (S, TA,) i. q. niylajN [i. e. Indigo-pigment]; (S, K;) or niylanojN; [which appears from what follows to be the right reading, though both nylj and nylnj are used in the present day for the purpose described in explanations of nwwr, to give a greenish colour to the marks made in tatooing;] (Msb;) i. e., (so accord. to the S and Msb; but in the K, and) the smoke [meaning the smokeblack] of fat, (IAar, T, S, M, Msb, K,) that adheres to the Tasot, (IAar, T,) with which the punctures made in tatooing are dressed, (S, Msb,) or filled in, (M,) that they may become green; (S, Msb;) or with which the women of the Arabs of the time of ignorance tattooed themselves: (T:) i. q. gunojN [q v.]; (IAar, T:) or, accord. to to Lth, the smoke [or smoke-black] of the wick, used as a collyrium or for tatooing; but, [says Az,] I have not heard that the women of the Arabs used this as a collyrium in the time of ignorance nor in the time of El-Islám; their using it for tatooing, however, is mentioned in their poems: (T:) or lamp-black; the black pigment (niqos) prepared from the smoke of the lamp; used for tattooing. (Comm. on the Mo'allakát, printed at Calcutta, p. 143.) ― -b2- Also, A kind of small stone, resembling A_ivomid, which is bruised, or brayed, and then taken up, like as medicine is by the lip. (M.) [The same is found in the K, excepting that, in this latter lexicon, the explanation is less full, and All~ivapu is substituted for Al$~afapu, the reading in the M.
nuw~aArN * and nuw~aArapN: see naworN.

naAy^irN * : see nay~irN. ― -b2- (tropical:) Apparent or plainly apparent. conspicuous, manifest, or evident; as also ↓ muniyrN. (Thus the pl. fem. of each of these is explained in the TA.) ― -b3- fitonapN naAy^irapN Sedition, or discord, or the like, happening and spreading. (Msb.) ― -b4- And naAy^irapN alone, Sedition, or discord, or the like: (Msb:) or sedition, or discord, or the like, happening: (TA:) and rancour, malevolence, or spite. (T:) enmity, or hostility, (T, S, A, Msb,) and violent hatred. (S, A, Msb.) See also naArN. You say, saEayotu fiY A_iTofaA='i Aln~aAy^irapi I laboured in stilling the sedition, or discord, or the like. (Msb.) And bayonahumo naAy^irapN Between them is enmity, or hatred, and violent hatred. (A, Msb.) -A2- One who occasions evils among men. (T.)
Anowaru * : see nay~irN, in two places. ― -b2- *aA A^anowru mino *aAka [This is lighter, or brighter, than that], (TA.)

tanowiyrN * The time when the dawn shines, or becomes light. (T, Mgh.) You say, Sal~aY Alfajora fiY Alt~anowiyri He performed the prayer of daybreak when the dawn shone, or became light. (Mgh.) See also 2.

manaArN * [originally manowarN] A place of light; as also ↓ manaArapN. (M. K.) ― -b2- A sign, or mark, set up to show the way: (As, T, S, M, K:) and a thing that is put as a limit or boundary between two things; (M, K;) or between two lands, (As, T,) made of mud or clay or of earth: (As, TA:) pl. manaAviru [respecting which see manaArapN]. (A.) It is [also used as a coll. gen. n.; as, for instance, where it is] said, in a trad., laEana A@ll~`hu mano gay~ara manaAra AlA^aroDi May God curse him who alters the marks of the limit between two lands: (T, TA:) or it may mean manaAra AlHarami the boundary-marks of the Haram [or sacred territory of Mekkeh], which [it is said] were set up by Abraham. (T, TA. *) And it is said in another trad, A_in~a liloA_isolaAmi SuwFY wamanaArFA (tropical:) Verily there are to El-Islám signs and ordinances whereby it is known. (TA.) ― -b3- See also SawomaEapN. ― -b4- The middle, or main part and middle, or part along which one travels, (maHaj~ap,) of a road. (M, K.)
muniyrN * : see nay~irN, in two places. ― -b2- See also naAy^irN.

manaArapN * , originally manowarapN; (A, K;) see manaArN. ― -b2- A stand for a lamp; a thing upon which a lamp is put: (T, S, M, A, K;) of the measure mafoEalapN. with fet-h (S, Msb) to the m; (S:) but by rule it should be with kesr, because it is an instrument (Msb.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb uses it, for the sake of metre, in the place of miSobaAH, in likening a bright spear-head, without rust, to a lamp. (M.) ― -b3- Also, A candle having a siraAj [or lighted wick]. (T.) ― -b4- [A pharos, or lighthouse.] ― -b5- The mená reh [or turret of a mosque, whence the English term “ minaret, ” so written in imitation of the Turkish pronunciation,] upon which the time of prayer is proclaimed; (S, Msb:) syn. miy^o*anapN, (K, TA,) vulgarly maA^a*anapN [which is the form given in the CK]. (TA.) ― -b6- [Any pillar-like structure. (See zuronuwqN.) ― -b7- The perch of a hawk, or falcon. (See marobaA^N.)] ― -b8- The pl. is manaAwiru and manaAy^iru: he who uses the latter likens the radical letter to the augmentative; (S, Msb, K;) like as they say maSaAy^ibu, which is originally maSaAwibu (S, Msb.)
musotaniyrN * : see nay~irN.

1 naAsa * , aor. yanuwsu, (S, M, A, Msb,) inf. n. nawosN (S, M, A, K) and nawasaAnN, (M, A, K,) It (a thing, S, M, as a look of hair, and an carring, A) moved to and fro; (S, A, K;) it was in a state of commotion, and moved to and fro, (M, TA,) hanging down; (TA;) it dangled, or hung down and was in a state of commotion or agitation. (M, Msb [but in the M, the verb in this last sense has only the former of the two inf. ns. assigned to it, though the other equally helongs to it.]) You say also, naAsa luEaAbuhu His slaver flowed and was in a state of commotion. (M.) [See also 5]

4 AnAshu *
He made it to move to and fro; (S, A;) he made it to be in a state of commotion. (M, K, TA,) and to move to and fro, (M,) and to hang down; (TA;) he made it to dangle, or to hang down and be in a state of commotion or agitation. (M.) It is said in a trad. (S, M. TA.) of Umm-Zara, (S, TA,) A^anaAsa mino HuliY~K A^u*unaY~a [He made my two ears to move to and fro, &c., with ornaments]; (S, M, TA;) meaning, that he ornamented her two ears with [ear-rings of the kinds called] qiraTap and $unuwf, which moved to and fro, &c., in them. (TA.)

5 tnw~s *
It, (a branch of a tree,) being blown by the wind, became shaken thereby, so that it moved much to and fro; as also tnw~E (TA.) [See also 1.]

naAsN * is applied to Men, and to jinn, or genii;
(S, Msb, K;) but its predominant application is to the former: (Msb:) it is said by some to be applied to both in the former of the last two verses of the Kur, A@l~a*iY yuwasowisu fiY Suduwri Aln~aAsi mina Aljin~api waAln~aAsi [who suggesteth what is vain in the breasts of people of the jinn and mankind]; unless by it be meant Aln~aAsiY [the forgetting]; or mn Aljn~p wAlnAs is added in explanation of a preceding word, AlwasowaAs, or of Al*Y, or it is in dependence upon ywsws; (Bd;) [but what corroborates the first explanation is the fact that] men and jinn are both termed rijaAl in the Kur, lxxii. 6; and the Arabs used to say, raA^ayotu naAsFA mina Aljin~i [I saw people of the jinn]: (Msb:) it is a pl. of A_inosN, (K,) originally A^unaAsN, (S, K,) a pl. which is rare [as to form]; (K;) or A^unaAsN is pl. of A_inosaAnN; (M, art. A^ns;) and nAs has the article Al prefixed to it, (S, M,) but not as a substitute for the suppressed ', because, were it so, it would not be found prefixed to the original, A^unaAsN, whereas it is found prefixed to this latter: (S:) this derivation, however, from A^unaAsN, contradicts its belonging to art. nws: (MF;) [but some hold that it does belong to this art.; and the form of its dim., to be mentioned below, favours their opinion: Fei says,] it is a noun applied to denote a pl., like qawomN and rahoTN; and its sing. is A_inosaAnN, from a different root: it is derived from naAsa, aor. yanuwsu, signifying “ it hung down and was in a state of commotion: ” and [agreeably with this derivation it is said that] its dim. is nuwayosN: (Msb:) some, again, said that Aln~aAsu is originally Aln~aAsiY. (L, TA, voce A_inosN.) See also A_inosN, throughout. -A2- See also nuwaAsN.

[
naAsuwtN *
Human nature; humanity; as also A_inosaiAny~apN: probably post-classical: opposed to laAhuwtN, q. v., in art. lyh.]
nawasaAtN * : see nuwaAsN.

nuwaAsN *
A [lock of hair such as is called] *uw^aAbap, that moves to and fro: (K, in explanation of *uw nuwaAsK the name of a king of El-Yemen:) or ↓ nuwaAsapN has this signification: (A:) [the former, therefore, is a coll. gen. n., and this is indicated in the S; and the latter is its n. un.:] and ↓ nawasaAtN signifies i. q. *awaAy^ibu, [pl. of *uw^aAbapN,] because they move about much. (TA.) ― -b2- What hangs to the roof, (M, A, &c. [a signification assigned in the K to naAsN, probably through the careless omission of the word Aln~uwaAsu by an early transcriber,] consisting of smoke, (A, TA,) [or soot,] &c. (TA,) The word in the T and O, as well as in the A [and M], is nuwaAsN. (TA.) ― -b3- The web of a spider: because of its fluttering. (M.)
nuwaAsapN * : see nuwaAsN.
naw~aAsN * , applied to man, (S,) Quivering (muDoTaribN), and flaccid, or flabby. (S, K.)
naAy^isN * act. part. n. of 1. Ex. xuyuwTN naAy^isapN Threads dangling or hanging down and moving about. (TA.)

naAwuwsN * , (M, Msb,) or naAw^uwsN, (Mgh,) Burialplaces of Christians: (M:) or a burial-place of Christians: (Mgh, Msb:) [De Sacy observes, that En-Nuweyree and El-Makreezee constantly use this word in speaking of the burial-places of the ancient kings of Egypt, and that it is from the Greek ναος: (“ Relation de l'Égypte par Abd-allatif; ” p. 508:) Freytag, on the authority of Meyd., explains it as signifying a coffin in which a corpse is enclosed: and 'Abd-el-Lateef applies the (expression naAwuwsN mino HajarK to the sarcophagus in the Great Pyramid: (see “ Abdollatiphi Hist. Æg. Comp.; ” p. 96:)] if Arabic, (M,) of the measure faAEuwlN: (M, Mgh, Msb:) pl. nawaAwiysu. (Mgh, TA.)

1 naA$ahu * , aor. yanuw$u, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. nawo$N, (S, A, Msb, K,) He took it, or reached it, absolutely, or with the hand, or with the extended hand; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ tnAw$hu, (A, TA,) inf. n. tanaAwu$N; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and ↓ AntA$hu, (A, TA,) inf. n. A_inotiyaA$N: (S, K:) it is also written with '; (A, K, TA, in art. nA^$;) and so is tanaAwu$N. (Msb, and K in art. nA^$.) And He took him, or reached him, to seize his beard, or his head. (ISk, S.) You say, naA$ahu nawo$apF xafiyfapF [He reached him with a feeble, or slight reach, with his spear or the like]. (A.) And Alr~imaAHu tanuw$uhu The spears reach him: occurring in a poem of Dureyd Ibn-Es-Simmeh. (TA.) And AlZ~ibaA='u tanuw$u AlA^araAka [The antelopes reach and take with their mouths of the trees called ArAk]; as also ↓ tanotaA$uhu. (A.) And Aln~aAqapu tanuw$u bifiyahA AlHawoDa [The she-camel reaches and takes with her mouth of the water of the drinking-trough]. (TA.) A poet says, (ISk, S,) namely, Gheylán Ibn- Horeyth Er-Raba'ee, (TA,)
fahoYa tanuw$u AlHawoDa nawo$FA mino EalaA
nawo$FA bihi taqoTaEu A^ajowaAza AlofalaA
And she reaches and takes of the drinking-trough, from above it, a copious draught by means of which she traverses [the middles of the] waterless deserts without needing other water. (S.) You say also, nu$otu mina AlT~aEaAmi $ayoy^FA I obtained somewhat of the food. (TA.) And AlwaSiy~apu nawo$N mina AlmaEoruwfi [The testament is a means of an attaining of benefit]: i. e., the testator gives [for yatanaAwalu in my original I read yunaAwilu] to the legatee without diminishing his property [during his own life]. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [xxxiv. 51,] mino makaAnK baEiydK ↓ waA^an~aY lahumu A@lt~anaAwu$u meaning, [But how shall] the attaining of belief [be possible to them from a distant place, i. e.,] in the world to come, when they have disbelieved in him [namely Mohammad] in the present world? in which passage some read [Alt~anaAw^u$u,] with '. (S.) [See art. nA^$.] Accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, in this instance, ↓ AltnAw$ signifies Returning. (K, * TA.) And 'Áïsheh said of her father, Ald~iyna binaEo$ihi A_iy~aAhu ↓ faA@notaA$a And he restored the religion, and laid hold upon it and took it from the abyss into which it had fallen; [by his exalting it;] in which instance, also, the verb is sometimes pronounced with '. (TA.) ― -b2- naA$a bihi, aor. as above, He clung, or clave, to him, or it. (TA.) -A2- nu$otuhu xayorFA, (Lth, S,) inf. n. nawo$N, (Lth,) I made him to attain good; (Lth, S;) and $ar~FA evil. (Lth.)

3 naAwa$uwhumo biAlr~imaAHi * , [inf. n. munaAwa$apN, They reached, or thrust, them with the spears, in near, but not close, conflict, being in like manner reached, or thrust, by them,] (A, Mgh,) is from tanaAwu$N in the first of the senses assigned to it above: (Mgh:) munaAwa$apN, in conflict, is the reaching one another [with spears or other weapons] (ISk, S, K) when the two parties are near [but not close]: (ISk, S, TA) and is like muhaAwa$apN, i. e., conflicting. (TA.) See also 6. ― -b2- nAw$ Al$~aYo'a He mixed with [or engaged in] the thing. (IAar.)

6 tanaAowa$a see 1, in three places. ― -b2- tanaAwa$uwhumo biAlr~imaAHi They [reached or] thrust them with the spears, [in near, but not close, conflict,] being in like manner [reached or] thrust by them: (Msb:) tanaAwu$N is the reaching one another with the spears [or other weapons] when the two parties are not close together. (TA.) See also 3.

8 A_inotawa$a see 1, in three places. ― -b2- AntA$hu also signifies he caused him to come, or go, forth (K, TA) from a place of destruction: or he took, led, or drew, him forth therefrom: (TA:) and he saved him, or rescued him, from destruction. (A, * TA.)

nawuw$N *
Strong: (K:) a man possessing might, or strength, courage, valour, or prowess: (S, TA:) as also naw^uw$N, q. v. (TA.) [In two copies of the S, I find the latter only, with '].

1 naASa * , (M, K,) aor. yanuwSu, (M,) inf. n. nawoSN
and manaASN (M, K) and maniySN (M) and nawiySN (K) and niyaASN, (K, accord. to the TA,) or niyaASapN, (accord. to a MS. copy of the K, and accord. to to the CK,) and nawaSaAnN, (K,) He put himself in motion: (K:) or he put himself in motion and went away. (M, TA.) You say, maA yanuwSu fulaAnN liHaAjatiY Such a one does not put himself in motion for [the accomplishment of] my want. (TA.) And maA bihi nawiySN There is not in him strength (S, M) and motion (or activity], (S, TA.) ― -b2- naASa liloHarakapi, inf. n. nawoSN and manaASN, He prepared himself for motion. (M, TA.) ― -b3- naASa Alfarasu, (Lth, M,) inf. n. nawoSN, (Lth, TA,) The horse, having his bridle pulled in, and being put in motion, raised his head; as also ↓ AstnAS: (Lth, M:) or ↓ A_isotinaASapN signifies a horse's putting himself in motion to run. (K.) ― -b4- naASa A_ilayohi, (K,) inf. n. nawoSN, (TA,) He rose to him. (K.) ― -b5- naASa, aor. yanuwSu, inf. n. nawoSN, He turned aside, or away: (M, TA:) he drew back, receded, retreated, or retired; (S, K *;) as also ↓ AstnAS: (S:) he fled; or turned away and fled: (TA:) he escaped, and outwent: (Msb:) and, inf. n. maniySN and manaASN, he escaped; or became safe, or secure: (M:) and accord. to IB, nuwSN, with, damm, [app. as an inf. n.,] also signifies the act of fleeing. (TA.) You say, naASa Eani AlA^amori He turned aside, or away, from the thing, or affair; he declined from it; he avoided it; as also laASa. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.) And naASa Eanohu, inf. n. nawoSN, He removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance, and separated himself, from him, or it. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) And naASa Eano qironihi, (S, A,) aor. yanuwSu, inf. n. nawoSN and manaASN, (S,) He fled, or turned away and fled, from his opponent, or adversary, (S, A,) and eluded him, (S,) or removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance, from him. (A) And it is said in the Kur, [xxxviii. 2,] walaAta Hiyna manaASK, meaning, When it was not a time of fleeing: (Az, TA:) or when it was not a time of drawing back and fleeing: (S, TA:) or when it was not a time of seeking, or petitioning, and of being aided, or succoured. (M, TA.)
3 naAowaSa see jur~apN.
10 A_isotanowaSa see 1, in three places.

nawoSN *
A wild ass; (S, M, K;) because he ceases not to raise his head, going to and fro, like one running away at random. (Lth, K. *)

naAy^iSN *
Raising his head, and running away at random: (M:) or a wild ass raising his head, and going to and fro, like one running away at random: (Lth, K *:) and ↓ maniySN a horse raising his head. (TA.)

manaASN *
A place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, preservation, or concealment: a place of refuge: (S, Msb, K:) a place to which one flees; (S;) a place of safety or security. (A.) -A2- See also 1, throughout.
maniySN * : see naAy^iSN.

1 naATahu * , aor. yanuwTu, inf. n. nawoTN, He suspended it; hung it. (S, Msb, K.) You say, nuTotu Alqirobapa biniyaATihaA [I suspended the water-skin by its nyAT, q. v]. (TA.) And niyTa Ealayohi Al$~aYo'u The thing was suspended to him, or it: and nuwTa Elyh: (TA:) or Ealayohi ↓ nuw~iTa, (S; accord. to two copies: the pronoun relating to a camel when loaded.) And niyTa bihi Al$~aYo'u The thing was attached to, or connected with, him, or it. (TA.) It is said in a trad, maA A^axa*onaAhu A_il~aA EafowFA bilaA sawoTK walaA nawoTK i. e. [We took him not save with case;] with neither beating, [lit. with neither whip,] nor hanging [or clinging]. (TA.) And in a proverb, kul~u $aAhK birijolihaA satunaATu [Every sheep, or goat, shall be hung by its hind leg]: i. e. every one who commits a crime shall be punished for it: or, accord to As, one ought not to punish for a crime, or an offence, any but the committer thereof. (TA.) And Hassán Ibn-Thábit says,
waA^anota daEiY~N niyTa fiY A=li haA$imK
kamaA niyTa xalofa Alr~aAkibi AlqadaHu Alfarodu
[And thou art an adopted person, who is connected with the family of Háshim, like as the single drinking-cup is connected behind the rider]. (TA.) See also $aAqa, in art. $wq.
2 naw~aTa see 1.

8 AntAT *
It was, or became, suspended, or hung; it hung; (K, TA;) bihi to him, or it. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (tropical:) It was, or became, distant, or remote, or far-extending. (S, TA.) You say, AntATt AlmafaAzapu, and, by transposition, A_inotaTat, (tropical:) The desert extended far; [as though it were connected with a desert like it; (see niyaATN;)] it was far-extending. (TA.) And AntATt AlmagaAziY (tropical:) The places of war were distant, or far-extending: from niyaATu AlmafaAzapi, meaning “ the far extent of the desert: ” or from AlnawoTu. (TA.) And AntATt Ald~aAru (tropical:) The house, or place of abode, &c., was distant. (IAar, K, TA.)

nawoTN *
A thing, (S, K,) whatever it be, (S,) that is suspended, or hung, from another thing; (S, K;) an inf. n. used as a subst.: (K:) and particularly a thing that is put, or hung, upon a camel, (EilaAwapN,) between two halves of a load, byn Eidolayoni, (K,) or, as A 'Obeyd says, bayona AlEuwdayoni [which, if not a mistranscription, app. means between the two staves of the saddle]; (TA:) the ElAwp being thus called because it is suspended (tunaATu) to the load: (Z, TA:) and a small [receptacle of palm-leaves, of the kind called] jul~ap, (Az, S, K,) containing dates (S, K) and the like, (K,) which is suspended from a camel, (S,) being hung, by its handles, from the saddle of the camel of burden: (Az, TA;) such, says Az, I have heard thus called by the people of El-Bahreyn: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anowaATN (S. K) and [of mult.] niyaATN (Az, K;) the former is pl. of nawoTN in the general sense first mentioned above: and also signifies what is suspended (nuw~iTa, as in two copies of the S, or nuwTa, as in the TA) upon the camel when he is loaded: (S, TA:) and i. q. maEaAliyqu [things suspended to a beast of burden; such as the qumoqumap and the qirobap and the miToharap]. (S, K.) It is said in a proverb EaATK bagayori A^anowaATK Taking [or reaching to take] without there being there anything suspended; which is like the saying “ Driving by singing without having a camel ” (S, L, See also art ETw.]) And in another proverb. A_ino A^aEoyaA AlbaEiyru fazidohu nawoTFA [If the camel be fatigued, add thou to him an appendage to his full load] meaning, if he be slow and inobsequious in his pace, do not thou lighten his burden: (K:) accord. to As, A_ino A^aEoyaA fazidohu nawoTFA is a proverb relating to the pressing a niggardly man. (TA.) ― -b2- *aAtu A^anowaATK the name of A particular tree, (S, TA,) of great size, (S,) which was worshipped in the time of ignorance, said by IAth to be the name of a particular gum-acacia-free (samurap) to which the believers in a plurality of gods used to suspend their weapons, and around which they used to circuit. (TA.) ― -b3- Aln~awoTu Almu*abo*ibu occurs in a trad. as meaning The leg of a rider, from fatigue or some other cause, ever dangling, or moving to and fro. (TA.)
nayoTN * : see niyaATN, in two places. and see art nyT.

niyaATN * The loop-shaped handle (Eurowap) of a qirobap [or water-skin]: (Msb:) the [appendage called] muEal~aq [q. v.] of a bow; (S, K;) by which it is suspended: (K, voce xaTama:) and of a qirobap: [by which it is suspended; (see 1, second sentence;) and of anything. (K.) ― -b2- See also $iyaAqN. ― -b3- Also (S, Msb [in the K, “ or, ” which is evidently a mistake,]) Aln~iyaATu [i. e. niyaATu Alqalobi The suspensory of the heart;] a vein, (S, Msb,) or a thick vein, (K,) [app. the ascending aorta,] by which the heart is suspended (S, Msb, K) from, (mino, S, Msb [or possibly this may mean forming a part of,]) or to, (A_ilaY, K,) the watiyn, [which seems here to signify the descending aorta, or, accord.
to the second rendering of mn, suggested above, the aorta altogether,] (S, Msb, K,) the cutting, or severing, of which causes death; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ nayoT: (S:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anowiTapN and [of mult.] nuwTN, with damm, (Az, K,) because the Y in niyaATN is originally w: the latter is allowable when the number is not meant [to be limited to a few]: or, accord. to some, there are two things thus called: the upper being that of the heart: and the lower, the faroj. (Az, L.) [Hence,] AlmuqaT~aEapu Aln~iyaATi (K, and so in a copy of the S, excepting that the former word is there without the article,) is applied to (tropical:) The A^aronab [or female hare], (S, K,) like muqaT~aEapu AlA^asoHaAri, (S,) as an appellation of good omen, i. e. as meaning that her nyAT will be severed: or, as some say, AlmuqaT~iEapu Aln~iyaATi, (K, and so in some copies of the S, excepting that the former word is there without the article,) as meaning that, by reason of her swiftness, her nyAT, or [as in the A,] the nyAT of [every one of] the dogs [that pursue her], will be severed. (K.) Hence also the saying, ↓ ramaAhu A@ll~`hu biAln~ayoTi, meaning [God smote him, or may God smite him,] with death. (S.) [See also art. nyT.] [Hence likewise,] Aln~iyaATu is applied to (tropical:) Two stars [app. s and t of Scorpio] between which is qalobu AlEaqorabi [which is the star and of that constellation]. (Sgh, K, TA.) ― -b4- Also, i. q. Alfuw^aAdu [which generally means The heart; but is probably here used in one of its other senses, namely, the appendages of the œsophagus, consisting of the liver and lungs and heart]. (K.) ― -b5- Also, A certain vein lying within the Sulob [i. e. backbone, or back], beneath the [portion of flesh and sinew called the] maton; and so ↓ Aln~aAy^iTu: (K:) or the latter is a vein extending in, or along, the Sulob, [in some copies of the K, qalob, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistake,] by the cutting of which the maSofuwr [or person in whose belly is yellow water, as explained in the TA,] is treated for the purpose of cure. (S, K.) ― -b6- niyaATu AlmafaAzapi (tropical:) The far extent of the desert: (TA:) or of the way thereof; as though it were connected with another desert, (S, K,) hardly coming to an end. (S, TA.) [Thus,] AlbaEiydu niyaATuhu, applied to the Hijáz, means AlbaEiydu muEal~aquhu (assumed tropical:) [i. e. Whereof every connected part, or appendant tract, is far-extending]. (Ham, p. XXX). The Rájiz, El-'Ajjáj, says,
wabalodapK baEiydapi Aln~iyaATi
majohuwlapK tagotaAlu xaTowa AlxaATiY
(assumed tropical:) [Many a region far extending, unknown, rendering unapparent the trace of the stepping of the stepper]. (S and O in the present art. and in art. gwl.)
Aln~aAy^Tu * : see niyaATN.

tanaw~uTN * , (S, K,) like takar~umN, (K,) and tunaw~iTN, (S, K,) with damm to the t (K) and fet-h to the n (TA) and kesr to the w, (K,) or tanaw~iTN, (as in some copies of the S,) and tunuw~iTN, (TA, voce tubu$~irN,) A certain bird, that lets down strings from a tree, (As, S, K,) and weaves its nest like an oilflask, suspended to those strings, (K,) then produces her young therein; and hence its appellation: (As, S:) a certain bird, like the qaAriyap in blackness, [or rather in dinginess,] that constructs its nest between two twigs, or branches, or upon one twig, or branch, making its nest long, so that a man cannot reach its eggs until he introduces his arm to the shoulder-joint: or, accord. to Aboo-'Alee, a certain bird, that suspends pieces of the bark of trees [formed into strings], and makes its nest at their extremities, to protect itself from serpents and men and *ar~ [or young ants, or small red ants]: (TA [see also SaAfirN:]) called in Persian kiyPuwo: (Kzw:) n. un. with p. (S, K.) [See De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., vol. iii., p. 499.] Hence the proverb, A^aSonaEu mino tanaw~uTK [More skilled in fabricating than a tnw~T]. (Meyd.)

tanowuATN *
What is hung (S, K) from, (S,) or upon, (K,) the [kind of vehicle called] hawodajN, for ornament: (S, K:) or the implements, or apparatus, &c., that are hung upon a horse. (Ham, p. 165) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) Adventives; or persons who introduce themselves among a people, and live among them, not being of their race; and persons whose fathers are free men, or Arabs, and whose mothers are slaves, and who have become conjoined with the genuine and pure Arabs, not being of them: for *uw Alt~anowaATi; [or *awuw Alt~anowaATi;] the latter of these two words being originally an inf. n.: or it may be an inf. n. used as an epithet. (Ham, ibid.) [See also manuwTN.]

manaATN *
A place of suspension, or hanging. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] fulaAnN min~iY manaATa Alv~uray~aA (tropical:) [Such a one is with respect to me as though he were in the place of suspension of the Pleiades]; i. e., in distance: (Sb, S, K * [in the K, h*A is put for fulaAnN; and in the CK, manATu is erroneously put for mnATa]:) or the meaning is, in such a station: the prep. being understood, as in *ahabotu Al$aA^oma and daxalotu Albayota: Z says, humo min~iY manaATa Alv~uray~aA (tropical:) [they are &c.] by reason of their elevated state. (TA.)

manuwTN *
Suspended; hung. (K.) You say, h`*aA manuwTN bihi This is suspended, or hung, to him, or it. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] h`*aA rajulN manuwTN biAlqawomi (assumed tropical:) This is a man adventive to the people; one who has introduced himself among them, and lives among them, not being of their race: (K, * TA:) or i. q. daEiY~N [one whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; &c.]: (K:) and manuwTN mu*abo*ibN is also applied to a person of this latter description who betakes himself to a people; the latter epithet being added to denote that he knows not to whom to assert himself related, like the wind wavering to the right and left. (TA.) See also tanowaATN.]

munotaATN * (tropical:) Distant, or remote; and far extending. (TA.) You say, munotaATu AlmaHal~i (tropical:) Whose place of abode is distant. (TA.) And gaAyapN munotaATapN (tropical:) A distant goal, or scope; or a far-extending space. (TA.)

div2.head: nwE &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 naA='a * , aor. yaniYo'u, (so in the S, Nh, L, Msb; but in some copies of the K, ynA'u, [which appears to be put by mistake for the inf. n. in the acc. case];) inf. n. naYo'N, (S,) and naY~N, without ', and nawo'N, (Sh,) It (flesh meat, &c.) was not, or did not become, sufficiently cooked; it was insufficiently cooked: (S, K:) (like nahiy^a:) or it was untouched by fire; (i. e., raw]. (L.) ― -b2- It (a thing) was not firmly, not soundly, not thoroughly, done. [See 4.] (TA.)
2 nay~aAa see 4.

4 AnA' AlA^amora *
He did the thing not firmly, not soundly, not thoroughly. AlAmr ↓ ny~A^, accord. to the K, signifies the same: but this is unknown, and not authorized by transmission [from the Arabs of the classical ages], and therefore not mentioned by IM nor by other leading lexicographers: the correct phrases are [when the verb is intrans.] nA' AlAmru [and AllHmu], and [when it is trans.] AnA' AllHma [and AlAmr]: the forms of the verb being like baAna and A^abaAna. (TA.) ― -b2- AnA', (S, incorrectly written in the K A^anoyaA^a, TA,) inf. n. A_inaA='apN, He insufficiently cooked flesh-meat [&c.]. (S, K.)

niYo'N * Flesh meat &c. insufficiently cooked: (S, K:) or untouched by fire; [i. e., raw]. (L.) It was also pronounced by the Arabs niY~N; but the original word is with '. (TA.) ― -b2- Wine untouched by the fire: cooked [or mulled] wine being called naDiyjN, (TA [written niY~N, without ']). ― -b3- Pure [and sweet] milk: sour milk being called nDyj: or milk just drawn from the udder, before it is put into the skin. (TA [written niY~N, without '.])
naY~N * [for naYo'N] Fat, as contradistinguished from flesh, [which is app. called naDiyjN]. (TA.)
nuyuwo'N * and nuyuwo'apN The state of being insufficiently cooked: (S, K:) or of being untouched by fire; [i. e., rawness]. (L.)
1 naAbahu * , aor. yaniybu, He hit him on his nAb, i. e., his canine tooth. (S, K.)

2 ny~b Als~ahoma *
He bit the wood of the arrow, to know whether it were strong or weak, and made an impression upon it with his canine tooth. (S, K.) ― -b2- ny~b fiyhi He (a beast of prey) made an impression upon him with his canine tooth: he fixed his canine teeth in him. (TA) ― -b3- ny~bt She (a camel) became extremely old: (Lh, S, K:) became what is termed a nAb. (A.) ― -b4- ny~b and ↓ tny~b (assumed tropical:) It (a plant) put forth its root. (K.) Also signifying the same with reference to white, or hoary hair. The root is thought by ISd to be thus likened to a canine tooth. (TA.) ― -b5- Zaf~ar fulaAnN fiY ka*aA wanay~aba (tropical:) Such a one clung to, caught to, or took fast hold upon, such a thing: [lit., stuck his nails and dog-teeth into it]. (A.) See also Zaf~ara.
5 tanay~aba see 2.

naAbN * [originally nayabN, The canine tooth, or dog-tooth; or eye-tooth; the tusk, or tush; or the fang; of certain animals:] one of the teeth; (S;) the tooth that is [next] behind the rabaAEiyap, [or next but one to the central pair of incisors:] (M, K.) [In this sense, the word is masc.:] the tooth thus called is mase., when thus called: [though if you call it sin~N (???)] but nAb when fem. signifies “ an old she-camel ” (Msb:) or, accord. to the M and K, it is fem. only in each of the above senses without distinction. (TA.) Sb says, that the Arabs observed the pronunciation termed imáleh (A_imaAlap) in the case of nAb in the nom. [as well as in the acc. and gen., in which latter case this pronunciation is agreeable with analogy on account of the final kesreh,] likening its (tropical:) to that in ramaY, [in which it is expressed in writing by Y,] because it is changed from Y: but this is extr. That is, this pronunciation of (tropical:) changed from Y or w is only observed [regularly] when the said A is a final radical letter; and specially in verbs: the instances of this kind that occur in nouns are extr.; and more (???) are these in which the A changed from Y is a medial radical letter. (TA.) [But the restriction to the case of verbs is inconsistent with what is said by Ibn-Málik and other high authorities: and so, too, is the restriction to the case of a final radical letter.] Pl. A^anoyubN (Lh, K) and A^anoyaAbN [both pls. of pauc.: but the latter is used as a pl. of mult.:] and nuyuwbN; (S, K;) the latter contr. to analogy, (S,) because [naAbN is originally nayabN, and] a word of the measure faEalN does not [regularly] assume the measure faEuwlN in the pl.; (TA;) to which should be added niyuwbN, a dial. var., as in the case of every pl. of the measure fuEuwlN of which the medial radical letter is Y: (M, F:) and pl. pl. A^anaAyiybu. (K, TA.) Ibn-Seenà says that no animal has both a nAb and a horn. (Msb.) ― -b2- naAbN An aged she-camel: (S, K:) not applied to a male camel: (S;) so called because of the length of her lush; (S;) by synedoche; the whole being called by the name of a part: (TA:) as also ↓ nayuwbN; (K;) accord. to some copies of the K, nay~awbN; but this is a mistake: (TA:) pl. of the former A^anoyaAbN and nuyuwbN (K) and niybN: (S, K:) or these are pls. of both the former of sing. (K. accord. to some copies; and TA.) Sb is of opinion that niybN is pl. of nAb, and says that the Arabs have made it of the measure fuEolN [as it is said to be in the S, for it is originally nuyobN like as they have the pl. of daArN, disliking the sound of nuyuwbN, because the Y is with dammeh, and preceded by dammeh, and followed by w. It is also said to be pl. of ↓ nayuwbN; as it is related, on the authority of Yoo, that certain of the Arabs say SiydN and biyDN, as pls. of SayuwdN and bayuwDN, agreeably with the dial. of those who say rusolN [instead of rusulN]; namely, the tribe of Temeem but their not saying nuyubN, like as they say SuyudN and buyuDN, is an argument in favour of the opinion of Sb. ― -b3- laA A^afoEalu *`lika maA Han~ati Aln~iybu [I will not do that as long as aged she-camels yearn towards their young ones i. e., I will never do it]. A proverb. (S.) ― -b4- The dim. of naAbN is nuyayobN, without p, because nAb, as applied to an aged she-camel, is like an epithet: (S:) or rather this formation of the dim. without nAb is a dev. from constant rule. (MF.) Sh says, that some of the Arabs make the dim. of nAb to be vuwayobN, because many an A such as that in nAb is changed from w: [or rather, this is generally the case:] but this, says Ibn-Es-Sarráj is an error on his part [who does (???) (S.) This apparently means, that Ibn-EsSarráj accuses Sh of an error; but such is not the case: for Sb himself says “ but this is an error on their part; ” i. e., on the part of the Arabs who say nwyb for nyyb (IB.) ― -b5- naAbu qawomK (tropical:) The lord, master, or chief, of a people: (S, K:) pl. A^anoyaAbN. (TA.) ― -b6- EaD~atohu A^anoyaAbu Ald~ahori, and nuyuwbuhu, [(tropical:) The dog-teeth of fortune bit him]. (A.) ― -b7- AnyAb are likewise met. assigned to evil, or mischief. (TA.)
nayuwbN * : see naAb.
nuy~abN * [as though pl. of naAy^ibN or naAy^ibapN] an epithet added to nuyuwbN as signifying “ canine teeth. ” to render the signification intensive, or energetic. (TA.)

A^anoyabu *
Having a large, or thick, canine tooth, (K,) that does not bite a thing without breaking it. (Th.)

1 naAta * , aor. yaniytu, inf. n. nayotN; as also naAta, aor. yanuwtu, inf. n. nawotN; (L, K;) He (a man) moved from side to side in walking (L, art nwt:) or he so moved by reason of weakness, or infirmity: (K:) or, by reason of drowsiness. (L, art. nwt, q. v.)

1 naAra Alv~awoba * , aor. yaniyruhu, (T, S, M, A, K,) inf. n. nayorN; (T, M, K;) and ↓ ny~rhu, (T, M, A, Mgh, K,) inf. n. tanoyiyrN; (T;) and ↓ AnArhu, (T. S, M, A, Mgh, K,) and hanaArahu, (S, M, TA,) like A^araAqa and haraAqa, (S,) aor. of the latter yuhaniyruhu (M, TA,) inf. n. A_ihonaArapN, (M,) or hinaArapN; (TA ??) He made, or put, to the piece of cloth a nyr; (T, S, M, K;) i. e., an Ealam [or ornamental border]; (T, S, * M, * A, Mgh, K, * TA;) syn. A^aEolamahu: (A:) and a woof; (S, * A, Mgh, TA; *) syn A^aloHamahu; (A;) contr. of A^asodaAhu and sad~aAhu (Mgh.) ― -b2- huwa yusad~iY AlA^umuwra wayuniyruhaA (A ???) yusodiY (TA) (tropical:) [He commences things, or affairs, and completes them].
2 nay~ara see 1.
4 AnArhu * and hanaArahu : see 1, throughout.
nayorN * : see niyrN.

niyrN * The Ealam [or ornamental border] of a piece of cloth: (T, S, M, A, K:) pl. A^anoyaArN. (M, K) It is related that 'Omar disliked it, (TA,) and that he forbade it. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) The side (Tur~ap) of a road: (T:) or the side (jaAnib) and wide or widening part (Sador), of a road. (so in some copies of the K, and in the TA: but in some copies of the former, “ or ” is put in the place of “ and: ”) or the conspicuous part of a road: (S:) or the conspicuous furrowed part of a road. (M, A, K.) ― -b3- The unwoven end (hudob) of a piece of cloth. (Ibn-Keysán, M, K) ― -b4- The woof of a piece of cloth. (T, S, A, Mgh, K.) When cloth is woven with a double woof, (EalaY niyrayoni,) it is more close in texture and more lasting. (S.) vawobN *uw niyrayoni signifies A piece of cloth strongly woven, with a double woof: (A:) or a piece of cloth woven with double thread: (T:) and [in like manner] ↓ vawobN munay~arN a piece of cloth woven with a double woof; (Lh, M, K;) i. e., with a double thread: (TA:) also called dayaAbuw*, (T, TA,) an arabicized word; (TA;) in Persian duwo Puwdo, or duwo buwdo, (as in different copies of the K,) or duwo baAfo. (T.) This mode of weaving is termed mutaA='amahN, which is the
making the woof of a double thread, and putting two threads together upon the Haf~ap [which here means the yarn-beam, on which the warp is rolled]. (T.) ― -b5- Hence, naAqapN daAtu niyrayoni (tropical:) A she-camel having an accession of fat upon former fat: (T:) or having, upon her, layers (SaHaAy^if) of fat; as also *aAtu A^anoyaArK: (A:) or advanced in years, yet having some remains of strength; (M, K;) and sometimes the epithet is applied in like manner to a woman: (M:) and naAqapN *aAtu A^anoyaArK a she-camel having thick flesh. (TS.) Also, rajulN *uw niyrayoni (tropical:) A man whose strength is double the strength of his companion: (S:) or strong and firm. (A.) And raA^aYN *uw niyrayoni (tropical:) Right opinion or counsel. (A.) And HarobN *aAtu niyrayoni (tropical:) Violent war. (T, A.) -A2- The canes (qaSab) and threads (xuyuwTap) [in a loom], when they are put together: (M, K:) [it is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p, as appears from what here follows:] ↓ niyrapN is a subst., signifying the threads and canes, (xuyuwTap and qaSabap, [or warp and, app., cane-roll, on which the warp is rolled when put into the loom, and from which it is gradually unrolled as the work proceeds,] when they are put together: when they are separate, the threads are called xuyuwTapN; and the cane, qaSabapN, or, if a staff, EaSFA: (AZ, Sh, T:) niyrapN is also explained as signifying one of the implements of the weaver, with which he weaves; namely, the transverse piece of wood [in the loom; the same as is described above]. (T.) In the following verse of an unknown poet,
↓ taqosimu A^usotiy~FA lahaA binayori
wataDoribu Aln~aAquwsa wasoTa Ald~ayori
[She divides warp that she has with cane-rolls, and beats the nákoos in the midst of the convent], the author may mean biniyrK, and may have altered the word by necessity; or ↓ nayorN may be a dial. form of niyru. (M.) One says of a man who neither harms nor profits, maA A^anota bisataApK walaA luHomapK walaA niyrapK (tropical:) [lit. Thou art not a warp nor a woof nor a cane-roll]. (T.) [See also a similar saying voce Haf~apN.] -A3- [The yoke of a bull; the piece of wood that is upon the neck of the bull, together with its apparatus: (M, K:) or the piece of wood that is placed transversely upon the necks of the two bulls (T, S) yoked together for ploughing: (T:) called niyru Alfad~aAni: (S:) pl. [of pauc.] A^anoyaArN and [of mult.] niyraAnN: (S, M, K:) of the dial. of Syria. (M.)
niyrapN * : see niyrN.

muniyrN * act. part. n. of 4: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] lasota fiY h*aA AlA^amori bimuniyrK walaA muloHimK (tropical:) [Thou art not in this affair a commencer nor a finisher: or a person who will do harm nor one who will profit]. (TA.)
munay~arN * : see niyrN. ― -b2- (tropical:) A skin that is thick (A, K, TA) and strong, (TA,) like a piece of cloth with a double woof. (A, TA.)
muhonaArN * , for munaArN, pass. part. n. of 4. (Ks, Lh, M.)

nayosaAnu * [vulg. niysaAn] The seventh of the Greek [or Syrian] months; (K;) [corresponding to April, O. S.] It is [said to be] a property of the water of its rain, that dough kneaded with it ferments without other treatment. (TA.)
1 naATa * , aor. yaniyTu, inf. n. nayoTN, It was, or became, distant, or remote, or far-extending; as also ↓ AntAT. (K.) [See the latter in art. nwT.]
8 A_inotayaTa see 1.

nayoTN * : see niyaATN, in art. nwT, in two places. ― -b2- Death: or a bier: or the term of existence: (K:) or the death which God connects (yanuwTuhu) [with one]: (IAar:) and if so, the Y is interchangeable with w, (IAth, TA,) the word being originally nayowiTN, then nay~iTN, and then nayoTN: (TA:) if a contraction, it is like hayonN and hay~inN, and layonN and lay~inN. (Az, TA.) You say, ramaAhu A@ll~`hu biAln~ayoTi, meaning [God smote him, or may God smite him,] with death: (S, in art. nwT, and TA:) or [may God smite him] with the death which He connects [with him]; as also ramaAhu A@ll~`hu binayoTihi. (IAar.) And A^ataAhu nayoTuhu His term of existence came to him. (TA.) And rumiYa fulaAnN fiY nayoTihi Such a one was cast into his bier; meaning, when he died. (TA.) See Tino'N.
niyaATN * : see art. nwT.
naAy^iTN * : see art. nwT.

div2.head: nyf &c.
div2.entryFree: See Supplement

niyluwfarN * , (Msb,) and nayoluwfarN, (Msb, and so in the CK,) or nayolawofarN, (so in copies of the K, and so accord. to the TA,) or, as some say, nayonuwfarN, or nayonuwofarN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) [The nymphæa, or lotus of Egypt and of Syria;] a certain well-known plant; (Msb;) a kind of sweet-smelling plant, which grows in stagnant waters, (K, TA,) called by the people of Egypt b$nyn, [i. e. ba$oniyn,] and by the vulgar nawofar; (TA;) [both of which last names are now given in Egypt to the nymphæa lotus, or white lotus, found in the neighbourhoods of Rosetta and Damietta; and the former, also, or perhaps both, to the nymphæa cærulea, or blue lotus, found in the same parts, and, until within a few years, in a lake on the north of Cairo, called Birket erRatlee, whence I have twice procure roots of this plant:] nylwfr [written in Persian niyloParo and niyluwParo and niyluwbaroko &c.] is a Persian word (A^aEojamiy~apN), and is said to be composed of niyl, [or indigo,] with which one dyes, and the name for a wing, [i. e., Paro;] as though “ winged with niyl [or indigo]; ” because the leaf is as though its two wings were dyed [with indigo]: (Msb:) the plant so called is cold in the third degree, moist in the second degree, emollient, good for cough and for pains of the side and lungs and chest; when its root, or lower part, (A^aSol,) is kneaded with water, and used as a liniment, several times, it removes the disease called Albahaq; and when kneaded with zifot, it removes the disease called daA='u Alv~aEolabi: (K, TA:) an excellent beverage is also prepared from it. (TA.) The imám Bedred-Deen Mudhaffar, son of the Kádee of Baalabekk, says, in his book entitled Suroor en-Nefs, that it is of many species; whereof [one or more] in Syria, used in perfume; and a species in Egypt, blue; and that its temperament is cold and moist in the second degree; that the smelling it is useful against hot diseases, and anxiety; and its juice in like manner; and that the beverage prepared from it is useful as a remedy for cough and roughness [of the throat] and pain of the side and chest, and is a laxative. The author of the Irshád and that of the Moojiz also mention, that the beverage prepared from it is an exception from other sweet beverages inasmuch as it does not become converted into yellow bile, which is wonderful; and its oil is more cold and moist than that of violets; and there is no flower more cold and moist than it. Er-Rázee, too, says that the smelling it is one of the causes of weakening the generative faculty, and that the beverage is one of the causes of stopping it; [for which purpose, or as an antiaphrodisiac, it is used in the present day by some of the women of Cairo;] notwithstanding which, it rejoices the heart, and is useful for palpitation of the heart. This art. is omitted by J and Sgh and the author of the L. (TA.)
nayonuwfarN * , or nayonawofarN: see art. nylwfr.
